site_title: China home sales continue to rise in latest sign of recovery
summary: China's home sales rose for a second month in March, with the value of new home sales by the 100 biggest developers increasing 29.2% to 660.9 billion yuan (S$127.8 billion). This signals a recovery after policymakers expanded support for the sector, following a 15% rise in February, the first increase in 20 months. Data also showed China's economic recovery gathered pace in March, with strong manufacturing, services, and construction activity gauges boosting the growth outlook for this year.

site_title: Netflix restructures film group as it scales back movie output
summary: Netflix is restructuring its film group to centralize decision-making and scale back its movie output. The company will combine units producing small- and mid-sized films, resulting in layoffs and the departure of two experienced executives, Lisa Nishimura and Ian Bricke. Film chief Scott Stuber aims to ensure high-quality titles by reducing output, after releasing over 50 projects last year. The move follows Netflix's introduction of a lower-priced streaming plan with advertising to boost revenue.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage at the Netflix booth is seen on the convention floor at Comic-Con International in San Diego, California, U.S., July 21, 2022. REUTERS/Bing Guan/File Photo
Aubrey Plaza in the second season of The White Lotus, which was filmed at San Domenico Palace, a Four Seasons resort hotel in Taormina, Sicily.

site_title: South-east Asian finance leaders in talks on containing global risks
summary: Finance leaders from the Association of South-east Asian Nations (Asean) gathered in Bali to discuss containing global risks amid recent global banking turmoil. The meeting focused on increasing local currency usage, connecting payment systems, and exploring cryptocurrencies and central bank digital currencies. Indonesia's deputy central bank governor Dody Budi Waluyo stated that the region aims to reduce dependency on US dollars and be more resilient to financial market turmoil. The meeting concluded with a proposal to increase local currency use for trade and investment, and to strengthen banking systems through stricter regulations.

images.alt_text: Not accounting for China, developing East Asia and the Pacific are anticipating a slower rate of growth in 2023, compared to 2022 and an earlier forecast.

site_title: Tech’s retrenchment hammers landlords with glut of empty offices
summary: US tech giants are retrenching, resulting in a glut of empty offices across major cities. Companies like Meta, Microsoft, and Amazon are dumping millions of square feet of office space, pushing vacancies to record highs. The tech downturn is spilling into the broader economy, with 174 million square feet of office space available for sublease across the US. This has significant implications for commercial real estate, with landlords struggling to refinance loans and investors facing a $53 billion financing gap through 2025. The situation is expected to worsen as $900 billion in commercial-property debt matures this year and next.

site_title: Global finance CEOs make first post-Covid visits to China
summary: Global finance CEOs, including Goldman Sachs CEO David Solomon, HSBC CEO Noel Quinn, and Standard Chartered boss Bill Winters, visited China for the first time since the Covid-19 pandemic, meeting with Chinese officials and regulators to cement relations with Beijing. The visits come as financial firms seek to boost their presence in China's second-largest economy. International financial institutions and investors are welcomed to expand in China, according to the China Securities Regulatory Commission's chairman, Yi Huiman.

site_title: DBS sets up special board committee to investigate online service disruption
summary: DBS has set up a special board committee to investigate the disruption to its digital banking services on March 29, following a two-hour outage that affected about 60% of customers. The committee, led by independent director Olivier Lim, will be supported by external experts and will conduct a full and detailed investigation. DBS chairman Peter Seah apologized for the incident, saying it was "sobering" for the bank and that ensuring uninterrupted digital services is its key priority. The Monetary Authority of Singapore has also taken steps, instructing DBS to submit its investigation findings.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
FILE PHOTO: A logo of DBS is pictured outside an office in Singapore January 5, 2016.  REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo  GLOBAL BUSINESS WEEK AHEAD
Given that fewer banking services are available at physical bank branches these days, and the falling number of branches, digital disruptions have a greater impact than ever.

site_title: EU to ease process of winding down medium-sized banks
summary: The European Union plans to simplify the process of winding down medium-sized banks by utilizing national deposit guarantee systems for funding. The European Commission's proposal, set to be released in April, aims to close funding gaps at struggling banks and avoid tapping uninsured depositors. This move comes after European Central Bank head Christine Lagarde called for governments to push ahead with a stalled EU deposit insurance scheme, citing the sector's resilience despite recent crises at Silicon Valley Bank and Credit Suisse.

site_title: UK house price fall quicker than expected with higher rates
summary: UK house prices fell 3.1% from last year, the sharpest annual pace since 2009, due to surging interest rates. The average home price dropped to £257,122, a 4.6% decline from its peak in August. The Bank of England's rate increases are slowing the market, with consumer confidence and household budgets under pressure from high inflation. Nationwide's chief economist, Robert Gardner, warns the market will struggle to regain momentum in the near term.

images.alt_text: Lenders authorised 43,500 home loans compared with 39,600 in January, the Bank of England (BOE) said.

site_title: Siemens investigating report employee worked for Russian hacking firm
summary: Siemens is investigating after a report claimed a former programmer from Russian IT company NTC Vulkan, linked to Russian security services, worked for the German engineering company in Munich. Siemens stated that it takes the allegations seriously and is looking into the matter, but cannot reveal the employee's identity due to data protection laws.

images.alt_text: The four bankers were found guilty on Thursday (Mar 30) of helping Sergey Roldugin (right), a concert cellist who has been dubbed “Putin’s wallet” by the Swiss government.

site_title: China’s green debt pioneer says transition market is bigger
summary: China's transition finance market is poised to boom, with potential growth faster than traditional green finance, according to Ma Jun, president of the Hong Kong Green Finance Association. Transition finance, which supports heavy-emitting industries to reduce emissions, is expected to surpass China's 25 trillion yuan green debt market. China's regulators are defining transition activities, and the country aims to peak emissions by 2030 and be carbon neutral by 2060. This move is seen as a catalyst for market growth, with local governments and financial institutions showing interest in transition finance.

site_title: Singapore, China agree to restore flights, people exchanges to pre-pandemic levels
summary: Singapore and China have agreed to work towards restoring flight connectivity and people-to-people exchanges between the two countries back to pre-pandemic levels. This agreement was made during a meeting between Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Chinese President Xi Jinping. The move aims to boost economic ties and revive travel between the two nations after the COVID-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsieng Loong said that economic cooperation between China and its Asian neighbours will be stronger if it is underpinned by a stable relationship.
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will meet officials during a visit to China.

site_title: Crypto exchange Bittrex to exit US due to regulatory challenges
summary: Crypto exchange Bittrex is shutting down its US operations due to regulatory challenges, citing an "unfeasible" environment. The company, founded in 2014, will allow customers to withdraw all funds until the end of April. This decision follows other digital-asset firms leaving the US market, including Nexo and Genesis Global Capital, amid enforcement actions by the US Securities and Exchange Commission. Bittrex's global business will continue to operate outside the US.

site_title: Chinese lithium producers set price floor as demand evaporates: sources
summary: Chinese top lithium producers agreed to set a floor price of 250,000 yuan (S$48,374.21) per tonne of lithium carbonate to slow a plunge in the price of the battery raw material, amid a significant slowdown in demand for electric vehicles in China. The move comes as spot prices have slumped by over 60% since their peak in late November. Offers as low as 150,000 yuan were also heard in the market, but the floor price is expected to help stabilize prices and strengthen market sentiment.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as inflation data boosts softer Fed policy hopes
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Friday after inflation data showed a slowdown in February, boosting hopes of a softer monetary policy approach from the Federal Reserve. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 42.93 points, or 0.13%, to 32,901.96, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained points. The improved inflation data suggests a potential shift towards more accommodative monetary policy, supporting market sentiment.

site_title: US government to provide US$1 billion for rural renewable energy
summary: The US government will provide up to $1 billion in grants to rural small businesses and farmers to invest in clean energy, starting Saturday. The funding, from the Inflation Reduction Act, aims to cut climate-harming emissions across the American economy. The grants can be used for renewable energy systems or energy-efficient improvements, according to the US Department of Agriculture's Rural Energy for America Program. This effort is part of the Biden administration's approach to expanding affordable clean energy to every zip code.

site_title: China to examine US chipmaker Micron’s products for cybersecurity risks
summary: China's Cyberspace Administration is conducting a cybersecurity review of US memory chip manufacturer Micron Technology Inc's products sold in the country. The move aims to protect the supply chain for critical information infrastructure, prevent hidden risks, and safeguard national security. The review follows a series of export controls imposed by the US on chipmaking technology to China and blacklisting of Chinese chip firms, including Micron rival Yangtze Memory Technologies. Micron's shares fell 3% after the announcement.

images.alt_text: SK Hynix parent SK Group plans to invest US$15 billion in the US chip sector, including to build an advanced chip packaging factory, and has said it is considering applying for funding.

site_title: UK economy avoids recession after growing in Q4
summary: The UK economy avoided recession after growing 0.1% in the October-to-December quarter, following a 0.1% contraction in the third quarter. This marks a smaller-than-expected contraction, contrary to previous Office for National Statistics data that showed no growth in the fourth quarter of 2022. The growth was driven by increased business at travel agents and state support for soaring energy bills.

images.alt_text: The CBI’s expected sales balance for April increased to +9 from -18 in March.

site_title: Rajah & Tann partner Danny Ong leaves to start law firm focused on crypto disputes
summary: Rajah & Tann partner Danny Ong is leaving to start his own law firm, Setia Law, focusing on crypto disputes. He will bring around 10 lawyers to the new firm, specializing in digital asset space disputes, fraud, and financial crimes. Ong, who spent 15 years at Rajah & Tann, represented clients such as B2C2 and Terraform Labs. As the digital asset space sees increasing legal action, Singapore's courts are becoming an important arena.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Do Kwon was previously based in Singapore but is no longer in the Republic.
FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies are seen in front of displayed FTX logo in this illustration taken November 10, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Vietnam needs 270 trillion dong to expand national fuel storage capacity by 2030
summary: Vietnam requires an investment of up to 270 trillion dong (S$15.3 billion) to expand its national fuel storage capacity to 75-80 days of net imports by 2030. The current capacity stands at 65 days. The majority of the investment is expected to come from businesses, according to a draft plan by the Ministry of Industry and Trade.

site_title: Diligence and thoroughness in investment decisions
summary: CFA Institute requires fund managers and investment professionals to exercise diligence, independence, and thoroughness in analyzing and recommending investments. Retail investors expect fund managers to utilize their expertise and knowledge in allocating funds, selecting securities, and managing performance. However, a case study by CFA Institute found that a portfolio manager failed to exercise diligence and thoroughness, underweighting risk factors such as security concentration and price volatility. The portfolio manager was reprimanded and fined, and the CFA Institute suspended his right to use the CFA designation. The case highlights the importance of adhering to the Diligence and Reasonable Basis Standard.

images.alt_text: With the different fees levied by different investment platforms, BT explains the different fees that investors will face.
MAS last month introduced a notice on business conduct requirements for CF advisers, setting out specific requirements to manage conflicts of interest and ensure proper governance and supervision.

site_title: FDIC exercises US$500 million in First Citizens stock to close SVB deal
summary: US regulators backstopped a deal for First Citizens to buy Silicon Valley Bank, triggering a potential $20 billion hit to the FDIC insurance fund. The FDIC exercised its equity appreciation right in First Citizens BancShares stock worth $500 million as part of the deal. First Citizens granted the FDIC equity appreciation rights, rather than paying cash upfront, and the deal does not require an immediate payment. The move aims to stabilize the financial system and prevent a broader bank run.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Maybank upgrades Mapletree Logistics Trust to ‘buy’ on latest acquisition news
summary: Maybank Securities upgraded Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) to 'buy' from 'hold' following its acquisition of eight logistics properties in Japan, Australia, and South Korea. Analysts believe the deal will be accretive to MLT's distribution per unit and keep aggregate leverage below 40%. The trust's target price was raised to S$1.80, reflecting increased DPU estimates. Despite a potential rise in leverage, analysts expect valuation gains and potential divestments to cap it.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
MLT is considering buying up to 10 properties in Asia Pacific, and divesting one in Hong Kong.

site_title: German unemployment up more than expected on sluggish economy
summary: German unemployment rose by 16,000 in March, exceeding expectations, to reach 5.6% due to a sluggish economy. Despite this, businesses show growing confidence that the energy crisis is over. The country is expected to enter a shallow recession, but recent data suggests the labor market has been resilient. Workers have pushed for higher wages to protect purchasing power amid inflation still above the European Central Bank's 2% goal.

site_title: Asean finance leaders to work closer to withstand global crises
summary: Asean finance leaders have agreed to strengthen cooperation to withstand future global crises, following recent global banking turmoil. The gathering in Bali, led by Indonesia, focused on areas like trade, investment, and bilateral tax agreements. Central bank governors emphasized the need to control inflation, direct monetary policy, and boost the use of local currencies for settlements to reduce volatility. The meeting also discussed regulating crypto assets and maintaining resilient banking systems, with Indonesia and the Philippines stating their systems are resilient and subject to stricter regulations.

images.alt_text: Frederick Chin, UOB's head of group wholesale banking and markets, delivering a keynote speech kicking off the 12th Wee Cho Yaw Business Forum on Mar 17, 2023.

site_title: Tencent, Sequoia join US$18.1 million fundraise of Horizon Quantum Computing
summary: Singapore-based Horizon Quantum Computing has raised US$18.1 million in a Series A funding round led by Tencent and Sequoia Capital India. Founded by Dr. Joe Fitzsimons in 2018, Horizon aims to develop tools for constructing complex quantum algorithms. The funding round also includes investors SGInnovate, Pappas Capital, and Expeditions Fund. Horizon is one of several quantum computing startups in Singapore, with a focus on achieving ultra-fast processing power with quantum computers.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Quantum computers and related technologies – such as quantum sensing and cryptography – could revolutionise everyday life.
Dr Tan Si-Hui spent over 18 years diving into the great unknowns of quantum science, before taking the leap into the startup world.

site_title: GM plans to phase out Apple CarPlay in EVs, with Google’s help
summary: General Motors plans to phase out Apple CarPlay and Android Auto in its future electric vehicles (EVs), starting with the 2024 Chevrolet Blazer, and instead develop built-in infotainment systems with Google. This shift aims to capture more data on consumer driving habits and charging patterns. GM's goal is to offer tightly integrated navigation and infotainment systems with features like assisted driving by 2035. Buyers of GM EVs will have access to Google Maps and Google Assistant at no extra cost for eight years.

site_title: ABB to launch US$1 billion share buyback on Apr 3
summary: ABB will launch a new $1 billion share buyback on April 3, aiming to repurchase up to 30 million shares. This is the latest in a series of buybacks by the Swiss engineering company, which has repurchased around 286 million shares for $8.6 billion since July 2020. The new scheme will see approximately 1.5% of ABB's issued shares bought back and cancelled, running until March 20, 2024.

images.alt_text: ABB's comments are viewed as indicators of the broader global economy’s health, as its products are used in many factories as well as transport and infrastructure projects.

site_title: Vietnam central bank to keep flexible monetary policy in 2023, fight inflation
summary: Vietnam's central bank has decided to maintain a flexible monetary policy in 2023 to control inflation amid external challenges. The bank aims to cut policy rates further to support economic growth, which slowed to 3.32% in the first quarter, down from 5.92% in the fourth quarter of 2022. The central bank also targets credit growth of 14-15% this year and aims to keep inflation under control, protecting the banking system and supporting struggling businesses, including manufacturers.

images.alt_text: The country’s current fuel storage capacity stands at 65 days of net imports.

site_title: China rolls over US$2 billion loan to Pakistan: finance minister
summary: China has rolled over a $2 billion loan to Pakistan, providing relief during the country's acute balance of payment crisis. The loan matured last week, and Pakistan's Finance Minister Ishaq Dar confirmed the rollover on March 31. This move comes as talks with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) over a $1.1 billion bailout tranche have hit a stalemate, with Pakistan's reserves dipping to just four weeks' worth of imports. The new maturity date and terms of the arrangement have not been disclosed.

images.alt_text: “Now we are being told that the commitments from friendly countries be fulfilled and God willing we will,” Pakistan's Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif told parliament in a live telecast speech.

site_title: Hot stock: Sembmarine rises 4.3% after bagging 6 billion euros in contracts
summary: Sembcorp Marine's shares rose 4.3% to a high of S$0.12 after securing contracts worth S$8.67 billion for offshore renewables projects. The company won three contracts to supply high-voltage transmission systems for mega offshore wind-farm projects in the Netherlands. Analysts are optimistic, with CGS-CIMB raising its target price to S$0.19 and DBS recommending a "buy". The company's current order book stands at S$23.1 billion, with analysts expecting more project wins from TenneT, a Dutch transmission system operator.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Sembmarine says it will continue to co-operate and work with Brazilian authorities on this matter.
Shares of Sembcorp Marine have been halted as at 1.24pm on Thursday.

site_title: Wimbledon to accept Russian and Belarusian players as ‘neutral’ athletes
summary: Wimbledon to allow Russian and Belarusian players to compete as "neutral" athletes this year, subject to certain conditions, including prohibiting expressions of support for Russia's invasion of Ukraine and funding from the Russian and/or Belarusian states. The decision comes after last year's ban due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The All England Lawn Tennis Club (AELTC) has developed the conditions in consultation with the UK government and international tennis bodies, aligning with the government's guidance. This change affects top-ranked players such as Daniil Medvedev and Aryna Sabalenka.

site_title: China’s Huawei says ‘out of crisis’ mode as revenue edges up
summary: Huawei Technologies reported a 0.9% increase in annual revenue, reaching 642.3 billion yuan, and a net profit of 35.6 billion yuan, down two-thirds from 2021. The company has emerged from "crisis mode" after US export controls since 2019 affected its smartphone business. Huawei spent billions on research to replace components affected by sanctions, and its R&D spending rose 13.2% to 161.5 billion yuan. The company aims to become more self-reliant in its semiconductor industry and is investing in 5G and green technologies.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Huawei logo is pictured at the IFA consumer tech fair in Berlin, Germany, September 6, 2019. REUTERS/Hannibal Hanschke/File Photo

Critics of Huawei and ZTE say that their close links to Beijing’s security services mean that embedding them in mobile networks could give Chinese spies and even saboteurs access to essential infrastructure.

site_title: Chinese property developer Sunac posts US$2 billion core loss in 2022
summary: Chinese property developer Sunac China reported a net core loss of 13.86 billion yuan (approximately $2.7 billion USD) in 2022, narrowing from a 25.30 billion yuan loss in 2021. The firm slowed project construction and incurred higher interest expenses amid a debt crisis in the sector. This follows a series of supportive government policies aimed at stabilizing the sector. Sunac's core net loss reflects the challenges faced by many Chinese developers, including defaults and lower-than-expected house sales.

site_title: The market for Picassos may be about to turn
summary: Pablo Picasso's market may be shifting, with declining popularity and waning influence on contemporary artists. Christie's valuation of a Picasso sold for $140m in 2015 was one of the highest estimates ever, but prices have grown twice as fast as the broader 20th-century art market since 1999. Fewer artists cite Picasso as an inspiration, with Marcel Duchamp and Philip Guston being more commonly cited, indicating a "monumental shift" in the art world.

images.alt_text: Auction house Sotheby’s had predicted the Picasso painting, a surrealistic depiction of his muse Marie-Thérèse Walter, to sell in excess of US$60 million.

A work by Andre Fougeron, France's foremost social realist painter, on loan to London's National Gallery from Centre Pompidou in Paris. To cut down on its carbon footprint, the French museum has been focusing on sourcing homegrown art rather than taking loans of pieces from the US or Asia. This cuts down on the round-trip flights by the artworks and curators.

A handout photo taken and released on October 9, 2022 by Extinction Rebellion shows climate activists with their hands glued to the perspex covering of Picasso's anti-war painting "Massacre in Korea" at the National Gallery of Victoria in Melbourne. - The protesters were "removed from the painting" more than an hour after their action was believed to have started, police said. The painting emerged unscathed. The new art exchange will be a test of whether art belongs in investor portfolios alongside stocks and bonds.

site_title: ICA probe into checkpoint disruptions reveals technical glitch, system overload
summary: A technical glitch and system overload may have caused a four-hour delay at Singapore's land checkpoints and Changi Airport on March 31. The Immigration and Checkpoints Authority (ICA) attributed the issue to a pre-scheduled system upgrade, which resulted in automated immigration clearance becoming unavailable. The disruptions affected all departure terminals at Changi Airport, arrival terminals at Terminals 2 and 4, and certain automated lanes for bus and motorcycle passengers. The issue was resolved by 3:44 pm, with only some automated arrival lanes still facing issues.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Long queues had formed at Changi Airport, with throngs of people waiting to enter departure gates.

site_title: Lower household electricity bills in Q2 as tariff falls 5.4%
summary: Singapore's electricity tariff will decline by an average of 5.4% in the second quarter, resulting in lower household bills. The tariff, which will fall to 27.43 cents per kWh on average, will decrease the average monthly electricity bill for families in HDB four-room flats by 5.3% to S$84.63. The decline is due to lower energy costs compared to the previous quarter, with energy costs estimated to decrease by 1.86 cents per kWh.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Singapore inflation higher in January after GST hike; headline at 6.6%, core at 5.5%
Singapore’s power grid vendor SP Group on Friday (Dec 30) attributed the price revisions to lower energy costs compared with the last quarter.
Only one per cent of consumers – including both households and businesses –  buy electricity wholesale, according to the Energy Market Authority.
Electricity tariff to rise by an average of 9.9% in Q2 as global energy prices surge

site_title: ComfortDelGro acquires remaining 10% stake in Ming Chuan Transportation
summary: ComfortDelGro has acquired the remaining 10% stake in Ming Chuan Transportation (MCPL) for S$1 million, making MCPL a wholly-owned subsidiary. The acquisition has no material impact on ComfortDelGro's net tangible assets and earnings per share for the financial year ending Dec 31, 2023. MCPL is a professional wheelchair transport company with over 70 specialized vehicles islandwide. The transaction was completed in cash using internal resources, following ComfortDelGro's 90% stake acquisition in January 2022 for S$8.5 million.

images.alt_text: ComfortDelGro logo at the ComfortDelGro headquarters located along Braddell Road on March 6, 2023.
Mark Christopher Greaves (left) and Choi Shing Kwok (right) are set to replace outgoing chairman Lim Jit Poh, who will retire on Apr 28.

The board of directors at ComfortDelGro has recommended a final dividend of S$0.0176 per share, and a special dividend of S$0.0246 per ordinary share to commemorate the 20th anniversary of the company’s listing on the Singapore Exchange

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore has introduced a Compass framework that awards bonus points to Employment Pass applicants for skills in "shortage" occupations, including financial advisory, carbon trading, and artificial intelligence. The World Bank has revised its 2023 growth forecast for developing East Asia and Pacific economies to 5.1%, up from 4.6%. OCBC group CEO Helen Wong's salary reached S$11.2 million in 2022, while Golden Mile Tower will be relaunched for collective sale on Apr 7 at a reserve price of S$600 million. Private residential rentals surged in Singapore, increasing rental yields.

site_title: Asia: Markets build on gains as bank, rate concerns ease
summary: Asian markets rose on Friday, March 31, as concerns over the banking sector eased and traders became more optimistic about central banks nearing the end of their interest rate hiking cycle. Expectations for borrowing costs to rise above 4% have lowered, and equities, which had been under pressure, pushed up. Top Fed officials warned that fighting inflation remains crucial, but comments failed to hurt sentiment. Hong Kong led the gains, with Shanghai, Tokyo, and other Asian markets also rising, while some markets, such as Manila and Jakarta, saw selling.

site_title: Italy privacy regulator opens probe on OpenAI over ChatGPT
summary: Italy's data protection authority has launched a probe on OpenAI over its ChatGPT tool, citing concerns over the collection and storage of user data without a clear legal basis. The regulator has given OpenAI 20 days to respond, threatening fines of up to 20 million euros or 4% of its annual revenue. This comes amid controversy over the tool's use of AI to gather personal data from users under 13 years old. The probe follows a complaint from a US tech ethics group urging the US Federal Trade Commission to halt the commercial deployment of AI technology.

site_title: Nominations open for 2023 Enterprise 50 Awards
summary: Nominations are open for the 2023 Enterprise 50 (E50) Awards in Singapore, recognizing the 50 most enterprising privately owned local companies. The awards, organized by The Business Times and KPMG, close on June 30. This year's theme, "Scaling New Heights, Conquering New Frontiers," highlights companies that have shown innovation and courage in an ever-changing environment. The awards will be announced in November, with a Sustainability Special Recognition Award introduced for companies that have made strides towards their environmental, social, and governance (ESG) goals.

images.alt_text: Joe Green Marketing's founder and managing director Boediman Widjaja (right) and marketing director Charlina Lim at the Enterprise 50 Awards in 2021.
Oilfield Services & Supplies general manager Michael Lim, managing director Kay Ong and business development manager Kenneth Loh at the Enterprise 50 Awards 2021 ceremony.
Over 760 business leaders and VIPs attended the gala dinner held at Resorts World Convention Centre on Nov 23 to honour Singapore’s 50 most enterprising privately-held companies.

From left: Frank Chen, founder and managing director of BR Metals; Victor Yeap, managing director of Yeap Medical Supplies; and Li Xiaowen, deputy managing director of Apro Asian Protection at the Enterprise 50 Awards on Wednesday.

site_title: BT Market Focus: Banking crisis fears ebb for a mixed week (Ep 38)
summary: The Singapore markets experienced a mixed week, with concerns over a banking crisis appearing to have receded. According to SGX's wrap, the week saw a rebound in the market, despite initial fears of banking failures. Claressa Monteiro, host of the podcast, discussed the situation with insights from The Business Times' newsdesk and other notable corporate news for investors. The banking fears appear to have eased, allowing the markets to recover and close the week on a positive note.

images.alt_text: Have markets turned a corner this week?
How much did the bank fails affect markets this week? Claressa Monteiro finds out.

site_title: Japan’s Toyota hands St Petersburg plant over to Russian state
summary: Toyota has handed over its St Petersburg plant to the Russian state entity NAMI, effective March 31, 2023. The Japanese carmaker had stopped vehicle production in Russia due to supply disruptions. The transfer includes the full ownership of plant buildings and land, with neither party disclosing a fee. NAMI, which has already acquired assets from Renault and Nissan, plans to resume production at the facility as soon as possible. The plant, which produced around 80,000 vehicles in 2021, was in operation since 2005 and produced Camry and RAV4 models.

images.alt_text: Japan’s biggest automaker said in a statement, however, that shortages of parts continue to be a problem.

site_title: China’s recovery strengthens as spending, construction surge
summary: China's economic recovery strengthened in March with a surge in non-manufacturing activity and construction, driven by increased spending and infrastructure projects. The manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI) eased to 51.9, still above the 50 mark, while a non-manufacturing gauge of activity reached 58.2, the highest level since 2011. Economists expect a rebound in consumer spending and stronger government spending to drive growth to 5.3% this year. Stocks in China and Hong Kong rose, and the currency edged higher, amid expectations of continued economic momentum.

images.alt_text: Not accounting for China, developing East Asia and the Pacific are anticipating a slower rate of growth in 2023, compared to 2022 and an earlier forecast.

NEW YORK, NEW YORK - JANUARY 26: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) during morning trading on January 26, 2023 in New York City. The stock market opened slightly higher this morning as investors awaited the release of fourth-quarter Gross Domestic Product (GDP) report. The report showed that the economy grew at an annual rate of 2.9 percent in the fourth-quarter with the rate decreasing slightly from a 3.2 percent growth rate in the third quarter.   Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Michael M. Santiago / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: India’s new trade policy aims to promote rupee trade
summary: India's new foreign trade policy aims to promote rupee trade with countries facing US dollar shortages to "disaster-proof" them and boost exports. The policy includes industry-specific targets to reach $2 trillion in exports by 2030 and a new amnesty scheme for one-time settlement of export defaults. The scheme will run until September 2023 and automate trade approvals, cutting charges for medium-sized and small businesses to secure government-backed benefits. This move is expected to help India effectively boost its exports amid slowing global trade.

site_title: Indonesia’s electric vehicle ambitions hinge on green mining drive
summary: Indonesia aims to become an electric vehicle powerhouse with its vast nickel reserves, but environmental concerns and lack of oversight hinder efforts. The country has signed $15 billion deals for battery and EV production, but experts warn of environmental mistakes from the past, including unregulated tin mining that destroyed forests and coral reefs. Indonesia needs to strengthen environmental safeguards, improve monitoring of standards, and ensure responsible waste management to attract EV manufacturers like Tesla. The country's efforts to curb climate change are threatened by regulatory uncertainty, lack of transparency, and unsustainable mining practices, making it a heightened risk for foreign investors.

images.alt_text: Indonesia, which has the largest nickel reserves in the world, will step up scrutiny of mining and order companies to manage nurseries to reforest depleted mines, said  President Joko Widodo.
The Ford badge and E-Transit logo are seen on a vehicle at Ford’s Dunton Technical Centre in Dunton, Britain, January 13, 2023.  REUTERS/Peter Nicholls

site_title: Amid housing rental boom, where are Singapore’s sweet spots for yield?
summary: Singapore's private residential rental yields surged 0.6% year-on-year to 4.1% in the fourth quarter of 2022, driven by a dramatic jump in private residential rents. The highest rental yields were recorded in District 9 (OUE Twin Peaks), District 18 (Melville Park), and District 1 (Marina One Residences). The increase in yields is attributed to the island-wide gross rental yield for 99-year leasehold non-landed private homes, which has risen 0.8% since the pandemic trough in Q2 2020.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
Reality check for landlords as rents may have peaked; viewings decline

site_title: China regulator asks East Money to take measures after breakdown
summary: China's securities regulator has asked East Money Information Co to take measures after its trading system broke down on March 21. The China Securities Regulatory Commission's Tibet bureau instructed East Money to investigate the matter, handle investor appeals, and strengthen its information system to ensure safe and smooth operation. The regulator set a three-month deadline for rectification and submission of a report. East Money has agreed to take corrective measures in line with requirements and submit the report on time.

site_title: Singapore, Malaysia travellers can now use QR code to pay in both countries
summary: Singapore and Malaysia have introduced a QR code payment system, allowing residents from both countries to make payments using DuitNow and Nets QR codes, respectively. This move aims to boost cross-border commerce and provide merchants with a more efficient means of making and receiving payments. The service is available to customers of local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC in Singapore, and CIMB Bank and Hong Leong Bank in Malaysia. The payment linkage is expected to expand to cross-border fund transfers and remittances by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim

Monetary Authority of Singapore managing director Ravi Menon made a live demonstration of a cross-border payment transfer with his counterpart, Shaktikanta Das, governor of the Reserve Bank of India. The PayNow-UPI launch event was officiated by Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and India Prime Minister Narendra Modi.

site_title: Eurozone inflation posts record drop, but core prices accelerate
summary: The eurozone experienced a record drop in inflation in March, primarily due to a significant decrease in energy prices compared to the same period last year. Consumer prices rose 6.9% in March, a 0.6% decrease from February, marking the largest deceleration since data collection began in 1991. However, core prices accelerated, suggesting the European Central Bank may need to consider further interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text:
(FILES) In this file photo taken on October 21, 2020 people wearing face masks walk in front of the euro sign at the former ECB headquarters in the city center of Frankfurt am Main, western Germany. - The European Central Bank is expected Thursday to unleash more stimulus to help shore up a eurozone economy devastated by the coronavirus pandemic, analysts said, in a move eagerly awaited by financial markets.

The Frankfurt institution already has a 1.35-trillion-euro ($1.6-trillion) emergency bond-buying programme in place, but ECB chief Christine Lagarde all but promised in October that extra support was on the way. (Photo by Yann Schreiber / AFP)

site_title: South Korea industrial output slumps, retail sales rebound
summary: South Korea's industrial output fell 3.2% in February, mainly due to a 17.1% drop in semiconductor and 4.8% decline in automobile production. However, retail sales rebounded 5.3% after a 1.1% drop in January, showing an uneven recovery for the trade-reliant economy. This data has raised concerns about South Korea's economy potentially falling into recession in the current quarter, given its reliance on exports for growth.

site_title: For T rex and kin, it was a stiff upper lip, not a toothy grin
summary: Scientists have challenged popular depictions of Tyrannosaurus Rex and other meat-eating dinosaurs by suggesting they likely had lip-like structures, not exposed teeth. Researchers analyzed skull and jaw anatomy, tooth wear patterns, and the relationship between tooth size and skull size, finding evidence of labial scales that covered the teeth. These "dino lips" would have protected the oral cavity from the environment and helped saliva secretions keep teeth hydrated. The study provides a more realistic interpretation of theropod facial features and aims to reframe dinosaurs as living animals, rather than movie monsters.

images.alt_text: The 3.9-metre skeleton has been mounted on a red carpet and under crystal chandeliers in a Zurich concert hall, where it will be on public display before going under the hammer on April 18.
Kohei Kimura, the owner of Funny Creatures Forest, said he takes extra care to ensure he is not contributing to animal mistreatment or the keeping of protected species.

site_title: US unveils stricter EV tax credit rules to take effect April 18
summary: The US Treasury Department has unveiled stricter electric vehicle tax rules, effective April 18, aiming to reduce or cut tax credits on some zero-emission models. The new requirements are part of President Joe Biden's effort to increase US EV sales to 50% by 2030, reducing dependence on China for EV battery supply chains. The rules trigger new requirements for critical minerals and battery components, and buyers have two extra weeks before the new rules take effect.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Visitors check a Tesla Model 3 car at a showroom of the U.S. electric vehicle (EV) maker in Beijing, China, Feb. 4, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo

site_title: Seven years, four areas, one chance
summary: Businesses face mounting expectations to tackle global challenges, but have they stepped up or back? To survive and thrive, they need inspiring, visionary leadership that drives transformative change. The private sector is seen as the most trusted institution to solve global challenges, with 80% of people looking to businesses to address climate, nature, and inequality crises. Businesses must transform their approach, focusing on catalyzing an urgent transition away from exploitative and extractive practices to socially just and regenerative ones. Four key areas can unlock this transformation: inspiring visionary leadership, rethinking value chains, transforming consumption, and creating an enabling context.

images.alt_text: In KPMG's CEO Outlook, 73 per cent of CEOs polled see corporate purpose having the greatest impact over the next three years, meaningfully driving financial performance for their respective corporations.
By doing good, corporations get imbued with a valuable “superpower” – one that positions them for success by setting them apart in the highly competitive business world.
As the apex body, the board sets the tone for corporate morality by encouraging and reinforcing moral reasoning and behaviour. PHOTO:

site_title: Hyundai offers free steering locks to combat TikTok thefts
summary: Hyundai Motor will distribute free steering-wheel locks to US customers and upgrade anti-theft software on 4 million vehicles after a surge in TikTok-inspired car thefts. The thefts target Hyundais and Kias lacking an engine immobilizer, which prevents the car from being started without a key. The company has already rolled out a free software upgrade to 1 million customers and will reimburse those who purchased steering wheel locks.

images.alt_text: “Water accumulation on the tow hitch harness module printed circuit board (PCB) may cause an electrical short, which can result in a fire,” the NHTSA said.
Hyundai Motor suspended operations at its Russian factory last March.

site_title: Thailand’s economic activity improves in February, central bank says
summary: Thailand's economy showed signs of improvement in February, with rising tourist arrivals and exports contributing to the rebound. The Bank of Thailand reported a current account surplus of $1.3 billion and a 4.1% decline in exports from a year earlier. However, private consumption and tourism activities also increased. The central bank trimmed its economic growth projections to 3.6% and 3.8% for this year and next year, respectively, amid concerns over global banking problems and higher costs.

site_title: Virgin Orbit to lay off about 85% of staff
summary: Virgin Orbit Holdings is laying off about 85% of its staff, approximately 675 employees, due to the company's inability to secure new investment. The move follows a failed rocket launch and a recent collapse of investment talks with Matthew Brown. The company expects to take related charges of around $15 million. Shares fell 38% in after-hours trade. Virgin Orbit had received $50 million in financing from Richard Branson's Virgin Group in November, but was unable to secure further funding.

images.alt_text: Its becoming sufficiently profitable to consider offering shares to the public is a sharp reversal that underlines how lucrative the post-pandemic travel boom has been for airlines.
Virgin Orbit, which normally operates from the Mojave Desert, put plans for a pre-Christmas UK launch on hold amid last-minute snags.

site_title: Jailed Malaysian ex-PM Najib loses final bid to review graft conviction
summary: Malaysia's top court has dismissed a bid by former Prime Minister Najib Razak to review his corruption conviction related to the 1MDB scandal. Najib was previously jailed for 12 years after the Federal Court upheld a guilty verdict handed down by a lower court. He can now only apply for a royal pardon, which could potentially see him released without serving the full term. This marks the end of Najib's judicial efforts to challenge the guilty verdict.

images.alt_text: Rohana Rozhan, the former chief executive officer of Astro Malaysia Holdings, has returned US$10 million related to the troubled state fund 1MDB.
Federal prosecutors ask US District Judge Margo Brodie in Brooklyn, New York, to order Ng to forfeit the sum as ill-gotten gains from the conspiracy to loot the Malaysian sovereign wealth fund.

High Court judge Mohamed Zaini Mazlan said state prosecutors failed to provide sufficient evidence to prove their case that Najib Razak (above) tampered with an official audit report on scandal-wracked state fund 1MDB.

site_title: Three freehold bungalows in Chancery area sold for S$61.1 million
summary: Three adjoining freehold bungalows in Chancery area sold for S$61.1 million, with proceeds going to registered charities. The buyer, a subsidiary of property developer Sustained Land, exceeded the indicative price of S$60 million set by the estate's executors. The bungalows, totaling 32,148 sq ft, were put up for sale on February 13 and drew over 10 offers from developers and high-net-worth families. The sale is seen as a rare opportunity to own a sizeable freehold bungalow in a prestigious location.

images.alt_text: The indicative price for all three properties is S$60 million.

site_title: India seeks US$2 trillion exports by 2030 in supply chain push
summary: India has set a target of reaching $2 trillion in annual exports by 2030, more than doubling its previous goal of $900 billion, as the country pushes to become a top choice for companies shifting supply chains away from China. The target, announced by the Trade Ministry, comes as India chairs the Group of 20 forum this year and Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government seeks to boost economic growth and create jobs. Despite challenges in meeting the goal, especially for goods exports, officials believe the target requires strong global economic growth and a shift in India's market share.

images.alt_text: “Tightening of financial conditions by central banks to tame inflation has raised concerns regarding the exacerbation of corporate debt vulnerabilities, with corporates being already highly leveraged,” the ministry said.

site_title: Multiple red flags are not yet slowing the generative AI train
summary: Generative AI systems, such as ChatGPT and Dall-E 2, have sparked debate over their potential risks and benefits. Critics argue that the technology poses alarming risks, including spreading misinformation and automating jobs, and call for better governance. Despite warnings from experts, including Bill Gates, the rapid development and widespread use of AI continue. A recent open letter signed by over 1,100 experts, including prominent AI researchers, has urged a six-month moratorium on leading-edge models until more robust governance is in place.

images.alt_text: Others turned to alternatives simply because OpenAI has trouble keeping up with the rising demand.

ChatGPT set off massive investment because “ninety-plus per cent of venture capitalists are actually very risk averse. Until you see a real application, people don’t really dive in,” Samir Kaul, a founding partner at Khosla Ventures said.

Silicon Valley-based Cerebras released seven models all trained on its AI supercomputer called Andromeda, including smaller 111 million parameter language models to a larger 13 billion parameter model.
Elon Musk, whose carmaker Tesla is using AI for an autopilot system, has been vocal about his concerns about AI.

site_title: Bank of Japan raises maximum amount of bond purchases for next quarter
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) raised the maximum amount of its planned Japanese government bond purchases for the next quarter, doubling down on its ultra-loose policy to defend against rising yields. The BOJ will buy between $3.57 billion-$6.57 billion of 5-year to 10-year bonds, exceeding its previous range of 775 billion yen. This move aims to contain rising yields, which have eased due to financial shocks, and maintain the central bank's ultra-low interest rates. The decision comes as the BOJ faces pressure to pare down its massive stimulus under new governor Kazuo Ueda.

images.alt_text: Markets are rife with speculation the BOJ could tweak or end YCC to mitigate such side effects when incoming governor Kazuo Ueda takes the helm from Haruhiko Kuroda.

site_title: Whatever the problem, it’s probably solved by walking
summary: Walking has long been recognized as a powerful tool for both physical and mental well-being. From Hippocrates to modern-day writers, numerous individuals have credited walking with soothing the mind, fueling creativity, and bringing emotional and spiritual clarity. A 500-mile walk across Spain's Camino de Santiago pilgrimage route, as experienced by author Andrew McCarthy, revealed the transformative power of walking, allowing individuals to connect with themselves and the world around them. As spring arrives, experts encourage readers to lace up and take advantage of walking's many benefits.

images.alt_text: Can moving the body heal the mind?
Cardio and strength training help the body in different ways.

site_title: SIA Engineering signs S$120.8 million services agreement with Scoot
summary: SIA Engineering Company signed a S$120.8 million, two-year agreement with Scoot, providing maintenance, repair, and overhaul, and fleet management support services, starting April 1. The deal has an option to extend for an additional year, yielding a potential labor revenue of S$120.8 million over three years. This follows a fresh services agreement with Singapore Airlines, also starting April 1, with a similar term and potential revenue. The deals are not expected to impact SIAEC's earnings per share for the 2024 financial year.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

site_title: China’s JD.com to spin off industrial, property units in US$1 billion Hong Kong floats
summary: JD.com, a Chinese e-commerce firm, plans to spin off its industrial and property units into standalone entities, listing them on the Hong Kong stock exchange in deals worth $1 billion each. The company will continue to hold a stake of over 50% in the units, JD Industrials and JD Property. This move comes after a regulatory crackdown in the Chinese technology sector, with rival Alibaba Group also planning to split into six units. The IPOs are expected to happen soon, pending financial market conditions.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo of JD.com is seen on a helmet of a delivery man in Beijing, China June 16, 2014. Picture taken June 16, 2014. REUTERS/Jason Lee/File Photo
In China, the company has been battling a slowing economy and the impact of strict Covid curbs.
China’s largest online retailer after Alibaba Group Holding will set up a 10 billion yuan fund intended to help employees.

site_title: Making new friends and rekindling old bonds
summary: CLA Global TS, a public accounting firm, is participating in the BT Corporate Golf League 2023, aiming to connect with clients, associates, and new people while giving back to the community. The team, comprising Henry Tan, CEO, and others, currently ranks fifth in the standings. Tan, who started playing golf over 30 years ago, believes the event supports Singapore's efforts to be Covid-resilient and boosts the economy through larger-scale in-person events.

images.alt_text: Triple winner Stanley Gan with Lim Han Ming, EMTM deputy managing editor, and Ken Sim (right), marketing manager, adidas Golf SEA.
Singapore Pools CEO Lam Chee Weng in action at Tanah Merah Conutry Club during the BT Corporate Golf League 2023.
Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong (seventh from right) at the official opening of Keppel Club at Sime Road on March 18, 2023. On his right is Transport Minister S Iswaran.
Jayaprakash Jagateesan (second from right), the group CEO of AlDigi Group, a member of ONERHT.

site_title: Alibaba stock overbought as spin-off prompts US$47 billion rally
summary: Alibaba's stock has surged 20% this week, adding $47 billion in market value, despite its 14-day relative-strength index exceeding 70, a signal of an overbought rally. The spin-off plan, which splits the company into six units, has sparked investor interest. This marks a reversal of the stock's performance in January, when it was oversold, and follows rival JD.com's Hong Kong listing announcement. The rally raises concerns about the stock's sustainability.

images.alt_text: Some analysts say Alibaba is currently undervalued as a standalone conglomerate and a breakup would allow investors to value each business division independently.

site_title: Asia infrastructure bank won't get distracted by geopolitics, says president
summary: The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) will maintain its apolitical stance and focus on its mandate, despite geopolitical tensions and pressures on multilateralism. AIIB President Jin Liqun stated that the bank needs to work together to safeguard multilateralism and support its clients, while also protecting its credit worthiness and Triple A rating. As of November, the AIIB had financed $37 billion in projects, and its president remains optimistic about its expansion plans across sub-Saharan Africa, Latin America, and Eastern Europe.

images.alt_text: This will be the first time AIIB enters the Asian venture capital market since its founding.

site_title: Citigroup sees global profits shrinking 5% in aftermath of banking turmoil
summary: Citigroup predicts a 5% global profit contraction this year due to banking turmoil and a potential recession. The bank's strategists attribute the risk to monetary tightening and stress in the banking sector. As investors seek quality, Citi upgraded the technology sector to "overweight" and downgraded the global financial sector to "neutral." US equities are expected to outperform European peers during a profit contraction, with a double upgrade to "overweight" and a downgrade of the European stock market to "neutral." Global equities are expected to remain range-bound to the year-end.

images.alt_text: The gathering of finance leaders from the Asean comes amid a backdrop of recent global banking turmoil.
With the financial turmoil of recent weeks subsiding, traders are refocusing on the battle against inflation, though expectations for how high borrowing costs will go have lowered.

site_title: MLT’s private placement closes at S$1.649 per unit; analysts positive on new acquisitions
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) has closed its private placement at S$1.649 per unit, raising S$200 million in gross proceeds. The issue price represents a 1.5% discount to its adjusted volume-weighted average price. Analysts, including CGS-CIMB and Maybank Securities, are positive on the trust's new acquisitions, citing expected accretive effects on distribution per unit and target prices raised to S$1.88 and S$1.80 respectively. The trust plans to use the funds to repay debt, partially fund acquisitions in Japan, Australia, and South Korea, and pay professional fees.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
MLT is considering buying up to 10 properties in Asia Pacific, and divesting one in Hong Kong.

site_title: Issue 43: Consumers bite on banks’ green loans; people matter in Asean Taxonomy
summary: Singapore banks are offering green consumer loans due to strong demand from environmentally conscious spenders, who are perceived as more creditworthy. The Asean Taxonomy's inclusion of a social impact assessment criterion may pave the way for country-level sustainable finance frameworks. While the green consumer loan segment is growing, it remains a small portion of overall loan portfolios. The Asean Taxonomy's update also includes a test for social factors, promoting human rights, preventing forced labor, and protecting children's rights. This new dimension may lay the groundwork for country-level taxonomies to address social issues.

images.alt_text: Kenneth Lim

The criteria for qualifying coal projects were laid out in the second version of Asean taxonomy for sustainable finance, released by the Asean Taxonomy Board after the market closed on Monday (Mar 27).
(Photo: RENDY ARYANTO/VVS.sg)
OCBC's head of global consumer financial services, Sunny Quek, says the take-up rate for the bank's Eco-Care loans is better than expected.
An employee inspecting a solar panel for defects at the module production line at REC Solar ASA manufacturing facility in Tuas on 5 September 2014.

ICVCM states that forestry projects under Redd+ – a UN framework created to guide activities in the forest sector that reduces emissions from deforestation and forest degradation – must also conform to the Cancun safeguards.

site_title: US consumer spending slows in February; inflation cooling
summary: US consumer spending rose 0.2% in February, after a 2.0% gain in January, as modest income gains offset the boost from the largest cost of living adjustment since 1981. Inflation showed signs of cooling, but remained elevated, potentially leading to another interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve this year. The economy continues to expand, but financial market stress from regional bank collapses and tightened lending standards may increase the risk of a recession later this year.

images.alt_text:
(FILES) In this file photo taken on October 21, 2020 people wearing face masks walk in front of the euro sign at the former ECB headquarters in the city center of Frankfurt am Main, western Germany. - The European Central Bank is expected Thursday to unleash more stimulus to help shore up a eurozone economy devastated by the coronavirus pandemic, analysts said, in a move eagerly awaited by financial markets.

The Frankfurt institution already has a 1.35-trillion-euro ($1.6-trillion) emergency bond-buying programme in place, but ECB chief Christine Lagarde all but promised in October that extra support was on the way. (Photo by Yann Schreiber / AFP)

site_title: Nissan, Renault confident of finalising alliance deal soon
summary: Nissan and Renault, a Japanese and French automaker alliance, are confident of finalizing their alliance deal soon. The companies are working towards signing definitive agreements, following months of talks. Renault will reduce its stake in Nissan from 43% to 15%, putting both companies on equal footing. Nissan will also acquire a 15% stake in Renault's electric vehicle unit Ampere. The agreement, which includes Mitsubishi Motors, was initially agreed upon in January 2023 and is expected to be completed shortly.

site_title: TikTok under fire reveals US$13 billion drop in founder’s fortune
summary: TikTok's CEO, Shou Chew, testified before Congress, revealing a smaller ByteDance ownership stake than previously known. This may have reduced Zhang Yiming's estimated net worth to $42.3 billion, down from earlier reports. Zhang, 39, is the co-founder of ByteDance, TikTok's Chinese parent, and owns about 20% of the company. The US testimony sheds new light on Zhang's fortune, which is now based on ByteDance's US$220 billion value.

images.alt_text: Politicians and cybersecurity experts have repeatedly raised concerns that TikTok’s parent company has too much insight into its 150 million monthly US users.
Lawmakers take turns battering Chew with inquiries for more than four gruelling hours, questioning TikTok’s ownership by Beijing-based ByteDance.
FILE PHOTO: A person holds a smartphone as Tik Tok logo is displayed behind in this picture illustration taken November 7, 2019. Picture taken November 7, 2019. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/File Photo

“TikTok is kind of rocky right now and the goal of a content creator is to grow yourself across platforms to have a solid community, you don’t just want to focus on one app,” said Cassidy Jacobson, whose TikTok account have 1.5 million followers.
Shou Chew fruitlessly tried to broaden the conversation to be about all social media companies — not just TikTok.

site_title: James Bond’s latest mission: to save King Charles III’s coronation
summary: James Bond's latest mission is to save King Charles III's coronation on May 6. Author Charlie Higson has been commissioned to write a new book, "On His Majesty's Secret Service", where Bond must thwart plans to disrupt the ceremony. The book, set 60 years after Ian Fleming's "On Her Majesty's Secret Service", will be published on May 4 and will feature the usual Bond elements, with royalties supporting the National Literacy Trust.

site_title: Australian housing may have found a floor, defying crash predictions
summary: Australian housing prices have defied predictions of a crash, rising 0.8% in March from February, according to CoreLogic data. This marks the first monthly gain since prices peaked in April last year. The rebound has been most pronounced in Sydney, where prices are up 1.4% month-on-month. Economists are surprised by the turnaround, but some attribute it to low housing stock, surging immigration, and rising rents. The Reserve Bank of Australia may pause its tightening campaign next week, raising hopes for a soft landing in the economy.

images.alt_text: A housing shortfall risks further fuelling rental inflation at a time when the economy is seeing a strong rebound in population growth from immigration.

site_title: Chinese companies rush for US listings ahead of new rules from Beijing
summary: Chinese companies rushed to list on the US market in March, raising a combined $82.3 million, as new Beijing rules take effect on April 1. The rules impose an approval system with a focus on national and data security, prompting firms like Chanson International and Hongli Group to seek listings before the new rules complicate the process. Despite the surge, the IPOs received tepid responses from investors, with some listings closing 40% below the issue price.

images.alt_text: The new rules for offshore listings will not lead to a rush for Chinese firms seeking initial public offerings in New York.

site_title: US: Stocks rally in final session of buoyant Q1
summary: US stocks closed the first quarter on a positive note, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 1.3%, the S&P 500 gaining 1.4%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumping 1.7%. The decline in headline inflation, which slowed to 5% in February, suggests moderating inflation pressures. The market's ability to rally despite recent banking industry turmoil is seen as "very bullish" by analysts. The quarterly gains, although modest, indicate a strong start to the year for US stocks.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 42.93 points, or 0.13 per cent, at the open to 32,901.96.

site_title: China stages combat patrols, crosses strait median line, says Taiwan
summary: China staged combat patrols and crossed the Taiwan Strait's median line, prompting Taiwan's defense ministry to condemn the "irrational" deployment. Nine Chinese aircraft crossed the median line, while Taiwan responded with its own aircraft and ships. The move comes amid heightened tensions, with Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen set to meet US House Speaker Kevin McCarthy in April. China claims Taiwan as its own territory and has increased military activities near Taiwan since last August's US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi visit.

images.alt_text: Tsai left Taipei on Wednesday (Mar 29) bound for New York on a plane that was guarded by F-16 fighters as it headed over the Pacific.

site_title: CPTPP membership will supercharge UK-Singapore partnership
summary: The UK has concluded negotiations to join the 11-member Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), marking a significant milestone in its trade and investment partnership with Singapore. The UK's accession will boost trade and investment between the two countries, with Singapore's combined GDP expected to increase by £11 trillion. The UK's membership will also give businesses greater access to the UK's market of 67 million consumers, creating jobs and opportunities across Singapore. The agreement is seen as a key step in the UK's commitment to free and fair trade and its investment in the Indo-Pacific region.

images.alt_text: Minister-in-charge of Trade Relations S Iswaran and UK Secretary of State for Business and Trade Kemi Badenoch at a virtual meeting where they announced the launch of negotiations on a new UK-Singapore Bilateral Investment Treaty.
Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsieng Loong said that economic cooperation between China and its Asian neighbours will be stronger if it is underpinned by a stable relationship.
Bill Winters, group CEO at Standard Chartered Bank  speaking during the UK-Asean Business Forum in London.
British High Commissioner to Singapore Kara Owen

site_title: Booty and a beast
summary: BMW has unveiled the M3 Touring, its first wagon version, offering a fast and versatile ride. The M3 Touring boasts a 2,993cc twin-turbocharged engine producing 510 horsepower. It features extensive customisation options, including engine, gearbox, suspension, steering, and brake settings. The vehicle's spacious boot can accommodate 500 litres of cargo, expandable to 1,510 litres with rear seats folded. The M3 Touring xDrive is the first wagon version of the M3, catering to drivers seeking a high-performance, adaptable vehicle.

images.alt_text: The GR86 feels like something created to engage the driver, with an analogue experience that rewards dedication and feel.
The MG ZS EV is based on a combustion car, so it still has the proportions of one.

site_title: PBOC calls out US banks for crypto risks, seeks more regulation
summary: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) has called for stronger regulation of digital finance, citing recent banking failures linked to US lenders involved in cryptocurrency transactions. Deputy Governor Xuan Changneng urged authorities to "verify and confirm" new technologies, rather than simply accepting them, to ensure financial stability. The comments come as Chinese officials have long had a hardline approach to the crypto industry, with the PBOC declaring initial coin offerings illegal in 2017. The PBOC is seeking more regulation to prevent risks and fraud associated with cryptocurrency.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: First Citizens BancShares and SVB (Silicon Valley Bank) logos are seen in this illustration taken March 19, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
The failures of SVB, and days later, Signature Bank, set off a broader loss of investor confidence in the banking sector that pummelled stocks and stoked fears of a full-blown financial crisis.

“We must ensure that our bank regulatory policies and supervision are appropriate for the risks and challenges that banks face today,” Nellie Liang (far right), the Treasury undersecretary for domestic finance, said in her testimony to the committee.

site_title: Performing arts in a high-tech, post-pandemic world
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has forced the performing arts industry to adapt and explore new ways of artistic expression, with technology playing a key role. Artists have turned to hybrid and digital workarounds, such as virtual reality and interactive experiences, to overcome challenges posed by closed borders and venues. The National Arts Council has continued to support this shift, offering grants that include digital elements and encouraging the use of technology to increase audience outreach. As the industry returns to theatres, there is a focus on interactivity and physicality, with innovative venues and collaborations fostering a sense of shared humanity.

images.alt_text: Sarah Choo Jing evokes the era of amusement parks in her haunting and melancholy video art.
At Walk Walk Don't Run, visitors are welcome into art spaces and design studios (such as Grey Projects,  featured here), to sit down and chat at length with the creatives.
Dance work Abyss choreographed by Hyerim Jang is one of the highlights of SIFA 2023.

site_title: AI experts disown Musk-backed campaign citing their research
summary: Four AI experts, including those from Google and DeepMind, have disowned a letter co-signed by Elon Musk, calling for a six-month pause in research on AI systems more powerful than Microsoft's GPT-4. The letter, citing 12 research papers, warned of profound risks to humanity, but critics argue it prioritizes apocalyptic scenarios over immediate concerns like biases in AI. Experts, including those who were cited in the letter, have criticized the FLI organization behind the letter for ignoring active harms and promoting a narrative that benefits its supporters.

site_title: Tokyo inflation slows further ahead of BOJ leadership shift
summary: Tokyo's inflation slowed further in March, with consumer prices excluding fresh food rising 3.2% from last year, down from February's 3.3%. This steady easing of price gains may support the Bank of Japan's view that inflation will slow below 2% in the next fiscal year. Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's stimulus measures, including a 20% discount on household electricity rates, are believed to have contributed to the moderation. The central bank will reassess its economic outlook at its April policy meeting.

images.alt_text: By pushing structural wage increases, PM Kishida said on Wednesday Japan would strive to narrow wage differentials between domestic firms and rivals overseas
The working age population is expected to rapidly decline from 2027, according to the study by independent think-tank Recruit Works Institute.

site_title: Gold prices dip as dollar firms ahead of US inflation data
summary: Gold prices dropped 0.1% to $1,978.39 per ounce, ahead of US inflation data that may influence the Federal Reserve's monetary policy. The dollar index rose 0.1%, making gold less affordable for buyers holding other currencies. Expectations of a potential rate-hike pause by the Fed, following the collapse of US regional banks, contributed to the decline. Markets see a 52.2% chance of the Fed standing pat on interest rates in May.

images.alt_text: The opportunity cost of holding non-yielding gold rises when interest rates are increased to bring down inflation.

site_title: Twitter makes some of its source code public
summary: Twitter made some of its source code public, uploading it to GitHub in two repositories. The move, led by billionaire owner Elon Musk, aims to increase transparency and trust among users. The code includes the recommendations algorithm, which controls the tweets users see on their timeline. Users can suggest modifications to the algorithm, which will be updated every 24-48 hours. The code does not include ad recommendations or sensitive user data, and Musk emphasized the need for third-party analysis to identify potential issues.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: A keyboard is placed in front of a displayed Twitter logo in this illustration taken February 21, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Stocks to watch: Mapletree Logistics Trust, Sembmarine
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust's private placement closed at S$1.649 per unit, partially funding the acquisition of eight Asia-Pacific assets worth over S$900 million. Sembcorp Marine secured a framework cooperation agreement for three offshore renewable projects worth S$8.7 billion.

images.alt_text: The Mapletree Business City located on Pasir Panjang Road on 26 July 2019.

site_title: Technology will drive the family office of the future
summary: Family offices are adopting technology to manage complex processes and improve efficiency. A digital platform with a single integrated data source is crucial for managing assets, investments, and transactions. This platform should handle complex hierarchies and information flows, provide auditable data, and ensure transparency and checks and balances. To mitigate cybersecurity risks, family offices must educate staff and family members about risks and implement routine system assessments with end-to-end encryption. Investing in a technology platform can optimize operations, reduce costs, and enable succession planning and governance, ultimately creating a more efficient and effective family office.

images.alt_text: Illustration for the article “Navigating the independent wealth management landscape”.

site_title: IMF chief urges members to plug funding gap for poor country fund
summary: IMF chief Kristalina Georgieva urged member countries to meet the US$16.0 billion target for the Poverty Reduction and Growth Trust (PRGT) fund, citing a 75% pledge rate and less than half the US$3.1 billion needed in subsidy resources. The fund, critical for helping poor countries weather the Covid-19 pandemic, faces a growing financing gap. Georgieva warned that a failure to secure resources would jeopardize the IMF's ability to provide support to low-income countries. The IMF estimates low-income countries' financing needs will reach about US$440 billion through 2026.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: International Monetary Fund (IMF) Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva attends a news conference following a meeting at the Federal Chancellery in Berlin, Germany November 29, 2022. REUTERS/Michele Tantussi/File Photo

site_title: Ascent Bridge CEO liaising to end bankruptcy application against him
summary: Ascent Bridge CEO Sun Quan has settled the outstanding amount due to the applicant of the bankruptcy application, which was filed against him on March 2. The company announced this in a bourse filing on March 31, and Sun is now liaising with the claimant lawyer to withdraw or discontinue the application. This development comes after the company previously disclosed the bankruptcy application, which arose from Sun's guaranteed repayment of a loan to one of his wholly-owned companies. Shares of Ascent Bridge closed flat at S$0.55 on the same day.

images.alt_text: pen, office, diary
Sharanya Pillai

site_title: Block says Cash App has 44 million verified monthly users after Hindenburg report
summary: Block, the payments firm behind Cash App, revealed 44 million of its 51 million monthly active customers were verified through its identity program as of December 31, accounting for 97% of Cash App inflows. The disclosure comes after a Hindenburg Research report alleged that 40-75% of accounts were fake, involved in fraud, or tied to a single individual, prompting Block to deny the allegations and consider legal action. Wall Street analysts largely dismissed the report's claims, and Block's shares rose 2% in response.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Cash App is seen at the main hall during the Bitcoin Conference 2022 in Miami Beach, Florida, U.S. April 6, 2022. REUTERS/Marco Bello/File Photo

site_title: World Bank raises forecast for developing East Asia and Pacific on China growth expectations
summary: The World Bank has raised its 2023 growth forecast for developing East Asia and Pacific economies to 5.1%, driven mainly by a higher forecast for China, now expected to grow at 5.1% compared to 3% in 2022. Excluding China, the region's growth is predicted to be at 4.9%, down from 5.8% in 2022. The forecast highlights the region's reliance on private consumption and goods exports, but also notes that global growth, commodity prices, and fiscal tightening could hold back growth in the region.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A participant stands near a logo of World Bank at the International Monetary Fund - World Bank Annual Meeting 2018 in Nusa Dua, Bali, Indonesia, October 12, 2018. REUTERS/Johannes P. Christo/File Photo
Elysia Tan

site_title: UK claims post-Brexit win by sealing trans-Pacific trade pact membership
summary: The UK has joined the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), a major Asia-Pacific trade pact, following nearly two years of talks. This marks the UK's first post-Brexit trade deal and its first membership in the bloc, which includes Singapore and 10 other countries. The UK's membership will bring in over 500 million people and account for 15% of global GDP. Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's office announced the news on Friday, March 31, 2023.

images.alt_text: Britain's Prime Minister Rishi Sunak speaks during a joint press conference with France's President at the end of the French-British summit, at the Elysee Palace, in Paris, on March 10, 2023 - British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak and French President Emmanuel Macron agreed a new pact to stop illegal cross-Channel migration after a summit in Paris on March 10, 2023 aimed at overcoming years of Brexit tensions. Both leaders hailed a new start in relations between the two neighbours, after intense talks in Paris which were also marked by expressions of unity in their support for Ukraine in fighting the Russian invasion. (Photo by Kin Cheung / POOL / AFP)

site_title: Mercedes amps up renewable energy switch with Iberdrola wind deal
summary: Mercedes-Benz has signed a power purchase agreement with Iberdrola to secure 140 megawatts of wind energy from a Baltic Sea wind park, aiming to cover 70% of its vehicle production energy demand from renewable sources by 2030. The deal is part of Mercedes' strategy to reduce production costs and carbon emissions, with the company now having solar, onshore, and offshore wind power purchase agreements for half of its electricity demand in Germany by the middle of the decade.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo of the Mercedes-Benz is seen outside a Mercedes-Benz car dealer in Brussels, Belgium March 13, 2023. REUTERS/Yves Herman/File Photo

site_title: World Court rules US wrong to freeze Iranian assets
