summary: The International Court of Justice ruled that the US illegally froze assets of Iranian companies and ordered the US to pay compensation, but rejected jurisdiction over $1.75 billion in frozen assets from Iran's central bank, which the US claimed was not protected by the 1955 friendship treaty. The ruling comes amid heightened tensions between the US and Iran, following recent strikes and stalled nuclear deal revivals. The US must pay compensation, but the amount will be determined later.

images.alt_text: Iran central bank was targeted by a distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attack on Thursday night.

site_title: Singapore-based crypto mogul who riled China before pushes the envelope again
summary: Singapore-based crypto mogul Justin Sun is pushing Huobi Global, a cryptocurrency exchange, to attract Chinese customers despite the country's ban on crypto trading. Sun believes China will reverse its ban after studying the industry's development in Hong Kong, but for now, he's focusing on other markets. The company has relaxed its geo-location controls, allowing users to register under a Dominican nationality, and has introduced a new funding route through Chinese banks. However, this approach has raised concerns among some Huobi workers, who fear it could attract the attention of local authorities.

images.alt_text: Justin Sun Photographer: Ore Huiying/Bloomberg

site_title: Musk’s AI letter is a ‘hot mess’ of hype, say critics
summary: Elon Musk and over 1,000 experts signed an open letter calling for a six-month pause in the development of powerful AI systems, citing risks to society and humanity. However, critics argue the letter misrepresents an academic paper and is a "hot mess" of AI hype. Critics, including experts Timnit Gebru and Emily Bender, claim the risks of AI are about concentration of power, oppression, and damage to information ecosystems, not just about AI being "too powerful".

images.alt_text: Elon Musk Photographer: Patrick T. Fallon/Bloomberg

site_title: Japan regional banks can weather foreign bond losses: regulatory official
summary: Japanese regional banks have strong capital buffers, making them resilient to foreign bond losses, according to a senior regulatory official. Despite unrealised losses of over 1.4 trillion yen (S$14 billion) at the end of last year, banks have enough capital to absorb potential losses. The official, Toshinori Yashiki, notes that Japanese banks are different from the failed Silicon Valley Bank, citing a deposit base from households and improved asset quality. No immediate need to review the regulatory framework is seen, but monitoring will increase in case of monetary policy changes.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Women walk under a sign of Japan's Financial Services Agency in Tokyo, Japan June 29, 2017. REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo

site_title: Governments’ criticism of Russia return to sport is deplorable: IOC
summary: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has defended its plan to allow Russian and Belarusian athletes to return to international sport, citing human rights concerns and citing examples of other countries' participation in international competitions despite ongoing conflicts. IOC President Thomas Bach criticized European governments' criticism, calling it "deplorable" and cutting into the autonomy of sport. Bach stated that governments should not interfere with how sport is run, and that their criticism has strengthened the unity of the Olympic movement.

images.alt_text: International Olympic Committee (IOC) president Thomas Bach (C) speaks during an IOC executive board meeting where the issue of Russian athletes will be discussed, in Lausanne, on March 28, 2023. - Poland, Ukraine and the Baltic states reiterated on March 27, 2023 their call to maintain the ban on Russian and Belarusian athletes at the Olympics, saying "not a single reason" existed to lift the restrictions. (Photo by Fabrice COFFRINI / AFP)

site_title: OCBC group chief Helen Wong’s salary reaches S$11.2 million in 2022, behind other local banks
summary: OCBC group chief executive officer Helen Wong's salary reached S$11.2 million in 2022, behind other local banks. Her salary for FY2021 was S$7.6 million after she was appointed CEO on April 15, 2021. The bank reported a net profit of S$1.3 billion for the fourth quarter ended December 2022, up 34% from the previous year. Despite this, its earnings missed the S$1.6 billion average estimate.

images.alt_text: Helen Wong, group CEO of OCBC
Yong Hui Ting

site_title: Japan 10-year bond yield hits near 3-week high as financial system worries ease
summary: Japan's 10-year government bond yield rose 1 basis point to 0.325%, its highest level since March 13, amid easing global financial worries. The 20-year and 30-year yields also increased, while the 2-year and 5-year yields rose 0.5 basis points. Investors sold save-haven debt as financial system concerns eased, with the yield catching up to overseas peers. Market participants await details on the Bank of Japan's bond purchase plans, which may lead to reduced yields across tenors amid a global bond rally.

images.alt_text:
A man looks at an electric quotation board flashing the Nikkei key index of the Tokyo Stock Exchange in Tokyo on April 12, 2017.
Tokyo stocks fell April 12 morning as the yen shot to five-month highs against the dollar over fears about growing tensions on the Korean peninsula and in the Middle East. / AFP PHOTO / Kazuhiro NOGI

site_title: US weekly jobless claims rise moderately; Q4 GDP trimmed
summary: US weekly jobless claims rose moderately to 198,000, slightly above forecast, but remain low. The economy grew at a solid clip in Q4, with a 2.6% annualized rate, but much of the increase came from inventory accumulation. Tightening lending standards could dampen labor demand, particularly in the information sector. Continuing claims rose moderately, and the unemployment rate remains at 3.6%. Despite these factors, labor market resilience is helping to keep recession at bay, with 1.9 job openings for every unemployed person in January.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage for a job fair is seen on 5th Avenue after the release of the jobs report in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., September 3, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Tesla pursues building a new US plant with China’s dominant battery maker
summary: Tesla is reportedly planning to build a battery plant in the US, in a deal with China's dominant electric-vehicle battery manufacturer Contemporary Amperex Technology (CATL). The plant, which would be wholly owned by Tesla, is expected to supply its EV assembly plant in Texas. The deal is seen as a move to lower costs and increase production volumes, amid increased competition. Tesla's senior global director of public policy, Rohan Patel, discussed the plans with the White House, seeking clarity on the Inflation Reduction Act rules.

images.alt_text: A Tesla supercharging station is seen in the early morning sun, in Kettleman City, California, U.S., January 25, 2023.  REUTERS/Mike Blake

site_title: Premier League clubs accused of avoiding £470 million in tax
summary: Premier League clubs are accused of avoiding £470 million in tax since 2015 through the construction of artificial contracts, according to Tax Policy Associates. The scheme involves football agents being paid for dual-representation, avoiding employment taxes and VAT. HMRC is investigating the matter, having recovered £573 million in unpaid taxes since 2015. The Premier League and HMRC are in talks about agent fees, with clubs aware of the latest tax rules.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Friday’s open; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% at the open on Friday, March 31, driven by global indices rallying overnight. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 3.33 points to 3,260.51. Sembcorp Marine, Mapletree Logistics Trust, and Genting Singapore were among the top traded counters. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC traded mixed, with OCBC up 0.6% and DBS down 0.1%. The rally came after global markets rebounded from concerns about the banking sector.

images.alt_text: The SGX logo at SGX Centre 1 located along Shenton Way on March 3, 2023.

site_title: Housing’s scarce supply derails buyers at key time for US deals
summary: The US housing market is struggling to find its footing as the spring home-sales season kicks off. Despite a slight dip in borrowing costs, transactions are hindered by a shortage of listings and an affordability crisis. New listings have tumbled 22% from a year earlier, and most existing mortgages have rates below 4%. Sellers are under pressure to lower prices, and homebuilders are cutting prices to attract buyers. The Federal Reserve's interest-rate hikes aim to tame inflation, but the market is grappling with regional-bank failures and their impact on interest rates and consumer confidence.

images.alt_text: Labour market resilience in the US is helping to keep recession at bay.
Supply in Britain’s £56 billion build-to-rent market has more than tripled in the last five years, according to a Knight Frank report published in December.

site_title: World Bank’s long-awaited reform plan would boost lending by US$5 billion a year
summary: The World Bank has submitted a long-awaited reform plan to boost annual lending to middle-income countries by about $5 billion annually to combat climate change and other global crises. The plan, which includes changes since a draft reviewed in January, aims to protect the bank's top-tier credit rating. The World Bank estimates that governments and the private sector in developing countries need to spend $2.4 trillion annually through 2030 to address climate change, conflict, and pandemics. The plan is expected to be discussed with the Development Committee steering body on April 12.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A participant stands near a logo of World Bank at the International Monetary Fund - World Bank Annual Meeting 2018 in Nusa Dua, Bali, Indonesia, October 12, 2018. REUTERS/Johannes P. Christo/File Photo

site_title: IMF urges BOJ to allow longer yields to move more flexibly
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged the Bank of Japan (BOJ) to consider allowing the longer end of the bond yield curve to move more flexibly, even while maintaining ultra-loose monetary policy. IMF Japan mission chief Ranil Salgado stated that policy should remain accommodative for now, but the BOJ should consider greater flexibility at longer-term yields to ease strain on financial institutions. This move aims to mitigate the side effects of the BOJ's current yield curve control (YCC) policy, which has been criticized for distorting bond pricing and making the market dysfunctional.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians walk past the Bank of Japan headquarters in Tokyo, Japan. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

site_title: Trump hit with criminal charges in New York, a first for a US ex-president
summary: Former US President Donald Trump has been indicted by a Manhattan grand jury on charges related to hush money paid to adult film actress Stormy Daniels, becoming the first US ex-president to face criminal charges. The investigation, led by Democratic Manhattan District Attorney Alvin Bragg, is one of several ongoing legal challenges facing Trump ahead of his potential 2024 presidential bid. Trump's lawyer has confirmed the indictment, but the specific charges have not been released. The indictment may reshape the presidential race, with some Republicans calling for Trump to drop out if charged.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Former U.S. President Donald Trump speaks during his first campaign rally after announcing his candidacy for president in the 2024 election at an event in Waco, Texas, U.S., March 25, 2023.  REUTERS/Leah Millis/File Photo

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as bank fears fade, focus on inflation data
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, March 30, as fears of a banking crisis eased, allowing investors to focus on key consumer spending data and the Federal Reserve's policy path. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 89.83 points, or 0.27%, to 32,807.43, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher.

site_title: US: Stocks close higher as fears of banking crisis ease
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday, March 30, as markets calmed following recent banking sector turmoil. The Dow Jones Industrial Average increased 0.4%, while the S&P 500 rose 0.6% and the Nasdaq Composite jumped 0.7%. This followed the seizure of Silicon Valley Bank, which raised hopes that emergency steps by regulators and private lenders have staved off contagion. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen emphasized the need for post-crisis reforms, and President Joe Biden called for tougher rules on midsized banks to prevent future failures.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., March 15, 2023. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly

site_title: UK delays decision on when to raise state pension age to 68
summary: The UK government has delayed a decision on raising the state pension age to 68, citing slowing rises in life expectancy. An independent review recommended a delay between 2041 and 2043, but Work and Pensions Secretary Mel Stride said a new review will be undertaken after the next general election, potentially deferring the decision until after 2027. The delay comes amid concerns about the impact on middle-age voters, with estimates suggesting each year of delay could cost the Treasury £9 billion.

images.alt_text: UK pension funds reduced their allocation to stocks from about 73 per cent in 1997 to 27 per cent in 2021, cutting exposure to British equities from 53 per cent to just 6 per cent over the same time period.

site_title: US court sanctions Google in privacy case, company’s second legal setback in days
summary: A US court sanctioned Google for a second time in recent days, after a judge said the Alphabet unit took too long to comply with a ruling last year in a data-privacy class action. The order stems from a class action claiming Google unlawfully tracked users while in private mode. Google has been barred from relying on certain employee witnesses and must pay a $79,000 fine. The company must also pay fees to two expert witnesses working for the plaintiffs and has been ordered to comply with a deadline stemming from a court order last year.

images.alt_text: There is intense rivalry between the two US tech giants in the multi-billion-dollar cloud computing business, where Google trails market leader Amazon and Microsoft.

An Indian appeals tribunal said CCI’s findings of Google’s anti-competitive conduct were correct, and the company was also liable to pay the fine, but it quashed four of the 10 antitrust remedies that had been imposed on Google to change its business model.

site_title: Applicants for Employment Pass to get bonus points for 27 ‘shortage’ roles
summary: Singapore's Manpower Ministry has released a list of 27 "shortage occupations" for which Employment Pass applicants can receive bonus points under the upcoming Compass framework. These roles include financial advisory, carbon trading, and artificial intelligence, and are in high demand due to local skills gaps. Applicants must score at least 40 points to qualify, with bonus points awarded for meeting specific criteria such as salary, qualifications, and diversity in the employer's talent pool. The list will be reviewed every three years, and firms can receive up to 10 bonus points for participating in economic initiatives or meeting local workforce development criteria.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Local shareholding is not a prerequisite for the M-SEP scheme, which targets companies that will contribute to Singapore's growth and competitiveness, said Dr Tan.
CEO of Goldbell Group Arthur Chua with Dr Tan See Leng, Minister for Manpower and Second Minister for Trade and Industry at Goldbell's Benoi Road premise.

site_title: Manila, Beijing to resume oil and gas talks in May, says Philippine minister
summary: The Philippines and China will resume discussions on jointly exploring oil and gas resources in the South China Sea in May, according to Foreign Affairs Secretary Enrique Manalo. The move aims to ease tensions between the two nations, which have disputed sovereign rights to natural resources in the strategic waterway. The talks will focus on terms of reference, with the Philippine position guided by constitutional requirements, and no document has been finalized yet.

images.alt_text: The Secretary of Foreign Affairs of the Philippines Enrique Manalo speaks during address a joint press conference with the German Foreign Minister on February 20, 2023 at the Foreign Office in Berlin. (Photo by Odd ANDERSEN / AFP)

site_title: Japan unveils fresh childcare plan, but funding remains unclear
summary: Japan's government has unveiled a fresh childcare plan to boost birth rates, which face a relentless decline. The plan includes expanding child allowances without income limits and aims to address the issue over the next three years. However, funding for the measures remains unclear, with a ruling party lawmaker demanding an additional eight trillion yen. The government has already earmarked 6.1 trillion yen for childcare measures, putting a strain on its already-tattered finances.

images.alt_text: The working age population is expected to rapidly decline from 2027, according to the study by independent think-tank Recruit Works Institute.
Last March, core inflation in Tokyo climbed 0.8 per cent, the fastest clip in more than two years at the time.
By pushing structural wage increases, PM Kishida said on Wednesday Japan would strive to narrow wage differentials between domestic firms and rivals overseas

site_title: Taiwan, China must do everything possible to avoid war: former president Ma
summary: Former Taiwanese President Ma Ying-jeou urged Taiwan and China to avoid war, stating it's the responsibility of leaders to ensure peace. During a meeting with China's Taiwan Affairs Office head Song Tao, Ma emphasized maintaining peaceful relations is the "general mainstream view of Taiwanese society." Ma's visit comes amid heightened tension, with China ramping up military and diplomatic pressure to force Taiwan to accept Chinese sovereignty. Ma's office said he is open to meetings with Chinese leaders, but no details were provided.

images.alt_text: Tsai left Taipei on Wednesday (Mar 29) bound for New York on a plane that was guarded by F-16 fighters as it headed over the Pacific.
Ma Ying-jeou is the first former or current Taiwanese president to visit China since the defeated Republic of China government fled to Taiwan in 1949 at the end of a civil war with the Communists.

site_title: Singapore stocks end week on a high, STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended the week with a 0.1% gain, closing at 3,258.90, after regional markets showed similar upward trends. The US is expected to suffer a recession this year, with some economists predicting the Federal Reserve will pivot away from rate hikes to cuts. Top gainers included Jardine Cycle and Carriage and Venture Corporation, while DBS, UOB, and OCBC were among the top losers.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Hong Kong’s benchmark Hang Seng Index climbed 1.1 per cent.
Mainland China computer, communications equipment and media indexes have surged between 29 per cent and 35 per cent this year, outstripping a rise of just 3.5 per cent in the benchmark CSI 300 Index.

site_title: Gearing up for the global nature economy
summary: Singapore, known as a "garden city," faces a mix of risk and opportunity due to its position as a global finance hub. The world is shifting towards new frameworks to value nature and incentivize its repair, with over half of global GDP dependent on natural systems and services. The recent adoption of a global biodiversity framework by Singapore and other governments, along with the participation of global companies, marks a new era in which countries and companies must play a role in halting and reversing nature loss. To remain a vibrant financial hub, Singapore must prepare for this transition by understanding its impacts and dependencies on nature and taking advantage of new markets and mechanisms.

images.alt_text: The giant forest trees in the Bukit Timah and Central Catchment nature reserves.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rally as banking worries fade
summary: European stocks rose 1.1% to a three-week high, driven by a Wall Street rally and easing banking concerns. The Stoxx 600 index hit its strongest level since March 10, with real estate stocks jumping 3.7% and banking stocks rising 1.5% after the sale of Silicon Valley Bank's assets and takeover of Credit Suisse. Retail giant H&M led gains with a 16.3% surge, while data showed Spain's consumer price inflation slowed to 3.3% in March, its weakest annual rate since August 2021.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Stoxx 600 index closed 1.3 per cent higher.

site_title: Meta explores changes to ad policies in Europe: reports
summary: Meta Platforms is exploring changes to its ad policies in Europe amid EU regulations targeting online campaigns. Executives are discussing a ban on political ads due to concerns about compliance. Alternatively, Meta may allow users to opt out of personalized ads or offer a version of its services targeting users with broad categories. The moves come as the company faces a compliance deadline for Ireland's Data Protection Commission rulings and faces fines for breaching EU antitrust laws.

images.alt_text: Employees of the social media giant, who get a rating of “met most expectations” in their 2023 year-end reviews, will receive a smaller percentage of bonus and restricted stock award due in March 2024, the WSJ report said.

site_title: China’s HiPhi luxury EV brand plans Europe entry in 2023
summary: Chinese luxury EV maker Human Horizons plans to launch its HiPhi brand in some European markets later this year, with a focus on western Europe or Scandinavia. The company will initially target younger, more affluent consumers with connected EVs featuring hi-tech features like facial recognition and projector headlights. HiPhi's X SUV and Z sedan currently sell in China, with a range of up to 430 miles and prices starting at around $119,791.26. The company aims to reach 4,000-5,000 sales this year and plans to announce a new lower-price model in Shanghai in April.

site_title: Golden Mile Tower set for en bloc relaunch at S$600 million reserve price
summary: Golden Mile Tower, a 99-year leasehold commercial development, is set to relaunch for collective sale on Apr 7 at a reserve price of S$600 million. The development, valued at S$598 million, comprises 405 strata lots with 251 retail units, 152 office units, and other amenities. Owners of retail units can expect an indicative amount of S$400,000 to S$16 million, while office unit owners can receive between S$587,000 and S$13.5 million. The building has a plot size of 8,727 sq m and a plot ratio of 4.46.

images.alt_text: Almost 90 per cent of Golden Mile Tower's owners have signed the collective sale agreement.
Golden Mile Tower was completed in 1974, one year after its sister building, Golden Mile Complex.
Situated between Nicoll Highway and Beach Road, Golden Mile Tower was completed in 1974, one year after its sister building, Golden Mile Complex.

site_title: Germans shun foreign deposits on fear of new crisis
summary: German households are shunning foreign deposits due to fears of a new crisis, similar to the Silicon Valley Bank collapse. Demand for foreign deposits dropped 15-20% since March 10, while German banks saw an increase in demand. This trend mimics the US exodus from small to large banks after SVB's collapse, potentially raising funding costs for weaker European economies. Foreign banks that were hoping to tap Germany's vast pool of cash, now miss out on significant deposits.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Traders work on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., November 11, 2022. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo
The euro rose 0.3 per cent to US$1.0880, and was on track to end the month with an almost 3 per cent gain.
The failures of SVB, and days later, Signature Bank, set off a broader loss of investor confidence in the banking sector that pummelled stocks and stoked fears of a full-blown financial crisis.

site_title: FTX’s Bankman-Fried pleads not guilty to campaign finance, China bribery charges
summary: Sam Bankman-Fried, the 31-year-old founder of FTX, pleaded not guilty to 13 US charges, including campaign finance law violations and China bribery. The new charges add to the pressure on Bankman-Fried, who faces decades in prison if convicted at his October trial. He had earlier pleaded not guilty to eight counts of fraud and conspiracy, and three former FTX employees have pleaded guilty to cooperate with prosecutors. Bankman-Fried is confined to his parents' home on a $250 million bond pending trial.

images.alt_text: The China case stemmed from a move by Chinese authorities to freeze Alameda accounts as part of what Bankman-Fried understood as a probe of an Alameda trading counterparty.

Under some of the proposed new conditions, Bankman-Fried would have a new phone with no Internet capability and a basic laptop with limited functions, but be forbidden from using other electronic communication devices.

site_title: Streaming device maker Roku to cut 200 jobs in second round of layoffs
summary: Roku, a streaming device maker, announced its second round of layoffs, cutting 200 jobs, approximately 6% of its workforce. The company expects to incur charges of $30-35 million related to the restructuring. This move comes as the US tech sector braces for a potential economic downturn. The job cuts and restructuring charges are expected to be completed by the end of the second quarter.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People play Electronic Arts' "FIFA" video game at the Microsoft Xbox booth at the Electronic Entertainment Expo, or E3, in Los Angeles, California, United States, June 16, 2015. REUTERS/Lucy Nicholson/File Photo

Employees of the social media giant, who get a rating of “met most expectations” in their 2023 year-end reviews, will receive a smaller percentage of bonus and restricted stock award due in March 2024, the WSJ report said.
Disney employed about 220,000 people worldwide as of Oct 1.

site_title: King Charles lauds unity on Ukraine war in bilingual Bundestag speech
summary: King Charles delivered a bilingual speech to the German Bundestag, praising the historic ties between Britain and Germany and their unity in the face of Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The monarch highlighted the "remarkably courageous" decision by Germany to provide large military support to Ukraine, and expressed pride in the strength of the partnership between the two countries. Charles also met with Ukrainian refugees in Germany, and played table football with some of them, drawing laughter from lawmakers.

images.alt_text: Britain's Queen Consort Camilla (left) and King Charles III wave as they greet the crowd at Buckingham Palace in London.

site_title: Apple wins reversal of US$502 million VirnetX patent infringement verdict
summary: Apple has won a reversal of a US$502 million patent infringement verdict against VirnetX, a patent licensing company. The US Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit ruled that the verdict could not stand after the US Patent Trial and Appeal Board cancelled the VPN patents at the center of the dispute. This follows a previous decision to affirm the invalidity of the patents. VirnetX separately won a US$302 million verdict against Apple in 2016.

site_title: Laughter, loopholes, liberation, and the Vietnam peace pact
summary: The 50th anniversary of the Paris Peace Accords, signed in 1973, marks a moment to reflect on the negotiations' "atmospherics" and the "loopholes" in the agreement. American and North Vietnamese negotiators, including Henry Kissinger and Le Duc Tho, used humor to break the ice and build rapport, with Tho requesting a promise that the US would not continue military involvement after the agreement. Kissinger responded with jokes, and the two sides laughed together, despite the seriousness of the talks. The agreement ultimately failed to prevent the US from withdrawing, allowing North Vietnam to maintain a military presence in the south, leading to the fall of Saigon in 1975.

images.alt_text: Schoolgirls perform during the 50th anniversary of the massacre in My Lai village, Vietnam, March 16, 2018.
President Joe Biden announces his plan to send M1 Abrams tanks to Ukraine, Jan 25, 2023.

site_title: Indonesian president pledges nickel mining clean up amid EV-led boom
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has pledged to step up scrutiny of nickel mining and order companies to manage nurseries to reforest depleted mines, amid concerns over environmental and social impacts. The country, with the world's largest nickel reserves, aims to improve monitoring of environmental standards and strengthen management control systems. The development of electric vehicles is driving the demand for nickel, but environmental groups have criticized the industry's environmental record, including pollution and land grabs. Widodo has also vowed to ensure all miners follow international best practices and will only approve new smelter permits if powered by renewable energy sources.

images.alt_text: The Ford badge and E-Transit logo are seen on a vehicle at Ford’s Dunton Technical Centre in Dunton, Britain, January 13, 2023.  REUTERS/Peter Nicholls
Dump trucks travel along a track at a nickel mine operated by Vale Indonesia in Sorowako, South Sulawesi, Indonesia. The company is emerging as an important producer of nicke.
Merdeka Battery is tapping into the surging global demand for electric cars by refining its nickel into battery materials.
Harita Nickel’s Halmahera Persada Lygend processing facility on Obi Island. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

site_title: Wildfires ravage Spain's Asturias, mostly by arsonists
summary: Wildfires broke out in Spain's northern Asturias region on March 30, with over 100 blazes started by arsonists, authorities said. The blazes, fueled by record-high temperatures, have burned 1,100 hectares of land in Galicia and another area in Valencia. Authorities banned access to forest tracks and restricted machinery use to prevent further fires. Regional leader Adrian Barbon vowed to prosecute those responsible, calling them "criminals and delinquents." The blazes come amid concerns of increased wildfires this year due to an unusually dry winter and rising temperatures caused by climate change.

images.alt_text: Pertamina said in a statement that the cause is still being investigated and evacuation is ongoing.

site_title: 🤷 Getting started with investing
summary: A trading account with a brokerage allows individuals to buy and sell shares on the stock exchange, as well as other securities. When choosing a brokerage, consider fees, which can eat into investment returns, and whether the platform offers the desired investment products. Opening a Central Depository Account (CDP) is also recommended, even if not for Singapore stocks, to access higher interest rates. Before investing, set aside sufficient cash savings, pay off high-interest loans, and be aware of hidden fees and charges.

images.alt_text: Daryl Choo

site_title: China’s Meizu unveils first smartphones since deal with Geely founder
summary: China's Meizu unveiled its first smartphones since being taken over by Geely founder Eric Li's venture, Xingji Meizu. The company launched three models priced between 2,999 and 6,299 yuan, using its homegrown FlymeOS operating system. This marks the first step for Xingji Meizu to integrate consumer electronics and travel, following Geely's entry into the premium smartphone sector. The move comes as Chinese consumers demand more smart technologies in their cars, with Meizu's Flyme Auto system also being showcased.

site_title: Janet Yellen says bank deregulation may have gone too far
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen warned that bank deregulation may have gone too far, contributing to the recent banking crisis. She emphasized the need to complete post-2008 financial reforms and repair regulatory cracks. Yellen identified non-bank financial intermediaries, including money-market funds, as areas needing attention to prevent "fire sales" that can cripple the broader financial system. The Fed has launched an investigation into the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and New York's Signature Bank, and Congress is likely to open its own inquiries. Yellen stressed that proper regulation is necessary to prevent financial crises and protect ordinary Americans.

images.alt_text: US bank stocks slid again on Thursday, pushing the S&P 500 banks index down to its lowest close since November 2020.

site_title: Manchester United returns to profit in second quarter
summary: Manchester United reported a net profit of £6.3 million (S$10.3 million) in the second quarter, reversing a loss of £1.4 million from the same period last year. The profit was driven by higher commercial revenue and lower wages. The club's American owners, the Glazer family, have launched a formal sale process, with several bids received, including from Sheikh Jassim Bin Hamad Al Thani and British billionaire Jim Ratcliffe. The club has not disclosed any details about the sale.

site_title: Philippine central bank head says ‘too early’ to halt rate hikes
summary: Philippine central bank Governor Felipe Medalla stated it's "too early" to pause interest rate hikes, citing a need for "enough low month-on-month inflation" to meet the 2.9% inflation forecast. Annual inflation remains near a 14-year high at 8.6%, and the central bank could continue its aggressive tightening cycle, having raised rates by 425 basis points since May. Medalla believes Philippine banks can absorb higher interest rates due to their liquidity and well-capitalization.

images.alt_text: Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) raised the overnight reverse repurchase rate by 25 basis points to 6.25 per cent.

site_title: After extraordinary rally, bonds' fate now with bank stability and inflation
summary: Global bond yields plummeted in March, with two-year US Treasury yields dropping 65 basis points, their largest monthly decline since 2008. The rally was fueled by banking turmoil and concerns over financial stability, rather than inflation, as investors sought safe havens. Despite positioning for higher US rate hikes, markets now price around a 50% chance of a rate cut, with European Central Bank rates seen peaking around 3.5%. Analysts expect mixed outcomes, with some predicting a recession and others expecting a pause in rate hikes, sparking wild market swings.

images.alt_text: Logos of Swiss banks UBS and Credit Suisse are seen on an office building in Zurich, Switzerland March 19, 2023. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse

site_title: CEO of United Hampshire US Reit manager to step down, CFO to take over
summary: Robert Schmitt, CEO of United Hampshire US Reit's manager, is stepping down due to health reasons, effective May 1. Gerard Yuen, current CFO, will take over as new CEO. Yuen was appointed CFO prior to the Reit's listing in 2020 and helped with its initial public offering. This change comes after Schmitt's health reasons were cited as the reason for his departure.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

site_title: China’s biggest bank ICBC posts 1.9% fall in Q4 profit
summary: ICBC, China's largest-listed lender, reported a 1.9% fall in fourth-quarter net profit to 94.7 billion yuan, down from 96.5 billion yuan a year earlier. Despite this, full-year profit increased 3.5% to 360.5 billion yuan, exceeding Refinitiv's estimate of 356.61 billion yuan.

site_title: Fire on Philippine ferry kills 29, including children; 225 rescued
summary: A fire on a Philippine ferry, MV Lady Mary Joy 3, killed 29 people, including 6-month-old baby, on Wednesday. The cause of the fire remains unknown. Rescuers found 225 people, including 36 crew, on board, with 11 drowning and 18 dying in the blaze. The incident highlights the Philippines' poor maritime safety record, with many overcrowded and aging ships in use.

site_title: China's Big Five banks post healthy results, warn of shaky recovery
summary: China's Big Five banks, including China Construction Bank, Bank of Communications, Bank of China, Agricultural Bank of China, and China's Industrial Bank, reported above 3.5% annual net profit growth. However, they warned that the country's recovery is not yet solid, citing shaky economic foundations. The banks' results were released amidst a mixed economic outlook, with some indicating a possible slowdown in growth.

images.alt_text: Global crypto firms scrambled to move funds away after the US banking crisis, with local companies such as crypto hedge fund MaiCapital — which held funds with Signature — urgently sought to open bank accounts in Hong Kong.

site_title: Karl Liew, son of Changi Airport Group’s ex-chairman, admits lying to judge in Parti Liyani case
summary: Karl Liew, son of Changi Airport Group's former chairman, pleaded guilty to one charge of giving false information to a public servant. He admitted lying to a district judge in the case involving his family's former maid, Parti Liyani, who was accused of stealing S$34,000 worth of items. The original conviction was overturned in 2020, and the case has been adjourned to April 14.

images.alt_text: The couple faced a police investigation as they were found to have lied under oath over Lee Suet Fern’s conduct in handling the last will of Singapore’s founding prime minister, Lee Kuan Yew.

site_title: Over 30,000 funds to get their ESG ratings downgraded at MSCI
summary: Approximately 31,000 funds will see their ESG scores lowered by MSCI due to a major overhaul of its methodology in response to market feedback. The changes, effective at the end of next month, include a more rigorous threshold for top ratings and will reflect a simpler methodology that focuses on the weighted average ESG score of underlying fund holdings. The move aims to provide more meaningful differentiation and a reflection of funds' ESG exposures for investors.

site_title: GovTech chief Kok Ping Soon to become SBF’s new CEO
summary: Kok Ping Soon, current GovTech CEO, will become the Singapore Business Federation's (SBF) new CEO-designate on April 1, concurrently serving as SBF CEO starting June 1. He replaces Lam Yi Young, who took on a deputy CEO role at Resorts World Sentosa in January. Kok's public sector experience will be crucial in helping businesses stay future-ready, according to SBF Chairman Lim Ming Yan.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Resorts World Sentosa hires the chief of Singapore Business Federation and a casino veteran from Marina Bay Sands.

Minister of State for Trade and Industry, and Culture, Community and Youth Low Yen Ling (foreground centre) and Singapore Business Foundation (SBF) chief executive officer Lam Yi Young (foreground right), hold their phones up with the OneTAC SG app and pose for pictures with guests after launch of the OneTAC SG platform at the SBF centre.
Singapore Business Federation (SBF) chairman Lim Ming Yan has been re-elected for a second term.

site_title: Global derivatives industry defends CDS after banking blow-ups
summary: The International Association of Swaps and Derivatives Association (ISDA) has defended Credit Default Swaps (CDS) amid concerns about their role in recent global banking turmoil. European regulators, including the European Union markets watchdog ESMA, are investigating market movements, including in the CDS market. ISDA's CEO Scott O'Malia argued that regulators already have access to extensive data on CDS trades and that the market is more transparent than previously thought. The credit derivatives market has shrunk significantly since the 2008 financial crisis, with gross market exposure decreasing from $5.4 trillion to $247 billion.

site_title: Euro rises as inflation takes centre stage, bank fears recede
summary: The euro rose 0.3% to US$1.0880, tracking a 3% gain for the month, as investors shifted focus to inflation data, which is expected to ease in Germany and Spain. Concerns over the banking sector receded, with the US dollar index falling 0.2% after a tumultuous month triggered by the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank. The European Central Bank is expected to maintain its hawkish stance, with two potential 25 basis point rate hikes by September.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Manpower Ministry reported a sustained demand for technological skills, citing ongoing digitalisation trends. In 2022, professionals, managers, executives, and technicians (PMETs) made up a rising share of Singapore's job vacancies, but still fell short of pre-pandemic levels. Meanwhile, Mapletree Logistics Trust is acquiring eight Asia-Pacific assets for over S$900 million and considering more purchases. The six-month Treasury bill closed with a yield of 3.85%, while Singapore hotel revenues and occupancy rates improved in February.

site_title: Singapore’s GIC to jointly buy Japanese HR software developer for US$2.6 billion: Nikkei
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC will jointly acquire Japanese human-resources software developer Works Human Intelligence for US$2.6 billion. GIC will acquire about half of Works Human's shares, with the remaining half held by Works Human executives and a new fund established by Bain Capital. This marks what may be GIC's largest acquisition. Works Human is a spinoff from the former Works Applications, which sold its human-resources management division to Bain in 2019 for 100 billion yen.

site_title: Shell pulls plug on 2 Singapore projects, says clean-energy transition unchanged
summary: Shell announces it will cease exploration of two projects in Singapore, a biofuels unit and a Group II base oil plant. Despite this, the company will continue to supply base oil and lubricants, biofuels, and other products to customers in Singapore and the region. Shell's "powering progress" strategy remains unchanged, with the company focusing on a decade-long plan to reduce carbon emissions and become a net-zero emissions energy business by 2050. Other projects, such as upgrading pyrolysis oil and launching electric ferries, will continue to move forward.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

“This divestment is in line with Shell’s work to focus its Upstream portfolio. Shell retains a strong presence in Malaysia’s upstream, gas-to-liquids, downstream and business services sectors,” the company said.
Saudi Aramco's performance has been bolstered by record production and oil prices soaring to around US$130 a barrel after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
An oil tanker near the port city of Nakhodka, Russia. Initial reports indicated that Russian oil was trading at or below the US$60 price cap. Now, some claim that reported prices are inaccurate.

site_title: EU takes next step to make companies report gender pay gap
summary: The European Union has taken a step towards tackling the gender pay gap, with the European Parliament voting to support a new directive requiring companies with at least 100 staff to disclose information on employee salaries. The rules also ban asking about previous salaries in job applications and require companies to publish information on gender pay gaps on their websites. The directive aims to reduce the 13% pay gap between men and women in the EU, with some countries, like Luxembourg, having smaller gaps, while others, like Latvia, have larger gaps.

images.alt_text: For equitable progress for all, we need to implement initiatives on diversity that target equitable opportunities for all, regardless of gender, ethnicity, age, socio-economic background, says Valerie Mantot-Groene, regional managing director, Asean, Apex Group. PHOTO:

site_title: China-driven growth seen helping emerging assets despite bank worries
summary: Analysts predict China-driven growth in emerging markets will help cushion the impact of banking turmoil in the US and Europe. Despite high interest rates, inflation, and stress among financial institutions, China's economic growth is expected to buffer developing nations. Strategists recommend careful picks to mitigate risks, with China's growth premium for emerging markets confirmed.

images.alt_text: At end-2021, 25 sovereigns were in default or arrears to China, up from an average of four a year between 2008 and 2015.

site_title: Fitch affirms Hong Kong at AA- with stable outlook
summary: Fitch Ratings has affirmed Hong Kong's credit rating at AA- with a stable outlook, predicting a 4% economic rebound this year after a 3.5% contraction in 2022. The Asian financial hub is expected to recover from pandemic restrictions and China's zero-Covid policies, with growth forecasted at 3.5% in 2024 and a narrowing budget deficit to 3.7% of GDP. The AA- rating indicates very low default risk and strong capacity for financial commitment payment.

site_title: BMW’s first million-dollar car launched in Singapore
summary: BMW has launched its first million-dollar car, the XM, a plug-in hybrid SUV, in Singapore with a price tag of S$1,003,888 (inclusive of COE). The car boasts a powerful hybrid system and extravagant design with unconventional proportions. With a 653-horsepower combination of an electric motor and 4.4-litre V8 engine, the XM is one of the speediest SUVs in the world, hitting 100 km/h in 4.3 seconds. Only 453 hand-built examples are available, making it a rare and exclusive vehicle.

images.alt_text: The Niro EV, a pure electric version, not only ticks all the boxes on the list of things you expect from a family crossover, it zips around without tailpipe emissions (which is hardly surprising since it doesn’t even have a tailpipe).
a Foodpanda rider performing battery swap at a Gogoro station.
Stopping to fill the iX5’s tanks at a hydrogen filling station in Antwerp that supplies cars, trucks and boats took us less than four minutes.

site_title: Charming Garden to try for en bloc sale again at unchanged S$175 million guide price
summary: A 999-year leasehold condominium in District 10, Singapore, known as Charming Garden, is set to be put up for collective sale via public tender on March 31. The four-storey development, located at 138 and 140 King's Road, features 32 apartment units and sits on an elevated site spanning 84,357 square feet. The sole marketing agent, Colliers, has maintained the unchanged guide price of S$175 million, which was first introduced in December 2022. The sale will test demand for prime projects in Singapore.

images.alt_text: The guide price translates to a land rate of about S$2,096 per square foot per plot ratio, Colliers said.

site_title: Evergrande chairman’s HK mansion fails to sell by targeted date
summary: Evergrande chairman Hui Ka Yan's luxury mansion in Hong Kong valued at HK$880 million (S$148.9 million) failed to attract a buyer by the desired timeline. Despite interest from dozens of potential buyers, including local wealthy families and mainland Chinese investors, bids fell short of the creditor's targets. The receiver of the property, Centaline Property Agency, did not accept any offers and the house will remain on the market. The property was seized by China Construction Bank (Asia) in November.

images.alt_text: Evergrande NEV said it is seeking to cut costs by reducing staff numbers and improving management efficiency.

site_title: SoftBank to book US$2.7 billion gain for Alibaba share transfer
summary: SoftBank will book a US$2.7 billion gain from transferring 178.7 million Alibaba shares to a subsidiary, citing improved management efficiency. The transfer is related to Alibaba's plan to split into six units and explore fundraisings or listings. The gain includes a previously deferred prepaid forward contract settlement of 117.1 billion yen (S$1.17 billion).

site_title: China regulator looking for buyers of SVB’s local venture
summary: Chinese regulators held a meeting to discuss the disposal of Silicon Valley Bank's 50% stake in SPD Silicon Valley Bank, a joint venture providing banking services to tech companies in China. Chinese banks have indicated interest, with discussions at a very early stage. The move aims to safeguard the nation's $54 trillion banking system from the US lender's collapse, amid concerns over loan losses and economic growth. The regulator's decision follows SVB's US operations being acquired by First Citizens BancShares and its UK business being taken over by HSBC Holdings.

images.alt_text: The failures of SVB, and days later, Signature Bank, set off a broader loss of investor confidence in the banking sector that pummelled stocks and stoked fears of a full-blown financial crisis.

site_title: Singapore stocks end winning streak on Thursday; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% on Thursday, ending a three-day winning streak, to close at 3,257.18. Despite a strong trading day with 308 gains outpacing 255 losers, the market was weighed down by the trio of lenders OCBC, UOB, and DBS, which declined 1.1%, 0.4%, and 0.3%, respectively. Analysts attribute the market's volatility to concerns about the Federal Reserve's monetary policy and the upcoming Q1 earnings season.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Hong Kong’s benchmark Hang Seng Index climbed 1.1 per cent.
Mainland China computer, communications equipment and media indexes have surged between 29 per cent and 35 per cent this year, outstripping a rise of just 3.5 per cent in the benchmark CSI 300 Index.
The MSCI World share index traded 0.6 per cent lower and Europe’s STOXX 600 index was down 1.6 per cent.

site_title: Watches and Wonders Geneva takes a glitzy turn this year
summary: Watches and Wonders Geneva, the world's largest luxury watch fair, has concluded its 2023 edition with a record-breaking attendance and numerous jaw-dropping timepieces from top brands. The fair, which ran from March 27 to April 2, featured 48 brands, including Rolex, Tudor, Patek Philippe, and Chanel, and attracted over 22,000 daily attendees. The event showcased innovative watches, including Grand Seiko's Tentagraph and Hublot's Big Bang Integrated Tourbillon. Celebrities, such as Julia Roberts and Roger Federer, lent their star power to the event, which has solidified the world's appetite for Swiss luxury watches, now considered a bonafide asset class.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan
The new Daytona features aesthetic adjustments, tweaked colours to enhance contrast, and most importantly, a new movement inside.

site_title: Four bankers who helped Putin’s friend set up Swiss bank account convicted
summary: Four bankers, including three Russians and one Swiss, were convicted on March 30 of lacking diligence in financial transactions while helping Sergey Roldugin, a concert cellist dubbed "Putin's wallet," move millions of francs through Swiss bank accounts between 2014 and 2016. The bankers aided Roldugin, a godfather to Putin's eldest daughter, in depositing funds in Swiss accounts. The conviction marks a significant development in Switzerland's efforts to combat money laundering and corruption linked to Russian officials.

site_title: A celestial experience with Chanel’s high jewellery
summary: Chanel's "1932" high jewellery collection has arrived in Singapore for the first time. The collection features extravagant pieces, including the Comète Constellation multi-tiered necklace with 20.16 carat cushion-cut diamonds. This marks a groundbreaking moment in jewellery design, as Chanel's 1932 collection was her only high jewellery exhibition, commissioned by the London Diamond Corporation during the Great Depression to revive the diamond market.

images.alt_text: Chanel’s journey to the stars
Première Édition Originale watch in steel coated with yellow gold, black leather, black-lacquered dial and high precision quartz movement (S$8,850)

site_title: White knight behind crypto exchange Zipmex says ‘not obligated’ to make payment, amid concerns of pullout
summary: V Ventures, the investor behind Zipmex's US$100 million bailout, claims it is not obligated to disburse US$1.25 million to fund Zipmex's working capital due to unresolved matters over the proposed scheme of arrangement. This move raises concerns about the crypto platform's efforts to save itself from insolvency, affecting tens of thousands of customers and employees. Zipmex's scheme of arrangement was approved by Singapore's High Court, but the investor's failure to transfer funds has sparked doubts about the deal's success.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Zipmex has about US$700,000 in cash in its bank balance. Without the financing, the company will survive till January, says its lawyer.
Zipmex could have been operating as a “digital-asset fund manager without permission,” Thailand's SEC said

site_title: Vietnam central bank to cut interest rates further
summary: Vietnam's central bank plans to cut interest rates further to support economic growth, according to Deputy Governor Dao Minh Tu. The move aims to increase liquidity and encourage lending, following a surprise rate cut in earlier this month. The country's economic growth slowed to 3.32% in the first quarter, partly due to weak global demand. The rate cuts are expected to allow local commercial banks to lower their lending rates, providing relief to the economy.

site_title: Ford, Vale Indonesia, Huayou sign deal for US$4.5 billion EV battery material plant
summary: US carmaker Ford Motor Co signed a $4.5 billion deal with Vale Indonesia and China's Huayou Cobalt to build a nickel processing plant in Indonesia's Southeast Sulawesi. The plant, expected to produce 120,000 tonnes of nickel per year, will support electric vehicle battery production. The project, valued at $4.5 billion, marks Ford's first investment in Indonesia and aligns with the company's goal of ensuring nickel for EV batteries is mined with ESG standards. Construction began in November, with commercial operation expected to start in 2026.

site_title: Sembmarine requests trading halt pending announcement
summary: Sembcorp Marine has requested a trading halt pending an announcement, with its shares halted at 1:24 pm on Thursday. The halt comes a day after the company released a statement regarding preliminary administrative proceedings against its subsidiary Estaleiro Jurong Aracruz related to Brazil's anti-graft probe Operation Car Wash. The group had previously announced that EJA was under investigation for alleged irregularities in its practices. The trading halt is the second this month, following a halt on March 23.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

site_title: This time, it’s different – it’s an interest rate issue, says top banking lawyer
summary: Top banking lawyer Rodgin Cohen says the current banking crisis is caused by an imbalance between banks' long-term assets and deposits created by a change in interest rates, rather than a credit issue like the 2008 financial crisis. He compares it to the 1980s thrift crisis, where rising interest rates created a mismatch between long-term assets and deposits. Cohen believes the situation can be contained without significant impact on consumers, and unlike SVB's collapse, Credit Suisse's issues are more long-term.

images.alt_text: As the Credit Suisse rescue plan emerged, UBS expressed concern about taking on its rival’s potential legal liabilities.

site_title: South Korea, TSMC express concern about US chip subsidy criteria
summary: South Korea and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) have expressed concerns over the US chip subsidy criteria, which require companies to share excess profits with the US government and may expose confidential corporate strategy. The US' CHIPS Act pool of $52 billion will be used for research and manufacturing funds, and the application process may require detailed cost structure information. South Korea's Trade Minister Ahn Duk-geun said the criteria may be "burdensome" for companies like Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix, while TSMC Chairman Mark Liu expressed concerns that certain conditions cannot be accepted.

site_title: Netflix tests idea of expanding gaming service to televisions
summary: Netflix is testing the idea of expanding its gaming service to television sets, a move that would bring its gaming offerings beyond smartphones and tablets. The company has included code in its app that references games played on TVs and uses phones as controllers, indicating a plan to launch a TV-based gaming service. This expansion would supplement Netflix's shows and movies and help retain customers as the company raises subscription prices. The move could also position Netflix as a competitor to cloud gaming services like Microsoft and Apple Arcade.

images.alt_text: Aubrey Plaza in the second season of The White Lotus, which was filmed at San Domenico Palace, a Four Seasons resort hotel in Taormina, Sicily.
US adult users will spend an average of nearly 56 minutes per day on TikTok this year, six minutes less than the time spent watching Netflix, the market tracker forecast.

site_title: Bondholders set to tussle with Sri Lanka over restructuring
summary: Sri Lanka is set to restructure its $84 billion debt to exit a decades-long economic slump, with global bondholders demanding that local debt holders share billions of dollars of losses. The government is balancing local interests with investor demands, with Treasury Secretary Mahinda Siriwardena indicating that some local debt will be included in the restructuring. A speedy resolution is crucial to avoid the fate of Zambia, which has stalled talks with its creditors, and the IMF has outlined a plan for a four-year loan program with conditions including debt reductions.

images.alt_text: Supporters of President Ranil Wickremesinghe light firecrackers after the IMF's approval of a US$3 billion bailout package.
At end-2021, 25 sovereigns were in default or arrears to China, up from an average of four a year between 2008 and 2015.

site_title: Google says Microsoft's cloud practices anti-competitive, critical of deals with rivals
summary: Google has accused Microsoft of anti-competitive cloud practices, citing deals with European cloud vendors as an attempt to silence critics. Google's Vice President Amit Zavery told Reuters that Microsoft's licensing terms create unfair advantages and limit customer choice. Microsoft has offered to change its practices in exchange for suspending an EU investigation, but Zavery says this doesn't address broader concerns. Google has urged EU regulators to examine Microsoft's cloud practices, which dominate the market with over 20% market share.

images.alt_text: Google Cloud grew 32 per cent, the slowest rise since the company began reporting the measure in 2019.

site_title: Hiring spree by China’s debt-laden local governments fuels fiscal fears
summary: China's debt-laden local governments are on a hiring spree, adding 190,000 jobs across the country, a 16% increase from 2022. Provinces like Gansu, Yunnan, and Guangxi are hiring civil servants at a record pace, with Gansu adding 4,249, Yunnan 5,696, and Guangxi 6,781. This move is seen as a way to create jobs for 11.58 million college graduates, but analysts worry it may strain regional finances and worsen debt risks, which total US$9 trillion.

images.alt_text: Li’s comments at an international business summit in the island province of Hainan, are his latest calls for Beijing to bolster its economic recovery.
Uncertainties from the global banking crisis and fallout on global economies will affect demand for China’s goods, adding to pressure on manufacturers.
The recovery in household consumption, long seen as key to improving sustainability of growth in the world’s second-largest economy, is likely to be gradual and uneven.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust buys 8 Asia-Pac assets for over S$900 million, plans private placement
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) is acquiring eight logistics properties in Japan, Australia, and South Korea for S$913.6 million, with plans for a private placement to raise S$200 million. The trust's manager aims to fund the acquisitions through debt financing and equity fundraising. The proposed transactions are expected to be accretive to the trust's distribution per unit and net asset value, with yields ranging from 3.5% to 4.6%. Analysts are mixed on the transactions, citing concerns over the timing and size of the deal, but noting the asset quality and pricing.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Jude Chan
Commercial Reits take a beating on Wednesday, while property developers trade in a sea of red.

As at Mar 8, 86 companies listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) had released their financial results for the quarter ended December last year. Of these, 47 companies reported a profit, while 39 ended the quarter in the red.

site_title: A look at past bank outages in Singapore, and their consequences
summary: DBS' digital banking services were disrupted for the entire day, affecting its Digibank and PayLah mobile apps, website, and mobile trading services, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) calling it "unacceptable." The incident comes ahead of MAS' tightened guidelines for financial institutions to respond to service disruptions, which take effect in June. This is the latest in a series of disruptions for Singapore's banks, including DBS' worst digital disruption in a decade in 2021, and previous outages at OCBC and UOB in 2022.

images.alt_text: DBS digital banking services 'returning to normal' on Wednesday night after two-day outage

site_title: Post-Art Basel, Hong Kong’s art scene continues to dazzle
summary: Hong Kong's art scene continues to thrive, with various exhibitions showcasing unique and thought-provoking works. Michele Chu's solo show at PHD Group explores themes of memory and loss through a series of immersive installations. Wang Tuo's video installations at Blindspot Gallery tackle art censorship in China, while Jes Fan and Tishan Hsu's works at Empty Gallery blur the line between technology and the human body. Meanwhile, Rirkrit Tiravanija's immersive installation at David Zwirner reimagines the concept of art as a communal experience. The Spectrosynthesis III exhibition at Tai Kwun explores queer cultures and histories, while M+'s Things, Places, Interactions exhibition showcases a wide range of design objects and furniture pieces.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Art Basel Hong Kong's sizzling sales figures reaffirm the city's pole position as an art hub.
Ian Tee's solo show at Yavuz Gallery features works inspired by Herman Melville's classic novel Moby Dick.

site_title: Tesla expects reduced tax credit for Model 3 by March-end
summary: Tesla announced that the US$7,500 tax credit for its Model 3 electric vehicle will be reduced by March 31 due to guidance from the US Treasury Department on sourcing of battery components. The credit is available only for consumers buying the model for personal use in the US. The Treasury Department's guidance, expected this week, will impact the credit available for some electric vehicles.

site_title: Toyota’s global sales notch up a February record as parts shortage eases
summary: Toyota's global sales reached a record for February, driven by a 10.3% increase to 773,271 vehicles, with domestic sales surging 53.2%. The company attributes the growth to easing parts shortages, which had previously hindered production due to the pandemic. Despite this, Toyota notes that parts shortages continue to be a problem, and worldwide production has increased for a second consecutive month.

site_title: China committed to economic opening up, reforms: Premier Li
summary: China is committed to economic opening up and reforms, Premier Li Qiang said at the Boao Forum for Asia, amid strained relations with the US and allies. Li pledged to introduce new measures to expand market access and optimize the business environment, while emphasizing the importance of peace for development. China's economy is expected to grow around 5% this year, with signs of recovery from Covid-19 curbs. Li also reiterated Beijing's opposition to trade protectionism and decoupling, amid US efforts to restrict China's access to advanced technologies.

images.alt_text: Chinese Premier Li is set to deliver a keynote speech at the Boao Forum for Asia as the event wraps up in the southern province of Hainan.
FILE PHOTO: Model of LNG tanker is seen in front of China's flag in this illustration taken May 19, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration//File Photo
China's data on key economic activity, including retail sales, industrial production and fixed asset investment, all show modest improvement with clear room for further growth.

site_title: China’s largest developer posts first loss since 2007 listing
summary: China's largest property developer, Country Garden Holdings, posted a net loss of 6.1 billion yuan in 2022, its first full-year loss since listing in 2007. The slump in the real estate sector is weighing on the developer, which has become a proxy for financial contagion. Revenue stood at 430 billion yuan, and core net profit reached 2.6 billion yuan. The loss may cast a shadow on Country Garden's 2023 earnings recovery, as the developer may lag behind peers in sales recovery, according to Bloomberg Intelligence analysts.

site_title: Sembmarine consortium bags 6 billion euros in contracts for offshore renewables project
summary: Sembcorp Marine and its consortium partner GE Renewable Energy's Grid Solutions have secured a 5-year framework cooperation agreement with TenneT for three offshore wind farm projects in the Netherlands, valued at 6 billion euros. The contract includes supplying high voltage direct current electrical transmission systems for three mega offshore wind farms with a combined capacity of 6 GW. Construction of the platforms is expected to begin in the third quarter of 2024, with completion anticipated between 2029 and 2031.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Shares of Sembcorp Marine have been halted as at 1.24pm on Thursday.
Sembmarine says it will continue to co-operate and work with Brazilian authorities on this matter.
DBS is now hopeful of Sembmarine's operational improvement post the merger, which has resulted in a stronger balance sheet and combined order book of over S$17 billion.
A signage of Sembcorp Marine.

site_title: A wine vintage takes a break from climate change
summary: The 2021 German wine vintage, particularly in regions like France and Germany, has yielded a unique set of kabinett Rieslings that resemble a "throwback" to pre-climate change vintages. After three years of hot temperatures, the '21 vintage was cool and wet, resulting in wines that are delicately sweet and refreshing. These wines, made from the kabinett style, were challenging to produce due to the need for growers to carefully manage the ripening process. The vintage has produced 12 bottles of kabinett Riesling, ranging from $24 to $55, that are considered "classic" and "pre-climate change wines."

site_title: US investment firm bets £300 million on red-hot UK rental market
summary: An American private equity firm, Harrison Street Real Estate Capital, has agreed to finance a £300 million (£492 million) housing development in Birmingham, UK, in the largest build-to-rent funding deal outside of London. The 722-apartment Great Charles Street development is backed by strong demographics and a growing pipeline of build-to-rent homes outside of London, with over 151,000 units in regional cities. This deal underscores confidence in the UK's red-hot rental market, which has seen supply more than triple in the last five years.

images.alt_text: Lenders authorised 43,500 home loans compared with 39,600 in January, the Bank of England (BOE) said.

site_title: Latest 6-month T-bill offers 3.85% yield; demand falls as banking crisis weighs on rate hike expectations
summary: Singapore's latest six-month Treasury bill (T-bill) closed with a cut-off yield of 3.85% on March 30, higher than the last auction but with lower demand due to the banking crisis weighing on rate hike expectations. The T-bill was 2.2 times subscribed for the S$4.3 billion allotment, down from the previous auction. Investors are seeking longer-term instruments, and market watchers attribute the lower demand to changed market sentiment caused by bank failures in the US and Europe.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Lawyers advised investors to read the fine print in bond instruments carefully before buying.

epa10536140 A man walks past the logo of Credit Suisse in Hong Kong, China, 22 March 2023. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority said Credit Suisse’s assets in Hong Kong made up 0.5 percent of the banking system’s total assets. Credit Suisse was purchased by rival UBS for over 3 billion US dollar after the collapse of the Switzerland-based investment bank.  EPA-EFE/JEROME FAVRE
UBS' proposed acquisition of Credit Suisse will trigger a complete write-down of the value of the latter's US$17 billion in perpetual Additional Tier-1 bonds.
MAS says it will remain in close contact with Finma, Credit Suisse and UBS as the takeover is executed.

site_title: PMET share of Singapore’s job vacancies rises in 2022; tech demand remains high
summary: Singapore's job vacancies rose in 2022, with professionals, managers, executives, and technicians (PMETs) accounting for 56% of record job vacancies, up from 53% in 2021. The tech sector remains highly sought after, with sustained demand for technological skills. The number of job vacancies eased to 104,500 in December 2022, but is expected to remain high due to structural trends like digital transformation. Employers are willing to offer higher salaries for specialized skills, and the share of non-PMET roles dipped in 2022, with 61% of job openings being for replacements rather than new positions.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

The net result is that locals can take on the jobs at “slightly higher levels”, Manpower Minister Tan See Leng said, citing findings from internal studies by his ministry on foreign workforce policies.
The number of job vacancies fell to 108,200 in September. Meanwhile, the ratio of job vacancies to unemployed persons also decreased to 2.20.

site_title: Regional groupings will help make Asia stronger: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of regional groupings in making Asia stronger and more resilient in a troubled global environment. He suggested building a "dense mesh of cooperation and interdependence" among countries, rather than a hub and spokes model, and highlighted the benefits of regional groupings such as Asean, the East Asia Summit, and the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership. Lee also stressed the need for stable, broader relationships with China and other external partners to foster economic cooperation and peace.

images.alt_text: Chinese Premier Li is set to deliver a keynote speech at the Boao Forum for Asia as the event wraps up in the southern province of Hainan.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as traders weigh rates outlook
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Thursday, with banking sector worries easing and traders weighing central banks' interest rate plans. Reassurances from authorities have contained the fallout from the collapse of US regional banks and the takeover of Credit Suisse. Speculation has led to bets on the Federal Reserve cutting borrowing costs by the end of the year, potentially ending the rate hike campaign sooner than expected.

images.alt_text: Worries over inflation have prompted investors to recalculate what they expect the Fed to do in its next meeting in May.

site_title: The metaverse is still the next big thing, Meta insists
summary: Meta's head of global affairs, Nick Clegg, reiterated the company's commitment to the metaverse, despite the tech industry's waning interest. Clegg emphasized the metaverse's potential in fields like education and healthcare, and its potential for user-friendly experiences. Meta plans to capitalize on the metaverse through advertising and commerce, but faces challenges from investors who have punished the company's past commitment to the technology. The metaverse's development will take time, with Clegg stating that the future of computing will take place in this virtual world.

images.alt_text: Meta Platforms dismissed telecoms providers’ arguments that the expansion of the metaverse, shared virtual worlds accessible via the Internet, would strain infrastructure capacity.
With Meta now hitting a nearly 25 per cent staff reduction, others in the tech world may follow suit. But if there was ever a time to break free of tech’s group-think mentality, this is it.
FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Meta Platforms' business group is seen in Brussels, Belgium December 6, 2022. REUTERS/Yves Herman/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Sovereign default at record high as global macroeconomic environment remains challenging: Fitch
summary: Fitch reports a record high in sovereign defaults, with 25 countries in default or arrears to China by the end of 2021, up from an average of four per year between 2008 and 2015. This marks a significant increase from 14 defaults across nine countries in 2020. Fitch attributes the rise in defaults to the challenging global macroeconomic environment.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Despite concerns about a potential recession, investors are pinning hopes that the new government leadership will reinstill confidence in the UK’s fiscal health.

site_title: China’s Premier Li steps up charm offensive for wary foreign firms
summary: Chinese Premier Li Qiang is delivering a keynote speech at the Boao Forum for Asia, a high-profile event aimed at restoring global confidence in China's economy. The speech comes as Beijing rolls out a charm offensive to court foreign businesses and investment, following years of disruptions due to Covid restrictions and escalating US tensions. Li has vowed to open up to global businesses, while acknowledging economic challenges, amid strained US-China relations and security risks for foreign companies operating in China.

images.alt_text: Uncertainties from the global banking crisis and fallout on global economies will affect demand for China’s goods, adding to pressure on manufacturers.
FILE PHOTO: Model of LNG tanker is seen in front of China's flag in this illustration taken May 19, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration//File Photo
China faces a shortage of an estimated 200,000 industry workers this year.

site_title: Citadel to resume hedge fund business in Japan with Tokyo office
summary: Citadel, a hedge fund firm, plans to set up a team in Tokyo, Japan, after shutting down operations in the country over a decade ago. The company is applying for an investment management licence and aims to tap local talent. This move is part of Ken Griffin's expansion of his footprint in Asia, with his other firm Citadel Securities doubling its headcount in the region in the past three years. The Tokyo office's opening date has yet to be decided.

site_title: Policymakers keep solving the wrong banking problem
summary: Banking institutions are inherently vulnerable due to their "maturity transformation" mechanism, which allows entrepreneurs access to long-term loans but exposes banks to liquidity risks. Policymakers' attempts to address this vulnerability, such as deposit insurance and capital buffers, are insufficient. The recent collapse of Silicon Valley Bank highlights that all banks are vulnerable by design, and a generalized panic can occur even with small losses. To fix the problem, policymakers need to adopt broad-based deposit insurance, swift liquidity provision, and stringent regulation, rather than focusing solely on strengthening banks' capital buffers.

images.alt_text: The basic function of banks is to provide money and credit, but depositors cannot monitor the soundness of banks in real time.
The closed gates of Credit Suisse's headquarters in Zurich, Switzerland. Perhaps we will look back on these few weeks as the time when the era of free market truisms ended.
The failures of SVB, and days later, Signature Bank, set off a broader loss of investor confidence in the banking sector that pummelled stocks and stoked fears of a full-blown financial crisis.

site_title: Indonesia stripped of U-20 World Cup hosting rights
summary: FIFA has stripped Indonesia of hosting the 2023 Under-20 World Cup, citing a failure to honour its commitments to the tournament. Indonesia's football federation cancelled the draw due to the governor of Bali refusing to host Israel's team, despite Indonesia being a predominantly Muslim country. The decision will be a setback for Indonesian football, which has a massive following but lacks international success since qualifying for the 1938 World Cup. A new host will be announced soon, and potential sanctions against the football federation may be decided at a later stage.

images.alt_text: The Club Benefits Programme affords clubs a share of national team competition revenues in return for releasing players and also protects clubs in case their players are injured on international duty.

site_title: One of HK’s most expensive homes reportedly seized from Chinese tycoon
summary: A Hong Kong bank seized one of the city's most expensive homes, 15 Gough Hill Road, from Chinese tycoon Chen Hongtian, who bought it for a record US$271 million in 2016. Other assets seized include a luxury apartment in the Frank Gehry-designed Opus building, Cheung Kei Center Block A and B in Hung Hom, and a parking lot. The seizures were made by Hang Seng Bank through PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) as part of a debt recovery effort.

site_title: BMW, Mercedes boom in Singapore as rich shrug off higher taxes
summary: In Singapore, luxury car ownership rights reached a record high, with 125 bidders paying up to S$116,020 for a 10-year permit, equivalent to 92% of the median annual household income. The quota system controlling the number of autos on the streets, limiting congestion and pollution, has driven up prices for BMWs and Mercedes, with one in four registered cars being either a Mercedes-Benz or BMW. The high cost of owning a car, despite government hikes, shows that rich Singaporeans are willing to pay for private vehicles.

images.alt_text: For larger cars and more powerful EVs, the COE premium ended at S$116,201, a 0.61 per cent increase over the previous high.
The drop in used car sales was less severe than the fall in new car registrations.

site_title: Thai February exports fall less than forecast
summary: Thai customs-based exports declined 4.7% in February, less than the forecasted 6.9% drop, marking the fifth consecutive month of decline. The decline was attributed to a slowing global economy and a high base from last year. Meanwhile, imports rose 1.1% from a year earlier, resulting in a trade deficit of $1.11 billion. The Commerce Ministry maintains its export growth target of 1-2% for the year.

site_title: Credit Suisse accused of aiding more tax evasion during broader tumult
summary: The US Senate Finance Committee has found "major violations" of a 2014 plea deal by Credit Suisse, accusing the bank of aiding rich Americans in hiding assets from the IRS.
