The report cites "what may be an ongoing criminal tax conspiracy" involving nearly $100 million in secret offshore accounts belonging to a dual US-Latin American family. Despite Credit Suisse's promises to close undeclared accounts, the bank has identified only $780 million in undeclared assets, with much revealed by whistleblowers. The committee's report raises concerns about Credit Suisse's potential breach of the plea deal and its pending acquisition by UBS, which faces its own legal liabilities.

images.alt_text: The Swiss bank first sold this form of notes in 2016 as a way of reducing the capital it was required to hold against operational risk.
Finma notes that Credit Suisse has a cultural problem that translated into a lack of accountability so it is not clear who is responsible for what.

site_title: Civil claim of 1.72 trillion rupiah against Keppel unit over ownership of Jakarta land ruled inadmissible
summary: A district court in Indonesia has ruled that a 1.72 trillion rupiah (S$152 million) lawsuit against Kepland Investama, a subsidiary of Keppel Land, over ownership rights for land plots in Jakarta was inadmissible. The claimant, Raden Saleh Abdul Malik, had alleged he was the legal owner of 17,000 square meter land plots, but his claim was based on a "girik" document not recognized under Indonesian agrarian law. The ruling upheld the inadmissibility of the lawsuit, effectively dismissing the claim.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim

site_title: Democratic leaders gather for Biden’s virtual summit, struggle to unite behind principles
summary: US President Joe Biden announced $690 million in funding to support democracies worldwide at a virtual Summit for Democracy, but the declaration, which includes backing for free and fair elections, was only endorsed by 73 countries. The summit, which included 120 nations, was criticized for lacking progress on human rights and democracy in foreign policy. Several countries, including India, Israel, and the Philippines, dissociated themselves from parts of the declaration, and a formal mechanism to hold participants to commitments remains unclear.

images.alt_text: U.S. and Chinese flags are seen in this illustration taken, January 30, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration
The new restrictions tied to the Chips Act aim to impose more onerous limitations on companies expected to secure incentives.
Biden noted that he had directed intelligence agencies to investigate Covid-19’s origins in 2021 including potential links to the Wuhan Institute of Virology.

site_title: As the tax environment changes, businesses must drive change from within
summary: Corporate tax leaders face challenges such as increased audit risk, lack of visibility and control, and digitalization lag. To strengthen compliance and add value, tax departments must transform how they work. Singapore is implementing a global minimum effective tax rate of 15% for large multinational companies, and companies must adapt to access required datasets. Internally, tax departments are grappling with resource constraints and organisational changes, driving the need for digitalization and process standardization. Companies are considering options such as outsourcing or in-house transformation to address these challenges and provide greater strategic value to the business.

images.alt_text: The next generation of business incentives could bring together domestic and regional strengths, offering investors the best of both worlds – all from a base in Singapore.
With BEPS Pillar 2, Singapore will need to consolidate its appeal to global MNEs and reframe its investment promotion strategies.

site_title: Alibaba to decide on control over new business units after IPOs
summary: Alibaba Group has announced its largest restructuring, transforming into a holding company structure with six business units. Each unit will have its own CEO and boards, with Alibaba retaining seats on those boards in the short term. The business units can pursue independent fundraisings and initial public offerings (IPOs) when ready, but Alibaba will decide whether to retain control after they go public. Analysts see the restructuring as a way to value each business division independently, potentially allowing investors to better value Alibaba as a standalone conglomerate.

images.alt_text: The refurbished Hong Kong Stock Exchange in Hong Kong, China, on Friday, June 24, 2022. Hong Kong dusted off the gong for the city's first in-person listing ceremony in two years. Photographer: Bertha Wang/Bloomberg
Alibaba 5x short DLCs suspended briefly on SGX as shares jump over 15%

site_title: Qantas, Airbus to invest in Australian biofuel refinery
summary: Qantas and Airbus will jointly invest A$2 million in a biofuel refinery in Queensland, Australia, to convert agricultural by-products into sustainable aviation fuel (SAF). The refinery aims to produce up to 100 million litres of SAF per year. The investment will support the airline's goal of using at least 10% of SAF in its fuel mix by 2030, with a target of 60% by 2050 to achieve net zero emissions. The project will help reduce carbon emissions by up to 80% and will be the fund's first investment in the Australian sustainable aviation fuel industry.

images.alt_text: Travelers prepare to board a passenger aircraft operated by Qantas Airways Ltd. at Sydney Airport in Sydney, Australia, on Wednesday, June 23, 2021. While losses at airlines globally from Covid-19 are set to surpass $174 billion by the end of 2021 -- wiping out half a decade of profits -- Qantas has become one of the most financially secure carriers anywhere in the world. Photographer: Brendon Thorne/Bloomberg
Sustainable aviation fuel is tipped to make the difference in the aviation sector, which is currently responsible for 5 per cent of man-made climate change. PHOTO:

site_title: Adani pulls back on grand ambitions after Hindenburg bombshell
summary: Gautam Adani's conglomerate is reevaluating its ambitions after Hindenburg Research's report alleging extensive corporate fraud, wiping out about $125 billion in market value since January. Adani is pulling back from petrochemicals, aluminium, steel, and road projects, focusing on core areas like power generation, ports, and green energy. The billionaire will avoid high-risk financing, instead opting for private bond placements and equity stake sales. This shift aims to restore confidence and address concerns about crony capitalism and Adani's ties to Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi.

images.alt_text: Adani Transmission and Adani Ports and Special Economic Zone “would be capped at current rating level of ‘BBB-/Stable’ till alleged concerns are ironed out,” Fitch said in an emailed statement.
The founders of the Adani Group also prepaid a US$500 million loan facility taken to finance the acquisition of Ambuja Cements.

site_title: Singtel in talks to integrate Telkom’s fixed broadband business into Telkomsel
summary: Singtel is in talks to integrate Telkom's fixed broadband business into its Indonesian associate Telkomsel, a move that would give Telkomsel a 70% share of Indonesia's high-growth fixed broadband market. The integration, if successful, would represent a win-win for both parties, with Singtel supporting the deal if it benefits Telkomsel and its shareholders. Negotiations are ongoing, with no certainty of a transaction.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Singtel signs MOUs with Telkom on regional data centres, fixed broadband business
Fixed broadband adoption in Indonesia has grown in recent years as users stream more video.
Maybank research lowered Singtel's core earnings projections for FY2023 to FY2025 by between 3 per cent to 8 per cent.
Singtel group chief executive Yuen Kuan Moon expects NCS’ margins to improve as the cost of scaling and business eases in the coming quarters.

site_title: To green South-east Asia, help SMEs fund their sustainability efforts
summary: South-east Asian small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are struggling to adopt sustainable practices due to lack of funding, expertise, and standardised reporting, despite ESG being a priority. The industry faces a "survival over sustainability" dilemma, with smaller players having few legal obligations and no immediate financial upside to ESG adoption. To address this, governments, large corporates, and digital financing platforms can provide incentives, tailored lending schemes, and education on ESG tradeoffs to help SMEs transition to more sustainable models.

images.alt_text: Singapore can leverage its deep network of investors – including pro-impact investing family offices – and emerging technology capabilities to contribute to regional impact investing.
Greening the entire economy is said to be key to Singapore's transition to a sustainable economic model - and blended finance will play a crucial role. PHOTO: ST

site_title: ‘Fifa’ publisher EA to cut 6% of workforce, reduce office space
summary: EA, the publisher of FIFA, is cutting 6% of its workforce, approximately 790 employees, and reducing office space. The restructuring is expected to incur $170-200 million in charges. This move follows other tech companies' layoffs amid a potential economic downturn. EA had about 12,900 staff at the end of March last year.

images.alt_text: In May, Take-Two closed its US$11 billion acquisition of Zynga, the company behind popular mobile franchises such as FarmVille.
The first game EA is making is based on Iron Man, a billionaire inventor and superhero who was the subject of one of the first hit Marvel movies, it announced last week.

site_title: Gold ticks down on firmer dollar, easing banking fears
summary: Gold prices fell 0.2% to $1,960.68 per ounce, as the US dollar strengthened and eased concerns about the global banking system. The dollar index rose 0.1%, making gold less affordable for foreign buyers. Market participants await US inflation data for further monetary policy clues, with a 41.2% chance of a 25-basis-point interest rate hike in May. The opportunity cost of holding non-yielding gold increases with rising interest rates, reducing its appeal.

images.alt_text: A worsening and prolonged banking turmoil and sooner-than-expected pivot by the Fed amid persistent fear could set the bullion on a historic surge
Ingots of 99.99 percent pure gold are placed in a workroom at Krastsvetmet precious metals plant in the Siberian city of Krasnoyarsk, Russia, January 31, 2023. REUTERS/Alexander Manzyuk

site_title: Fed official tells US Congress many to blame for Silicon Valley Bank failure
summary: Fed official Michael Barr told US Congress that the failure of Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) was a result of failures by bank management, supervisors, and regulators, including the Federal Reserve and Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC). Depositors withdrew over $42 billion in a single day, catching regulators off-guard. Barr criticized SVB for its lack of a chief risk officer and modeling of interest rate risk, but lawmakers questioned the Fed's response. The Fed and FDIC are expected to produce reports on the failure by May 1, with lawmakers seeking accountability and more aggressive action to prevent similar crises.

images.alt_text: “We must ensure that our bank regulatory policies and supervision are appropriate for the risks and challenges that banks face today,” Nellie Liang (far right), the Treasury undersecretary for domestic finance, said in her testimony to the committee.
The bank failures come as S&P 500 companies are headed for their second straight decline in year-over-year quarterly earnings.
The FDIC reached a similar agreement with NYCB worth as much as US$300 million that would likewise turn a profit if the regulator exercised those rights as of Monday.

site_title: Heeton offers exchange of outstanding 6.8% notes due November 2023
summary: Heeton Holdings is offering holders of its 6.8% fixed-rate notes due November 2023 an exchange option to swap their existing notes for new notes due November 2026, with a higher coupon rate of 7%. The exchange includes a cash top-up of S$20,000 for each S$180,000 in principal amount. The offer is part of Heeton's "prudent capital management strategy" to term out its debt maturity profile, allowing noteholders to remain invested in the group. The invitation period is from March 30 to April 19, with an early exchange deadline of April 14.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Real estate conglomerate Heeton Holdings has appointed former MP Lee Bee Wah as its independent non-executive director.
Heeton warns of FY2020 loss due to Covid-19 pandemic
Heeton Holdings appoints new CEO

site_title: Keppel aims to hit S$200 billion in AUM by 2030
summary: Keppel Corp aims to raise its assets under management (AUM) from S$50 billion to S$200 billion by 2030, focusing on sustainable development and decarbonization. The company plans to invest in digitalization and net-zero solutions for its customers. Three new funds will be launched, including the Keppel Core Infrastructure Fund and the Keppel Sustainable Urban Renewal Fund, with a target size of US$2.5 billion and US$2 billion, respectively. Keppel also plans to achieve half of its electricity usage from renewable energy sources by 2025 and 100% by 2030.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
The subsidiary, Keppel Philippines Properties, and Opon-KE Properties will sell its 50 per cent interest in SM Keppel Land, which owns The Podium West Tower and The Podium Mall.

site_title: FCC proposes rules to reassess foreign-owned US telecom services authority
summary: The FCC proposed new rules to reassess foreign-owned US telecom services authorisations, citing national security concerns. The rules, proposed by FCC chair Jessica Rosenworcel, would require foreign-owned licence holders to undergo a periodic review and renewal process. The move comes after the FCC revoked China Unicom's US unit authorisation in 2022 and banned approvals of new telecommunications equipment from China's Huawei Technologies and ZTE. The reviews would involve close consultation with national security colleagues and aim to ensure the US telecommunications regulator can regularly assess foreign companies' authorisations.

images.alt_text: The new restrictions tied to the Chips Act aim to impose more onerous limitations on companies expected to secure incentives.
“Today spectrum plays a central role in American life in a way that it never did before, from cellphones to aviation safety to weather prediction,” NTIA administrator Alan Davidson said.
Some international airlines have privately expressed reluctance to install filters absent a legal requirement from the FAA, officials told Reuters.

site_title: FDIC hires Newmark to sell US$60 billion of Signature Bank loans
summary: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) has hired Newmark Group to sell approximately $60 billion of Signature Bank loans, following the bank's collapse into receivership. The sales process, expected to take 90 days, will be led by a team at Newmark, excluding loans assumed by New York Community Bancorp. The loans, which total $33.13 billion of Signature's commercial real estate loans at the end of 2022, remain in FDIC receivership pending sale.

site_title: Europe: Banks boost stocks, UBS climbs after naming Ermotti CEO
summary: European stocks rose 1.3% on Wednesday, driven by gains in banking stocks, including UBS, which jumped 3.7% after naming Sergio Ermotti as its new CEO. The Stoxx 600 index was headed for monthly losses but is now on course for quarterly gains. Meanwhile, chipmaker Infineon raised its outlook, and German consumer sentiment is expected to improve in April despite energy prices still being high.

images.alt_text: Worries have surfaced that commercial property could be the next shoe to drop if problems in global banking markets trigger a broader credit crunch for the multi-trillion-dollar sector.

site_title: JPMorgan, Goldman plan to start trading private credit loans
summary: Wall Street banks JPMorgan, Goldman Sachs, and Barclays are planning to start trading private credit loans, a move that could reshape the market. The firms are discussing secondary-market transactions with private debt funds to help direct lenders manage their portfolio mix and free up capital for new deals. However, concerns over increased volatility and potential erosion of yield premiums remain, with some warning that secondary trading could ultimately erode the benefits of private credit over high-yield bonds and leveraged loans.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan, the nation’s largest bank, told all employees they “should never give the appearance of exploiting a situation of stress or uncertainty”.

site_title: Bank of America’s financial planning app draws US$55 billion over two-plus years
summary: Bank of America's digital personal finance tool, Life Plan, has attracted over $55 billion in new money since its 2020 launch. The app, which has 10 million users, allows customers to set financial goals and manage their bank and brokerage accounts. Artificial intelligence has helped the tool gain traction, especially among millennials and Gen-Z users, with 63% of users falling into this age group. The app's virtual assistant, Erica, also saw a surge in usage in 2022, with over 33.5 million client interactions.

images.alt_text: The FDIC reached a similar agreement with NYCB worth as much as US$300 million that would likewise turn a profit if the regulator exercised those rights as of Monday.
JPMorgan, the nation’s largest bank, told all employees they “should never give the appearance of exploiting a situation of stress or uncertainty”.

site_title: Oil dips on profit taking, markets debate supply tightness
summary: Oil prices fell on Wednesday, with Brent crude closing 0.5% lower at $78.28 a barrel and West Texas Intermediate crude falling 0.3% to $72.97, as investors took profits from recent gains and markets debated supply tightness. A surprise drop in US oil stockpiles and a halt to Iraqi Kurdistan oil exports were offset by a smaller-than-expected Russian output cut. The market awaits clarity on the banking crisis and US Federal Reserve's plans for rate hikes, which could impact oil demand.

images.alt_text: Oil prices were expected to draw continued support from signs of recovering demand in China.

site_title: Gold all aglow as it nears historic surge
summary: Gold has recaptured the $2,000 an ounce mark, nearing its historic record high of $2,075 an ounce in August 2020. The metal's ascent is driven by safe-haven flows amid banking turmoil and concerns over a possible "credit crunch" that could hurt global growth. The US Federal Reserve's recent 25 basis point rate hike has sparked uncertainty, but a milder hike or pause could bode well for gold. Demand from central banks and fear of inflation also support the metal's price.

images.alt_text: Gold prices jumped 2 per cent on Wednesday after the Fed raised interest rates.
Oanda senior market analyst Edward Moya notes that Yellen’s comments, coupled with expectations of further Fed rate cuts later this year, have led to a rally in gold prices.

site_title: Evolution in global value chains key for a green and resilient Asean
summary: Asean's economies have shown resilience in recovering from the COVID-19 pandemic, with 5.6% growth in 2022. However, the region's global value chains (GVCs) have been exposed to weaknesses due to the pandemic, Russian invasion, and climate change. To maintain benefits from global trade and resilience, Asean must transform into a technology and knowledge hub, leveraging its young workforce, technology, and innovation to strengthen GVCs and mitigate risks.

images.alt_text: ADB's analysis found that the effect of new environmental elements in bilateral investment treaties is “positive and significant” for total FDI and green FDI.
Asean has much to recommend itself to clean energy investors, but the region’s economic development model remains based on fossil fuels. PHOTO:

site_title: Singapore’s venture boom falters as industry ponders future
summary: Singapore's venture capital industry has experienced a downturn due to a global slowdown, casting a chill over the once-booming sector. The industry's meteoric rise, fueled by relaxed regulations and tax policies, has stalled. The Singapore government's efforts to promote entrepreneurship and startup fundraising have not been enough to counter the market volatility. The industry is now bracing for more collapses and challenges in the year ahead, with players struggling to secure funding.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Generative AI could also boost non-AI startups in the region.

site_title: US: Stocks rise on strength in banks, semiconductor shares
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday, March 29, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 1.0% at 32,717.60. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also advanced, with semiconductor firms leading the gains. Micron jumped 7.2%, Intel surged 7.6%, and Nvidia advanced 2.2%. Regional banks and Lululemon Athletica also saw significant increases. The market's recovery was attributed to the apparent containment of a banking industry crisis and lower volatility in the bond market.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 172.29 points, or 0.53 per cent, at the open to 32,566.54.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, ST Engineering, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, Keppel
summary: DBS' digital services experienced a day-long disruption, prompting the Monetary Authority of Singapore to take "commensurate supervisory actions". ST Engineering secured a US$1.2 billion contract with the Singapore Navy, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding acquired a 21-storey commercial building for S$399 million. Keppel aims to raise its assets under management to S$200 billion by 2030. Global Palm Resources launched an offer to take the company private at S$0.25 per share, and SIA Engineering signed a fresh services agreement with Singapore Airlines.

images.alt_text: Saxo analysts said in a note that banking sector risks may now be abating, but they reckon there will be a “flight of deposits” from smaller banks to larger banks and money markets or other safer or higher interest rate tools.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Thursday’s open; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.1% or 2.45 points to 3,260.09 at 9:01 am on Thursday, bucking the global trend of gains. Banking shares were mixed, with DBS down 0.7% and OCBC down 0.1%, while UOB rose 0.2%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index rose 1%, 1.4%, and 1.8% respectively on Wall Street.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim

Saxo analysts said in a note that banking sector risks may now be abating, but they reckon there will be a “flight of deposits” from smaller banks to larger banks and money markets or other safer or higher interest rate tools.

site_title: K-pop giant Hybe still a winner despite unsuccessful takeover attempt of SM
summary: Hybe Corporation, the management company behind K-pop group BTS, has exited its takeover bid for SM Entertainment after failing to secure a majority stake. Despite this, Hybe now owns an 8.8% stake in SM, giving it significant influence. The company will also partner with SM and Kakao, a South Korean internet giant, for their fan platform businesses, potentially integrating SM artists onto Weverse. This exit reflects Hybe's growth ambitions and its plans to diversify, including acquiring top-tier record labels in the Latin music market and US music brands.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Hybe chairman Bang Si-hyuk says that the company is planning a substantial number of acquisitions and investments this year, as the K-pop giant looks to boost its US presence.

Shares of South Korean entertainment company Hybe Corporation suffered from a US$1.7 billion rout last week after members of Korean pop sensation BTS – managed by Hybe – said they would halt group activities while they focused on individual projects for a while.
The singers said the time apart would be healthy for the band and urged fans not to view the development as negative.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as banking crisis fears ebb
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Wednesday as concerns about a banking crisis eased, lifting risk sentiment and boosting investor expectations for a pause in the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 172.29 points, or 0.53%, to 32,566.54, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher.

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding buys CBD office building for S$399 million to ‘deepen roots in Singapore’
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding acquired 39 Robinson Road, a 21-storey office building in Singapore's central business district, for S$399 million. The purchase aims to deepen the company's roots in Singapore and preserve capital in a highly inflationary environment. Ren Letian, executive chairman and CEO, stated that the acquisition is a "one-off exercise" and the company's focus remains on its core shipbuilding business. A professional real estate manager will be appointed to manage the building and attract institutional investors and family offices.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
Yangzijiang Financial Holding  executive chairman Ren Yuanlin says he remains cautiously optimistic of Yangzijiang Financial’s prospects for 2023.
Yangzijiang Shipping is “dormant”, and its net asset value is “negligible” as compared to the group’s, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding stated in a bourse filing.

site_title: Yen is Wall Street’s favourite trade
summary: Wall Street has shifted its preference to the Japanese yen as a hedge against global economic shocks, driven by the recent banking crises in the US and Switzerland. The yen has surged over 3% in March, with investors betting it will reach 120-125 per dollar in the next 12 months. However, experts warn that the yen's "safe haven status" may not be sustainable, and interest-rate differentials could make it an expensive hedge. The dollar's potential slide is also seen as a counterforce to the yen's rise.

images.alt_text: The sharp appreciation of the US dollar through 2021 and much of last year caused a lot of problems in developed and developing countries alike; they will be thankful for the respite as the value of the greenback eases.

site_title: China Construction Bank Q4 profit rises 8.8%
summary: China Construction Bank (CCB) reported an 8.8% increase in Q4 net profit to 76.6 billion yuan, driven by steady results. The bank warned the country's economic recovery is not yet solid, citing mounting pressures and turmoil in international financial markets. Despite this, CCB's non-performing loan ratio fell to 1.38% and net interest margin narrowed to 2.02%. The bank's full-year profit rose 7.06% to 323.9 billion yuan, beating analyst estimates.

site_title: Keeping inflation at bay, the Swiss way
summary: Switzerland successfully managed inflation by leveraging its strong currency, resilient energy supply, and strict price controls. The country's ability to weather inflation stems from its hydroelectric energy source, which reduces reliance on oil and gas, and its ability to produce much of its food. Singapore can learn from Switzerland's strategies, including maintaining a stable currency, diversifying its energy mix, and increasing labor productivity. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) can also learn from Switzerland's monetary policy approach, which involves managing the exchange rate to maintain price stability.

images.alt_text: Money managers ditched the Swiss franc at the fastest rate in two years last week in the run-up to the dramatic takeover of Credit Suisse by UBS.

The quarterly decision on Thursday (Mar 23) by policymakers led by Thomas Jordan matches that of the European Central Bank, which raised by the same amount last week, and follows Wednesday’s move by the Federal Reserve to hike by a quarter point.

site_title: What’s a good carbon credit? Governance body sets the criteria
summary: The Integrity Council for the Voluntary Carbon Market (ICVCM) has set criteria for "good" carbon credits, requiring them to quantify uncertainty in emissions reductions and identify users of credits. This aims to address overestimation and double-counting issues in the crediting market. The ICVCM's Core Carbon Principles (CCP) and assessment framework will guide the development of credible carbon credits, with part two expected in the second quarter of 2023. The move seeks to enhance the credibility of carbon credits and support efforts to address climate change.

images.alt_text: Survival International has slammed the Northern Kenya Rangelands Carbon Project as making millions from “breaking down” indigenous people’s traditional grazing systems and replacing them with a centrally controlled system more akin to commercial ranching.
An audit team at the Rimba Raya Biodiversity Reserve, in Central Kalimantan, Indonesia.
Generics on sustainability and ESG and climate resilience

site_title: Malaysia and Singapore – a corridor key to Asean’s growing prosperity
summary: Malaysia and Singapore have signed agreements to boost the green and digital economies, highlighting the potential for the two South-east Asian neighbours to collaborate and drive prosperity in the region. The countries contribute nearly a quarter of Asean's total GDP, with a projected combined GDP of $914 billion in 2023 expected to reach $1.15 trillion by 2027. Easier cross-border trade is expected to benefit businesses looking to expand in Malaysia, Singapore, and across the bloc, ultimately benefiting the entire region.

images.alt_text: While it is important to be risk conscious, treasurers need to have tools and processes in place that enable smarter decisions and future growth says Standard Chartered Bank's Peter Wong.

site_title: BOE says global investors’ appetite for risk is falling sharply
summary: The Bank of England warned that global investors are sharply reducing their appetite for risk due to turmoil in the financial system, citing a survey that found over half of respondents expect a "high-impact" event. The central bank also cautioned that private-equity owned and highly-indebted companies may struggle to refinance debts as interest rates rise, particularly in commercial real estate. This marks the BOE's first official assessment of UK financial conditions since the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and Credit Suisse Group.

images.alt_text: Consumer price inflation rose unexpectedly to 10.4 per cent last month, with food and drink costs rising at the fastest rate since 1977.

site_title: Bank of Singapore appoints Ranjit Khanna as global market head of Middle East
summary: Bank of Singapore has appointed Ranjit Khanna as global market head of Middle East and chief executive of its Dubai International Financial Centre (DIFC) branch, effective April 3. Khanna, a 25-year veteran, joins from Union Bancaire Privee, where he led a team of 200 employees across Singapore and Dubai. His appointment comes as the bank sharpens its focus on growing its presence in the Middle East, where the region is expected to see significant wealth growth globally.

images.alt_text: he Dubai Financial Services Authority (DFSA) said the fine on the Dubai International Financial Centre (DIFC) branch of Bank of Singapore was reduced from US$2 million, as the bank had offered the regulator an “enforceable undertaking” to remediate the failings and agreed to settle the matter

To position for 2023, analysts The Business Times spoke to recommended plays on interest rate movements as well as China’s reopening. But they also advised caution as there are still plenty of risks looming.

site_title: US dollar soothed by uneasy market calm
summary: The US dollar rose 0.7% to a one-week high against the yen, steadying against major peers after recent declines. The dollar index was flat at 102.42, while the euro and sterling were up slightly. Experts attribute the calm market to a return to normalcy, but warn that the market is testing for weak points and may see a shift away from safe-haven currencies.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. Dollar banknotes are seen in this illustration taken July 17, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Retail sales growth in US expected to slow, trade group says
summary: US retail sales are expected to grow between 4% and 6% by the end of 2023, reaching $5.13-$5.23 trillion, according to the National Retail Federation. This represents a slowdown from 2022's 7% growth. Despite this, the forecast remains above the pre-pandemic average annual retail sales growth rate of 3.6%. Online sales are expected to grow 10-12%, while brick-and-mortar stores account for 70% of total retail sales. The forecast comes with caveats, including signs of a cooling labor market and increasing consumer reliance on credit.

site_title: Saudi Arabia’s First Mills seeks US$1 billion value in IPO
summary: Saudi Arabia's First Mills is planning an initial public offering (IPO) on the local stock exchange, aiming to value the company at up to US$1 billion. Founded in 2017, First Mills produces 850,000 tonnes of flour annually and is owned by investors including Saudi Arabia's Almutlaq Group and the United Arab Emirates' Essa Al-Ghurair Investment. The company has appointed SNB Capital as its financial adviser and is seeking regulatory approval for the offering of a 30% stake within weeks.

site_title: Penang attracting investors’ interest; property and investment markets are abuzz
summary: Penang's property market is experiencing significant growth, with 17,297 properties worth RM9.5 billion changing hands in the first nine months of 2022, a 44% year-on-year increase in transactions and a 31.5% increase in transaction value. Analysts attribute this surge to increasing interest from both local and overseas buyers, driven by Penang's transformation into the "Silicon Island of the East."

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng
Kuala Lumpur, the capital city of Malaysia, continued to achieve a high hotel occupancy rate of over 60 per cent in February this year.
Malaysia has registered 188,002 property transactions worth RM84.4 billion in the first 6 months this year, a year-on-year increase of 34.5 per cent in volume and 36.1 per cent in value.

site_title: Freeport Indonesia gets govt recommendation to ship 2.3 million tonnes copper concentrate before June ban
summary: Freeport Indonesia has received a government recommendation to export 2.3 million tonnes of copper concentrate until June, as Indonesia plans to ban raw mineral exports from June to promote domestic processing. The company is building a $3 billion processing facility in East Java with a capacity of 1.7 million tonnes, expected to start operations in 2024. A permit from the trade ministry is still required for the exports.

site_title: Growing love for electric SUVs tripled India’s lagging EV sales
summary: India's electric vehicle sales tripled to 49,800 units last year, driven by demand for affordable, compact electric SUVs. The growth is attributed to ride-sharing startups and foreign carmakers, such as Warren Buffett-backed BYD, which aims to capture 40% of the Indian EV market by 2030. Homegrown manufacturers like Tata Motors and Maruti Suzuki India are also increasing investments in EVs, with plans to build 593 charging stations on highways and expressways to alleviate range anxiety.

images.alt_text: Uber has set a 2040 target for 100 per cent of its rides to be in zero-emission vehicles, public transport or with micro-mobility, including in India.

site_title: Geely to include eight Chinese powertrain plants in Renault JV: sources
summary: Geely will include eight Chinese powertrain plants and one in Sweden in its joint venture with Renault and Saudi Aramco, called "Horse," to develop more efficient petrol engines and hybrid systems. The goal is to become a leading supplier of combustion and hybrid engines by the end of 2023, with 19,000 workers and 15 billion euros in annual revenue. Geely will contribute eight plants, while Renault will bring three R&D centers and Saudi Aramco will provide know-how on e-fuels and hydrogen.

site_title: Champagne is outperforming gold and the S&P 500. Here’s what to buy
summary: Champagne outperforms gold and the S&P 500, with some vintages increasing in value by over 200%. Iconic brands like Dom Perignon and Krug continue to attract investors, driven by luxury appeal and rarity. Grower champagnes, such as Jacques Selosse and Cédric Bouchard, are also gaining popularity. Experts predict continued strong demand, with prices potentially leveling out for premium names like Salon and increasing for undervalued brands. Recommended investments include 2008 Dom Perignon, 2006 Krug, and 2012 Louis Roederer Cristal.

site_title: Enterprise Singapore deputy CEO to helm Workforce Singapore as its chief moves to Tote Board
summary: Dilys Boey, deputy CEO of Enterprise Singapore, will take over as chief executive of Workforce Singapore on July 1, replacing Tan Choon Shian. Boey has over 25 years of experience in management consulting and corporate development, previously leading the people consulting practice at EY. Tan, who led WSG for six years, will succeed Fong Yong Kian as CEO of the Tote Board. The changes were announced by the Ministry of Manpower and Ministry of Finance.

images.alt_text: 40,000 locals have benefitted from Career Conversion Programmes since 2016
In the autonomous universities, annual enrolment in accountancy degree programmes has fallen to 5,182 in 2021, down from 5,650 in 2017.

site_title: What’s better than OpenAI? Developers shop for alternatives
summary: Artificial intelligence startup Tome has shifted from relying on OpenAI's GPT-3 model to combining it with models from Anthropic and Stable Diffusion. The move is part of a growing trend among developers to reduce reliance on a single AI model provider, driven by concerns over cost, reliability, and the need for specialized models tailored to specific tasks. As the market for generative AI is expected to reach $98.1 billion by 2026, multiple startups and investors are embracing competitors to OpenAI, casting a shadow on the company's dominance in the field.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk, whose carmaker Tesla is using AI for an autopilot system, has been vocal about his concerns about AI.
Mainland China computer, communications equipment and media indexes have surged between 29 per cent and 35 per cent this year, outstripping a rise of just 3.5 per cent in the benchmark CSI 300 Index.
Cybersecurity experts warn that the increasing use of AI-powered technology could facilitate the work of scammers and cybercrime syndicates.

site_title: US pending home sales unexpectedly rise to highest since August
summary: US pending home sales rose 0.8% in February to 83.2, the highest since August, indicating a possible stabilization of the housing market after last year's rapid increase in borrowing costs. This increase contrasts with economists' expectations of a 3% decline. Mortgage rates eased to a six-week low, driving demand for home purchases. The housing sector's contraction appears to be ending, according to NAR's chief economist, Lawrence Yun.

images.alt_text: Prices have continued to soften as seller discounts become more common in a market where buyer demand has been sagging for months.

site_title: 'Lily Savage', UK star who made drag mainstream, dies at 67
summary: UK comedian and entertainer Paul O'Grady, best known for his alter ego Lily Savage, has died at 67. O'Grady made drag culture mainstream with his character and went on to present various TV shows, including "For the Love of Dogs." He was a campaigner for LGBTQ+ rights and animal welfare, and received tributes from the British royal family, lawmakers, and celebrities, including Elton John. O'Grady won numerous awards, including a TV Bafta, and was honored by Queen Elizabeth II in 2008.

images.alt_text: Jennifer Aniston and Adam Sandler play a married couple in the 2019 Netflix film 'Murder Mystery' and its sequel, which begins streaming on Friday.

site_title: Astronomers discover one of the biggest black holes ever recorded
summary: Astronomers have discovered one of the largest black holes ever recorded, weighing over 30 billion times the mass of the Sun. The ultramassive black hole was detected using a new technique called gravitational lensing, which magnifies and bends light from a distant galaxy. This technique could help spot thousands more black holes in the coming years, offering a breakthrough in understanding these celestial monsters.

images.alt_text: The burst of gamma-rays – the most intense form of electromagnetic radiation – was first detected by orbiting telescopes on Oct 9.

site_title: For US$74,000, you can go on the ultimate James Bond vacation
summary: Black Tomato has partnered with Eon to offer a James Bond-themed vacation for $74,000, with only 60 spots available. The 5-night trips include activities such as skiing, yacht tours, and private training sessions with stunt doubles, as well as exclusive access to filming locations and interactions with actors. A 12-night journey, "The Assignment," is also available for $60,000, featuring glamorous jet travel to Bond locations in Europe. The trips are the culmination of a years-long collaboration with Eon, who approached Black Tomato due to their success in recreating literary and cinematic journeys.

site_title: Rare pink diamond goes to auction for more than US$35 million
summary: A 10.57-carat, cushion-cut pink diamond called The Eternal Pink is set to auction for over $35 million at Sotheby's in New York, potentially breaking records for the most expensive price per carat. The "Fancy Vivid" diamond, considered "glowing" and "Internally Flawless," has the highest ranking for color and clarity, making it comparable to art masterpieces. Mined in Botswana and crafted in the US, The Eternal Pink's estimated price per carat is $3.3 million, challenging the record set by The Williamson Pink Star in 2022.

images.alt_text: At 18.18 carats, the Fortune Pink diamond is the largest pear-shaped “fancy vivid pink” diamond ever sold under the hammer, Christie’s auction house said.

site_title: Vietnam’s Vincom Retail in stake sale talks with strategic investors: sources
summary: Vietnam's largest conglomerate, Vingroup, is in talks to sell a stake in its shopping mall arm, Vincom Retail, to strategic investors, including Thailand's Central Group. Vincom Retail, valued at $2.8 billion, would be one of the largest M&A transactions in Vietnam in recent years. The move comes as Vingroup seeks to develop its loss-making electric vehicle car maker, VinFast, and expand in the US. Discussions with potential buyers are ongoing, with no final decision yet made.

site_title: Investors pull US$1.6 billion from Binance after CFTC lawsuit
summary: US investors pulled US$1.6 billion from Binance, a cryptocurrency exchange, after the US CFTC sued the company on Monday, alleging it operated an "illegal" exchange and a "sham" compliance program. Since the lawsuit, Binance has seen US$1.6 billion in overall withdrawals, with US$852 million in the last 24 hours. This marks a significant increase from the average daily withdrawals of US$385 million over the past two weeks.

site_title: Philippines’ Duterte ready to ‘face the music’ as ICC forges ahead with probe
summary: Former Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has publicly stated he is ready to "face the music" as the International Criminal Court (ICC) continues its investigation into thousands of killings during his presidency. Duterte, who campaigned on a promise to kill drug dealers, is being investigated for possible crimes against humanity. He claims to have done what was necessary, despite thousands of drug users and alleged dealers being killed during his "war on drugs." The ICC has rejected the Philippines' request to suspend the probe, and Duterte has joked he will likely be dead by 80, preventing the ICC from prosecuting him.

images.alt_text:

But analysts say he is unlikely to face charges after he steps down on June 30, 2022. site_title: UBS brings back Ermotti as CEO to oversee Credit Suisse deal
summary: UBS is bringing back Sergio Ermotti as CEO to oversee the acquisition of Credit Suisse Group, replacing Ralph Hamers after just over two years. Ermotti, 62, will take over after the annual general meeting next week and will focus on navigating the complex integration. He has previous experience in crisis and restructuring, having steered UBS through a rogue trader crisis and revamped the bank's governance policies. UBS shares rose 3% after the announcement, and Hamers will stay at the bank for a transition period.

images.alt_text: UBS’ acquisition of Credit Suisse will provide an opportunity for foreign banks to expand into Swiss corporate finance.

site_title: UK mortgage approvals rise in sign of stability returning
summary: UK mortgage approvals rose 4,900 to 43,500 in February, exceeding forecasts and signaling a stabilization in the housing market. This increase follows a decline in January, the first since August, and suggests improving consumer confidence and resilience in the labour market. Mortgage rates rose 36 basis points to 4.24%, but the housing market is still expected to fall on balance this year.

images.alt_text: The CBI’s expected sales balance for April increased to +9 from -18 in March.
Firms across the two sectors were more optimistic about their prospects over the next 12 months, with the degree of confidence hitting its highest since March 2022.
The supply of property coming on the market is expected to rise by about 2.5 per cent in the April-June period.

site_title: ComfortDelGro to appoint new chairman and deputy chairman in April
summary: ComfortDelGro is set to appoint Mark Christopher Greaves as chairman and Choi Shing Kwok as deputy chairman in April, replacing outgoing chairman Lim Jit Poh, who will retire on April 28. Greaves, 66, is an independent director with experience in audit and risk management, while Choi, 64, is an independent director with a background in engineering and a former senior civil servant. The appointments are contingent on their re-election as directors at the group's next annual general meeting.

images.alt_text: Generic pictures of SGX
ComfortDelGro logo at the ComfortDelGro headquarters located along Braddell Road on March 6, 2023.

site_title: SIA Engineering signs fresh S$1.14 billion services agreement with SIA
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) signed a fresh S$1.14 billion services agreement with Singapore Airlines, starting on April 1, 2023, for a two-year term. The new deal supersedes the previous one entered in 2019 and is expected to yield SIAEC a labour revenue of S$1.14 billion over three years. The agreement does not significantly impact SIAEC's net tangible asset per share or earnings per share. SIAEC shares rose 0.9% on the news.

site_title: Japan PM Kishida sets eye on wage rises as focus of ‘new capitalism’
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has announced plans to implement "new capitalism" focusing on wage increases, innovation, and social problem-solving through startup support. The plan aims to narrow wage gaps between domestic firms and overseas rivals by June. Kishida places human capital investment at the core of his growth strategy, addressing Japan's acute labor crunch due to an aging population. This follows major companies agreeing to 3.8% average wage increases, the largest in about three decades, in response to Kishida's pressure.

images.alt_text: The working age population is expected to rapidly decline from 2027, according to the study by independent think-tank Recruit Works Institute.

site_title: Fitch says two Adani entities face contagion risks
summary: Fitch Ratings has downgraded Adani Transmission and Adani Ports and Special Economic Zone to 'BBB-/Stable' due to concerns over weak governance within the Adani Group and potential contagion risks. The downgrade comes amid allegations of improper tax use and stock manipulation by Hindenburg Research, which the conglomerate has denied. The rating agency has capped these entities at their current rating level until concerns are resolved.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Condo rental prices rose 3.5% in February, a steeper increase than the 1.4% rise in January, according to flash estimates from SRX and 99.co. Meanwhile, the Singapore Savings Bond saw a rise in applications, exceeding the available amount, after months of falling demand. Global Palm Resources launched a privatization offer at S$0.25 per share, and Sembmarine clarified that preliminary administrative proceedings against one of its subsidiaries are related to past conduct linked to an ongoing probe into money laundering and graft activities.

site_title: Second Chance Properties’ H1 net profit doubles on sale of investment properties
summary: Second Chance Properties' net profit for the first half of 2023 doubled to S$9.2 million due to a gain of S$4.33 million from the sale of investment properties. This came at the cost of a 29.4% drop in rental revenue and a 10.9% drop in revenue from its gold business segment. The company reported a negative working capital of S$40.4 million and has decided not to declare a dividend for the half-year period. Its gold business is expected to remain profitable and operate in company-owned premises.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
nzsecond - Second Chance Properties Net Profit fell 6 per cent to $3.53m

site_title: Adidas drops Black Lives Matter trademark opposition
summary: Adidas is withdrawing its opposition to a Black Lives Matter trademark application, citing the process is already underway. The company initially objected to a three-stripe design similar to its logo being used on clothing and other items by the Black Lives Matter Global Network Foundation. The decision may have avoided potential misinterpretation of Adidas' stance on the anti-racism movement. The trademark application was filed in 2021, and the US Trademark Office had yet to make a decision.

images.alt_text: The partnership between Adidas and Beyoncé is set to end later this year after another round of merchandise from the Ivy Park line hits market,  according to the WSJ.

site_title: Chatbot dreams drive frenzied tech rally in China
summary: China's tech, media, and telecom shares have surged 29-35% this year, outpacing the benchmark CSI 300 Index's 3.5% rise. Investors are betting on chatbot development, driving record trading volume and inflows into TMT-focused funds. However, analysts warn of potential instability and market distortion, citing concerns over the sector's fundamentals and the "syphon effect" of speculative bets. Despite the frenzy, some believe winners will emerge, while others predict a "washout" before the market settles.

site_title: China's CNOOC reports record 2022 profits, double previous year
summary: China's state-controlled oil and gas company CNOOC reported a record 2022 net profit of 141.7 billion yuan, more than doubling its previous year's figure. Total oil and gas output rose 8.9% to 624 million barrels of oil equivalent, with a target of 650-660 million barrels for this year. CNOOC aims for 6% average annual production growth by 2025, when output is forecast to reach 2 million barrels per day. The company's all-in production cost decreased to $30.39 per barrel in 2022.

images.alt_text: Cnooc is one of the largest remaining international explorers in the North Sea.

site_title: The only cure for the bank-run contagion is time, but the damage is already done
summary: A banking crisis has highlighted the financial system's vulnerability to periodic bouts of primal fear, similar to the 2008 global financial crisis. The crisis began with Silicon Valley Bank's collapse due to over-allotment of reserves to long-term Treasuries, which plummeted in value due to the US Federal Reserve's interest-rate hikes. The digitisation of banking accelerated the spread of panic, with bank runs and deposit withdrawals reaching unprecedented levels. While time may be the only cure for bank-run contagion, the series of runs may have already done economic damage, with the probability of a 2008 pre-Lehman recession being high.

images.alt_text: Attention of Credit Suisse AT1 bondholders may turn to whether the bank's management could be seen to be responsible for the current situation.
The Swiss bank first sold this form of notes in 2016 as a way of reducing the capital it was required to hold against operational risk.

site_title: China Life profit falls 37% on stock market slump, Covid impacts
summary: China Life Insurance reported a 37% drop in net income to 32.1 billion yuan (S$6.2 billion) due to a stock market slump and economic slowdown. The decline was attributed to Covid lockdowns and outbreaks that hampered sales. The nation's largest life insurer also faced challenges in its first year under chairman Bai Tao, who sought to shift to higher-margin, long-term products. The profit drop comes as the company navigates a probe into its predecessor's tenure.

site_title: Vietnam Q1 growth slows due to shrinking exports amid weaker demand
summary: Vietnam's economy grew at a slower pace in Q1 2023 due to shrinking exports amid weaker global demand. The country's GDP expanded by 3.32% in the first quarter, down from 5.92% in the previous quarter and 5.02% in Q1 2022. Exports declined 11.9% year-over-year, with a significant drop in smartphone and electronics shipments. Industrial production also contracted 2.2% year-over-year, but analysts expect a revival in the second quarter. The government aims to cap inflation at 4.5% and has cut interest rates to boost economic growth.

images.alt_text: This picture taken on December 2, 2022 shows employees working inside a packaging factory of Nam Thai Son Group in Ho Chi Minh City. - Almost half a million workers have been forced to work fewer hours as orders fall in the Southeast Asian country, one of the world's largest exporters of clothing, footwear and furniture. The cost-of-living crisis in Europe and the United States -- major markets for Vietnamese-produced goods -- has seen the buying power of Western shoppers take a dive. (Photo by Nhac NGUYEN / AFP) / To go with AFP Focus 'Vietnam-Economy-Labour' by Tran Thi Minh Ha

site_title: Google scores partial victory in Android antitrust case in India
summary: An Indian appeals tribunal partially upheld the Competition Commission of India's (CCI) findings against Google, ruling the company liable for anti-competitive conduct and ordering a $161 million fine. The tribunal quashed four of the 10 antitrust remedies, allowing Google to avoid restrictions on hosting third-party app stores. This decision provides relief for Google after the Indian Supreme Court refused to suspend the remedies in January. The ruling is seen as less sweeping than the European Commission's 2018 ruling against Android.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man walks past the sign of "Google for India", the company's annual technology event in New Delhi, India, September 19, 2019. REUTERS/Sankalp Phartiyal/File Photo

site_title: ECB says more hikes needed if bank stress stays contained
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) will need to increase interest rates further if recent financial stress in the system remains contained, according to chief economist Philip Lane. Lane stated that if financial stress is "non-zero, but fairly limited," interest rates will still need to rise. However, if the stress becomes stronger, the ECB will reassess its next move. This comes as the ECB recently hiked interest rates by a half point earlier this month, and hawkish policymakers are calling for further tightening to address inflation and financial stability.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen outside the European Central Bank (ECB) building, in Frankfurt, Germany, July 21, 2022. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo

site_title: Alibaba split-up plan boosts Hong Kong stock market; China edges up
summary: Hong Kong-listed Alibaba surged 12.2% after announcing a plan to split into six units and explore fundraisings or listings, boosting optimism that Beijing's crackdown on the tech sector may be ending. The company's restructuring plan, which is the largest in its 24-year history, lifted the Hang Seng Tech Index and Hang Seng benchmark, while also sending shares of other major internet firms like Tencent, Meituan, and JD.Com up. China's CSI 300 benchmark edged up 0.2% as investors await more data on the country's economic recovery.

images.alt_text: The refurbished Hong Kong Stock Exchange in Hong Kong, China, on Friday, June 24, 2022. Hong Kong dusted off the gong for the city's first in-person listing ceremony in two years. Photographer: Bertha Wang/Bloomberg

site_title: Singapore shares track higher on Wednesday, STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.2% to 3,262.54, driven by gains in the banking sector, with Jardine Cycle and Carriage and Sats being top advancers. Saxo analysts note that banking sector risks may be easing, but could lead to a "flight of deposits" to safer tools, potentially crippling economic momentum.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., March 15, 2023. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly
Uma Devi

site_title: Apple launches K-Pop offensive in Samsung’s home turf of South Korea
summary: Apple has launched a K-pop promotion in South Korea, the home turf of rival Samsung, with the goal of boosting spending post-Covid. The company opened its fifth store in Seoul's Gangnam district and set up a pop-up studio featuring exclusive spatial audio of NewJeans's hit song OMG. This move is part of Apple's broader strategy to ramp up its presence in Asia's key growth markets, with plans to open more stores in South Korea and other countries, including Malaysia and India. The use of K-pop artist collaborations is a common tactic employed by tech companies to fuel demand among loyal fans.

site_title: DBS’ digital services disruption on Wednesday ‘unacceptable’: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has criticized DBS for a day-long disruption to its digital services on Wednesday, describing it as "unacceptable". The bank had apologized for the inconvenience and promised to conduct a thorough investigation. MAS has instructed DBS to take "commensurate supervisory actions" and will review the bank's IT systems to ensure high system availability. The disruption comes after a similar incident in November 2021, resulting in additional capital requirements for DBS.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo of DBS is pictured outside an office in Singapore January 5, 2016.  REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo  GLOBAL BUSINESS WEEK AHEAD

site_title: Taiwan’s president defiant after China threatens retaliation for US trip
summary: Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen departed for the US, defying China's threat of retaliation for meeting US House Speaker Kevin McCarthy. Tsai stated she would not be swayed by external pressure, vowing to promote Taiwan's "road of freedom and democracy" as it engages with the world. China has warned against any US support for Taiwan, viewing it as a challenge to its sovereignty claims. The US says Tsai's transits are routine and that China should not use them as a pretext for aggressive actions.

images.alt_text: epa10548302 Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen waves during her departure for Central America, inside Taoyuan International Airport, in Taoyuan, Taiwan, 29 March 2023. Tsai embarks on a journey to diplomatic allies Guatemala and Belize, with earlier stops in New York and Los Angeles.  EPA-EFE/RITCHIE B. TONGO

site_title: Why investing in women is key for a greener future
summary: Investing in women is crucial for a greener future, as they play a vital role in shaping markets and societies. Research shows that firms with greater gender diversity reduce carbon emissions by 5% and banks with more women on their boards direct more finance towards sustainable investments. However, women face barriers to participating in the green economy, with 85% of women-owned businesses remaining unserved or underserved financially. Integrating gender into finance is not a trade-off, but a trade-up, and companies are beginning to take note, with over 70,000 women entrepreneurs receiving financial support. This approach aims to address gender disparities and promote inclusive economic growth during the transition to net-zero economies.

images.alt_text: Gender diversity. Covid-19 has impacted employees across all levels; and the best leaders are those who have adapted leadership and communication styles to show empathy and forge closer bonds with their workforce.

site_title: Spotlight on watches
summary: The Watches & Wonders Geneva, the largest watch show of the year, has begun with over 50 brands participating. The event features dazzling booths and show-stopping timepieces, with celebrity appearances by Julia Roberts, David Beckham, and Roger Federer. The trade fair runs until April 1, offering a glimpse into the latest watch releases. Recent notable watch-related events include Vacheron Constantin's 270th anniversary celebration, Franck Muller, Hublot, and Jaeger-LeCoultre's Year of the Snake celebrations, and Bvlgari's stellar year in the luxury market.

site_title: Japan to face 11 million worker shortfall by 2040, study finds
summary: Japan is expected to face a worker shortfall of over 11 million by 2040, according to a study by the Recruit Works Institute. The working-age population is expected to decline rapidly from 2027, shrinking by 20% to 59.8 million by 2040. Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has pledged 1 trillion yen to train workers for high-skilled jobs, but experts warn that boosting immigration may not be a viable solution in the long-term. Labor shortages are likely to become acute in sectors like transportation, construction, and healthcare, exacerbating Japan's aging population crisis.

site_title: T-Rex skeleton on show in Zurich before auction
summary: A nearly complete 3.9-metre Tyrannosaurus-Rex skeleton, dubbed Trinity, is set to go under the hammer at a Zurich auction house on April 18. The 67-million-year-old skeleton, made up of bone material from three T-Rex specimens, has been mounted in a concert hall for public display. Estimated to fetch between $6.5 million and $8.7 million, experts believe the true value could be higher. The skeleton, assembled from a combination of original bones and replicas, will be sold by a private individual, raising concerns about the trade's impact on scientific research and preservation.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - In this photograph taken in Zurich on March 28, 2023, Yolanda Schicker-Siber (L) takes part in the installation of 'Trinity' a Tyrannosaurus-Rex skeleton dating back 67-million years which will be auctioned in Switzerland on April 18, 2023, marking the first such sale in Europe. - Towering 3.9 metres (12.8 feet) in the air, the skeleton dubbed Trinity skeleton is made up of bone material from three T-Rex specimens, has been valued at between six to eight million Swiss francs ($6.5-8.7 million), according to the auction catalogue. (Photo by ARND WIEGMANN / AFP)

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Wednesday’s open; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.2% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dropping 7.66 points to 3,247.88. The market saw a slight imbalance, with 59 gainers and 45 losers, despite 82.1 million securities changing hands worth S$58.9 million. The decline follows the overnight US market close, where stocks ended lower.

images.alt_text: ST20230303_202311925234 Kua Chee Siong/ pixgeneric/ Generic pix of the SGX logo at SGX Centre 1 located along Shenton Way on March 3, 2023.
Jessie Lim

site_title: SK Hynix to seek further exemption from US chip curbs against China
summary: SK Hynix, the world's No 2 memory chip maker, plans to build an advanced chip packaging plant in the US, despite US curbs on chip exports to China. The company will seek a one-year exemption from the curbs after the current period ends in October. CEO Park Jung-ho said talks with the US government are expected to go well, and the company will apply for an extension when the authorisation expires. SK Hynix had previously received a one-year exemption to supply equipment to China.

images.alt_text: Employees walk past the logo of SK Hynix at its headquarters in Seongnam, South Korea, April 25, 2016. REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji

site_title: Malaysia may hike interest rate if high inflation persists: central bank
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara, may consider adjusting its benchmark interest rate if inflation persists, despite keeping it unchanged at 2.75% for two meetings this year. Governor Nor Shamsiah Mohd Yunus said the monetary policy aims to ensure price stability and sustainable growth, with inflation expected to moderate but stay elevated for the rest of the year. The central bank projects 2.8-3.8% inflation and 4-5% GDP growth in 2023.

images.alt_text: Bank Negara governor Nor Shamsiah Mohd Yunus said the monetary policy remains focussed on ensuring price stability in support of sustainable growth.
The headquarters of Bank Negara Malaysia in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: Thailand sticks to quarter-point rate hike to tame inflation
summary: The Bank of Thailand's monetary policy committee unanimously raised the one-day repurchase rate by 25 basis points to 1.75%, marking the fifth consecutive rate hike to combat inflation. The decision prioritizes inflation control amid a steady economic recovery, as policymakers aim to maintain growth while keeping prices in check. The move aligns with a Bloomberg survey that 19 out of 22 economists expected the rate hike.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Thailand's Central Bank Governor Veerathai Santiprabhob poses with the Bank of Thailand logo after an interview with Reuters in Bangkok, Thailand, August 5, 2016.  REUTERS/Chaiwat Subprasom/File Photo

site_title: Volare’s partial offer for Sabana Reit closes with need to scale back acceptances
summary: Volare Group's partial offer to acquire an additional 10% of Sabana Industrial Real Estate Industrial Trust (Sabana Reit) at S$0.465 per unit closed on March 24, with valid acceptances representing 27.7% of issued units. The offeror can only acquire 109,612,132 units, with excess units accepted on a prorated basis. This follows a previous announcement that the offer had turned unconditional. The acquisition aims to diversify Volare's business and build its real estate portfolio.

images.alt_text: A six-storey industrial building with a ground level carpark. 151 Lorong Chuan, New Tech Park, Singapore 556741.
Michelle Zhu

site_title: The US dollar’s coming slide will be welcomed by the world
summary: The US dollar is expected to weaken as the Federal Reserve changes its monetary policy stance, easing the pressure on currencies worldwide. The Fed's shift in interest rate hikes and doubts about a recession will reduce the dollar's influence, allowing other currencies to strengthen. The euro has gained 12.5% against the dollar in the past six months, while sterling and the Japanese yen have also performed well. The dollar's decline is seen as a welcome relief for countries that struggled with high interest rates, and is expected to correct the "dollar smile" imbalance that skewed in favor of the US currency.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. Dollar banknotes are seen in this illustration taken July 17, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Demand rises for latest Singapore Savings Bond with 10-year average return at 3.15%
summary: The latest Singapore Savings Bond (SSB) tranche, set to mature in 10 years, received a record-breaking S$758.1 million in applications, exceeding the offered amount of S$700 million. The April tranche offers a 10-year average return of 3.15% and a first-year interest rate of 3.01%. This marks a significant increase from previous tranches, which saw declining demand due to falling yields. The auction closed amid global banking turmoil, with higher demand attributed to the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and Credit Suisse.

images.alt_text: A staff counts Singapore dollar currency notes at a money changer booth at Raffles Place financial business district in Singapore on October 6, 2022. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)
Tan Nai Lun

site_title: China’s factory activity likely expanded at a slower pace in March: Reuters poll
summary: China's factory activity likely expanded at a slower pace in March, according to a Reuters poll. The official manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI) is expected to slow to 51.5, down from 52.6 in February. This suggests an uneven economic recovery amid weak global demand and a property slump. The country's GDP growth is expected to slow, adding pressure on policymakers to meet a modest annual growth target of around 5% this year.

site_title: Ivy League prices are pushing US$90,000 a year
summary: The annual tuition and fees for Ivy League schools are nearing US$90,000, with some schools already surpassing the US$80,000 mark. Yale University, for example, broke the US$80,000 barrier in 2022, while Brown University's cost of attendance is almost US$85,000. Despite financial aid covering around 50% of students, the rising costs pose a challenge, with economist Beth Akers stating that "at some point, that math stops working out" and degrees may no longer be worth the cost.

images.alt_text: The idea is to teach kids about the technology, its limits and promise, and prepare them for jobs where they’ll need to use AI.
The bond-free scholarship, funded by the SPH Foundation, was set up in 2006 under the suggestion of the late Lim Kim San.

site_title: Lower fuel costs nudging South-east Asia consumers to switch to EVs: Deloitte
summary: A new Deloitte study found that lower fuel costs, perceptions of a better driving experience, and less maintenance required are the top motivators for South-east Asian consumers to switch to electric vehicles (EVs). Climate change concerns are not a top motivator, despite government messaging. The shift towards EVs is happening most quickly in Singapore, where hybrid EVs are in high demand, and consumers are willing to wait longer for their vehicles. However, concerns about charging infrastructure remain, particularly in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Generic photo of vehicles being charged at a Electric Vehicle (EV) charging station on Aug 5, 2022. Can be used for future Electric Vehicles, cars, vans/commercial vehicles and charging stories.
Vivienne Tay

site_title: A fellowship where one learns to marry social and business objectives
summary: David Ebenezer Toh, CEO of The Ebenex Group, launched Roxy Rockstars, a 3-day train-and-place programme for youth aged 18-35, to equip them with skills for careers in the events industry. The programme is a collaboration between The Ebenex Group and various organizations, including mining company BHP, to deliver cost-effective events that benefit social welfare groups. The programme is part of the Company of Good (COG) Fellowship, a talent development programme that aims to bring about change that benefits both business and society. Through the programme, Toh and other participants have learned to think about how to transform their companies systematically and holistically, from being profit-driven to being purpose-driven.

images.alt_text: Companies deliver value to all stakeholders by doing more in the people, society, governance, economic and environment areas.
Companies must work to make a difference in the society, and this begins with having a corporate purpose.

site_title: Alibaba 5x short DLCs suspended briefly on SGX as shares jump over 15%
summary: Alibaba's 5x short daily leveraged certificates (DLCs) on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) were suspended briefly after shares jumped 15.3% in Hong Kong and 14.3% on the New York Stock Exchange. Trading halted for 30-45 minutes due to the airbag mechanism triggered by the significant price movement. Alibaba shares rose to HK$97 in Hong Kong and US$98.40 on the NYSE.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Alibaba Group is seen lit up at its office building in Beijing, China August 9, 2021. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo
Yong Hui Ting

site_title: Climb Central keeps a foothold in the crowded rock-climbing market
summary: Climb Asia, the owner of Climb Central, a Singapore-based indoor climbing gym chain, faces a tough year ahead due to declining demand from its COVID-19 peak. The oversaturated market with over 40 climbing gyms has led to a decrease in new participants and a loss of existing ones. Climb Central's revenue has not recovered to pre-pandemic levels, with its flagship outlet recording $1.1 million and $1.3 million in 2021 and 2020, respectively. The company is focusing on existing gyms and resuming community engagement activities to stabilize and recover.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
