site_title: Hong Kong art market hits pre-pandemic highs despite curbs
summary: Hong Kong's art market has rebounded to pre-pandemic levels, with over 86,000 visitors and reported sales of more than $98 million at the recent Art Basel fair. This reflects the city's return to its status as a hub for the Asian art market. Despite the national security law, which has impacted free speech, the market has shown resilience. Foreign artists and collectors have taken advantage of Hong Kong's market, and auction houses remain confident in the city's position. The market's growth is attributed to its well-structured market, lack of customs duties, and value-added taxes, making it an attractive destination for collectors.

site_title: Saudi’s China refinery deal covers crude oil storage and petrochemical supplies
summary: Saudi Aramco has agreed to a 20-year crude supply deal with Chinese chemical group Rongsheng Petrochemical, controlling owner of Zhejiang Petrochemical Corp, and will purchase a 10% stake in the company. The deal includes agreements on crude oil storage in eastern China's Zhoushan port, with ZPC providing 18.6 million barrels of storage space. Aramco will also supply Rongsheng with petrochemical feedstocks and receive plastics and petrochemicals in return, as part of a 20-year partnership.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Saudi Aramco logo is pictured at the oil facility in Abqaiq, Saudi Arabia October 12, 2019. REUTERS/Maxim Shemetov/File Photo

site_title: Barclays CEO calls cutting emissions ‘defining’ issue for banks
summary: Barclays CEO CS Venkatakrishnan emphasized the need for banks to reduce high-emissions activities as the world shifts towards a low-carbon economy. He stated that banks play a crucial role in promoting this shift, and that cutting emissions is one of today's "defining issues." The company aims to cut its carbon footprint and reduce financing for high-emitting industries, with a goal of being a "net-zero" bank by 2050.

images.alt_text: A circular economy would motivate recycling and reusing products, rather than wasting them and drawing on new resources.
The EU law will require all new cars sold to have zero CO2 emissions from 2035, and 55 per cent lower CO2 emissions from 2030, versus 2021 levels.

site_title: Irish house prices set for worst first quarter in a decade
summary: Ireland's house prices recorded their worst first quarter in a decade, with asking prices falling 0.3% from the previous quarter. This marks the first time since 2013 that prices fell at the beginning of a year. Higher interest rates have made financing more expensive, contributing to the decline. Experts expect a "modest" decline of less than 5% over the next three to six months, but some predict house prices may still increase modestly unless interest rates continue to rise.

site_title: GlobalData estimates value of ST Engineering’s naval contract at US$1.2 billion
summary: ST Engineering wins a US$1.2 billion contract to construct six military vessels for the Singapore Navy, with deliveries expected from 2028. Each vessel is valued at US$200 million. The contract is not expected to impact the company's net tangible assets per share or earnings per share for the current financial year.

images.alt_text: ST Engineering booth at the Singapore Airshow 2022 on February 17, 2022.
Yong Hui Ting

site_title: Vietnam artist in race to ensure ‘heroic mothers’ not forgotten
summary: Vietnamese artist Dang Ai Viet, 75, is painting portraits of 2,765 "heroic mothers" who lost two or more loved ones during the Vietnam War. Viet, a former guerrilla in the Mekong Delta, aims to preserve their memories and ensure they are not forgotten. She has traveled over 10,000 km in six months, meeting the women and including details of their loved ones' deaths. Viet's portraits will be handed over to the families, giving them a tangible reminder of their sacrifice.

images.alt_text: Thomas Dambo, best-known for his towering wooden “troll” sculptures, is sending fans on a complex quest to find his recently-completed hundredth troll, one of his fairytale-inspired creations named "Moon Mother".

site_title: Asia: Stocks rally as banking anxiety eases; Alibaba surges
summary: Asian stocks rose sharply on Wednesday, with the MSCI Asia-Pacific index gaining 0.82% as concerns over the banking sector eased. Alibaba's stock surged 15% after the company announced plans to split into six units, lifting investor confidence in the Chinese tech sector. The dollar was on the defensive, while the euro and sterling edged higher. The US Federal Reserve's next meeting in May now has a 51% chance of keeping interest rates steady, down from 60% previously, according to market pricing.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong shares were up 0.5 per cent mid-morning, Sydney rallied 1.1 per cent and Seoul rose 0.4 per cent. Jakarta gained 0.3 per cent and Singapore was up 0.3 per cent.

site_title: Global Palm Resources chief and family launch privatisation offer at S$0.25 per share
summary: The Adijanto family, led by Global Palm Resources chief Suparno Adijanto, has launched a S$0.25 per-share privatization offer for the palm oil producer. The offer aims to acquire all issued shares, excluding treasury shares, with the condition of garnering a minimum 50% acceptance of voting rights. The offer price represents a 93.8% premium over the last traded price and is seen as an opportunity for shareholders to liquidate their investments at a premium. The Adijanto family has stated it does not intend to make major changes to the business or management team.

images.alt_text: palm oil, oil, palm
Michelle Zhu

site_title: Thailand beats Q1 tourism target with 6.15 million arrivals
summary: Thailand exceeded its first-quarter tourist arrival target with 6.15 million visitors between January and March 27, surpassing the initial goal of 6 million. The government estimates 25-30 million arrivals for the full year, with tourists expected to spend 1.5 trillion baht (S$58 billion). The government urged hospitality businesses to charge fair prices amid reports of price increases at some outlets.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices rise for second straight month in February
summary: Hong Kong's private home prices rose 2.2% in February, the second consecutive monthly increase, with the largest gain since May 2020. The rise was attributed to improved sentiment following China's border reopening, interest rate expectations peaking, and new project launches. This marks the 13th consecutive year Hong Kong topped the Demographia survey as the least affordable city globally, with Sydney and Vancouver trailing behind.

images.alt_text: The session will be held jointly by the HKMA and the SFC, the two regulators overseeing stablecoins and crypto exchanges.

Shipping containers and gantry cranes at the Kwai Tsing Container Terminals in Hong Kong, China, on Monday, March 14, 2022. Hong Kong is schedule to release trade figures on March 28. Photographer: Bertha Wang/Bloomberg

site_title: Japan’s Dai-ichi Life turns US$260 billion portfolio back to JGBs
summary: Japan's largest listed life insurer, Dai-ichi Life, is shifting investments to super-long Japanese government bonds to match its liabilities, following the Federal Reserve's interest rate increases. The firm's core unit manages a US$260 billion portfolio and will increase investments in 30-year and 40-year notes to match the duration of its liabilities, which span decades. This move aims to reduce hedging costs associated with currency risks. Dai-ichi's incoming president, Tetsuya Kikuta, stated that reducing hedged foreign bond investments is necessary due to the interest rate gap between the US and Japan.

images.alt_text: Foreign investors bought a net 4.096 trillion yen (S$41.7 billion) worth of Japanese government bonds (JGB) with maturities of more than one year in the week ended March 18 – the largest amount since the ministry began publishing data in 2005.

site_title: Filipino fintech Advance raises US$16 million
summary: Advance, a Filipino fintech startup, has raised US$16 million in pre-Series A funding led by Do Ventures and Lendable. The funding will be used to develop financial products for its customers in the Philippines and Vietnam, where it recently expanded. Advance provides salary advances and financial services to workers in both countries, aiming to address a major credit gap. The startup serves over 200 companies, including Sitel Philippines and Inspiro, and plans to expand its offerings to include financial wellness and education products.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Perplexity is part of a growing wave of startups seeking to use artificial intelligence to loosen Google’s hold on online search.

site_title: Steeper rise in condo and HDB rents in February on falling volumes
summary: Condo and HDB rental prices in Singapore rose in February, with condo rents increasing 3.5% and HDB rents rising 1.2%. This marks the highest monthly increase in condo rents in a year and a larger increase than the 1.4% rise in January. Despite a 18.6% decline in condo rental volumes, prices continued to rise due to a larger supply of new units entering the market. Experts predict that rental growth may ease later in the year as a substantial supply of new homes enters the market.

images.alt_text: Generic picture of property construction
Jessie Lim

site_title: Ramadan bazaar stallholders struggle with steep rents, competition
summary: Stallholders at the Geylang Serai Ramadan bazaar in Singapore are struggling with high rents, low visitorship, and steep competition. Rents have skyrocketed to S$24,000 for some kebab stalls, with others paying S$20,000 or more. The bazaar operator has promised exclusivity to some vendors, but other sellers have appeared despite these agreements. Stallholders are concerned they won't be able to recoup their investment, with some spending up to S$100,000. Despite the challenges, some vendors remain optimistic, citing the bazaar's popularity and the community's willingness to spend.

images.alt_text: Both HDB and condos register rental increases even as volume declined in February
Bangkok did even better than Tokyo, with a total of eight spots besides the Le Du which specialises in creatively reworked Thai dishes.

site_title: Musk, experts urge pause on training AI systems more powerful than GPT-4
summary: Elon Musk and over 1,000 AI experts and executives are urging a six-month pause on training AI systems more powerful than GPT-4, citing potential risks to society and humanity. The group, including Stability AI CEO Emad Mostaque and DeepMind researchers, calls for the development of shared safety protocols for advanced AI designs. They believe powerful AI systems should be developed only when their effects are positive and risks are manageable. The pause aims to ensure the development of AI is done responsibly and with independent expert oversight.

images.alt_text: On Monday, Nvidia released a paper showing that it could use a combination of artificial intelligence techniques to find better ways to place big groups of transistors.

The seeming success of ChatGPT, which became the fastest-growing online service of all time soon after its launch, sparked a race between Google and Microsoft to plug generative AI into many parts of their software.
Microsoft licenses the data in its Bing search index to other companies that offer web search.  In February, it integrated a cousin of ChatGPT, OpenAI’s AI-powered chat technology, into Bing.

site_title: Global creditors face long fight with China developers for money
summary: Global creditors face a long and challenging battle to recover money from China's troubled developers, with the nation's US$735 billion offshore bond market continuing to be roiled for a third year. Despite efforts to meet domestic obligations, creditors have been stymied by lengthy debt restructuring processes and litigation, with many resorting to winding-up petitions, a risky legal action that could backfire. A recent plan by China Evergrande Group has raised concerns that investors may have to wait years to get their money back, highlighting the challenges faced by overseas investors in China's credit market.

images.alt_text: China faces a shortage of an estimated 200,000 industry workers this year.

site_title: AMC soars on report Amazon weighs offer for theatre chain
summary: AMC Entertainment Holdings surged 13% after a report by Intersect stated that Amazon is considering acquiring the struggling theatre chain. Amazon has a market value of about $4 billion and plans to release 12-15 movies annually through AMC. Shares rose as much as 21% in New York, with analysts questioning the viability of an AMC acquisition due to its massive debt and inflated valuation.

images.alt_text: Amazon.com is widening deployment of its contactless technology with existing customers, vice-president Dilip Kumar said in an interview.

Yet Apple has been funding movies from the inception of its Hollywood studio and the smartphone maker’s ambitions in film have grown since it won an Academy Award for best picture for 2021’s CODA (above).
AMC Networks had 1,739 full-time and 287 part-time employees as of Dec 31.

site_title: South Korea vows support for domestic consumption, cautious on inflation
summary: South Korea unveiled measures to boost domestic consumption, aiming to attract more foreign tourists and increase spending. The government plans to increase weekly flights to 90% of 2019 levels by September and implement low-key measures to support the tourism industry. However, the measures stop short of addressing inflation, which remains above the 2% target, and the economy is expected to slow to 1.1% this year. President Yoon Suk Yeol emphasized the need to recover pre-pandemic consumption levels, but the government is cautious not to stoke inflation.

images.alt_text: The consumer sentiment index rose to 92.0 in March from 90.2 in February.
South Korea faces the prospect of its population of 51 million people more than halving by the end of this century.

site_title: Australian inflation eases, bolstering case for rate pause
summary: Australian inflation eased in February, with the consumer price indicator advancing 6.8% from a year earlier, down from 7.4% in January. The RBA may consider a rate pause at its April policy meeting, bolstered by the inflation result. Despite this, the central bank is likely to retain a tightening bias given consumer-price growth remains above its 2-3% target. The RBA has raised rates by 3.5 percentage points since May, citing a desire to engineer a soft landing in the economy.

images.alt_text: Aftershocks from the banking crisis overseas are also raising wholesale funding costs at a time when the major banks need to refinance hundreds of billions in debt.
The RBA has raised rates by 3.5 percentage points since May 2022.

site_title: Jefferies profit falls as dealmaking slump trims results
summary: Jefferies Financial Group reported a 59% decline in net income to $133.6 million in its fiscal first quarter, due to a 42% drop in investment banking revenue. Despite this, fixed income revenue rose 63% to $330.7 million. The company's CEO, Richard Handler, expects pent-up demand for mergers and acquisitions but notes that interest rates will determine whether deals return.

images.alt_text: Jefferies didn’t announce any changes in the Sumitomo stake on Monday.

site_title: Gold edges lower as banking relief, steady dollar dampen demand
summary: Gold prices edged down 0.2% to $1,970.79 per ounce, as the US dollar steadied and fears of a bigger banking sector crisis subsided. The dollar index rose 0.1%, making gold more expensive for buyers holding other currencies. Despite concerns about inflation, the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding gold rises when interest rates are increased. The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates by 25 basis points in May, according to market pricing.

images.alt_text: Gold prices slipped more than 1 per cent on Monday as investors scaled back on safe-haven trading.

site_title: Giant meatball of extinct mammoth unveiled in the Netherlands
summary: An Australian company, Vow, unveiled a giant meatball made from sheep cells inserted with a mammoth gene called myoglobin at a science museum in the Netherlands. The meatball, created to promote cultured meat as a sustainable alternative, has the aroma of crocodile meat and is not intended for consumption. The company used an alternative to traditional methods, avoiding animal death in the process. The product is currently undergoing rigorous tests before being brought to market in the European Union, where it could potentially capitalize on the lack of regulation.

images.alt_text: Scientists operating the HiRISE, which has been circling Mars since 2006, crunched the data that made it back to Earth and have now published a picture of the face.
Scientists have warned that climbing temperatures have wrought major changes to ocean stability faster than previously thought

site_title: Sa Sa’s cautious revival shows pessimism over Hong Kong recovery
summary: Hong Kong's biggest cosmetics chain, Sa Sa International Holdings, plans to open just 5-7 new stores this year, reflecting pessimism over the city's economic recovery. The company's chief financial officer expects sales to return to pre-pandemic levels in 2026, and tourists' contribution to revenue may decline to 60% from 70%. Sa Sa will focus on local consumers and expand in Singapore and Malaysia, but has a conservative outlook on the city's tourism industry.

images.alt_text: Investors will have to weigh L’Oreal’s slowing momentum even as it continues to beat expectations.

site_title: US charges Sam Bankman-Fried with bribing Chinese officials
summary: US officials have charged former FTX CEO Sam Bankman-Fried with bribing Chinese officials, alleging he authorised at least $40 million in payments to secure unfrozen $1 billion in cryptocurrency accounts. This is the 13th criminal charge against Bankman-Fried, who has pleaded not guilty and is out on bail. The move stems from a probe by Chinese authorities in early 2021 and comes as part of broader charges including wire fraud, money laundering, and election finance violations.

images.alt_text: Under some of the proposed new conditions, Bankman-Fried would have a new phone with no Internet capability and a basic laptop with limited functions, but be forbidden from using other electronic communication devices.

site_title: Shortage of fresh graduates could force consolidation in Singapore’s accounting market
summary: Singapore's accounting market faces a shortage of fresh graduates, with total enrolment in accountancy degree programmes falling to 5,182 in 2021. Smaller accounting firms are struggling to hire, with the Big Four firms outbidding them for graduates. In response, smaller firms are offering higher pay, but this also leads to higher manpower costs and increased competition. Experts predict consolidation among smaller players, potentially concentrating accounting services among larger firms, and suggest reforms to the qualification exams and promotion of the profession to potential students.

images.alt_text: EY is on track to hire around 220,000 people in the 12 months to July 2023, having achieved its highest growth in nearly two decades in the previous period – and this is before a potential break-up of its auditing and consulting divisions takes effect. The break-up will create more jobs as well.
The salary increases came as firms struggle to retain staff.

site_title: Memory chipmaker Micron expects revenue drop, expects AI to boost sales in 2025
summary: Micron Technology expects its third-quarter revenue to drop nearly 60% from a year earlier due to a chip industry glut, but forecasts a 15% headcount reduction and keeps investments at $7 billion for fiscal year 2023. Despite the challenges, CEO Sanjay Mehrotra is confident about the long-term and points to artificial intelligence (AI) as a growth area, citing Micron's technology and product roadmaps to address AI's increasing demand for memory chips. The company expects a record calendar year 2025 in terms of market size for the memory chip industry.

images.alt_text: Micron had about 48,000 employees worldwide as of Sep 1.

site_title: Alibaba’s breakup shows global tech firms how to unlock value
summary: Alibaba Group Holding has announced a plan to split into six units, sending its stock soaring 15% as the company aims to raise funds and eventually explore initial public offerings. The move aligns with China's policy to reduce the monopolistic nature of tech giants, and could serve as a blueprint for similar firms. Global tech giants such as Tencent Holdings, JD.com, and Baidu are also expected to follow suit, with some analysts predicting substantial upside potential as investors come to appreciate the value of their business segments.

images.alt_text: News of the restructuring comes one day after Alibaba founder Jack Ma was spotted at a primary school in Hangzhou, marking his first public appearance in mainland China in over a year.
Yungu Education, the school that Ma founded, has posted photographs and a video of him visiting the premises.

site_title: China tackles chip talent shortage with new courses, higher pay
summary: China is ramping up efforts to develop home-grown semiconductor talent amid a shortage of 200,000 industry workers. Enrolments for undergraduate and post-graduate courses in chip engineering have surged, with entry-level salaries doubling to 400,000 yuan. However, experts argue that China's emerging chip curriculums lack hands-on industry experience, and students often graduate without internship experience. Private schools are offering short-term solutions, such as chip engineering bootcamps, to address the shortage, but solving it will be a long-term campaign.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Model of LNG tanker is seen in front of China's flag in this illustration taken May 19, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration//File Photo
China's data on key economic activity, including retail sales, industrial production and fixed asset investment, all show modest improvement with clear room for further growth.
Li thanked the foreign representatives in the audience for the support they’d offered over the years and urged them to “take a long-term view” amid economic challenges.

site_title: Apple launches buy now, pay later service in US
summary: Apple has launched its buy now, pay later (BNPL) service, Apple Pay Later, in the US, allowing users to split purchases into four payments over six weeks with no interest or fees. The service, available through the Mastercard Instalments programme, will enable users to apply for loans between $50 and $1,000 for online and in-app purchases. The launch is expected to disrupt the financial technology sector, potentially taking market share from existing players like Affirm Holdings and PayPal, as consumers seek easier payment options amid inflation.

images.alt_text: Apple CEO Tim Cook praises China for its rapid innovation and its long ties with the US iPhone maker, according to local media reports.

Yet Apple has been funding movies from the inception of its Hollywood studio and the smartphone maker’s ambitions in film have grown since it won an Academy Award for best picture for 2021’s CODA (above).

site_title: Binance billionaire Zhao, the crypto king who wants the world
summary: Binance founder Changpeng Zhao (CZ) is facing a major setback after being sued by the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) for allegedly operating an "illegal" exchange. The CFTC claims Binance ran a "sham" compliance program, failed to establish money-laundering checks, and concealed its US user base. CZ has denied the allegations, stating they are "incomplete" and "mischaracterized." The lawsuit comes after Binance was also under investigation by the US Department of Justice for alleged criminal sanctions violations and money laundering.

images.alt_text: Changpeng Zhao, who has an estimated net worth of almost US$28 billion, bought a home in Dubai in 2021 in what he said was a show of support for a city he describes as “very pro-crypto”.
The derivatives regulator said Binance shirked its obligations by not properly registering with it.
“Initial analysis indicates matching engine encountered a bug on a trailing stop order,” Binance chief executive Changpeng Zhao said in a tweet.

site_title: Binance crackdown threatens US trading firms, spooks market
summary: A US regulator's lawsuit against Binance Holdings threatens American trading firms that worked with the exchange, as the CFTC alleges they used shell companies and virtual private networks to trade cryptocurrencies. The case, which involves three unnamed US firms, has sent chills across the industry and could impact US firms' ability to conduct business if they lose their US licenses. Binance called the lawsuit "unexpected and disappointing," but US trading firms are concerned about the implications, with one firm stating that the suit could hurt liquidity in the digital-asset space.

images.alt_text: Changpeng  Zhao was born in China before moving to Canada in 1989 when he was 12, two months after China’s Tiananmen Square crackdown on pro-democracy protesters.
Changpeng Zhao, who has an estimated net worth of almost US$28 billion, bought a home in Dubai in 2021 in what he said was a show of support for a city he describes as “very pro-crypto”.
The derivatives regulator said Binance shirked its obligations by not properly registering with it.

site_title: Time to raise deposit insurance cap of S$75,000; count SRS funds threshold separately from ordinary deposits
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is considering raising the deposit insurance cap from S$75,000 to S$100,000 or higher to better protect small depositors, as the current cap may not be sufficient to cover the growing savings of Singaporeans. The cap currently covers Singapore dollar-denominated deposits, including Supplementary Retirement Scheme (SRS) funds, which have seen significant growth. Raising the cap would provide better protection for depositors, particularly those with higher savings, but would also increase costs for financial institutions.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Deposits at small banks fall US$119 billion to US$5.46 trillion in the week ended March 15.

A sign for Deutsche Bank AG at a bank branch in the financial district of Frankfurt, Germany, on Thursday, Feb. 2, 2023. Deutsche Bank vowed to increase profit and revenue further this year, after snapping a long streak of market share gains in trading in the final quarter of Chief Executive Officer Christian Sewing's turnaround plan. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg
The ‘moral hazard’ of a higher federal insurance limit on US bank deposits

site_title: Sembmarine unit’s ‘alleged irregularities’ linked to Brazil’s Operation Car Wash
summary: Sembmarine's subsidiary, Estaleiro Jurong Aracruz, is being investigated by Brazil's Comptroller General of the Union (CGU) for "alleged irregularities" linked to money laundering and graft activities. The investigation is related to past conduct, not against Sembmarine or its subsidiaries. The company will continue to cooperate with Brazilian authorities on the matter.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

Keppel O&M, a unit under Keppel Corporation, is currently working towards a merger with Sembcorp Marine (Sembmarine) after shareholders approved the proposed merger through an extraordinary general meeting last December.
Sembcorp Marine's net order book stands at S$7.1 billion as at the end of its third quarter, of which S$6.7 billion comprises new contracts acquired in the year to date.

Brazil's new President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva (centre), accompanied by his wife First Lady Rosangela "Janja" da Silva (second from right),  after his inauguration ceremony at the National Congress, in Brasilia, on Jan 1, 2023.
Brazil's Operation Car Wash not a magic bullet

site_title: South Korea consumer sentiment improves to nine-month high in March
summary: South Korea's consumer sentiment index reached a nine-month high in March, rising to 92.0 from 90.2 in February. The improvement was attributed to easing inflation expectations, with the median of consumers' inflation expectations for the next 12 months falling to 3.9% from 4.0% in the previous month. The rise in the living conditions index, which rose 1.1 points, led the headline index higher, while the spending outlook sub-index fell 0.7 points. The Bank of Korea attributed the increase to the slowing inflation and government plans to delay public cost increases.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembmarine, Straits Trading, Keong Hong
summary: Investigations into Sembcorp Marine's Estaleiro Jurong Aracruz are linked to Brazil's Operation Car Wash, a corruption effort. The company has not faced civil or administrative charges. Straits Trading's board proposed a scrip dividend scheme, while Keong Hong Construction won a S$118 million tender. Sembmarine's shares rose 4.8% on Tuesday, and Straits Trading and Keong Hong's shares ended flat. No charges have been brought against the companies or their subsidiaries.

site_title: Commodity futures, nickel mining stocks among ways for investors to ride nickel rally
summary: Nickel prices are expected to continue their rally, with supply unlikely to keep pace with demand, driven by the growing use of electric vehicles (EVs) in Asia. Analysts recommend investing in nickel futures, commodity futures, or ETFs as a way to ride the nickel rally. Jim Rogers and Nirgunan Tiruchelvam suggest that buying shares of nickel companies can also be a viable option, but with associated risks. Indonesia, with its substantial nickel reserves, is expected to benefit from the nickel rally, with analysts predicting strong economic growth.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Dump trucks travel along a track at a nickel mine operated by Vale Indonesia in Sorowako, South Sulawesi, Indonesia. The company is emerging as an important producer of nicke.

Contracts on the LME, which are the global benchmarks for industrial metals including aluminium, copper and nickel, are underpinned by physical metal in the network of warehouses around the world – any trader holding a contract to delivery receives a parcel of metal in an LME-registered warehouse.
Harita operates the country’s first high-pressure acid leaching (HPAL) smelter on Obi island in North Maluku.

A nickel mine in Indonesia. Most of Indonesia's nickel is currently exported to China as low-grade pig iron, but more investment could allow it to be processed into higher-value battery-grade exports.

site_title: Nickel investments may reward investors with solid returns amid EV boom
summary: Nickel prices are expected to rise amid the booming electric vehicle (EV) industry, with demand for the metal increasing due to its essential role in lithium-ion batteries. Analysts predict nickel prices to average US$30,000 per tonne this year, up from a forecast of US$22,500 per tonne, driven by demand from mainland China and the peaking of the US dollar. Indonesia is expected to become an increasingly important producer and exporter of refined nickel, with global refined nickel production expected to rise to 3.6 million tonnes by 2031.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

“Armed with substantial nickel reserves, Indonesia’s ambition to be the EV hub of South-east Asia will help drive its economic growth,” said Henry Wibowo, JP Morgan’s head of Indonesia research and strategy.

Contracts on the LME, which are the global benchmarks for industrial metals including aluminium, copper and nickel, are underpinned by physical metal in the network of warehouses around the world – any trader holding a contract to delivery receives a parcel of metal in an LME-registered warehouse.
Harita operates the country’s first high-pressure acid leaching (HPAL) smelter on Obi island in North Maluku.
Tesla aims to augment its own output with 4680 cells from Korea’s LG Energy Solution and Japan’s Panasonic – an insurance policy to secure future EV production
A nickel mining site located beside farms belonging to villagers on Wawonii island, south-east Sulawesi.
Indian businessman Prateek Gupta and his companies, against whom Trafigura secured a US$625 million freezing order this week, have a checkered history in the trading world.

site_title: Crypto fugitive Do Kwon tells police he got VIP service on the run
summary: Do Kwon, co-founder of Terraform Labs, told Montenegrin officials he received luxury treatment during months on the run due to a cryptocurrency fraud that wiped out at least $40 billion. Kwon and his companion entered Montenegro illegally and spent time in a neighboring country before being arrested on falsified travel documents. This comes as US federal prosecutors and South Korea have expressed intentions to seek Kwon's extradition to face criminal charges.

images.alt_text: Police officers escort South Korean crypto mogul Do Kwo in Podgorica, Montenegro.
The 31-year-old was arrested at the Podgorica airport in Montenegro on a South Korean warrant.
The 31-year-old was detained in Podgorica along with Hon Chang Joon while trying to fly to Dubai using falsified Costa Rican travelling documents.

site_title: Proper regulation will bring legitimacy to crypto market: Animoca chairman
summary: Yat Siu, chairman of Animoca Brands, believes that proper regulation will bring legitimacy to the cryptocurrency market, which he notes has rebounded since hitting rock bottom at the end of 2022. The market's trillion-dollar market capitalization holds significant potential for investors, with trading volumes reaching billions. Siu emphasizes that the industry is working well, despite its volatility, and that regulation will help stabilize the market.

site_title: Europe: Stocks erase gains as banking sentiment remains fragile
summary: European stocks closed flat on Tuesday, erasing gains, amid lingering concerns about a broader credit crunch in the global banking sector. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.8% earlier but settled flat, with real estate stocks taking the hardest hit, sliding 2.7% to a five-and-a-half-month low. The European Central Bank's top supervisor expressed concerns about investor sentiment, and a recent decline in Deutsche Bank shares has raised worries about a renewed recession.

images.alt_text: European stocks are looking to end the first quarter of the year with gains, buoyed by signs of economic resilience and hopes that central banks are near the end of their tightening cycles.

site_title: US: Stocks fall as bond yields climb
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday, March 28, as bond yields rose, despite solid consumer confidence data. The S&P 500 slipped 0.2% to 3,971.27 and the Nasdaq Composite Index lost 0.5% to 11,716.08. The Dow Jones Industrial Average also dropped 0.1% to 32,394.25. The rise in bond yields pressured tech shares, which are seen as more reliant on debt. This comes amid concerns about contagion from the failure of Silicon Valley Bank and other mid-sized US banks.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 2.77 points, or 0.01 per cent, at the open to 32,434.85.

site_title: Oil prices rise on Kurdish supply risks and banking relief
summary: Oil prices rose on Tuesday, extending gains from the previous session, due to supply disruption risks from Iraqi Kurdistan and hopes that banking sector turmoil is contained. Brent crude futures rose 0.7% to $78.65 a barrel and West Texas Intermediate crude rose 0.5% to $73.20 a barrel. The halt of 450,000 barrels per day of oil exports from Iraq's northern Kurdistan region and expectations of recovering demand in China contributed to the price increase. Banking sector optimism also lifted crude prices, with a weaker US dollar making oil less expensive for international buyers.

images.alt_text: US crude oil stockpiles were seen rising about 200,000 barrels last week, a preliminary Reuters poll showed on Monday.

site_title: EV giant BYD Q4 profit jumps 12 times to 7.3 billion yuan
summary: Chinese EV giant BYD reported a 12-fold increase in Q4 profit to 7.3 billion yuan, with a 446% increase in 2022 net profit to 16.6 billion yuan. BYD's EVs are powered by its self-developed lithium batteries, the Blade Battery. The company's domestic market lead is solidified with a wide range of products.

images.alt_text: BYD has been slowing output since the start of the year when industry-wide sales began to slow and China ended a national subsidy programme for EVs and plug-in electric vehicles.

The BYD HAN EV is displayed during an exhibition test drive as the Chinese electric-vehicle producer announces its expansion to the consumer market next year in Mexico, in Toluca, Mexico November 29, 2022. REUTERS/Toya Sarno Jordan

site_title: Microsoft unveils OpenAI-based chat tools for fighting cyberattacks
summary: Microsoft has unveiled new chat tools called Copilots, powered by OpenAI's GPT-4 language system, to help cybersecurity teams detect and respond to cyberattacks. The tools analyze connections between various parts of a hack, such as suspicious emails and malware files, and provide reports and summaries of incidents. The system can also learn from users and share data with other clients. Microsoft plans to roll out the tool to select customers first, with the goal of making it available to more users in the future, as hackers continue to evolve and speed up their attacks.

images.alt_text: Microsoft licenses the data in its Bing search index to other companies that offer web search.  In February, it integrated a cousin of ChatGPT, OpenAI’s AI-powered chat technology, into Bing.

site_title: Reframing Singapore’s investment attractiveness in a post-BEPS world
summary: Singapore must reframe its investment promotion strategies to consolidate its appeal to global multinational enterprises (MNEs) after the implementation of Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) Pillar 2 from 2025. The country needs to strengthen its small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and invest in its people to create a compelling environment for investors. A three-pronged approach is key, focusing on driving a vibrant industry ecosystem, catalyzing close partnerships between foreign investors and local SMEs, and rethinking the measure of success in attracting FDI to focus on output-oriented metrics.

images.alt_text: The next generation of business incentives could bring together domestic and regional strengths, offering investors the best of both worlds – all from a base in Singapore.

Pillar 2 of BEPS 2.0 introduces a minimum effective tax rate of 15 per cent for multi-national enterprise (MNE) groups with annual group revenues of at least 750 million euros. This will be implemented in Singapore on or after Jan 1, 2025.

site_title: Banks in France face more than US$1.1 billion fines after raids
summary: French banks, including Societe Generale and BNP Paribas, face collective fines of over $1.1 billion for tax fraud and money laundering related to dividend payments. The investigation, launched in 2021, involved raids on multiple banks and was part of a larger probe into dividend arbitrage strategies. The fines include penalties and back interest, and the prosecutor's office in Paris invited anyone with further information to come forward. The investigation adds to negative sentiment in the banking industry, following recent scandals in the US and Europe.

images.alt_text: Increased pressure from investors follows evidence that banks are failing to rein in fossil finance.

site_title: US consumer confidence unexpectedly rises in March
summary: US consumer confidence unexpectedly rose in March to 104.2, beating analyst expectations, but remains below last year's average. The increase is attributed to improved outlooks for younger consumers and those earning over $50,000. However, consumers plan to spend less on discretionary categories like dining and amusement parks, but more on necessary items like healthcare and home maintenance. This uptick in consumer confidence adds pressure on the Federal Reserve to control rising prices, which remain above its target of 2%.

images.alt_text:
MIAMI, FLORIDA - JUNE 09: A cargo ship sits at PortMiami on June 09, 2022 in Miami Beach, Florida. The US trade deficit shrunk in April, reflecting a drop in the value of imports amid COVID-19 lockdowns in China while exports climbed. The deficit dropped by 19.1%, to $87.1 billion. site_title: Myanmar Junta dissolves Suu Kyi’s party after it boycotts poll
summary: Myanmar's military government dissolved the National League for Democracy (NLD), the pro-democracy party of Aung San Suu Kyi, after it boycotted the upcoming elections. The NLD, along with 40 other parties, failed to register within the 60-day deadline under a new law allowing for automatic disqualification and dissolution. The Union Election Commission will continue to accept applications for new parties, and the junta has called for existing parties to comply with the law. The NLD's boycott comes amid ongoing struggles in Myanmar since the 2021 coup, with the UN and US labeling the planned elections as a "sham".

site_title: China completes first yuan-settled LNG trade
summary: China has successfully completed its first yuan-settled liquefied natural gas (LNG) trade through the Shanghai Petroleum and Natural Gas Exchange, involving 65,000 tonnes of LNG imported from the UAE. This marks a significant step for China's efforts to establish its currency internationally and weaken the US dollar's grip on world trade. The move follows President Xi Jinping's announcement in December that China would use the Shanghai exchange as a platform for yuan settlements of oil and gas trades.

site_title: US housing cools further, with prices down 3% from the peak
summary: US housing prices have continued to decline, falling 0.2% from December and 3% from their record high in June. The national index is down 3.8% annually, with some cities experiencing significant declines, including San Francisco (-7.6%) and Seattle (-5.1%). Experts attribute the slowdown to sagging buyer demand, easing mortgage rates, and uncertainty over the economy, which may lead to stricter lending requirements and higher borrowing costs.

site_title: The slow-motion tidal wave consuming the economy
summary: The US economy is facing unprecedented challenges, including climate change, demographics, deglobalization, and artificial intelligence. Economic models are failing to keep pace with these emerging forces, and experts warn of an existential threat to civilization. The economy has experienced erratic behavior, with yo-yo inflation and housing cycles, and economists are struggling to predict the future. The risks from these factors will accelerate over the next decades, and if economic models cannot adapt, the prospects for forecasting are bleak. A more adaptable approach, akin to that of a cockroach, may be necessary to survive in a world of radical uncertainty.

images.alt_text: A printed balloon with Chinese flag is placed on a U.S. flag in the shape of U.S. map outline, in this illustration taken February 5, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration
A robotic arm picks up sorting containers at an Amazon fulfillment centre in the United States.
The closed gates of Credit Suisse's headquarters in Zurich, Switzerland. Perhaps we will look back on these few weeks as the time when the era of free market truisms ended.

site_title: For battered US bank shares, earnings may make or break
summary: US bank shares may experience relief from their recent rout after quarterly earnings reports starting next month, which could provide more details about the sector's overall health. The S&P 500 bank index has dropped 16% since March 8, with the failure of Signature Bank and problems at other lenders adding to the turmoil. Analysts expect earnings to be a key factor in determining the sector's future, with some saying results could either calm or exacerbate the market's concerns, depending on what bank executives say.

images.alt_text: The meeting comes as markets seesaw amid concerns that a two-week-old banking crisis sparked by the failures of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank could worsen, spreading more runs on smaller banks
Following the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank, the US Treasury, Federal Reserve and Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation stepped in to protect insured deposits – those up to US$250,000 per client.

site_title: ChatGPT poses serious security risks; ditch passwords
summary: Cybersecurity experts warn that the increasing use of AI-powered technology, such as ChatGPT, poses serious security risks and could facilitate the work of scammers and cybercrime syndicates. The AI chatbot app has reached 100 million active users in just a few months, surpassing social media platforms. Experts fear that phishing scams could increase with the rise of AI-powered technology, citing a 41% jump in Singapore's phishing scams in 2022. As companies continue to develop AI-enhanced search capabilities, cybersecurity experts urge caution and highlight the need for stronger security measures.

images.alt_text: The cybersecurity industry must be ready to fight AI-powered exploits, says Palo Alto Networks' Sean Duca.
ChatGPT had “ignited a conversation about the implications of generative AI for cybersecurity”, Darktrace noted on Wednesday.

site_title: Philippines president backs merger of two state lenders to create country's biggest bank
summary: Philippines President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. is backing the merger of state-run Development Bank of the Philippines (DBP) and Land Bank of the Philippines (LBP) to create the country's largest bank by assets. The merger, previously approved in 2016 but scrapped, aims to save over 5 billion pesos in operating costs. The union of DBP and LBP would have combined assets of 3.8 trillion pesos, surpassing BDO Unibank's 3.7 trillion pesos. The move is seen as a response to recent financial developments abroad, including the collapse of US banks.

images.alt_text: China's data on key economic activity, including retail sales, industrial production and fixed asset investment, all show modest improvement with clear room for further growth.

site_title: Developer Sunac China reaches restructuring deal with offshore creditor group
summary: Sunac China, a major Chinese property developer, has reached a restructuring deal with an offshore creditor group to address $9 billion of debt. As part of the agreement, debt will be exchanged into convertible bonds or new notes with interest rates between 5% and 6.5%. Creditors can also convert debt into shares in Sunac's property management unit or extend the maturity of certain notes by one year. The restructuring is expected to take effect on September 30, and Sunac's shares remain suspended due to the ongoing financial reports release.

images.alt_text: An advertisement of property developer Sunac China Holdings is seen at a residential complex in Shanghai, China March 25, 2018. Picture taken March 25, 2018. REUTERS/Stringer A

site_title: US officials signal new rules for banks after SVB, signature failures
summary: US financial officials signal a major regulatory overhaul of the banking sector in response to the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank. The overhaul aims to address underlying issues and improve the resilience of the banking system. Key steps include enhanced stress tests, a long-term debt requirement for big banks, and explored liquidity rules. The Federal Reserve and FDIC will propose changes to deposit-insurance coverage and capital requirements, but face concerted Republican opposition, with lawmakers blaming the Biden administration's fiscal stimulus for high inflation.

images.alt_text: The bank failures come as S&P 500 companies are headed for their second straight decline in year-over-year quarterly earnings.
Following the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank, the US Treasury, Federal Reserve and Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation stepped in to protect insured deposits – those up to US$250,000 per client.
An employee inspecting a solar panel for defects at the module production line at REC Solar ASA manufacturing facility in Tuas on 5 September 2014.

site_title: Economic imperatives of climate action
summary: Economic policies on climate change are not aligned with scientific evidence, as mainstream economics prioritizes short-term GDP growth over climate mitigation. A new book highlights the need for economic analysis to be integrated with climate science to inform policy responses. To address climate change, countries should adopt carbon pricing, such as a carbon tax or carbon trading, and focus on regenerative growth through renewable energy and a circular economy. A strong economic policy response is urgently needed to complement climate action and avoid the "price of inaction" far exceeding the "price of action."

images.alt_text: Having laid out a path for coal's phase-out to obtain sustainable financing, Asean must ensure that its framework is working as intended.

(FILES) This file photo taken on January 3, 2023 shows cranes and cargo ships at Nanjing port in China's eastern Jiangsu province. - China's exports in December fell the most since 2020, according to official figures released on January 13, 2023, after health restrictions hit the economy hard. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Straits Trading seeks to adopt scrip dividend scheme
summary: Straits Trading, a diversified investment company, is seeking to adopt a scrip dividend scheme, allowing eligible shareholders to opt for dividend payouts in new shares instead of cash. This move aims to create long-term sustainable value for shareholders and retain cash for growth, strengthening working capital and financial flexibility. The scheme will not incur brokerage fees or related costs.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

site_title: US: Wall Street muted at open after recent bounce; banks in focus
summary: US stock markets opened flat on Tuesday, following a three-day rally in the S&P 500 and Dow, driven by support for the banking sector and a deal on Silicon Valley Bank assets. The Dow Jones rose 2.77 points, or 0.01%, to 32,434.85, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite opened lower.

site_title: Keong Hong unit bags S$118 million tender for office building
summary: Keong Hong Construction, a unit of Keong Hong Holdings, has secured a S$118 million tender for a 20-storey office building in Cecil Street, Singapore. The project, with a 35-month construction period, will feature restaurants on the first floor and a basement carpark. The contract does not significantly impact Keong Hong's earnings per share for the year ending September 30.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

site_title: Asean’s place in a ‘dramatically altered’ world
summary: Singapore's UOB head of group wholesale banking and markets, Frederick Chin, sees opportunities for Asean in a "dramatically altered" world, driven by re-globalisation and climate action. Chin believes Asean's competitive edge in cost, labor force, and infrastructure will help it capitalize on reorganized supply chains. He predicts Singapore's total trade flows will exceed US$1 trillion annually, with the region's trades with China and the US contributing significantly to this growth. Chin also emphasizes the need for Asean to ramp up clean-energy investments to meet climate goals.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
Venture helps companies design and produce high-tech products. Its margins have been consistently been around 10 per cent in the last five years.
Asean has much to recommend itself to clean energy investors, but the region’s economic development model remains based on fossil fuels. PHOTO:

Asean’s participation in the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) – the world’s largest trade agreement – will bring about a virtuous cycle of global investment and talent flows into this region, says UOB's Chew Mun Yew.
CGS-CIMB notes that Singapore banks do not share the same risks which led to the event due to strong corporate governance and risk management.

Barclays and DBS do not expect monetary policy tightening in April. Meanwhile, the Bank of America predicts a steepening of the Singapore dollar nominal effective exchange rate, and Maybank, UOB and HSBC expect re-centring.
While the ongoing banking crisis may wreck less damage than the global financial crisis, stocks can still be in for a rough ride and recovery prospects look unexciting.
DBS, OCBC and UOB branches in Singapore.

site_title: WHO revises Covid-19 vaccine recommendations for Omicron-era
summary: The World Health Organization has revised its Covid-19 vaccination recommendations, suggesting that healthy children and adolescents may not need a shot, but older, high-risk groups should get a booster between 6-12 months after their last vaccine. The agency defines high-risk populations as older adults and younger people with significant risk factors, recommending an additional shot for these groups. Healthy children and adolescents are considered "low priority" for vaccination, with countries advised to consider factors like disease burden before recommending vaccination.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, Director-General of the World Health Organization (WHO), speaks during a news conference in Geneva, Switzerland, December 20, 2021. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: ERP rates at 7 locations to increase by S$1 from April 3
summary: The Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) rates at 7 locations in Singapore will increase by S$1 from April 3, aiming to ease congestion on expressways. This decision follows LTA's monitoring of traffic conditions in February, which showed traffic building up at several stretches of expressways. The rate increase will be implemented during 16 time periods.

images.alt_text: LTA said traffic has been building up on several stretches of expressways, and these changes have been made in response to traffic conditions observed throughout January this year.

site_title: AI computing startup Cerebras releases open source ChatGPT-like models
summary: Cerebras Systems, a Silicon Valley-based AI chip startup, released seven open-source ChatGPT-like models trained on its AI supercomputer Andromeda. The models range from 111 million to 13 billion parameters, allowing for more complex generative functions. The smaller models can be deployed on phones or smart speakers, while larger ones run on PCs or servers. The release aims to foster collaboration and counter the trend of closed-source AI models, following the success of OpenAI's ChatGPT.

site_title: Influencers, online mobs targeted in China social media cleanup
summary: China plans to crack down on harmful social media content, including targeting influencers and online mobs, as part of a broader effort to increase control over the internet. The government aims to "rectify" the spread of certain content on short video platforms and control teenage addiction to these apps. Officials also plan to combat "water armies" – users paid to spread messages online – and target those making money from harming companies' and entrepreneurs' reputations. This move follows previous curbs on the tech industry, including limiting gaming time for children and tightening oversight of the short video industry.

site_title: Alibaba to split into six, plans new IPOs in historic overhaul
summary: Alibaba plans to split its $220 billion empire into six units, raising funds and exploring initial public offerings (IPOs). The move, which includes e-commerce, media, cloud, and other divisions, aims to increase autonomy and pave the way for future spinoffs. The restructuring, rare for major Chinese tech firms, is seen as a response to government crackdowns on tech giants, which have suppressed innovation. Alibaba's shares rose 8% in pre-market trading, and analysts believe the move could serve as a blueprint for the industry.

images.alt_text: Yungu Education, the school that Ma founded, has posted photographs and a video of him visiting the premises.

site_title: Caution in crisis-hit Israel after Netanyahu pauses judicial reforms
summary: Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has paused the legislative process of his controversial judicial reforms, a move seen as a concession to widespread protests and a general strike. The reforms, which would give politicians more power over the judiciary, sparked a nationwide walkout and mass protests. Netanyahu's decision was met with skepticism, with critics warning that it does not amount to a genuine peace deal. The crisis has revealed deep rifts within Netanyahu's coalition and has led to speculation about the fate of the ousted defense minister, Yoav Gallant.

images.alt_text: A camper wagon with electoral banner depicting Benjamin Netanyahu, who has focused his message on high living costs – a top concern for voters – and dismissing his trial as “rigged” and “a joke”.

site_title: Self-driving startup Venti raises US$28.8 million to speed up growth
summary: Self-driving startup Venti Technologies has raised US$28.8 million in Series A funding to accelerate growth of its autonomous vehicle business for the logistics and supply chain industry. The company, founded in 2018, has been developing its self-driving technology for three years at Singapore's largest container port and is already generating revenue. CEO Heidi Wyle plans to deploy dozens of self-driving vehicles this year, focusing on ports, airports, and warehouses. Investors include LG Technology Ventures and UOB Venture Management.

site_title: Ramsay, Sime Darby plan to revive sale of Asia healthcare venture
summary: Ramsay Health Care and Sime Darby plan to revive the sale of their Asia-focused healthcare joint venture, Ramsay Sime Darby Health Care, valued at RM6 billion (S$1.8 billion). The companies are in talks with financial advisors to explore a sale to strategic investors, following earlier discussions that fell through. The revival comes as healthcare assets gain favor amid economic uncertainty, with options including a sale or initial public offering (IPO) on the Malaysia Stock Exchange.

site_title: US trade deficit widens as exports decline
summary: The US trade deficit widened 0.6% to $91.6 billion in February, driven by a 3.8% decline in exports to $167.8 billion, with motor vehicle shipments plummeting 11.9%. Imports slipped 2.3% to $259.5 billion, but businesses restocked goods at a steady clip. The widening trade deficit may drag on economic growth in the first quarter, with economists forecasting a 3.2% GDP increase.

images.alt_text: The survey’s flash services sector PMI increased to 53.8 this month, the highest level since last April, from 50.6 in February.

site_title: Adidas, Beyoncé end partnership after slow sales, WSJ reports
summary: Adidas and pop star Beyoncé have ended their partnership following disappointing sales, according to the Wall Street Journal. The partnership, which began in 2020, will conclude later this year after another Ivy Park merchandise drop. Adidas CEO Bjorn Gulden is seeking to revamp the brand, which is still recovering from its cancelled Yeezy partnership. The move comes as the German company continues to face challenges in the fashion industry.

site_title: Danish artist hatches epic global troll hunt
summary: Danish artist Thomas Dambo is sending fans on a worldwide quest to find his 100th troll sculpture, "Moon Mother", hidden in a secret spot in the forest. The complex treasure hunt requires fans to piece together codes placed near his existing trolls across the globe. Dambo, known for his towering wooden sculptures inspired by Scandinavian folk tales, hopes his art can show people that trash is a treasure and encourage them to venture out into nature.

images.alt_text: Senior Parliamentary Secretary for Sustainability and the Environment Baey Yam Keng (right) with Naomi Chu, the first prize winner in the Primary School category of the Art of Trash competition by presenting partner UBS Singapore.

In Paperclip Embrace, two busts of humans made entirely of paperclips hold each other; the work refers to a metaphor by philosopher Nick Bostrom, who in the 2000s imagined what would happen if AI was programmed to create paper clips.

site_title: IMF wants external financing commitments fulfilled to release funds, Pakistan PM says
summary: Pakistan Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif stated that the International Monetary Fund (IMF) wants external financing commitments fulfilled from friendly countries before releasing $1.1 billion in bailout funds. The funding is crucial for Pakistan to avoid default on its obligations and unlock other external financing avenues. Several countries, including Saudi Arabia, China, and the UAE, have made commitments to help Pakistan. An agreement is expected once remaining points, including a proposed fuel pricing scheme, are settled, with the IMF requiring Islamabad to explain the scheme before any loan deal.

images.alt_text: Pakistan has completed almost all of the prior actions except for the external financing requirement the IMF wanted it to for clearing US$1.1 billion in disbursements under the US$6.5 billion Extended Fund Facility agreed in 2019.

site_title: Sam Bankman-Fried, prosecutors reach new bail agreement
summary: Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of FTX, has reached a new bail agreement with US prosecutors. Under the proposed conditions, he will be forbidden from using electronic communication devices except for a new phone with limited internet capabilities and a basic laptop with monitoring software to track user activity. These restrictions aim to prevent tampering with the conditions, with no administrative access allowed. The agreement follows a judge's warning that Bankman-Fried could be sent to jail pending trial.

site_title: The best restaurants in the UK and Ireland, according to Michelin
summary: The UK and Ireland's top-rated restaurants, according to the 2023 Michelin Guide, retained their three-star status, with no new additions or losses. The announcement ceremony, held at the Silverstone Circuit, honored chefs who received new stars in 2021 and 2022. This year's event marked the first live ceremony in two years, celebrating the restaurant industry's recovery after a tough few years. The UK's top-rated restaurants, including Core by Clare Smyth, were recognized for their exceptional fine dining experiences.

images.alt_text: Hanazen's kitchen takes up the bulk of the space, with two facing charcoal grills.
The 2022 Asia's Best 50 awards was held in Bangkok.

site_title: UK’s Queen Consort Camilla: from palace margins to royal limelight
summary: Queen Consort Camilla, 75, marks her first international state visit with her husband King Charles III to Germany, following a long journey from palace margins to royal limelight. After being vilified in the 1990s, Camilla has won acceptance for her support of her husband and charitable work, including her role as president of the Royal Osteoporosis Society. With her popularity ratings lower than most senior royals, Camilla is increasingly regarded as a warm and down-to-earth figure, with her husband and son Prince William supporting her.

images.alt_text: Queen Mary's Crown has been removed from display at the Tower of London for modification work ahead of the Coronation of Britain's King Charles and Queen Camilla on May 6, in London.
A television interview broadcast on ITV of Britain's Prince Harry on Jan 8, 2023, ahead of the publication of his book, 'Spare'.

site_title: US dollar slips as banking sector fears ebb
summary: The US dollar fell 0.18% against a basket of currencies, nearing a seven-week low of 101.91, as investors regained confidence in the banking sector after First Citizens BancShares' agreement to buy Silicon Valley Bank's deposits and loans. The Australian dollar rose 0.39% and the euro reached a five-day high against the dollar as eurozone government bond yields rose. Analysts warn that the US dollar's recent sell-off may have been overdone, and the market may have moved too far, too fast in its dovish repricing of the Federal Open Market Committee's outlook.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index, which measures the currency against six rivals, rose 0.1 per cent at 103.09, having gained 0.5 per cent on Friday amid worries in the European banking sector.

site_title: AI search startup raises US$26 million to offer rival to Google
summary: Perplexity AI, a conversational search engine using artificial intelligence, has raised $26.6 million in funding led by New Enterprise Associates. The startup offers a new search model where users type simple queries and receive short answers generated by its AI systems. Perplexity's funding round includes Google's own AI researchers as investors. The company has also launched an iOS app, primarily catering to mobile traffic, and aims to loosen Google's hold on online search with its AI-powered search engine.

site_title: Potential Red Sea disaster could throw spotlight on the need for salvors
summary: The FSO Safer, a 1976-built VLCC, is anchored off Yemen's Red Sea coast with about a million barrels of crude oil on board. The UN Development Programme has bought a new tanker and plans to transfer the crude in an operation estimated to cost $130 million. If the oil spills, it could cause a catastrophic disaster, with estimated cleaning costs of $20 billion. The UN is trying to prevent a maritime disaster, and the International Salvage Union has expertise in preventing pollution. Salvors' industry body ISU has published a pollution prevention survey, highlighting the importance of maintaining a strong global salvage industry.

images.alt_text: Stranded ship Ever Given, one of the world's largest container ships, is seen after it ran aground, in Suez Canal, Egypt March 28, 2021. Suez Canal Authority/Handout via REUTERS ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY. NO RESALES. NO ARCHIVES##########nahcargo29##########

site_title: China is an oasis of clarity with upside for stocks
summary: China's economic indicators show modest improvement, with clear room for further growth, and a policy environment that provides clarity in uncertain global markets. The country's policymakers are unconstrained by inflation, with low headline inflation and core inflation, and are expected to continue supporting a gradual but sustained economic recovery. This underpins the expectation that China equities will outperform global equities in the coming months, driven by earnings growth of 15% in 2023 and valuations that are bound to improve.

images.alt_text: John Woods

site_title: EU countries approve 2035 phaseout of CO2-emitting cars
summary: EU countries have approved a landmark law requiring all new cars sold to have zero CO2 emissions by 2035, and 55% lower CO2 emissions by 2030, compared to 2021 levels. The law, which was delayed due to opposition from Germany, aims to drive the rapid decarbonization of new car fleets in Europe. However, Germany won an exemption for cars running on e-fuels, allowing them to continue selling CO2-emitting vehicles until 2035. The EU's climate policy is now set to enter into force.

site_title: Hyflux winds up two units over unpaid debts
summary: Hyflux Membrane Manufacturing and Hyflux Engineering, two subsidiaries of the now-defunct water treatment firm Hyflux, have been ordered to be wound up by the High Court following a successful application by the claimant, Tan Kok Quan Partnership. The two companies have not been able to pay the debt sought to be recovered and have current liabilities exceeding current assets. The winding-up order follows Hyflux's placement under judicial management in 2020 and its subsequent approval for winding up in 2021.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Lum is being sued by Hyflux for claims of at least S$690.6 million over alleged negligence and breach of fiduciary duty.
Hyflux's liquidators say they have received total proof of debt amounting to around S$1.5 billion, but the realisations from the asset sales are unlikely to exceed S$100 million.
The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority is finalising the outcome of its inspection on the audits by KPMG in its role as Hyflux’s external auditors.
Hyflux announced the Tuaspring project in 2011, and issued S$400 million worth of preference shares that year
Besides the criminal charges, Olivia Lum, founder and former chief of water treatment firm Hyflux, is also being sued by the liquidators and the Hyflux group.
If convicted, former Hyflux chief executive Olivia Lum will face imprisonment of up to seven years, a fine not exceeding S$250,000, or both, on each SFA charge

site_title: Singapore stocks end higher on Tuesday; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks ended higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) advancing 0.5% to 3,255.54 points, driven by gains from local banks and other sectors. The benchmark index rose despite rising recession fears and the global banking crisis, with investors turning to safer asset classes. Top advancers included Jardine Cycle & Carriage, UOB, DBS, and OCBC, while Venture Corporation was the biggest decliner.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Hong Kong’s benchmark Hang Seng Index climbed 1.1 per cent.
The MSCI World share index traded 0.6 per cent lower and Europe’s STOXX 600 index was down 1.6 per cent.
The US dollar index, which measures the currency against six rivals, rose 0.1 per cent at 103.09, having gained 0.5 per cent on Friday amid worries in the European banking sector.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Resale condominium units in Singapore saw a 50.3% increase in sales in February 2023, with 756 units sold, marking the first increase after four months. A new $200 million cold-chain logistics facility is set to create 130 jobs, while a portfolio of 11 HDB shophouses and a retail unit are up for sale at $52.2 million. Meanwhile, an independent financial adviser deemed GK Goh's offer to take the company private as "fair and reasonable." The Singapore stock market ended higher, with the STI up 0.5%, despite factors like the banking crisis and inflation.

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS reinstates coverage on Sembmarine, predicts a profitable FY2024
summary: DBS Group Research has reinstated coverage on Sembcorp Marine with a "buy" call and a target price of S$0.14. The analyst predicts the combined entity will turn profitable in FY2024, driven by a stronger balance sheet and combined order book of over S$17 billion. The group expects revenue of S$6.7 billion and net profit of S$214 million in FY2024, despite risks from investigations and oil price fluctuations.

images.alt_text: A signage of Sembcorp Marine.
This could be the year the stars align for Sembmarine

site_title: EU agrees on retaliation to counter economic coercion
summary: The European Union has agreed to allow retaliation against countries that exert undue economic pressure on EU members, such as China's trade restrictions on Lithuania. The EU's anti-coercion instrument (ACI) will enable the bloc to impose restrictions like higher import tariffs or limited access to EU public tenders if dialogue fails. The legislation, which should take effect in the second half of 2023, aims to counter a spillover of geopolitical tensions into trade and serve as a deterrent against economic coercion.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file photo taken on January 3, 2023 shows cranes and cargo ships at Nanjing port in China's eastern Jiangsu province. - China's exports in December fell the most since 2020, according to official figures released on January 13, 2023, after health restrictions hit the economy hard. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Portfolio of HDB shophouses, Peninsula Plaza retail unit for sale at S$52.2 million guide price
summary: A portfolio of 11 HDB shophouses and a retail unit in Peninsula Plaza is up for sale in Singapore at a guide price of S$52.2 million. The assets, including shophouses in mature residential hubs, are classified into two clusters, with the first cluster featuring seven shophouses leased to 7-Eleven on a long-term basis, offering an "attractive, stable and defensive income stream." The second cluster includes four shophouses and a retail unit, with all assets fully tenanted and offering immediate rental income.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
The $15.9 million guide price for the Housing and Development Board shophouses at Lorong 7 Toa Payoh translates to S$1,865 per square feet.
According to Huttons, rents of private homes are estimated to increase up to 10 per cent in H2 2022.
pixgenerics/ST20220629_202283358097/Ng Sor Luan/Generic photos of HDB flats for story on home loans rates increasing.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rise as banking contagion fears ease; China stocks fall
summary: Hong Kong's benchmark Hang Seng Index rose 1.1% on Tuesday as investor fears of deeper banking stress eased following the sale of Silicon Valley Bank to First Citizens BancShares. China's blue-chip CSI300 Index fell 0.3%, while Hong Kong tech stocks climbed 0.9%, with Tencent up 4.2%. China's Premier Li Qiang vowed to open up further to foreign investors and maintain economic expansion.

site_title: German regulator launches antitrust review of Microsoft
summary: Germany's antitrust regulator, the Bundeskartellamt, has launched an investigation into Microsoft's market power, potentially leading to an investigation of the US tech giant's business practices. The regulator will decide whether to designate Microsoft as a "company of paramount significance for competition across markets," which would allow it to take action against anti-competitive practices. This marks the first stage of a two-step process and does not yet involve an assessment of specific practices at the company. The Bundeskartellamt has previously designated Alphabet (Google) and Meta (Facebook) as companies of paramount significance.

images.alt_text: Microsoft licenses the data in its Bing search index to other companies that offer web search.  In February, it integrated a cousin of ChatGPT, OpenAI’s AI-powered chat technology, into Bing.
The surge comes after the UK Competition and Markets Authority narrowed the scope of their merger probe, putting the stock around 11 per cent below Microsoft’s US$95-per-share offer.

site_title: How do so many endangered creatures end up in Japan’s animal cafes?
summary: Japan's exotic animal cafes feature a wide variety of endangered and protected species, including slow lorises and radiated tortoises. A survey found 3,793 individual animals from 419 species, with 52 threatened with extinction. Many cafes allow customers to buy and take home animals, posing risks to animal welfare and conservation. Despite this, some owners claim to prioritize animal welfare and conservation, highlighting the need for regulation and oversight in the industry. The cafes' popularity with locals and tourists raises concerns about the long-term impact on these species and the environment.

images.alt_text: Trade in ivory is illegal in Vietnam but wildlife trafficking remains widespread.

Safari-goers watching elephants in South Africa. The African forest elephant is listed as “critically endangered”, and the African savanna elephant, “endangered” by the International Union for Conservation of Nature.

site_title: Philippines eyes military pension fix to avert ‘fiscal collapse’
summary: Philippine Finance Secretary Benjamin Diokno warned of a "fiscal collapse" if the government doesn't overhaul its military pension system, which is putting a strain on the national budget. The current system, which requires the state to fully fund pensions, is unsustainable and would lead to a fiscal collapse if not addressed. The government plans to require active and incoming soldiers to contribute to their pensions instead, and also stop indexing retirees' pensions to the salary of active personnel of similar rank. The reforms aim to free up fiscal space and narrow the fiscal shortfall.

site_title: In ‘Alma,’ flamenco star Sara Baras warms up
summary: Spanish flamenco star Sara Baras performed her show "Alma" at the New York City Center, marking her first time at the annual Flamenco Festival New York. The production, which features traditional flamenco rhythms and bolero-inspired music, showcases Baras' technical abilities and a more relaxed, warm stage presence. While the show still centers around Baras, she treats her dancers with a collegial affection, and the choreography includes moments of soulfulness and connection with the audience. The performance was well-received, with a standout bluesy sax solo by Diego Villegas.

images.alt_text: Whisky bottles and albums adorn the walls of Beatbox.
Duran Duran, formed in Birmingham, central England, in 1978, enjoyed huge success in Britain and the US, and have been seen as innovators in the then new medium of music videos.

site_title: Cryptoverse: Buoyant bitcoin’s losing its liquidity
summary: Bitcoin's price has jumped 40% to around $27,700 since March 10, but its market depth has reached its lowest level of liquidity in 10 months. According to data provider Kaiko, the market depth for the top two trading pairs is 5,600 bitcoin, equivalent to about $155 million, and slippage has increased by 2.5 times. This lack of liquidity can lead to wild price swings, and experts warn that complete replacements for collapsed liquidity providers are unlikely to emerge soon.

images.alt_text: The infamously volatile cryptocurrency seems positively hale and hearty, just as a banking meltdown drives markets into the arms of a recession.
Bitcoin has long traded in tandem with tech stocks, but that cord may be fraying just as smart-contract tokens increasingly take up its crypto super-growth mantle.

site_title: South Korea seeks ‘emergency’ plan to boost world’s lowest birthrate
summary: South Korea's President Yoon Suk Yeol has proposed an "emergency" plan to boost the country's low birthrate, which ranks as the lowest in the world. With a population expected to halve by the end of the century, the president aims to address the issue through initiatives such as expanded childcare services, improved working conditions for parents, and financial support for newlyweds. The government has spent over $200 billion in the past 16 years to increase the population, but experts suggest it may take decades to achieve a stable population rate of 2.1.

images.alt_text: Channel A's reality TV show "Living Together without Marriage" is filmed at a studio in Seoul, South Korea, Feb 24, 2023.

site_title: China’s new premier courts foreign CEOs with vow to open economy
summary: China's new Premier Li Qiang vowed to open the country's economy wider to the outside world, promising a "broad space" for foreign companies to develop. Li emphasized the importance of taking a long-term view amid economic challenges and stated that China's growth will provide new momentum for the world economy. The comments aim to reassure investors and international businesses about China's economic recovery and commitment to the global system.

images.alt_text: Anti-graft checks in China usually follow five-year cycles, with fresh rounds kicking off after the twice-a-decade party congress concludes.
