Global crypto firms scrambled to move funds away after the US banking crisis, with local companies such as crypto hedge fund MaiCapital — which held funds with Signature — urgently sought to open bank accounts in Hong Kong.

site_title: Binance CEO CZ has more than ‘FUD’ to worry him now
summary: Binance CEO Changpeng Zhao (CZ) is facing a lawsuit from the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) for alleged violations of derivatives regulations. The CFTC alleges Binance failed to register as a US derivatives exchange and intentionally structured its businesses to avoid US laws. CZ has denied the allegations, stating Binance does not trade for profit and follows trading policies. The lawsuit may shape the future of the crypto industry, which is grappling with the US government's increasing efforts to bring the industry into compliance with financial laws.

images.alt_text: The derivatives regulator said Binance shirked its obligations by not properly registering with it.
“Initial analysis indicates matching engine encountered a bug on a trailing stop order,” Binance chief executive Changpeng Zhao said in a tweet.
FILE PHOTO: Smartphone with displayed Binance logo and representation of cryptocurrencies placed on a keyboard in this illustration taken November 8, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: UK civil servants plan strike as school leaders reject offer
summary: UK civil servants plan a large-scale strike on April 28, following the rejection of a government pay offer by school leaders. The strike, which will also affect workers for the energy regulator Ofgem, is part of a month of proposed industrial unrest. The decision comes after education unions rejected a new pay offer for teachers, citing a one-time payment and a 4.3% rise as insufficient. The strike will be the culmination of a series of walkouts affecting the UK's schools, railways, hospitals, and postal service, putting pressure on Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's administration.

images.alt_text: Britain sought to end months of walk-outs in the healthcare sector by offering a 5 per cent wage increase for the coming year for 1 million nurses, paramedics, midwives and other workers in England.

site_title: Five things to note about Credit Suisse’s AT-1 bonds
summary: Credit Suisse has written down all of its Additional Tier-1 (AT-1) bonds to zero, leaving affected bondholders frustrated and confused. The move appears to depart from legitimate expectations of bondholders, who believe their investment ranks above equity investors in the capital structure. Several European regulators have publicly stated that bondholders will only bear losses after shareholders' equity is depleted. Affected bondholders are advised to consider dispute resolution options and review their bond documentation for applicable provisions.

images.alt_text: Lawyers advised investors to read the fine print in bond instruments carefully before buying.

epa10536140 A man walks past the logo of Credit Suisse in Hong Kong, China, 22 March 2023. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority said Credit Suisse’s assets in Hong Kong made up 0.5 percent of the banking system’s total assets. Credit Suisse was purchased by rival UBS for over 3 billion US dollar after the collapse of the Switzerland-based investment bank.  EPA-EFE/JEROME FAVRE
The Swiss bank first sold this form of notes in 2016 as a way of reducing the capital it was required to hold against operational risk.

site_title: US, Japan strike trade deal on electric vehicle battery minerals
summary: The US and Japan have struck a trade deal on electric vehicle battery minerals, aiming to counter China's dominance in the sector. The pact will expand access to tax breaks under the US Inflation Reduction Act for EVs using materials collected or processed in Japan. The deal is similar to an agreement with the European Union and will boost cooperation on critical mineral supply chains. The US and Japan will also refrain from imposing export duties on critical minerals traded between them and discuss non-market policies affecting trade in critical minerals, targeting countries such as China.

images.alt_text: Japanese public support for the cabinet of Prime Minister Fumio Kishida rose to 48 per cent, exceeding the disapproval rate for the first time in seven months, the Nikkei newspaper reported on Sunday.

site_title: Facebook owner Meta planning lower bonus payouts for some employees: WSJ
summary: Meta, the owner of Facebook, plans to lower bonus payouts for some employees, particularly those who received a "met most expectations" rating in their 2023 year-end reviews. The bonus multiplier will be cut to 65% from 85%, and the company will assess staff performance twice a year. This change is not related to workforce restructuring, which includes cutting 10,000 jobs this year.

site_title: Markets are wrong on US rate-cut bets: BlackRock
summary: BlackRock says US markets are wrong to expect imminent US rate cuts by the US Federal Reserve, citing a "new, more nuanced phase of curbing inflation" ahead. Despite fears of a banking crisis, the Fed will continue to raise interest rates, according to BlackRock Investment Institute strategists. This view clashes with TD Securities and DoubleLine Capital LP, who predict rate cuts as the risk of recession grows. BlackRock favours inflation-linked bonds, citing stubborn inflation and a tight labour market, and is retaining an underweight position in developed-market equities.

images.alt_text: Following the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank, the US Treasury, Federal Reserve and Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation stepped in to protect insured deposits – those up to US$250,000 per client.
A worsening and prolonged banking turmoil and sooner-than-expected pivot by the Fed amid persistent fear could set the bullion on a historic surge

site_title: HK regulators to host meeting to help crypto firms with banking
summary: Hong Kong regulators are hosting a meeting to help crypto firms establish banking relationships, amid efforts to establish the city as a hub for virtual assets. The joint session between the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Securities and Futures Commission will facilitate dialogue and share experiences on opening bank accounts. The move comes as the sector faces difficulties due to stringent know-your-customer and anti-money laundering rules, and follows a recent collapse in US crypto-friendly banks. A growing interest among Chinese state-owned lenders has also provided a positive development for the industry.

site_title: Commonwealth Capital’s new cold-chain logistics facility to create 130 jobs
summary: Singapore is set to gain a new $200 million cold-chain logistics facility, operated by Commonwealth Kokubu Logistics, which is expected to create up to 130 jobs. The facility, expected to be completed in 2025, will have a 500,000 square foot floor area and 80 million kg of cold storage capacity. The facility will enhance Singapore's standing as a trade and logistics hub, and increase the country's frozen warehouse capacity by over 80,000 pallet positions. The project aims to support Singapore's food security and supply-chain capabilities, and Commonwealth Capital plans to establish similar facilities across South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: Work to strengthen Singapore's crisis management is of "great urgency" due to the increasing risk of animal viruses spilling over to humans, with the climate crisis exacerbating this risk, said Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong.

Enhancing systems at key food supply facilities such as at Jurong Fishery Port would better support contract tracing and control measure enforcement, in the case of future disease outbreaks, says Zaqy.
Glico's newest Pocky factory in Karawang is its largest, with a total floor space of 57,000 square metres.

site_title: China’s Nio opens trial for high-speed EV battery swapping stations
summary: China's Nio begins trial operation of high-speed EV battery swapping stations, aiming to reduce service costs and speed up swapping to under 5 minutes. The Power Swap Station 3.0 can store up to 21 battery packs and is part of Nio's push to make battery swapping a viable alternative to rapid-charging technology. The company plans to operate 900 of the latest power swap stations globally by year-end, following 1,323 stations already in operation.

images.alt_text: Ford Motor’s Mach-E electric sport utility vehicle is down to a starting price of 209,900 yuan, about a third cheaper than in the US.
The company sold 122,486 cars in 2022, up 34 per cent from a year earlier after introducing a new sport utility vehicle and two sedans.
BYD is staking a claim to the mid-market where the Japanese companies operate, with a line up of electric models such as the crossover SUV Song PLUS, starting from 140,000 yuan.

site_title: Crisis averted, but market gets wrong signals
summary: The US Treasury, Federal Reserve, and Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation stepped in to protect insured deposits at Silicon Valley Bank, the second-largest bank failure in US history, by backing deposits beyond the $250,000 limit. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen clarified that the government would not provide blanket insurance to all banks, but would use emergency actions to prevent contagion. The move aims to calm financial markets and prevent a broader banking crisis, but may send the wrong signal to financial markets about the government's willingness to intervene.

images.alt_text: Circumstances that caused Credit Suisse to fail are to a degree unique. But like all banks, it grappled with a common backdrop of markedly higher interest rates which spurred a revaluation of risk.
The closed gates of Credit Suisse's headquarters in Zurich, Switzerland. Perhaps we will look back on these few weeks as the time when the era of free market truisms ended.
Customers wait in line outside a branch of the Silicon Valley Bank in Wellesley, Massachusetts, US, March 13, 2023.

site_title: Japanese telecom carrier KDDI joins Oasys gaming blockchain
summary: Japanese telecom carrier KDDI has joined gaming blockchain network Oasys, becoming the second Japanese telecom operator to do so after SoftBank in February. As a validator, KDDI will help secure and verify transactions on the blockchain, while also collaborating with Oasys in gaming and entertainment areas. This move aligns with KDDI's earlier launch of digital asset services, including a digital wallet, streaming, and virtual shopping.

site_title: TransitLink, EZ-Link apps to merge; commuters to get one-stop access to bus, MRT fare payment services
summary: TransitLink and EZ-Link apps to merge, offering one-stop access to bus and MRT fare payment services. The merger aims to simplify the experience for commuters, eliminating confusing processes. The Land Transport Authority (LTA) plans to integrate the services into one app by mid-2024, with the goal of merging the companies into a single entity in the second half of 2024.

images.alt_text: Under the new collaboration, C&C would lease Gogoro 2 Series Smartscooters to foodpanda riders, who can swap out depleted batteries for new ones in seconds at battery swapping stations.
Starting from Mar 31, there will no longer be peak or off-peak charges but instead a single all-day charge.
ST Engineering is withdrawing from the development of autonomous buses, given the "significant" financial resources required.

site_title: BlackRock can’t compete with free Advil in China pension race
summary: BlackRock, a leading global investment firm, is struggling to gain traction in China's trillion-dollar pension market. Despite being allowed to join the market due to its experience with a previous trial, BlackRock has yet to issue any products. Local residents, like logistics executive Judy Deng, are hesitant to invest with foreign companies, citing unfamiliarity with their operations. This suggests that BlackRock faces stiff competition from local banks and financial institutions, making it challenging for the firm to attract clients in the Chinese pension market.

images.alt_text: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) has completed redevelopment works at Toh Guan Road East.

The product “mainly invests in a mutual fund managed by BlackRock Investment Management (UK) Limited and would help qualified domestic investors ... diversify assets globally,” CR Trust said in a statement.
Japan’s government is likely to appoint academic Kazuo Ueda as the next Bank of Japan governor when Haruhiko Kuroda’s second term ends in April.

site_title: Allianz applies to set up new fund management unit in China
summary: Allianz Global Investors has filed an application to set up a new fund management unit in China, seeking Beijing's approval to expand in the world's second-largest economy. The move marks a major step for the German financial conglomerate to boost its presence in China's mutual fund market, establishing a greenfield fund unit in addition to a Sino-foreign joint venture it originally formed in 2003. This is the latest from a growing list of foreign asset managers, including BlackRock, Fidelity International, and Schroders, to establish wholly-owned fund units locally.

site_title: EU reaches deal to roll out car charging points across bloc
summary: The European Union has reached a deal to install electric and hydrogen charging points across the region by 2026, 2028, and 2031. The plan aims to support the transition from combustion engines, with charging stations for cars every 60 km and trucks every 120 km. The deal also aims to make 90% of heavy-duty vehicles zero-emission by 2040, and all new cars sold in the EU emissions-free by 2035. The agreement is seen as a crucial step in reducing emissions and making driving and charging electric cars as simple and convenient as driving a petrol-powered vehicle.

site_title: Merdeka Battery plans Indonesia’s 2nd-largest 2023 IPO
summary: PT Merdeka Battery Materials, an Indonesian nickel producer, plans to raise up to 9.62 trillion rupiah (S$846 million) through its initial public offering (IPO). The company aims to develop a high-pressure acid leaching plant in Sulawesi island to produce 120,000 tons of nickel per year. The IPO proceeds will be used to repay a US$300 million loan facility and work capital. This is set to be Indonesia's second-largest IPO this year, following PT Trimegah Bangun Persada's Harita Nickel.

site_title: Gold edges higher on softer dollar; banking optimism limits appeal
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,958.85 per ounce on Tuesday as the US dollar eased, making bullion more affordable for buyers holding other currencies. The dollar index fell 0.1%, despite efforts by regulators to contain banking system worries. Investors scaled back on safe-haven trading, instead focusing on riskier assets. Higher interest rates tend to discourage investment in non-yielding bullion, with the US Federal Reserve likely to keep interest rates steady in its May meeting.

images.alt_text: US  gold futures fell 0.3 per cent to US$1,977.20 on Monday.

site_title: India’s US$1 trillion bond market sees rising clout of insurers
summary: India's sovereign bond market is seeing a significant shift as the country's growing wealth is being invested in long-term debt, led by insurers and pension funds. The market's yield curve has flattened, with insurers snapping up 10-to-40-year debt, reducing the government's reliance on banks and easing concerns over funding infrastructure projects. Insurers now own 26% of government bonds, up from 22% in 2010, and are expected to continue growing their demand for long-maturity bonds, driven by a thriving derivative trade and a desire for guaranteed returns.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) seal is pictured on a gate outside the RBI headquarters in Mumbai, India, February 2, 2016. REUTERS / File photo
India has become a major consumer of Russian crude, turning the Opec+ producer’s oil into fuels that are often shipped to other regions such as Europe and the US.

site_title: Asia: Shares up as bank crisis fears ease
summary: Asia's shares rose on Tuesday, March 28, as global markets rebounded from fears of a banking crisis, with Silicon Valley Bank's sale easing concerns. Bank shares led the gains, with Hong Kong, Sydney, and Seoul rising. Tokyo and Shanghai were nearly flat, while Taipei dropped 0.8%. The World Bank warned of a potential economic slowdown in China, but analysts say the banking crisis fears are easing, providing investors with breathing room ahead of key data releases.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong was nearly two per cent lower in Monday morning trade, with Shanghai down 0.7 per cent.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Tuesday’s open after mixed close on Wall Street; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.5% on Tuesday, driven by a positive start for banking stocks following the news that First Citizens BancShares would acquire Silicon Valley Bank's deposits and loans. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 15.75 points to 3,254.78. Banking stocks led the gains, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC advancing 0.1%, 0.8%, and 0.5% respectively. Other active index counters included CapitaLand Investment and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
The benchmark Straits Times Index ended the first trading day of the week with a gain of 0.8 per cent or 26.39 points to 3,239.03.
The parent company of Boustead Projects garners 95.5 per cent in shareholding interest of the unit.

site_title: FDIC deals for failed SVB, Signature Bank included sweeteners
summary: The FDIC struck deals with First Citizens BancShares Inc. and New York Community Bancorp to acquire Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) and Signature Bank, respectively. The FDIC offered First Citizens a $70 billion credit line and NYCB a similar deal worth up to $300 million, with the goal of resolving the bank failures quickly and preventing a crisis. The deals included sweeteners, such as equity appreciation rights and a 20% earning-per-share boost for NYCB. The FDIC aimed to minimize costs and maintain the deposit insurance fund's solvency, while also providing liquidity to the acquiring banks.

images.alt_text: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. headquarters in Washington, DC. Photographer: Al Drago/Bloomberg

site_title: Food prices push UK shop price inflation to new high: BRC
summary: The UK's shop price inflation rose to 8.9% in March, its highest in at least 18 years, driven by soaring food prices. The British Retail Consortium attributed the increase to rising sugar costs, poor harvests in Europe, and a weakening pound. Fruit and vegetable prices also rose due to import costs. Annual consumer price inflation, including services, reached 10.4% in February, a 41-year high. The BRC's chief executive, Helen Dickinson, warned that shop price inflation has yet to peak.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People shop next to the clubcard price branding inside a branch of a Tesco Extra Supermarket in London, Britain, February 10, 2022. Picture taken February 10, 2022. REUTERS/Paul Childs/File Photo

site_title: GSK posts strong results for cancer drug it sees as blockbuster
summary: GSK's cancer drug Jemperli, also known as dostarlimab, showed strong results in a trial for endometrial cancer, reducing disease progression and risk of death in 72% of patients. The drug, combined with chemotherapy, helped 36% of patients overall. GSK is planning to apply for another US approval in the first half of the year and is seeking to expand its use to treat several types of cancer. The results strengthen GSK's belief in Jemperli's potential to transform cancer treatment, with the company investing heavily in the drug.

images.alt_text: GSK headquarters in London. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: Red Bull family’s US$8 billion wealth boom tops all Asia dynasties
summary: The Red Bull family, led by the Thai Yoovidhya family, has seen a significant wealth boom, adding $7.8 billion to their fortune since 2022, surpassing all other Asian dynasties. Their stake in privately held Red Bull GmbH has contributed to the massive gain, with the company posting record revenue last year, selling over 11 billion cans. The Yoovidhyas' wealth now stands at over $27 billion, with the majority coming from their Red Bull stake. Despite controversies, the family is expected to maintain its control over the business, with the next generation facing challenges such as growing competition and market-dominance abuse concerns.

images.alt_text: Red Bull energy drink cans are seen in a supermarket in Bangkok, Thailand, August 4, 2020. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha

site_title: Takeover target of Nintendo family office asks for Japan government probe
summary: A Japanese construction company, Toyo Construction, is seeking a government probe into alleged breaches of foreign ownership rules by Yamauchi-No 10 Family Office (YFO), which owns 27% of the company. Toyo claims YFO failed to notify the government before acquiring its stake, violating regulations. YFO has denied the claims, stating it followed proper procedures and is not intimidated by "groundless claims". The move highlights the increasing role of national security in takeover battles, particularly in Japan.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man stands in front of Nintendo's logo at the presentation ceremony of its new game console Switch in Tokyo, Japan January 13, 2017. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo

site_title: Boustead Singapore garners 95.5% of real estate unit Boustead Projects at offer close
summary: Boustead Singapore's voluntary unconditional cash offer for real estate player Boustead Projects closed on Monday with 95.5% of shares owned, surpassing the 95% required. The offeror's parent company will request trading suspension from Tuesday's market open. Boustead Projects must restore its free float or provide a 'fair and reasonable' exit offer, with limited options available, including selling down shares or issuing new shares to public shareholders.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

site_title: Harita Nickel raises US$659 million in Jakarta IPO priced at top
summary: Indonesian metal and mining firm Harita Nickel raised about US$659 million through its initial public offering (IPO) priced at the top of a marketed range. The company sold about 8 billion shares at 1,250 rupiah (S$0.10) apiece. This surpasses the marketed range of 1,220 rupiah to 1,250 rupiah. A representative for the company declined to comment on the transaction.

images.alt_text: Harita operates the country’s first high-pressure acid leaching (HPAL) smelter on Obi island in North Maluku.

site_title: Six habits of highly effective investors
summary: Investing early and developing good habits can significantly impact one's portfolio. Six habits of highly effective investors include: (1) starting to invest as early as possible to harness the power of compound interest, (2) drilling down to the fundamentals of each investment, (3) maintaining a long-term view to avoid short-term market fluctuations, (4) reinvesting dividends and capital gains to accelerate compounding, (5) sticking to an investment plan with clear goals and guidelines, and (6) taking care of one's downside by assessing risks and avoiding big losses. By adopting these habits, investors can make their investment process more efficient and achieve better results.

site_title: Credit Suisse’s catastrophe bonds could outlive the bank
summary: Credit Suisse's catastrophe bonds, designed to insure the bank against operational risks such as fraud and accounting errors, could outlive the bank itself, according to DBRS Morningstar. These bonds, issued in 2016, have not been triggered or written down despite the bank's government-brokered sale to UBS. DBRS Morningstar's Marcos Alvarez stated that the bonds will not be triggered or redeemed in the short term, as the coverage will be novated to the surviving entity, UBS.

images.alt_text: epa10536140 A man walks past the logo of Credit Suisse in Hong Kong, China, 22 March 2023. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority said Credit Suisse’s assets in Hong Kong made up 0.5 percent of the banking system’s total assets. Credit Suisse was purchased by rival UBS for over 3 billion US dollar after the collapse of the Switzerland-based investment bank.  EPA-EFE/JEROME FAVRE

site_title: After doling out huge loans, China is now bailing out countries
summary: China has emerged as a new heavyweight lender of last resort, providing $240 billion in emergency financing to debt-ridden countries since 2021, surpassing the International Monetary Fund (IMF). The country has been helping countries with strategic locations or significant natural resources, with loans often at adjustable rates. China charges higher interest rates, typically 5%, compared to the IMF's 2%. The country's Belt and Road Initiative has enabled it to lend $900 billion to 151 lower-income countries, with some accusing China of "debt trap diplomacy." China's role as a lender of last resort reflects its growing economic superpower status and efforts to limit reliance on the US dollar.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Chinese national flag is pictured, following the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, in Shanghai, China, October 14, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Mastercard, Visa among firms in talks to buy fintech Pismo
summary: Mastercard and Visa are in talks to acquire fintech company Pismo, which provides cloud-based payment and banking platforms. Pismo is being valued at around $1 billion and has investors including SoftBank Latin America Fund, Amazon.com, and Redpoint Ventures. The negotiations are ongoing, and a deal has not been reached, with the talks potentially ending without an agreement. Pismo's platforms allow banks and financial companies to rapidly launch products for various payment services.

images.alt_text: Visa and Mastercard credit cards are displayed for a photograph in Tiskilwa, Illinois, U.S., on Tuesday, Sept. 18, 2018. Visa Inc. and Mastercard Inc. agreed to pay as much as $6.2 billion to end a long-running price-fixing case brought by merchants over card fees, the largest-ever class action settlement of an antitrust case. Photographer: Daniel Acker/Bloomberg

site_title: Nvidia shows new research on using AI to improve chip designs
summary: Nvidia released a paper on using artificial intelligence to improve chip design, aiming to optimize transistor placement for better chip performance, cost, and power consumption. The research combined reinforcement learning with a second layer of AI, surpassing previous findings by Google. According to Nvidia chief scientist Bill Dally, the industry's reliance on cheaper transistors is slowing progress, and more clever design is needed to deliver value to customers. This approach contradicts Gordon Moore's prediction of decreasing chip costs, highlighting the need for innovative design solutions.

images.alt_text: A smartphone with a displayed NVIDIA logo is placed on a computer motherboard in this illustration taken March 6, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

site_title: Asean must ensure path is right after bold step on coal financing
summary: Asean's Taxonomy Board has established a framework for coal's phase-out to secure sustainable financing, a necessary step in the fight against climate change. The move is a bold step in the right direction, but the Board must regularly assess its effectiveness and be prepared to sunset the transition framework if needed. The phase-out of coal is crucial to avoid the worst of climate change, given its significant contribution to global electricity generation.

images.alt_text: This photo taken on September 21, 2021 shows smoke from coal combustion rising from the chimneys at the Suralaya coal power plant in Cilegon. - Smokestacks belch noxious fumes into the air from a massive coal-fired power plant on the Indonesian coast, a stark illustration of Asia's addiction to the fossil fuel which is threatening climate targets. (Photo by BAY ISMOYO / AFP) / TO GO WITH Climate-UN-COP26-Asia-coal,FEATURE by Haeril Halim and Sam Reeves

site_title: Condo resale volumes rise 50.3% in February; first increase after four months: SRX, 99.co
summary: Resale condo volumes in Singapore rose 50.3% in February, driven by pent-up demand after the Chinese New Year period. This marks the first increase in resale volumes since October 2022. The highest transacted price in February was S$20.5 million for a resale unit at Nassim Park Residences. Despite the increase, sales volumes were still lower than the five-year average and 4.2% lower than February 2022. Analysts note that the property market faces headwinds from global economic uncertainties, but a smaller interest rate hike by the US Fed may support the resale condo market.

images.alt_text: Condominiums and HDB flats as viewed from Ghim Moh Link on Feb 17, 2023. Can be used for stories on money, property, land, invest, budget, income, finance, financial, URA, HDB, housing, marriage, fertility, BTO, population, economy, and development.
Jessie Lim

site_title: Australian bank worries turn from chaos overseas to profits at home
summary: Australia's major banks, despite being influenced by the overseas banking crisis, are unlikely to be caught in turmoil due to post-global financial crisis reforms. A stress test by an Australian prudential regulator found bank capital would remain above minimum levels in a worst-case scenario, including a 43% house price drop and 11% unemployment. The banks are instead focusing on managing competition in the home loan market and attracting deposits, which is reducing their margins. Despite this, wholesale funding costs are rising, requiring major banks to refinance hundreds of billions in debt.

images.alt_text: The Central Business District (CBD) skyline is pictured at sunset in Sydney, Australia, June 4, 2021. REUTERS/Loren Elliott

site_title: Kuroda says BOJ needs to be ready to issue digital yen
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that the central bank needs to be prepared to issue digital yen, a central bank digital currency (CBDC), to coexist with other forms of money. The BOJ will launch a pilot programme in April to test the digital yen, aiming to be ready in case the government decides to issue a digital currency. This move follows a growing trend of countries, including China, launching CBDCs. Kuroda emphasized the importance of flexibility in responding to changing circumstances, highlighting the need for the BOJ to be prepared for a digital payment system.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man walks in front of the headquarters of Bank of Japan in Tokyo, Japan, January 18, 2023.   REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo

site_title: Strengthen regulation against greenwashing
summary: Corporates are exploiting consumers' and investors' enthusiasm for sustainability by engaging in "greenwashing," making misrepresentations about their environmental practices. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) has warned that limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius is achievable, but requires immediate action to cut emissions. Companies' pursuit of profits is undermining efforts to address the climate crisis, highlighting the need for stronger regulation against greenwashing.

images.alt_text: Hands painting pollution blue and polluting chimneys green. Greenwashing malpractice concept.

site_title: British Airways to cut Easter flights due to Heathrow worker strikes
summary: British Airways will reduce its Easter flights due to planned strikes by London Heathrow Airport employees, canceling 32 flights a day from March 31. The airline has made the adjustments following Heathrow's requirement to limit passenger numbers during the strike. This decision affects passengers traveling to and from Heathrow during the Easter holiday weekend.

images.alt_text: British Airways planes sit on the tarmac at London Heathrow airport on Tuesday, November 5, 2002.  British Airways is leading European carriers in cutting costs, planning to reduce its workforce 23 percent to 43,500 employees and save 650 million pounds a year by 2004. Photographer: DD/Bloomberg News.

site_title: GK Goh independent financial adviser deems privatisation offer ‘fair and reasonable’
summary: Independent financial adviser Deloitte & Touche Corporate Finance recommends GK Goh shareholders accept a S$1.26 per-share offer to take the company private. The offer price is deemed "fair and reasonable" after considering market quotations, liquidity, historical market performance, and the company's financials. If successful, the offeror plans to restructure GK Goh's asset mix. The proposed delisting and privatisation are seen as a positive move for shareholders.

images.alt_text: private, privacy, green
Yong Hui Ting

site_title: Australian retail sales decelerate as rate hikes crimp spending
summary: Australian retail sales slowed in February, with a 0.2% increase from the previous month, as households continue to pull back on discretionary spending due to high cost of living pressures. This marks a levelling-out of spending after a surge in January and a decline in December. The Reserve Bank of Australia's aggressive interest rate increases since May 2022 are believed to be contributing to the slowdown in spending.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A worker pushing a trolley walks with pedestrians past the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) head office in central Sydney, Australia, March 7, 2017. Picture taken March 7, 2017.   REUTERS/David Gray/File Photo

site_title: Israeli government in chaos as judicial reform plans draw mass protests
summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's coalition is in chaos as mass protests over judicial reform plans continue, with tens of thousands of protesters returning to the streets in Tel Aviv and Jerusalem. The protests, which began after the sacking of Netanyahu's defense chief, have led to a general strike and threaten to break apart the nationalist-religious coalition. The plans, seen as a threat to democracy, had been suspended, but Netanyahu's government remains under pressure to halt the overhaul of the judiciary. The situation remains volatile, with the future of the government uncertain.

site_title: Thomas Zilliacus, a reported bidder for Manchester United, and his ties with Singapore
summary: Thomas Zilliacus, a reported bidder for Manchester United, is also known in Singapore as the former chairman of YuuZoo Networks, a suspended company. Zilliacus has ties to Singapore investors and has experience in the country's financial sector, including as the Asia head of Nokia. He submitted a bid to buy Manchester United through his investment firm, XXI Century Capital, which will finance half of the club's purchase price, with the remaining half paid by Manchester United fans. His bid is reportedly on the same level as those tabled by billionaire Jim Ratcliffe and Sheikh Jassim Hamad Al Thani.

images.alt_text: Thomas Zilliacus, chief executive officer of YuuZoo Corp., stands for a photograph before a Bloomberg Television interview in Singapore, on Wednesday, Sept. 16, 2014. Zilliacus sees huge opportunity in China for the Singapore-listed social e-commerce network operator. Photographer: Bryan van der Beek/Bloomberg
Jessie Lim

site_title: In a first, Asean allows coal phase-out to raise sustainable financing
summary: Southeast Asia's Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) has allowed coal phase-out to access sustainable financing through the inclusion of coal phase-out in its taxonomy. The second version of Asean taxonomy for sustainable finance provides clear conditions for coal phase-out to obtain transition financing, enabling coal-reliant countries to pay for decarbonization and a 'just transition'. This marks the first time any regional taxonomy has specified such conditions, paving the way for Asean's numerous coal-fired power plants to access transition financing if they retire assets in a timely manner.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
Asean has much to recommend itself to clean energy investors, but the region’s economic development model remains based on fossil fuels. PHOTO:

site_title: The BRI transformation makes it a more – not less – useful tool for China
summary: China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) has undergone significant changes since its inception in 2013. Initially aimed at improving connectivity in trade, investment, people-to-people, and financial cooperation, the BRI has shifted towards a more security-oriented concept, with a focus on expanding China's influence globally. The US-China rivalry and worsening relations have damaged the BRI's image, but China continues to promote the initiative through new frameworks like the "Community with a shared future for mankind" and the Global Development and Security Initiatives. The BRI has transformed into a vehicle for China's UN engagement, elevating its role in global development and security discourse.

images.alt_text: People near a mine operated by MMG Las Bambas, in a region where locals claim mining activity has negatively affected crop yields and killed livestock, outside of Cusco, Peru October 14, 2021.
Construction of the Luang Prabang Railway Bridge near Luang Prabang in Laos in 2018. This project is part of the Belt and Road Initiative.
Asean and BRI: Opportunity amid adversity

site_title: China anti-graft agency to inspect major state-owned companies
summary: China's Central Commission for Discipline Inspection will inspect over 30 major state-owned enterprises, including China Investment and PetroChina, under the new leadership of the Communist Party. The inspection is part of the agency's first major scrutiny and follows the twice-a-decade party congress, which granted President Xi Jinping a third term as party leader. The move aims to tackle corruption and ensure accountability among top officials.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Chinese national flag is seen in Beijing, China April 29, 2020. REUTERS/Thomas Peter/File Photo

site_title: Disney begins the first round of 7,000 expected job cuts
summary: Disney has begun its first round of 7,000 expected job cuts as part of a $5.5 billion savings drive. The first group of employees will be notified over the next four days, with a second, larger round expected in April. The company, under CEO Bob Iger, aims to improve financial performance, particularly in its streaming TV businesses, which lost over $1 billion in the quarter ending in December. The cuts will affect various parts of the company, including theme parks and ESPN sports networks.

images.alt_text: Walt Disney Studios in Burbank, California. Photographer: Eric Thayer/Bloomberg

site_title: Oil rises over US$3 on Kurdistan export halt, banking optimism
summary: Oil prices rose over $3 on Monday, driven by a halt to exports from Iraq's Kurdistan region, which accounts for about half a percent of the global oil supply. The stoppage, due to an arbitration decision requiring Baghdad's consent, has added to concerns about oil supplies. However, a US banking acquisition and easing of financial turmoil worries have also supported prices. Brent crude futures rose 4.2% to $78.12, while West Texas Intermediate US crude closed 5.1% higher at $72.81.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures fell by 78 cents, or 1 per cent, to settle at US$75.91 a barrel on Thursday.

site_title: World Bank warns of 'lost decade' in global growth without bold policy shifts
summary: The World Bank warns that the global economy is heading for a "lost decade" of low growth, with potential GDP growth expected to slump to a three-decade low of 2.2% per year through 2030. To reverse this trend, policymakers must adopt bold initiatives to boost investment, productivity, and labor force participation. However, concerted efforts to boost investment in sustainable sectors, cut trade costs, and leverage growth in services could boost potential GDP growth by up to 0.7 percentage point to 2.9%.

images.alt_text: There is no escaping the extreme level of uncertainty due to the spillovers from the Silicon Valley bank's collapse, among other US regional banks.

site_title: Small US banks lose US$109 billion in deposits in a single week
summary: US small banks lost $109 billion in deposits in a single week, while large banks gained $120 billion, according to Federal Reserve data. This shift occurred amid a banking crisis following the failures of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank. Small banks' total deposits fell 1.5% in the week, marking the first annual decline since 1986. Deposits also left the country's banking system for money-market mutual funds, with growth of $121 billion in those funds. The trend suggests a decline in US banking system deposits of $53 billion for the week.

images.alt_text: An employee inspecting a solar panel for defects at the module production line at REC Solar ASA manufacturing facility in Tuas on 5 September 2014.

site_title: Manulife US Reit clarifies US bank exposure after share price falls 14%
summary: Manulife US Reit clarified its US bank exposure after its share price fell 14% following news of US regional banks' troubles. The real estate investment trust's manager stated that none of its lenders are regional banks, and its loans are mainly secured by international banks and Singaporean lenders. The company has a fully drawn unsecured sustainability-linked loan facility to refinance its US$105 million mortgage loan. A potential transaction involving Mirae Asset is ongoing, with due diligence currently underway.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

site_title: Housing market in tech hubs cooling faster than other parts of US
summary: US housing markets in tech hubs, such as Seattle, San Jose, and Austin, are cooling faster than other parts of the country due to layoffs in the tech industry and elevated mortgage rates. Decades-high inflation and interest rate hikes, along with weak consumer demand and an economic slowdown, are contributing factors. Redfin's report notes that uncertainty around the banking and tech industries is deterring buyers, with some cancelling contracts or bowing out of their search for a home. The New York metro area is also expected to feel the impact of banking turmoil.

site_title: China banks court crypto firms in Hong Kong after mainland ban
summary: China's state-owned banks have been reaching out to crypto firms in Hong Kong, offering banking services or making inquiries, amid the US banking crisis. This move suggests China's push to become a major digital asset centre has Beijing's backing, despite a ban on crypto trading on the mainland. At least three Chinese banks, Bank of Communications, Bank of China, and Shanghai Pudong Development Bank, have made contact with local crypto firms, with some even visiting their offices to pitch their services.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A representation of cryptocurrencies in this illustration taken, January 24, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Rolex wows fans with new Daytona, zany dials, and a totally new watch
summary: Rolex unveiled several new timepieces at the Watches and Wonders trade show in Geneva, including the 60th-anniversary Oyster Perpetual Cosmograph Daytona, featuring a new movement and aesthetic adjustments. The brand also introduced the Perpetual 1908, a new watch named after its creation year, and the GMT Master-II in 18-carat yellow gold. Additionally, Rolex released the Oyster Perpetual "Celebration" Dial, featuring a colorful bubbled motif, and the Oyster Perpetual Day-Date 36 with an inspirational keyword display.

site_title: Potential sale of Manulife US Reit’s manager to Mirae calls into question steadfastness of its sponsor
summary: Manulife US Reit's Reit manager, owned by sponsor Manulife, is reportedly being sold to Korean asset manager Mirae Asset Global Investments. The potential deal raises concerns among investors, as a change of sponsor is not what they had been hoping for. Manulife US Reit's leverage has risen to 49% after a 10.9% decline in portfolio valuation, and investors are worried about the potential for a "golden parachute" for the sponsor despite the Reit's poor performance. The deal has sparked debate over governance and the alignment of interests between the external manager and unitholders.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
The valuation of Figueroa in Los Angeles declined by 33.1 per cent last year
Mirae Asset is said to be buying Manulife US Real Estate Management for some 200 billion won (S$206.4 million).

site_title: Europe: Shares rebound as banking jitters ebb on SVB deal
summary: European stocks rose 1.1% on Monday, rebounding from a week of turbulence over banking sector concerns. The Stoxx 600 index recovered after news of First Citizens BancShares acquiring Silicon Valley Bank's deposits and loans. European banks rose 1.4%, with UBS shares up 1.1%, while healthcare stocks led the gains, up 1.9%. Despite concerns over the banking sector, an Ifo institute survey showed German business morale unexpectedly rose in March, adding to signs of economic resilience.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index falls 1.4 per cent, but still posts a weekly gain supported by a sharp recovery earlier this week.

site_title: Saudi Aramco boosts China investment in two refinery deals
summary: Saudi Aramco has agreed to acquire a 10% stake in privately controlled Rongsheng Petrochemical for $3.6 billion, bolstering its investment in China. The deal includes a joint venture in northeast China and an expanded stake in Rongsheng Petrochemical, providing 690,000 barrels of crude oil daily. This marks a significant boost to Aramco's position as China's top crude oil supplier.

images.alt_text: Aramco will construct a refinery and petrochemical complex in Liaoning Province with North Huajin Chemical and Panjin Xincheng.

site_title: SVB failure casts a chill across Asean’s climate startups landscape
summary: Silicon Valley Bank's collapse has cast a chill across Southeast Asia's climate startups, with concerns about potential liquidity problems and tightening credit conditions. Climate tech startups and venture capitalists have expressed worries about their access to affordable global capital, despite assurances from regulators that deposit accounts are guaranteed. The collapse has also highlighted the need for deposit insurance and asset diversification. While some investors remain optimistic about the long-term growth of climate tech, others are cautious about the current funding landscape, which may favor established companies over new startups.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Deposits at small banks fall US$119 billion to US$5.46 trillion in the week ended March 15.

ChatGPT set off massive investment because “ninety-plus per cent of venture capitalists are actually very risk averse. Until you see a real application, people don’t really dive in,” Samir Kaul, a founding partner at Khosla Ventures said.
JPMorgan, the nation’s largest bank, told all employees they “should never give the appearance of exploiting a situation of stress or uncertainty”.

site_title: Comedy is suffering because ‘you have to be careful’ now, says Aniston
summary: Jennifer Aniston expressed concerns that comedy has become too cautious, making it difficult for comedians to make fun of themselves and life. In an interview, she stated that the need to be "very careful" has made it challenging for comedians to create humor that is self-deprecating and lighthearted, instead of policing every word.

images.alt_text: Aubrey Plaza in the second season of The White Lotus, which was filmed at San Domenico Palace, a Four Seasons resort hotel in Taormina, Sicily.
Netflix is lowering prices in countries that account for a small percentage of its subscriber base.

Tennis balls at the Australian Open tournament in Melbourne. This week, Netflix’s latest sports documentary series, Full Swing, which focuses on men’s professional golf, became available, just weeks after its tennis-focused series, Break Point, debuted.
'Friends' actor James Michael Tyler dies at 59

site_title: Tesla overcomes Australia’s EV hostility with surge in sales
summary: Tesla has seen a surge in sales in Australia, overcoming the country's initial reluctance to adopt electric vehicles. The company's supply chain issues have subsided, with wait times for new Tesla models now under a week. Second-hand Model 3 prices have also decreased, with some selling for under the price of a new model. Australia's current Labor government has introduced tax exemptions on new EVs and is examining fuel-efficiency standards to boost the adoption of electric cars. The percentage of EVs in Australia has increased from 1% to 6.8% in a year, with Tesla's Model 3 being the country's third-best selling car.

images.alt_text: Ford Motor’s Mach-E electric sport utility vehicle is down to a starting price of 209,900 yuan, about a third cheaper than in the US.
CATL has reported net income for the 12 months ended Dec 31 of 30.72 billion yuan (S$6 billion), an increase of 92.9 per cent from the previous year.
Tesla's Model Y at the opening ceremony of the new Tesla Gigafactory for electric cars in Gruenheide, Germany. Shares in Tesla have rallied this year, but are still down 51 per cent from a 2022 high.
Prices of Tesla’s Model S cars were cut by US$5,000.
Tesla’s initial spending in the plant will involve between US$5 billion and US$6 billion in a first stage before likely reaching a US$10 billion investment in different phases, the governor said.

site_title: Sembcorp’s solar and energy storage project in Indonesia terminated
summary: Sembcorp Industries has terminated a joint-development agreement with Indonesian companies PLN Batam and Trisurya Mitra Bersama to build a 1 Gigawatt peak solar and energy storage project in the Batam, Bintan, and Karimun region. The project was planned to generate approximately 1 GWp of solar power, but all parties have mutually agreed to end the joint-development agreement and the consortium has been dissolved.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Sembcorp to build integrated solar and energy storage systems with Indonesia's PLN Batam and Suryagen

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as SVB deal eases bank crisis worries
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Monday after a buyout deal for Silicon Valley Bank's deposits and loans calmed banking sector worries. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 39.19 points, or 0.12%, to 32,276.72. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained, with the S&P 500 rising 11.94 points, or 0.30%, to 3,982.93, and the Nasdaq Composite gaining 44.58 points, or 0.38%, to 11,868.54. The deal eased concerns about bank stress, contributing to the positive market start.

site_title: China will maintain certain level of growth amid transition: Premier Li
summary: Chinese Premier Li Qiang stated that China will maintain a certain level of economic growth as it transitions to higher quality growth. Despite global economic challenges, China will continue to expand its market opening and connect with international financial rules. The country aims to achieve a modest annual growth target of around 5% this year. Li emphasized that China's economy will speed up changes in quality, efficiency, and driving force, providing new impetus for world economic growth.

images.alt_text: China will levy a 20 per cent income tax for small firms with annual sales not exceeding 1 million yuan, effective from the start of 2023 to the end of 2024, the  finance ministry said in a notice.
China's industrial profits in the January-February period dropped 22.9 per cent from a year earlier, the National Bureau of Statistics said on Monday.

site_title: India's Maharashtra state to produce less sugar as mills close early
summary: Maharashtra, India's top sugar-producing state, is expected to produce 10.7-10.8 million tonnes of sugar in the 2022-2023 marketing year, down 16% from the earlier forecast of 12.8 million tonnes. This reduction is due to sugar mills closing early, with 155 of 210 mills stopping operations by March 26. The lower sugar output may prevent India from exporting additional sugar, potentially supporting global prices and benefiting rivals Brazil and Thailand.

images.alt_text: Ethanol prices in India have also been on the rise, and this has encouraged the diversion of sugarcane for ethanol production rather than sweetener production.

A labourer separates grains of wheat from the husk at a wholesale grain market in Ghaziabad on May 17, 2022. - The United States hopes that India will reverse its decision to ban exports of wheat, which will worsen global shortages of the commodity, Washington's top diplomat to the United Nations said on May 17. (Photo by Prakash SINGH / AFP)

site_title: PE investors remain optimistic on investment opportunities despite market uncertainty
summary: Private equity investors remain optimistic about investment opportunities despite market uncertainty, citing lessons from history. The current market environment, marked by rising interest rates and market volatility, may present attractive opportunities in sectors such as tech, cross-border software, and infrastructure. Experts, including KKR's Ashish Shastry and Ardian's Michael Hu, suggest that areas of capital scarcity, such as tech and private credit, may also be attractive for investors, particularly in Asia.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
TE Asia was co-founded by group chief executive officer Eng Aik Meng (above) and TPG in 2014

Buyout firms with direct lending businesses, such as Blue Owl Capital, Blackstone (above) and Apollo Global Management, disbursed a total of US$151.3 billion in 2022 for so-called middle-market deals – midsized acquisitions by private equity firms.

site_title: Fifa to pay clubs US$355 million for sending players to 2026 and 2030 World Cups
summary: FIFA has increased compensation to US$355 million for clubs releasing players for the 2026 and 2030 World Cups through the Club Benefits Programme. The program protects clubs from injuries and provides a share of national team competition revenues. A renewed Memorandum of Understanding was signed between FIFA and the European Club Association (ECA) to better represent clubs in decision-making processes. The agreement also paves the way for a 32-team Club World Cup every four years, starting in 2025, and a new international calendar.

site_title: China banks concerned about credit ratings in debt overhauls
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, has expressed concerns over multilateral development banks' reluctance to offer debt relief in sovereign debt restructuring. Director General Jin Zhongxia stated that institutions such as the World Bank and International Monetary Fund cite their credit ratings as a reason for not restructuring debt, which China believes should be an "equitable burden" shared by these institutions. This criticism comes amid China's experience of lending hundreds of billions of dollars to developing countries, with some countries defaulting and China facing criticism for hindering debt restructuring processes.

images.alt_text: “We have dialogue with China and we’re making some progress,” Malpass said, citing China’s participation an International Monetary Fund programme to help Sri Lanka.

site_title: Binance and CEO sued by US futures regulator over trading, derivative violations
summary: The US Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) sued Binance Holdings, the world's largest cryptocurrency exchange, and CEO Changpeng Zhao for allegedly violating trading and derivatives rules. The CFTC claims Binance failed to register properly, shirking its obligations. The lawsuit was filed in federal court in Chicago on March 27. This marks a significant regulatory action against a major cryptocurrency player, highlighting ongoing regulatory scrutiny in the industry.

images.alt_text: “Initial analysis indicates matching engine encountered a bug on a trailing stop order,” Binance chief executive Changpeng Zhao said in a tweet.

site_title: Zurich bank looks to capitalise on Credit Suisse's demise
summary: Zuercher Kantonalbank (ZKB), Switzerland's largest state-owned cantonal bank, is expected to benefit from the planned merger of UBS and Credit Suisse. CEO Urs Baumann stated that the bank has received inflows from various sources, driven by customers seeking safe havens. ZKB posted a record profit and strong inflows of client money, with a 31% jump in net new assets. The bank may consider acquiring businesses from Credit Suisse and is open to external growth. Analysts predict ZKB will be a main beneficiary in Switzerland, but the bank's growth will be limited by its ownership structure and government guarantees.

images.alt_text: Finma notes that Credit Suisse has a cultural problem that translated into a lack of accountability so it is not clear who is responsible for what.

site_title: US issuing new childcare guidance for semiconductor chips subsidy programme
summary: The US Commerce Department is set to begin accepting applications in late June for a $39 billion manufacturing subsidy program, part of a $52 billion semiconductor manufacturing and research program. The new childcare guidance, released Monday, requires companies seeking major awards to provide affordable, high-quality childcare for low- and medium-income households, with the goal of making childcare "within reach" for these families. The program also includes a 25% investment tax credit for building chip plants, estimated to be worth $24 billion.

site_title: Property veteran Nicholas Mak quits ERA
summary: Nicholas Mak, head of research and consultancy at ERA Realty Network, has resigned, effective March 27, 2023. Mak, who joined ERA in 2019, cited the past four years as a "fruitful learning experience" before starting the next stage of his career. ERA's key executive officer, Eugene Lim, confirmed Mak's departure and expressed appreciation for his contributions to the agency. The move follows a significant exodus of ERA agents to rival PropNex in 2022.

images.alt_text: Photo by Yen Meng Jiin: Interior and exterior of Apac Realty (ERA)
The property cooling measures introduced last September weighed on transaction volumes in the second half of 2022, said chief executive Marcus Chu.

Apac Realty, which holds the regional master franchise rights for ERA Realty, reported earnings of S$23.9 million for the first three quarters of 2022, down 8.5 per cent from S$26.1 million last year.

site_title: French refineries barely running as strikes enter week 4
summary: French oil refineries are operating at a fraction of normal capacity due to strikes entering their fourth week, with four out of six refineries barely running. The strikes, affecting 32% of operators, have reduced diesel supply by 200,000 barrels a day and could leave up to 80% of crude-processing capacity offline. This has weakened global oil prices and accelerated the pace of diesel being taken out of storage, particularly in key import terminals.

images.alt_text: Strikers blocking a motorway on Thursday; polls show that a majority of voters oppose President Emmanuel Macron’s plan to delay the state pension age by two years to 64.
Brent futures fell US$1.07, or 1.3 per cent, to settle at US$81.59 a barrel, their lowest close since Feb 22.

site_title: Trendlines Group to pause creation of new startups, focus on exits to deliver dividends
summary: Trendlines Group, a Singapore-listed venture capital firm, plans to pause new investments and focus on exits to deliver dividends to shareholders. The company has 56 portfolio companies and will prioritize helping them achieve successful exits, which can take 8-10 years. Despite the current chill in startup interest, Trendlines expects its investments in food and medical tech to remain relevant as populations grow and age. The company aims to distribute dividends to shareholders, with significant exit activity expected in the next couple of years.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

Guest of honour and Minister of Health Ong Ye Kung noted that CEOs and boards of today have more things to worry about, amid an increasing emphasis on the “less tangible but crucial aspects”, such as environmental, social and governance (ESG) related considerations.
Trendlines seeks new board member after independent director retires
Trendlines Group inks conditional subscription agreement for S$20.3m

site_title: Crown Resorts’ data vendor hacked, limited number of its files impacted
summary: Crown Resorts, Australia's largest casino operator, confirmed a data breach at its third-party file transfer service, GoAnywhere, where hackers obtained a limited number of its files. Despite this, Crown stated that no customer data was compromised and business operations remained unaffected. The incident occurred nearly two months after suspicious activity was identified by US cybersecurity firm Fortra, which also impacted organizations such as Rio Tinto. Crown's announcement follows recent high-profile cybersecurity breaches in the country.

site_title: Myanmar junta leader urges foreign powers to back its return to democracy
summary: Myanmar's junta leader, Min Aung Hlaing, urged foreign powers to support the military's return to democracy, despite international condemnation of his rule. He claimed the opposition's narratives were false and that the military would take action against "terrorists" trying to destroy the country. The junta plans to hold a sham election in August, which has been widely dismissed. Human rights groups accuse the military of committing atrocities, with at least 1.2 million displaced. The junta insists it is targeting terrorists, not civilians, and will take "lawful actions" against them.

images.alt_text: US State Department Counselor Derek Chollet says that Washington is planning new sanctions that would stifle the junta’s income and ability to buy weapons, though he didn’t offer specifics
Since a junta seized power in February 2021, Myanmar has been plunged into chaos, with a resistance movement fighting the military on multiple fronts following a bloody crackdown on opponents.

site_title: Ikea completes sale of Russian factory to local firm
summary: Ikea has sold its factory in Novgorod, Russia to local firm Invest Plus, retaining the majority of the workforce and guaranteeing jobs for at least a year. The sale, which was over a year in the making, follows Ikea's pause of operations in Russia due to the Ukraine conflict. Invest Plus aims to resume production and supply the Russian market with Ikea products, with plans to restart full production in two to three months.

images.alt_text: Beverages imported from Japan and China on sale in Vladivostok, Russia. Sellers have been advertising drinks such as Coca-Cola as imported, so buyers know it is the real thing.

site_title: New heads at EDB, EnterpriseSG and ministries from May 1
summary: The Economic Development Board (EDB) announced changes in leadership effective May 1, 2023. EDB Chairman Beh Swan Gin will join the Ministry of Trade and Industry as Permanent Secretary of Development. Png Cheong Boon will take over as EDB chairman, while Lee Chuan Teck becomes Enterprise Singapore's new CEO. Three other permanent secretary re-designations were also made across various ministries. The changes aim to strengthen government departments and drive economic growth.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Large manufacturing projects from the electronics sector accounted for 66.7 per cent of fixed asset investment commitments in 2022.

site_title: Deutsche Bank London HQ sold for £257 million to Malaysia’s Gamuda
summary: Malaysia's Gamuda has acquired Deutsche Bank's London office, Winchester House, for £257 million. The property, currently occupied by Deutsche Bank until April 2024, will be refurbished into a sustainable office space for global financial institutions and tech corporations. The deal was made in partnership with UK private equity firm Castleforge. The acquisition marks one of the City's biggest property deals this year, following a trend of investors seeking sustainable office spaces amid rising interest rates.

images.alt_text: A sign for Deutsche Bank AG at a bank branch in the financial district of Frankfurt, Germany, on Thursday, Feb. 2, 2023. Deutsche Bank vowed to increase profit and revenue further this year, after snapping a long streak of market share gains in trading in the final quarter of Chief Executive Officer Christian Sewing's turnaround plan. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

site_title: Coinbase calls for efforts to create inflation-proof stablecoins
summary: US crypto exchange Coinbase Global has called for efforts to create inflation-proof stablecoins, also referred to as "flatcoins." This move comes as the company seeks to explore the potential of stablecoins, which are designed to maintain a constant value, amid the recent woes of the banking system. Coinbase believes that inflation protection overlays could provide a cushion against elevated post-pandemic price pressures, making stablecoins more attractive to crypto investors.

images.alt_text: Shares of Coinbase plunged as much as 20 per cent in New York, after it disclosed late on Wednesday (Mar 22) that it had received a so-called Wells notice from the SEC.
Founded in San Francisco in 2012, Coinbase is one of the oldest and most well-known trading crypto trading venues globally, with a rare US public listing.

site_title: Scottish National Party elects Humza Yousaf as leader after chaotic race
summary: The Scottish National Party (SNP) has elected Humza Yousaf as its leader, succeeding Nicola Sturgeon. Yousaf, 37, a health secretary, won the contest after a chaotic battle, despite criticism over the state of the health service under his watch. He faces significant challenges, including fixing the party's record on health and education, resolving a scandal over island ferry contracts, and reinvigorating the campaign for Scottish independence. Yousaf will be formally appointed as first minister on March 28, marking a new era for the SNP.

images.alt_text: “The government committed to reviewing the criminal regime to ensure that the FCA can take action against market abuse in a way that is commensurate to the seriousness and market impact of the abusive behaviour,” the finance ministry and FCA said in a joint statement.

Britain's Prime Minister Rishi Sunak (L) and European Commission chief Ursula von der Leyen hold a joint press conference following their meeting at the Fairmont Hotel in Windsor, west of London, on Feb 27, 2023.

site_title: Jack Ma returns to China as government tries to quell private sector fears
summary: Jack Ma, founder of Alibaba, has returned to China after a more than year-long stay overseas, amid efforts by the government to quell concerns from the private sector. His return is seen as a sign of support for the government's softer tone towards the private sector, as China's economy recovers from three years of Covid curbs. Ma, a former English teacher, discussed topics such as artificial intelligence and potentially returning to teaching.

images.alt_text: Jack Ma has since late 2022 gradually resumed the globetrotting that once defined China’s best-known entrepreneur..

site_title: Asean must dramatically ramp up clean-energy investments to meet climate goals: IEA report
summary: Southeast Asia must significantly increase clean-energy investments to meet its climate goals, aiming for $180 billion annually by 2030, according to a report by the International Energy Agency (IEA) and Imperial College Business School. The region's economic development model relies heavily on fossil fuels, and regulatory barriers, high costs, and lack of transparency hinder private investments in renewable energy. To achieve net-zero emissions by 2050, the region needs stronger regulatory frameworks, better risk management tools, and improved data transparency, as well as greater international and domestic policy support.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

According to the IPCC, emissions must be halved by the mid-2030s if the world is to have any chance of limiting temperature rise to 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels – a key target enshrined in the Paris accord.
Biodiversity concerns and a just transition to a low-carbon economy are becoming more important to investors, Robeco's survey says
Public sector to drive sustainable bond issuance in Asean in 2023: Moody’s

site_title: Cash-rich BioNTech plans to spend about 1 billion euros more on research this year
summary: BioNTech plans to spend up to €1 billion more on research and development and up to $500 million on share buybacks this year, driven by its commercial success of the Covid-19 vaccine. The company expects to authorise new share buybacks worth up to $500 million, having already spent $1.3 billion on its own shares. BioNTech's cash balance of €13.9 billion plus receivables will support these investments, despite expected commercial revenues of $5 billion in 2023, a 9% drop from last year. The company will also focus on oncology and infectious-disease vaccine development.

site_title: Largest strike in decades brings Germany to a standstill
summary: Germany's transportation sector came to a standstill on Monday as the largest strike in decades brought the country to a halt. Airports, bus, and train stations were closed, disrupting millions of passengers. The Verdi trade union and EVG railway union called a 24-hour strike, demanding higher wages to combat inflation, which reached 9.3% in February. The strike, which affects 2.5 million and 230,000 employees, is part of a broader wave of labor strikes in Europe.

images.alt_text: The industrial action will begin at midnight on Sunday for 24 hours and also affect some ports, with the Verdi and EVG transport and railway unions expecting severe disruption to travel.

site_title: South Korean construction deals fall by record amid slowdown
summary: South Korea's construction deals plummeted by a record 18.4% in the last quarter, with private sector contracts declining the most, according to the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure and Transport. The decline was driven by rising interest rates weakening demand and inflation fueling costs. This slowdown in construction activity adds to factors weighing on the country's economy, which saw its gross domestic product contract last quarter. The construction sector's decline also contributed to slumping construction investment and exports.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as banking fears persist
summary: Asian stocks were mixed on Monday, with Hong Kong and Shanghai down, while Tokyo, Singapore, and Sydney rose. The decline was fueled by concerns over troubled lender Deutsche Bank, which saw its shares plummet 14% before closing 8.5% lower. US President Joe Biden and European officials attempted to calm investors, but the situation highlights growing pressure on the banking system in major Western economies. Markets are likely to remain in flux as concerns persist, with some analysts suggesting the turmoil could help tame inflation.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong was dragged by heavy losses in heavyweight HSBC, while Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore and Wellington were also down on Friday.

site_title: SVB deal helps to steady banks amid credit crunch concerns
summary: Silicon Valley Bank's sudden collapse last month destabilized the banking sector, drawing European lenders into investors' focus. A buyer, First Citizens BancShares, has acquired SVB's deposits and loans, helping shares in European lenders recover partially. The deal, worth up to $500 million, has boosted confidence, but experts warn that the issue of guaranteeing deposits at smaller US regional banks remains. The sector's volatility has raised concerns about the impact of interest rate hikes on the global economy, with some policymakers closely monitoring the situation for potential credit crunch risks.

images.alt_text: First Citizens has entered into a purchase and assumption agreement for all deposits and loans of SVB; the deal includes the purchase of about US$72 billion SVB assets at a discount of US$16.5 billion.

site_title: How China keeps putting off its ‘Lehman moment’
summary: China has once again averted a catastrophic financial crisis, this time with the collapse of Evergrande Group, a major property developer. The government intervened to help arrange a restructuring of the company's debt, preventing a potential global depression. Unlike Western economies, China's financial system is heavily controlled by the government, allowing regulators to direct resources and apportion pain as needed. While warnings of a Chinese financial reckoning resurface periodically, China's history of preventing financial catastrophes suggests its ability to manage its economy may be more resilient than predicted.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The China Evergrande Centre building sign is seen in Hong Kong, China December 7, 2021. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo

site_title: Indian banks to gain US$36 billion in deposits as funds get taxed
summary: India's decision to tax returns from fixed-income mutual funds is expected to bolster lenders' efforts to attract deposits, potentially garnering $36 billion. This move comes as credit growth has surged 15.7% annually, while deposit collections lag behind at around 10%. The tax change aims to reduce the gap between credit off-take and deposits, mitigating asset-liability mismatches and funding costs. Lenders are raising deposit rates to make them more attractive, posing risks to profits, but are expected to see a slower rise in deposit costs due to gradual rate hikes.

images.alt_text: “Tightening of financial conditions by central banks to tame inflation has raised concerns regarding the exacerbation of corporate debt vulnerabilities, with corporates being already highly leveraged,” the ministry said.

site_title: Singapore stocks begin week on more upbeat note, STI up 0.8%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.8% on its first trading day of the week, closing at 3,239.03 points. Local traders focused on market opportunities despite concerns over banking sector turmoil and inflation. Regional markets declined, with the Hang Seng Index falling 1.8% and the Nikkei 225 adding 0.3%. Analysts attributed the calm market to investors' understanding of the current banking issues, which are different from the 2008 subprime mortgage crisis.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
The MSCI World share index traded 0.6 per cent lower and Europe’s STOXX 600 index was down 1.6 per cent.
China expects inbound and outbound tourist numbers in 2023 to reach more than 90 million, recovering to 31.5 per cent of pre-pandemic levels.
Hong Kong’s benchmark Hang Seng Index slumped 2.7 per cent, the lowest close since early December.
Deutsche Bank slumped as much as 15 per cent, the biggest decline since the early days of the pandemic, in March 2020.
The yen – long seen as a safe haven at times of stress – rallied as a fall in Asian bank stocks overnight spread to Europe on Monday.

site_title: Philippines may tout benchmark retail dollar bond offer in April
summary: The Philippines is planning a benchmark-sized retail US dollar bond offer, targeting individuals and retail investors, with the schedule to be announced in April. Finance Secretary Benjamin Diokno stated that the announcement will be made in Washington, with the target size of at least $500 million. This move is part of the government's efforts to boost infrastructure spending. The bond offer will be the first of its kind under the administration of President Ferdinand Marcos Jr.

images.alt_text: BSP has raised the key rate by 3.5 percentage points so far in this tightening cycle, starting in May, taking the benchmark rate to 5.5 per cent which is the highest since 2008.
The dollar bond offer follows the Philippines' US$2 billion three-tranche global bond deal in early October.

site_title: Deutsche Bank bounces as analysts reassure its financial health
summary: Deutsche Bank shares rose 5.2% on Monday after analysts reassured the bank's financial health, citing its "very solid" fundamentals. Hedge funds shifted their attention away from the bank following the collapse of Credit Suisse Group and regional US banks. European regulators' efforts to reduce leverage and improve capital positions have resulted in a healthier balance sheet. Analysts also pointed out Deutsche Bank's reduced exposure to the commercial real estate sector as a reason for the decline. German Chancellor Olaf Scholz's comments on Friday also contributed to the bank's rebound.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank slumped as much as 15 per cent, the biggest decline since the early days of the pandemic, in March 2020.

site_title: Lloyds races to sell Chinese tycoon’s Canary Wharf office loan
summary: Lloyds Banking Group is racing to sell a £175 million loan secured against a Canary Wharf office block owned by Cheung Kei, a unit of Chinese tycoon Chen Hongtian, ahead of its imminent maturity. The loan is part of a larger effort by the lender to offload non-performing loans amid a sharp decline in commercial real estate values. Cheung Kei has also defaulted on another nearby office block and is attempting to sell that property, further highlighting the challenges facing the market.

images.alt_text: London, which is the lowest-yielding region in the whole country, has seen the biggest jump in cash investors so far this year.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Malaysia's capital market reached a record RM179.4 billion in 2022, with investors advised to carefully read fine print in bond instruments. AT1 bondholders may face difficulty getting their money back if a restructuring occurs, and Genting Malaysia could gain RM2.9 billion from the sale of its Miami property. Keppel's Philippines subsidiary will sell its remaining stake in a property for 8 billion pesos. Office rents in Singapore's CBD rose in Q1 despite economic concerns, and the STI increased 0.8% at the start of the week.

site_title: Hong Kong’s exports slide as weak global demand hits recovery
summary: Hong Kong's exports fell for the ninth consecutive month in February, with overseas shipments dropping 8.8% from a year earlier, and imports decreasing 4.1% from a year ago. The trade deficit was US$5.8 billion. Despite expectations of a 23% drop, the decline was less severe than in recent months. The government attributes the slowdown to weak global demand, particularly from China, and expects a moderation in growth in advanced economies this year to weigh on Hong Kong's export performance.

images.alt_text: Shanghai-based Shimao, in the process of restructuring US$11.8 billion of offshore debt, is among the many Chinese developers that defaulted last year.

site_title: Diversity, equity and inclusion: Beyond a feel-good concept
summary: Companies that prioritize diversity, equity, and inclusion (DE&I) tend to outperform the broader market over the long term, driven by greater innovation, higher employee engagement rates, and increased profitability. DE&I is a key environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factor, and share prices of companies with strong DE&I track records have consistently outperformed the market. Despite the growing sustainable finance market, gender-lens investing remains in its infancy, with only $17 billion in gender-labelled financial products out of $40 trillion in global sustainable investment.
