To accelerate gender equality, financing solutions such as gender bonds and social bonds are being explored, with the goal of empowering 100 million women and girls worldwide by 2030.

images.alt_text: “The pervasive underrepresentation of women in economics is systemic and structural,” Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala (right), the first woman to head the World Trade Organization while Christine Lagarde (Left), president of the European Central Bank, said that more needed to be done.
Women-powered private firms in Asia, including unicorn Airwallex, a payments company co-founded by Lucy Liu, ranked first on list compiled by JP Morgan Private Bank and Ernst & Young.
Ethnic minorities now account for 190 of the 1,064 board positions at FTSE 100 companies, 31 as chairs or executive directors.
Nomura International, the Japanese lender’s London-based investment bank, previously said it wanted 19 per cent of women in senior management positions by 2022.
Research has found a positive link between brands that embrace DE&I and their reputation.

site_title: Over S$3.5 billion in ‘Eco-Care’ loans made since March 2021: OCBC
summary: OCBC has disbursed over S$3.5 billion in Eco-Care loans since March 2021, exceeding expectations. The loans, which cover home, renovation, and car purchases, aim to promote eco-friendly consumption habits. To qualify, applicants must pass the Building and Construction Authority's energy efficiency assessment. This initiative is part of OCBC's efforts to support sustainable growth and reduce carbon footprint.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Recovery in ESG bond issuance seen in 2023 as rates stabilise, inflation subsides
Harnessing green financing to push the boundaries of innovation
Dr Darian McBain, chief sustainability officer of MAS, was the guest of honour at the Project Greenprint industry showcase event, where ESGpedia was launched.
OCBC extends S$148m green loan using BCA's new assessment tool

site_title: Swedish mortgage lending falls for first time as rates rise
summary: Sweden's mortgage lending declined for the first time on record in February, with a 274 million Swedish kronor drop from the previous month. Total lending to households grew 2.8% on year, marking the 10th straight month of slowing credit growth. The decline in mortgage lending is attributed to rising home loan rates and the country's sluggish housing market, which has seen a 15% drop in home prices since its peak last year. This marks a global trend of slowing credit growth in response to rising interest rates.

site_title: Saudi National Bank chair resigns after Credit Suisse buyout
summary: Saudi National Bank's chairperson Ammar Al Khudairy resigned due to personal reasons, following comments that led to Credit Suisse's stock plummeting. Al Khudairy stated the bank wouldn't raise its stake, sparking regulatory concerns. The Swiss bank later received a $54 billion lifeline, but ultimately took a $1 billion investment loss in the deal. Saeed Mohammed Al Ghamdi will replace Al Khudairy as chair, while Talal Ahmed Al Khereiji will act as CEO. The resignation comes amid fears about the health of the financial sector and Credit Suisse's takeover by UBS.

images.alt_text: The Saudi National Bank headquarters (right) in the King Abdullah Financial District in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. The bank's 9.9 per cent stake in Credit Suisse is now valued at about 304 million Swiss francs following the UBS offer.

The most recent losses on Credit Suisse are a stark reminder of a series of investments made by Gulf investors during the 2008 global financial crisis, many of which ended in financial loss or legal battles.

site_title: First Citizens buys Silicon Valley Bank
summary: First Citizens has entered into a purchase and assumption agreement to buy Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) for about $72 billion, including $16.5 billion in assets at a discount. SVB was seized by regulators following a run on the lender. The deal includes the purchase of SVB's deposits and loans, while about $90 billion in securities and other assets will remain in the receivership. The estimated cost of the failure to the Deposit Insurance Fund is around $20 billion.

images.alt_text: First Citizens could reach a deal as soon as Sunday to acquire Silicon Valley Bank from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp (FDIC), according to Bloomberg News, which first reported the development.

site_title: Former Taiwan president arrives in China pledging peace
summary: Former Taiwanese President Ma Ying-jeou visited China on Monday, becoming the first sitting or former Taiwanese leader to do so since the Communist revolution in 1949. Ma, who served as president from 2008-2016, aimed to promote peace and improve relations between Taiwan and China. His visit was criticized by Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party, which views it as an attempt by China to pressure Taiwan into accepting its sovereignty. Ma's trip comes amid heightened tensions between Beijing and Taipei.

site_title: Will ESG investing solve our pressing problems?
summary: ESG investing has achieved significant commercial success, with funds reaching $3 trillion by 2021, but its impact on achieving sustainability goals is questionable. A principal-agent problem exists, where investors delegate decisions to portfolio managers, who may prioritize financial returns over ESG considerations. Studies show that ESG funds often have higher fees and may not deliver better ESG scores, leading to virtue-signaling. Businesses, not investment vehicles, have a significant impact on ESG and sustainability. To create long-term value, businesses must take a principal's approach, integrating ESG considerations into business decision-making, rather than delegating sustainability to a designated officer.

images.alt_text: The Financial Conduct Authority said in a letter to ESG benchmarks compilers that a preliminary review had shown that the quality of their disclosures was poor.
As a trusted partner, internal auditors support the stakeholders in connecting the dots by assessing the organisation’s ESG risks from multiple perspectives.

site_title: Credit Agricole launches China M&A and investment banking business
summary: Credit Agricole, France's second-largest listed bank, has launched a new unit, Credit Agricole (Beijing) Advisory Services, focusing on cross-border merger and acquisition in China. The unit, which began operations on March 10, aims to connect local and international clients to investment opportunities. This move follows other global banks expanding their presence in China, including Standard Chartered, JPMorgan, and Morgan Stanley. The new unit is overseen by Huai Yang and is expected to strengthen Credit Agricole's capabilities in the region.

site_title: Eliminating the improbable
summary: A year ago, the market outlook was bleak due to high inflation, but with a recent surge of inflation being unlikely, the outlook has improved significantly. Bond markets have changed their views on recession prospects twice, and stock prices have shown resilience despite gyrations. Investors can eliminate the improbable and focus on the remaining truth, suggesting a difficult economy this year but potentially positive returns in 2024.

images.alt_text: International Monetary Fund (IMF) Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva says: “At a time of higher debt levels, the rapid transition from a prolonged period of low interest rates to much higher rates – necessary to fight inflation – inevitably generates stresses and vulnerabilities, as evidenced by recent developments in the banking sector in some advanced economies.”
Real estate was already the most shorted industry across global equities, according to a Mar 17 report by S&P Global. It was the third most-shorted sector in the US.

site_title: UK retailers turn positive on sales hopes after bleak winter
summary: UK retailers reported their first positive sales expectations in seven months, according to the Confederation of British Industry's survey, with the expected sales balance for April increasing to +9 from -18 in March. This marks a significant turnaround from the previous months, with sales expectations remaining negative since May last year. The positive sign comes as consumers face high inflation and rising interest rates. CBI principal economist Martin Sartorius attributed the resilience to stabilizing retail activity, but emphasized the need for further action to address labour shortages and skills gaps.

images.alt_text: Firms across the two sectors were more optimistic about their prospects over the next 12 months, with the degree of confidence hitting its highest since March 2022.
Consumer price inflation rose unexpectedly to 10.4 per cent last month, with food and drink costs rising at the fastest rate since 1977.

site_title: China Evergrande’s EV unit may shut down without new funding
summary: China Evergrande New Energy Vehicle (NEV) Group warned it may shut down production of electric cars without new financing, citing a need for 29 billion yuan (S$5.6 billion) in funding. The company has delivered just 900 of its delayed flagship model and has a significant amount of liabilities, with almost 59 billion yuan in liabilities and total equity of 691 million yuan. If funding is not secured, the company risks discontinuing production, making it unlikely to rival Tesla as the world's biggest electric vehicle maker.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The China Evergrande Centre building sign is seen in Hong Kong, China December 7, 2021. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo

site_title: Keppel subsidiary to sell remaining stake in Philippines property for 8 billion pesos
summary: Keppel Corporation announced it will sell its 50% stake in SM Keppel Land, owner of The Podium West Tower and The Podium Mall in Manila, to BDO Unibank for approximately 8 billion pesos (S$195 million). The deal, expected to be completed by mid-2023, aims to unlock capital for new growth opportunities. The sale is part of Keppel's Vision 2023 asset monetisation plans and is not expected to have a material impact on the group's net tangible assets or earnings per share for the current financial year.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Malaysia’s total funds raised reach record RM179.4b in 2022: Securities Commission
summary: Malaysia's capital market raised a record RM179.4 billion in 2022, a 36.6% increase from RM131.3 billion in 2021. This exceeds the five-year pre-pandemic average of RM121.4 billion. Despite global and domestic headwinds, the capital market remained "resilient and orderly" in 2022, according to Securities Commission Malaysia executive chairman Awang Adek.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng

Securities Commission Malaysiachairman Awang Adek Hussin unveils a series of digital-centric initiatives with measures that will further harness the potential of the capital market in accelerating the recovery and continued growth of the country's economy.

site_title: Tech’s AI armies are huge, yet struggling to innovate
summary: The world's largest tech firms, including Amazon, Microsoft, and Google, have amassed thousands of AI specialists but struggle to innovate, despite investing heavily in AI research and development. In contrast, OpenAI, a tiny firm with 154 employees, has achieved remarkable success with its chatbot ChatGPT, which became the fastest-growing online service of all time. The industry's biggest players are racing to catch up, with Google and Microsoft partnering with OpenAI and investing billions of dollars. However, Amazon's own AI efforts have been met with mixed results, and the company has been laying off staff, including those working on its Alexa virtual assistant.

images.alt_text: ChatGPT set off massive investment because “ninety-plus per cent of venture capitalists are actually very risk averse. Until you see a real application, people don’t really dive in,” Samir Kaul, a founding partner at Khosla Ventures said.
Bing Image Creator will be integrated into Bing chat, rolling out initially in Creative mode starting Tuesday for users on desktop and mobile, Microsoft said.

site_title: Indonesia’s Bank Mandiri mandates banks for US dollar bond deal
summary: Indonesia's Bank Mandiri has mandated six investment banks to work on a US dollar senior bond deal, marking one of the first debt deals by a major bank in Asia since recent global finance upheaval. The lender and its advisers will hold calls with European and Asian investors starting on Monday, subject to market conditions. The expected size and tenor of the deal were not specified. This move could provide insight into Bank Mandiri's financial health and market confidence.

site_title: Vietnam’s VPBank sells US$1.5 billion stake to Japan’s SMFG unit
summary: VPBank, a Vietnamese lender, has sold a 15% stake to Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group (SMFG) for approximately $1.5 billion through a private placement. The deal is part of VPBank's capital raising plan to achieve its growth strategy over the next five years. This marks the end of a years-long sale process and is part of Japan's efforts to invest in Asia's rapidly expanding middle class.

site_title: Thai election to be a close race between parties, surveys show
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha's support is slipping, with opposition party Pheu Thai led by 36-year-old Paetongtarn, daughter and niece of ex-premiers, far ahead in opinion polls. Pheu Thai has 37-46% support, while ruling coalition parties combined have around 50%. The May 14 election is expected to be a close race, with parties vying for parliamentary seats and deciding on a prime minister by the end of July.

images.alt_text: CGS-CIMB thinks Pheu Thai Party is likely to win half of the House of Representatives in the upcoming election.
Thai Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha poses with members of the media, after the King endorsed a decree to dissolve parliament on March 20, 2023.

site_title: Explore new ways to widen ownership of Singapore homes and commercial property
summary: Google's significant investment in Singapore, including its data centres and office spaces, has contributed to the city-state's thriving property sector. The government's efforts to attract businesses and talent have led to a vibrant market, generating substantial tax revenue. To further share the gains, experts suggest widening property ownership through initiatives like real estate investment trusts (Reits), tokenisation, and relaxing stamp duty rules for private homes. Additionally, allowing funds to buy private homes without Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty could increase local ownership and rental income.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
Alexandra Technopark accounted for 9.8 per cent of FLCT’s portfolio value as at end December.
New Tech Park in Lorong Chuan is among the portfolio properties of Sabana Industrial Reit, which is among the 10 trusts with the lowest gearing ratios reported.

site_title: China issues preferential tax policy for small firms, household businesses
summary: China's finance ministry has introduced a preferential tax policy for small firms and household businesses, effective from 2023 to 2024. The policy includes a 20% income tax rate for small firms with annual sales not exceeding 1 million yuan (S$193,630) and taxable income not exceeding 3 million yuan, and a limit on the number of employees and total assets. This move aims to support the country's economic recovery.

site_title: A year after borders reopened, Malaysia’s hotel occupancy rate now close to pre-pandemic level
summary: Malaysia's hotel occupancy rate has returned to near pre-pandemic levels, with over 60% occupancy in February, according to the Malaysian Association of Hotels. The average room rate has increased by 38% to RM246, and revenue per available room (RevPar) has seen a 87% growth to RM133. The country aims to welcome 15.6 million international tourists this year, with revenue projected at RM47.6 billion. Popular destinations such as Langkawi and Melaka are seeing strong demand, with occupancy rates above 60% in some areas, and new hotels are expected to open this year.

images.alt_text: The first Paris Baguette outlet in Pavilion Kuala Lumpur has attracted the attention of Malaysian shoppers.
Malaysia's tourism-related stocks have gained buying interest as analysts expect the Chinese tourists will catalyse the country's economy.

site_title: European stocks rebound as banking jitters ease
summary: European stocks rebounded 1.3% on Monday, as banking jitters eased following news that First Citizens BancShares would acquire Silicon Valley Bank's deposits and loans. European banks jumped 2.8% after shedding 3.8% on Friday, while Swiss bank UBS rose 2.5% after Credit Suisse rose 3.6% following a weekend statement from the Swiss financial regulator FINMA. The STOXX 600 index reached a 1.3% gain by 0705 GMT.

site_title: AI deals hit by funding winter but VCs eye fresh opportunities
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) startups in South-east Asia are gaining attention from venture capital firms (VCs) despite a funding winter last year. The breakthrough of generative AI tools like OpenAI's ChatGPT has sparked fresh excitement, with many VCs optimistic about the sector's potential for growth. While big tech companies will dominate the landscape, VCs see opportunities for startups to carve out their niche, particularly in business-to-business AI applications and industries such as fintech, e-commerce, and logistics.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
The rise of ChatGPT is a wake-up call for everyone with a wifi connection to re-think how they engage in the cyberverse.
The Stripe move represents one of the first known integrations of OpenAI’s new technology, underscoring large companies’ interest in embedding AI in their product offerings.

site_title: Banking turmoil has potential to trigger financial crisis: ANZ CEO
summary: Australian banks face potential fallout from global banking turmoil, with ANZ CEO Shayne Elliott warning it could trigger a financial crisis. Authorities worldwide are on high alert following the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank in the US, and the emergency takeover of Credit Suisse. Although it's too early to predict a 2008-style crisis, Elliott notes the global "war on inflation" and rapid rate hikes have caused casualties, with mortgage customers in Australia showing signs of strain.

images.alt_text: Short interest in financial stocks sold on major US exchanges was at 1.4 per cent - the lowest of all sectors studied.
JPMorgan, the nation’s largest bank, told all employees they “should never give the appearance of exploiting a situation of stress or uncertainty”.
Deposits at small banks fall US$119 billion to US$5.46 trillion in the week ended March 15.
First Citizens could reach a deal as soon as Sunday to acquire Silicon Valley Bank from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp (FDIC), according to Bloomberg News, which first reported the development.

site_title: Shanghai expat exodus shows Covid Zero’s enduring scars
summary: Shanghai, China's most international city, is experiencing an exodus of foreigners and foreign investment due to the lingering effects of its Covid Zero policy. A year after a brutal two-month lockdown, many expats are leaving, including a Russian fashion entrepreneur who plans to move to New Zealand. Foreign companies have also reduced their presence, with some looking to invest in other countries to alleviate risk. China's top brands remain cautious about consumer recovery, and the country's reputation is at risk of being restored, with officials urged to undertake efforts to regain confidence.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will meet officials during a visit to China.

A staff member advertises clothing at the main shopping area in Shanghai, China, March 14, 2023. A lingering sense of caution about the sustainability of China's rebound points to a potentially rocky year ahead.
Ding has noted at the China Development Forum in Beijing (pictured) that opening to the outside world is a national policy.

site_title: Australia’s performance in Brisbane Olympics ‘threatened by underfunding’
summary: Australia's performance in the 2032 Olympics in Brisbane is threatened by underfunding, according to AOC chief executive Matt Carroll. A $2 billion funding shortfall is expected over the next decade, putting Australian sport at risk of failure. Carroll called for increased funding for sports and the Australian Institute of Sport, and a ministry for sport to be established. Without a major funding boost, Australia's performance in the 2032 Olympics is unlikely to match previous showings.

images.alt_text: Brisbane will become the third Australian city to host the Summer Olympics, after Melbourne in 1956 and Sydney in 2000.

site_title: Gold eases on steady dollar; market focus on banking risks
summary: Gold prices fell 0.3% to $1,977.20 due to a steady US dollar, making bullion less affordable for overseas buyers. Authorities attempted to calm investor fears over a potential liquidity crisis in the global banking sector. The dollar index edged up 0.1%. Markets are pricing in an almost 87% chance of the Fed standing pat on interest rates in its May meeting. The banking crisis brings the US closer to recession, according to Minneapolis Federal Reserve President Neel Kashkari.

images.alt_text: Gold prices jumped 2 per cent on Wednesday after the Fed raised interest rates.

site_title: Indonesia tax office eyes exit from finance ministry amid probe
summary: Indonesia's tax office is considering splitting from the finance ministry amid a probe into a $20 billion scandal. A majority of tax officials support the proposal, which would need parliamentary and presidential approval. The move aims to boost state revenue and improve tax compliance, currently among the lowest in peers. The proposal, first discussed by previous finance ministers, is seen as a response to a crisis of confidence and discontent among civil servants, who feel the current structure hinders their ability to root out corruption.

site_title: Genting Malaysia could realise RM2.9 billion in gains from sale of Miami property: Maybank
summary: Genting Malaysia's prime waterfront property in Miami could fetch RM2.9 billion (S$873.1 million) if sold for US$1 billion, according to Maybank. The sale, which attracted five bids exceeding US$1 billion, will likely be used to fortify Genting's balance sheet and bid for a lucrative downstate casino licence in New York, potentially adding RM0.53 per share to its target price. Maybank maintains its "buy" recommendation for Genting Malaysia, citing a 14.7% potential upside from its current price.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Genting, which owns casino resorts in Malaysia, Singapore and the US, acquired the Florida property and some nearby real estate for about US$236 million in 2011.
Brokers’ take: Maybank upgrades Genting to ‘buy’ on return of Chinese tourists
Resorts World Singapore, which Genting Singapore operates, is set to see footfall normalise in 2023 as China reopens and tourist arrivals normalise.
Net profit for the six months ended Dec 31, 2022, rose to S$255.7 million from S$95.1 million in the same period a year prior.
Analysts are expecting Genting Singapore to be a key beneficiary of an influx of tourists following China’s reopening.

site_title: Latest John Wick tops North America box office in a big, bloody opening
summary: Keanu Reeves' latest film "John Wick: Chapter 4" has opened at the top of the North America box office with an estimated US$73.5 million in ticket sales. The neo-noir action thriller, directed by Chad Stahelski, has received mostly positive reviews, with many praising its well-choreographed action sequences. The film, starring Reeves, Donnie Yen, and Bill Skarsgard, has outdone its predecessors in terms of box office performance, with each Wick sequel managing to surpass the previous one.

images.alt_text: "Scream VI" starring (from left) Melissa Barrera and Jenna Ortega took in an estimated US$44.5 miilion at the North America box office.

site_title: Economists expect US recession, above-target inflation this year
summary: US economists predict a recession and above-target inflation this year, with over two-thirds seeing inflation remaining above 4% at the end of 2023. The National Association for Business Economics survey found 217 economists believe the US will enter a recession, while 5% think it's currently in one. The Federal Reserve has raised rates to combat inflation, which reached 6.0% in February, exceeding its 2% target. Economists also slightly increased the chances of a "soft landing" – avoiding a recession while bringing down inflation – from 27% to 30%.

images.alt_text: The survey’s flash services sector PMI increased to 53.8 this month, the highest level since last April, from 50.6 in February.
Orders for transportation equipment fell 2.8 per cent after tumbling 14.0 per cent in January. Motor vehicle orders decreased 0.9 per cent.
FILE PHOTO: The U.S. Federal Reserve building is pictured in Washington, March 18, 2008. REUTERS/Jason Reed/File Photo

site_title: Sorry you were laid off. ‘CFBR.’
summary: The tech sector has seen a significant increase in layoffs, with over 161,000 people losing their jobs in 2022 and over 148,000 this year. To combat the trend, job seekers are turning to LinkedIn, where a phenomenon known as "commenting for better reach" (CFBR) has become widespread. CFBR involves people commenting on layoff posts to signal solidarity and potentially increase their visibility. This practice has been credited with helping job seekers find new opportunities and has become a key way for people to network and rely on LinkedIn's algorithm.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Jamie Dimon, Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer of JPMorgan Chase & Co., gestures as he speaks during an interview with Reuters in Miami, Florida, U.S., February 8, 2023. REUTERS/Marco Bello/File Photo

site_title: Cybersecurity researchers give details of Pinduoduo app malware
summary: Cybersecurity researchers at Kaspersky Lab have identified malicious code in versions of Pinduoduo, a Chinese shopping app, which exploited known Android vulnerabilities to escalate privileges, download and execute additional malicious modules, and gain access to users' notifications and files. The malicious code was found in versions of the app distributed through local app stores in China, where it was used to install backdoors and gain unauthorized access to user data. Google suspended the app from its Android app store, and PDD Holdings, the app's owner, has rejected claims of malicious code.

images.alt_text: PDD booked revenue of 39.82 billion yuan for the quarter ended Dec 31, compared with estimates of 41.01 billion yuan.

site_title: Far East Hospitality Trust receives full S$18 million incentive fee from Central Square divestment
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust (FEHT) received an additional S$18 million from the divestment of Central Square to City Developments Limited (CDL), bringing the total aggregate sum to S$331.2 million. This represents a 67% premium to Central Square's book value and an 80.7% premium to its purchase price in 2012. FEHT's manager expects to net a gain of S$130.3 million from the divestment, unlocking latent value in its hospitality assets and strengthening its balance sheet.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Keppel Corp's Philippines-listed subsidiary is divesting its remaining stake in a property for around 8 billion pesos (S$195 million).

site_title: Brokers’ take: RHB downgrades Starhill Global Reit to ‘neutral’ on impact from arbitration
summary: RHB downgraded its recommendation on Starhill Global Reit to "neutral" due to the potential impact of an arbitration claim from anchor tenant Myer. The Reit's divestment of its Japanese property Daikanyama could be used to pare down debt, and analysts believe it could limit the claim's effect. Analyst Vijay Natarajan expects a temporary 15% drop in distribution per unit, but also notes that the Reit's performance is improving with occupancy at 93% and footfall increasing.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Digital Core Reit said it has no banking relationship with fallen Silicon Valley Bank.
Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust’s VivoCity recorded positive rent reversion at 7.9 per cent.

site_title: Prime office rents grow amid tight supply in Q1: Knight Frank
summary: Office rents in Singapore's Central Business District (CBD) rose 1.3% quarter-on-quarter in Q1 2023, driven by tight supply and demand for flexible office space. Despite worsening economic sentiment, 94.1% of office buildings were occupied, with prime-grade spaces in Raffles Place/Marina Bay averaging S$10.83 per square foot per month. Knight Frank attributes steady occupancy rates to redevelopment projects and a demand for quality office spaces that foster a superior work experience, citing Singapore as a "flight-to-safety" hub.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim

ST20221029-202253130955-Lim Yaohui-pixgeneric/
Skyline of the Central Business District (CBD) along the Singapore River on Oct 29, 2022.
Can be used for stories on money, job, manpower, tourist, tourism, property, land, commercial, office, finance, financial, and CBD.

site_title: Weighing bank AT1 perps: Are you compensated enough for the risk?
summary: A Swiss bank's AT1 perpetual bond, a hybrid instrument used to cushion banks' capital in a crisis, was recently written down completely due to the bank's takeover by UBS. The loss-absorption mechanism, which allows regulators to trigger a writedown of the bond if the bank's capital falls below a certain threshold, was triggered by the regulator's decision. This decision highlights the risks associated with bank perps, which carry higher yields to compensate for higher risks. Investors should scrutinize offer documents and consider the risks before investing in these instruments, which are often classified as highly complex and open to accredited investors and institutions.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

A photograph shows a logo of Credit Suisse bank in Zurich, on March 23, 2023. - The marriage of UBS and Credit Suisse was hastily arranged to prevent a global financial meltdown -- but the resulting megabank could cause domestic problems in Switzerland, the central bank admitted on March 23, 2023. (Photo by Fabrice COFFRINI / AFP)
UBS told Credit Suisse wealth bankers in Zurich this week that it is weighing financial sweeteners for them to stay as it seeks to reassure key staff following the takeover.

The most recent losses on Credit Suisse are a stark reminder of a series of investments made by Gulf investors during the 2008 global financial crisis, many of which ended in financial loss or legal battles.

site_title: Waste reduction a key hospitality focus as consumption rises with tourism’s return: Ascott MD
summary: The hospitality industry is shifting its focus to waste reduction as tourism rebounds and consumers increasingly prioritize sustainability. CapitaLand Investment's chief financial and sustainability officer, Beh Siew Kim, emphasizes the importance of embracing a circular economy to minimize waste and reduce environmental impact. Key strategies include leveraging waste management and circular economy solutions, adopting green building practices, and educating consumers about sustainability efforts. Companies that fail to prioritize sustainability risk losing market share, while those that successfully implement sustainability initiatives can command a price premium and enjoy higher occupancy rates.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah
Sustainable aviation fuel is tipped to make the difference in the aviation sector, which is currently responsible for 5 per cent of man-made climate change. PHOTO:
Beachgoers in Bali. Indonesia has committed to prioritising sustainability in its tourism industry.

Travelers prepare to board a passenger aircraft operated by Qantas Airways Ltd. at Sydney Airport in Sydney, Australia, on Wednesday, June 23, 2021. While losses at airlines globally from Covid-19 are set to surpass $174 billion by the end of 2021 -- wiping out half a decade of profits -- Qantas has become one of the most financially secure carriers anywhere in the world. Photographer: Brendon Thorne/Bloomberg
Companies deliver value to all stakeholders by doing more in the people, society, governance, economic and environment areas.

site_title: China’s rattled developers turn to business they disdained
summary: China's struggling real estate developers are shifting to construction services as contractors, a field they previously disdained, due to the country's housing downturn. Dozens of developers, including blue-chip giants, are competing in this space, generating smaller revenues than traditional development. The business provides asset-light models, allowing developers to earn healthy profit margins without acquiring land. With the government pushing to complete stalled projects, the demand for construction services is increasing, potentially becoming a lifeline for the sector during the downturn. This shift is expected to represent at least 30% of the real estate industry in the next five years.

images.alt_text: An advertisement of property developer Sunac China Holdings is seen at a residential complex in Shanghai, China March 25, 2018. Picture taken March 25, 2018. REUTERS/Stringer A
FILE PHOTO: The China Evergrande Centre building sign is seen in Hong Kong, China December 7, 2021. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo
Ding has noted at the China Development Forum in Beijing (pictured) that opening to the outside world is a national policy.

site_title: China industrial profits drop on weak demand, falling prices
summary: China's industrial profits dropped 22.9% in the January-February period, the largest decline since 2020, as factories struggled to recover from a Covid-induced slump and prices continued to decline. Foreign firms saw a steeper drop, with profits plummeting 35.7%, while private and state-owned enterprises also saw significant declines. The decline in profits was attributed to weak market demand and falling prices, with the economic recovery facing headwinds from higher-than-expected unemployment and a continued slump in real estate investment.

images.alt_text: Ding has noted at the China Development Forum in Beijing (pictured) that opening to the outside world is a national policy.

Home to most foreign company headquarters and a quarter of China’s expatriate population before 2022, Shanghai has seen an exodus since the brutal two-month lockdown that crippled the city of 25 million from late last March.

site_title: IMF chief warns risks to financial stability have increased
summary: IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva warned that risks to financial stability have increased, citing the recent turmoil in the banking sector and higher debt levels. She expects 2023 to be a challenging year due to global growth slowing to below 3.0% and increasing uncertainties. Georgieva praised China's rebound as a bright spot for the world economy, forecasting a 5.2% growth rate for China this year. She urged China's policymakers to focus on raising productivity and rebalancing the economy towards more durable consumption-driven growth.

images.alt_text: Finma notes that Credit Suisse has a cultural problem that translated into a lack of accountability so it is not clear who is responsible for what.

site_title: Japan’s public approval for PM Kishida’s cabinet rises to near 50%: media
summary: Japan's public approval for Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's cabinet has risen to 48%, exceeding disapproval for the first time in seven months, according to a Nikkei newspaper poll. The approval rate increased 5 percentage points from February, while the disapproval rate fell to 44%. This marks a significant shift in public sentiment, with Kishida's cabinet now holding a near 50% approval rate. The poll results suggest a slight improvement in the government's popularity.

site_title: TPG weighs sale of Singapore healthcare firm at US$1b valuation
summary: TPG is exploring the sale of its Singapore-based healthcare company, TE Asia Healthcare Partners, valued at nearly US$1 billion. The firm has received preliminary interest from investment funds and other hospital operators. TE Asia, co-founded by Eng Aik Meng and TPG in 2014, operates clinics and hospitals in Southeast Asia. The sale process is at an early stage, and TPG may still decide against proceeding. Other buyout firms in the region, such as Southern Capital Group and Quadria Capital, are also considering divesting their healthcare investments.

site_title: Analysts foresee positive market responses to a likely Pheu Thai win
summary: Thailand's upcoming May 14 election is expected to provide a positive market response, with analysts predicting a Pheu Thai Party win. Based on historical market reactions to past general elections, CGS-CIMB and Maybank Securities expect the market to respond positively, with potential gains in sectors such as commerce, ICT, and property. A Pheu Thai win is likely, with the party teaming up with the Palang Pracharat Party to secure Senate seats. The analysts also expect a strong tourism sector and improving economic outlook, leading to a 4% GDP growth forecast for 2023.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

epa10285731 Tourists walk past a tuk tuk in a popular tourist area of Khaosan Road in Bangkok, Thailand, 04 November 2022. Over 3 million tourists visited Thailand in the month of October according to figures from the Transport Ministry, doubling the number of tourists arriving in the country in September, with the bulk of the tourists arriving by air. Thailand's tourism is experiencing a boost after the country lifted all COVID-19 restrictions measures in October.  EPA-EFE/DIEGO AZUBEL
Thai Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha poses with members of the media, after the King endorsed a decree to dissolve parliament on March 20, 2023.

Paetongtarn garnered 38.2 per cent of support in a poll of 2,000. Her approval jumped from 34 per cent in the previous poll conducted in December.
Pheu Thai, the party leading in pre-election surveys, has vowed to almost double daily minimum wages by 2027.

site_title: China developer Shimao seeks buyer for Hong Kong hotel
summary: Chinese property developer Shimao Group is seeking to sell its Hong Kong hotel, the Sheraton & Four Points by Sheraton Tung Chung Hotel, for at least HK$6.5 billion (S$1,103 million). The hotel, which opened in 2020, has a 1,200-key capacity and is the second-largest hotel in the financial hub. Shimao, which is restructurings US$11.8 billion of offshore debt, aims to use the sale to repay its debt. The hotel will be sold via an Expression of Interest process, with interest from local investors, major developers, and foreign funds.

site_title: French PM reaches out to opposition ahead of next day of protests
summary: French Prime Minister Elisabeth Borne announced plans to meet opposition leaders next month to discuss pension reform protests. She also stated that she will not use the controversial mechanism to force through the unpopular reforms without a parliamentary vote, outside of budget matters. The protests, which began weeks ago, aim to block the reform, which includes raising the retirement age from 62 to 64. Borne's move is seen as an attempt to address the opposition's concerns and potentially ease tensions ahead of another day of action by unions.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A person holds a smartphone as Tik Tok logo is displayed behind in this picture illustration taken November 7, 2019. Picture taken November 7, 2019. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/File Photo
French riot police confronting protesters during a demonstration against the French government's pension reform in Paris on March 23, 2023.

(FILES) In this file photo taken on January 31, 2023, protesters demonstrate on a second day of nationwide strikes and protests over the government's proposed pension reform, in Nantes. - The French government's plan to reform the pension system, which includes hiking the minimum retirement age, will begin to be debated in parliament on February 6, 2023, with a third day of nationwide strikes and protest against the bill planned for February 7. The French president is facing his biggest standoff with France's trade unions since coming to power in 2017, with the outcome of a series of strikes and protests seen as decisive for both sides. (Photo by LOIC VENANCE / AFP)

site_title: Team Centurion’s Gan is individual category champion at third leg of BT Golf League
summary: Team Centurion's Stanley Gan won the individual category at the third leg of the BT Corporate Golf League, held on March 24. Dominant Team Boss extended their lead in the competitive team category. Gan, 60, claimed three podium spots and won two prizes in the lucky draw. This victory marks Team Centurion's continued dominance in the league.

images.alt_text: Singapore Pools CEO Lam Chee Weng in action at Tanah Merah Conutry Club during the BT Corporate Golf League 2023.
Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong (seventh from right) at the official opening of Keppel Club at Sime Road on March 18, 2023. On his right is Transport Minister S Iswaran.

Using geolocation data near golf courses in the United States, a Stanford study found there was 278 per cent more people playing golf at 4pm on a Wednesday in August 2022 than in August 2019. And there were 83 per cent more golf games being played on a weekday in August 2022 than in August 2019.
Jayaprakash Jagateesan (second from right), the group CEO of AlDigi Group, a member of ONERHT.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Corp, Far East Hospitality Trust, Sembmarine, Sembcorp Industries, Rex
summary: Keppel Corp's Philippines-listed subsidiary is divesting its remaining 50% stake in The Podium West Tower and The Podium Mall for around S$195 million. Far East Hospitality Trust (FEHT) expects to gain S$130.3 million from the divestment, up from an earlier estimate. Sembcorp Marine's shares fell 8% after its wholly-owned subsidiary was facing investigations for alleged irregularities. Sembcorp Industries will explore building smart industrial parks in nine Vietnamese provinces. Rex International Holding emphasized its commitment to the oil and gas space despite diversification needs.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
wider market

site_title: New Zealand security chiefs increasingly concerned about foreign interference
summary: New Zealand's intelligence agencies are growing concerned about foreign interference and malicious cyber activity ahead of the October elections. State-sponsored cybersecurity actors were linked to 34% of recorded incidents in the past year, up from 28% the previous year. The agencies are working with the election authority to improve cybersecurity and procedures, and will brief political parties on security and foreign interference threats. The concern is not just domestic but also international, with geostrategic competition intensifying globally, including in the Pacific region.

images.alt_text: House prices have dived the past year as the central bank raises interest rates to fight inflation.

site_title: Manager Conte leaves Tottenham ‘by mutual consent’
summary: Antonio Conte has left Tottenham "by mutual consent" after the team's struggles to secure a top-four finish in the Premier League. Conte, who took over in November 2021, will be replaced by assistant Cristian Stellini until the end of the season. Tottenham chairman Daniel Levy stated that the team needs to "pull together" and "step up" to secure the highest possible finish for the club. The team currently sits fourth in the Premier League table, but only two points above fifth-placed Newcastle in the race for Champions League qualification.

images.alt_text: Barcelona have already been charged with corruption by Spanish prosecutors for payments between 2001 and 2018 to a company owned by Spanish league’s former refereeing chief Jose Maria Enriquez Negreira., totalling around 7.3 million euros.

Portugal's forward Cristiano Ronaldo celebrates scoring his team's third goal during the Uefa Euro 2024 qualification match between Portugal and Liechtenstein at the Jose Alvalade stadium in Lisbon, Portugal, March 23, 2023.

site_title: How can Singapore businesses support women leaders?
summary: Singapore businesses can support women leaders by recognizing and leveraging their unique strengths, rather than relying on a one-size-fits-all approach. Companies should develop tailored leadership development programs that focus on individual strengths, rather than gender, and provide opportunities for women to build their personal brand. Additionally, shifting the dialogue to focus on women's strengths and achievements, rather than what they lack, is crucial in driving collective systemic change. By doing so, businesses can help women build confidence, overcome unconscious biases, and reach their full leadership potential.

images.alt_text: If we keep an open mind in our talent recruitment, cast our net deep and wide enough and commit to a rigorous interview and selection process, we will naturally increase the diversity of our talent pool.
Stefanie Yuen Thio, K Shanmugam, Tan Su Shan and Piyush Gupta

site_title: First Citizens in advanced talks to buy Silicon Valley Bank: source
summary: First Citizens BancShares Inc is in advanced talks to acquire Silicon Valley Bank, according to a person familiar with the matter. The potential deal could be finalized as soon as Sunday, following an initial report by Bloomberg News. First Citizens has around $109 billion in assets and $89.4 billion in total deposits, making it a strong candidate to take over the struggling Silicon Valley Bank.

site_title: Credit Suisse faces possible disciplinary proceedings: Finma
summary: Credit Suisse faces possible disciplinary proceedings from Switzerland's banking regulator, Finma, due to a cultural problem that led to a lack of accountability among top managers. Finma president Marlene Amstad stated that the bank's negligence in handling risks was favored by unclear lines of responsibility. The outcome of whether to start fresh proceedings remains uncertain, with Finma exploring options but not acting as a law enforcement agency.

images.alt_text: UBS’ acquisition of Credit Suisse will provide an opportunity for foreign banks to expand into Swiss corporate finance.

site_title: China’s top brands stay cautious on post-Covid consumer recovery
summary: China's top consumer brands, including Li Ning and Anta Sports Products, remain cautious about the sustainability of the country's post-Covid consumer recovery. Despite a boom in demand since the Lunar New Year, executives are hedging their bets with wide revenue forecasts and deep discounts to clear old inventory. The market is expected to face uncertainties in the first half, and consumer confidence may take time to return. Companies are tempering their optimism, with Yum China Holdings and Starbucks warning about keeping a "level head" amidst rising unemployment and a real estate slump.

images.alt_text: Sustainable aviation fuel is tipped to make the difference in the aviation sector, which is currently responsible for 5 per cent of man-made climate change. PHOTO:
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will meet officials during a visit to China.
Ding has noted at the China Development Forum in Beijing (pictured) that opening to the outside world is a national policy.

site_title: Real estate leader on NY Fed board warns on commercial real estate risks
summary: US real estate leader Scott Rechler warns that the commercial real estate finance market is at risk of a systemic crisis if lenders and regulators don't work together to address maturing debt. With $1.5 trillion in commercial real estate debt set to mature in the next three years, Rechler calls for a program to provide lenders with flexibility to develop responsible refinancing plans. He fears that failure to act could lead to a crisis in the banking system, particularly regional banks, which would put pressure on local governments and the economy.

images.alt_text: The meeting comes as markets seesaw amid concerns that a two-week-old banking crisis sparked by the failures of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank could worsen, spreading more runs on smaller banks

site_title: Property investment platform RealVantage turns rising interest rates to its favour
summary: RealVantage, a Singapore-based property investment platform, sees an opportunity in rising interest rates, which are affecting global real estate markets. The platform provides individual investors with access to institutional-grade assets, including secured debt financing deals. CEO Keith Ong believes countries like Australia and the UK offer huge potential for growth, despite a smaller secondary loan market in Singapore. As investors face declining property values and the end of cheap debt, RealVantage may benefit from the market shift.

images.alt_text: Keith Ong, CEO, RealVantage
Ry-Anne Lim

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Monday’s open; STI up 0.6 per cent
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.6% or 18.67 points to 3231.31 at 9:01am on Monday, March 27, 2023, driven by gains from local banks despite Deutsche Bank's woes. The index has had a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

images.alt_text: Shares on the Singapore bourse rose on Tuesday amid a mixed showing by regional peers
Jessie Lim

site_title: Saudi Aramco signs deals with Chinese partners to build refinery
summary: Saudi Aramco has signed deals with Chinese partners North Huajin Chemical and Panjin Xincheng to build a refinery and petrochemical complex in Liaoning Province, China. The project aims to create a world-leading, integrated downstream sector in China, focusing on high conversion of liquids directly into chemicals. The agreement was announced by Amin Nasser, Saudi Aramco's president and CEO, at the China Development Forum in Beijing on March 26.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Logo of Saudi Aramco is seen at the 20th Middle East Oil & Gas Show and Conference (MOES 2017) in Manama, Bahrain, March 7, 2017. REUTERS/Hamad I Mohammed/File Photo

site_title: US regulators say banking system 'sound and resilient'
summary: US regulators say the banking system remains "sound and resilient" despite stress on some institutions, according to a meeting of the Financial Stability Oversight Council. The council, chaired by Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen, discussed current banking conditions and noted that while some institutions have come under stress, the overall system remains resilient. The announcement comes as markets continue to seesaw amid concerns that a two-week-old banking crisis sparked by Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank failures could worsen, spreading runs on smaller banks.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: A security guard stands outside of the entrance of the Silicon Valley Bank headquarters in Santa Clara, California, U.S., March 13, 2023. REUTERS/Brittany Hosea-Small/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: PM Lee to meet Xi Jinping on official visit to China
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will visit China from March 27 to 31, marking his first official trip to the country. The visit includes stops in Beijing, Guangzhou, and Bo'ao in Hainan Province, where Lee will deliver a speech at the Bo'ao Forum for Asia Annual Conference. The trip is an invitation from China's new Premier Li Qiang, and Lee will also meet with President Xi Jinping, who recently assumed an unprecedented third five-year term as state president.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong during his media wrap up for the 40th & 41st ASEAN Summit on November13, 2022 at Sokha Hotel, Phnom Penh, Cambodia.
Claudia Chong

site_title: Malaysia says ex-Astro CEO returned US$10 million linked to 1MDB
summary: Rohana Rozhan, former CEO of Astro Malaysia Holdings, has returned US$10 million linked to the 1MDB scandal. The funds were recovered after an investigation by Malaysia's Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission (MACC) found no evidence of her involvement in embezzlement. The money was returned to the government last year after the MACC completed its probe, which also found she had no knowledge of her ex-boyfriend Tim Leissner's source of funds. No further legal action was taken against her.

site_title: WealthBT: Women and investing - busting pesky myths (Ep 24)
summary: Women and investing are often hindered by misconceptions, with many relying on their spouse for financial decisions. Experts Evy Wee, head of financial planning and personal investing at DBS, emphasizes the importance of foundation knowledge and confidence in overcoming fears and taking calculated risks. She also highlights the need for tailored financial planning for single women, particularly in preparing for recession-proofing investments and creating a comprehensive financial plan. A gender-neutral approach to financial planning is recommended, but acknowledging the unique needs of women is crucial for effective financial planning.

site_title: Elon Musk puts Twitter’s value at just US$20 billion
summary: Elon Musk has valued Twitter at US$20 billion, significantly lower than the US$44 billion he paid for the platform five months ago. This valuation is based on an internal email seen by American news media. The email discusses a new stock compensation program for Twitter employees and the attribution of stock in X Holdings, Twitter's umbrella company. This valuation is lower than that of Snap (US$18.2 billion) and Pinterest (US$18.7 billion).

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Twitter logo and a photo of Elon Musk are displayed through magnifier in this illustration taken October 27, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: World can’t afford US-China conflict: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong warned that the world cannot afford a conflict between China and the US, citing China's growing economic and political influence. Lee emphasized the need for stabilizing relations and building trust between the two nations, acknowledging that the current deteriorating relationship has led to increasingly aggressive rhetoric. The US and China have hit a low point after a series of crises, including the US shooting down a Chinese spy balloon, and officials are now uncertain about a potential phone call between Presidents Biden and Xi Jinping.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong during his media wrap up for the 40th & 41st ASEAN Summit on November13, 2022 at Sokha Hotel, Phnom Penh, Cambodia.

site_title: When selling an ‘£8 million’ flat for 25% less is the right call
summary: A luxury-plus London apartment initially valued at £8 million was relisted at a 25% discount after the sellers' relocation plans changed, with an acceptable offer accepted. The sellers, motivated by a desire to be closer to their ageing parents, initially sought an unscrupulous agent's advice. The agent's advice was to focus on the buyer's perspective, asking "What's in it for me?" to understand their motivations. By repositioning the property and cutting the asking price, the sellers were able to secure a sale, highlighting the importance of understanding buyer motivations in luxury property deals.

images.alt_text: A view of residential properties with the skyline of London's financial district seen behind, seen from Alexandra Palace in London on January 15, 2023. (Photo by Justin TALLIS / AFP)

site_title: Genting’s prime Miami property attracts bids topping US$1 billion
summary: A 15.5-acre waterfront parcel in Miami, previously owned by the Miami Herald, has attracted five bids exceeding US$1 billion, according to broker Michael Fay. Genting, a Malaysian gaming giant, acquired the site for US$236 million in 2011 and plans to invest the proceeds in its US resorts. Potential uses include office space, high-end condos, or an entertainment destination. The highest bid was just under US$1.5 billion, with Genting set to narrow the field to three before making a final decision in the coming weeks.

images.alt_text: The Genting Bhd. logo is displayed at the Genting Resorts Hotel in the Genting Highlands, Selangor, Malaysia, on Tuesday, June 16, 2009. Genting Bhd., Asia's largest listed casino operator, bought a 3.2 percent stake in MGM Mirage for $100 million, MGM spokesman Gordon Absher said on June 10. Photographer: Goh Seng Chong/Bloomberg News

site_title: US weighs energy sanctions on Myanmar hurting allies
summary: The US is considering imposing energy sanctions on Myanmar's state-owned oil and gas company, Moge, to curb the junta's income and ability to buy weapons. This move could harm American allies involved in the energy sector, particularly Thailand and South Korea. The sanctions could prompt China to fill the void and exert greater economic influence on Myanmar. Washington is still assessing the extent of any measures, but the US has already targeted Moge with sanctions earlier this year and has been in close consultation with its allies.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. State Department Counselor Derek Chollet speaks during an interview in Seoul, South Korea, July 11, 2022. REUTERS/Hyonhee Shin/File Photo

site_title: Pocky seeks larger bite of snack market with new Indonesia factory
summary: Japan's Ezaki Glico has opened its largest Pocky factory in Indonesia, a 1.9 trillion rupiah (S$165.8 million) facility in Karawang, supplying the flagship snack to South-east Asia and North America. The 57,000 square meter factory aims to increase Pocky's reach in Indonesia, where the snack accounts for 76% of Glico Asia Pacific's total confectionary sales. The move is part of the company's strategy to boost market share outside Japan, with exports to the US expected to begin this spring.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

site_title: Most assets still in oil and gas; diversification needed to ensure longevity: Rex
summary: Rex International Holding, an oil and gas company, acknowledges the need for diversification to ensure its longevity due to the finite nature of hydrocarbons and environmental concerns. Despite producing over 9,000 barrels per day, the company plans to increase production and reserves, and evaluate new drillings and acquisitions. However, it also recognizes the importance of ESG factors and notes that financing is becoming increasingly difficult. To address this, the company is exploring high-impact investments outside of oil and gas, with a focus on securing its future for all stakeholders.

images.alt_text: An oil platform operated by a Norwegian subsidiary of Singapore's Rex International. The company tops the list in terms of absolute growth. PHOTO: REPSOL

site_title: Thai central bank to hike another 25 bps on March 29 to make up for lost time: poll
summary: The Bank of Thailand (BOT) is expected to hike interest rates by 25 basis points on March 29 to combat inflation, which dropped to 3.79% in February but remains above the target range of 1-3%. This is the fifth consecutive rate hike. A Reuters poll of 22 economists found 18 expected the rate hike, while four predicted no change. The BOT has signaled its tightening cycle is not yet over, unlike its neighbors Malaysia and Indonesia.

images.alt_text: Thai baht banknotes of various denominations sit inside a drawer for an arranged photograph at a Super Rich 1965 Co. currency exchange store in Bangkok, Thailand, on Thursday, Aug. 22, 2013. Thailand's baht fell to the weakest level since August 2010 after Federal Reserve minutes showed officials support a cut in stimulus this year should the U.S. economy improve. Photographer: Dario Pignatelli/Bloomberg

site_title: Sinopec full-year earnings decline on impact from Covid curbs
summary: Sinopec Group reported a net income of 66.2 billion yuan for 2022, down from 72 billion yuan the previous year due to COVID-19 restrictions in China that reduced fuel demand. The company attributed the decline to lower refining and chemical unit performance. Sinopec plans to increase capital expenditure by 165.8 billion yuan this year to compensate for increased costs and is lobbying for higher export quotas to take advantage of stronger diesel margins overseas.

site_title: India’s Reliance Industries names new chief financial officer
summary: Reliance Industries has appointed Srikanth Venkatachari as its new chief financial officer, effective June 1. He succeeds Alok Agarwal, who held the position since 2005. Venkatachari, currently the joint CFO, will also serve as senior advisor to Reliance Chairman Mukesh Ambani.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Labourers rest in front of an advertisement of Reliance Industries Limited at a construction site in Mumbai, India, March 2, 2016. REUTERS/Shailesh Andrade/File Photo

site_title: Which celebrities are facing backlash for crypto promotion?
summary: The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has charged eight celebrities, including Lindsay Lohan, Jake Paul, and Soulja Boy, with illegally promoting crypto assets without disclosing their financial ties. The celebrities agreed to pay settlements totaling $400,000. The SEC alleges that the celebrities' endorsements of unsound or unexplained investments can lead to financial losses for their fans. Experts warn that celebrities' endorsements should not be taken as investment advice. The charges mark the latest crackdown on celebrities promoting risky investments to fans.

images.alt_text: bitcoin, money, decentralized

site_title: Decoding the secret language of plants
summary: Scientists have discovered that plants communicate through electrical signals, which could be a secret language. Researchers in Singapore have developed a device to deliver and monitor these signals, allowing them to study plant behavior and potentially engineer plants to produce signals that induce resistance to pests. The discovery has sparked debate about plant intelligence and sentience, with some arguing that plants may be more intelligent than previously thought. While the technology holds promise, the biggest challenge is understanding the plant language, and the concept remains a topic of ongoing research and discussion.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
The whey protein in Perfect Day's Very Dairy milk is made in a lab, using a bioengineered form of the fungus Trichoderma reesei.
The days of unicorns running rampant may well be over.

site_title: Dollar outshines euro and sterling amid European bank jitters
summary: The dollar index rose 0.536% to 103.140, surpassing the euro and sterling, amid European bank jitters. The euro fell 0.71% to US$1.0753, while sterling dropped 0.53% to US$1.222. This trend is attributed to risk aversion, with safe-haven assets like gold and the yen outperforming. The US Federal Reserve's cautious stance on rate hikes following banking sector turmoil is also contributing to the dollar's strength.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. Dollar and Euro banknotes are seen in this illustration taken July 17, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration//File Photo

site_title: Short sellers step up bets against US office owners on bank turmoil
summary: Short sellers have increased their bets against US office landlords, betting that the US regional banking crisis will slash credit availability to property owners. Hedge funds are using credit derivatives and equities to bet against companies and their debt, with nearly 40% of shares in the iShares US Real Estate ETF sold short. The US regional banking crisis could have serious implications for commercial real estate finance, with many lenders losing deposits and potentially cutting into their ability to finance real estate.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians stand along the waterfront in Weehawken, New Jersey, across the Hudson river from the skyline of midtown Manhattan, New York, at sundown, on March 22, 2023. (Photo by Leonardo Munoz / AFP)

site_title: Standard Chartered to sell business in Jordan
summary: Standard Chartered plans to sell its Jordanian business to Arab Jordan Investment Bank (AJIB), subject to central bank approval. The sale includes corporate, commercial, and institutional banking, consumer lending, and private banking businesses, with all employees transferring to AJIB. This move follows AJIB's plans to exit seven markets in Africa and the Middle East, as the emerging markets-focused lender seeks to expand its presence in the region.

site_title: Airlines, hotels making more sustainable choices as travel rebounds
summary: Airlines and hotels are adopting more sustainable choices as travel rebounds, with sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) and green technologies expected to play a key role in reducing carbon emissions. According to OCBC Investment Research, SAF will be crucial in meeting the aviation industry's goal of net-zero carbon emissions by 2050. Hotels are also focusing on water conservation, energy efficiency, and reducing carbon emissions, with many setting climate-based targets and committing to sustainable practices. As travel demand increases, sustainable options are becoming more accessible, with travel websites displaying sustainability information for properties.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah
(Photo: RENDY ARYANTO/VVS.sg)

According to the IPCC, emissions must be halved by the mid-2030s if the world is to have any chance of limiting temperature rise to 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels – a key target enshrined in the Paris accord.

The Synthesis Report by the UN’s Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change carries the finding that the solution set currently at the world’s disposal to fix its climate change woes is more compelling than previously thought.

site_title: Strict rules constrain first Hong Kong protest in two years
summary: Hong Kong held its first protest in two years on Sunday, March 26, against a land reclamation plan, with strict rules in place, including a 100-person cap and mandatory number tags. The event, the first officially authorised protest since the COVID-19 pandemic measures were lifted, showed the measure of dissent still allowed in the city. Protest organiser Cyrus Chan said police closely examined banners and placards, while one marcher described the arrangements as "ridiculous" and "intimidation". The restrictions have been deemed "disproportionate" by experts, raising concerns about freedom of speech and assembly.

images.alt_text: UBS agreed on Sunday to a government-brokered deal to take over Credit Suisse for 3 billion Swiss francs.

site_title: Sembcorp joint venture explores building sustainable industrial parks in 9 Vietnam provinces
summary: Sembcorp Industries' joint venture, Vietnam Singapore Industrial Park (VSIP), is exploring sustainable industrial parks in nine Vietnamese provinces. The company signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with province leaders to conduct feasibility studies for smart and sustainable industrial parks. Five industrial parks valued at approximately US$1 billion are planned, with projects progressing to a cooperation agreement subject to central government investment registration certificate. The collaboration aims to enhance socio-economic development through higher value manufacturing, job creation, and new urban area development.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp Industries is staring at S$54 million in fines and civil claims for its water-treatment joint venture in China's illegal discharge of wastewater.
Claudia Chong

site_title: Technical setup suggests further downside for USDJPY
summary: The US dollar-Japanese yen currency pair (USDJPY) is expected to extend its downtrend, with a breakdown below a rising wedge formation on March 10 and a bearish crossover of the 20 exponential moving average (20 EMA) below the 50 EMA. The Relative Strength Index (RSI) and Moving Average Convergence Divergence (MACD) also indicate a bearish sentiment, with RSI below 50 and MACD in negative territory. A temporary rebound to test resistance around 131.8 is expected, with targets set at 128.95 and 127.2 if the pair continues to depreciate.

images.alt_text: The German equity benchmark was not spared from recent risk-off moves as investor sentiment was soured in the wake of US regional bank collapses (Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank).

site_title: I took over my father’s finances at 25. The lessons were hard-won
summary: A 25-year-old woman, Samantha Chencharik, took over her father's finances after he suffered a grand mal seizure and was placed in a medically induced coma. She had to navigate her father's complicated and secretive finances, which led to her learning valuable lessons about financial management and caregiving. Chencharik's experience highlights the challenges of becoming a caregiver at a young age and the importance of transparency in managing finances. She emphasizes the need for a partnership between the parent and caregiver to ensure the parent's wishes are carried out while also setting boundaries to protect oneself.

images.alt_text: Investing in stocks can be scary at first, but this should pale in comparison to the fear of running out of money when we retire.
SVB seems to have failed investing in US Treasuries – is this the first time a bank failed because it had too many Treasuries?

site_title: Sembcorp leads buyback tally for second consecutive week
summary: Sembcorp Industries led the buyback tally for the second consecutive week, buying over 3.4 million shares at an average price of S$4.09 per share. The company's total consideration for the five sessions was S$32.4 million. In contrast, DBS, OCBC, and Suntec Reit were among the top net institutional outflow for the week. Institutions were net sellers of Singapore stocks, with a total outflow of S$109 million. Meanwhile, UOB, Genting Singapore, Golden Agri-Resources, Wilmar International, and Sembcorp Industries were among the top net institutional inflow for the week.

images.alt_text: Institutions were net sellers of Singapore stocks over the five sessions that spanned Mar 10 to Mar 16 with S$107 million of net outflow.

site_title: Credit Suisse takeover hands Swiss business a big headache
summary: UBS' acquisition of Credit Suisse threatens to drastically shrink financing options for small and mid-sized companies in Switzerland, as the 166-year-old bank's demise leaves a void in complex corporate finance services. Despite local concerns about monopolistic power, regulators show little push to keep the Swiss business independent. Analysts value Credit Suisse's Swiss unit at around 10 billion Swiss francs, about triple what UBS paid for the whole bank, and predict increased pressure to spin off the unit, potentially harming local jobs and competition.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Logos of Swiss banks UBS and Credit Suisse are seen in Zurich, Switzerland March 20, 2023. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Germany faces travel chaos as airport, rail workers strike
summary: Germany's air and rail services will be severely disrupted on Monday due to a one-day strike by transport and railway unions Verdi and EVG. The strike, starting at midnight, will affect major airports including Frankfurt and Munich, and long-distance, regional, and local trains. The unions are demanding a 10.5% pay raise for public sector workers amid record inflation and a cost of living crisis. The strike coincides with a peak travel period ahead of Easter.

images.alt_text: The UK has lost 2.67 million days to labour disputes since June last year.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for March 24, 2023, provides an overview of the tanker and dry bulk market. The Capesize market declined early in the week but showed a midweek recovery, with the timecharter average reaching over $15,000. The Panamax market experienced slow erosion, with limited activity in the North Atlantic. The Ultramax/Supramax sector had a patchy week, with sustained interest from the US Gulf and Mediterranean regions. The Suezmax market continued its upward trend, with the Aframax market experiencing gains in the North Sea and Mediterranean. The VLCC market was softer across all regions, with the LNG market experiencing downward pressure due to high storage and supply levels.

images.alt_text: As we finish the week, BLNG2g US-UK closes at $53,697 – a fall of $3405 throughout the week. BLNG3g US-Japan finishes at $60,571, a fall of $5373.

site_title: Small US banks see record drop in deposits after SVB collapse
summary: US small banks saw a record drop in deposits, falling $119 billion to $5.46 trillion in the week ended March 15, following the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank. This is the largest decline as a percentage of overall deposits since 2007. Meanwhile, borrowings at small banks increased to a record $669.6 billion, with some banks using this to build war chests as a precautionary measure. Large US banks saw a smaller increase in deposits, rising $67 billion to $10.74 trillion, while also increasing borrowings by $251 billion.

images.alt_text: A sign for Deutsche Bank AG at a bank branch in the financial district of Frankfurt, Germany, on Thursday, Feb. 2, 2023. site_title: Lebanon in confusion as daylight savings dispute deepens divisions
summary: Lebanon's caretaker Prime Minister Najib Mikati has decided to roll clocks forward an hour on April 20, defying the last weekend of March as usual, amid a dispute over daylight saving time. This decision, aimed at allowing Muslims to break their fast an hour earlier during Ramadan, has been met with opposition from the influential Maronite church, which claims no consultations were held. The move has deepened divisions in a country still recovering from a 1975-90 civil war, with businesses and media organizations announcing they will also enter daylight saving time, causing potential chaos.

images.alt_text: A car drives near a clock tower in Jdeideh, Lebanon March 25, 2023. REUTERS/Mohamed Azakir

site_title: China vice-premier pledges nation will continue to open up
summary: Chinese Vice-Premier Ding Xuexiang pledged that China will continue to open up to the world, citing it as a national policy, in a speech at the China Development Forum in Beijing. The country's economy has rebounded since lifting COVID-19 restrictions, with domestic demand driving growth. However, challenges remain, including falling exports and a weak property market. China's Finance Minister Liu Kun announced plans to expand fiscal expenditure and increase transfer payments to local administrations. The US business community has expressed concerns over market-access challenges, but Foreign Minister Qin Gang said China's opening up will offer "triple" benefits for US businesses.

images.alt_text: China will create a market-oriented, legal and international business environment and strengthen the policy guidance to support advanced manufacturing, said Chinese Premier Li Qiang.
Investors track key political events in China for word on GDP growth target and national security policy

site_title: Global IPO market revival undermined by banking, recession risks
summary: The global initial public offering (IPO) market has faced a slump due to banking and recession risks, despite initial optimism at the start of 2023. In 2023, companies have raised just $19.7 billion via IPOs, down 70% from last year, with the US seeing the steepest decline. Banking sector troubles, including the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank, have added uncertainty to the market, with investors hesitant to invest in businesses they don't know. Secondary offerings have been a bright spot, but bankers remain cautiously optimistic that equity capital markets activity will pick up soon.

site_title: Ex-WWE chief McMahon pays back US$17.4 million in investigation costs
summary: Vince McMahon, former WWE chairman and CEO, has paid US$17.4 million to cover investigation costs related to alleged misconduct, including agreements to suppress allegations of sexual misconduct and infidelity. McMahon retired as CEO and chairman in July last year but returned to the board in January after the probe was completed.

site_title: A crypto fugitive’s very public life while on the run
summary: South Korean crypto mogul Do Kwon, a fugitive, appeared on a livestream with Martin Shkreli in November after the South Korean government issued a warrant for his arrest. Kwon was seen smiling and nodding in response to Shkreli's comments about jail not being so bad. The incident has raised questions about Kwon's ability to evade authorities and his willingness to engage with the public despite being on the run. Kwon's current whereabouts and status remain unknown.
