site_title: General insurance underwriting profit up 15% on strong health segment performance
summary: The general insurance sector in Singapore saw a 15% increase in gross written premiums to S$9.3 billion in 2022, driven by a 9.6% growth in the domestic segment. The health segment was the strongest contributor, with a 19% increase in gross written premiums and a profit of S$64.5 million. Underwriting profit for the sector rose 14.8% to S$301.6 million. The General Insurance Association attributed the sector's growth to the increasing demand for corporate health coverage.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
General insurance sector posts underwriting profit of S$262.7m despite more claims paid out
Underwriting profit up for general insurance sector
General insurance sector posts turnaround in underwriting profits in 2020, but this may not be sustainable: GIA

site_title: At New York’s most exclusive whisky bar, a pour can go for US$1,300
summary: New York's exclusive whisky bar, Beatbox, opens with a limited capacity of four guests, accessible only to those who have dined at Kono, the yakitori spot next door. The bar follows Japan's "you've got to know someone" concept, where priority access is given to regulars and their friends. A pour of whisky can cost up to $1,300, and reservations can be made through Instagram for new customers. The intimate, midcentury modern-styled bar features whisky bottles and vinyl records on its walls.

site_title: Temasek’s Sheares Healthcare leads US$4 million round in mental health startup ThoughtFull
summary: Singapore-based digital mental health startup ThoughtFull has raised a US$4 million pre-Series A round led by Temasek-owned Sheares Healthcare Group. ThoughtFull operates a digital platform offering video calls and text-based mental health coaching, and plans to use the funds to scale its business across Asia and conduct clinical research. The round also involved Vulpes Investment Management, The Hive Southeast Asia, and global family offices. ThoughtFull aims to provide seamless, end-to-end mental healthcare solutions.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

site_title: UBS likely to shrink Credit Suisse’s US$10 billion shipping portfolio: WSJ
summary: UBS is likely to shrink Credit Suisse's $10 billion shipping portfolio, which was inherited as part of its emergency takeover. The portfolio involves Greek ship owners using deposits as collateral to finance new ships. UBS may sell the portfolio, but doing so could prompt owners to move their accounts elsewhere. Swiss authorities announced the takeover last week to contain a crisis of confidence in global banking.

site_title: Airports of Thailand to invest 36.8 billion baht to expand low-cost terminal
summary: Airports of Thailand plans to invest 36.8 billion baht to expand its low-cost terminal at Bangkok's Don Mueang Airport, increasing passenger capacity from 30 million to 40 million per year. Construction will begin in 2023 and finish in 2029, boosting tourism income and national income. The expansion will include 12 aircraft parking stands and 11 jet bridges. The project will be funded using operating cash flow, aiming to increase income from tourism and the service sector.

site_title: After another rate hike, Fed signals no let-up in fight against inflation
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised its benchmark rate by a quarter of a percentage point, signaling no let-up in its fight against inflation. Despite concerns about bank runs, the Fed believes inflation is the more imminent threat and expects a slowdown in lending activity, potentially slowing economic activity. Chairman Jerome Powell dismissed the crisis, but his comments were met with market panic, with shares of affected banks plummeting. The Fed is unlikely to cut rates and will continue to focus on inflation risks, with economists predicting another rate hike in May.

images.alt_text: The ‘moral hazard’ of a higher federal insurance limit on US bank deposits

site_title: New Zealand house sales hit lowest since 1983 as prices plunge
summary: New Zealand's annual house sales have reached their lowest level in nearly 40 years, with 60,589 sales in the 12 months through February, a 33% decline from 2022. House prices have plunged 14% over the past year due to rising interest rates to combat inflation. The central bank's interest rate hikes are expected to continue, with economists predicting further falls in the year ahead. First-home buyers are also staying out of the market, with some reaching their limit due to high interest rates.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand said it was aware of the current financial stability issues “with a small number of banks internationally”, adding it was in regular contact with other regional regulators and regulated entities.
The RBNZ, which is aiming to engineer a recession in 2023 to suppress demand and rein in inflation, predicted growth of 0.7 per cent for the fourth quarter.

site_title: Open letter to Rex International Holding’s directors and management
summary: A shareholder expresses concern over Rex International Holding's diversification into non-oil and gas businesses through acquisitions by management family members, depleting shareholder value. The company has adequate cash reserves and proprietary technology, but its core oil and gas business is struggling. The management's actions are seen as a betrayal of shareholder trust and a distraction from the core business. The shareholder calls for the management to refocus on oil and gas exploration and production, upgrade skills, and utilize the company's share buyback mandate to boost shareholder value.

images.alt_text: Rex is hopeful that Xer, which sold its first drone through a tender to the Swedish government, will sell more units this year.
UOB Kay Hian downgrades its call on Rex International Holding (Rex) to “sell”, due to its poor financial results in 2022 and the group’s diversification plans.

site_title: Kredivo raises US$270 million in Series D funding
summary: Kredivo, a fintech startup, has raised US$270 million in a Series D funding round led by Japan's Mizuho Bank. Existing investors joined the round, with plans to use the funds to expand its buy now, pay later (BNPL) ecosystem and support the launch of its neobank Krom. The company aims to become a digital financial services platform for tens of millions of consumers in South-east Asia, despite challenging market conditions.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

site_title: Japan’s Eneos to study sustainable aviation fuel production with Australia
summary: Japan's Eneos Holdings has agreed to study the production of up to 500 million litres of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) and renewable diesel per year with Australia's Ampol. The two companies will explore the use of waste feedstocks in Queensland, Australia, to produce biofuels for domestic consumption and exports. Eneos aims to expand its supplies of SAF to meet global aviation industry demand and reduce carbon footprint. Japan's top airlines, All Nippon Airways and Japan Airlines, have committed to using SAF to meet 10% of their fuel needs by 2030.

site_title: Short seller Hindenburg Research says another report coming soon
summary: Hindenburg Research, a short-selling firm led by Nate Anderson, plans to release a new report soon, but details are scarce. The firm gained prominence after its January report on Gautam Adani's group wiped out over $150 billion in market value. Hindenburg, which operates with its own capital, prefers to be known as a forensic research outfit rather than a hedge fund. The upcoming report's timing and content have not been disclosed.

site_title: Work ‘still ongoing’ on how to define workplace discrimination in upcoming law: Zaqy
summary: Singapore's Senior Minister of State for Manpower Zaqy Mohamad stated that work on defining workplace discrimination under upcoming laws is ongoing, with feedback regarding the definition still being discussed. The proposed legislation aims to ban discrimination against five protected characteristics, with recommendations including monetary and non-monetary remedies for employees and proportionate penalties for employers. Zaqy hopes employers and employees will uphold merit-based employment principles, while panellists emphasized the need for a balance between deterrence and fair HR practices to ensure the legislation is not overly harsh.

images.alt_text: More remedies for workers, employer penalties proposed for Singapore’s anti-discrimination law
Under the new guidelines, employers should be sensitive to the cultures, values and beliefs of their employees when developing, promoting or implementing any non-work-related activities.
Some have expressed concern that they will be pressured into supporting diversity efforts at work following the repeal of Section 377A, said several Members of Parliament.

site_title: Gold edges higher after Federal Reserve signals pause in rate hikes
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,972.72 per ounce on Thursday after the US Federal Reserve signaled a possible pause in interest rate hikes, citing recent financial sector turmoil. The Fed raised interest rates by 25 basis points and indicated only one more hike may be needed this year. This move boosted gold prices, seen as a hedge against inflation, and made bullion more attractive in a low-interest-rate environment.

images.alt_text: Gold is traditionally considered a hedge against inflation, but higher rates increase the opportunity cost of holding the non-yielding asset.

site_title: Dial-back in headline inflation to 6.3% in February; core holds steady at 5.5%
summary: Singapore's headline inflation eased to 6.3% in February, the lowest in nine months, due to lower private-transport inflation. Core inflation, excluding accommodation and private transport, remained unchanged at 5.5%. Food inflation remained steady at 8.1%. Economists expect a slight decline in full-year 2023 core inflation forecast and no change in monetary policy tightening in April. Despite a softer tone on imported inflation, the authorities still project regional inflation will remain supported by Asia's resilient growth.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Economists barely change 2023 forecasts for Singapore’s growth, inflation: survey
Core inflation is expected to remain high in the coming months, providing room for further monetary policy tightening, economists say.

site_title: After Federal Reserve, Europe’s central banks to decide on rates
summary: European central banks, including the Bank of England, Norwegian, and Swiss central banks, are set to announce interest-rate decisions on Thursday, March 23, amid stubbornly-high inflation. The decision follows the US Federal Reserve's 25 basis point rate hike to combat inflation. The Bank of England is expected to raise rates by 25 basis points, its eleventh consecutive increase, while the Swiss National Bank is forecast to raise rates by 50 basis points. The moves aim to bring down inflation and tighten credit conditions for households and businesses, despite recent turmoil in the banking sector.

images.alt_text: Gold bars from the Credit Suisse are seen in a shop in Zurich, Switzerland March 20, 2023. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse

site_title: Chinese firm invents lockdown-inspired kissing machine for remote lovers
summary: A Chinese startup, Siweifushe, has developed a lockdown-inspired kissing machine called MUA, which transmits kiss data through motion sensors in silicon lips and captures sound and warmth to create a more authentic experience. The device, priced around $50, was inspired by China's prolonged lockdowns during the Covid-19 pandemic and has sold over 3,000 units in its first two weeks. The MUA has received mixed reviews, with some users finding it intriguing while others feel uncomfortable, particularly due to its lack of tongue.

images.alt_text: Dr. Tan Min-Han, founder and chief executive officer, Lucence, sees the approval of Medicare as a door opener for other insurance providers in the US.

site_title: Defensive equities, high-grade fixed income, gold to outperform amid US banking system concerns
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen's comments about not insuring all US bank deposits have raised concerns about the stability of the US banking system, overshadowing a 25-basis-point rate hike by the Federal Open Market Committee. Defensive equities, high-grade fixed income, and gold are expected to outperform amid market volatility, with analysts suggesting a possible end to the current rate hike cycle and a softer US dollar. Investors are shifting focus to growth-oriented sectors, including consumer staples and telecoms, and are taking a more defensive approach in asset allocation.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
The Bank of England is trying to reconcile Britain’s weak economic outlook and the worries about global banks with stubbornly high price growth.

site_title: Participation in SkillsFuture Singapore programmes falls in 2022; still higher than 2019
summary: SkillsFuture Singapore (SSG) programme participation fell year on year in 2022, but remained higher than pre-pandemic levels, with 560,000 individuals and 20,000 enterprises participating. Demand for short courses remained high, with over 32,000 attendees. SSG-supported training improved work performance for 97% of trainees, and small and medium-sized enterprises comprised 96% of participating companies.

images.alt_text: It would become an offence for anyone to put up misleading advertisements that a course is funded or accredited by SkillsFuture Singapore, if a proposed amendment bill is passed.

site_title: Hong Kong hiring seen picking up in 2023 as bonuses slide
summary: Hong Kong is expected to see an increase in hiring in 2023, with 44% of company chiefs planning to add staff, up from 40% last year, according to a KPMG survey. Salaries are also expected to rise, with a 23% average increase for those changing jobs in 2022. However, bonuses are expected to decrease, averaging 2.43 months, down from 2.21 months in 2021. The hiring and salary trends come as Hong Kong emerges from its Covid controls and faces a tight employment market.

site_title: CDL, MCL to start previews for Tembusu Grand at prices from S$2,296 psf

The 638-unit development will feature one-bedroom to five-bedroom units, with prices starting from S$1.248 million (S$2,368 psf) for one-bedroom units to S$4.028 million (S$2,354 psf) for five-bedroom units. Sales bookings will start on April 8, and the project offers over 40 recreational facilities and smart-home systems.

images.alt_text: Bukit Sembawang Estates' Liv @ MB sold more than 75 per cent of its 298 units on its launch weekend.
URA awards Jalan Tembusu and Lentor Hills site to highest bidders
Both sites fall under the confirmed list in the first half 2023 government land sales programme. Together, they may yield around 1,540 residential units.

site_title: China Evergrande’s EV unit may shut down without new funding
summary: China Evergrande New Energy Vehicle (NEV) Group warned it may shut down production if it can't secure new funding, citing a lack of cash and significant liabilities. The company, which had pledged to rival Tesla within three to five years, has delivered only 900 of its delayed flagship model and is considering staff reductions and asset sales. Evergrande NEV's shares have been suspended since April last year, and the company faces a cash flow gap of 5 billion yuan to 7 billion yuan from 2023 to 2026.

images.alt_text: Evergrande said on Monday that a key bondholder group had agreed to its proposed terms and that it plans to publish the details on Wednesday.
An ad hoc group of offshore bondholders has expressed support for China Evergrande Group’s plan, and a restructuring support agreement is being drafted.

site_title: Australian crypto exchange weighs potential Hong Kong base
summary: Australian cryptocurrency exchange Independent Reserve plans to explore opportunities in Hong Kong, following the city's efforts to create a hub for digital-asset businesses. The company's CEO, Adrian Przelozny, stated that Independent Reserve will visit Hong Kong to learn about the upcoming regulations and consider opening another office in Asia. This move comes as a growing number of firms, including crypto market data provider Kaiko, plan to relocate to Hong Kong from Singapore due to the city's more favorable regulatory environment.

site_title: ‘Zombie’ developers increase in South Korea as property market wobbles
summary: South Korea's property market is experiencing a rise in "zombie" developers, with 36.1% of listed developers unable to fully cover interest expenses in the third quarter of last year. This increase is attributed to the Bank of Korea's rate hikes and a growing number of unsold homes, leading to difficulties in paying short-term debt. Risks are particularly high for small and medium-sized developers, prompting policymakers to call for more scrutiny of their debt positions. The central bank's further rate hikes may exacerbate the issue, potentially increasing the share of zombie firms this year.

site_title: Celebrities Lindsay Lohan, Jake Paul charged for touting crypto
summary: US celebrities Lindsay Lohan and Jake Paul have been charged by the Securities and Exchange Commission for touting cryptocurrencies on social media without disclosing they were paid. They agreed to pay $40,670 and $101,887 in restitution and fines, respectively. The charges are part of a broader crackdown on cryptocurrencies following the FTX collapse, targeting other celebrities including Justin Sun and several others for marketing and manipulating crypto assets without proper disclosure.

images.alt_text: A spokesperson for Circle told Reuters that chief strategy officer Dante Disparte’s account had been hacked.

site_title: China expected to account for 40% of this year’s oil demand recovery
summary: China is expected to account for 40% of the global oil demand increase this year, driven by its economy emerging from strict lockdowns, according to consultancy Wood Mackenzie. China's economy is forecast to grow 5.5% this year, resulting in a 2.6 million barrels per day increase in global oil demand. Despite this, oil prices are unlikely to reach 2022 levels, with Brent crude averaging around $89.40/bbl this year, according to the report.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures rose US$1.37, or 1.8 per cent, to settle at US$76.69 a barrel on Wednesday.

site_title: China Evergrande will swap defaulted debt in court restructuring
summary: China Evergrande Group has proposed a debt restructuring plan, allowing offshore creditors to swap defaulted debt for new securities. The plan, worth billions of dollars, will see Scenery Journey creditors receive US$6.5 billion in new bonds and Tianji investors receive US$800 million in new notes. The restructuring aims to allow Evergrande to focus on returning to normal operations, but analysts warn it may lead to prolonged delays in completing projects and a blow to buyer confidence. The plan's success will depend on the performance of the securities chosen by bondholders.

images.alt_text: Having touted the car as early as 2019 and pledging to rival Tesla within three to five years, Evergrande NEV has been plagued by production delays and setbacks.

site_title: Asia: Markets fall with Wall Street after Fed rate hike, warning
summary: Asian markets fell on Thursday, tracking losses on Wall Street after the US Federal Reserve hiked interest rates again, dealing a blow to hopes of rate cuts later this year. The 25-basis-point rise was half of what was expected, with Fed boss Jerome Powell warning that "rate cuts are not in our base case." Analysts say the Fed must balance inflation and credit conditions, with speculation of another rate hike in May. Oil prices fell back as traders fret over demand from rate hikes and economic slowdown concerns.

Daniels received a $130,000 hush payment from Trump just before the 2016 presidential election, which is being investigated by the Manhattan district attorney. Trump has denied any wrongdoing, but Daniels has spoken out about their consensual relationship and the promises he made to her, including a role on "The Apprentice." The scandal has sparked a public feud between Daniels and Trump, with Daniels taunting him with crude nicknames on social media.

images.alt_text: Trump at the NCAA wrestling championships in Tulsa, Oklahoma on Saturday; the probe comes as he seeks the Republican nomination for the presidency in 2024.

site_title: Inflation shock puts Bank of England on course to raise rates again
summary: The Bank of England is expected to raise interest rates for the 11th time in a row, driven by a surprise jump in inflation to 10.4% in February. Despite a weak economic outlook and global bank concerns, the BoE aims to reconcile high price growth with its economic outlook. Most economists expect a quarter percentage-point increase in Bank Rate, with some speculating that this may be the last rate hike in the BoE's run.

site_title: First Republic downgraded by fitch amid cash crunch

The bank, which received a $30 billion deposit from a consortium of US banks, is currently operating at a loss and faces challenges in repaying the deposit. The ratings firm warned of further downgrades, citing concerns over the bank's capital position and the fair market value of its securities and loans.

site_title: In Australia, state election challenges powerful slot machine industry
summary: In Australia's New South Wales, the ruling conservative coalition is promising to make slot machines cashless in a bid to tackle problem gambling and money laundering. The plan, which could be implemented by 2028, aims to set loss limits for gamblers and curb the powerful "pokies" industry. The move has raised hopes among anti-gambling campaigners, who blame the industry for leaving hundreds of thousands of Australians financially ruined. The outcome of the state election, which is seen as a key test of the government's commitment to reform, is uncertain, with the main opposition Labor party expressing reluctance to support the measures.

images.alt_text: Half of Australia’s poker machines are in New South Wales.
The Philippine gaming industry has attracted foreign and domestic firms to set up sprawling casino-resorts, creating tens of thousands of jobs in the past decade.

site_title: Spotify has spent less than 10% of its US$100 million diversity fund
summary: Spotify's $100 million Creator Equity Fund, established in February 2022, spent less than 10% of its budget on promoting diversity in music and podcasts, according to sources. The initiative faced a slow start, shifting priorities, and internal challenges, including a delayed 2023 budget and undetermined priority projects. This comes after a similar Spotify fund for podcasts was impacted by layoffs last year, according to a union representing workers.

site_title: Oil up 2% as dollar weakens on small Federal Reserve rate hike
summary: Oil prices rose 2% to a one-week high as the US dollar weakened following a small Federal Reserve rate hike. Brent crude futures rose $1.37, or 1.8%, to $76.69 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose $1.23, or 1.8%, to $70.90. The rate hike hinted at a potential pause in future increases, contributing to the dollar's decline and oil price surge.

images.alt_text: Brent crude settled up US$1.53, or 2.1 per cent, at US$69.33 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) closed up US$1.69, or 2.5 per cent to US$69.33.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Thursday’s open; STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.6% to 3,200.88 at open on Thursday, following the US Federal Reserve's 0.25% interest rate hike. Losers outnumbered gainers 80 to 35, with banking shares heavily impacted. Key counters like Singtel (-1.7%), OCBC (-1%), and DBS (-0.2%) declined, while Sembcorp Marine and CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust closed flat. site_title: Job site Indeed cuts 2,200 positions as tech sector cools
summary: Indeed, a job site owned by Japan-based Recruit Holdings, is cutting approximately 2,200 positions, about 15% of its workforce, amid a cooling job market. The company cited a slowing economy and rising interest rates as reasons for the layoffs, which will affect nearly every team. This move joins other tech companies, including Amazon and Meta Platforms, in retrenching workers. CEO Chris Hyams expects human resources tech revenue to decline in fiscal 2023 and possibly 2024.

images.alt_text: The Swiss company’s move is in line with downsizing efforts across the tech industry.

site_title: US Federal Reserve delivers small rate hike amid global banking turmoil
summary: The US Federal Reserve delivered a small interest rate hike of 0.25% to balance inflation risks with banking system instability. The move comes after the collapse of two US banks, with Fed Chairman Jerome Powell reassuring investors about the banking system's soundness. Powell attributed the Silicon Valley Bank's collapse to poor management, not broader weaknesses. The Fed's actions aim to pause further rate increases, amid global banking turmoil and ongoing economic concerns.

summary: Tesla's price cuts in China have triggered a price war, with over 30 carmakers offering discounts to compete. The price war, which started in October, has led to hefty discounts, with some models being up to 14% cheaper than last year and almost 50% less expensive than in the US and Europe. Industry experts predict the market will undergo "profound fundamental consolidation" as weaker players face "survival challenges." Despite this, Tesla's shares have rallied 60% this year, outperforming major Chinese EV makers.

site_title: EU to clean up product ‘greenwashing’ mess
summary: The European Union has proposed a directive to tackle "greenwashing" in environmental labels, aiming to make them more transparent and easier to understand. The plan targets companies exploiting consumers' environmental concerns with dubious claims about products' environmental benefits. The directive will not ban the "carbon neutral" label, but instead, will require companies to provide more detailed information about their claims. The move aims to increase trust in environmental labels and protect consumers from misleading advertising.

site_title: Young, fast and ambitious
summary: Singapore Realtors Inc (SRI) aims to nearly double its workforce to 2,000 by the end of 2023, driven by its strong growth despite the Covid-19 pandemic.
