site_title: US: Stocks tumble after Federal Reserve rate hike, concerns on economy
summary: US stocks tumbled 1.6% on Wednesday, with the Dow and Nasdaq falling 1.6% and 1.7% respectively, after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates by a quarter-point for the ninth straight time to combat inflation. Banking sector turmoil and concerns about economic activity weighed on investors, with US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen's comments on deposit insurance adding to jitters. The Fed's decision was seen as a "no-win position," with paused rate hikes sparking market worries about the banking sector's woes.

images.alt_text: Following Credit Suisse’s shotgun takeover by UBS, and US authorities and large banks helping prop up some of the more vulnerable regional institutions, investors are breathing a little more easily, leading to the US dollar losing some of its safe-haven appeal this week.

site_title: Renault invites bank pitches for listing its electric vehicle arm
summary: Renault is inviting investment banks to pitch for a role on the planned initial public offering (IPO) of its Ampere electric-vehicle (EV) business, with a potential valuation of around 10 billion euros. The French carmaker aims to narrow the gap with bigger rivals like Stellantis and raise funds for EV development. The IPO could be listed on the Euronext Paris bourse as soon as the fourth quarter, with deliberations ongoing due to market conditions.

images.alt_text: Geely previously announced a hybrid gasoline engine development deal with Mercedes-Benz and holds a stake in the German automaker.
Renault chief executive Luca de Meo says the carmaker is in talks with US car dealer AutoNation, to start selling Alpine sports cars in the US.

site_title: The ‘moral hazard’ of a higher federal insurance limit on US bank deposits
summary: The FDIC made an arbitrary decision to rescue all depositors of Silicon Valley Bank, the first US bank to fail, sparking concerns about the "moral hazard" of a higher federal insurance limit on US bank deposits. This move restored investor confidence in banks like First Republic and the US stock market. However, experts warn that these plans could stall or backfire, as the crisis is a classic bank run rather than an asset-related blow-up, and millions of Americans are trying to withdraw cash, making it harder to contain.

images.alt_text: While the ongoing banking crisis may wreck less damage than the global financial crisis, stocks can still be in for a rough ride and recovery prospects look unexciting.
The closed gates of Credit Suisse's headquarters in Zurich, Switzerland. Perhaps we will look back on these few weeks as the time when the era of free market truisms ended.
For now, at least, it looks like there is no need to panic over possible contagion from the implosion of the banks in the US and Europe.

site_title: EU unveils ‘right to repair’ rules to cut tech waste
summary: The European Union has proposed new "right to repair" rules, aiming to reduce 35 million tonnes of waste from discarded products each year. The regulations would force manufacturers to repair goods still under guarantee if it costs less than replacement, and give consumers the right to demand repairs within 10 years of purchase. The proposal also aims to raise consumer awareness by setting up online databases for repair services. The rules must be negotiated before becoming law, with green groups welcoming the move but calling for further extensions to the legal guarantee period.

site_title: Sunak wins vote on key part of post-Brexit deal with EU
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's post-Brexit deal with the EU, including the "Stormont brake" which hands Northern Irish lawmakers a veto over new EU rules, has won the backing of 515 MPs. The vote marked a significant victory for Sunak, despite opposition from 22 Tory MPs, including former prime ministers Boris Johnson and Liz Truss. The government can now move forward with the new Windsor Framework, which aims to reset strained ties between Britain and the EU, and could pave the way for devolved government to restart in Northern Ireland.

images.alt_text: Democratic Unionist Party leader Jeffrey Donaldson says the proposed "Stormont brake" does not deal with the "fundamental issue, which is the imposition" of European Union law by the Northern Ireland Protocol.

site_title: Internal audit’s role in ESG reporting
summary: Internal auditors play a crucial role in supporting stakeholders by assessing ESG risks from multiple perspectives. As investors increasingly demand greater corporate transparency, companies are under pressure to gather, assess, and disclose their ESG positions. The Singapore Exchange requires listed companies to publish annual sustainability reports, which must include an internal review by the internal audit department to increase stakeholder confidence in the accuracy and reliability of the information disclosed. Internal auditors provide independent assurance on sustainability governance, ESG-related risks, and opportunities, and can adopt a continuous auditing approach to provide a pulse check on the business throughout the year.

images.alt_text: Corporate ESG disclosures have come a long way, but do they serve their intended purpose of informing the market of how well companies are managing such issues? / AFP PHOTO / ROSLAN RAHMAN
Control Self Assessment can be a cost-effective and well-accepted way for listed companies to conduct sustainability internal reviews.

site_title: Logitech cuts 300 jobs on post-Covid slump in computer gadgets
summary: Logitech, a Swiss company, is laying off approximately 300 employees as part of a global reorganization. The move is in line with downsizing efforts across the tech industry, following a post-Covid slump in computer gadget demand. Revenue plummeted 22% in the third quarter of 2023, attributed to the broader macroeconomic environment and lower spending. The company's CEO, Bracken Darrell, cited "lower enterprise and consumer spending" as the main reason for the decline. This move follows recent layoffs in the tech industry, with Logitech having 8,200 employees as of March 2022.

site_title: Battle to buy Manchester United heats up as Sheikh Jassim, Ratcliffe submit second bids
summary: Sheikh Jassim, a Qatari banker, and British billionaire Jim Ratcliffe have submitted second bids for Manchester United, following the initial bids last month. The bids, worth around £4.5 billion, aim to surpass the Premier League record price paid for Chelsea. Sheikh Jassim's bid promises to wipe the club's $620 million debt and invest in a new stadium and training ground, while Ratcliffe wants a 69% stake for "purely in winning things" and calls the club a "community asset." The Glazer family has set a world record valuation of £6 billion for the club, with bidders expected to hear from United next week.

images.alt_text: Manchester United's Dutch striker Wout Weghorst (L) scores their fourth goal during the UEFA Europa league round of 16 first leg football match between Manchester United and Real Betis at Old Trafford stadium in Manchester, north-west England, on March 9, 2023. (Photo by DARREN STAPLES / AFP)
Liverpool's Roberto Firmino celebrates after scoring the 7-0 goal during the English Premier League soccer match between Liverpool FC and Manchester United in Liverpool, March 5, 2023.
Qatari banker Sheikh Jassim Bin Hamad Al Thani (left) and British billionaire Jim Ratcliffe have rival bids on the table.

site_title: Singapore corporate perpetuals weaken; analysts see market holding up for stronger issuers
summary: Singapore's corporate perpetuals have weakened following Credit Suisse's debt wipeout, but market analysts expect the impact to be short-lived. The value of Credit Suisse's US$17 billion in perpetual Additional Tier-1 bonds will be completely written down, but Singapore corporates' credit fundamentals are expected to hold up, making their perpetuals trade normally. Analysts predict tougher scrutiny and higher costs for issuers, but strong corporates can still access the market with attractive yields. The market for new issues may take a hit, but perpetuals remain a viable option for investors who understand the risks.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Gold bars from the Credit Suisse are seen in a shop in Zurich, Switzerland March 20, 2023. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse
Investing in fixed income will provide stable income during times of market volatility, while helping to diversify one's portfolio.
The Credit Suisse rescue has caused turmoil in European markets, with banks’ bond prices under pressure as investors focus on the potential risks of holding AT1 bonds.
The government-brokered deal to rescue Credit Suisse wiped out 16.3 billion Swiss francs of the bank's CoCo bonds. This has sparked a selloff in CoCo securities of other banks.

site_title: The ongoing banking debacle is not a rerun of the global financial crisis – neither its good nor its bad bits
summary: A banking crisis is unfolding globally, with three US banks failing and Credit Suisse rescued by UBS. Unlike the 2008 global financial crisis, this one is less damaging, with regulators responding swiftly and the US government backing deposits. However, recovery prospects are unexciting, with credit conditions tightening and interest rates likely to remain low. The crisis may slow economic growth, and investors should not bet on equities markets soaring. Strong economic drivers, such as China's growth, may be absent in the near term, making the risk-reward for global equities unexciting, except for Singapore's equities, which may fare relatively well.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
Credit Suisse’s decline resembles that of a former champion boxer who has simply taken too much punishment.

Some analysts expect the United States to continue hiking rates to curb inflation, while others believe that the ongoing crisis may prompt the Federal Reserve to either slow down or hit the brakes temporarily.
Credit Suisse shares plunged 60 per cent in early trade on Monday, as investor optimism about official efforts to stem a banking crisis quickly evaporated.
SVB might have maintained the confidence of its depositors if it had actively managed its assets and shored up its equity base when the Fed began raising rates a year ago

site_title: Syngenta’s US$9.5 billion IPO moves closer with Shanghai bourse hearing
summary: Syngenta's US$9.5 billion initial public offering (IPO) is moving forward after the Shanghai Stock Exchange scheduled a hearing for the Swiss agrichemicals and seeds company's listing plan. This marks the fourth round of reviews since Syngenta first filed its application in July 2021. The Chinese parent, ChemChina, plans to keep a majority stake after the IPO, which is expected to value Syngenta at around US$50 billion. The IPO is one of the world's largest this year.

site_title: Boeing wins Japan Airlines order for 21 MAX jets: sources
summary: Boeing has secured a deal worth at least $2.5 billion to sell 21 737 MAX jets to Japan Airlines Co, marking the first order for the aircraft by JAL. The deal follows a two-year delay and comes after JAL placed an order for 20 MAX jets in July. Boeing aims to secure a foothold in JAL's mainline fleet, competing with Airbus single-aisle A320s in use by ANA's Peach unit and JAL's Jetstar Japan.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A airport worker drives a luggage transport vehicle past one of the company's Boeing Co's 787 Dreamliner plane (L) and a Beoing 767 at Narita international airport in Narita, east of Tokyo, November 11, 2013. JREUTERS/Toru Hanai/File Photo

site_title: UBS shares storm back to pre-Silicon Valley Bank levels with post-deal surge
summary: UBS shares surged 3.6% to 20.12 Swiss francs, erasing recent losses, following a post-deal surge after the Swiss government brokered a historic takeover of Credit Suisse. The deal has eased concerns about the finance sector's stability, with European banks leading gains. Despite concerns about integration and balance sheet risks, investors are focusing on potential cost-savings and improved market share. UBS has announced a bond buyback and is selectively approaching staff and assets from Credit Suisse.

images.alt_text: Logos of Swiss banks UBS and Credit Suisse are seen on an office building in Zurich, Switzerland March 19, 2023. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse

site_title: Amazon has rolled out contactless tech to 200 locations including Panera cafes
summary: Amazon has expanded its contactless technology to over 200 locations, including Panera cafes, with plans to deploy it at 10-20 Panera cafes in the coming months. The technology allows customers to scan their palms to pay, and also retrieves rewards accounts and order histories. Despite macroeconomic headwinds, Amazon is seeing demand for the technology, citing the importance of retaining existing customers. The company has also recently announced plans to eliminate 9,000 more jobs, following a previous round of layoffs.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Dilip Kumar, Vice President, Physical Retail & Technology for Amazon is pictured at an Amazon checkout-free, large format grocery store in Seattle, Washington, U.S. February 21, 2020. Picture taken February 21, 2020.  REUTERS/Jason Redmond/File Photo

site_title: Coinbase gets SEC notice signalling intent to sue over crypto offerings
summary: Coinbase received a notice from the SEC indicating plans to bring an enforcement action against the largest US crypto exchange, citing unregistered securities and products. The notice, a Wells notice, covers Coinbase's exchange, staking service Coinbase Earn, and Coinbase Wallet. This development follows SEC Chair Gary Gensler's warnings that many crypto offerings are securities and require registration. The notice gives Coinbase time to rebut the agency's allegations, which may lead to an enforcement action, lawsuit, or settlement and fines.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A representation of the cryptocurrency is seen in front of Coinbase logo in this illustration taken, March 4, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration//File Photo

site_title: UK factory price expectations fall to lowest since March 2021: CBI
summary: The UK's manufacturing sector saw a decline in output and order books, with the net balance for manufacturing order books falling to -20, the weakest reading since February 2021. This is attributed to a challenging demand environment. The CBI's gauge of expected selling prices fell to +25, the lowest since March 2021. Export orders also decreased to -23. The survey suggests that the demand environment is weakening, with selling price expectations expected to decrease further.

site_title: Stablecoin issuer Circle says exec’s Twitter giveaway offer was scam, account was hacked
summary: Circle, the issuer of stablecoin USDC, confirmed that its chief strategy officer Dante Disparte's Twitter account was hacked after posting a link offering holders a "one-time bonus" of free cryptocurrency. The account claimed the bonus was a way to thank users for their support, but the link was actually a scam. Circle stated that Disparte's account was taken over by a scammer and warned that any such links are scams. The incident occurred amid concerns about Circle's exposure to Silicon Valley Bank's collapse.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Word "Crypto" and stock graph are seen through magnifier displayed in this illustration taken September 4, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: ‘Necessary’ raising of French retirement age to take place by year-end: Macron
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron has reaffirmed that a new pension law, which raises the retirement age to 64, is necessary and will take effect by the end of the year. Macron stated that he has "no regrets" and wants to improve his relationship with labor unions, who have been protesting the law. The law has sparked widespread protests, strikes, and violence, with Macron calling for an end to "extreme violence." The opposition has called for Prime Minister Elisabeth Borne to be fired, but Macron has backed her, instead tasking her with further involving citizens and unions in decision-making.

images.alt_text: Demonstrators march through the shopping center at Chatelet les Halles, during a protest against pension reform, in Paris, France, March 18, 2023.
he failure of the no-confidence vote will be a relief to Macron.

The Senate adopted the bill earlier on Thursday morning, but misgivings in the ruling party and reluctance by right-wing opposition MPs to side with Macron meant the government risked losing a vote in the lower house.

site_title: Surging demand for derivatives is fuelling Bitcoin’s resurgence
summary: Bitcoin's price surge, up 70% this year, is fueled by high demand for derivatives, with open interest in Bitcoin options reaching an all-time high. Derivative trading volumes now account for over 60% of total crypto exchange activity. Traders are taking bullish positions, with a high demand for calls, and investors are seeking opportunities in the market amid the banking crisis. The derivatives market's growth is seen as a trend that could play out in other markets, with institutional traders increasingly using derivatives to hedge their portfolios.

site_title: Ukraine needs US$411 billion for reconstruction, recovery: World Bank
summary: Ukraine's reconstruction and recovery needs have increased to $411 billion, a year after Russia's invasion, according to a joint assessment by Ukraine's government, the World Bank, the European Commission, and the United Nations. This is a $62 billion increase from the previous estimate of $349 billion. The World Bank expects Kyiv to require $14 billion in critical and priority reconstruction and recovery investments in 2023.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - A Ukrainian tank fires at Russian positions near Kreminna, Lugansk region, on January 12, 2023, amid the Russian invasion of Ukraine. (Photo by Anatolii Stepanov / AFP)

site_title: Amazon raises hourly pay for UK workers by 50 pence; union mulls more strikes
summary: Amazon raised the minimum starting pay for its UK employees by 50 pence, to between £11 and £12 per hour, starting in April. The move comes after a walkout by hundreds of workers at an Amazon warehouse in Coventry, who are demanding £15 an hour to cope with the cost-of-living crisis. The union, GMB, has announced a new wave of strikes in response to the pay rise, calling it an "insult." Amazon has raised UK hourly wages by 10% over the past seven months, but the union says it's not enough.

images.alt_text: Amazon workers talk to motorists passing a picket line outside the Amazon fulfilment centre in Coventry, central England on March 2, 2023, in a continuation of  their industrial action at the depot. - Workers were protesting against levels of pay, but also against other conditions including target-led performance measures set by an algorithm. (Photo by Darren Staples / AFP)

site_title: China to boost support for high-end manufacturing: Premier Li
summary: China's Premier Li Qiang announced plans to boost support for high-end manufacturing, aiming to create a market-oriented, legal, and international business environment. The move comes amid increasing pressure from the US on restricting access to Chinese semiconductors and AI technology. Li emphasized the need to strengthen the manufacturing industry and increase policy guidance to achieve self-reliance. This comes as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: Chinese Premier Li Qiang speaks during a news conference following the closing session of the National People's Congress (NPC), at the Great Hall of the People, in Beijing, China March 13, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Pool

site_title: Oldest known Hebrew Bible displayed in Israel ahead of sale
summary: The oldest known near-complete Hebrew Bible, the Codex Sassoon, is being displayed in Israel ahead of its sale at auction in New York for up to $50 million. Estimated to be 1,100 years old, the manuscript is one of only two surviving codices containing the Hebrew Bible's 24 books. It was written around 900 AD in the land of Israel or Syria and was sold in 1000 AD, later re-emerging in 1929. The Codex Sassoon is a significant cultural artifact, bridging the Dead Sea Scrolls and modern standard texts of the Hebrew Bible.

images.alt_text: In 2018, sales exceeding US$1 million at the three auction houses yielded US$7.44 billion. By 2022, they’d grown 9.5 per cent, to US$8.15 billion.

site_title: Boris Johnson says 'I did not lie' to parliament over lockdown parties
summary: Former British Prime Minister Boris Johnson denied lying to parliament over rule-breaking Covid-19 lockdown parties, stating he acted in "good faith" during a hearing with lawmakers. The Committee of Privileges is investigating whether Johnson intentionally misled the House of Commons, which could lead to a suspension and potentially prompt a by-election if it lasts longer than 10 days. Johnson claimed he was not warned the events broke the rules and accused the committee of bias.

images.alt_text: A video grab from footage broadcast by the UK Parliament's Parliamentary Recording Unit (PRU) shows former British Prime Minister Boris Johnson making his opening statement as he attends a Parliamentary Privileges Committee hearing, in central London on March 22, 2023. - Britain's former prime minister Boris Johnson re-entered the bear pit of parliamentary inquisition on Wednesday for a grilling about "Partygate" that could decide his political future. (Photo by PRU / AFP) / RESTRICTED TO EDITORIAL USE - NO USE FOR ENTERTAINMENT, SATIRICAL, ADVERTISING PURPOSES - MANDATORY CREDIT " AFP PHOTO / PRU "

site_title: US 30-year mortgage rate falls to a five-week low of 6.48%
summary: US mortgage rates fell to a five-week low of 6.48%, driven by a 23 basis-points drop in the contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage, according to Mortgage Bankers Association data. This decrease helped boost home purchase applications for the third-straight week, with a 2.2% increase in the index of mortgage applications. Despite the drop, mortgage rates remain elevated, and lending standards are expected to tighten, posing headwinds for the housing market. The Federal Reserve is also projected to announce another interest rate hike, which may impact mortgage rates.

site_title: Tencent stems revenue drop as China poised for gaming recovery
summary: Tencent Holdings reported a revenue increase of 144.95 billion yuan (S$28.1 billion) for the three months ended December, exceeding forecasts and fuelling hopes for a Chinese gaming recovery. The company's net income rose to 106.3 billion yuan, driven by the resumption of approvals for blockbuster games and endorsement from top officials. Despite concerns about Beijing's regulatory clampdowns, Tencent is well-positioned to benefit from a post-Covid rebound, with its global gaming sales and international expansion on the horizon.

images.alt_text: Tencent Music, China’s answer to Spotify, has seen torrid paid user growth as it invested heavily into music licensing deals and offering live shows and concerts on the platform.

site_title: More banks will fail over next two years, says Man Group CEO
summary: Man Group CEO Luke Ellis warned that more banks will fail over the next two years, with smaller and regional US banks and challenger banks in Britain potentially at risk. Ellis stated that the crisis is not yet over, citing the recent collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and the emergency rescue of Credit Suisse. Central banks have taken measures to ensure the flow of cash between banks globally, but Ellis believes policymakers have not fully addressed the issue.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Luke Ellis, CEO of Man Group, speaks during the Global Financial Leaders' Investment Summit in Hong Kong, China November 3, 2022. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo

site_title: India's law firms fret about poaching, plan fee hikes as foreigners gain a foothold
summary: India has allowed foreign law firms to establish offices in the country, starting March 10, to offer M&A and corporate advisory services to foreign clients. However, their remit will be limited to not appearing before courts or advising on Indian laws. Local firms are concerned that fees will increase and top talent may be poached, with some predicting a significant rise in pricing. The move is seen as a step towards establishing India as a hub for international commercial arbitration, but local lawyers worry about the potential loss of business and the impact on the wider legal market.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of the Indian Supreme Court building is seen in New Delhi December 7, 2010. REUTERS/B Mathur/File Photo

site_title: Lagarde vows ‘robust’ policy, with ECB ready to act as needed
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde vowed a "robust" policy approach to combat inflation, aiming to bring inflation back to 2% over the medium term. She emphasized the bank's readiness to act if needed, while also supporting financial markets. Officials have been raising interest rates aggressively, and Lagarde reiterated that there is no trade-off between price stability and financial stability, with tools available to provide liquidity support if necessary.

images.alt_text: President of the European Central Bank Christine Lagarde holds a press conference on the eurozone monetary policy following the meeting of the governing council of the ECB in Frankfurt am Main, western Germany, on October 27, 2022. (Photo by Daniel ROLAND / AFP)

site_title: Boustead Projects must restore free float, or make ‘fair and reasonable’ exit offer: SGX Regco
summary: Boustead Projects must restore its free float within 2 days or provide a fair and reasonable exit offer by an independent financial adviser, or face delisting. The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX Regco) stated this after Boustead Singapore acquired 92.5% of Boustead Projects' shares, leaving the public with only 7.5%. This decision comes as Boustead Projects' takeover offer by its parent company Boustead Singapore closes on March 27.

images.alt_text: The entrance of Boustead Singapore’s office.
Janice Lim

site_title: US: Wall St opens muted ahead of Fed rate decision
summary: Wall Street opened muted on March 22 ahead of the Federal Reserve's rate-setting meeting. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 9.59 points, or 0.03%, to 32,570.19, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite opened lower, with the Nasdaq dropping 2.61 points, or 0.02%. The Fed's decision will balance inflation and banking sector concerns.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., March 14, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Banking turmoil will not be major hit to commodities finance: CFOs
summary: Major energy trading firms say a recent bank share rout won't significantly impact commodities finance, despite concerns of a global recession and cut fuel demand. Brent crude oil prices hit their lowest since 2021, but prices have since rebounded. Industry executives caution that smaller firms, particularly in Switzerland, may face credit line squeezes due to the UBS-Credit Suisse deal. Despite global banks tightening controls, export credit agencies have entered the commodities finance market, providing alternative funding options.

images.alt_text: Oil’s early slide occurred despite a historic deal in which UBS, Switzerland’s largest bank, agreed to buy Credit Suisse in an attempt to rescue the country’s second-biggest bank.
Brent crude settled up US$1.53, or 2.1 per cent, at US$69.33 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) closed up US$1.69, or 2.5 per cent to US$69.33.

site_title: Fresh scrutiny on CoCo bonds: Wealthy families advised to tread carefully
summary: Credit Suisse's CoCo bonds, a type of high-risk bank debt, are under renewed scrutiny among wealthy families' advisers. The three billion Swiss franc deal to take over Credit Suisse has resulted in a forced write-down of its perpetual subordinate debt. Investors are becoming wary, leading to widening spreads on CoCo debt, making it more costly for banks to go to market. Many advisers have zero exposure to banks' CoCo issuance, with some citing 2-4% exposure to Credit Suisse's CoCo debt. This shift is prompting caution among investors in the riskiest segment of bank debt.

images.alt_text: Logos of Swiss bank UBS and Credit Suisse in Zurich, Switzerland March 20, 2023. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse
Genevieve Cua
Tan Nai Lun

site_title: US dollar eases as investors weigh up outlook for Fed rates
summary: The US dollar eased to five-week lows on March 22 as investors awaited the Federal Reserve's policy meeting, which may signal a quarter-point interest rate hike. Despite concerns over the banking sector, investors expect a rate hike, with a 25 basis point increase being the most likely outcome. The Fed's decision and chair Jerome Powell's comments will influence the dollar's appeal as a safe-haven currency.

site_title: Ammonia fuel provider Amogy raises US$139 million with Temasek’s participation
summary: US-based ammonia fuel provider Amogy has raised US$139 million in its Series B-1 round, led by SK Innovation and with participation from Temasek and other existing investors. The funding will support Amogy's organisational development and manufacturing of its ammonia-to-power technology. The company plans to present its first ammonia-powered, zero-emission tugboat late this year and its first commercial offering in 2024, aiming to forge a path towards net-zero 2050 and make the world more sustainable.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

site_title: Nvidia tweaks flagship H100 chip for export to China as H800
summary: Nvidia has modified its flagship H100 chip to create the H800, making it legal for export to China. The H800 reduces chip-to-chip data transfer rate to about half that of the H100, making it compliant with US export control regulations. The new chip is being used by Chinese technology firms such as Alibaba, Baidu, and Tencent for cloud computing and generative AI technologies. This move comes as US regulators have imposed rules to slow China's development in key technology sectors, including semiconductors and artificial intelligence.

images.alt_text: The proposal limits recipients of US funding from investing in the expansion of semiconductor manufacturing in foreign countries of concern such as China.
Adobe added AI to some of its most popular software, including Adobe Photoshop and Adobe Illustrator. The technology was developed in partnership with Nvidia.
The new platform is named after Cuda, the software most AI developers use to access Nvidia’s graphics processing unit (GPU) and which has given Nvidia chips a huge competitive edge.

site_title: Computing networking pioneer Metcalfe wins top industry prize
summary: Computing networking pioneer Bob Metcalfe, 76, has won the Association for Computing Machinery's 2022 Turing Award for his role in inventing, standardizing, and commercializing the Ethernet, a technology that remains the foundation of the Internet. The award comes with a $1 million prize. Metcalfe's work, done in the early 1970s, enabled the connection of computers and paved the way for the Internet. He now focuses on improving connections between artificial neural networks, citing the vast room for improvement as cause for optimism on the future of AI.

site_title: Minimal exposure to Credit Suisse AT1 debt for unit trusts, but far more for fund houses
summary: Funds in Asia have minimal exposure to Credit Suisse's worthless Additional Tier-1 (AT1) bonds, with the exposure generally less than 1% at the individual fund level, according to Morningstar data. Despite this, asset managers such as Pimco, Invesco, and BlackRock hold significant amounts of the bonds. The regulator's rescue takeover of Credit Suisse ordered a wipeout of the AT1 debt, leaving bondholders with nothing. Some bondholders are considering legal action, citing that CoCos rank higher than equity in priority for repayment during bankruptcy.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Genevieve Cua
Credit Suisse stock slumped as much as 31 per cent on Mar 15 when the chairman of its largest shareholder, Saudi National Bank, ruled out investing any more in the company.
Credit Suisse’s decline resembles that of a former champion boxer who has simply taken too much punishment.
Gold bars from the Credit Suisse are seen in a shop in Zurich, Switzerland March 20, 2023. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse
A view of a Credit Suisse signage at an office in Singapore March 20, 2023. REUTERS/Edgar Su
MAS says it will remain in close contact with Finma, Credit Suisse and UBS as the takeover is executed.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Senior Minister of State for Manpower Zaqy Mohamad warned that employees who are terminated and rehired may choose to join another company for greater employment certainty. The Ministry of Manpower will investigate cases of employers misclassifying employees to avoid obligations. Singapore does not plan to invest directly in Asean Power Grid cross-border infrastructure. Credit Suisse's AT1 bond conversion was deemed "idiosyncratic" and does not reflect the outcome of other AT1 securities. Ohmyhome's Nasdaq debut ended at $4.07, 1.8% above its IPO price. CDL acquired Sofitel Brisbane Central hotel for $177.7 million.

site_title: Thai economy to grow 3-4% this year, policy rate to ensure recovery
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to grow 3-4% this year, supported by the tourism sector, despite weakening exports due to global demand slowdown. Finance Minister Arkhom Termpittayapaisith stated that monetary and fiscal policies must work together to ensure economic growth and stability. The Bank of Thailand is expected to raise its key rate by a quarter point at its next meeting on March 29. Inflation has eased, allowing Thailand to maintain its monetary policy independence from the US. The government's fiscal position remains stable, with a public debt of 61.26% of GDP.

images.alt_text: The strategy has helped prevent the private sector’s cost of borrowing from rising too fast and given room for every sector to adjust, BOT deputy governor Mathee Supapongse said.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries weighs waste management unit sale, sources say
summary: Sembcorp Industries, a Singapore-based energy company, is considering selling its waste management unit, SembWaste, to investors. The company is working with a financial adviser and could seek up to US$700 million for the unit. Other firms have shown interest in the business, and deliberations are ongoing. SembWaste was acquired by Sembcorp in 2020 for S$28 million. The decision to sell is private, and a representative for Sembcorp did not immediately comment on the matter.

site_title: Singapore stocks extend gains on Wednesday; STI up 1.5%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.5% to close at 3,220.98, marking its second consecutive gain. The market saw 386 gainers and 208 losers, with 1.87 billion securities worth S$1.39 billion traded. Analysts attributed the calm risk environment to the absence of negative banking developments and expectations of a reassuring stance from the Federal Reserve. Key gainers included Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust, DBS, OCBC, and UOB.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
The US and European rally filtered through to Asia, where banks were among the big gainers with tech firms.
Singapore stocks opened higher/lower on Wednesday

site_title: Bill Gates touts GPT as revolutionary leap in tech
summary: Bill Gates has praised OpenAI's GPT, a language-generation AI tool, as a revolutionary technology that could change the world. He likened it to the graphical user interface, which enabled easy computer interaction. Gates has been working with OpenAI since 2016 and believes AI can reduce global inequities in healthcare, education, and climate change. However, he also raised concerns about the technology's impact on the workforce, legal system, and privacy, and emphasized the need for governments and philanthropy to ensure AI benefits everyone, not just the wealthy.

images.alt_text: Bing Image Creator will be integrated into Bing chat, rolling out initially in Creative mode starting Tuesday for users on desktop and mobile, Microsoft said.
Google describes Bard as an experiment allowing collaboration with generative AI, technology that relies on past data to create rather than identify content.
Microsoft founder Bill Gates purchased 10.8 million Heineken shares, worth 883 million euros at current market prices
Bill Gates, Microsoft co-founder, says: "The new programs like ChatGPT will make many office jobs more efficient by helping to write invoices or letters. "

site_title: Xi departs Russia after 'new era' summit with Putin
summary: Chinese leader Xi Jinping departed Russia on Wednesday after a summit with President Vladimir Putin, marking a display of unity against the West. The two nations expressed concerns over Nato expansion in Asia and agreed to deepen their partnership, with Putin calling for dialogue and respect for all countries' territorial sovereignty. However, no breakthrough was reached to end the fighting in Ukraine, with Putin stating that China's 12-point position paper on the conflict could serve as a basis for a peaceful settlement, but Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky remains waiting for a response from Beijing.

images.alt_text: Putin and Xi signed a “no limits” partnership agreement last year just weeks before Russia invaded Ukraine.

site_title: China regulator questions Dalian Wanda on unit’s HK IPO plan
summary: China's securities regulator is scrutinizing Dalian Wanda Group's unit, Zhuhai Wanda Commercial Management, about $4.4 billion in potential payments if a mainland mall business does not go public in Hong Kong by the end of 2023. The unit may need to repurchase about $5.8 billion of equity from pre-IPO investors. This comes after a similar failed attempt by China Evergrande, which raised concerns about liquidity pressure. Dalian Wanda initially delayed the IPO due to market volatility and has since priced a new 3-year bond.

images.alt_text: Shoppers and pedestrians walk along Nanjing Road in Shanghai, China, on Sunday, June 6, 2021. Consumers in China remain cautious even though the Covid-19 outbreak has been under control for much of the past year. Photographer: Qilai Shen

China’s yearlong campaign to control runaway property prices has pummeled its biggest developers, tanking home sales 11 months straight and obliterating US$65 billion in wealth for real estate moguls.

site_title: Battle for Man Utd heats up ahead of deadline for improved bids
summary: Qatari banker Sheikh Jassim Bin Hamad Al Thani and British billionaire Jim Ratcliffe are in a heated bidding war to buy Manchester United, with at least six bids expected to be submitted by the deadline. Ratcliffe, a boyhood United fan, has set a valuation of £4.5 billion, while Sheikh Jassim is reportedly ready to submit a second indicative bid. The Glazer family, who own the club, are seeking a price of £6 billion. The bidding process will continue, with potential buyers who receive a bid ahead of others possibly entering into exclusivity negotiations.

images.alt_text: Ineos chairman Jim Ratcliffe is pictured at Old Trafford in Manchester, Britain, March 17, 2023 REUTERS/Phil Noble

site_title: Pimco, Invesco face losses in Credit Suisse debt writedown
summary: Pimco and Invesco, two major asset managers, face significant losses after Credit Suisse's takeover by UBS. Pimco holds around $807 million of Credit Suisse's Additional Tier-1 (AT1) bonds, which are set to fall to zero, while Invesco holds around $370 million. The write-down of $17.3 billion of AT1 bonds is expected to trigger a complete wipeout of the securities. Some investors, including Pimco, are preparing to push back on the regulator's decision, with potential litigation or recovery of value through claims against Credit Suisse.

images.alt_text: Logos of Swiss bank UBS and Credit Suisse in Zurich, Switzerland March 20, 2023. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse
Gold bars from the Credit Suisse are seen in a shop in Zurich, Switzerland March 20, 2023. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse
For now, at least, it looks like there is no need to panic over possible contagion from the implosion of the banks in the US and Europe.
Circumstances that caused Credit Suisse to fail are to a degree unique. But like all banks, it grappled with a common backdrop of markedly higher interest rates which spurred a revaluation of risk.
Citi said the Credit Suisse move was unlikely to undermine the broader AT1 market in Asia in the long term.

site_title: As May 14 polls loom, Thais once again wish for a more democratic future
summary: Thailand is set to hold a general election on May 14, with many voters hoping for a more democratic future after years of military rule. The election pits the Pheu Thai Party, backed by Thaksin Shinawatra's niece Paetongtarn, against military-linked candidates, including Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha. The outcome is seen as crucial, as the appointed senate has significant power in selecting the next prime minister, regardless of the election result. Analysts warn that the post-election maneuvering could lead to a conservative-royalist bureaucratic state or a qualitatively different government.

images.alt_text: The incumbent Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha is betting the return of millions of tourists and billions of US dollars in stimulus programmes will boost South-east Asia’s second largest economy and his election prospects.
Paetongtarn garnered 38.2 per cent of support in a poll of 2,000. Her approval jumped from 34 per cent in the previous poll conducted in December.
Pheu Thai, the party leading in pre-election surveys, has vowed to almost double daily minimum wages by 2027.

site_title: China approves its first mRNA vaccine, from domestic drugmaker CSPC
summary: China has approved its first domestically developed mRNA vaccine against Covid-19 by CSPC Pharmaceutical Group. The vaccine trials showed incidents of adverse effects were substantially lower in an elderly group compared to an adult group, which could be a boon for China. This approval comes as China has declined to use Western Covid shots to support domestic research and follows its efforts to develop vaccines using mRNA technology since 2020.

site_title: South Korea takes step to cut homeowners’ tax as housing prices tumble
summary: South Korea's government has lowered official reference housing prices by 18.6% to combat declining property prices, resulting in a potential 29-39% reduction in property taxes for homeowners. This move aims to put a floor under the slumping market and prevent a hard landing. The tax cuts will benefit single homeowners, while multiple homeowners will pay heavier taxes. The measures follow a series of government actions to stabilize the property market.

site_title: UK's Vistry says housing market conditions are improving
summary: The UK's Vistry Group reported a 21% rise in annual profit, beating market expectations, as housing market conditions improve. Despite elevated mortgage rates and concerns over a potential economic downturn, Vistry noted an improved sales trend in the first 11 weeks of the current fiscal year, with a year-to-date average private sales rate per site per week increasing to 0.62. This uptick in buyer sentiment suggests a potential turnaround in the British housing sector.

site_title: Elixir Technology makes third foray into India market
summary: Elixir Technology, a Singapore-based software company, is making its third attempt to enter the Indian market through a consortium. The group, led by Excelpoint Technology and supported by Enterprise Singapore, will bid for smart-city projects in India, offering digital solutions in healthcare, cybersecurity, and other areas. This move aims to capitalize on the Indian government's push for digital transformation and smart cities. The company believes joining a consortium will increase its chances of success in the competitive Indian market.

images.alt_text: Networking opportunities from the consortium leaders allowed Environsens to pitch its solutions and secure multiple water filtration projects with state governments there, said chief executive Shailesh Kharkwal.
SMEs' top concern for the year ahead is the rising global interest rates, according to a DBS survey released on Mar 20.
SMEs can tap digitalisation, grants to mitigate rising costs: business leaders
Incubator Ghostwriter hosts its first pop-up: Guerilla, a collaboration between Son Pham, the owner of Sonny’s Pizza, and June Baek, a bartender.

site_title: South Korea cuts homeowner tax as housing prices tumble
summary: South Korea has lowered official reference housing prices by 18.6% to combat falling housing prices amid rising inflation and a cooling economy. This reduction will lead to a 29-39% decrease in property taxes for homeowners, with single-home owners likely to see the largest tax cuts. The move aims to put a floor under slumping property prices, which have been falling for nine consecutive months.

site_title: Swiss, Japanese watch collectors outperform with 40% returns
summary: Luxury watch collectors in Switzerland and Japan have outperformed other regions with 40% returns on their watch collections, according to data from Chrono24. This surpasses returns of 24% for Dutch collectors and 25% for German collectors. The countries' strong watch-making industries may have contributed to this performance, with Switzerland home to brands like Omega and Rolex, and Japan producing brands such as Seiko and Grand Seiko.

images.alt_text: The S&P 500 stock index averaged annual returns of 8 per cent from August 2018 to January 2023 while a basket of pre-owned watch models from top Swiss brands grew at more than twice the pace.
“You see supply going up significantly for models that we would literally have killed for just a couple of months before.” said Arjen van de Vall, CEO of Watchfinder.
Rolex certified pre-owned watches will only be sold by authorised dealers, beginning with Swiss retailer Bucherer and then others next year.

site_title: Hong Kong Art Basel is back
summary: Hong Kong's art scene is thriving with the return of Art Basel Hong Kong, a major Asian art fair, after the lifting of the mask mandate. The event is expected to see impressive sales, alongside numerous gallery and museum show openings, including Yayoi Kusama at M+ museum and satellite art fair Art Central.

site_title: No current plans for Singapore to invest directly in Asean Power Grid cross-border infrastructure
summary: Singapore does not plan to invest directly in the Asean Power Grid's cross-border infrastructure, according to Second Minister for Trade and Industry Tan See Leng. Instead, the government aims to work with regional partners to provide a framework and ecosystem for commercial players to build the infrastructure. The Asean Power Grid aims to integrate the national power systems of 10 member states, facilitating decarbonisation efforts through the integration of significant renewable energy potential in the region.

images.alt_text: Both countries inked six government-to-government agreements at the Singapore-Indonesia Leaders’ Retreat, the sixth such retreat between PM Lee and Indonesian President Joko Widodo.

One of the world’s biggest greenhouse gas emitters, Indonesia last year set a more ambitious target for reducing carbon emission by 31.89 per cent on its own, or 43.2 per cent with international support, by 2030.
Vietnam, which has the highest solar power generation capacity in the region, is facing setbacks in its clean energy transition due to inadequate grids and regulations.

site_title: Japan’s land prices up at fastest pace since 2008 on gradual economic recovery
summary: Japan's land prices rose at the fastest pace since 2008, with a 1.6% increase in 2022, driven by economic recovery and low interest rates. Residential land prices grew 1.4% and commercial prices rose 1.8%, with demand for housing and offices boosted. The trend spread to rural areas, and land prices in industrial areas also increased, driven by the e-commerce industry. The government survey surveyed 26,000 locations and will provide a basis for land transactions.

images.alt_text: In Japan, mortgage holders haven’t had to worry about rising interest rates for more than a decade, with the central bank keeping borrowing costs at rock-bottom levels to combat deflation.

site_title: Hot stock: Medtecs rises over 20% on heavy trading, triggers SGX query
summary: Medtecs International, a protective gear manufacturer listed on the Catalist, saw its shares surge over 20% on Wednesday due to unusually high trading volumes. The company reached a midday trading price of S$0.136, with 11.7 million securities changing hands, exceeding its average daily volume of 4.7 million. This prompted a query from the Singapore Exchange regarding the counter's "unusual price movements."

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Catalist-listed Medtecs gains as much as 19.4 per cent, while Top Glove rises 5.9 per cent.
Medtecs reported a loss for H1 2022 as demand and prices for PPE and facemasks fall.
Medtecs booked additional marketing, advertising and distribution expenses to promote the ‘Medtecs’ brand and own-brand products and grow its e-commerce business.

site_title: Bank crises and moral hazard: Regulators toe a fine line
summary: The global banking crisis, exemplified by Credit Suisse's failure, differs from the 2008 US subprime mortgage crisis in that it is not solely driven by a single factor, but rather a combination of higher interest rates and lax controls. Regulators face a fine line in addressing moral hazard, with the recent takeover of Credit Suisse by UBS raising questions about whether it constitutes a bailout. The crisis highlights the need for regulators to strike a balance between ensuring the stability of the financial system and avoiding excessive regulation that could stifle economic growth.

images.alt_text: The deal struck late on Sunday prevented the collapse of the country’s second-biggest lender by folding it into the largest.
The closed gates of Credit Suisse's headquarters in Zurich, Switzerland. Perhaps we will look back on these few weeks as the time when the era of free market truisms ended.

site_title: Japan's Rakuten plans to list banking unit in US$800 million IPO
summary: Rakuten plans to list its banking unit, Rakuten Bank, in an initial public offering (IPO) valued at approximately $807 million. The company will sell existing shares and issue new ones to investors, seeking a cash boost amid market uncertainty. The listing comes as global banks face challenges, but Japanese banks are seen as resilient. Rakuten's IPO will test demand for its online lender, which has struggled with years of losses. The offering is expected to provide a significant cash injection for the e-commerce giant.

images.alt_text: Rakuten tapped the market in November for US$500 million at a whopping 12 per cent yield.

site_title: Swiss sweat over size of new superbank
summary: Swiss banking giant Credit Suisse has been saved from collapse after agreeing to merge with UBS, creating the country's largest bank. The deal, struck on Sunday, prevented the collapse of Credit Suisse, the second-largest lender in Switzerland. The merged entity will be the largest bank in Switzerland, raising concerns about its size and potential risks. Both firms were deemed "too big to fail" by regulators before the deal, and their merger is expected to have significant implications for the global banking system.

images.alt_text: CGS-CIMB notes that Singapore banks do not share the same risks which led to the event due to strong corporate governance and risk management.
For now, at least, it looks like there is no need to panic over possible contagion from the implosion of the banks in the US and Europe.
A view of a Credit Suisse signage at an office in Singapore March 20, 2023. REUTERS/Edgar Su

site_title: CDL to acquire Sofitel hotel in Brisbane for A$177.7 million
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) is acquiring an 87.9% stake in Sofitel Brisbane Central hotel for A$177.7 million, marking CDL's third hotel in Australia and its entry into Brisbane's hospitality sector. The 30-storey hotel, with 416 rooms, will continue to be managed by Accor Group. CDL executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng sees the acquisition as an attractive opportunity to expand in Australia and enhance recurring income.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
The St Katharine Docks deal increases the group’s total commercial assets in the UK to around £1 billion.

mzcdl23 - Left to right: Mr Sherman Kwek – CDL Group Chief Executive Officer, 
Mr Kwek Leng Beng – CDL Executive Chairman and Mr Kwek Eik Sheng – CDL Group Chief Operating Officer.



Copyright: City Developments Limited (CDL)
City Developments Limited (CDL) headquarters along Robinson Road. The company said on Monday that it is in talks to acquire the St Katharine Docks (SKD) development in London

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall St rally as Fed decision replaces bank worries
summary: Asia markets rallied on Wednesday as the US and European rally filtered through, with banks and tech firms leading the gains. The recent turmoil over the banking sector has eased, with government support and reassurances from US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen providing stability. Investors are now focused on the US Federal Reserve's policy decision, with some analysts predicting a pause in interest rate hikes to prevent a blow-up in the financial sector.

images.alt_text: In early Asian trade, Hong Kong rose with lenders HSBC and Standard Chartered well up, while Shanghai, Singapore, Seoul, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta were also in positive territory.

site_title: World Bank chief urges China to restructure poor nation debt
summary: World Bank Chief David Malpass urged China to be more active in restructuring discussions for developing countries in debt crisis. China, a major lender to poor nations, has included nondisclosure clauses in loan contracts, making it difficult to evaluate the contracts. Malpass called for China to participate in debt restructuring programs, citing China's participation in an International Monetary Fund program to help Sri Lanka. The World Bank chief emphasized the need for a restructuring process to help countries achieve a sustainable debt structure.

images.alt_text: World Bank executive directors are set to discuss the plan in the coming weeks.

site_title: UBS offers to buy back bonds sold days before Credit Suisse deal
summary: UBS Group is offering to buy back 2.75 billion euros worth of bonds it issued just days before announcing a deal to acquire Credit Suisse Group. The bonds, due in 2028 and 2032, can be tendered for cash at a re-offer price. The move comes as a result of "exceptional corporate actions" announced on March 19, 2023. The deal opens on March 22 with early and final expiration deadlines on March 28 and April 4, respectively.

images.alt_text: The deal struck late on Sunday prevented the collapse of the country’s second-biggest lender by folding it into the largest.

site_title: Australia growth seen weaker, recession risk rises, survey shows
summary: Australia's economic growth is expected to be weaker than anticipated, with GDP decelerating faster each quarter to 1% in the final three months of 2023, down from an initial 2.4% in the first three months. Inflation is predicted to ease from 7.1% in the first quarter to 4.1% in the fourth quarter. The Reserve Bank of Australia's aggressive policy tightening cycle has increased the recession probability to 40%, up from 35%.

images.alt_text: The RBA’s most aggressive tightening cycle in a generation has created a political problem for Prime Minister Anthony Albanese.

site_title: Credit Suisse staff face more deferred pay pain on Swiss ban
summary: Credit Suisse staff face uncertainty over their deferred pay as the Swiss government temporarily suspends deferred remuneration granted in 2022 due to the bank's takeover. The bank's executive board had previously given up cash bonuses for this year. Staff who earned shares are now worth a fraction of their original value, with the stock set to be converted to UBS shares at a 22.48-to-1 ratio. The permanent status of contingent capital awards remains unclear, adding to the uncertainty for staff.

images.alt_text: Logos of Swiss bank UBS and Credit Suisse in Zurich, Switzerland March 20, 2023. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse
Credit Suisse staffers will be waiting to see how long the suspension lasts and the permanent status of the lender’s contingent capital awards.

site_title: UK inflation accelerates unexpectedly sticking in double digits
summary: UK inflation unexpectedly accelerated to 10.4% in February, its highest level in 45 years, according to the Office for National Statistics. This marks the first time inflation has risen above 10% in four months. Economists had expected a decline into single digits, and the unexpected jump is likely to prompt the Bank of England to boost interest rates again. The pound surged on the news, fueling concerns about the UK's economic outlook and the government's ability to meet its 2% inflation target.

site_title: Marcos says new military bases with US to be 'scattered' around the Philippines
summary: Philippines President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. announced plans to establish four new military bases with the US, in addition to five existing locations, amid China's growing assertiveness in the South China Sea and towards Taiwan. The new sites will be scattered around the Philippines, with some in the north, Palawan, and Luzon, the island closest to Taiwan. The move aims to boost the country's ability to defend the eastern side of Luzon. The US has committed $80 million in infrastructure investments at the existing sites, and Marcos said the new bases will enhance regional peace and stability.

images.alt_text: The Philippines says a Chinese coast guard ship directed a “military-grade laser” at its vessel in the South China Sea during a supply mission on Feb 6.

Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr (left) and Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida conclude their joint remarks to reporters following their talks in Tokyo on Thursday (Feb 9). Marcos is on a five-day visit to Japan that began on Wednesday.

site_title: Cuban rum masters preserve a century-old tradition
summary: Cuban rum master Cesar Marti is preserving a century-old tradition by refining the production of rum, which is made entirely from molasses and involves a short fermentation period and discontinuous distillation. Marti, 46, has been named a "first rum master" and is now training his apprentice, Mitehel Niebla, 42, who has been learning the trade for seven years. The Cuban rum production system was recently added to UNESCO's intangible cultural heritage list, recognizing the importance of preserving this tradition that has been passed down through eight generations.

images.alt_text: Farmers are facing a choice between selling grapes at a huge loss or keeping costs to a minimum and not harvesting.

site_title: Japan to spend 2 trillion yen on inflation aid ahead of local polls
summary: Japan plans to allocate over 2 trillion yen (S$20.2 billion) in additional aid to ease the impact of high inflation ahead of local elections. The measures include handouts for low-income households and support for households using liquefied petroleum gas. The government aims to reduce inflation by shaving 0.3 percentage points off consumer prices. Economists believe the measures will have a limited impact on prices and Bank of Japan policy, with the BOJ likely to exclude the impact due to the short duration. The move is seen as an attempt to boost public approval for the ruling government.

images.alt_text: Kishida also said Japan wanted Russia’s invasion of Ukraine to end as soon as possible and called on the “Global South”, a broad term referring to countries in Africa, Asia, Oceania and Latin America, to “show solidarity” after his talks with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi.
“The declining birthrate problem is a fight against time,” Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida said.

site_title: Taking the consortium route into India
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are entering the Indian market through a consortium model, which provides networking opportunities, business leads, and shared resources. The Enterprise Singapore (EnterpriseSG) agency facilitates the partnerships, which have helped SMEs such as Environsens and HVS Engineering secure contracts worth over S$1 million and S$650,000, respectively. The second round of the consortium, launched in 2022, aims to snag opportunities in the Internet of Things (IoT) space, with Environsens expecting further revenue of S$3 million by end-2023.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Co-founder and chief executive of Elixir Technology, Lau Shih Hor, believes joining a consortium will help the company have a fruitful entry into the Indian market.

site_title: COE premiums for cars hit all-time high
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) prices for cars and electric vehicles reached record highs in a recent tender exercise. COE premiums for larger cars and more powerful EVs ended at S$116,201, a 0.61% increase from the previous high. This surpasses the previous record set in January 2013. The COE premium for cars up to 1,600 cc and 130 bhp, as well as EVs with up to 110 kilowatts of power, finished at S$93,503, a 6.25% increase from S$88,000.

site_title: Nick Leeson, former rogue trader, is now a private spy
summary: Nick Leeson, the former rogue trader who caused Barings Bank's $1.4 billion loss in 1995, has joined corporate intelligence firm Red Mist Market Enforcement Unit as a private spy. He will investigate financial misconduct to help investors seek compensation when regulators are unable to assist. Leeson's expertise, gained from his experience on the "other side of the equation," will aid in uncovering psychology of those involved in financial crimes. The firm, run by ex-Black Cube operative Seth Freedman, has helped clients including a Taiwanese shipping tycoon and has a track record of bringing convicted traders on board.

images.alt_text: John Soh and Quah Su-Ling were found guilty for their involvement in the October 2013 penny stock crash that wiped S$8 billion in market capitalisation from penny stocks on the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: China Evergrande set to unveil offshore debt restructuring proposal
summary: China Evergrande Group is set to unveil a restructuring proposal for its $22.7 billion offshore debt on Wednesday. The plan, agreed upon by a key bondholder group, gives creditors options to swap debt into new bonds with extended maturity and equity in two Hong Kong-listed units. The new bonds will carry various tenors and coupons, including an 8-year bond with a 9% coupon. Evergrande expects to sign a supporting agreement with general creditors by the end of March, with the restructuring taking effect on October 1.

images.alt_text: An ad hoc group of offshore bondholders has expressed support for China Evergrande Group’s plan, and a restructuring support agreement is being drafted.
A winding-up order issued to China Evergrande could have broad implications for China’s US$60 trillion financial system.

site_title: Making a meaningful impact in diverse ways
summary: Five Singaporean companies are making a meaningful impact through various initiatives. Parkroyal Collection Marina Bay offers sustainability tours through its Urban Farm, while P&G launched the Beautiful Minds programme to drive disability-inclusive employment. PSA Health@Home volunteers engaged seniors in Easter egg painting, and CMC Markets partnered with Sophia Women to drive financial literacy for women. Meanwhile, Thevar 2.0 showcases mod-Indian cuisine and CMC Markets' partner, NCSS, rallied partners to better engage volunteers. These efforts demonstrate companies' commitment to delivering value to all stakeholders and making an impact in diverse ways.

images.alt_text: Companies must work to make a difference in the society, and this begins with having a corporate purpose.

site_title: Biden stunts growth in China for chipmakers getting US funds
summary: The US has introduced new restrictions on chipmakers that receive federal funds to build in China, aiming to limit their expansion. The restrictions, part of the $50 billion Chips and Science Act, bar firms from increasing advanced chip production capacity by 5% in China and limit spending on investments in advanced capacity to $100,000. These measures aim to thwart Beijing's ambitions while securing the US supply of critical components for AI, supercomputers, and electronics. The rules apply to companies like Intel, Samsung, and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing (TSMC), potentially hindering growth in China's semiconductor industry.

images.alt_text: China is working on a more than 1 trillion yuan support package for its semiconductor industry.

site_title: Asia banks may face difficulty bolstering capital via AT1s: Citi
summary: Asian banks may face difficulty replenishing capital via Additional Tier-1 (AT1) bonds due to a recent Credit Suisse write-down. The Swiss regulator wiped out Credit Suisse's $23.2 billion AT1 bonds as part of its takeover deal, triggering a re-pricing of AT1 bonds across Asian banks' capital structures. This may slow balance sheet expansion, tame inflation, and rate hike pace, particularly for smaller banks more reliant on AT1s. The broader AT1 market in Asia is unlikely to be undermined in the long term, with greater investor protections in place.

images.alt_text: While most US and European banking stocks have corrected sharply following the collapse of several banks over the week, the impact on Asian financials has been more contained, noted industry watchers.
UBS agreed on Sunday to a government-brokered deal to take over Credit Suisse for 3 billion Swiss francs.
Gold bars from the Credit Suisse are seen in a shop in Zurich, Switzerland March 20, 2023. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse

site_title: Just Eat cuts 1,700 jobs in move toward gig model it snubbed
summary: Just Eat Takeaway.com is cutting 1,700 UK drivers as part of its shift towards a gig-worker business model. The company, which pays its drivers hourly wages and benefits, aims to become more efficient amid a slowdown in food-delivery app demand. This move reverses CEO Jitse Groen's stance on the gig-worker model, which he once vowed to end. The changes will not impact service for partners or customers, and drivers will receive six weeks of pay.

images.alt_text: Takeaway, whose shares have lost two thirds of their value over the past year, had long been seeking to sell the iFood stake, but had been unable to reach terms.

site_title: In just over a week, four banks have failed. Are there more land mines waiting to blow up other banks?
summary: Four US banks have failed in the past week, with Silvergate Capital and Silicon Valley Bank collapsing due to crypto exposure and startup withdrawals, respectively. Signature Bank and First Republic Bank also fell victim to the crisis. The US government has intervened to prevent contagion, and the Federal Reserve is set to meet to discuss monetary policy. Despite the concerns, some experts believe that the banking crisis is unlikely to have a significant impact on Asian central banks, which have limited exposure to the affected banks. The situation remains uncertain, but the US government's swift action has so far prevented a wider financial crisis.

images.alt_text: Jeanette Tan
A view of a Credit Suisse signage at an office in Singapore March 20, 2023. REUTERS/Edgar Su

WASHINGTON, DC - SEPTEMBER 19: The Marriner S. Eccles Federal Reserve Board Building is seen on September 19, 2022 in Washington, DC. The Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) is set to hold its two-day meeting on interest rates starting on September 20.   Kevin Dietsch/Getty Images/AFP

A monthly survey carried out by investment bank BofA following the collapses of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank, but before Sunday’s Credit Suisse takeover, showed the perception of risk levels worsening dramatically.
Who pays the bill in bank rescues? The decisions of central bankers and politicians who make the call will spread the pain, certainly unequally, and over a long period of time.

site_title: MOM will act against employers who misclassify employees for cost-cutting
summary: The Ministry of Manpower in Singapore will investigate and take action against employers who misclassify employees to avoid employer obligations. Senior Minister of State for Manpower Zaqy Mohamad warned that employees who are terminated and rehired may choose to join another company for greater employment certainty. The ministry will also look into cases where employers terminate employees' contracts but engage their services under conditions that effectively make them employees. The move aims to safeguard the rights of full-time and part-time drivers under the Progressive Wage Model.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
THE OPW will cover general drivers, such as lorry drivers, and specialised drivers, such as bus drivers.
Reiterating the need for workers, businesses and industries to transform in tandem, Zaqy says: “The outcomes vary, depending on how different companies progress and how different sectors progress.”
As the jobs-skills integrator for the precision engineering sector, Nanyang Polytechnic will work with employment agencies and training providers to enhance placement support for jobseekers.

site_title: Circle USDC stablecoin redemptions rise to about US$6 billion
summary: Circle's USD Coin stablecoin saw a surge in redemptions, reaching about $6 billion, as users continue to withdraw funds despite the firm's efforts to recover deposits caught up in the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank. Since March 13, investors have redeemed $5.76 billion of USDC, while Circle has issued $874 million. This trend may be attributed to the recent market rally, with traders shifting funds from USDC to other cryptocurrencies.

images.alt_text: The decision to move funds to Capital Union in recent days was the result of worsening banking conditions for crypto businesses in the US, Alex de Lorraine, Archblock’s chief financial and operating officer said.
Exchanges Binance and Coinbase Global had temporarily halted certain conversions of the stablecoin, which is used to facilitate trading and as a haven from price swings.

site_title: Marvell to cut 4% of workforce in response to chip slowdown
summary: Marvell Technology is cutting about 320 jobs, or 4% of its workforce, due to an industry slowdown. The move, confirmed on Tuesday, marks the company's first significant layoffs in the US in several years. Marvell cited the need to streamline its organization to take advantage of promising opportunities. The job cuts follow similar steps taken by other major chipmakers, including Intel, Micron Technology, and tech companies like Amazon and Microsoft.

site_title: Singapore banks do not share similar risks leading to Credit Suisse AT1 write-off: CGS-CIMB
summary: Singapore banks are not at risk of experiencing a similar write-off of Credit Suisse's Additional Tier 1 (AT1) bonds, according to a report by CGS-CIMB. This is due to strong corporate governance and risk management, resulting in robust market and consumer confidence. Singapore banks, including UOB, DBS, and OCBC, have little exposure to Credit Suisse's AT1 debt and make up only a small part of their total investments. While investors should monitor for potential spillover effects, CGS-CIMB believes the impact is likely to be insignificant for Singapore's banking sector.

images.alt_text: DBS, UOB and OCBC ATMs at the Singapore Institute of Management (SIM) on March 12, 2020.
Vivienne Tay

site_title: Air India expansion stirs tension over airline flying rights
summary: India's new Air India carrier has sparked tension over airline flying rights, with foreign carriers like Emirates and Turkish Airlines seeking increased access to the country's growing market. The government has not eased curbs on capacity, citing a need to recapture lost traffic and create an economic powerhouse. Analysts say the refusal to relax curbs is a tactical move, but may be delayed until after the upcoming elections.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A woman walks past Air India airlines branding at a park in Mumbai, India, October 19, 2021. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas/File Photo

site_title: Credit Suisse tells Hong Kong clients to ‘embrace new reality’
summary: Credit Suisse, rescued from an emergency buyout, held a glitzy investment conference in Hong Kong, reassuring clients to "embrace the new reality" as it prepares for life under new management. The bank's Hong Kong assets represent 1.6% of the local banking sector, and authorities say the takeover by UBS will prevent further economic turmoil. Despite concerns, clients expressed confidence in the takeover, citing the Swiss government's backing, and the event drew over 1,600 institutional investors.

images.alt_text: The logo of Credit Suisse bank is seen outside its office building in Hong Kong, China March 20, 2023. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu

site_title: US banks face scrutiny as Fed rate decision looms
summary: US banks face scrutiny as the Federal Reserve's meeting on Wednesday looms, with investors divided over whether the central bank will pause its interest rate hikes to ensure financial stability. Recent market turmoil has eased, but worries about systemic contagion persist, particularly for mid-sized US lenders like First Republic Bank. The bank's efforts to secure a capital infusion have been unsuccessful, and it is considering downsizing or seeking a government backstop. Policymakers have stressed that the current turmoil is different from the 2008 financial crisis, but the US Treasury has announced a review of the failures of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank.

images.alt_text: An automated teller machine (ATM) sign outside a Credit Suisse Group AG bank branch in Zurich, Switzerland, on Tuesday, March 21, 2023. Recruiters across the world are getting an unprecedented flood of calls from Credit Suisse bankers seeking new jobs as the embattled Swiss lender is set to be taken over by UBS Group AG. Photographer: Stefan Wermuth/Bloomberg

site_title: Gold ticks higher as investors brace for Fed rate verdict
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,942.96 per ounce as the dollar eased, ahead of the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. Investors await a 25-basis-point rate hike, which could increase the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding gold. The dollar index's decline made bullion less expensive for buyers holding other currencies. Spot silver, platinum, and palladium also gained, while the SPDR Gold Trust's holdings fell 0.16% to 923.11 tonnes.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Gold bullion is displayed at a precious metal dealer in Hatton Garden, London, Britain July 21, 2015. REUTERS/Neil Hall/File Photo

site_title: Putin, Xi pledge friendship but talks yield no Ukraine breakthrough
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin and Chinese leader Xi Jinping met for two days, pledging a "no limits" partnership and criticizing the West, but failed to reach a diplomatic breakthrough on Ukraine. Despite warm words and promises of economic cooperation, Putin blamed Ukraine and the West for rejecting a proposed peace plan, while Xi barely mentioned the conflict. The talks marked Putin's biggest display of diplomacy since the Russia-Ukraine invasion last year, and Kyiv remains hopeful that China's neutrality could help facilitate a peaceful settlement.

images.alt_text: epa10535306 Chinese President Xi Jinping (L) and Russian President Vladimir Putin (R) attend the signing ceremony of documents concerning the further development of the comprehensive partnership and strategic cooperation between Russia and China, at the Kremlin, in Moscow, Russia, 21 March 2023.
