site_title: Ex-Goldman banker Ng seeks celebrity prison for 1MDB fraud
summary: Roger Ng, a former Goldman Sachs banker, has asked a US judge to serve his 10-year prison term in Danbury, Connecticut, a low-security federal prison. Ng, convicted of conspiring to violate US anti-bribery laws and taking part in a money-laundering scheme, requires mental health treatment due to post-traumatic stress disorder. His lawyer requested the "lowest-possible designation" for his client. Ng was extradited from Malaysia, where he spent six months in a squalid prison before his trial.

images.alt_text: Roger Ng on March 9. Photographer: Yuki Iwamura/Bloomberg

site_title: Nike profitability lags even as sales outpace expectations
summary: Nike reported a 14% increase in global revenue to $12.4 billion in the quarter, beating Wall Street's expectations. However, the company's profitability missed estimates due to markdowns, high freight and material costs, and excess inventory. Nike expects revenue to grow this fiscal year by a high-single-digit percentage, but gross margin is forecast to decline 250 basis points. The company cited "higher markdowns to liquidate inventory" as a major factor in the decline in profitability.

images.alt_text: People visit the Nike store at 5th Avenue during the holiday season in New York City, U.S., December 9, 2022. REUTERS/Eduardo Munoz

site_title: Time for Singapore businesses to walk the talk on DE&I
summary: A new report by FleishmanHillard suggests that Singapore businesses are not living up to their diversity, equity, and inclusion (DE&I) ambitions, despite a strong desire from Singaporeans for companies to take action. The report found that 75% of Singaporeans expect their companies to have a dedicated DE&I leader, and nearly half want DE&I training. The "leadership gap" is seen as a major obstacle to achieving DE&I goals, with the report highlighting the need for more effective action from companies to support their workforces on issues such as gender, economic status, and disability.

images.alt_text: Diversity, silhouettes, resilience, credit: PIXABAY

site_title: A new chapter of capitalism emerges from the banking crisis
summary: A new chapter of capitalism is emerging from the banking crisis, with a shift towards a mercantilist form of finance, where the state plays a more significant role. Global banking is likely to be reshaped by this change, with regulators embracing a more interventionist approach. The focus is on liquidity, rather than asset quality, and there will be new rules, but not on the same scale as after the 2008 crisis. The collapse of Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) and Credit Suisse Group highlights the need for banks to prioritize survival over revolutionary ideas. The debate will center on whether to protect depositors more fully or stop moral hazard, with some new regulations expected. The trend towards dirigisme, where finance is seen as an arm of the state, is expected to continue, with national governments taking a more active role in guiding the financial sector.

images.alt_text: epa10531430 The gate is closed at the entrance of the headquarters of the Swiss bank Credit Suisse (CS) at Paradeplatz in Zurich, Switzerland, 19 March 2023 morning. Shares of Credit Suisse lost more than one-quarter of their value on 15 March 2023, hitting a record low after its biggest shareholder, the Saudi National Bank, told outlets that it would not inject more money into the ailing Swiss bank. Its shares recovered briefly on 16 March after Switzerland's central bank announced that it was to loan CS money but fears of turmoil in the global banking sector persist.  EPA-EFE/MICHAEL BUHOLZER

site_title: MeTech JV files second lawsuit against ex-director Deng Yiming
summary: MeTech International has filed a second lawsuit against ex-director Deng Yiming in the High Court, alleging that he sold overpriced machines used for growing diamonds to its subsidiary's former joint-venture partner, Asian Eco Technology. The machines, valued at a higher price than their fair market value, were sold in October 2021. This lawsuit follows a previous one filed by MeTech over missing diamond seeds and loose diamonds. Deng is still a director at XDC and Asian Eco Technology.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
The diamonds were last in Deng’s possession, and the director had, to date, not satisfactorily addressed issues relating to them, Metech said in a bourse filing.

The latest requisition letter referred to the company’s announcement on Nov 6 in relation to another requisition letter dated Nov 4 from Ng Eng Tiong, who is seeking an EGM to remove the company’s chief executive officer.

Besides the removal of the CEO, Ng in his requisition letter is also seeking a resolution that the appointment of any director to the company’s board from the date of the requisition to the date of the EGM be invalidated and such directors (if any) to be removed from office with effect from the date of the EGM.

site_title: Credit Suisse staff face more deferred pay pain on Swiss ban
summary: Credit Suisse staffers face further pay cuts as the Swiss government temporarily suspends deferred bonuses granted in 2022. The bank's stock has plummeted, wiping over $600 million from the value of deferred stock held by bankers. The suspension affects thousands of managing directors and director-level staff who received contingent capital awards, which were designed to give the bank more capital in times of crisis. The lender's executive board has already canceled cash bonuses for last year, and the status of the contingent capital awards remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: UBS agreed on Sunday to a government-brokered deal to take over Credit Suisse for 3 billion Swiss francs.

site_title: Oil rises 2% in retreat from 15-mth low as banking fears subside
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Tuesday, extending a retreat from a 15-month low, as banking fears subsided following the rescue of Credit Suisse. Measures to stabilize the banking sector calmed concerns about a financial crisis that would hurt economic growth and cut fuel demand. Oil prices are expected to remain stable for now, with Brent crude settling at $69.33 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate closing at $69.33.

images.alt_text: Oil pumping jacks, also known as "nodding donkeys", operate in an oilfield near Dyurtyuli, the Republic of Bashkortostan, Russia, November 19, 2020.

site_title: Fifty years of floating currencies
summary: The Bretton Woods monetary system, established in 1944, collapsed in 1973, and its demise marked the emergence of a new, more resilient regime of floating currencies. The shift to flexible exchange rates has allowed countries to set monetary policies independently, adjust to trade shocks, and avoid speculative attacks. While periods of extreme exchange-rate swings have led to government intervention, the trend towards flexibility has resumed, and many countries have adopted floating exchange rates. The benefits of floating exchange rates outweigh the advantages of fixed rates, and the last major foreign-exchange intervention to lower a currency's value was in 2011, marking a shift towards refraining from competitive devaluations.

site_title: African carbon project hit by ‘blood carbon’ allegations; Singapore’s carbon marketplace assessing situation
summary: A carbon project in Northern Kenya, dubbed the world's largest soil carbon project, has been accused of making millions by "breaking down" indigenous people's traditional grazing systems and replacing them with a centrally controlled system. The Northern Kenya Rangelands Carbon Project has had its credits suspended by carbon offset certifier Verra while a "quality control review" is underway. Climate Impact X, which had planned to auction off credits from the project, is working to gather facts before determining the next steps.

images.alt_text: The Northern Kenya Carbon Project, the world’s first large-scale grasslands soil carbon project, has become the subject of "blood carbon" dealings.
Wong Pei Ting

site_title: GameStop shares surge as cost cuts drive surprise profit
summary: GameStop posted a surprise profit for its fourth quarter, driven by cost cuts and lower selling, general and administrative costs. The company's adjusted profit per share was 16 US cents, exceeding Wall Street expectations. Shares surged nearly 50% in extended trading. GameStop has been focusing on digital sales and reducing inventory, with online sales capabilities being strengthened. However, analysts expect the company to return to losses next quarter, citing a "one-off" result and lower-than-historical gross margins.

images.alt_text: People walk by a GameStop in Manhattan, New York, U.S., December 7, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly

site_title: Changi Airfreight Centre in need of hardware, tech improvements: freight forwarders
summary: Changi Airfreight Centre is facing space and technology constraints, with freight forwarders citing overflowing cargo, exposure to weather elements, and risks of pilferage and damage. The 47-ha centre, operated by Changi Airport Group (CAG) and ground-handling agents SATS and dnata, is experiencing peak season challenges. Improvements are underway, including the redevelopment of land plots and the implementation of the Truck Dock Slot Booking system. However, some logistics veterans argue that automation and digitalization are lacking, and the cold chain is often broken due to insufficient docks and manual processes.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Gross proceeds from the rights issue will be used to partially fund the inflight caterer and ground handler’s acquisition of Paris-based Worldwide Flight Services.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Wednesday’s open; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.6% on Wednesday, led by gains in the US and Europe. The Straits Times Index (STI) increased 20.37 points to 3,194.3, with 84 gainers outnumbering 31 losers. Banking shares, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC, opened higher, while Singtel traded 0.8% higher. The S&P 500 rose 1.3%, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average and Nasdaq Composite Index also gained.

images.alt_text: The reception area at the Singapore Exchange Ltd. (SGX) headquarters in Singapore, on Tuesday, Feb. 7, 2023. SGX is scheduled to release earnings results on Feb. 9. Photographer: Nicky Loh/Bloomberg

site_title: Slowly or all at once? The banking rescue dilemma
summary: Policymakers face a difficult decision in bank rescues, with the question of who pays the bill sparking debate. A survey of tech industry experts found that those who would lose 10% a year for 10 years would rather lose 80% of their wealth in the first year. Central bankers and politicians, with significant wealth and experience, are likely to make decisions that spread the pain, unequally and over time. The US government has indicated it will not guarantee all depositors, and banks will have to pay for recent rescues with additional fees.

images.alt_text: The basic function of banks is to provide money and credit, but depositors cannot monitor the soundness of banks in real time.

Tung Lok Restaurants formed a joint venture with Safra to manage a cafe, while Metech International filed a second lawsuit against former director Deng Yiming due to allegedly overpriced machines. Trading halts were also called for by offshore company Jasper Investments and HG Metal Manufacturing.

site_title: Ohmyhome ends Nasdaq debut at US$4.07, 1.8% above IPO price
summary: Singapore-based real estate platform Ohmyhome made its Nasdaq debut, trading at US$4.07, 1.8% above its IPO price of US$4. The company raised around US$14.6 million from its initial public offering (IPO), with plans to use the funds for market expansion, research and development, and working capital. Ohmyhome's shares rose 1.8% in after-hours trading, following its listing on March 21.

Ohmyhome co-founders cum sisters, Rhonda and Race Wong.

site_title: UK commercial property values to fall more slowly in Q2: RIB
summary: UK commercial property values are expected to fall 1.6% in the second quarter of 2023, slower than the 2.9% drop in the first quarter, according to a survey by Robert Irving Burns. Rental values are forecast to decline 0.4% and sales values to edge down across all sub-categories, with the office sector seeing the largest fall of 2.7%. The economy is showing signs of improvement, with some measures of Britain's economy having improved in recent months, and the sector is expected to be a "buyers market" for investors with access to capital.

images.alt_text: The Financial Conduct Authority said in a letter to ESG benchmarks compilers that a preliminary review had shown that the quality of their disclosures was poor.
While the immediate focus for UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's foreign policy may be Russia, a proper strategy is needed across all of the UK’s key relationships.

site_title: Silicon Valley Bank’s former owner, FDIC bracing for fight over US$2 billion
summary: The FDIC is bracing for a fight over $2 billion in cash seized from Silicon Valley Bank's former parent company, SVB Financial, following the bank's closure on March 10. SVB Financial claims the FDIC took "improper actions" to cut off the parent company from its cash, while the FDIC disputes this, saying it was necessary to protect deposits. The FDIC is holding the cash while investigating potential claims against SVB Financial, which has $3.4 billion in debt and manages $9.5 billion of investors' money.

images.alt_text: SVB might have maintained the confidence of its depositors if it had actively managed its assets and shored up its equity base when the Fed began raising rates a year ago

Bids are due on Friday (Mar 24) for the so-called “bridge bank” that the FDIC set up to take receivership of SVB’s assets and liabilities, the people said. Separately, the regulator will take bids by Wednesday for SVB Private Bank, or the remnants of Boston Private, the wealth-oriented bank SVB acquired in 2021.

site_title: Citadel Securities boosts China presence as peers cut costs
summary: Citadel Securities, a US hedge fund, plans to expand its business in China, hiring more people and building a bigger on-shore presence in the country. Despite economic uncertainty, the company sees China as a key driver of global economic growth, with its Asia operations growing rapidly. Citadel Securities has more than doubled its headcount in Asia in the past three years and now has offices in Hong Kong, Sydney, and Singapore. The company's expansion in China comes as other financial firms cut costs amid market volatility.

images.alt_text: The Citadel Securities logo is seen at their offices in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., October 31, 2022.  REUTERS/Andrew Kelly

site_title: US: Stocks close higher as First Republic recoups some losses
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, with the S&P 500 up 1.3% to 4,002.87, the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 1.0% to 32,560.60, and the Nasdaq Composite Index up 1.6% to 11,860.11. Regional banking stocks, including First Republic Bank, recouped losses, with First Republic up 29.9% and Seacoast Banking Corporation up 4.6%. The VIX index declined, suggesting a calming of market volatility. The rally comes ahead of a US Federal Reserve interest-rate decision.

site_title: Six-storey Boat Quay shophouse reaps S$16 million profit for seller
summary: A six-storey conservation shophouse at 52 Boat Quay in Singapore has been sold for S$37 million, generating a profit of S$15.65 million for the seller, Alan Chong, who paid S$21.35 million for the property in 2018. The sale comes amid a slowdown in shophouse deals due to rising interest rates and a widening price gap between buyers and sellers, with year-to-date shophouse transaction value down 7.7% compared to the same period last year.

site_title: Adobe, Nvidia AI imagery systems aim to resolve copyright questions
summary: Adobe and Nvidia have partnered to develop AI-powered image generation tools that address copyright concerns. Adobe's "Firefly" feature uses trained data from Adobe Stock images to create images that can be used commercially, with creators able to receive payments. Nvidia's "Picasso" AI-image generator also plans to pay royalties. The collaboration aims to promote responsible AI development and ensure permissioned data is used.

site_title: First Republic rescue may rely on US backing to facilitate deal
summary: US officials are exploring government backing to facilitate a deal to rescue First Republic Bank, which has lost over 80% of its stock market value this year due to customer withdrawals. Talks are ongoing, with possible measures including lifting assets, offering liability protection, and easing capital rules. The government's potential financial support is unclear, and an agreement is not guaranteed. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen stated the US is committed to mitigating financial-stability risks and maintaining public confidence in the banking system.

site_title: Tung Lok and Safra to jointly manage cafe
summary: Tung Lok Restaurants and Safra have entered into a joint venture to manage a cafe, Camo Cafe & Bar, with the first outlet set to open at Safra's Choa Chu Kang clubhouse in May. site_title: EV-maker Nio surges, says ‘very confident’ of hitting sales goal
summary: Nio, a Chinese electric vehicle maker, is confident it will meet its target of doubling sales to 250,000 electric vehicles in 2023, citing new models, expanded charging networks, and autonomous driving technologies. The company's shares surged 8.6% in early Hong Kong trading after CFO Steven Feng expressed confidence in meeting the target. Fellow regional lenders Western Alliance Bancorp and PacWest Bancorp also rose. The KBW Regional Banking Index increased 5.5% due to a broad sector rally.

site_title: Putin, Xi discuss Chinese peace proposal for Ukraine
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin and Chinese leader Xi Jinping discussed a Chinese proposal calling for a de-escalation and eventual ceasefire in Ukraine, with Putin praising Xi as a "dear friend." The proposal, which includes 12 points, has been largely dismissed in the West as a ploy to buy Putin time. US officials fear any ceasefire would merely freeze the front lines, handing Russia an advantage. Xi has invited Putin to visit China, but analysts doubt his visit will result in military backing.

site_title: US seeks to prevent China from benefiting from US$52 billion chips funding
summary: The US Commerce Department has released proposed rules to limit US$52 billion in semiconductor funding from benefiting China and other countries deemed of concern. The proposal restricts investments in foreign countries and limits joint research with entities of concern. Critical semiconductors, used for military capabilities, are also subject to tighter restrictions. Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo said the measures will help the US stay ahead of adversaries. The department plans to accept applications for a $39-billion semiconductor manufacturing subsidy programme in late June.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as bank fears ease, focus on Fed
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday as Credit Suisse's rescue calmed banking crisis fears, while investors awaited the Federal Reserve's monetary policy meet. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 176.13 points, or 0.55%, to 32,420.71, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained, up 0.62% and 0.76%, respectively. Market sentiment improved as investors shifted focus away from banking concerns.

site_title: Seroja Investments to receive delisting notice by Mar 24
summary: Seroja Investments, a Singapore-listed company, will receive a delisting notice from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) by March 24 due to its failure to acquire a new business for a new listing by the deadline of May 20 last year. The company, which became a cash company after selling its operating business in 2019, has been on the hunt for a new viable business in line with listing rules. Seroja Investments has not requested any deadline extension.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim

site_title: Central bank rate bets send US dollar, sterling, Swiss franc different ways
summary: The US dollar fell 0.3% to 103.02, while sterling steadied, as traders anticipated limited rate hikes from the Federal Reserve and Bank of England due to banking sector concerns. The Swiss franc rose against the dollar, expecting a 50-basis-point hike from the Swiss National Bank, prioritizing inflation control over market turmoil. Market focus shifted to central bank meetings this week, following recent volatility.

site_title: Streaming boosts recorded music revenue, China market growing
summary: Global recorded music revenues rose 9% to US$26.2 billion in 2022, driven by growth in paid subscription streaming and income from advert usage. Streaming accounted for 67% of total revenues, with total streaming increasing 11.5% to US$17.5 billion. China entered the top five global markets, while recorded music revenues grew in every region, with sub-Saharan Africa and Latin America leading the way.

site_title: Rex International’s diversification moves draw doubters
summary: Rex International Holding, a Singapore-listed company, has announced diversification moves through investments in commercial drone maker Xer Technologies and Swedish medtech startup Moroxite T. Despite the potential for growth, the investments are raising concerns among investors due to the companies' loss-making status and the involvement of Rex's controlling shareholders in the deals. The acquisitions have drawn scrutiny from regulators and analysts, who question the company's commitment to its oil and gas businesses and the potential risks to minority shareholders.

site_title: Vietnam seeks new investor incentives as cross-border tax rules loom
summary: Vietnam's central bank has established a special panel to address concerns that new OECD cross-border tax rules may negate the benefits of its current tax incentives. The OECD's plan, which aims for a global minimum corporate tax rate of 15%, could impact Vietnam's competitive edge as a regional manufacturing hub. The bank will cooperate with the Ministry of Finance and a working group to develop supportive policies and measures to attract foreign investment while adhering to international commitments. Vietnam seeks to maintain its competitiveness despite the looming tax changes.

site_title: ECB’s Lagarde says digital euro has key role in payment autonomy
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde emphasized the digital euro's role in safeguarding European payment autonomy, citing the need for resilience in the face of single-source reliance. She warned of the dangers of relying on a single means of payment, referencing Russia's energy supply tactics. The European Commission plans to propose a legal framework for a digital euro by June, with a final decision pending. Lagarde acknowledged the digital euro can't match cash's anonymity, but emphasized its intention to be safe, sovereign, and accessible.

site_title: URA tender draws 4 bids for assisted living development at Parry Avenue
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has received just four bids for a pilot private assisted living development at Parry Avenue, with analysts attributing the muted response to the site's care component. The 12,912.1 square metre site must allocate at least 20% of its maximum permissible GFA to health and medical use, including 100 mandatory nursing home beds. The successful tenderer will operate a residential care business, primarily catering to elderly owners of nearby landed housing estates.

site_title: US existing home sales rebound; year-over-year house prices fall
summary: US existing home sales rebounded 14.5% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.58 million units in February, ending 12 straight monthly declines. This surge is attributed to a decline in house prices on an annual basis, pulling buyers back into the market. Sales increased in all four regions, with notable gains in the Midwest, West, and South. Economists had forecast a 5% rebound, but the actual increase exceeded expectations, suggesting the housing market is stabilizing at low levels.

images.alt_text: Nationwide, the typical rent for a single-family home rose 5.7 per cent from a year earlier, data from the real estate analytics provider show.

site_title: Banking turmoil pounding investor confidence
summary: Global investor confidence has plummeted to one of the lowest levels in 20 years due to US banking system turmoil and recession worries. A BofA survey found the perception of risk levels worsened dramatically, with a Financial Market Risk Indicator of 7.7, surpassing previous peaks during the Ukraine war and Covid outbreak. European fund managers cited a systemic credit event as the biggest risk for markets, with nearly a third believing it's the most likely source of danger, up from 8% in February.

images.alt_text: The sudden shock of the recent banking sector turmoil means traders are now increasing their bets that the US Federal Reserve will pause its hiking cycle to ensure financial stability.

site_title: Rent inflation for US single-family homes drops near two-year low
summary: US single-family home rents rose 5.7% from a year earlier, the lowest rate in nearly two years, according to CoreLogic. This marks the ninth consecutive month of easing rent increases, with all 20 major metro areas posting single-digit annual rent growth. Rent inflation is now below 1% in Phoenix and Miami, while Orlando saw the highest year-over-year increase at 8.9%. The typical single-family home costs around $3,100 to rent in New York and $3,500 in Los Angeles.

site_title: BT, UOB extend deadline for Sustainability Impact Awards to Apr 30 , Events & Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: BT and United Overseas Bank (UOB) have launched the "Sustainability Champions" award, recognizing individuals and organizations that demonstrate exceptional commitment to environmental sustainability. The award aims to inspire and encourage others to adopt sustainable practices. Winners will be selected based on their innovative and impactful initiatives, which can be in areas such as renewable energy, waste reduction, and carbon footprint reduction. The award ceremony will take place at the Singapore Sustainability Awards, honoring the best in sustainability practices in Singapore. The award is part of a growing movement to promote sustainability in the region.

site_title: Italy’s Antitrust probes TikTok over ‘French scar’ dangerous content
summary: Italy's antitrust authority has launched an investigation into TikTok, alleging the app breaches rules by allowing the publication of "dangerous content" such as suicide and self-harm. The probe involves TikTok's Irish and Italian divisions, and follows growing international concerns about the potential for Chinese government access to users' data. The watchdog stated that adequate systems to supervise third-party content are lacking, and the app violates its guidelines for removing such content. This investigation adds to TikTok's tightening regulatory scrutiny.

images.alt_text: The app faces growing pressure in Washington including calls to ban the app by many in Congress who fear its US user data could fall into the hands of China’s government.

TikTok will be banned on all devices with access to New Zealand’s parliamentary network by the end of March, said Parliamentary Service chief executive Rafael Gonzalez-Montero.
TikTok’s leadership is now considering more drastic measures to keep operating in the US, including separating from its parent, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Singapore to ‘strengthen crisis management muscles’ post-Covid: DPM Wong
summary: Singapore Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong announced plans to strengthen crisis management muscles post-Covid-19. The country has expanded its toolkit for disease outbreaks, including a wider range of border measures and five key parameters for safe management. Wong emphasized the need for building healthcare expertise, local production capabilities, and infrastructure to prepare for the next pandemic, while also being adaptable. He acknowledged concerns from MPs on effective government spending and trust, but assured that the government's actions were money well spent, with 80% of Covid-related spending going directly to beneficiaries.

site_title: Vietnam fintechs in hot seat with lending malpractice on government’s radar
summary: Vietnam's largest pawnshop operator, F88 Investment, is under investigation for alleged extortion and overcharging in debt collection activities. The incident has sparked concerns over predatory lending practices in the country's unbanked and underbanked segment, where about 70% of the population relies on non-traditional financial alternatives. Authorities are scrutinizing fintech businesses, particularly those offering subprime lending, amid growing demand for quick and easy loans. Experts warn that stricter regulations may be imposed if scandals linked to fraud and wrongdoings emerge.

images.alt_text: “The Ministry of Public Security and police forces at provincial levels have recently broken up several organised crime rings of debt collectors,” the ministry said in a statement.

site_title: Europe: Banks spur rebound in stocks as contagion fears recede
summary: European stocks rose 1.3% on Tuesday, led by banking stocks, as contagion fears receded following a raft of measures to stabilize the sector. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index gained, with lender-heavy indexes of Spain and Italy outperforming the broader market. Banking stocks globally breathed a sigh of relief after UBS's takeover of Credit Suisse and coordinated actions by central banks. The US Federal Reserve is expected to hike interest rates by a smaller 25 basis points, potentially sending a message that the crisis is averted but not over.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index gained 1.0 per cent by the close, after having fallen nearly 2 per cent earlier in the day.

site_title: Prosecution disputes Khua’s version of events in second day of hearing for Vibrant CEO
summary: Vibrant Group CEO Khua Kian Keong is facing charges over allegedly pushing former KTL Global chairman Tan Tock Han down stairs, resulting in a fractured shoulder. Khua claims Tan was unconscious after the fall, while Tan said he remained conscious and disoriented. Prosecution disputes Khua's version of events, citing a lack of witnesses reporting help being called. CCTV footage shows a cleaning staff member passing the door at the time of the incident, but not responding to Khua's shouts. The case will be decided on June 13.

site_title: Credit Suisse shareholder group flags override of vote in UBS merger
summary: Credit Suisse shareholder group Ethos Foundation is considering legal action over the rushed merger with UBS Group, citing a breach of shareholder rights. The merger, completed over the weekend, may scare off institutional investors, according to Ethos CEO Vincent Kaufmann, who described it as a "big failure of corporate governance." The foundation, which advises those holding 3-5% of Credit Suisse stock and $400 billion in assets, is weighing its options amid concerns over the impact on Switzerland's reputation for good governance.

site_title: Yellen vows to safeguard US bank deposits, may need more interventions
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said the recent actions to protect bank deposits have strengthened public confidence in the US banking system, but may need further interventions to protect smaller institutions from deposit runs that threaten contagion. Yellen cited the successful steps taken to protect uninsured deposits in two failed banks and created new liquidity facilities, stating they have reduced the risk of further bank failures. However, a move to expand deposit guarantees faces opposition from the conservative Republican House Freedom Caucus, and regulators will examine the failures of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank in coming weeks.

site_title: Decisive action on banks in Washington
summary: US President Joe Biden's administration successfully averted a financial crisis with a US$30 billion rescue package for First Republic Bank, following the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank. The administration employed a federal law allowing a "systemic risk" exception to guarantee deposits, and the Federal Reserve launched a special lending program to ensure banks had access to central bank credit. These moves prevented a "bank run" that could have endangered billions of dollars in deposits and threatened the entire financial system, with Biden's decision hailed as a major economic leadership accomplishment.

images.alt_text: By promising to reimburse the depositors of Silicon Valley Bank, Biden risks being portrayed as beholden to powerful elites.

site_title: Credit Suisse collapse likely to tarnish Switzerland’s reputation as a safe place to invest
summary: Credit Suisse's collapse may tarnish Switzerland's reputation as a safe place to invest, potentially deterring the world's rich from putting their money and assets into the country. The Swiss National Bank and government have pledged 100 billion and 9 billion Swiss francs, respectively, to mitigate massive withdrawals and risks. Despite UBS chairman's claims of a business worth over $5 trillion, analysts are skeptical, and S&P Global Ratings has slashed UBS' outlook to negative. The collapse may lead to years of repairing Switzerland's reputation and could result in substantial litigation costs and restructuring.

site_title: Sri Lanka bailout conditional on tackling corruption: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has approved a $3 billion bailout package for Sri Lanka, conditional on tackling corruption and government mismanagement. The package comes after China offered debt relief assurances, and is the 17th IMF loan facility for Sri Lanka since 1965. The bailout is aimed at easing a range of import bans and restoring foreign exchange reserves, but critics warn that it may not address the root causes of Sri Lanka's economic crisis. President Ranil Wickremesinghe has vowed to implement austerity measures, including tax rises and energy subsidy cuts, to shore up state revenue.

images.alt_text: While shortages have eased, inflation has somewhat cooled and reserves have inched up to US$2.2 billion in February, the nation needs the IMF loan to turn the corner after falling into a deep recession in 2022.

site_title: Microsoft launches image-creation tool on Bing powered by OpenAI’s tech
summary: Microsoft has launched an image-creation tool on its Bing search engine, powered by OpenAI's DALL-E technology. The tool, called Bing Image Creator, will be integrated into Bing chat and will initially roll out in Creative mode for desktop and mobile users. This feature allows users to create pictures based on text prompts, utilizing the same technology behind OpenAI's DALL-E.

images.alt_text: A view shows a Microsoft logo at Microsoft offices in Issy-les-Moulineaux near Paris, France, January 25, 2023. REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes

site_title: How smart clients invest in themselves – and why
summary: Investing in oneself is crucial, according to experts, as it yields a deeper understanding of a client's investor personality. A study of 52 individuals from diverse backgrounds revealed that people invest in themselves through various means, including physical comforts, emotional diets, and relationships. Key takeaways include prioritizing self-care, finding a balance that works, and investing in experiences that broaden one's perspective. To effectively serve clients, it's essential to learn their "why" and understand the underlying motivations behind their investment decisions, leading to a more personalized approach to wealth management.

site_title: India’s Karnataka government approves 80 billion rupee investment from Foxconn unit
summary: The Karnataka government in India has approved an 80 billion rupee (S$1,292.2 million) investment by Foxconn, a unit of Taiwan's Foxconn, leading to the creation of 50,000 jobs. The investment is part of Foxconn's plans to build a facility in India to manufacture Apple's AirPods, following the tech giant's shift in production away from China due to strict Covid-related restrictions and tensions between Beijing and Washington.

site_title: Punch-drunk Credit Suisse was fated to fall
summary: Credit Suisse, one of Switzerland's two major banks, has collapsed and was taken over by rival UBS. The bank's decline was caused by a loss of trust in the market, exacerbated by scandals, poor financial reporting, and a series of leadership changes. The takeover is a significant embarrassment for Swiss authorities, who had prioritized maintaining a stable banking system. The deal has also highlighted the dangers of a highly consolidated banking system and the potential risks of "bail-in" mechanisms, which may wipe out holders of certain bonds.

site_title: Two years after Ever Given incident, global shipping body renews Suez Canal cooperation deal
summary: The International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) and the Suez Canal Authority (SCA) have extended a cooperation deal, initially signed in May 2022, to maintain open communication on key issues impacting international shipping operations. The deal covers topics such as toll pricing, environmental protection, and decarbonization, as the global shipping body and SCA aim to work together to tackle collective challenges and achieve mutual goals. The extension signifies a long-term commitment to collaboration, following a significant disruption caused by the Ever Given grounding in 2021.

site_title: EU court rules Mercedes-Benz owes drivers compensation if illegal defeat devices caused damage
summary: The European Court of Justice (ECJ) ruled that Mercedes-Benz must pay compensation to drivers if the company's illegal defeat devices caused damage to their vehicles. The court stated that if a defeat device is found to be illegal and the buyer has suffered damages, the carmaker must provide compensation. German courts will determine if the software qualifies as a defeat device and if its use is justified. Mercedes-Benz has stated that it will wait to see how national courts apply the decision to federal law, and that vehicles with recalled software updates can still be used without restriction.

site_title: Why you should consider bonds amid earnings fears
summary: The article suggests considering bonds as a stable investment option amidst market volatility and fears of a recession. With yields at attractive levels not seen in decades, bonds provide stable income and help diversify a portfolio. The recent Silicon Valley Bank debacle and Credit Suisse fears have led to increased demand for safe-haven assets, with bond markets outperforming equities. Investing in fixed income can offer a reliable source of income during market uncertainty, making it a viable alternative to riskier assets.

site_title: China’s Tencent Music beats quarterly revenue estimates
summary: Tencent Music Entertainment Group, China's answer to Spotify, reported a 114.7% increase in net profit to 1.15 billion yuan in the fourth quarter, beating analysts' estimates. The platform's paid user growth was driven by investments in music licensing deals and live shows. Revenue also recovered, exceeding estimates at 7.43 billion yuan.

site_title: Singapore to increase healthcare capacity, amend laws for future health crises
summary: Singapore's government plans to strengthen its healthcare capacity, improve public health research capabilities, and set up a Communicable Diseases Agency to better prepare for future health crises. The government will also amend laws to deal with a wider range of public health scenarios, with four tiers replacing the existing Dorscon colour-coding system. Additionally, the government will retain a network of vaccination centres, improve pandemic preparedness and response, and establish a Healthcare Reserve Force to respond to future crises.

site_title: Boris Johnson says he misled MPs, but acted in ‘good faith’ on lockdown parties
summary: Former UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson has submitted a 52-page legal document to Parliament's Privileges Committee, admitting he made inaccurate statements in the House of Commons about lockdown parties but claims he acted "in good faith." Johnson denied deliberately misleading parliament, stating he corrected the record at the earliest opportunity. The committee's findings on whether Johnson misled parliament remain uncertain, with an initial update suggesting multiple instances of alleged misconduct.

summary: Banking stocks remained steady on Tuesday after the rescue of Credit Suisse, with investors cautiously optimistic about the US Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates. The sudden shock has increased bets that the Fed will pause its hiking cycle to ensure financial stability, despite lingering concerns about contagion risk. The Swiss banking sector is expected to remain prosperous, and Asian banks have seen a slight increase in share prices. The focus now shifts to the Fed's meeting this week, with traders divided over whether the central bank will raise its benchmark policy rate.

site_title: Nvidia positions for quantum computing with new products
summary: Nvidia unveiled Cuda Quantum, a platform for building quantum algorithms using classical computer coding languages, at its developer conference GTC. The open-source platform enables seamless integration of quantum computing with classical computers. Nvidia also launched the DGX Quantum hardware system, designed to connect quantum computers with classical computers. The move positions Nvidia as a key player in quantum computing, allowing domain scientists to integrate quantum technology into their applications. The platform aims to facilitate the development of hybrid applications and critical methods for quantum computing's future.

site_title: Duran Duran to reunite with original guitarist Andy Taylor
summary: Duran Duran, the iconic British band, is set to reunite with original guitarist Andy Taylor for a new project. Taylor, who left the band in 1986 due to other pursuits, will join his former bandmates Simon Le Bon, Nick Rhodes, John Taylor, and Roger Taylor for a few tracks. The new recordings will feature extended Duran Duran family and friends, and the project is expected to be released later this year. Taylor's stage four metastatic prostate cancer diagnosis was revealed in November, and the band expressed their "thrill" at the announcement.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's government will maintain Covid-19 vaccination centres even in Dorscon Green to administer booster shots as needed. The country is restructuring its Ministry of Health, strengthening hospital capacity, and improving public health research capabilities. Singapore is also studying greenwashing practices in other countries and strengthening food distribution facilities against future emergencies. summary: The global economy is experiencing uncertainty due to the turmoil in the US and European banking sectors, particularly following the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank. Financial markets are struggling to gauge the future, leading to significant volatility. Interest rates have declined sharply, prompting concerns about further rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. Central banks are likely to be cautious as they monitor the tightening in credit conditions. Meanwhile, China's economy is recovering from the COVID slump, with the PMI index rising sharply for manufacturing and non-manufacturing. However, emerging markets are experiencing a bifurcation in global business sentiment, with western economies under pressure from aggressive monetary policy.

site_title: Solutions ranked in UN’s ‘how-to guide to defuse the climate time-bomb’
summary: The United Nations' Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) has released a report ranking climate solutions by their potential to reduce global emissions by 2030. The top five most significant actions include forest restoration, solar, wind, carbon sequestration in agriculture, and conservation management. These solutions, estimated to cost $100 or less per ton of carbon dioxide equivalent, could reduce global emissions by at least half of the 2019 level. The report also highlights the importance of "climate solidarity" among big emitters, with wealthier countries expected to mobilize financial and technical resources to support emerging economies in reducing emissions.

site_title: Indonesia passes jobs decree into law, easing investment uncertainty
summary: Indonesia's parliament passed a jobs decree into law, easing investment uncertainty. The new law replaces the 2020 Jobs Creation law, which was criticized by labor and green groups as being too pro-business. Despite opposition from the Labour Party, the law maintains most of the changes brought about by the previous law, with some small changes on labor rules. The passage is seen as crucial for existing and potential investors, providing clarity and certainty. The Labor Party plans to challenge the law in the Constitutional Court and calls for a nationwide strike.

images.alt_text: Indonesian chief economics minister Airlangga Hartarto says the regulation is to ensure legal certainty, and achieve the government’s investment target amid global geopolitical uncertainty.

site_title: Google begins opening access to its ChatGPT competitor Bard
summary: Google has begun releasing its chatbot Bard to the public, allowing users to join a waitlist for English-language access in the US and UK. Bard is an experiment in collaboration with generative AI, which relies on past data to create content rather than identify it. This move comes as a response to Microsoft's successful release of ChatGPT, sparking a competitive rush in the AI technology sector to put AI into more users' hands. Google aims to reshape how people work and win business through this initiative.

site_title: Overcoming fear in investing: Invest in what you know
summary: Investing in the stock market can be daunting, especially for those afraid of losing money. However, the fear of playing it safe and letting inflation erode savings is a costly mistake. Research shows investors feel the pain of a loss twice as much as the joy of an equivalent gain, making risk a necessary component to grow wealth. Overcoming fear can be done by investing in what's known and trusted, such as favorite companies, and taking calculated risks to avoid running out of money in retirement.

site_title: Kishida in Ukraine for talks with Zelenskiy
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida visited Ukraine for talks with President Volodymyr Zelenskiy, becoming the final G7 leader to do so since Russia's invasion over a year ago. Kishida's visit aims to show support for Ukraine, following a policy speech in India where he condemned Russia's invasion. The trip takes place amid a proposed cease-fire between China and Russia, but Kyiv has been cool to Beijing's plan. Kishida's government has imposed sanctions on Russia and sent military equipment to Ukraine, with public support for the country's cause being high in Japan.

site_title: Climate investors get more sophisticated, but paltry data continues to hamper decision-making: report
summary: Climate investors have become more sophisticated in understanding the impact of their investments on carbon emissions, with 48% of respondents making or planning to make a public commitment to net-zero by 2050. However, a lack of data and knowledge remains a significant challenge, with 55% of investors citing a need for better data on biodiversity loss and 64% expressing doubts about their ability to assess the financial implications of biodiversity loss. Despite this, 51% of investors say the energy crisis has reinforced the importance of backing renewables, and 40% have increased engagement with energy companies to move away from fossil fuels.

site_title: Philippines gaming regulator weighs sale of casinos for 80 billion pesos
summary: The Philippine gaming regulator, Pagcor, is considering selling all 41 casinos it operates to raise 80 billion pesos (S$2 billion) in government revenue. The move aims to focus on regulatory functions and follows the country's freewheeling gaming sector's recovery from the pandemic. Pagcor chairman Alejandro Tengco stated that privatisation is being seriously considered, with the goal of implementing it during his term, which runs until 2028. Selling the casinos would generate revenue and boost the gaming sector, which has created tens of thousands of jobs in the past decade.

site_title: To avert a financial crisis, the Fed seems poised to keep interest rates unchanged
summary: The US Federal Reserve is considering keeping interest rates unchanged at its upcoming meeting to avert a financial crisis, amid a banking panic triggered by the sudden collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and other major banks. The Fed has already intervened with emergency measures to increase the flow of US dollars through the global banking system. Analysts predict that the Fed may decide to prioritize restoring confidence in banks over fighting inflation, which could lead to a potential credit crunch and recession. The Fed must walk a "tightrope" between these competing risks, with some experts warning of a possible "credit freeze" on the horizon.

images.alt_text: Crisis averted at First Republic Bank, after America's biggest banks agreed on a US$30b rescue package for the troubled lender.
There is no escaping the extreme level of uncertainty due to the spillovers from the Silicon Valley bank's collapse, among other US regional banks.
While the ongoing banking crisis may wreck less damage than the global financial crisis, stocks can still be in for a rough ride and recovery prospects look unexciting.
Investing in fixed income will provide stable income during times of market volatility, while helping to diversify one's portfolio.

site_title: Singapore stocks rebound on Tuesday as banking fears fade; STI up 1.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1.1% to 3,173.93 on Tuesday, led by gains in local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC. The rebound was driven by Wall Street's positive performance and declining implied volatility. Flagship carrier Singapore Airlines was the top performer, while Emperador Inc was the only STI stock to fall. The market saw 1.34 billion securities worth S$967.5 million traded, with gainers outnumbering losers 319 to 234.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
The flurry of calls highlight the heightened anxiety by Credit Suisse’s staff amid a takeover that has been described by UBS chairman Colm Kelleher as an “emergency rescue”.
MAS says it will remain in close contact with Finma, Credit Suisse and UBS as the takeover is executed.

site_title: Apac Realty to expand real estate services to Laos
summary: Apac Realty, a real estate services provider, has signed a 25-year franchise agreement with ERA Laos, granting it exclusive rights to operate ERA member broker offices in Laos. The agreement expands Apac Realty's presence in the Indochina region and advances its strategic growth plans. Laos is expected to register growth of 3.1-6.2% in 2023, driven by strong domestic consumption and foreign investment, particularly from China. This expansion deepens Apac Realty's foothold in the region, with a network of over 21,900 agents across 11 countries and territories.

images.alt_text: Photo by Yen Meng Jiin: Interior and exterior of Apac Realty (ERA)
Janice Lim

site_title: High interest rates sent home prices sliding in Sweden
summary: House prices in Sweden plummeted 15% from their peak in March 2022 to the end of last year, largely due to high interest rates and a global surge in inflation. The war in Ukraine, energy crisis, and rising inflation have pushed up interest rates, causing households to cut spending and reducing demand for housing. This has led to a severe housing market downturn, with many apartments selling for less than their original purchase price. Analysts predict a recession in Sweden, with economists forecasting a 1.8% decline in gross domestic product and private consumption this year.

images.alt_text: A front loader operates on a construction site in the Sodermalm district of Stockholm, Sweden, on Monday, June 17, 2013. Sweden's regulator on May 21 tripled the risk-weights banks need to apply to mortgages to 15 percent to limit losses from any potential housing crisis and try to stem growth in household indebtedness.

site_title: Demand for truffles in Dubai is soaring. Here’s the man to call
summary: Massimo Vidoni, a 54-year-old Italian native, has become known in Dubai as the "Truffleman" due to his expertise in supplying high-quality truffles to top restaurants. His business, Italtouch, imports nearly 4,000 kilograms of truffles annually from countries like Italy, France, and Spain. Demand for truffles in Dubai has soared, with the import value nearing US$4 million in 2021. Vidoni's services were previously unavailable to chefs in Dubai, who relied on general food importers with limited truffle offerings. His introduction of truffles to the market has led to a significant increase in truffle consumption, with top chefs like Francesco Guarracino now purchasing 10 kg to 20 kg of truffles weekly.

images.alt_text: Anne-Sophie Pic constantly challenges herself to take her cuisine to the next level.

site_title: Covid-19 underscores importance of diversified strategy for supply chain resilience: Gan Kim Yong
summary: Singapore Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong emphasized the importance of a diversified strategy for supply chain resilience during the Covid-19 pandemic. The government's approach included diversifying imports, enhancing local manufacturing, and stockpiling essential supplies. This strategy helped mitigate disruptions and maintain supply chains. Gan also highlighted the need for adaptability and balance in decision-making, as seen in the gradual reopening of Singapore's borders. The government's efforts have contributed to the country's recovery, with Changi Airport passenger traffic expected to recover to pre-pandemic levels by next year.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

Enhancing systems at key food supply facilities such as at Jurong Fishery Port would better support contract tracing and control measure enforcement, in the case of future disease outbreaks, says Zaqy.

One step to fortify Singapore’s public health system ahead of the next pandemic is setting up a dedicated centre for public health, similar to other countries' centres for disease control, says Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong.
Red tape and red crosses served as safe distancing markings when Singapore underwent a period of "heightened alert" in June 2021.

site_title: Vanguard to exit China funds JV with Ant, close Shanghai office: sources
summary: US fund giant Vanguard Group is exiting a joint venture with Ant Group in China, ending its six-year presence in the country. Vanguard will shut its Shanghai office and lay off staff, with Ant considering acquiring its 49% stake. The move contrasts with expansions by US rivals BlackRock and Fidelity in recent years. Vanguard's exit comes two years after it decided not to pursue a fund management unit in China, a U-turn from previous plans. The Shanghai government has been notified of the planned withdrawal.

site_title: Hong Kong overnight funding costs double in sign of cash squeeze
summary: Hong Kong's overnight funding costs surged 253 basis points to 4.14% on Tuesday, the largest gain since 2006. Analysts attribute the increase to stress in the global financial system, quarter-end cash hoarding, and speculation about equity-related outflows. The rate surge is also linked to traders unwinding long US dollar positions against the Hong Kong currency and a decline in the city's liquidity pool. Despite the city's leader, John Lee, stating that Hong Kong's banking system is resilient, the move is seen as a sign of a cash squeeze in the market.

site_title: Thailand to hold general elections on May 14 as Prayuth bids to extend his near decade-long rule
summary: Thailand will hold a general election on May 14, with opposition parties leading in a pre-poll survey. Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha is seeking to extend his nearly decade-long rule, but faces voter discontent and economic challenges. The election will determine the next leader, with a two-ballot system allocating 100 seats based on party proportions. Prayuth's approval rating has fallen to third place, with the Pheu Thai Party and Move Forward party leading the polls, as the country prepares for its first election since 2019.

images.alt_text: epa08774206 Thai Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha (C) as see on a monitor screen, speaks to the members of the House of Representatives and Senate during a special session inside the meeting chambers of Thai Parliament, in Bangkok, Thailand, 26 October 2020. The government will hold a special session of parliament on 26 and 27 October to find the solution to ongoing street protest, which are calling for the resignation of Thai Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha, a new constitution and monarchy reform.  EPA-EFE/NARONG SANGNAK

site_title: Hot stock: LMIRT plunges 22.7% to all-time low of S$0.017
summary: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) shares plummeted 22.7% to an all-time low of S$0.017 on Tuesday, amid heavy trading and news that the trust would not pay its March 2023 distribution to holders of its perpetual securities. This decision follows downgrades by Moody and Fitch due to refinancing risk, and affects unit holders of LMIRT and those who bought its June 2017 perpetual securities. The unpaid sum is noncumulative and does not accrue in distribution.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

site_title: German investor morale tumbles on bank concerns
summary: German investor morale plummeted in March, dropping to -46.5 from -45.1, below analysts' prediction of -44.3. The ZEW economic research institute attributed this decline to concerns about a new financial crisis, triggered by the collapse of US mid-sized lenders and the demise of Credit Suisse. Investors worry about potential bank failures and increased restrictions, with some experts downplaying the drop as a reaction to recent developments. The poor assessment of economic conditions suggests a persistently weak economic outlook.

site_title: BYD reduces shifts at two electric vehicle plants in China: sources
summary: BYD, China's largest electric vehicle (EV) manufacturer, has reduced shifts at two of its auto assembly plants, the Xian and Shenzhen plants, due to weaker industry-wide demand in the country. The company, which outsells Tesla in China, has reduced shifts to four days a week at the Xian plant and to two days a week at the Shenzhen plant. BYD has been slowing output since the start of the year as the country ended a national subsidy programme for EVs and plug-in electric vehicles.

site_title: Volkswagen says there’s never been a better time to build an EV factory in the US
summary: Volkswagen has moved forward with plans to build a $2 billion electric vehicle factory in South Carolina, producing 200,000 EVs annually, as part of its Scout Motors brand. The decision was influenced by the US federal Inflation Reduction Act, which provides incentives for domestically produced EVs. VW opted to build its own facility instead of hiring a contract manufacturer, citing the benefits of early location and control over production. The factory, set to open in 2026, will employ 4,000 workers and aims to compete with American stalwarts like the Ford Bronco and Jeep Wrangler.

images.alt_text: Russian auto manufacturer GAZ, which was contracted to produce Volkswagen vehicles at its factory in Nizhny Novgorod, had sued the German carmaker for breach of contract after Volkswagen terminated the agreement in August.

German carmaker Volkswagen presents its new electric ID. 2all model, an electric vehicle that costs less than 25,000 euros, in Hamburg, Germany, March 15, 2023. REUTERS/Fabian Bimmer     TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY

As Volkswagent works toward a target of 50 per cent electric vehicle sales globally by 2030, over two-thirds of the five-year investment budget is allocated towards electrification and digitalisation.
Volkswagen confirmed in December it was looking for sites for a plant in Canada.

site_title: Asia: Markets rebound as bank fears ease, Fed decision in view
summary: Asian markets rebounded on Tuesday as lender fears eased following support from authorities for depositors and troubled banks. The Federal Reserve's policy decision is expected later in the week. Despite a takeover of Credit Suisse, concerns about a wider crisis have subsided, and analysts warn it's too early to say the crisis is over. The Dow and European markets rose, while the dollar tumbled against peers, and oil prices fell as investors worry about a possible recession.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks fell more than two per cent, with heavyweight HSBC off four per cent. That came even as the city’s monetary authority said its banking sector had “insignificant” exposure to Credit Suisse.

site_title: Singapore to strengthen food distribution facilities, infrastructure for future crises
summary: Singapore is strengthening its food distribution facilities and infrastructure to enhance resilience against future emergencies and pandemics. The government is upgrading key facilities such as Jurong Fishery Port and Pasir Panjang Wholesale Centre with improved security, surveillance, and access control systems. Additionally, the government is exploring the use of private infrastructure, including hotels and exhibition spaces, for emergency housing and developing dual-use facilities with both peacetime and crisis functions.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan

One step to fortify Singapore’s public health system ahead of the next pandemic is setting up a dedicated centre for public health, similar to other countries' centres for disease control, says Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong.
Red tape and red crosses served as safe distancing markings when Singapore underwent a period of "heightened alert" in June 2021.

site_title: US awards US$94 million for innovative mobility projects
summary: The US Transportation Department has awarded $94.8 million to 59 projects focused on advanced technology to boost road safety, improve transit reliability, and use drones and sensors. The grants, part of the $500 million "Smart" mobility initiative, aim to foster innovations that make transportation safer, more reliable, and sustainable. Recipients include cities like Detroit, New Jersey, and Los Angeles, which will use the funds to implement smart intersections, wrong-way driving prevention systems, and drone technology for medical care and equipment deliveries.

site_title: China gives chipmakers easier subsidy access to help guide industry recovery: FT
summary: China is implementing a more than 1 trillion yuan ($194.6 billion) support package for its semiconductor industry, aiming to guide its recovery. The package will provide easier access to subsidies and more control over state-backed research for select chipmakers, including SMIC, Hua Hong Semiconductor, and Huawei. These companies will also be allowed to play a bigger role in state-sponsored research projects without having to meet previously necessary performance goals. The move is seen as a response to tightening US restrictions on China's technological advances.

site_title: We need to talk about the carbon budget
summary: The world's carbon budget is dwindling, with the IPCC estimating 300 gigatonnes of CO2 available to limit global heating to 1.5 deg C. However, substantial fossil fuel reserves and vast carbon storage in the Global South pose a significant challenge. The Global North must take action to reduce emissions, while the Global South needs significant climate adaptation finance and a transition to net zero. A balanced approach to distributing remaining emissions rights equally per capita across the globe could deliver an efficient use of the world's remaining emissions budget.

images.alt_text: US Energy Secretary Jennifer Granholm said the Biden administration makes no apologies for the IRA, and challenged EU allies to follow the US lead by providing more subsidies of their own.

One of the world’s biggest greenhouse gas emitters, Indonesia last year set a more ambitious target for reducing carbon emission by 31.89 per cent on its own, or 43.2 per cent with international support, by 2030.

Travelers prepare to board a passenger aircraft operated by Qantas Airways Ltd. at Sydney Airport in Sydney, Australia, on Wednesday, June 23, 2021. While losses at airlines globally from Covid-19 are set to surpass $174 billion by the end of 2021 -- wiping out half a decade of profits -- Qantas has become one of the most financially secure carriers anywhere in the world. Photographer: Brendon Thorne/Bloomberg

site_title: Higher upside potential for Bukalapak amid push for profitability, DBS says
summary: DBS Group Research has issued a report recommending "buy" calls for Sea and Bukalapak, and a "hold" call for Grab, citing the potential for higher upside for Bukalapak due to its "rock-bottom valuation" and expected re-rating in nine to 12 months. DBS has set a target price of 355 rupiah for Bukalapak, implying a 57% upside from its current price.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
GoTo, formed through a merger of ride-hailing provider Gojek and e-commerce firm Tokopedia, cut 600 roles from its workforce this month, adding to the 1,300 jobs it axed last year.
Grab will likely achieve its earlier break-even goal even in a slowing economy.
GoTo said it expects adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation to turn positive in the fourth quarter of 2023, about a year ahead of its previous target.
Patricia Sosrodjojo, partner at Seedstars International Ventures.
Tech IPOs in the region has tapered off after a flurry of listings from Grab to Blibli, as exiting via public markets aren't as attractive to investors as in the past.

The app of Indonesian e-commerce company Bukalapak, which is among the unicorns that have suffered share price drops. The shares of Bukalapak and Singapore-based Grab Holdings have fallen more than 65 per cent since their IPOs.
Sea Limited founder Mr Forrest Li, who is taking over Singapore Premier League club Home United and privatising it to become Lion City Sailors.
The latest cuts affect fewer than 500 full-time and contract workers in Shopee’s customer service team in Indonesia.
Sea executed a “decisive pivot to focus on efficiency and profitability”, said CEO Forrest Li in a press statement.

site_title: S-E Asia’s conglomerates should increase exposure to higher-growth sectors to stay ahead: EY
summary: A study by EY-Parthenon found that South-east Asian conglomerates risk underperforming due to their limited exposure to emerging sectors, with 80% of revenue coming from old-economy sectors. The consultancy recommended that companies increase their exposure to technology, healthcare, and other higher-growth sectors, citing examples of pure-play companies outperforming conglomerates. EY advises companies to adopt strategies such as building digital ecosystems, agile capital allocation, and asset-light business models to regain dominance in the next decade.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Sea Limited founder Mr Forrest Li, who is taking over Singapore Premier League club Home United and privatising it to become Lion City Sailors.

site_title: Credit Suisse bankers flood headhunters from Singapore to London
summary: Credit Suisse bankers are seeking new jobs as the Swiss lender is set to be taken over by UBS Group, described as an "emergency rescue". From Singapore to London, headhunters are receiving unprecedented calls from anxious staff, with some firms handling over 20 senior investment bankers. The job market is challenging, with major banks cutting roles, and many Credit Suisse staff may be dismissed after joining UBS, according to a headhunter. The takeover is expected to lead to job cuts, with the investment bank likely to be impacted.

images.alt_text: The Credit Suisse rescue has caused turmoil in European markets, with banks’ bond prices under pressure as investors focus on the potential risks of holding AT1 bonds.
Less than a week after large US banks pumped US$30 billion in deposits into the midsized US lender, investors dumped First Republic on worries that infusion of capital would not be enough.
Credit Suisse's Additional Tier-1 bonds would be wiped out as part of the rescue deal, to add US$16 billion of equity to support the UBS takeover.

site_title: Hong Kong developer opens new office towers amid record vacancy
summary: Hong Kong property developer Sino Land is opening new office towers in non-core areas, including Landmark South in Wong Chuk Hang, to capture demand for cheaper office space amidst record-high vacancies of 13 million square feet in February. Private wealth-management companies are interested in these areas, and many employees also reside nearby. The move aims to capitalize on the demand for alternative office spaces outside traditional districts like Central.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong was the most expensive destination in Asia.

Hong Kong’s banking sector was in a healthy liquidity position, the authority said, with the average Liquidity Coverage Ratio for major institutions at 162.3 per cent in Q4 2022, well above the 100 per cent minimum requirement.

site_title: These are the world’s most expensive cities for business travel
summary: The world's most expensive cities for business travel in 2022 were: New York ($796 per day), Washington DC, San Francisco, Geneva, and Zurich. US cities dominated the ranking, while Hong Kong was the most expensive destination in Asia. Inflation and pandemic-fuelled travel costs contributed to the increase. London and Paris retained their top ten positions, while Luanda, Angola, was the priciest place in Africa, with a daily charge of $US 1,080.

site_title: Brokers’ take: UOBKH downgrades Rex to ‘sell’, lowers target price to S$0.10
summary: UOB Kay Hian has downgraded its rating on Rex International to "sell" due to the company's poor financial results and diversification plans. The research house lowered its target price to S$0.10 from S$0.45, citing concerns over Rex's ability to consistently produce oil. The downgrade comes after UOBKH lowered its earnings estimates for FY2023 and FY2024 by 48% and 54%, respectively. The company's recent acquisitions unrelated to its core business of oil and gas have also raised concerns about its corporate governance.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Rex is hopeful that Xer, which sold its first drone through a tender to the Swedish government, will sell more units this year.

site_title: Covid report based on China samples puts suspicion back to animal origins
summary: A new analysis of Covid-19 samples from a Wuhan, China market found evidence of the novel coronavirus along with genetic material from multiple animals, including raccoon dogs, which are susceptible to the disease. The samples suggest that the Huanan Wholesale Seafood Market was the epicentre of the pandemic, with some samples showing more animal genetic material than human genetic material, indicating possible SARS-CoV-2 infections in animals.

images.alt_text: Biden noted that he had directed intelligence agencies to investigate Covid-19’s origins in 2021 including potential links to the Wuhan Institute of Virology.

One step to fortify Singapore’s public health system ahead of the next pandemic is setting up a dedicated centre for public health, similar to other countries' centres for disease control, says Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong.

site_title: Nadal out of top 10 for first time since 2005
summary: Tennis star Rafael Nadal has slipped out of the top 10 for the first time since 2005 due to a hip issue that ended his Australian Open title defence in the second round. His absence from the Indian Wells Masters 1000 event resulted in a four-place drop to 13th in the rankings. However, with Nadal preparing to return to action at the Monte Carlo Masters ahead of the French Open, where he has won 14 times, his time outside the top 10 may be short.

images.alt_text: None of the sport’s three other Grand Slams in Australia, France and the US have imposed similar bans.
Andy Murray beat his Czech opponent 6-0 3-6 7-6(6), fighting back from 5-3 down in the decider.

site_title: Credit Suisse memorabilia up for grabs in online shops after merger
summary: Credit Suisse memorabilia, including gold bars and branded merchandise, is being sold online in Switzerland following the bank's takeover by UBS. Dozens of items, such as blue and red ski hats, stamps, and sports bags, have been uploaded to popular marketplaces. The sale is expected to continue until the merger is complete, with sellers seeking to attract those looking to own a piece of Swiss financial history. The fate of the Credit Suisse brand remains uncertain, with UBS to decide whether to continue it after the takeover.

images.alt_text: The flurry of calls highlight the heightened anxiety by Credit Suisse’s staff amid a takeover that has been described by UBS chairman Colm Kelleher as an “emergency rescue”.
The Credit Suisse rescue has caused turmoil in European markets, with banks’ bond prices under pressure as investors focus on the potential risks of holding AT1 bonds.
Less than a week after large US banks pumped US$30 billion in deposits into the midsized US lender, investors dumped First Republic on worries that infusion of capital would not be enough.

site_title: Hong Kong financial system resilient to bank crisis, Lee says
summary: Hong Kong's financial system is resilient to the global banking crisis, according to top officials. Leader John Lee stated that the banking sector is operating smoothly and the market's liquidity is abundant. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority reported a 0.7% increase in the Hang Seng benchmark on the same day. Exposure to Credit Suisse Group is considered insignificant, with the one-month cost of interbank borrowing falling to 3%. Immediate concerns over the global financial system have dissipated, with HSBC clawing back some losses.

site_title: Gold prices ease as market focus turns to US Fed meeting
summary: Gold prices eased on Tuesday, falling 0.1% to US$1,977.69 per ounce, as investors awaited the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting, where interest rate hikes are expected to be paused. Following a surge to a 2-year high of US$2,009.59 on Monday, the market shift was driven by central banks' efforts to contain the banking crisis and stabilise financial markets. The US central bank is seen holding its benchmark lending rate, with a 53% chance of a pause.

images.alt_text: A rally in bullion prices sparked by the global banking rout forced Indian dealers to offer steeper discounts on physical gold to lure retail customers and led to a drop in China premiums last week.

site_title: Hong Kong opens doors to billionaires in family office push
summary: Hong Kong is hosting a Wealth for Good summit, attracting over 100 family office representatives from around the world, including billionaires like Paul Desmarais III and Jerry Yang. The event aims to showcase Hong Kong's advantages as a finance hub, with a focus on "wealth for" themes such as technology, art, and philanthropy. The government is also planning to roll out a tax concession for single family offices and has set a target of getting at least 200 family offices to set up or expand operations in the city by 2025.

images.alt_text: MAS regulates MFOs and screens SFOs that apply for tax incentives, Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam says when asked about the processes to check applicants' identities and source of funds.
The banking crisis has unfolded just as Hong Kong reopened to the world, with the city hosting the Credit Suisse Asian Investment Conference this week.
Hong Kong had a record high 13 million square feet of empty premium office space in February.

site_title: China weighs cut of about 2.5% in 2023 crude steel output: sources
summary: China is considering a 2.5% cut in crude steel output in 2023 to curb emissions, following a two-year-old policy to reduce the world's largest steel sector's impact on the environment. The plan, proposed by policymakers, has not yet been finalized and is expected to be set before the end of June. This move aims to support economic growth after last year's slow recovery, while also meeting China's climate goals, including reaching peak carbon dioxide emissions by 2030 and achieving carbon neutrality by 2060.

site_title: Samsung wins jury trial in ‘S10’ trademark lawsuit
summary: A Los Angeles federal jury ruled in favor of Samsung Electronics, finding that its Galaxy S10 phones do not infringe on the trademark rights of talent-management agency S10 Entertainment & Media. The jury found no likelihood of consumer confusion between the two brands, as Samsung had priority to the "S10" name due to its earlier Galaxy S "family" of marks. S10 Entertainment & Media had argued that Samsung's advertising would confuse customers into thinking the brands were affiliated, but the jury rejected this claim.

images.alt_text: Samsung has been aggressively expanding its most advanced plants at home in Pyeongtaek.

FILE PHOTO: An employee of Samsung Electronics walks past LED lighting drums displayed for visitors at a showroom at the company's headquarters in Seoul October 28, 2011. Samsung Electronics Co overtook Apple Inc as the world's top smartphone maker in the July-September period with a 44 percent jump in shipments, and forecast strong sales in the current quarter in a clear warning to its rivals.   REUTERS/Jo Yong-Hak

site_title: Issue 2: Grab gets rated; carbon market inclusivity
summary: Grab, a Singapore-based super app, has earned an MSCI ESG rating of "AA", the second-highest possible rating, making it an "ESG leader" among major ride hailers. This rating indicates that Grab prioritizes environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors, demonstrating its commitment to sustainability.

images.alt_text: Kenneth Lim

site_title: US studies ways to guarantee all bank deposits if crisis expands
summary: US officials are studying ways to temporarily expand Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) coverage to all deposits, aiming to prevent a potential financial crisis. The Treasury Department is reviewing emergency authority to insure deposits greater than the current $250,000 cap without formal consent from Congress. This move comes after midsize banks called for broader government intervention following three lender collapses and a fourth firm's struggles to avoid a similar fate. One potential framework involves using the Treasury Department's authority to take emergency action and lean on the Exchange Stabilisation Fund.

images.alt_text: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. headquarters in Washington, DC. Photographer: Al Drago/Bloomberg

site_title: Cryptoverse: Bitcoin passes the bank stress test
summary: Bitcoin has risen 21% this month, outperforming the 1.4% decline of the S&P 500 and the 8% gain of gold, amidst a banking crisis that has led to a recession.
