The cryptocurrency's 30-day correlation with the S&P 500 has dropped to -0.12, indicating a move away from stocks. Bitcoin's price surge has forced some short-sellers to cut their bets, but its core ethos as a decentralized financial asset independent from the central financial system is being rediscovered, with the total crypto market capitalization jumping 23% to $1.1 billion.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A representation of bitcoin is seen in an illustration picture taken on June 23, 2017. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier/File Photo

site_title: China’s Geely beats estimates, snapping four-year profit decline
summary: Geely Automobile Holdings, a Chinese automaker, reported earnings that beat estimates, ending a four-year profit decline. Net income rose 9% to 5.26 billion yuan, while revenue climbed 46% to 147.96 billion yuan. Despite this, gross margin fell 3 percentage points due to surging costs and lower margins for new energy vehicles. Geely set a sales target of 1.65 million units for 2023, focusing on electric vehicles, autonomous driving, and exports. The company's export rose 72% last year, with sales in China rising just 2%.

images.alt_text: A Zeekr Co. 001 electric vehicle at Zhejiang Geely Holding Group Co.'s Zeekr Intelligent Factory in Ningbo, Zhejiang Province, China, on Wednesday, Feb. 22, 2023. Geely, one of China's largest carmakers, has joined a local price war by offering discounts of as much as 30,000 yuan ($4,350) on some of its models. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: UOBKH expects narrowing H2 losses for Malaysia’s glove sector, flags deep value opportunity
summary: Malaysia's glove sector is expected to narrow losses in the second half of 2023, with UOB Kay Hian upgrading its sector rating to "overweight". Analysts predict earnings will bottom out in the first half of 2023, followed by a positive adjustment in average selling prices and moderating costs. The sector is projected to lose RM92 million in 2023, but recover to RM655 million in 2024, driven by recovering ASPs and utilisation rates. Sector valuations are considered deep value, with a favorable reward-to-risk payoff.

images.alt_text: epa08723304 A worker collects newly made gloves inside the Top Glove factory at Setia Alam, outside Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, 06 October 2020. Top Glove is the world's largest rubber glove manufacturer.  EPA-EFE/FAZRY ISMAIL
Michelle Zhu

site_title: China’s overnight repo rate hits two-year high on signs of liquidity stress
summary: China's overnight repo rate surged to a two-year high of 2.4505% on March 21, driven by seasonal cash demand and quarter-end funding needs. Short-term primary money rates rose, while the People's Bank of China's move to cut the reserve requirement ratio by 25 basis points from March 27 is expected to alleviate liquidity stress. Market watchers believe the tight funding conditions are temporary, with monetary easing measures set to take effect soon, potentially easing pressure on banks.

images.alt_text: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) building in Beijing.Source: Bloomberg

site_title: Australia puts policy pause back on the table as economy slows
summary: Australia's central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), is considering pausing its policy tightening cycle due to an uncertain economic outlook and restrictive interest-rate settings. The RBA raised interest rates to 3.6% in its latest meeting, but minutes showed policymakers were already focused on economic uncertainties. The decision comes as the global banking sector faces stress, and financial markets imply the RBA will stand pat at its April meeting. This move may ease concerns for Prime Minister Anthony Albanese, who has been trying to persuade a heavily indebted electorate to accept higher interest rates to combat inflation.

images.alt_text: Outside the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) building in Sydney. Photographer: Brendon Thorne/Bloomberg

site_title: Sri Lanka gets US$3 billion IMF loan to ease economic crisis
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) approved a US$3 billion loan programme for Sri Lanka, a 48-month programme aimed at stabilizing the nation's economy and restructuring its debt. The loan includes an immediate disbursement of approximately US$333 million. The IMF stated that Sri Lanka has been hit hard by an economic and humanitarian crisis, exacerbated by pre-existing vulnerabilities and policy missteps.

images.alt_text: The bankrupt nation grappled with soaring costs, depleted funds and severe supply shortages for much of 2022.

Economic mismanagement coupled with the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic left Sri Lanka severely short of US dollars for essential imports at the start of last year tipping the country into the worst financial crisis since Independence from the British in 1948.

site_title: Boustead Projects shares to be suspended as company loses free float
summary: Boustead Projects shares will be suspended after Boustead Singapore acquired 91.74% of its shares, leaving the public with only 8.3% ownership. This violates the Singapore Exchange's free float requirement of at least 10%, which may lead to delisting. Boustead Singapore has stated its intention to privatize and delist its real estate subsidiary since its takeover offer was announced in February.

images.alt_text: The entrance of Boustead Singapore’s office.
Janice Lim

site_title: Ferrari says ransomware attack exposed clients’ names, email
summary: Ferrari confirmed it was hit by a ransomware attack that exposed client information, including names, email addresses, and phone numbers, but no payment details or car ownership information was stolen. The company stated it won't meet ransomware demands and has begun an investigation with a cybersecurity firm. Despite the breach, Ferrari's operations have not been impacted.

site_title: Credit Suisse rescue eases crisis fears, First Republic shares dive
summary: US lender First Republic's shares plummeted nearly 50% on Monday after investors worried that a recent $30 billion deposit infusion from large US banks may not be enough to keep the bank afloat. Ratings agency S&P Global downgraded the bank deeper into junk status, citing liquidity risks. JPMorgan Chase & Co is reportedly leading talks with other big banks to stabilize First Republic with a possible investment. The turmoil overshadowed a positive day for banking stocks globally, with UBS Group's takeover of Credit Suisse easing crisis fears.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A First Republic Bank branch is pictured in Midtown Manhattan in New York City, New York, U.S., March 13, 2023. REUTERS/Mike Segar/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Screening of Winnie the Pooh horror film cancelled in Hong Kong
summary: A screening of the Winnie the Pooh horror film "Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey" in Hong Kong has been cancelled due to technical reasons. The film's distributor, VII Pillars Entertainment, did not respond to requests for comment. The cancellation comes amid concerns over censorship, as Chinese censors have previously targeted the film's main character due to online comparisons with President Xi Jinping. The move is seen as a challenge to Hong Kong's government, which is promoting the city as a cultural hub despite a new censorship law that bars films deemed to endanger national security.

site_title: Britain’s financial industry plans blueprint for post-Brexit ‘kickstart’
summary: Britain's financial industry plans to release a blueprint by 2024 to boost London's role as a post-Brexit global financial centre by 2030. Key players, including Lloyd's insurance market, Schroders, and Barclays, will work together to develop a roadmap to compete with centres like New York and Singapore. The City of London's policy chairman, Chris Hayward, stated that there is currently a lack of an overarching vision and strategy for UK financial services. This plan aims to capitalize on London's position as the world's second most important financial centre after New York.

images.alt_text: The Financial Conduct Authority said in a letter to ESG benchmarks compilers that a preliminary review had shown that the quality of their disclosures was poor.
While the immediate focus for UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's foreign policy may be Russia, a proper strategy is needed across all of the UK’s key relationships.
Individuals surveyed by the Bank of England (BOE) said they thought CPI inflation would be at 3.9 per cent in 12 months, down from 4.8 per cent when asked in November.

site_title: Singapore studying developments in greenwashing  in other countries
summary: Singapore is studying greenwashing practices in other countries to assess the need for specific guidance or regulations. Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan stated that the Consumer Protection (Fair Trading) Act is "sufficiently broad" to address greenwashing claims, but the Consumers Association of Singapore and the Competition and Consumer Commission have not received specific complaints. Existing guidelines under the Singapore Code of Advertising Practice ensure advertisers clearly explain environmental claims, but Tan acknowledged the importance of further study on the issue.

images.alt_text: Shoppers carry shopping bags on Orchard Road in Singapore, on Monday, Aug. 22, 2022. Singapore announces its consumer price index (CPI) figures on Aug. 23. Photographer: Ore Huiying/Bloomberg

site_title: Covid-19 White Paper aims not to critique but draw lessons after honest appraisal: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong announced the release of Singapore's Covid-19 after-action review (AAR) White Paper, which aims to draw lessons from the pandemic without criticizing the government's actions. Three key takeaways include fortifying the public health system, enhancing forward-planning capabilities, and strengthening national resilience. To address these lessons, Singapore plans to set up a dedicated centre for public health, establish a dedicated team for forward-planning, and diversify supply chains and safeguard reserves. The government also aims to improve surveillance testing, communication, and mental health support for migrant workers.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Red tape and red crosses served as safe distancing markings when Singapore underwent a period of "heightened alert" in June 2021.
The couple faced a police investigation as they were found to have lied under oath over Lee Suet Fern’s conduct in handling the last will of Singapore’s founding prime minister, Lee Kuan Yew.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Boustead Projects, Fortress Minerals, Second Chance, LMIRT, Soilbuild Construction
summary: Boustead Projects' shares are set to be suspended after Boustead Singapore acquired 91.7% of its shares, aiming to take the company private. Fortress Minerals announced a proposed placement to raise S$9 million for mine development and exploration efforts. Other notable developments include NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer being 9.8 times oversubscribed and OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, previously a DBS veteran.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
In the wider Singapore market, losers outnumbered gainers 407 to 194, with 1.53 billion securities worth S$1.23 billion changing hands.

site_title: Credit Suisse AT1 bondholders consider possible legal action
summary: Lawyers from Switzerland, the US, and UK are discussing possible legal action with Credit Suisse Additional Tier 1 (AT1) bondholders over the state-backed rescue deal, which wiped out the bonds. The rescue deal, involving UBS, resulted in bondholders receiving nothing, while shareholders received $3.23 billion. Funds such as Lazard Freres Gestion, Pimco, and GAM Investments are exposed to potential losses, with Pimco holding 3.49% of its fund in Credit Suisse AT1 bonds. A call for bondholders is likely to be convened, amid European regulators' decision to impose losses on shareholders before bondholders.

images.alt_text: Less than a week after large US banks pumped US$30 billion in deposits into the midsized US lender, investors dumped First Republic on worries that infusion of capital would not be enough.
FILE PHOTO: Logos of Swiss banks UBS and Credit Suisse are seen in Zurich, Switzerland March 19, 2023. REUTERS/Moritz Hager/File Photo
Credit Suisse shares plunged 60 per cent in early trade on Monday, as investor optimism about official efforts to stem a banking crisis quickly evaporated.

site_title: Asian banks preferred on lower-risk, limited  contagion from recent banking fallout: analysts
summary: Asian banks are seen as relatively low-risk due to their lower exposure to US and EU corporate bonds, which has contained the impact of recent banking fallout in the US and European Union. The MSCI Asian Financial Index fell 4.2% since March 8, compared to a 10.6% decline in the MSCI World Financials Index. Analysts favor Asian banks with "overweight" views, citing conservative oversight and strict funding parameters, as well as economic reopening and recovering domestic consumption driving re-rating. Indonesia's banking sector is seen as promising, with a 29.5% growth rate in credit card and non-mortgage consumer loans.

images.alt_text: agriculture, rice plantation, thailand
Yong Hui Ting

site_title: UBS erases losses as investors weigh Credit Suisse deal impact
summary: UBS erased losses after its shares rose 2.16% following the announcement of a government-brokered, 3 billion Swiss franc deal to prevent a wider international banking crisis. The deal values Credit Suisse at a fraction of its closing price, with government backstops and guarantees to ease the pain for UBS. However, the takeover complicates UBS' investor pitch and may require years to work through the integration, with analysts citing uncertainties on the implementation of new capital requirements and the future of share buybacks.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse shares plunged 60 per cent in early trade on Monday, as investor optimism about official efforts to stem a banking crisis quickly evaporated.

site_title: Four ways to fix the bank problem
summary: The global banking system is facing a crisis, with high leverage and potential mark-to-market losses. Reforms introduced after the 2008 financial crisis have not been sufficient, and depositors are unable to monitor bank soundness in real-time. Four potential solutions to reform the banking system include tightening regulation, increasing bank robustness, and abandoning the combination of money and risky loans. The "Chicago Plan" proposes matching liabilities to public deposits with similar assets, allowing for central bank digital currencies and risk intermediation by mutual funds or banking institutions. Immediate reforms are necessary to prevent costly instability.

images.alt_text: Euro dollars, US dollars, currency, notes, money

site_title: TikTok hits 150 million US monthly users, up from 100 million in 2020
summary: TikTok has reached 150 million monthly active US users, up from 100 million in 2020. The app faces growing pressure in Washington, with calls to ban it due to concerns over US user data falling into China's government hands. Six US senators have backed bipartisan legislation to give President Biden new powers to ban TikTok, and the company has rejected spying allegations, stating that divestment of its Chinese owners does not solve national security concerns.

images.alt_text: Numerous countries have raised concerns over Tiktok's proximity to the Chinese government and hold over user data across the world.
TikTok will be banned on all devices with access to New Zealand’s parliamentary network by the end of March, said Parliamentary Service chief executive Rafael Gonzalez-Montero.
TikTok’s leadership is now considering more drastic measures to keep operating in the US, including separating from its parent, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Technology-based carbon credits clear at RM18.50 at Bursa Malaysia’s inaugural auction; nature-based ones fetch RM68
summary: Bursa Malaysia's inaugural carbon auction has cleared, with technology-based credits selling at RM18.50 (S$5.52) per credit and nature-based ones at RM68. A total of 150,000 carbon credits were bought by 15 Malaysian companies, including Petronas and MayBank. The auction aims to raise awareness of voluntary carbon markets and offsetting opportunities in the country, with Bursa Malaysia CEO Muhamad Umar Swift noting that it provides a clear signal for project developers to develop carbon credit projects.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Bursa Malaysia opened an exchange this month, joining more than a dozen that are underway or planned across the region.
Bursa Malaysia CEO Muhamad Umar Swift at the launch of the first Shariah-compliant carbon exchange in the world on Dec 9, 2022 in Kuala Lumpur.

site_title: Koh Beng Seng to step down as Great Eastern chairman
summary: Great Eastern's board chairman Koh Beng Seng will step down on April 22, with Soon Tit Koon taking over as the new chairman. Koh has served as chairman since 2014 and will also relinquish other roles. He will be replaced by Soon Tit Koon, who has been on Great Eastern's board since 2008.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Europe: Stocks end turbulent day up as markets assess Credit Suisse rescue
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 index rose 1.0% at close, reversing early losses after UBS' swift takeover of Credit Suisse. Banking shares rebounded, with the sector gaining 1.3% despite Credit Suisse's 55.7% slump. Investors remain concerned about the bank's AT1 bonds, which will be valued at zero. European stocks are up 3.7% for the year, despite the recent collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank.

images.alt_text: A US$30 billion lifeline by large US banks for embattled lender First Republic Bank, less than a day after battered Credit Suisse clinched a mega central bank loan, has boosted the bank index earlier in the day.

site_title: Oil prices rebound after hitting lowest since 2021 on banking fears
summary: Oil prices rebounded by over 1% on Monday after hitting their lowest levels in 15 months due to concerns about a recession sparked by the global banking sector. Despite a historic deal between UBS and Credit Suisse, oil prices initially fell as much as $3 a barrel. However, gains on Wall Street and central banks' pledge to enhance market liquidity helped lift prices. The US Federal Reserve is set to make a decision on rate hikes on Wednesday, which may influence oil prices, and the G7 is unlikely to revise the $60-per-barrel price cap on Russian oil this week.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures rose 35 cents, or 0.5 per cent, to US$73.32 a barrel by 0007 GMT after a near 12 per cent loss last week, its biggest weekly fall since December.

site_title: US: Stocks end higher but First Republic shares pummelled
summary: US stocks ended higher on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 Index rising 1.2% and 0.9% respectively, as turmoil in the banking sector may be easing. Switzerland's UBS agreed to a takeover of troubled Credit Suisse, and the US Federal Reserve unveiled a coordinated effort to improve banks' access to liquidity. However, shares of First Republic Bank plummeted 47.3% despite a $30 billion deposit from a coalition of US lenders, with the bank's credit rating cut to B+ from BB+.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., March 6, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Asian central banks face little impact from US, Europe banking crisis
summary: Asian central banks are unlikely to be significantly impacted by the US and European banking crisis, but a pause in US Federal Reserve rate hikes could provide them with more breathing room for policy tightening. The crisis may prompt the Fed to slow down or pause rate hikes, giving Asian central banks more flexibility to adjust their monetary policies. However, Asian central banks are largely driven by domestic inflation and growth concerns, and may continue to raise rates as expected, particularly in countries such as Australia, India, and the Philippines.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: An eagle tops the U.S. Federal Reserve building's facade in Washington, July 31, 2013. REUTERS/Jonathan Ernst/File Photo/File Photo
Tessa Oh

site_title: Fortress Minerals proposes S$9 million placement to fund projects
summary: Fortress Minerals proposes a S$9 million placement by issuing 23.3 million new shares at S$0.386 each, a 9.9% discount to its previous market price. The company aims to fund its mining and exploration projects with the raised capital. This is within the 10% discount limit set by Catalist rules, with a discount of only 0.1%. The placement is part of Fortress Minerals' plans to build a new integrated processing plant at its Cermat Aman mine to produce high-grade iron ore, copper, and pyrrhotite concentrate.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
The licenses grant Fortress Minerals to conduct prospecting operations for copper, nickel and cobalt minerals.
Average realised selling price during the quarter fell to US$119.80 per DMT, compared to US$143 per DMT the year before.
Revenue fell 69.8 per cent to US$5.2 million in Q4.
Brokers' take: Phillip downgrades Fortress Minerals on missed forecasts

site_title: Second Chance net profit for H1 2023 to ‘increase significantly’
summary: Second Chance Properties, a Singapore-based real estate company, expects a significant increase in net profit for the first half of 2023 due to the sale of investment properties. The company's net profit is expected to rise by 528% compared to the previous year, primarily driven by gains from the sale of properties and the disposal of equity instruments.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim

site_title: The chief digital officer is also the chief collaboration officer: HSBC’s Shayan Hazir
summary: HSBC's Chief Digital Officer for Asean, Shayan Hazir, emphasizes the importance of digital adoption in showcasing the bank's efforts. Hazir's role involves connecting various aspects of the bank and fostering collaborations with key stakeholders. He highlights emerging technologies such as Web3, ChatGPT, and sustainable technologies as key trends in the future of financial services, and his team's focus is on curating and adopting these technologies to provide customers with state-of-the-art services.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun

One of the key trends that John Chen, Standard Chartered's head of corporate sales for Singapore and head of commodity sales for Asean, has noticed is market dislocation which contributes to volatility in commodity prices.
Hundreds of retail investors in Hong Kong — HSBC’s biggest market — were particularly upset when it scrapped its dividend in 2020 during the Covid-19 pandemic.
HSBC is among banks who have been seeking to increase shareholders returns as rising interest rates propel profits, but its outlook has long been complicated by geopolitical tensions.

site_title: South Korea’s early exports fall further as global demand cools
summary: South Korea's early exports declined further, falling 17.4% in the first 20 days of March, with chip sales plummeting 44.7% and shipments to China tumbling 36.2%. The slump is attributed to weak global demand for semiconductors and China's slow reopening. This marks the third consecutive decline in Korean exports, which have been declining since late last year due to sliding semiconductor prices and deteriorating energy prices.

images.alt_text: While property markets around the world have weakened due to surging borrowing costs, South Korea’s has been hit especially hard.

site_title: India’s strong corporate debt profile key to macroeconomic stability: finance ministry
summary: India's finance ministry states that the country's strong corporate debt profile is a key factor in maintaining macroeconomic stability. Tightening of financial conditions by central banks to tame inflation has raised concerns about exacerbating corporate debt vulnerabilities, but these concerns are limited for India. High corporate leverage is a concern, as interest rate hikes can impact debt servicing and refinancing costs, increasing the risk of defaults. Despite this, the ministry believes India's strong corporate debt profile will help maintain macroeconomic stability.

site_title: China’s EV revolution shows grim future for Japan’s car titans
summary: China's electric vehicle (EV) market is gaining momentum, posing a significant threat to Japan's car titans, including Toyota, Honda, and Nissan. BYD, a Chinese EV upstart, is staking a claim to the mid-market with its lineup of electric models, starting from 140,000 yuan. China's EV sales are forecast to reach 9 million in 2023, with market penetration expected to hit 35%. Japan's automakers have seen declining sales in China, with Honda and Nissan's sales falling for two years and Toyota's sales declining for the first time in a decade.

images.alt_text: Rare earths have long been a pain point for automakers and the clean-energy sector, because of unpredictable prices and China’s tight grip on the supply chain.
BYD’s new discounts follow price cuts announced by Tesla in early January.

site_title: Biden signs bill requiring declassification of Covid origins information
summary: US President Joe Biden signed a bill requiring the declassification of information related to the origins of the coronavirus that causes Covid-19. The bill aims to release as much information as possible about the origin of Covid-19, with Biden stating he will declassify and share information consistent with national security. This move comes after Biden directed intelligence agencies to investigate Covid-19's origins in 2021, including potential links to the Wuhan Institute of Virology.

images.alt_text: One step to fortify Singapore’s public health system ahead of the next pandemic is setting up a dedicated centre for public health, similar to other countries' centres for disease control, says Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong.
The WHO voiced confidence that it will be able to declare an end to the emergency some time in 2023, saying it was increasingly hopeful about the pandemic phase of the virus coming to a close.

site_title: Australia’s nuclear subs deal versus its China trade ties
summary: Australia has signed a three-part nuclear submarine deal with the US and Britain, aiming to boost its security. The accord includes US and British nuclear submarine port visits from 2027, used Virginia-class nuclear-powered boats in the 2030s, and jointly designed nuclear-powered subs with American components in the 2040s. The deal is seen as a reassurance to Australians, but critics question its feasibility and impact on Australia's military capabilities.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden (centre) with British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak (right) and Australia's Prime Minister Anthony Albanese during the Aukus summit on Mar 13; after 18 months of negotiations, US and UK leaders last week announced details of their plan to provide a fleet of nuclear-powered submarines to Australia over 30 years.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Tuesday’s open; STI up 0.8%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.8% to 3,163.43 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 102 to 39, driven by gains in banking shares and heavyweight counters such as Sembcorp Marine and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding. The positive sentiment was fueled by overnight rises in US and European equities, following a deal between Switzerland's UBS and troubled rival Credit Suisse.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Shares of Boustead Projects are set to be suspended

site_title: ‘Climate time bomb ticking’, emissions must urgently be cut: UN chief
summary: UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres warns that the world's "climate time bomb is ticking" due to rising temperatures and carbon dioxide levels. To limit a 1.5°C temperature rise, emissions must be halved by mid-2030s, a key target in the Paris accord. Guterres urges rich nations to slash emissions sooner, aiming for net zero by 2040, describing the IPCC's new assessment as a "survival guide for humanity."

site_title: A targeted approach to attracting tech companies may work best for SGX
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is struggling to attract tech companies for initial public offerings (IPOs), with UK-based semiconductor company Arm opting for a US-only listing. Critics blame poor decisions on exchange management, regulators, and politicians, but experts say it's a reflection of the current reality of global capital markets. Non-US exchanges may have a fighting chance with smaller or mid-sized IPO aspirants, and SGX should focus on convincing them to stay local. The exchange has successfully attracted secondary listings from companies like Nio and Emperador, and may yet capture a dual or secondary listing of a large home-grown tech play.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Arm said last week it would pursue a US-only listing this year, dashing the British government’s hopes that the tech giant would return to the London stock market.
Arm is a jewel of the UK tech industry.

site_title: Turkey quake reconstruction exceed US$100 billion
summary: A devastating 7.8-magnitude earthquake in southeastern Turkey and parts of Syria has caused over $104 billion in damage, with more than 50,000 people killed. The Turkish government has set a "recovery costs" estimate at $104 billion, while the UN estimates $14.8 billion for Syria. Donors have pledged funds, including $1.1 billion from the European Commission for Turkey and $108 million for humanitarian aid in Syria. Aid groups urge donors to increase commitments, citing poor response to the initial funding call.

images.alt_text: The Feb 6 earthquakes of 7.8 magnitude and 7.5 magnitude, the most deadly in modern Turkey’s history, killed more than 44,300 people.

site_title: Putin tells Xi he’ll discuss China’s blueprint for Ukraine
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin has agreed to discuss China's initiative to end the conflict in Ukraine, following a meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping. Xi's visit to Moscow aims to broker a peace deal, but Kyiv has been skeptical of Beijing's plan. The US and its allies have also rejected the proposal. After meeting with Putin, Xi will speak with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy by video link, marking Xi's first conversation with the Ukrainian leader since the war began.

images.alt_text: Russian President Vladimir Putin and Chinese President Xi Jinping attend a meeting at the Kremlin in Moscow, Russia, March 20, 2023. Russian Presidential Press Service/Handout via REUTERS ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY. NO RESALES. NO ARCHIVES. MANDATORY CREDIT.
A motorcade transporting members of the Chinese delegation, including President Xi Jinping, upon their arrival in Moscow, Russia, on March 20, 2023.

site_title: Protesters set rubbish on fire as French government barely survives no-confidence vote
summary: Protesters in central Paris set piles of rubbish on fire on March 20 after France's government narrowly survived a no-confidence vote on a deeply unpopular pension reform. The vote failed by a small margin, but the government's survival was seen as a relief. The proposed pension reform, which aims to raise the retirement age to 64, had sparked widespread protests and opposition. The outcome will allow the government to push forward with the legislation, despite the public's disapproval.

images.alt_text: Strikers blocking a motorway on Thursday; polls show that a majority of voters oppose President Emmanuel Macron’s plan to delay the state pension age by two years to 64.

site_title: Global water crisis needs accelerated action on all fronts
summary: The global water crisis is worsening, with billions lacking safe water, sanitation, and handwashing facilities, while climate change exacerbates water-related extremes. The World Water Day theme, "Accelerating Change," emphasizes the need for climate action to match or exceed the pace of climate change. The UN 2023 Water Conference aims to create a bold, whole-of-society approach to accelerate action across governments, businesses, and the public. Governments, businesses, and individuals must work together to ensure decision-makers understand the importance of sustainable water management, with a focus on water reuse, recycling, and awareness-raising efforts to empower people with knowledge.

images.alt_text: An aerial photo taken on June 20, 2022 showing flooded streets and buildings following heavy rains in Wuyuan, in China's central Jiangxi province.

The new rules by the administration of President Joe Biden would prevent nearly 584 million tons of pollutants from being released through coal plant wastewater each year, according to the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).

Waste collectors on polystyrene boats look for plastic and glass to recycle in Yangon's Pazundaung Creek. Dozens have taken to the creek's murky waters after being driven to find work by a post-coup economic crisis.

site_title: ECB’s Lagarde repeats wording on rate hike and Credit Suisse
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde reiterated her stance on rate hikes, stating the bank is monitoring market developments closely and ready to respond as necessary to preserve price stability and financial stability. She repeated her previous statement on Credit Suisse, welcoming swift action by Swiss authorities. The ECB's latest projections show inflation nearing the 2% target by 2025, but still above it.

images.alt_text: The ECB said the elevated level of uncertainty reinforces the importance of a data-dependent approach to the Governing Council’s policy rate decisions.

site_title: First Republic shares tumble again as liquidity worries linger
summary: First Republic Bank's shares have dropped 15% on Monday, extending a recent 80% decline, amid concerns over liquidity despite a $30 billion US rescue. The bank is in talks to raise capital from other banks or private equity firms, and S&P Global downgraded it into junk status. Shares of other regional banks rebounded, with some gaining significant ground, as a US official said deposit outflows had slowed. The market expects a conclusive resolution through an asset sale, with short sellers making a significant profit on paper since last Monday.

images.alt_text: S&P downgraded First Republic to junk on Wednesday, lowering its rating to BB+ from A-.

site_title: 'Dear friends' Xi and Putin meet in Moscow as Ukraine war rages
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping met with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Moscow, marking Xi's first trip since securing an unprecedented third term. The meeting aimed to deepen economic ties and promote Beijing's role as a potential peacemaker in the Ukraine conflict. Xi presented a 12-point proposal to solve the crisis, while Putin expressed admiration for China's economic development and cooperation in various fields. Despite Western pressure on Russia, Putin signed a "no limits" partnership with Xi, and the two leaders agreed to strengthen their relations.

images.alt_text: Russian President Vladimir Putin and Chinese President Xi Jinping attend a meeting at the Kremlin in Moscow, Russia, March 20, 2023. Russian Presidential Press Service/Handout via REUTERS ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY. NO RESALES. NO ARCHIVES. MANDATORY CREDIT.

site_title: Vietnam seizes 7 tonnes ivory in largest wildlife smuggling case in years
summary: Vietnamese authorities seized 7 tonnes of ivory smuggled from Angola, the largest wildlife smuggling case in years, hidden in a container declared as peanuts. The cargo transited via Singapore, following a similar 600kg ivory find last month at Haiphong City's Lach Huyen Port. The seizure comes after a court sentenced a man to 13 years in prison for trafficking nearly 10 tonnes of endangered animal parts from Africa. The investigation continues, highlighting the ongoing issue of wildlife trafficking in Vietnam despite the country's ban on ivory trade.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Ivory tusks are displayed after being seized by security forces at the port of Lome and set to be shipped to Vietnam, January 28, 2014. REUTERS/Noel Kokou Tadegnon/File Photo

site_title: Indonesia sets aside US$455 million to subsidise electric motorcycle sales
summary: Indonesia allocates US$455.88 million to subsidize the sale of electric motorcycles through 2024, aiming to increase the number of EVs on the road from nearly 32,000 to 1 million. The subsidies will cover 800,000 new electric motorcycles and 200,000 combustion engine conversions, with eligible vehicles meeting minimum local content requirements. The move is part of the government's plan to reduce fossil fuel consumption, develop EV production facilities, and take advantage of Indonesia's rich nickel reserves.

images.alt_text: Motorcyclists wait at a checkpoint in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Wednesday, Aug. 4, 2021. Southeast Asia’s largest economy has been topping the world’s tally of daily Covid-19 deaths as the delta variant spreads through the country and overwhelms its hospitals. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

site_title: Disagreement between Vibrant’s Khua and KTL’s Tan involved dealings of S$2.4 million
summary: Vibrant Group CEO Khua Kian Keong is facing charges for allegedly pushing former KTL Global executive Tan Tock Tan down stairs, causing a shoulder fracture. Khua had three dealings totaling S$2.4 million with Tan, including S$933,800 for shares in 2015. Khua claimed Tan owed him the money, which KTL Global had signed a subscription agreement for but failed to fulfill. A court ordered KTL Global to repay Khua the full amount on March 13.

site_title: Evercore’s bid to wind up Hwa Hong over S$8.7 million disputed fees dismissed
summary: Evercore Asia's bid to wind up Hwa Hong Corporation over disputed S$8.7 million fees was dismissed by Justice Hoo Sheau Peng. The court found triable issues with respect to the debt, requiring further determination by the court. Evercore must pay S$25,000 in legal costs to Hwa Hong. The dispute is part of a larger litigation involving Evercore, Hwa Hong, and four former directors over professional fees.

images.alt_text: Generic pix of the Supreme Court or High Court building on Jan 6, 2023.
Tay Peck Gek

site_title: Northern Ireland’s DUP lawmakers to vote against new Brexit deal
summary: Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) leader Jeffrey Donaldson announced that his party's members of the British parliament will vote against a key part of the government's Brexit deal, the "Stormont brake", which would allow Britain to stop new EU laws from applying to goods in Northern Ireland. The DUP cites the protocol's imposition of EU law as the fundamental issue, rather than the brake itself. This vote is set to take place later this week.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: DUP (Democratic Unionist Party) leader Sir Jeffrey Donaldson speaks as he launches the DUP election manifesto at a diesel generating set facility, in Craigavon, Northern Ireland, April 28, 2022. REUTERS/Clodagh Kilcoyne/File Photo

site_title: 850 compulsory retrenchment notices in 2023 so far; one quarter from tech: MOM
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) has received approximately 850 compulsory retrenchment notices in Singapore since the start of 2023, with around a quarter coming from the information and communications sector. About 65% of late submissions were made before the retrenchments took effect, allowing for employment assistance to be offered to affected employees. Employers who submitted notifications late are issued with caution letters.

images.alt_text: Generic photo on growing our economy and equipping our workers
Elysia Tan

site_title: Soilbuild seeks to overturn order to pay S$1 million to subcontractor
summary: Soilbuild Construction Group will apply to overturn an order from the Singapore Mediation Centre to pay S$1 million to its subcontractor, instead opting to pay the amount as security while pursuing further legal proceedings. The company had previously disagreed with the subcontractor's claim of S$1.28 million, which was lodged in February 2023. The outcome of this adjudication is expected to have a minimal impact on Soilbuild's financial position for the 2023 financial year.

images.alt_text: Myanmar was the first market that Soilbuild went into when it expanded overseas. It tapped into the lack of supply for high-end residential development project in Yangon and developed Rosehill Residences which was launched in 2015.
Janice Lim

site_title: Uncertainty reigns as Fed mulls whether to raise interest rates
summary: The Federal Reserve is uncertain about whether to raise interest rates amid turmoil in financial markets. Futures prices suggest a 65% probability of a quarter-percentage point rate hike, while economists are split on the decision. The Fed considers the risk of allowing inflation to become embedded versus aggravating a broader banking crisis. The central bank's meeting on Wednesday will be closely watched, with expectations ranging from a rate hike to a pause. Policymakers will weigh recent economic data, including inflation reports, and the impact of coordinated actions to ease funding stress in global markets.

images.alt_text: US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell has signaled a willingness to speed up interest rate hikes if needed.

site_title: Why this executive engineer also plans activities for children during work hours
summary: SP Group, Singapore's national grid operator, encourages its employees to volunteer their time and skills to benefit seniors, youth, and young children in need. Executive engineer Giles Ee, 28, carves out time from his work to plan activities for children, including a marine-themed play that was well-received by lower-income families. The company has contributed $2.1 million to benefit over 5,000 children and their families through its SP Kids at Heart initiative, which aims to enhance social mobility and lifelong outcomes for vulnerable children.

site_title: Riskiest bonds of Europe and Asian banks fall on Credit Suisse deal
summary: Credit Suisse's government-brokered takeover deal by UBS wiped out 16.3 billion Swiss francs of the bank's CoCo bonds, sparking a selloff in CoCo securities of other European banks. This has led to record declines in riskiest bonds of European lenders and Asian banks, with some posting historic losses. The deal has raised concerns about contagion risk, with funding costs for banks expected to increase. Investors are selling off riskier securities, including lower-rated issuers and down the capital stack.

images.alt_text: The logo of Credit Suisse bank is seen outside its office building in Hong Kong, China March 20, 2023. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu

site_title: UK financial watchdog slams poor disclosures by ESG benchmark compilers
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has criticized ESG benchmark compilers for poor disclosures to investors, stating that a preliminary review found significant shortcomings. The FCA warned that compilers must improve their disclosures to avoid punishment, including enforcement action. The regulator aims to crack down on greenwashing, or misleading climate-friendly claims, by tightening ESG rules. The FCA will conduct further work to address the issues and will take formal action if necessary.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage for the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA), the Britain's financial regulatory body, is seen at its head office in London, Britain, March 10, 2022. REUTERS/Toby Melville/File Photo

site_title: Philippines sees no significant impact from global banking crisis
summary: The Philippines' central bank, Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, expressed optimism that the global banking crisis won't significantly impact the local industry and economy. Governor Felipe Medalla stated that the crisis doesn't seem to affect the Philippines' Global Systemically Important Banks, and the country's banking system remains strong. The central bank has implemented reforms and has emergency loan facilities in place to address any liquidity conditions. Finance Secretary Benjamin Diokno also suggested that the BSP could opt for a narrower interest rate hike or keep policy settings unchanged due to global uncertainty.

images.alt_text: The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) revised its projection for the 2023 balance of payments deficit to US$1.6 billion, or 0.4 per cent of GDP, from US$5.4 billion, or 1.3 per cent of GDP.

site_title: Rising airline emissions could trigger global caps as early as 2024, warns trade group
summary: A top airline trade group, Iata, warns that rising airline emissions could trigger global emissions-related requirements as early as 2024 under the United Nations-led scheme, Corsia. The industry generates 3% of global emissions and is expected to rebound from the Covid-19 pandemic-induced slump. Airlines will start buying carbon offsets to meet emissions obligations, but critics argue that offsets do not lower actual emissions. The industry is also exploring alternative options, such as sustainable aviation fuel, which is in short supply and exorbitantly costly.

images.alt_text: Travelers prepare to board a passenger aircraft operated by Qantas Airways Ltd. at Sydney Airport in Sydney, Australia, on Wednesday, June 23, 2021. While losses at airlines globally from Covid-19 are set to surpass $174 billion by the end of 2021 -- wiping out half a decade of profits -- Qantas has become one of the most financially secure carriers anywhere in the world. Photographer: Brendon Thorne/Bloomberg

site_title: One multi-family office application, 200 single-family office tax incentive applications pending: Tharman
summary: Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam stated that one multi-family office (MFO) application and approximately 200 single-family office (SFO) tax incentive applications are pending approval. MFOs are regulated by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) like other fund managers, while SFOs, which manage assets belonging to only one family, are not subject to licensing in Singapore. The majority of SFOs apply for tax incentives on income derived from their investments managed in Singapore, and are subject to MAS requirements for money laundering and terrorism financing risks.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Lennon Lee, Partner, Financial Services Tax Leader, PwC Singapore.

According to EDB, the changes aim to encourage GIP investors to deploy more funds in the local financial system and generate more jobs for Singaporeans, including in the finance, tax, legal, and fund management fields.

site_title: Japan plans US$75 billion investment across Indo-Pacific to counter China
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announced a US$75 billion investment plan to promote an open and free Indo-Pacific region, aiming to counter China's growing assertiveness. The plan includes four pillars: maintaining peace, cooperation on global issues, global connectivity, and maritime safety. Japan pledged to expand cooperation with countries in the region and promote freedom of navigation, while increasing maritime defense and security among like-minded nations. The plan is seen as a bid to forge stronger ties with countries in South and Southeast Asia and to balance China's growing dominance.

images.alt_text: Australia and India, along with the US and Japan, are members of the so-called Quad – a group of democracies that have been ramping up security and economic ties to counter China’s growing influence.

site_title: US: Wall St opens mixed on bank fears, rate-hike pause hopes
summary: US stocks opened mixed on Monday as investors weighed a potential state-backed takeover of Credit Suisse and the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.03% to 31,872.33, while the S&P 500 opened higher by 0.02%. The Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.14% to 11,614.39. Investors are also monitoring the Federal Reserve's rate-hike pause hopes, which could influence market sentiment.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., March 6, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: SVB to be broken up and sold in two auctions
summary: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) has decided to break up Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) and hold two separate auctions for its traditional deposits unit and private bank. The FDIC will seek bids for the bridge bank until March 24 and for the private bank until March 22. This decision comes after the lender's failure to find a buyer and the parent company filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The FDIC is considering retaining some of the assets that are underwater, and the auctions are expected to attract bids from bank and non-bank financial firms.

site_title: China still seeking answers a year after plane crash
summary: China's aviation regulator said Monday they are still investigating the cause of the 2022 crash of China Eastern Airlines' Flight MU5735, which killed all 132 people on board. The Boeing 737-800 crashed into a mountainous region in Guangxi province on March 21, 2022, in China's deadliest aviation disaster in 28 years. Experts have inspected over 100 pieces of wreckage, and a final report could take two years or more to compile. The investigation is focusing on the actions of the crew and the performance of key components before the crash.

site_title: China to import 27 new video games, including Tencent, NetEase titles
summary: China's online gaming regulator approved 27 foreign games, including titles from Tencent, NetEase, and Bilibili, in its second batch of imports. This marks the end of a 18-month crackdown on the video game industry, which resumed issuing game licenses to homegrown games in April 2022. The approved games include "Merge Mansion," "Audition: Everybody Party," and "Shanyao! Youjunshaonu." The approval of foreign games is seen as a positive step for China's gaming industry, which had been halted since August 2021.

site_title: More Apac companies include ESG metrics in exec compensation: study
summary: A study by WTW found that 63% of companies in the Asia-Pacific region incorporate environmental, social, and governance (ESG) metrics into their executive compensation programs. The highest disclosure levels were seen in Japan, Australia, and Singapore, with over half of Singaporean companies using social metrics in their incentive plans. While this is lower than the global average of 75%, the study suggests that companies in the region are increasing their ESG commitments, particularly in areas like climate, human capital, and diversity.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Green infrastructures accounts for the largest share of an estimated US$3 trillion funding gap for climate mitigation in South-east Asia, according to Bain and Temasek.

site_title: Amazon to cut 9,000 jobs in second round of layoffs
summary: Amazon is cutting 9,000 jobs in its second round of layoffs, citing an uncertain economy as the reason for the cost and headcount cuts. The company added substantial staff in the past few years, but now aims to be more streamlined. The cuts will be concentrated in its cloud services, advertising, and Twitch units. This move follows other tech giants like Microsoft, Salesforce, Alphabet, and Meta Platforms, which have also slashed thousands of jobs in recent months. CEO Andy Jassy attributed the decision to the uncertain economy and the need to reduce costs.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) announced it will discontinue the Temporary Electricity Contracting Support Scheme (Trecs) on May 1, citing reduced volatility in global energy prices. Meanwhile, Credit Suisse's Singapore operations will continue with no interruptions after its takeover by UBS. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) stated that the takeover will not affect local banking stability. Additionally, MAS plans to set up an information-sharing platform to combat money laundering and a new bill will be introduced to facilitate such sharing.

site_title: Tesla’s vision of EVs without rare earths will spur magnet race
summary: Tesla's plan to remove rare earths from its electric vehicle motors has sent shockwaves through the industry, prompting a magnet "race" for alternatives. The company's use of ferrite magnets, made of iron and mixed with materials like barium and strontium, is seen as a potential solution. Other carmakers, including BMW and General Motors, have also sought to reduce reliance on rare earths. As demand for rare earths is forecast to surge, companies are racing to develop more efficient and cost-effective alternatives, with some already achieving comparable performance to rare earth-based systems.

site_title: Xi arrives in Moscow, giving Putin boost amid Ukraine invasion
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping arrived in Moscow on March 20, 2023, for talks with Russian President Vladimir Putin, aiming to broker an end to Russia's war in Ukraine. Xi's 12-point proposal, which has been met with skepticism by Ukraine and the US, includes calls for a ceasefire and increased economic cooperation. The visit is seen as a significant boost to Putin, who has faced international pressure over his invasion. The two leaders will hold talks and a state dinner, with Xi expected to deliver a strong message of support to Putin.

images.alt_text: Putin made a surprise trip to occupied Mariupol, the Ukrainian city largely destroyed by a months-long Russian siege

site_title: GoTo’s Q4 net loss widens to 19.5 trillion rupiah despite lift in profitability metrics
summary: GoTo Group, an Indonesian on-demand services company, reported a widening net loss of 19.5 trillion rupiah (S$1.7 billion) in its fourth quarter, despite improved profitability metrics. The company attributed the loss to non-cash factors, including goodwill impairment and restructuring costs. However, net revenue jumped 199% to 3.4 trillion rupiah, and adjusted loss improved 52% to 3.1 trillion rupiah. GoTo expects to reach positive adjusted earnings by the end of 2023, with its shares surging after the announcement.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Sea Limited founder Mr Forrest Li, who is taking over Singapore Premier League club Home United and privatising it to become Lion City Sailors.

site_title: BT correspondent bags Story of the Year award
summary: Wong Pei Ting, a Business Times correspondent, won the Story of the Year award for her June 2022 report on top university students in Singapore changing their preferred education or career tracks to courses in hot sectors such as data science and environmental sustainability. The report was one of the 20 most-read BT stories in June 2022 and was recognized for its data-driven approach, which validated a trend observed by the journalist. This is Wong's second win in two years, following last year's win by a senior correspondent for a report on the closure of Singapore's largest independent electricity retailer.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
BT senior correspondent bags Story of the Year prize for iSwitch scoop

site_title: Thailand’s DTGO said to weigh Singapore Reit IPO for US$609 million UK assets
summary: Thai conglomerate DTGO is considering listing its UK hospitality assets via a real estate investment trust (Reit) in Singapore, potentially raising £200 million (S$327.3 million). The UK assets, worth about £500 million, could be the second pound-denominated Reit IPO in Singapore, following Elite Commercial Reit's 2020 offering. The decision is at an early stage, and DTGO could still decide not to proceed with the IPO. The move would be much-needed for Singapore, which has seen only one IPO this year, raising just US$12.6 million.

site_title: Safe-haven yen rises as investors assess Credit Suisse rescue
summary: The yen surged against the US dollar as investors reacted to the Credit Suisse takeover, which included a significant write-down of US$17 billion in AT1 bonds. This move unnerved investors and led to a decline in Asian and European bank stocks. The yen rose to its lowest since February, with the US dollar falling to 130.96 yen, its lowest since February 10. Central banks bolstered confidence in the global banking system by offering currency swaps, and yields on US Treasury notes fell as investors moved into government bonds.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Banknotes of Japanese yen are seen in this illustration picture taken September 22, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Bank stocks fall on Credit Suisse, adding to US$1 trillion wipeout
summary: Bank stocks slumped on Monday after the historic takeover of Credit Suisse, wiping out a class of bondholders and adding to the US$1 trillion plunge in global financial shares. UBS' acquisition of Credit Suisse will erase the value of US$275 billion in bank funding, potentially causing a tailspin. The Stoxx Europe 600 Banks Index fell 1.6%, with 41 out of 44 bank stocks declining. The takeover raises concerns about the impact on international and regional banks, and the ripple effect on the bond and equity market.

images.alt_text: The government-brokered deal to rescue Credit Suisse wiped out 16.3 billion Swiss francs of the bank's CoCo bonds. This has sparked a selloff in CoCo securities of other banks.

site_title: Russian court freezes all Volkswagen assets in Russia
summary: A Russian court has frozen all Volkswagen assets in Russia, following a lawsuit by Russian auto manufacturer GAZ after Volkswagen terminated an agreement to produce vehicles in Russia. The move comes as Western countries imposed sanctions on Moscow over the conflict in Ukraine, leading to Volkswagen's suspension of operations in Russia. The court's decision freezes Volkswagen's assets in Russia, pending a resolution of the dispute.

site_title: China charges Tsinghua Unigroup’s former chairman with corruption
summary: China's anti-graft watchdog has charged the former chairman of Tsinghua Unigroup, Zhao Weiguo, with corruption and illegally earning profits for his friends and family. Zhao allegedly handed profitable businesses to relatives and friends, and purchased goods from associates at higher-than-market rates, causing significant losses to national interests. The Central Commission for Discipline Inspection made the charges, which are part of a broader effort to curb corruption within China's state-owned enterprises.

site_title: German producer prices rise more than expected in February
summary: Germany's producer prices rose 15.8% in February, exceeding expectations of a 14.5% increase, but marking the fifth consecutive month of easing inflation. This signals that inflation in Europe's largest economy may be slowing down. Compared to January, prices fell 0.3%, contrary to the expected 0.5% drop.

site_title: Indonesia’s GoTo has narrower adjusted loss after cost cuts bite
summary: Indonesia's GoTo Group reported a narrower adjusted loss of 3.1 trillion rupiah ($271 million) in the fourth quarter, down from 6.5 trillion rupiah a year earlier, due to extensive cost cuts. Net revenue tripled to 3.4 trillion rupiah, driven by resilient demand in South-east Asia. The company cut 600 roles from its workforce this month, adding to the 1,300 jobs it axed last year, and expects adjusted Ebitda to turn positive in the fourth quarter of 2023.

site_title: What financial crisis? US economy has investor backing, survey shows
summary: A survey of 519 retail and professional investors found that over 60% believe the Federal Reserve has not lost credibility, contradicting recent market trends. Despite the collapse of US banks and recession warnings, most respondents predict a soft landing for the US economy, with about two-thirds forecasting a favorable outcome. The survey suggests that the market's extreme reaction to the financial turmoil may be misplaced, with investors anticipating a still-strong US economy.

images.alt_text: The central banks will step up so-called swap line operations, which give non-US central banks greater access to dollars.

UBS will pay 3 billion Swiss francs (S$4.33 billion) for 167-year-old Credit  Suisse and assume up to US$5.4 billion in losses in a deal backed by a massive Swiss guarantee and expected to close by the end of 2023.

The collapse this month of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank prompted a flood of deposits out of regional lenders and into the nation’s largest banks, including JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America.

Repricing of credit risk followed the collapse of US tech lender Silicon Valley Bank and a crisis of confidence in Credit Suisse Group that tipped the Swiss lender’s investment-grade bonds into distress.

More than 23,000 investors, brokers, bankers and assorted hangers-on flocked to the French Rivera for the annual real estate conference last week, hopping between sponsored yachts and hotel suites and intending to pick over the few deals currently being shopped around.

site_title: Eurozone bond yields drop as contagion risk spooks investors
summary: EUROZONE government bond yields dropped on March 20 as investors spooked by the risk of a banking crisis, following UBS' deal to buy Credit Suisse. The Swiss central bank and other major central banks, including the Federal Reserve, teamed up to reassure markets by providing liquidity. UBS will pay 3 billion Swiss francs for Credit Suisse. This move aims to mitigate the contagion risk, leading to a decrease in bond yields, which have hit their lowest since mid-December 2022.

site_title: Indonesia central bank governor gets approval for new term from parliament body
summary: Indonesia's central bank governor, Perry Warjiyo, secured approval for a second term from a key parliamentary body, pledging to maintain a "pro-stability" monetary stance until 2024. Warjiyo has vowed to strengthen Bank Indonesia's policy mix to achieve price stability and support sustainable economic growth. He has also set a new inflation target range of 1.5-3.5% and reaffirmed interest rate hikes sufficient to guide inflation back to target later this year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Indonesia's Central Bank Governor Perry Warjiyo arrives for a media briefing at Bank Indonesia headquarters in Jakarta, Indonesia, January 19, 2023. REUTERS/Ajeng Dinar Ulfiana/File Photo

site_title: Stunned Credit Suisse staff fear uncertain future despite UBS rescue deal
summary: Credit Suisse staff fear an uncertain future after the Swiss bank agreed to a state-backed rescue deal with UBS, with shares plummeting 60% in early trade. The deal, worth $4.3 billion, caps a week of market tension and angering bondholders by writing down debts to zero. With 50,000 employees globally, staff are worried about job security and the impact on business operations, with some clients potentially moving assets to other banks.

images.alt_text: A view of a Credit Suisse signage at an office in Singapore March 20, 2023. REUTERS/Edgar Su

site_title: Shoe recycling farce: Traders of second-hand textiles, shoes excluded from process chain
summary: Singapore's shoe recycling initiative, launched by US petrochemical giant Dow and Sport Singapore, has been compromised after shoes were diverted for resale in Indonesia. To address the issue, the government has taken remedial steps, including appointing only contractors and subcontractors not involved in second-hand trading of textiles or shoes, conducting regular spot checks, and transporting collected shoes without aggregation or sorting. Minister Edwin Tong assured that the project is "running well" and 10,000 kilograms of shoes have been processed, with plans to use the remaining recycled shoe granules in public sports facilities.

images.alt_text: Empty bins for a shoe recycling program, a joint project sponsored by Dow and the Singapore government, are seen outside a warehouse owned by Yok Impex, a Singaporean textile and shoe trader, where 10 of the original 11 pairs of shoes were traced to before leaving Singapore's borders for Indonesia, in Singapore, Jan 6, 2023.
Wong Pei Ting

site_title: Change makes fools of us all
summary: US banking crisis reflects changes in interest rates, regulation, and the digital age. Silicon Valley Bank's collapse is linked to the long era of low interest rates, which regulators struggled to address even with the Dodd-Frank Act intact. The collapse is also attributed to bank managers' failure to hedge against rising interest rates, mid-sized banks' lobbying for exemptions, venture capitalists' panic, and the Federal Reserve's delayed response to inflation. The author suggests that change makes fools of us all, and that multiple factors, including technological and economic shifts, contributed to the crisis.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An employee holds the door open at the Silicon Valley Bank branch office in downtown San Francisco, California, U.S., March 13, 2023. REUTERS/Kori Suzuki/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: A customer is escorted into the Silicon Valley Bank headquarters in Santa Clara, California, U.S., March 13, 2023. REUTERS/Brittany Hosea-Small/File Photo

site_title: It’s the banking regulations, stupid
summary: The failure of Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) is attributed to fundamental flaws in the prevailing governance framework, specifically the requirement of a razor-thin capital cushion and the assumption of solvency on a held-to-maturity basis. SVB's capital was insufficient to cover its $15 billion loss on $86 billion in residential mortgage-backed securities, and the bank's regulators allowed it to leverage its capital more than tenfold. The failure highlights the need for a more robust understanding of banking regulation and the correction of outdated regulatory frameworks, rather than simply doubling down on existing regulations.

images.alt_text: SVB might have maintained the confidence of its depositors if it had actively managed its assets and shored up its equity base when the Fed began raising rates a year ago
The Federal Reserve (Fed) has promised to investigate how it supervised SVB Financial Group’s Silicon Valley Bank, now the second-biggest failure of a US lender in history.
SVB’s collapse is inseparable from the long era of low interest rates.

site_title: Signature Bank’s crypto business wasn’t part of takeover deal
summary: Signature Bank's crypto business will not be part of the takeover deal with Flagstar Bank. The FDIC will return about $4 billion of deposits related to Signature's digital assets business to customers directly. The Signet real-time payments network, used by crypto participants, will remain under the FDIC's control and be subject to a later arrangement. This move aims to facilitate the transfer of traditional currencies for crypto platforms and investors affected by the shutdown of Silvergate Capital and Signature Bank.

images.alt_text: Signage outside a Signature Bank branch in New York. Photographer: Stephanie Keith/Bloomberg

site_title: Taiwan central bank says raising rates could help curb inflation expectations
summary: Taiwan's deputy central bank governor, Yen Tzung-ta, stated that raising interest rates could help curb inflation expectations, despite an aversion to raising rates during export downturns. The current inflation wave is expected to continue, with absolute levels remaining high. Taiwan's economy, driven by semiconductor production, has shrunk 0.41% in the fourth quarter due to global consumer demand and the economic effects of the Ukraine war. The central bank is considering a rate change, but economists expect it to keep the policy interest rate unchanged at its upcoming meeting.

images.alt_text: Cars drive past Taiwan's central bank in Taipei, Taiwan, December 14, 2022. REUTERS/Ann Wang

site_title: Shazam! sequel tops N America box office but lacks magic
summary: Shazam! Fury of the Gods topped the North American box office with an estimated $30.5 million opening, but this represents a sharp drop-off from the original Shazam!'s $53.5 million opening. The sequel, which cost over $110 million to make, has received tepid reviews. Analysts consider the result disappointing, with one calling it "one of the worst starts for a major Hollywood superhero film". The film's poor opening is a contrast to the original's success, raising questions about the sequel's potential.

images.alt_text: "Scream VI" starring (from left) Melissa Barrera and Jenna Ortega took in an estimated US$44.5 miilion at the North America box office.

site_title: European banks battered in early trade after Credit Suisse rescue
summary: European banks suffered significant losses on Monday, with Credit Suisse shares plummeting over 63% and UBS Group shares down 12.9%. The historic state-backed rescue of Credit Suisse by UBS, backed by a coordinated central bank effort, led to the market volatility. An index of bank stocks fell 5.8% at 0821 GMT, as investors reacted to the unprecedented move.

site_title: Probe into Lee Hsien Yang and wife made public as they had absconded, among other reasons: Shanmugam
summary: Home Affairs and Law Minister K Shanmugam disclosed that a police investigation into Lee Hsien Yang and wife Lee Suet Fern was made public as they absconded after being found to have lied under oath during judicial proceedings. The couple was investigated for their role in handling the last will of Singapore's founding prime minister, Lee Kuan Yew. Shanmugam stated that disclosing the investigation was in the public interest, as the couple's conduct was already a matter of public record. The police will continue to investigate, and the couple has the right to provide explanations if they decide to cooperate.

site_title: Sweden’s teens drive Porsches and BMWs, no licence needed
summary: In Sweden, teenagers aged 15 and older can drive modified cars without a driver's license, as long as the vehicle's speed is limited to 30 km/h. This is made possible by an almost century-old regulation, known as an "A-traktor" or "EPA", which originated from agricultural vehicles. The practice has gained popularity, but authorities are concerned about the rise in road accidents. Experts are urging caution, but the Swedish teens' love for fast cars remains a topic of interest, with many customizing their vehicles to drive without proper licensing.

images.alt_text: 22-year-old Oskar (R) and his brother, 19-year-old Jakob Flyman, work in their garage, specializing in converting regular cars into A Traktors, on February 28, 2023, in Balsta, northwest of Stockholm, Sweden. - Too young for a driver's licence at 15, Evelina Christiansen is already cruising in a sleek BMW in Sweden, where teens can drive any car modified to roll no faster than a golf cart. An almost century-old regulation originally applied to agricultural vehicles allows kids 15 and older to drive without a proper driver's licence, providing the vehicle has been altered to have a maximum speed of 30 kilometres per hour (18.6 miles per hour). Called an "A-traktor" -- with Swedes often using the older designation EPA -- these cars and trucks have become so popular in recent years that authorities are now concerned about a rise in road accidents. (Photo by Jonathan NACKSTRAND / AFP)

site_title: CPF nominations are treated the same as wills and hence not revoked upon divorce: Tan See Leng
summary: Singapore's CPF (Central Provident Fund) nominations, which determine who receives savings upon death, are not revoked upon divorce, Minister for Manpower Tan See Leng stated. Similar to wills, these nominations are considered valid and will be honored even after a divorce, as the CPF member may still intend to provide for their ex-spouse and children from the marriage. This policy aims to ensure the continued support of the CPF member's loved ones.

images.alt_text: CPFboard.jpg

site_title: Thailand dissolves parliament, election in May
summary: Thailand's parliament has been dissolved ahead of an election in May, which will reignite a long-running power struggle between a military-backed establishment and a political movement dominated by the Shinawatra family. The election, set for May 14, will choose members of parliament, with the winner expected to become prime minister by the end of July. The opposition Pheu Thai party's Paetongtarn Shinawatra is leading in opinion surveys, with her support jumping 10 points. The move is seen as a return of political decision-making power to the people, with the King as head of state.

images.alt_text: Paetongtarn garnered 38.2 per cent of support in a poll of 2,000. Her approval jumped from 34 per cent in the previous poll conducted in December.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall on banking sector uncertainty; STI down 1.4%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 1.4% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) losing 43.52 points to close at 3,139.76 points. The decline was attributed to uncertainty in the banking sector, particularly in the US and Europe. Local lenders DBS, UOB, and OCBC all suffered losses, while Hongkong Land and Emperador were the only two gainers. The market's cautious environment was reflected in the 407 to 194 loss-gain ratio, with 1.5 billion securities worth S$1.2 billion changing hands.

images.alt_text: ST20230303_202311925234 Kua Chee Siong/ pixgeneric/ Generic pix of the SGX logo at SGX Centre 1 located along Shenton Way on March 3, 2023.
Jude Chan

site_title: US and other G7 members oppose Japan’s push for fossil fuel investment
summary: The US and other G7 members have opposed Japan's proposal to invest in fossil fuels and deploy technologies to support their use for power generation. Officials from the US and UK have questioned the lack of a deadline for phasing out coal and a more ambitious plan to eliminate fossil fuels in the power sector. Japan's draft communique, seen as a potential draft of a G7 statement, has been revised amid ongoing negotiations, with concerns over the environmental and economic impacts of using hydrogen and ammonia to curb emissions.

images.alt_text: “The declining birthrate problem is a fight against time,” Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida said.
Japan said it plans to ease licensing requirements on  essential ingredients for the manufacture of displays and semiconductors that go into gadgets, including Apple iPhones.

site_title: Credit Suisse deal hands Saudi National Bank US$1 billion investment loss
summary: Credit Suisse's top shareholder, Saudi National Bank, has seen its US$1 billion investment in the troubled Swiss lender plummet in value to about US$439 million following the UBS acquisition offer. The bank's 9.9% stake in Credit Suisse is now valued at 304 million Swiss francs, a significant loss for the Riyadh-based lender. This marks one of the biggest losses among the saga that led to UBS' acquisition of Credit Suisse.

images.alt_text: The German share price index DAX graph is pictured at the stock exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, November 25, 2022.    REUTERS/Staff
In a package orchestrated by Swiss regulators on Sunday, UBS will pay 3 billion Swiss francs (S$4.33 billion) for 167-year-old Credit Suisse and assume up to US$5.4 billion in losses.

site_title: Pinduoduo owner’s revenue falls short on weak consumer spending
summary: Pinduoduo, a Chinese e-commerce platform, reported revenue of 39.82 billion yuan for the fourth quarter, falling short of estimates of 41.01 billion yuan. The company's revenue growth, 46% year-on-year, was driven by a weak consumer spending environment in China, where post-reopening consumer recovery remains patchy. PDD's shares fell 7% in premarket trading, while competitors Alibaba and JD.com reported single-digit gains for the same period. The company's international platform Temu saw a significant increase in gross merchandise value to US$192 million in January.

site_title: Switzerland wakes up to new era after historic bank merger; employees ‘shocked‘
summary: Switzerland's Credit Suisse has been taken over by UBS in a government-brokered rescue, marking a new era for the country's banking expertise. The deal, worth 3 billion Swiss francs, comes after customer and market confidence in Credit Suisse evaporated. Combined assets of the two banks hold up to 140% of Swiss GDP, and UBS will assume up to $5.4 billion in losses. The Swiss Bank Employees Association has expressed shock and demanded that job cuts be minimized.

images.alt_text: In a package orchestrated by Swiss regulators on Sunday, UBS will pay 3 billion Swiss francs (S$4.33 billion) for 167-year-old Credit Suisse and assume up to US$5.4 billion in losses.

site_title: Israel’s Netanyahu softens judicial overhaul after Biden call
summary: Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced a softening of the hard-right government's judicial overhaul plan, following a call from US President Joe Biden. Most of the reforms will be shelved until the legislature reconvenes on April 30, amid nationwide protests and concerns from Western allies. The revised bill would still limit the power of judges in selecting nominees to the bench, but with a more balanced composition and fewer potential government clouts. Netanyahu's office assured Biden that Israel's democracy is healthy, and the move is seen as an attempt to calm the constitutional crisis and avoid further escalation.

images.alt_text: epa10531470 Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu attends a weekly cabinet meeting in the prime minister's office in Jerusalem, 19 March 2023. Nationwide protests against the government's judicial reform plans are being held for eleven weeks in a row. Israel's parliament passed a draft law limiting the power of the Israeli Supreme Court in a first reading on 14 March.  EPA-EFE/ABIR SULTAN / POOL

site_title: Petroleum, LNG products boost Malaysia’s February exports; nearly 10% growth exceeds forecasts
summary: Malaysia's February exports exceeded forecasts with a 9.8% year-on-year increase to RM112.3 billion, driven by double-digit growth in petroleum, LNG, and electrical and electronic products. The country's total trade rose 11% year-on-year to RM205 billion, while the trade surplus decreased 1.3% to RM19.6 billion, surpassing economists' projections of 4.5% growth.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's exports rose 1.6 per cent from a year earlier in January, slower than expected, government data showed on Monday.

site_title: Chevron suspends production at Thai oil field
summary: Chevron has suspended production at its Benchamas oil field in the Gulf of Thailand following an accident last week that killed one crew member. The incident occurred when seawater leaked into an oil storage vessel. Chevron's focus is on responding to the incident, not restarting production, and preparations are underway to return the body of the fatally injured crew member to the victim's family. The oil field's production remains offline, with no timeline provided for its resumption.

site_title: Hedge funds that bet on Credit Suisse rescue face uneven results
summary: Hedge funds that invested in Credit Suisse's bonds before its rescue deal with UBS are facing uneven results. The funds, which specialize in buying bonds from companies on the brink of bankruptcy, bought Credit Suisse's ordinary bonds at a 40% loss and its AT1 bonds at a 60% loss. However, some of these bonds have since risen sharply, with the AT1 bonds trading at a 20-cent-on-the-dollar price.
