The deal, which includes wiping out AT1 bondholders, is seen as a "lottery ticket" for some investors, with UBS adding $16 billion of equity to support the takeover.

images.alt_text: The German share price index DAX graph is pictured at the stock exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, November 25, 2022.    REUTERS/Staff

Signage for Credit Suisse Group AG outside a building in Hong Kong, China, on Friday, March 17, 2023. The $54 billion lifeline won by Credit Suisse on Thursday gives it a fighting chance to rebuild its business. Some clients aren't waiting around to find out how that goes. Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg
The government-brokered deal to rescue Credit Suisse wiped out 16.3 billion Swiss francs of the bank's CoCo bonds. This has sparked a selloff in CoCo securities of other banks.

site_title: Asia better placed than developed economies, Morgan Stanley says
summary: Morgan Stanley analysts say Asian economies are better equipped to handle a global banking crisis, citing strong liquidity and stable debt-to-GDP ratios. Unlike developed economies, Asia's domestic demand is expected to remain robust, reducing the downside risk to growth. Analysts predict some tightening in lending standards in Asia but expect it to be less intense than in the US. The growth impact on Asia will depend on the US economy's evolution, with two possible scenarios: a mild recession or a hard landing, both of which will have less severe effects on Asia.

images.alt_text: Phillip Securities is positive on Singapore banks and maintains its  "overweight" rating on the sector.

Hong Kong’s banking sector was in a healthy liquidity position, the authority said, with the average Liquidity Coverage Ratio for major institutions at 162.3 per cent in Q4 2022, well above the 100 per cent minimum requirement.
MAS says it will remain in close contact with Finma, Credit Suisse and UBS as the takeover is executed.

site_title: Achieving contentment is the biggest gain
summary: A wealth advisory expert celebrates 25 years in the industry, reflecting on his philosophy of "sufficiency," which emphasizes contentment and prioritizing what truly matters. He argues that investing in riskier assets in pursuit of higher returns is unnecessary, as evidence-based instruments can generate reliable long-term returns. By focusing on what's truly important, individuals can achieve peace of mind and make better financial decisions, rather than being driven by the need to accumulate wealth. This approach is seen as counter-cultural in the wealth management industry, but the expert believes it leads to the greatest gain.

images.alt_text: Back in 1973, the idea of spreading all your investment dollars across the entire market, instead of picking winners, seemed like crazy talk.
Positive returns do not necessarily mean you have accumulated enough for retirement.

site_title: Malaysia Subang Airport’s revamp plan to be finalised by end-June
summary: Malaysia's Transport Minister Anthony Loke announced that the redevelopment plan for Subang International Airport will be finalized by the end of June, instead of April, due to technical issues. The plan aims to upgrade the airport into a premium regional city airport. The collaboration between Malaysia Airports Holdings and WCT Holdings, the operator of Subang Skypark terminal, is also being delayed. Loke expressed disappointment over KLIA's ranking of 67th in the World Airport Survey, but remains confident that the airport can become one of the top 10 in the future.

images.alt_text: Capital A CEO Tony Fernandes (from right) and the company’s chief airport and customer experience officer Kesavan Sivanandam as well as AirAsia CEO Bo Lingam at the launching ceremony of the new AI-powered concierge “Ask Bo”.

site_title: From greens to browns: Burkina Faso’s eco-friendly golf course
summary: Burkina Faso's Ouagadougou Golf Club is a pioneer in water conservation in golf, featuring earth, stones, and sinewy shrubs as fairways instead of manicured lawns. Founded in 1975, the club boasts three certified golf courses and is certified by the French golf federation. This eco-friendly approach brings a unique aspect to the country, which is typically known for turmoil, suffering, and poverty. The club's innovative approach showcases the potential for golf to promote water conservation and sustainability.

images.alt_text: Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong (seventh from right) at the official opening of Keppel Club at Sime Road on March 18, 2023. On his right is Transport Minister S Iswaran.

Using geolocation data near golf courses in the United States, a Stanford study found there was 278 per cent more people playing golf at 4pm on a Wednesday in August 2022 than in August 2019. And there were 83 per cent more golf games being played on a weekday in August 2022 than in August 2019.
Jayaprakash Jagateesan (second from right), the group CEO of AlDigi Group, a member of ONERHT.

site_title: In the face of high home rentals, consider growing a build-to-rent segment
summary: Singapore's high home rentals, which rose 29.7% in 2022, may not require heavy government intervention. However, the rapid increase can hurt young adults trying to secure a home, singles below 35, and foreigners who may choose not to pursue education or job opportunities here due to high costs. A build-to-rent (BTR) segment in the private housing market could provide more choice and competitive rates, benefiting home renters and investors alike. The government could consider selling sites for BTR projects, potentially exempting developers from Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD).

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee

List Sotheby’s International Realty’s senior associate vice-president Steve Tay believes that 2023 will be a record year for rental markets, with demand continuing to be strong as China reopens its borders and more foreigners, especially from North Asia, decide to set up a base in Singapore.
The practice of agents taking a commission from their tenants has become the norm - at least for now - and mostly involves corporate clients and foreigners who are new to Singapore.

Rents for the condo market climbs 1.4 per cent in January from December 2022, while HDB rental prices rise 0.6 per cent from the month before, according to flash estimates from SRX and 99.co on Tuesday (Feb 28).

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks hit 3-month low on bank contagion fears; China ends down
summary: Hong Kong's benchmark Hang Seng Index plummeted 2.7% to its lowest close since early December, driven by banking stocks amid concerns of risk contagion. A government-orchestrated acquisition of Credit Suisse by UBS failed to ease fears after the bank's collapse sent Asian shares lower. China stocks also declined, with the CSI300 Index losing 0.5%, despite Beijing's fresh monetary-easing measures to support economic growth. Hong Kong-listed banking stocks tumbled, with HSBC's shares dropping 6% and Standard Chartered's shares falling 7%.

site_title: MAS to set up information-sharing platform to combat money laundering under new Bill
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is set to establish an information-sharing platform, named Cosmic, to combat money laundering and other illicit financial activities. The Financial Services and Markets (Amendment) Bill, introduced in Parliament, empowers MAS to create and maintain the electronic system. The platform will allow financial institutions to share information on customers who show suspicious behavior, enhancing efforts to prevent and detect money laundering, terrorism financing, and the financing of proliferation of weapons of mass destruction.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
MAS to roll out platform requiring information-sharing among banks in 2023 to fight money laundering
MAS reiterates the hazards of cryptocurrency trading for the general public in its response to queries on FTX's operations in Singapore.
The proposed amendments will also allow for polling stations to be set up in adjacent electoral divisions, to make it more convenient for voters who stay near an electoral boundary.

site_title: EMA to stop temporary electricity scheme from May 1 as volatility eases
summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) of Singapore announced it will discontinue the Temporary Electricity Contracting Support Scheme (Trecs) on May 1 due to reduced energy price volatility. Global energy prices have become less volatile, and more long-term retail contracts are available to large consumers. Consumers on Trecs or wholesale electricity prices are encouraged to consider retail contracts for greater price certainty. EMA will build on lessons from the energy crisis to introduce enhancements, including institutionalizing crisis management measures and strengthening consumer protection.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

Power pact: Keppel Infrastructure CEO Cindy Lim and Royal Group Power chairman Neak Okhna Kith Meng display the power purchase and export agreement that was signed on Wed (Mar 15). Singapore government to build power generation capacity if tenders draw insufficient interest

site_title: Singapore’s Lucence secures US Medicare approval for its cancer tests
summary: Lucence, a Singapore-based biotech startup, has secured US Medicare approval for its cancer tests, marking the first time an Asian healthcare services provider has received national insurance approval in the US. The approval allows Medicare to reimburse patients for using Lucence's blood test, LiquidHallmark, to detect lung cancer. The test, which profiles 80 genes across 15 cancers, can aid in personalized cancer treatment. The approval is seen as a significant milestone for Lucence, with CEO Dr. Tan Min-Han stating it opens doors for the company to be considered by other insurance providers in the US.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Companies like Moderna are examples of  investments in companies that can build their solutions around long-term trends and enduring behaviours.
Small drug developers without any approved products on the market were forced to cut costs by dropping some drug study programmes and implementing layoffs as funding dried up.

site_title: Mercedes set to invest billions in e-vehicles plants
summary: Mercedes plans to invest billions in electric vehicle production, aiming to switch to electric cars by the end of this decade. The company will modernize its plants in China, Germany, and Hungary, with investments including a three-digit million amount per plant and a low single-digit billion dollar sum for painting system upgrades. The investments will focus on cutting energy and water consumption, and reliance on gas. Mercedes is also considering expanding its US plant in Tuscaloosa, where it can benefit from government subsidies.

images.alt_text: A new version of Volkswagen’s flagship ID.3 electric car model will go on sale from the end of March for just under 40,000 euros.

site_title: Hong Kong banking sector exposure to Credit Suisse ‘insignificant’: monetary authority
summary: Hong Kong's banking sector has "insignificant" exposure to Credit Suisse, according to the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, with total assets of the Swiss bank in Hong Kong totaling around HK$100 billion (S$17 billion). The exposure represents less than 0.5% of the total assets of the Hong Kong banking sector. The exposure does not pose a risk to the stability of the Hong Kong financial system, with the banking sector maintaining a healthy liquidity position, exceeding the 100% minimum requirement. The exposure is also not significant enough to trigger a wider international banking crisis.

images.alt_text: More than 23,000 investors, brokers, bankers and assorted hangers-on flocked to the French Rivera for the annual real estate conference last week, hopping between sponsored yachts and hotel suites and intending to pick over the few deals currently being shopped around.

site_title: Bank of Japan debated side-effects of easy policy, room for more steps: March meeting summary
summary: The Bank of Japan maintained its ultra-loose policy at its March meeting, with many board members agreeing to sustain massive stimulus to achieve the 2% inflation target. However, some members expressed concerns over lingering distortions in the yield curve and the need to improve market functions. The central bank will continue to monitor the effects of its bond yield control policy and be prepared to take further steps if necessary.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians walk in front of the Bank of Japan (BoJ) head office building (C) in Tokyo on April 27, 2022. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)

site_title: Credit Suisse’s 9,000 job cuts are foretaste of UBS takeover
summary: Credit Suisse has undergone a government-brokered takeover by UBS Group, which is expected to result in significant job cuts, potentially in the tens of thousands. The combined entity plans to cut its annual cost base by over $8 billion by 2027. UBS chairman Colm Kelleher stated that the investment bank will be downsized, likely ending plans for a CS First Boston spinoff. Credit Suisse's management will remain in place until the deal closes, after which their future will be decided by UBS.

images.alt_text: UBS Group over the weekend agreed to buy Credit Suisse.

site_title: Taiwan chip exports to China sputter on tensions, falling demand
summary: Taiwan's exports of integrated circuit (IC) chips to China and Hong Kong fell 31.3% in February, the worst decline since 2009, due to Washington-Beijing tensions and cooling demand. The decline was attributed to US efforts to restrict China's access to advanced chipmaking machinery. Total semiconductors shipped worldwide declined 17.3%, while exports to the US rose 22.3%. Taiwan's chip production has bolstered its economy, but demand for advanced technology has cooled rapidly.

images.alt_text: Ma will visit China from Mar 27 to Apr 7, and go to the cities of Nanjing, Wuhan, Changsha, Chongqing and Shanghai.

site_title: UBS CEO warns staff Credit Suisse ‘is still our competitor’
summary: UBS CEO Ralph Hamers has warned staff not to discuss business matters with Credit Suisse employees until the deal closes, citing Credit Suisse as a competitor. UBS is paying 3 billion francs for Credit Suisse, described as an "emergency rescue" to address client outflows and a massive market rout. The deal supports UBS's growth ambitions in the Americas and Asia-Pacific, and is expected to be completed by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: The two lenders together employed almost 125,000 people at the end of last year.

Hong Kong’s banking sector was in a healthy liquidity position, the authority said, with the average Liquidity Coverage Ratio for major institutions at 162.3 per cent in Q4 2022, well above the 100 per cent minimum requirement.
MAS says it will remain in close contact with Finma, Credit Suisse and UBS as the takeover is executed.

site_title: India to splurge 980 billion rupees on airports as travel rebounds
summary: India plans to invest 980 billion rupees (S$15.94 billion) in airports over two years to boost capacity to 220 airports by 2025, aiming to meet growing travel demand. Existing airports are running out of parking and landing slots, and the country wants to be a powerhouse in air transport. India aims to have more than 90 carbon-neutral airports by 2024, but experts warn that large-scale infrastructure projects could increase emissions and air pollution, costing the country US$95 billion annually.

images.alt_text: Air India’s Boeing 787-8 Dreamliner at Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj International Airport in Mumbai.Photographer: Indranil Aditya/Bloomberg

site_title: New York Community Bancorp to pursue deal for Signature Bank
summary: New York Community Bancorp is pursuing a deal to acquire failed Signature Bank, with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation potentially announcing the acquisition as soon as this week. Signature Bank, like Silicon Valley Bank, had a deposit base mostly uninsured and was under investigation by regulators due to its work with crypto clients. An acquisition by NYCB could be a significant undertaking, potentially surpassing $100 billion in assets and triggering tougher regulatory requirements.

images.alt_text: The FDIC is aiming to sell both SVB and Signature in their entirety, while offers for parts of the banks could be considered if whole company sales do not happen.
Silicon Valley Bank’s fall last week was the biggest US bank failure in more than a decade.
Signage outside a Signature Bank branch in New York. Photographer: Stephanie Keith/Bloomberg

site_title: Credit Suisse tells staff bonuses will still be paid, go to work
summary: Credit Suisse has assured staff that promised bonuses and pay increases will still be paid, despite a takeover by UBS Group. The bank will maintain "business as usual" and has confirmed no changes to payroll arrangements. Bonuses will be paid on March 24, with no expected changes for remaining jurisdictions. The takeover is part of a government-brokered deal to contain a crisis of confidence in global financial markets.

images.alt_text: A Credit Suisse Group AG logo at a bank branch in Zurich, Switzerland, on Sunday, March 19, 2023. Swiss authorities plan to change the country’s laws to bypass a shareholder vote on the transaction as they rush to finalize a deal before Monday. Photographer: Pascal Mora/Bloomberg

site_title: Stocks to watch: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, Golden Energy, Ho Bee Land, EC World Reit
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's unit has been ordered by Singapore's High Court to wind up, but the company claims it won't impact its operations or financial condition. Golden Energy and Resources raised its exit offer price by 13% after criticism from minority investors. ComfortDelGro's subsidiary acquired a UK-based private hire company, while Ho Bee Land sold industrial assets worth S$115 million. EC World Reit's lenders agreed to extend the deadline for its outstanding loans to April 30.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim

site_title: Investors punish UBS after Credit Suisse rescue
summary: UBS shares plummeted 16% on Monday, the largest one-day fall since 2008, after its weekend rescue of struggling rival Credit Suisse. UBS agreed to buy Credit Suisse for 3 billion Swiss francs, with a hefty backstop from Swiss authorities. The deal has raised concerns among investors about long-term benefits, with Credit Suisse shares sliding 60% and its AT1 bonds valued at just $0.01. Analysts predict that UBS can extract value from the acquisition, but the deal's impact on other European banks remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: A sign above an entrance to the UBS Group AG headquarters in Zurich, Switzerland, on Tuesday, April 19, 2022. UBS increased pay for junior bankers in the U.S. for a second time in less than a year, bringing the Swiss lender in line with Wall Street rivals trying to stem defections amid a race for talent. Photographer: Pascal Mora/Bloomberg

site_title: First Republic downgraded by S&P for the second time in a week
summary: S&P Global downgraded First Republic Bank to junk, lowering its rating to B+ from A-, citing concerns over the bank's ability to stabilize deposits and recover franchise value. The downgrade follows a $30 billion uninsured deposit by the 11 largest US banks. Moody's also cut the bank's rating to below investment grade. The rating firm warns that attracting meaningful deposits will be difficult, constraining the bank's business position.

site_title: Gold prices drop 1% after Credit Suisse-UBS deal spurs risk-on mood
summary: Gold prices dropped 1% on Monday after a risk-on mood improved following the deal between Swiss lenders UBS and Credit Suisse, which aimed to stabilize global financial markets. The safe-haven appeal of gold decreased, leading to a decline in spot gold to $1,969.14 per ounce. The deal also led to a rise in US futures and a decrease in Asian stocks. Meanwhile, US futures rose 0.2% and Asian stocks steadied despite contagion fears.

images.alt_text: Gold is considered a hedge against economic uncertainties, and tends to gain on expectations of lower interest rates, which reduce the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

site_title: Asia: Stocks drop despite Credit Suisse buyout, central banks’ pledge
summary: Asian stocks fell despite Credit Suisse's buyout, with Hong Kong's HSBC dropping 4% and other regional markets following suit. The decline came amid concerns over the financial sector, sparked by the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank, Signature Bank, and Silvergate. Central banks pledged to provide liquidity to troubled lenders, while Wall Street titans injected $30 billion into under-pressure First Republic Bank. The US Federal Reserve is set to meet this week, with speculation that it may pause interest rate hikes to provide stability to markets.

images.alt_text: Singapore stocks opened higher on Monday

site_title: Xi’s embrace of Putin dents his chances of playing peacemaker on Ukraine
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping's upcoming visit to Moscow will likely be seen as a show of support for Vladimir Putin, despite his efforts to broker an end to the Russian war in Ukraine. Xi's "rock solid" backing of Putin may make it harder for him to be taken seriously as a mediator, with Ukraine's allies dismissing his vague peace proposals. The visit comes as tensions between the US and China have spiked, and Putin has made a surprise trip to occupied Mariupol, where he plans to meet with Xi and discuss energy and arms trade.

images.alt_text: Russian President Vladimir Putin, flanked by Sevastopol Governor Mikhail Razvozhayev (left), and Metropolitan Tikhon Shevkunov (right), chairman of the Patriarchal Council for Culture, as he visits the Chersonesos Taurica historical and archeological park during a visit to Crimea on the ninth anniversary of its annexation by Russia from Ukraine.

site_title: Used car sales down 7.7% in first two months of 2023, new car registration falls 23.8%
summary: Used car sales dropped 7.7% in the first two months of 2023, with 1,143 cars sold, compared to 1,224 in 2022. New car registrations fell 23.8% during the same period. Dealerships are not in a hurry to buy used cars due to sufficient inventory, and some are registering brand-new cars to meet demand, driving up COE premiums. This practice may artificially inflate COE prices, as pre-registered cars are often unused for months before being sold.

images.alt_text: At S$91,101, the premium for commercial vehicle COE – applicable for vans, trucks and lorries – was 3.8 per cent higher than the S$87,790 posted a fortnight ago.

site_title: UK foreign policy needs to regain relevance
summary: The UK's foreign policy has lost relevance, with the government's recent strategy release failing to address gaps in defence capabilities, undermining the country's NATO contribution. The UK's post-Brexit relationships with the EU, China, and the US are also uncertain, with a need for greater strategic clarity. The country's historical influence and unique strengths should be leveraged, but unrealistic expectations should be tempered. A refreshed foreign policy is necessary to restore the UK's international clout, which could impact global security and economic prosperity.

images.alt_text: Putin made a surprise trip to occupied Mariupol, the Ukrainian city largely destroyed by a months-long Russian siege

summary: Credit Suisse has informed staff that some clients may consider moving wealth assets to another bank due to concerns over concentration risks following the acquisition by UBS. The Swiss regulators have orchestrated a deal where UBS will pay 3 billion Swiss francs for Credit Suisse and assume up to US$5.4 billion in losses. UBS will become the global leader in managing wealth for the wealthy, potentially triggering concerns for clients. Credit Suisse staff are advised to inform clients of the planned acquisition and communicate details of its investment banking business in due course.

site_title: What sets Singapore banks apart from Credit Suisse: Phillip Securities
summary: Singapore banks remain a positive investment opportunity despite the recent collapse of Credit Suisse, according to Phillip Securities. Analyst Glenn Thum notes that Singapore banks have a higher net interest income and a positive return on equity (ROE) of 12.5%, compared to Credit Suisse's negative ROE of 16.1%. Phillip Securities maintains its "overweight" rating on the sector, citing attractive dividend yield projections and excess capital ratios. The local banks' ability to pass on higher funding costs to customers also contributes to their profitability.

site_title: Oil edges up on historic Swiss banks deal, central banks support
summary: Oil prices rose Monday after a near 12% loss last week, its largest weekly fall since December, as UBS struck a deal to buy Credit Suisse and central banks sought to reassure and stabilize global financial markets. Brent crude futures rose 35 cents to $73.32 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 37 cents to $67.11 a barrel. The Swiss bank deal and central banks' measures to inject liquidity into the markets are restoring market confidence, leading to a relief rally in risk assets, including the crude markets.

images.alt_text: Oil prices have tracked equity markets lower, dogged by the banking sector crisis and worries about possible recession.

site_title: Credit Suisse: a bank sunk by scandals
summary: Credit Suisse, a Swiss bank once considered a pillar of stability, collapsed due to repeated missteps and scandals. The bank's share price plummeted after its main shareholder stated it would not invest more money, leading to a takeover by domestic rival UBS. The woes began with the 2021 collapse of Greensill, a financial firm that Credit Suisse heavily invested in. Other factors contributing to the bank's downfall included the Archegos hedge fund collapse, bribery scandals in Mozambique, and allegations of dirty money holdings and money laundering.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse got a US$54 billion vote of confidence from the Swiss National Bank, but the value of its CoCos tumbled, leaving holders nursing some serious losses along with serious apprehensions.

A Credit Suisse Group AG bank branch in Zurich, Switzerland, on Sunday, March 19, 2023. Swiss authorities plan to change the country’s laws to bypass a shareholder vote on the transaction as they rush to finalize a deal before Monday. Photographer: Pascal Mora/Bloomberg

Signage for Credit Suisse Group AG outside a building in Hong Kong, China, on Friday, March 17, 2023. site_title: Banking crisis in US, Europe has no direct impact on Singapore’s monetary policy: Alvin Tan
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) has stated that the ongoing banking crisis in the US and Europe will not directly impact the country's monetary policy, which focuses on medium-term structural factors. MAS Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan said the organization will consider current global and domestic economic developments for inflation and growth. The long-term path of inflation is influenced by factors such as demographics, technological advances, and central banks' commitment to low and stable inflation. Singapore's banking system remains sound and resilient, with minimal exposure to failed US banks and Credit Suisse.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
MAS says it will remain in close contact with Finma, Credit Suisse and UBS as the takeover is executed.

site_title: Philippine finance chief sees quarter-point rate hike or halt
summary: Philippines' Finance Secretary Benjamin Diokno expects the central bank to consider a 25 basis point rate hike or keep it unchanged at its policy meeting on March 23. This decision is influenced by the Federal Reserve's shift to smaller interest rate hikes, allowing other central banks to slow their pace of monetary tightening. Diokno anticipates inflation to ease to 4% by the third quarter, down from a 14-year high of 8.6% in February. A possible reduction in banks' reserve requirement ratio could also happen this year.

images.alt_text: The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) revised its projection for the 2023 balance of payments deficit to US$1.6 billion, or 0.4 per cent of GDP, from US$5.4 billion, or 1.3 per cent of GDP.
The lessons from all the disruptions since 2020 have underscored how the term “supply chain” itself is something of a misnomer, because it suggests that global trade is seamless and unbreakable.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Monday’s open; STI down 0.32 per cent
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.32% or 10.11 points to 3,173.17 at Monday's open, tracking global market losses due to a brewing banking crisis. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index all declined. European shares recorded their worst week in five months, with the Stoxx 600 closing 1.3% lower. Banking shares were mixed, with DBS rising 0.2% and OCBC falling 0.7%.

site_title: Brokers’ take: UOBKH upgrades NetLink to ‘buy’ on safe-haven appeal
summary: UOB Kay Hian upgraded its call on NetLink NBN Trust to "buy" from "hold", citing its fibre network infrastructure provider as a "high-yielding, safe-haven stock". The brokerage raised FY2023 to FY2025 net profit forecasts by 7-15% due to higher fibre connection assumptions. NetLink's core earnings exceeded expectations, and the group is expected to post a 6.4% dividend yield over the next three years. Despite recent share price weakness, UOBKH believes the stock remains a good shelter amid market volatility due to its strong earnings visibility and healthy balance sheet.

summary: Analysts remain optimistic on commercial Reits in Singapore and Malaysia amid interest-rate volatility, which is expected to persist in the near term. RHB downgraded S-Reits to "neutral" but expects modest cap rate expansion and no large drops in asset value. DBS recommends investors stay invested in logistics, retail, and hospitality sectors, citing earnings stability. UOBKH maintains its "market weight" recommendation for Malaysian Reits, citing neutral risk-to-reward returns and decent yields. Analysts prefer Reits with strong balance sheets and sponsor support, such as CapitaLand Ascendas Reit and Axis Reit.

site_title: Hot stock: Golden Energy up 6.1% to historical high of S$0.95 on higher exit offer price
summary: Golden Energy & Resources (Gear) shares rose 6.1% to a historical high of S$0.95 on Monday after the mining group increased its offer to take the company private by 13% to S$0.181 per share. This is the highest the counter has traded since listing on the Singapore Exchange. The revised offer includes a cash alternative price of 6,500 rupiah, up 18% from 5,500 rupiah. Gear had previously announced plans to delist and reduce its energy coal exposure, sparking criticism from minority investors.

site_title: China’s surprise RRR cut puts focus on bank lending rates
summary: China's People's Bank of China (PBOC) unexpectedly cut the reserve requirement ratio (RRR) by 25 basis points, providing liquidity to banks and potentially lowering lending rates. The move aims to stabilize growth, expand domestic demand, and consolidate the economy's recovery. Economists predict one-year loan prime rates will remain unchanged, but some analysts foresee a 10 basis-point reduction in loan prime rates later this year. The RRR cut follows heightened financial market turmoil and China's GDP growth target of around 5% for the year.

images.alt_text: The People’s Bank of China (PBOC) in Beijing, China.

site_title: Bitcoin thrives in chaos, breaks above US$28,000 for first time since June
summary: Bitcoin reached a 9-month high of $28,258 on March 19, surpassing the $28,000 mark for the first time since June 2022. The digital asset has risen 70% since the start of the year, with other digital assets like Ethereum and altcoins also experiencing significant gains. Traders attribute Bitcoin's resilience to declining real interest rates, expanding liquidity conditions, and a perceived shift into a new regime. Despite broader market fluctuations and conflicting signals from the Fed, Bitcoin bulls see the asset as a hedge against inflation.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Building a solid personal finance plan (Ep 139)
summary: Financial planning isn't complicated, according to Laurent Bertrand, CEO of BetterTradeOff. He discussed misconceptions about financial freedom, how to factor in volatile times, and why people still don't invest. Bertrand also shared insights on good debt, how to avoid what happened to Silicon Valley Bank, and the importance of building a solid financial plan. He emphasized that financial planning isn't daunting and encouraged listeners to take control of their finances.

site_title: UK property sellers lift asking prices despite worry about slump
summary: UK property sellers have lifted asking prices by 0.8% to £365,357, despite concerns of a housing market slump, according to Rightmove's data. This increase follows a sharp rise in January and a stable February. The data suggests a recovery in the market, particularly for first-time buyers, with sales of two-bedroom properties recovering 4% from 2019 levels. However, larger homes are facing difficulty in selling, with prices 10% below 2019 levels. The Bank of England's interest-rate pause is expected to ease worries about the economy.

site_title: Debunking the myth of the matrix
summary: Disney CEO Bob Iger has announced he is "de-matrixing" the company, eliminating the matrix-led organizational structure. The matrix, where teams report to multiple leaders, is often used to utilize experts in different areas of the business. However, it can lead to confusion, miscommunication, and micromanagement. Iger's move aims to streamline the company and improve decision-making. Experts argue that a clear distinction between strategy and tactics is essential, and that a quarterly review of top relationships can resolve conflicts. The de-matrixing process aims to promote open communication and collaboration among employees.

images.alt_text: Earlier Wednesday, Disney announced upbeat financial results, led by big gains at its theme parks.

Caring for others is no soft option in life nor is it easy to do properly. It requires discipline to think about them, not you. It demands being effectively tough, not brutally brash. It presupposes a release to independence, not a debilitating lasting dependence.

The balancing act between keeping customers and remaining profitable makes that inevitable. Customers are making the same choices. site_title: Former Taiwan president Ma open to meeting leaders on landmark China trip
summary: Former Taiwan President Ma Ying-jeou will embark on a landmark trip to China on March 27-April 7, marking the first visit by a Taiwanese president since the 1949 civil war. The trip, focused on student exchanges and ancestral respects, will not include a visit to Beijing, according to Ma's office. Ma, a senior member of Taiwan's opposition party, will meet senior officials, but his availability for meetings with Chinese leaders is at their discretion. The trip aims to reduce tensions between Beijing and Taipei, with the presidential office hoping Ma will demonstrate Taiwan's democratic values.

site_title: Macron wants pensions reform to complete ‘democratic journey’
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron wants his pensions reform to complete its "democratic journey" after months of protests and debate. The contentious legislation will be adopted in parliament on Monday unless two motions of no-confidence pass. Macron expressed his wish for the text to "go to the end of its democratic journey with respect for all."

site_title: Credit Suisse says US$17 billion of its debt now worthless, angering bondholders
summary: Credit Suisse has announced that $17 billion of its Additional Tier 1 debt will be written down to zero, angering bondholders, as part of its rescue merger with UBS. The Swiss regulator, FINMA, made the decision to bolster the bank's capital, reflecting authorities' desire for private investors to share the pain from Credit Suisse's troubles. AT1 bondholders will appear to be left with nothing, while shareholders will receive $3.23 billion under the UBS deal.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for March 17, 2023, shows mixed market trends across various segments. The Capesize market saw a slight improvement, with a time charter average of $15,867, while the Panamax market experienced a muddling week. The Supramax market remained buoyant, with the S10TC average gaining 922 points to settle at 14,502. Handysize freight levels were positive, with healthy demand from the US Gulf and East Coast South America. The VLCC market eased slightly, while the Suezmax market improved with a busy program in West Africa and the US Gulf. The Aframax market reversed its recent trend, with rates rising in the North Sea and Mediterranean. The LNG market remained healthy, with spot rates flat and up to one-year deals being worked extensively.

images.alt_text: A roundup of the week’s tanker and dry bulk market (Mar 10, 2023).

site_title: Australian banks are ‘unquestionably strong’, RBA’s Kent says
summary: Australian banks are "unquestionably strong" with solid capital and liquidity buffers, according to RBA assistant governor Chris Kent. Despite global financial system stresses, Australian banks' capital and liquidity positions exceed regulatory requirements, allowing them to issue bonds without issue. The RBA is in its most aggressive tightening cycle in a generation, with a 3.6% cash rate hike, but Kent believes banks' balance sheets will continue to benefit from their strength. The RBA will monitor the impact of monetary policy on consumer spending and inflation.

images.alt_text: Australia's he jobless rate dropped to 3.5 per cent, from 3.7 per cent, in February.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Maybank upgrades Genting to ‘buy’ on return of Chinese tourists
summary: Maybank Research upgraded Genting Singapore to "buy" from "hold" due to the return of Chinese tourists to Singapore, expected to drive the group's mass market gross gaming revenue above pre-Covid levels. The analyst raised the target price to S$1.18 from S$0.96, citing increased earnings estimates of 18-20% from FY2023 to FY2024. Mass market revenue is likely to exceed pre-Covid levels "comfortably" driven by Singapore's booming property prices, which created wealth for Singaporeans and increased their propensity to gamble.

site_title: Federal Reserve, other central banks move to boost global dollar liquidity
summary: The US Federal Reserve and other major central banks announced a coordinated effort to boost global dollar liquidity, following concerns about the global banking sector. The central banks will step up swap line operations, giving non-US central banks greater access to dollars, and increase the frequency of 7-day maturity operations from weekly to daily. The move aims to calm worries and ease strains in global funding markets, helping to mitigate the effects of interest rate rises on credit supply. This follows the recent UBS takeover of Credit Suisse.

site_title: SMEs’ top priority for 2023 is ensuring cashflow and maintaining costs: survey
summary: Singapore small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) prioritize cash flow and costs in 2023, with 62% of respondents citing these concerns. Rising global interest rates, labour costs, and inflation are top worries. Exploring new markets and digital transformation are also key priorities, with 31% and 21% of respondents respectively. Only 1% prefer a purely digital banking partner, with most SMEs seeking a trusted and reliable banking partner. Managing cash flow and liquidity needs is critical, with 35% of respondents citing the cost of deployment as a challenge in building a sustainable business.

site_title: MAS, banks seek to calm investors amid potential credit crunch, heightened recession risk
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has stated that it will remain in close contact with Finma, Credit Suisse, and UBS as the takeover is executed, ensuring the stability of Singapore's financial system. Despite initial negative market reactions, MAS does not expect the acquisition to impact the stability of Singapore's banking system. Customers of Credit Suisse will continue to have full access to their accounts, and the bank's contracts with counterparties remain in force. Analysts, however, warn of potential credit crunch and recession risks, with some predicting a pullback in interest rates and a surge in gold prices.

site_title: Issue 3: Lemons in ESG
summary: Climate reporting is plagued by inconsistencies, with significant discrepancies found in greenhouse gas emissions disclosures by Singapore's blue-chip index stocks. The lack of globally accepted standards and assurance makes it challenging for investors to discern between genuine climate efforts and greenwashing. A growing market for used cars-like ESG reporting is creating a "lemon problem," where buyers are deterred by the uncertainty, and only the most principled companies can thrive. To address this, common global standards and auditing of climate reporting are urgently needed, with mandatory sustainability reporting on the horizon for many companies.

site_title: Four powerful Singaporeans share how they change mindsets, build confidence and succeed at work
summary: Four influential Singaporeans, including a bank CEO, a minister, and a law firm founder, share their experiences on empowering women and overcoming obstacles in the workplace. They emphasize the importance of changing mindsets through decisive programs, adopting an attitude of resilience and accountability, and building confidence through networking and self-practice. Key takeaways include: creating programs of change to shift mindsets, having a resilient attitude to overcome skepticism, and identifying strengths and seeking supportive environments to build confidence.

site_title: Logging into Zoom at the beach could land you a tax bill
summary: National tax authorities and the OECD are addressing the blurred lines between work, residency, and time off due to the remote-working revolution. The issue of how long someone can work abroad before being taxed in another country is unclear. This could lead to clearer rules and implications for social security and pension payments. The OECD aims to provide guidance on these issues, which could impact individuals and companies working remotely across Europe.

site_title: China launches recruitment drive for college graduates
summary: China is launching a recruitment drive for college graduates, with the goal of creating around 12 million urban jobs this year, up from the 2022 target of 11 million. The drive, hosted by the Ministry of Human Resources and Social Security, will feature 27 job fairs across the country from March 19 to May 26. Authorities aim to keep the survey-based jobless rate at around 5.5% this year, a more ambitious goal than last year's target. The recruitment drive is part of China's efforts to boost employment and meet its job creation goals.

site_title: Credit Suisse perpetual securities’ prices fall to distressed levels
summary: Credit Suisse's perpetual securities prices have fallen to distressed levels, with risks of non-call and writedowns remaining elevated. The bank remains under pressure despite tapping a 50-billion Swiss franc liquidity facility and offering to buy back senior debt. UBS is reportedly considering a partial or whole acquisition, with a bid price of up to 0.25 francs a share. Swiss authorities are also considering nationalization as a viable option. The bank's CET1 ratio needs to be maintained above 13% to avoid a downgrade, and its credit ratings remain a notch above junk level, with Fitch warning of high execution risks.

site_title: Lacking health workers, Germany taps robots for elder care
summary: Germany is tapping robots, specifically the humanoid "Garmi," to address its growing elderly care needs. The robot, developed by a team of scientists and medical practitioners, can perform diagnostics, provide care, and treatment. Garmi is part of a new sector called geriatronics, which combines robotics, IT, and 3D technology for geriatrics and nursing. The robot aims to alleviate staffing shortages, with an estimated 670,000 unfilled caregiver posts by 2050. While acceptance by patients is a major challenge, researchers believe Garmi can offer personalized services, such as serving meals and organizing video calls, and could be integrated into society by 2030.

site_title: Nuclear subs won’t halt China-Australia thaw, ministers say
summary: Australia's government is confident that plans to acquire nuclear-powered submarines under the Aukus agreement won't derail its relations with China. Despite the security deal's aim to counter China's military ambitions, Trade Minister Don Farrell said talks on reviving frozen ties are progressing well, with an invitation to Beijing still standing. Farrell expressed confidence in a stabilisation of the relationship, citing Australia's focus on national interest and national security.

site_title: Lesson from Silicon Valley Bank – even risk-free assets are worth less after interest rates rise
summary: US bank failures, including Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank, are part of a process of tightening financial market conditions to slow economic growth and quell inflation. The rapid rise in interest rates has reduced the value of even risk-free assets, such as US government bonds. Regulators have stepped in to address bank runs, but heightened nervousness among depositors may lead to greater caution in managing assets, making debt more expensive and less available. Investors should bide their time, preserving capital as financial market conditions remain tough, and consider allocating a portion of their portfolios to cash and short-term bonds.

site_title: Janus Henderson eyes client focus, new asset classes to grow
summary: Janus Henderson Investors, a global asset manager, is shifting its focus to meeting client needs and introducing new asset classes to reverse years of fund outflows. Under new CEO Ali Dibadj, the company plans to streamline processes, reduce costs, and diversify into emerging markets, private credit, and municipal bonds. Dibadj aims to break the 21-quarter outflow streak and achieve flat or positive net new revenue growth within the next three to five years. The company has also been building its distribution channels in Asia, where it sees significant growth opportunities.

site_title: Critics, experts in demand for sustainability panels
summary: Multinational companies are forming sustainability advisory panels to seek external expertise and avoid echo chambers in their sustainability decisions. Experts and former industry leaders, such as climate strategists and journalists, are being recruited to scan the horizon for ESG issues that may impact the companies. These panels provide an ongoing feedback mechanism to keep strategies in check and are seen as essential for companies to cope with growing disruption. The panels are also expected to consider themes such as extended producer responsibility and human rights due diligence, and may eventually include once-shunned activists as candidates.

site_title: Credit Suisse’s First Boston plan in doubt amid crisis talks
summary: Credit Suisse's planned spin-off of its investment banking business, CS First Boston, is in doubt amid a renewed crisis of confidence. The business, led by CEO-designate Michael Klein, was set to be separated and eventually listed, but UBS, the potential buyer, shows little interest in the business, putting plans on hold. The riskier investment banking operations are a sticking point in the UBS takeover talks, with one scenario involving UBS seeking to divest or unwind part of the business. The spin-off's future remains uncertain, with Credit Suisse considering alternative options, including accelerating the effort or winding down the investment bank.

site_title: DAX Index rally faces risk of stalling amid headwinds
summary: The DAX Index, a key German stock market indicator, has seen a steady rally since reversing from troughs near 12,000 in late September last year, with gains of over 20%. However, recent headwinds, including hot inflation data and US regional bank collapses, pose a risk to the rally. The index's recent technical breakdown and bearish divergence in technical indicators suggest a potential retracement back to the 13,800 level, threatening the rally's momentum and stability.

site_title: US dollar slips as banking turmoil snares markets
summary: The US dollar declined 0.604% as traders awaited the Federal Reserve's policy meeting, expected to result in a 0.25% interest rate hike. Banking turmoil, including Credit Suisse's 8% drop and First Republic's 30% decline, fueled market concerns of a potential recession. US banks sought record emergency liquidity from the Federal Reserve, but failed to halt their stock declines.

site_title: Central banks try to calm markets after UBS deal to buy Credit Suisse
summary: Central banks, including the US Federal Reserve and European Central Bank, intervened to calm markets after Swiss authorities persuaded UBS to buy Credit Suisse in a historic deal. UBS will pay 3 billion Swiss francs and assume up to $5.4 billion in losses, backed by a massive Swiss guarantee. The move aims to restore calm in the banking sector, which has been walloped by a crisis sparked by the collapse of two regional US banks earlier this month. The coordinated action is seen as a decisive intervention to stem contagion and support euro zone banks.

summary: S-REITs with the lowest gearing ratios reported as of end-February average 32% gearing, indicating a relatively stable financial position. Among these, Sabana Industrial Reit's New Tech Park in Lorong Chuan is mentioned. The gearing ratio is a key metric monitored by investors, and the current trend suggests a cautious approach to interest rate increases by the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting on March 21-22.

site_title: Credit Suisse said to push back against UBS’s US$1 billion offer
summary: Credit Suisse is pushing back against UBS's $1 billion offer to buy the firm, citing a price that is too low and would hurt shareholders and employees. The troubled Swiss bank, which closed down 8% on Friday, believes the offer is inadequate and has backing from its largest shareholder, Saudi National Bank. UBS has insisted on a material adverse change clause that would void the deal if Credit Suisse's credit default spreads jump by 100 basis points or more.

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding says winding up of unit won’t impact group’s operations, financial condition
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's subsidiary, Yangzijiang Shipping, is considering an appeal against a High Court order to wind up over US$4.8 million in unpaid debt. Despite this, the company claims the winding up won't impact its operations and financial condition, citing the unit's "dormant" and "negligible" net asset value. The unit is expected to wind up within four weeks, with liquidators appointed to handle the assets.

site_title: Small-cap stocks can outperform the STI, if investors know where to look
summary: Analysts suggest that small-cap stocks, particularly those in the property sector, can outperform the Straits Times Index (STI) if investors focus on companies with good track records and dividend payments. Small-cap stocks with a market value of less than S$2 billion are expected to deliver market-beating opportunities, but investors should carefully evaluate their underlying businesses before investing. Experts recommend paying close attention to companies that have delivered dividends despite challenging times, such as Propnex.

As at Mar 8, 86 companies listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) had released their financial results for the quarter ended December last year. Of these, 47 companies reported a profit, while 39 ended the quarter in the red.

site_title: Asia bank bonds so far avoided scale of stress in US, Europe
summary: Asian bank bonds have outperformed peers due to factors such as less hawkish central banks and stickier deposits, which reduced spreads on riskier dollar bonds by less than 42 basis points. This contrasts with US, Germany, France, and Italy, where spreads widened by more than 100 basis points. Analysts attribute the stability to state support and policy easing, but warn of potential second-round effects and "out of control" financial contagion risks.

site_title: Investors need to ignore the doomsayers driven by turmoil
summary: Investors are being swayed by doomsday predictions and market turmoil, leading to impulsive decisions and missed opportunities. The collapse of Silicon Valley Bank has fueled speculation about interest rates and bank stocks, but experts warn that no one can predict market movements. Instead of reacting to speculation, investors should focus on a low-cost, broadly diversified portfolio and ignore predictions, as history shows that markets recover and investors can achieve similar returns over the long term.

images.alt_text: An exposure to commodity futures could help to diversify a portfolio and hedge against inflation. But for production-weighted ETFs investing in futures contracts, energy has by far the largest weight of typically over 50 per cent.

site_title: After S$4.6 million refurbishment, Keppel Club is both inclusive and exclusive
summary: Keppel Club, a private-public golf facility, has reopened after a S$4.6 million refurbishment. The updated facility features new tee-boxes, bunkers, and greens. The club, which was established in 1904, now offers inclusive rates for non-members, particularly seniors. At the official opening, Transport Minister S Iswaran described the club as balancing inclusivity and exclusivity, allowing both members and the public to enjoy the facilities.

site_title: Former Taiwan president Ma to visit China in landmark trip
summary: Taiwan's former president Ma Ying-jeou is set to visit China from March 27 to April 7, marking the first time a former or current Taiwanese leader has visited since the Republic of China government fled to the island in 1949. The trip comes amid heightened tensions between Beijing and Taipei as China pressures Taiwan to accept sovereignty. Ma, a senior member of Taiwan's opposition party, previously met with Chinese President Xi Jinping in 2015. The visit is seen as a significant development in cross-straits relations.

images.alt_text: US State Department spokesman Ned Price described Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen’s expected travel as “transit” rather than a “visit” to the United States, which supports but does not recognise the self-ruling democracy claimed by Beijing.

site_title: Pent-up demand floods Malaysia’s events industry as corporate ‘revenge spending’ continues
summary: Malaysia's events industry is experiencing pent-up demand from the corporate sector, driven by "revenge spending" following the easing of pandemic restrictions. Since May 2022, venue sourcing platform Ask Venue has received around 1,000 enquiries almost every month, with a 15-20% conversion rate to sales. Venue package prices have risen 20-25% in the second half of 2022, with costs also driven up by inflation and a weakening ringgit. Industry players expect the country's business events industry to achieve 80% of pre-pandemic performance this year, with China's reopening expected to fuel further growth.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng
The first Paris Baguette outlet in Pavilion Kuala Lumpur has attracted the attention of Malaysian shoppers.
Malaysia's tourism industry players observed that there are increasing number of Chinese tourists choose to travel in smaller groups and more outdoor activities due to health safety concerns.
Tourism players are enhancing and reviewing their offerings to diversify their tourist source markets, experts said.

site_title: FDIC said to move towards breakup plan for Silicon Valley Bank
summary: US regulators are moving towards a breakup solution for Silicon Valley Bank, failing to find a suitable buyer for the entire company. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp (FDIC) is seeking to sell the failed bank in at least two parts, with bids due on Friday for the "bridge bank" taking receivership of SVB's assets and liabilities, and Wednesday for SVB Private Bank or the remnants of Boston Private.

images.alt_text: Some analysts expect the United States to continue hiking rates to curb inflation, while others believe that the ongoing crisis may prompt the Federal Reserve to either slow down or hit the brakes temporarily.

site_title: Michael Platt’s BlueCrest lost 7% this year amid Silicon Valley Bank tumult
summary: Michael Platt's hedge fund BlueCrest Capital Management lost approximately 7% this year due to market volatility sparked by Silicon Valley Bank's collapse. The fund previously saw a 153% surge last year. The recent bank closures have fueled speculation that the Federal Reserve may pause rate hikes, causing turmoil among funds positioned for further tightening.

site_title: Take care that so-called white knights don’t circumvent tougher due diligence standards
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has introduced new due diligence standards for corporate finance advisers in major capital market transactions, including IPOs, RTOs, and business combinations. The new rules aim to ensure stricter compliance and regulatory standards, but critics argue that MAS and the Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) should also require purposed white knights to publicly disclose their intentions, including plans to inject new assets and businesses into the listed company within 12-24 months. This disclosure must precede a white-wash waiver and listing approval to ensure full transparency and accountability.

images.alt_text: MAS last month introduced a notice on business conduct requirements for CF advisers, setting out specific requirements to manage conflicts of interest and ensure proper governance and supervision.
This is to improve industry standards and allow investors to make more informed decisions, MAS said in a release on Thursday (Feb 23).

site_title: Finding true north on the corporate moral compass
summary: A corporate moral compass is shifting, with boards re-evaluating their organizations' purposes. The four seasons of corporate morality, from prioritizing financial success to focusing on social responsibility, have led to a growing emphasis on stakeholder capitalism and moral purpose. In 2019, the Business Roundtable signed a statement committing to stakeholder capitalism, and many corporations are now seeking to redefine their purpose. Boards are encouraged to have a moral compass, set organizational values, and reinforce moral reasoning and behavior, as the world becomes increasingly politicized and socially conscious.

site_title: Asset manager Anatole to open Singapore office: report
summary: Anatole, a Hong Kong-based asset manager, plans to open an office in Singapore, potentially shifting some functions to the city-state. Anatole's chief operating officer, Gary Lee, described the Singapore office as an "outpost" and expressed continued bullishness on China's recovery, despite the firm cutting its exposure to China. The move may still involve a smaller presence in Hong Kong.

site_title: Issue 41: DBS’ emissions scorecard vs its loan book; SVB contagion fears could hit climate finance
summary: DBS, a Singaporean bank, has released its first emissions report card, showing a positive growth in sustainable financing share in key decarbonisation sectors. This growth is expected to set the stage for greater emissions reductions. The bank's ability to achieve its net zero targets is seen as a step towards reducing its environmental impact. The move is part of the growing trend of banks and financial institutions prioritizing sustainability and environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in their operations.

images.alt_text: DBS said its financed emissions for O&G fell to 35.6 metric tons of carbon dioxide equivalent (MtCO2e) in 2022, from 38.6 MtCO2e

site_title: Biden says banking crisis has calmed down
summary: US President Joe Biden has reassured investors and depositors that the global banking system is safe, following the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank. Biden stated that the banking crisis has calmed down, after financial stocks lost billions of dollars in value. Large US banks injected $30 billion in deposits into First Republic Bank to rescue it. Biden is seeking greater authority for regulators to tackle banking sector issues, including higher fines for managers and clawing back executives' compensation.

site_title: Issue 4: Governance reloaded; Khazanah won’t let go
summary: In Singapore, the percentage of companies disclosing present and historical board seats held by directors is declining. This trend raises concerns about the nation's Code of Corporate Governance. Professor Mak Yuen Teen, a renowned corporate governance scholar, is re-examining the code to address these issues. The decline in disclosure may impact the effectiveness of the governance framework, highlighting the need for improvements to ensure transparency and accountability in corporate governance practices.

site_title: Diversity versus meritocracy
summary: A robust hiring process can naturally increase diversity in the talent pool, contradicting the myth that meritocracy and diversity are mutually exclusive. Organizations should commit to a rigorous interview and selection process to find diverse and well-qualified candidates. Despite a lack of genuine belief in the benefits of gender diversity, there is still a need for a more robust board selection process to source for a broader and diverse slate of candidates. Achieving diversity and meritocracy simultaneously is possible, and setting clear goals on board diversity is crucial to improving long-term business outcomes.

images.alt_text: Nomura International, the Japanese lender’s London-based investment bank, previously said it wanted 19 per cent of women in senior management positions by 2022.

At companies in the Hang Seng Index, almost 20 per cent of directors are women, ahead of the 15 per cent in Nikkei 225 companies but below the major indices in Australia, the US or Europe, where the proportion is closer to one-third.

Research shows that women tend to hold back from applying for jobs unless they’re 100 per cent qualified for a particular role, whereas men tend to apply for positions even where they don’t meet all the criteria.
Ethnic minorities now account for 190 of the 1,064 board positions at FTSE 100 companies, 31 as chairs or executive directors.

site_title: Thai politicians dangle 3.1 trillion baht worth of campaign promises
summary: Thai politicians have made promises worth 3.1 trillion baht in campaign pledges, including doubling daily minimum wages to 2,000 baht by 2027 and tripling cash handouts to 1,000 baht a month. The promises, made by the top nine parties, will require significant funding, with two parties estimated to need 2 trillion baht each per year. Analysts are concerned about the impact on Thailand's already stretched public finances and fragile economic recovery from the pandemic.

site_title: China wine tariff pushes Australia’s grape growers into crisis
summary: Australia's grape growers are facing a crisis due to China's punitive tariff on Australian wine, which has reduced sales by 97% since 2020. The tariff, imposed in response to Australia's investigation into the origin of COVID-19, has led to a glut of unsold red wine and pressured grape prices. Many farmers are choosing between selling grapes at a huge loss or not harvesting to minimize costs. The industry's decline has also led to concerns about the long-term viability of family-owned farms, with some considering selling or exiting the industry.

images.alt_text: The desire to achieve greatness in wine often means figuring out how others define it, but the most original wines begin with smaller ambitions.

site_title: Putin makes surprise trip to Russian-occupied Mariupol in wake of ICC warrant
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin made a surprise visit to the Russian-occupied Ukrainian city of Mariupol, amid international criticism following an ICC warrant accusing him of war crimes. The visit, which included meeting with residents and discussing reconstruction efforts, was seen as a gesture of defiance. Putin had not publicly commented on the ICC warrant, but his spokesman described it as "null and void." The visit marked Putin's first to the Russian-occupied parts of Ukraine's Donbas region since the war began, and came after months of largely staying inside the Kremlin.

site_title: Trump says he expects to be arrested on Tuesday, calls for protests
summary: US President Donald Trump expects to be arrested on Tuesday as New York prosecutors consider charges over a $130,000 hush money payment to a porn star, according to Trump's statement. Trump, who is seeking the Republican nomination for the presidency in 2024, called on his supporters to protest, despite warnings from politicians that such actions could incite violence. The investigation is one of several legal woes Trump faces, including a state-level criminal probe in Georgia and a special counsel investigation into his handling of classified documents.

images.alt_text: The posts on his Facebook page and YouTube channel, which are titled “I’M BACK!”, show a CNN video announcing Trump’s election as president in the 2016 race against Hillary Clinton.

site_title: Riskiest corporate borrowers left in lurch by bank mayhem
summary: The banking crisis, sparked by Silicon Valley Bank's collapse and Credit Suisse Group's crisis, has tightened financial conditions, making it harder for riskiest corporate borrowers to raise cash. Junk-rated issuers face soaring borrowing costs, with average yield spreads exceeding 1,000 basis points, and leveraged loans plummeting to a 10-week low. Vulnerable borrowers in sectors like retail and travel may struggle to access capital, forcing them to get creative with incentives to attract lenders, and potentially leading to a hard landing for the US economy.

site_title: Evergrande gets creditor support for restructuring: sources
summary: China Evergrande Group has reached an agreement with a group of major creditors for a plan to restructure its offshore debt, ahead of a key winding-up petition hearing. An ad hoc group of offshore bondholders has expressed support for the plan, which includes terms of a debt-to-equity swap option and debt extension arrangements. The agreement is being drafted, with advisers Moelis & Co and Kirkland & Ellis involved. This development is seen as a positive step for the struggling developer, which is the world's most indebted.

images.alt_text: A winding-up order issued to China Evergrande could have broad implications for China’s US$60 trillion financial system.

site_title: Issue 1: Singapore’s green bond framework, Asean’s green funding gap
summary: Singapore has published a green bond framework aligned with international standards, setting the stage for the government to issue up to S$35 billion of green bonds by 2030. The framework, which covers eight categories, aims to support sustainable development and mitigate climate change. A new report by Temasek and Bain estimates that South-east Asia needs US$3 trillion in cumulative investments to limit global warming to 1.5°C by 2030, with only US$20 billion invested so far.

images.alt_text: Kenneth Lim
The renewables sector represents a US$30 billion opportunity by 2030, US$20 billion of which will be for solar energy.

site_title: Doubts creep in at US construction’s big show in Las Vegas
summary: The US construction industry's first big trade show since the pandemic, ConExpo, took place in Las Vegas, showcasing hundreds of machines and highlighting strong demand and order backlogs. Suppliers like Caterpillar and Deere expressed optimism, citing a "good" input from construction customers, while some equipment buyers, like Durante Rentals, expressed caution due to low demand for new office space, apartments, and retail storefronts. Experts warn that rising interest rates and financial market uncertainty could lead to a pullback in construction projects, particularly for contractors in areas without high-profile mega-projects.

site_title: Mortgages, wine and renovations: Silicon Valley Bank’s deep tech ties
summary: Silicon Valley Bank, a regional bank catering to the high-growth tech industry, was deeply intertwined with the lives and businesses of investors, entrepreneurs, and executives. The bank provided loans to top venture firms, startups, and even its own funds, and invested in companies such as OpenDoor and Chainalysis. SVB also offered mortgages to founders with little cash, and provided lower-interest-rate loans to many entrepreneurs. Its collapse has sent shockwaves through the startup world, with many investors and founders citing the bank's "virtuous cycle" that fueled the tech industry's growth.

site_title: State firms turning into China’s hottest stock trade
summary: China's state-owned companies are experiencing a surge in popularity, with a gauge of the largest government-backed stocks gaining 7% in 2023, outperforming the benchmark CSI 300 Index by nearly five percentage points. State firms accounted for half of the top 10 best-performing stocks, with eye-popping gains including China Satellite Communications Co's 118% surge. Regulators' hopes for higher dividends and plans to revive the sector are driving the momentum, with investors optimistic about the sector's potential to play a bigger role in Beijing's economic policy initiatives.

site_title: Reality check for landlords as rents may have peaked; viewings decline
summary: Landlords in Singapore's rental market may be facing a reality check as rents may have peaked, according to real estate agents. Fewer tenants, high rents, and an uncertain economic climate are attributed to the slowdown. Agents report that viewings are declining, with listings taking longer to secure tenants, and landlords are struggling to accept the moderating market. Tenants are no longer rushing to commit to leases, asking for one-year leases instead, while landlords are trying to lock in tenants with longer contracts. Agents predict a more normal market, with rents remaining reasonable for the first half of the year.

images.alt_text: The practice of agents taking a commission from their tenants has become the norm - at least for now - and mostly involves corporate clients and foreigners who are new to Singapore.
Singapore saw annual rents jump 28 per cent in the quarter from a year earlier, according to a report by Knight Frank.

site_title: Motor racing: Saudi Arabia open to hosting two F1 races in near future
summary: Saudi Arabia is open to hosting two Formula One races per year, with a new track planned for Qiddiya near Riyadh potentially ready by 2027. The country has made its debut in F1 in December 2021 and has hosted the Jeddah Corniche street circuit since last year. Prince Khalid bin Sultan al-Abdullah al-Faisal stated that the demand for F1 in Saudi Arabia is growing and that hosting two races is "doable." The decision would depend on various factors, but the prince expressed confidence that Saudi Arabia could host two races in the near future.

images.alt_text: “Williams Racing have placed their faith and trust in me, and I will do the same in return. " James Vowles said.
The race in Shanghai, originally scheduled for Apr 16, has been axed for the fourth year in a row.

site_title: Why Credit Suisse’s “Coco” bonds are causing anxiety
summary: Credit Suisse's contingent convertible bonds (CoCos), worth $17.3 billion, have plummeted in value, leaving investors with significant losses. The Swiss National Bank provided a $54 billion vote of confidence for Credit Suisse, but the CoCos' value has tumbled, sparking concerns. If regulators step in to protect depositors, the CoCos would be written off, and the bank's senior debt would be converted to equity. This is a high-risk, low-priority debt instrument, and the potential for writedown is a concern, similar to the 2017 Banco Popular Espanol case.

site_title: Credit Suisse brings US bank panic home for European real estate
summary: Credit Suisse's collapse has triggered a US bank panic, causing uncertainty in the European real estate market. The collapse of Silicon Valley Bank has led to a drop in stocks, prompting depositors to move their money to larger banks, which have significant real estate lending ties. This has resulted in a funding gap of approximately 200 billion euros, with investors struggling to underwrite deals due to an uncertain outlook on interest rates. The real estate market has seen a decline in transaction volumes, with European real estate returns hitting a 20-year low in the final quarter of last year.

site_title: Midsized US banks ask FDIC to insure deposits for 2 years
summary: A coalition of midsized US banks has asked the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp (FDIC) to extend deposit insurance coverage for two years, citing the need to stabilize the banking sector and prevent further bank failures. The request comes after the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank, prompting customers to withdraw deposits from smaller banks and seek refuge in larger ones. The banks propose paying for the extended insurance coverage by increasing the deposit-insurance assessment on participating lenders.

site_title: New World Development leads Hong Kong’s gains in board diversity
summary: Hong Kong's New World Development Co has made the biggest gain in gender diversity among the city's blue chips, adding three women to its board of directors in the fourth quarter, doubling the number of women at its highest level of governance. The company now has 35% of seats held by women, surpassing the average for Hong Kong's listed companies. This move follows a rule that requires firms to have at least one female director, expected to create over 1,300 new board seats for women.

site_title: Credit Suisse is in crisis. What went wrong?
summary: Credit Suisse, Switzerland's largest bank, is facing a crisis due to scandals, mounting losses, and client outflows. The bank's share price slumped 31% on March 15 after its largest shareholder, Saudi National Bank, ruled out further investment. The crisis was triggered by the bank's willingness to engage with clients who other banks avoided, including a spying scandal and a massive leak of client data. The Swiss central bank offered to lend up to $72 billion and buy back debt to stabilize the bank. The government is considering acquiring a stake in the bank or separating its Swiss unit.

site_title: Michael Platt lists his superyacht for 139.9 million euros eyeing an upgrade
summary: British billionaire Michael Platt, the second-richest person in Britain with a fortune valued at $11.2 billion, is selling his 75-meter superyacht Arrow for 139.9 million euros due to plans to upgrade to a larger 110-meter yacht. The sale is part of Platt's efforts to scale up his wealth, including a recent listing of his penthouse for $21 million and a move to a full-floor apartment in the Central Park Tower. Platt's hedge fund, BlueCrest Capital Management, saw a record 153% gain last year, boosting his fortune by $3 billion.

site_title: How AI could upend the world even more than electricity or the internet
summary: Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) is seen as inevitable and could bring about a paradigm shift "orders of magnitude" greater than previous technological changes. AGI, which enables machines to perform tasks with human-like cognitive abilities, could free people from menial tasks and usher in a new era of creativity. However, experts warn that it could also threaten jobs and raise insurmountable social issues, such as creative authenticity and bias. As tech giants like Microsoft and OpenAI push their generative AI tools to the next level, concerns about the potential risks and benefits of AGI continue to grow.

site_title: US Federal Reserve to balance banking woes, inflation in next rate decision
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell signaled a willingness to speed up interest rate hikes if needed to tackle persistent inflation, but most analysts predict a 25-basis-point rate increase due to market turbulence following Silicon Valley Bank's rapid collapse. The Fed has raised rates eight times since last year to combat decades-high inflation, but a bigger 50-basis-point hike is now considered "off the table." Powell emphasized the need to tame "widespread" inflationary pressures, but recent economic data, including slowing inflation and contracting corners of the economy, may ease pressure on the Fed to move more aggressively.

site_title: Golf at 3pm Thursday? Sure, it’s the Afternoon Fun Economy
summary: A Stanford study found that golf games at 4pm on Wednesdays increased by 278% and weekday games by 83% in 2022 compared to 2019. This trend, dubbed the "afternoon fun economy," is driven by millions of Americans working remotely, allowing them to extend their leisure time into the afternoon. As a result, businesses like golf clubs, fitness studios, and salons are seeing a surge in demand for afternoon services, with some experiencing a 50% increase in bookings. This shift may be contributing to the economic rebound since 2020, as workers use leisure resources to boost productivity.

images.alt_text: Officials are unsure how to treat people doing a temporary stint abroad and how long those can last before it’s classed as permanent.
Da Nang is home to nearly 900 foreign-invested projects with a total investment capital of US$5.9 billion.
student, typing, keyboard

site_title: LME rocked by new nickel scandal after finding bags of stones
summary: The London Metal Exchange (LME) has discovered bags of stones instead of nickel at a warehouse in Rotterdam, compromising a handful of its contracts. The discovery, which affects 54 tonnes of metal worth around $1.3 million, raises questions about the exchange's systems and procedures. This incident comes at a time when the metals world is still reeling from a recent nickel crisis and a massive alleged fraud involving missing nickel cargoes. The LME has invalidated the affected contracts and is asking licenced operators to recheck warranted nickel, but the incident has sparked concerns about the safety and security of the exchange's contracts.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the London Metal Exchange, in London. The LME says said that it had taken active steps to enhance nickel market liquidity and transparency.

site_title: Beijing may allow foreign financial firms to list in China: ex-finance minister
summary: China may allow foreign financial firms to list in the country, in line with its efforts to open up its financial industry. Former finance minister Lou Jiwei stated that conditions would need to be met before such a move. Vice-chairman Cao Yu of the China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission also expressed China's willingness to respond to foreign financial institutions' demands.
