This move comes as China seeks to attract foreign capital to aid its economic recovery after the end of its zero-Covid policy.

site_title: MG’s ZS EV wins some and loses some
summary: The MG ZS EV has undergone a facelift and drivetrain upgrade, enhancing its electric SUV's performance and features. The updated model boasts a 177-horsepower motor, improved infotainment system, and a quieter ride. However, the added power comes at the cost of a reduced range of 320 kilometers, compared to 335 km previously. The ZS EV now competes more fiercely in the electric market, with rivals like the BYD Atto 3 and Kia Niro EV offering longer ranges. Despite this, the MG ZS EV remains a viable option, offering practicality and refinement.

images.alt_text: This battery-powered hatchback from China might well be the best car you’ve never heard of.
The BYD Atto 3's coquettishly slim front lamps create the impression of a dragon face.

site_title: Bringing together the movers and shakers of Corporate Singapore
summary: The Business Times Corporate Golf League 2023, an annual event presented by Singapore Pools, brings together Corporate Singapore's movers and shakers for a relaxed and friendly atmosphere. Jayaprakash Jagateesan, executive director and CEO of The ALDigi Group, participated in the event as part of ONERHT, a platform of brands that supports the league. Jagateesan enjoys the networking opportunities and camaraderie on the golf course, and ONERHT aims to promote corporate social responsibility through the event. He also emphasizes the importance of golf in promoting physical and mental skills, and encourages more corporates to join the league to build connections and give back to the community.

images.alt_text: Audi Singapore managing director Markus Schuster in action at The Business Times Corporate Golf League 2023.
The Singapore Pools team (from left): former Cabinet Ministe Yaacob Ibrahim, Singapore Pools CEO Lam Chee Weng, Singapore Pools board member Lee Kwok Cheong, and Mohd Norhelmy.
"The Business Times" editor Chen Huifen speaking at a networking event on Feb 2 to launch the BT Corporate Golf League 2023 tournament.

site_title: Oil: Prices settle down, post big weekly losses on bank fears
summary: Oil prices settled lower, reversing early gains, amid concerns about the banking sector crisis and recession. Brent crude futures fell 2.3% to $72.97 a barrel and US WTI crude fell 2.4% to $66.74 a barrel, marking their biggest weekly declines in months. Analysts expect constrained global supply to support oil prices, and OPEC+ members attributed the price weakness to financial drivers.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures rose US$1.37, or 1 per cent, to settle at US$74.70 a barrel, while the West Texas Intermediate crude futures (WTI) gained 74 cents, or 1.1 per cent, to settle at US$68.35 a barrel.

site_title: 'I'm back': Trump returns to YouTube and Facebook after two-year ban
summary: Former US President Donald Trump has returned to YouTube and Facebook after a two-year ban, posting a video announcing his election in 2016 with a "Trump 2024" screen. His Twitter account was reinstated in November by Elon Musk. Trump's return gives him access to 146 million followers across three platforms, potentially aiding his 2024 presidential campaign. YouTube restored his channel citing a balance between voter access and real-world violence risk, while Meta reinstated his Facebook and Instagram accounts earlier this year.

images.alt_text: Guo Wengui, an exiled Chinese businessman with ties to former Donald Trump adviser Steve Bannon, sits as he appears on charges of leading a complex conspiracy to defraud Guo's online followers out of more than US$1 billion at a courthouse in New York, March 15, 2023 in this courtroom sketch.
Prices for imports from China across some of the most affected industries increased as much as 25 per cent in 2021.

site_title: North Korea claims almost 800,000 people have signed up for military to fight against US
summary: North Korea claims approximately 800,000 citizens have signed up to join or reenlist in the military to counter the US, following the launch of its Hwasong-17 intercontinental ballistic missile. The move comes amid ongoing US-South Korea military drills, dubbed "Freedom Shield 23". The launch drew condemnation from governments in Seoul, Washington, and Tokyo, with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un accusing the US and South Korea of increasing tensions. The development raises concerns about the escalating tensions between the two sides.

images.alt_text: People watch a television news screen showing a picture of North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un witnessing the recent test-firing of a Hwasong-17 intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM), at a railway station in Seoul on March 17, 2023. - North Korea said the projectile it test-fired on March 16 was an intercontinental ballistic missile known as Hwasong-17, the state news agency KCNA reported. (Photo by Jung Yeon-je / AFP)

site_title: Nomura sets even lower goals for women in leadership roles
summary: Nomura International, a Japanese lender's London-based investment bank, has set an even lower goal for women in senior management positions, aiming for 17% by 2026, after missing its initial target of 19% by 2022. The UK Treasury's sixth annual review of Women in Finance Charters found that 29 companies, including Nomura, failed to meet their 2022 targets, with many citing reasons such as senior women leaving or low turnover in senior management. Despite this, the report notes a slight positive trend, with the share of female leaders across top financial firms growing to 35% in 2022.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Nomura Securities is seen at the company's Head Office in Tokyo, Japan, November 28, 2016.  REUTERS/Toru Hanai//File Photo
Ethnic minorities now account for 190 of the 1,064 board positions at FTSE 100 companies, 31 as chairs or executive directors.
Women made up more than 24 per cent of the board members of MSCI AC World Index companies in 2022 compared with about 18 per cent in 2018.

site_title: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway rejects call for silence on hot-button issues
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway has urged shareholders to reject proposals that restrict its discussion on hot-button social and political issues, and disclose more about its climate change and diversity efforts. The company, led by Buffett, also rejected a proposal to let someone else be chairman while remaining CEO. Berkshire Hathaway reported a 8% increase in Buffett's compensation to $401,589 in 2022, and his net worth remains the world's sixth-largest at $101.6 billion.

images.alt_text: Warren Buffett professed continued faith in the resilience of the United States, saying: “I have yet to see a time when it made sense to make a long-term bet against America.”

site_title: Baidu, Pony.ai win permits to offer driverless robotaxi services in Beijing
summary: Baidu and Pony.ai have received permits to offer fully driverless robotaxi services in Beijing. Baidu's Apollo service will deploy 10 autonomous vehicles in a technology park, while Pony.ai will operate a robotaxi service in the city. The permits mark a step forward for the companies, which have been testing the service since December. The vehicles will not have human drivers or safety operators, and the companies will operate in three Chinese cities, including Wuhan and Chongqing.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Apollo logo is seen on a car of Baidu's driverless robotaxi service Apollo Go, in Wuhan, Hubei province, China February 24, 2023. REUTERS/Josh Arslan/File Photo

site_title: Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes makes plea to put off prison as she appeals
summary: Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes is appealing her 11.25-year prison sentence for defrauding investors, just five weeks before her scheduled prison date. Her lawyers argue that her appeal raises "substantial questions" of law or facts, and that she should remain free on bail. The government counters that Holmes is a flight risk due to her conviction and the purchase of a one-way ticket to Mexico during her trial. A judge will decide on her bail request and restitution of approximately $800 million to investors by early April.

images.alt_text: Lawyers for Holmes, 38, filed a single-page notice of appeal late Friday (Dec 2) in federal court in San Jose, California.

Former Theranos CEO Elizabeth Holmes arrives at the Robert F. Peckman Federal Courthouse to face sentencing following her conviction on four counts of fraud in the saga of the now defunct blood testing start-up, in San Jose, Calif. on Nov 18, 2022.

site_title: Thaksin’s daughter widens lead for Thai premiership in poll
summary: Thaksin Shinawatra's daughter, Paetongtarn, has widened her lead in the Thai premiership, garnering 38.2% of support in a poll ahead of the May general election. Her party, Pheu Thai, received 49.75% backing, while incumbent Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha secured 15.7%. Paetongtarn's approval jumped to 34% from 34% in December's poll. The Pheu Thai party has pledged to lift the minimum wage and boost economic growth, while Prayut's government has faced nearly a decade of military-backed rule.

site_title: US money market funds’ weekly inflows hit 3-year high on bank worries
summary: US money market funds saw their largest weekly inflows in nearly three years, with a net $108.17 billion added from March 8 to March 15, amid investor concerns over the collapse of three US banks. Investors pulled out of risk assets, selling $9.74 billion in large-cap and $1 billion in mid-cap equity funds, while small-cap funds attracted $97 million. The influx was eased by large US banks' infusion into First Republic Bank.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Woman holds U.S. dollar banknotes in this illustration taken May 30, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Making the most of the AGM at a complex time
summary: Singapore's annual general meeting (AGM) season approaches amidst uncertainty, with companies facing challenges such as inflation, high interest rates, and geopolitical tensions. To reassure stakeholders, boards must outline a robust plan to navigate these challenges and showcase their long-term value-creation proposition. Companies with strong sustainability reports and diverse board compositions will be well-positioned to secure stakeholders' confidence. Hybrid AGMs are expected to remain the default format, allowing for flexibility in meeting shareholders' preferences. Ultimately, the spirit and substance of engagement will count, with stakeholders seeking assurance on how companies will weather economic headwinds and chart their sustainability course.

images.alt_text: Singapore should not be a laggard when it comes to corporate governance practices such as the disclosure of executive remuneration, but should move the needle, said June Sim, head of Listing Compliance, SGX RegCo. (PHOTO: BT)
Sembmarine shareholders will not be able to raise questions about the deal in person or vote at a physical extraordinary general meeting, as the meeting is being held virtually.

site_title: Thailand heads for elections as Prayuth dissolves parliament
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha has dissolved parliament, paving the way for elections in May. The move, which comes days before the House of Representatives' four-year term ends, is aimed at extending military-backed rule despite widespread unpopularity. Prayuth has submitted the decree for royal endorsement and is betting on the return of tourists and stimulus programs to boost the economy. However, he faces tough competition from opposition parties, including the Pheu Thai Party led by Paetongtarn Shinawatra, daughter of former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra. Elections are expected to take place on May 7, with the outcome uncertain due to the military's influence in Thai politics.

images.alt_text: epa10493758 Thai Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha (C), with candidates of Ruam Thai Sang Chart Party in next elections during a party's event in Bangkok, Thailand, 27 February 2023. Prayut agreed to be a candidate for prime minister of the newly formed Ruam Thai Sang Chart Party (United Thai Nation) in next general election on 07 May 2023, after he announced to seek another term in office to retrain power.  EPA-EFE/NARONG SANGNAK

site_title: The Fed was too late on SVB even though it saw problem after problem
summary: The US Federal Reserve has promised to investigate how it supervised Silicon Valley Bank's (SVB) collapse, now the second-biggest failure of a US lender in history. Despite spotting problems and issuing formal warnings to the bank's leaders, the Fed was too late to prevent the collapse. SVB's lack of a chief risk officer and its heavy investment in low-interest bonds contributed to its downfall. The Fed's internal review will be published by May 1, and the Justice Department and Securities and Exchange Commission are also investigating the bank's collapse.

images.alt_text: The plan to seek bankruptcy protection comes after the tech lender said on Mar 13 it was planning to explore strategic alternatives for its businesses, including the holding company, SVB Capital and SVB Securities.
Digital Core Reit said it has no banking relationship with fallen Silicon Valley Bank.
California banking regulators shut down Silicon Valley Bank on March 10 after a run on the lender, which had US$209 billion in assets at the end of 2022.

site_title: SVB Financial seeks bankruptcy protection as banking turmoil persists
summary: SVB Financial Group filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on March 17, seeking buyers for its assets. This comes after the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank, with financial stocks losing over billions in value. The company has about $2.2 billion in liquidity and $209 billion in assets. The move aims to shore up confidence amid concerns of a financial contagion, but emergency measures have so far failed to dispel worries.

images.alt_text: Digital Core Reit said it has no banking relationship with fallen Silicon Valley Bank.
California banking regulators shut down Silicon Valley Bank on March 10 after a run on the lender, which had US$209 billion in assets at the end of 2022.
The FDIC is aiming to sell both SVB and Signature in their entirety, while offers for parts of the banks could be considered if whole company sales do not happen.

site_title: Vietnam's VinFast says 3 sales executives have left EV firm
summary: Vietnam-based electric vehicle startup VinFast announced that three senior sales and customer-service executives have left the company, including deputy chief executive Gareth Dunsmore, chief marketing officer Greg Tebbutt, and former chief service officer Craig Westbrook. The departures come amid a delayed and costly rollout of VinFast's first EVs in California, its debut overseas market. The company is facing challenges in the US EV market, where established competitors like Tesla are driving down prices and preparing new models. VinFast is looking to break into the market despite its own financial struggles, which resulted in a $2.1 billion loss in 2022.

images.alt_text: VinFast plans to make EVs at its factory in Haiphong in Vietnam’s north and ship them to the US.

site_title: Britain’s healthcare workers to decide on new pay offer by end of April, say unions
summary: Britain's healthcare workers will decide by the end of April whether to accept a government pay proposal offering a 5% wage increase for 1 million nurses, paramedics, and other workers. The offer includes a one-off payment and a 5% pay rise, but unions have criticized it as below inflation. Three unions have recommended acceptance, while Unite has not, citing concerns over the non-consolidated lump sum and the offer's impact on the recruitment crisis. Strikes have been paused pending the decision, which will end if members approve the deal in votes or consultations.

images.alt_text: Unions representing National Health Service workers say that the government has imposed years of real-term pay cuts.

site_title: UK pension funds flee the equity market, adding to London woes
summary: UK pension funds significantly reduced their exposure to British equities, cutting allocation from 73% in 1997 to 27% in 2021, resulting in a £400 billion (S$652.4 billion) loss of demand. This shift is partly due to an accounting change in 2000, leading to pension funds selling equities and investing in bonds. The reduction in demand has created a self-fulfilling downward spiral, contributing to a deep valuation discount for London listings, with companies like Softbank's Arm listing in the US instead.

site_title: YouTube restores Donald Trump’s channel
summary: YouTube has lifted restrictions on former US President Donald Trump's channel after a more than two-year suspension following the 2021 Capitol Hill riot. Trump now has access to key platforms for fundraising and reaching his 146 million followers. The decision was made after evaluating the risk of real-world violence while allowing voters to hear from major national candidates. Trump's campaign team has not commented on the move, which comes as he prepares for another presidential run in 2024.

site_title: Creating a future in which plastic is always recycled
summary: Singapore aims to increase its plastic recycling rate to 70% by 2030, with a focus on implementing better waste management systems, educating consumers, and scaling up advanced recycling technology. The country has already seen improvements, with 6% of plastic waste recycled in 2021, and the global recycled plastics market projected to grow to $43.5 billion by 2026. Researchers have found that plastic can have a smaller environmental footprint than alternatives, and new technologies like chemical recycling can process mixed plastic waste into valuable products.

images.alt_text: A garbage collector gathering recyclable plastic at the Ban Tarn landfill site in Chiang Mai, Thailand.
Among the G20 countries that have yet to introduce national bans on single-use plastic products are Brazil, the United States, Indonesia and Turkey, the report said.

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding unit ordered to wind up over unpaid US$4.8 million debt
summary: Singapore's High Court has ordered Yangzijiang Shipping to be liquidated due to an unpaid debt of over $4.8 million to Liberian company Trinity Seatrading. The debt arose from a botched sale of an oil tanker, with Trinity Seatrading seeking monetary compensation of $3.25 million and interest. Yangzijiang Shipping had transferred its stakes in at least 40 subsidiaries to a sister company, raising concerns about the value of these assets. The company has 28 days to file an appeal against the winding-up order.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Trinity Seatrading’s application, without stating Yangzijiang Shipping’s alleged debt amount, will be heard by Singapore High Court on Jan 20.

site_title: Majority of EC World Reit’s lenders agree to extend repayment deadline to Apr 30
summary: Majority of EC World Reit's lenders agree to extend the repayment deadline to April 30, with 86% of onshore lenders and 89% of offshore lenders approving the extension, subject to finalizing terms and conditions. The extension is part of a revised repayment plan to repay 25% of outstanding loans by December 31. The company had previously announced divestments to raise funds, but delays in lenders' internal approval processes led to an initial deadline extension to February 28.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
EC World Reit is in the process of completing proposed divestment of its indirect interests in Bei Gang Logistics (above).
As at Mar 7, EC World Reit has some S$57.7 million in offshore bank loans and S$81.2 million in onshore bank loans to repay.

site_title: Property portal 99.co raises US$11 million in Series C extension
summary: Property portal 99.co has raised US$11 million in an extension of its Series C fundraising round co-led by Gaw Capital Partners and OCBC NISP Ventura. The additional funding will support the 99 Group's growth and expansion through strategic partnerships and acquisitions. This round follows the initial Series C round in July last year, which raised US$52 million. Gaw Capital Partners contributed US$10 million, while OCBC NISP Ventura provided US$1 million. The funding will aid the company's expansion plans.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim

site_title: Sam Goi adds to Envictus and JB Foods stakes
summary: Institutional investors in Singapore were net sellers of stocks over the five sessions from Mar 10 to Mar 16, with a total outflow of S$107 million. The Straits Times Index declined 1.8%, while the Hang Seng Index and FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI fell 3.9% and 3.7%, respectively. UOB, DBS, and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding led the net institutional outflow, while Sembcorp Industries, Wilmar International, and OCBC led the net institutional inflow. 23 companies conducted share buybacks, with Sembcorp Industries and OCBC being the top two. Director and substantial shareholder transactions also saw over 100 changes, with Wilmar International chairman Kuok Khoon Hong increasing his stake and Hong Lai Huat Group deputy chairman Ong Bee Huat acquiring shares in his own company. Envictus International Holdings non-executive director Sam Goi increased his stake in the company, and JB Foods non-executive director Sam Goi also acquired shares in the company.

images.alt_text: A man walks in front of the Singapore Exchange building (SGX) on July 21, 2022.

site_title: Credit Suisse loses equities heads in Asia as exodus worsens
summary: Credit Suisse is experiencing an exodus of senior executives in its Asia-Pacific equities business, with several key heads departing amid concerns over the bank's financial health. Nick Silver, head of equities for Japan, and Jonathan Jenkins, head of equity sales, are among those leaving, while Chris Prasertsintanah, head of equities for South Asia, has also departed. The departures follow a crisis of confidence for the bank, which has tapped the Swiss National Bank for billions of francs and offered to repurchase debt, following the failure of Silicon Valley Bank.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse shares surged by as much as 32 per cent in the first few minutes of trade on news of the lifeline, and were last up 24 per cent in heavy volume, reversing some of the losses that stripped off a quarter of its market value the day before.

site_title: Huawei ban would have significant impact on German mobile network: ministry
summary: Germany's economy ministry warns that a ban on Huawei and ZTE components could significantly impact the country's mobile network, potentially disrupting mobile operators' ability to fulfill coverage requirements. The review of telecom tech suppliers, not targeting specific manufacturers, may lead to extensive replacements, with operators not receiving compensation under current legislation. Critics claim Huawei's close ties to Beijing's security services could grant Chinese spies access to essential infrastructure, while the companies dispute these claims, citing protectionist motives.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Huawei logo is seen during Munich Auto Show, IAA Mobility 2021 in Munich, Germany, September 8, 2021. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo

site_title: US: Stocks end lower as banking shares resume sell-off
summary: US stocks ended lower on Friday as banking shares resumed their sell-off, with First Republic Bank's stock plummeting 33% despite a $30 billion rescue package. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.2% and the S&P 500 declined 1.1%, while the Nasdaq Composite Index dropped 0.7%. Analysts expect next week's monetary policy decision by the US Federal Reserve to be closely watched, amid ongoing concerns about the banking sector and inflation.

images.alt_text: First Republic’s shares have been hit hard by the turmoil in the banking sector, after the demise of three lenders knocked confidence in the industry and saw customers of regional lenders pull deposits.

Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange on March 3, 2023. - Wall Street stocks rose early Friday, extending a market upswing despite lingering worries about the likelihood of more central bank interest rate hikes. (Photo by TIMOTHY A. CLARY / AFP)

Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange on March 3, 2023. - Wall Street stocks rose early Friday, extending a market upswing despite lingering worries about the likelihood of more central bank interest rate hikes. (Photo by TIMOTHY A. CLARY / AFP)

site_title: WeWork reaches deals to cut debt, extend maturities
summary: WeWork has struck deals to cut debt by $1.5 billion and extend maturities, infusing the company with $540 million in new funding. The flexible-workspace provider aims to preserve cash amid a potential economic downturn. Key investor SoftBank Group's $1 billion unsecured notes will be converted to equity. WeWork expects to turn a core profit this year, thanks to cost cuts, and has less than $2 billion in net debt once the deal closes. The company faces a likely fallout from mass layoffs and a forecast of weak current-quarter revenue.

images.alt_text: In February, WeWork forecast weak current-quarter revenue in a sign that its business was feeling the heat of mass layoffs as companies reduce their real estate footprint.

site_title: Tapping creativity at the Underdog Inn
summary: Underdog Inn in New York City offers a unique cocktail experience with 12 draught cocktails on tap, featuring ingredients such as honey ginger and roasted chicory. The selection allows for efficient service and easy sampling, with options ranging from simple to complex flavors. The bar's retro hip-hop vibe is reflected in its drinks menu, and the nitro-charged cocktails offer a creamier texture. The concept also incorporates art and music, with prints of Jean-Michel Basquiat's paintings adorning the walls and a DJ Kool Herc-inspired comic book menu.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng
Nighthawks, the bar's signature drink, is a hot-and-cold variation on the espresso martini.
The NSC Gin & Tonic is inspired by childhood memories of snacking on guava slices dusted with plum powder.

site_title: UBS explores buying all or parts of Credit Suisse
summary: UBS is exploring acquiring all or parts of Credit Suisse, amid a crisis of confidence for the Swiss bank. Swiss regulators are urging UBS to consider various solutions, including a combination with Credit Suisse, to stabilize the bank. The Swiss National Bank and regulator Finma are orchestrating talks between the two banks' boards, which are set to meet this weekend. UBS prefers to focus on its standalone strategy and is hesitant to take on risks related to Credit Suisse, while Credit Suisse seeks time to implement its turnaround plan after receiving a $54 billion credit line from the central bank.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse stock slumped as much as 31 per cent on Mar 15 when the chairman of its largest shareholder, Saudi National Bank, ruled out investing any more in the company.
Wealthy Chinese clients have become much more worried about parking money in Swiss banks because of the nation’s tough approach to applying sanctions.
FILE PHOTO: Switzerland's national flag flies above a logo of Swiss bank Credit Suisse in front of a branch office in Bern, Switzerland November 29, 2022. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: ComfortDelGro unit buys British private hire company for £7.25 million
summary: ComfortDelGro has acquired British private hire company Vedamain for £7.25 million (S$11.8 million) through an all-cash deal. Vedamain operates 500 private hire cars under the KingKabs brand in Chester, England. The acquisition has no material impact on ComfortDelGro's net tangible assets or earnings per share for the financial year ending Dec 31, 2023. The deal was funded through internal resources and was completed on a "willing buyer willing seller" basis.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
ComfortDelGro logo at the ComfortDelGro headquarters located along Braddell Road on March 6, 2023.

site_title: Vice-chairman of Thai Beverage, F&N and Frasers Property dies
summary: Khunying Wanna Sirivadhanabhakdi, 79, vice-chairman of Thai Beverage, F&N, and Frasers Property, died on March 17. She was the wife of Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi, chairman of all three companies. The boards of the companies issued a joint statement expressing their condolences and thanking her for her contributions during her tenure as vice-chairman.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim

site_title: JPMorgan's Jamie Dimon plays key role in bank rescue, in echo of 2008
summary: Jamie Dimon, CEO of JPMorgan Chase, played a key role in a bank rescue effort following the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank. He consulted with Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and Fed Chair Jerome Powell to boost confidence in the financial system. Dimon's efforts helped persuade 11 major US banks to deposit $30 billion into First Republic Bank, a regional lender facing financial instability. The move came as a lifeline to First Republic, but shares remained down, indicating lingering concerns over the financial sector. Dimon's leadership and expertise in the industry helped ease crisis fears, but investors remain worried about the situation.

images.alt_text: A trader works at the post where First Republic Bank stock is traded on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., March 16, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid
First Republic’s shares have lost over two-thirds of their value in the past seven days and are down more than 72 per cent month-to-date.

site_title: Coinbase is in talks with clients about starting new overseas crypto platform
summary: Coinbase is in talks with clients about establishing a new overseas crypto-trading platform, potentially to hedge against the intensifying US crackdown on cryptocurrencies. The talks are confidential, but the company has expressed concerns about the regulatory environment in the US. An international platform could diversify Coinbase's revenue stream, as its existing businesses, such as coin custody and stablecoins, have come under increased scrutiny in the US. The move follows regulatory actions against crypto companies in the US and the shuttering of crypto-friendly banks.

site_title: The size factor matters for actual portfolios
summary: The size factor, which suggests small- and medium-cap stocks outperform large-caps, has been debated among researchers. Recent studies argue that its utility is questionable, citing weak empirical evidence and theoretical support. However, a multi-factor portfolio analysis shows that the size factor improves the Sharpe ratio, despite its marginal statistical interest. The size factor's positive weight in the optimal portfolio demonstrates its diversification benefits, making it a valuable addition to a multi-factor portfolio, even with close to no premium.

images.alt_text: Joseph Simonian
The book, "The Enduring Value of Roger Murray'', is a fresh look at Murray and restores one's confidence in fundamental analysis, especially value investing.
Based on an extensive review of literature, it appears there is no tradeoff between diversity and investment performance.

site_title: UK household inflation outlook eases ahead of rate decision
summary: Households in the UK have revised down their inflation expectations, with 3.9% forecast for the next 12 months, down from 4.8% in November. This decrease indicates growing confidence in the Bank of England's ability to control the cost-of-living crisis. UK 2-year yields fell, and money markets eased rate hike wagers, pricing a 4.27% terminal rate by June. Official data may show inflation falling from 10.1% to single digits for the first time since last August.

images.alt_text: Hunt says that although headline corporate tax will increase, most companies will be able to offset this with tax breaks for investments.
Striking junior doctors, civil servants and teachers attend a rally at Trafalgar Square in London, UK, on Wednesday, March 15, 2023.

Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt has ruled out a major spending spree or big tax cuts in his budget plan but confirmed a three-month extension of energy bill subsidies for households and extended a decade-long fuel duty freeze.

site_title: China Jan-Feb fiscal revenue shrinks despite pick-up in economy
summary: China's fiscal revenue fell 1.2% in the first two months of 2023, despite signs of economic recovery after the lifting of pandemic curbs. Revenues totaled 4.56 trillion yuan, while expenditures rose 7% to 4.09 trillion yuan. State land sale revenue slumped 29% due to cautious property developers. The central bank announced a reserve cut to support growth momentum, but warned of uneven recovery and debt risks for some local governments. Economic growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: The People’s Bank of China (PBOC) said it would cut the reserve requirement ratio (RRR) for all banks, except those that have implemented a 5 per cent reserve ratio, by 25 basis points (bps), effective Mar 27.

The dramatic policy U-turn as Beijing tightens its grip on a broad range of areas including finance, technology and data security, threatened business confidence and roiled the market, with bond trading volumes plunging over two days.

As China reopens after dropping its zero tolerance policy for Covid-19 in December, convincing foreign investors to return to China will help reinvigorate an economy that grew at its slowest rates last year in half a century.

site_title: Russian central bank retains hawkish stance as it keeps rates unchanged
summary: Russia's central bank maintained its hawkish stance, keeping interest rates unchanged at 7.5% despite a widening budget deficit and labour shortages posing inflationary risks. Annual inflation slowed to 7.65% as of March 13, leading to a temporary drop below the 4% target in coming months. The bank remains concerned about inflationary risks and may consider rate hikes at upcoming meetings, with analysts predicting a possible increase to around 8.5% by the end of the year.

site_title: Europe: Shares record worst week in five months on bank crisis jitters
summary: European shares logged their worst week in five months, falling 4% this week, due to concerns over a brewing global banking crisis. A US$30 billion lifeline by large US banks for embattled First Republic Bank and a mega central bank loan by Credit Suisse failed to alleviate fears. The bank index lost 2.6% and Stoxx 600 declined 1.3% on Friday. Eurozone inflation eased, but underlying price growth continued to accelerate. Investors are now focusing on the Federal Reserve's meeting next week, with traders expecting a 25 bps hike.

images.alt_text: The safe-haven US dollar rose sharply, with the US dollar index surging 0.9 per cent to 104.65.
The Stoxx 600 closed the day 1.3 per cent higher after dropping 0.6 per cent and touching a fresh 10-week low following the rate hike decision.

site_title: First Republic rout resumes as rescue package fails to stem drop
summary: First Republic Bank shares plummeted 23% on Friday, marking their worst week ever, amid the turmoil in the banking sector. The lender reported a dwindling cash position and suspended dividend payments after the US Federal Reserve reported its borrowings varied from $20 billion to $109 billion. Analysts downgraded the stock to neutral, citing "unprecedented uncertainty" and a potential need for a capital raise. The move follows a volatile session on Thursday when Wall Street's biggest banks pledged $30 billion in aid, but some investors questioned the move, calling it a "bad policy" to spread risk.

images.alt_text: The plan to seek bankruptcy protection comes after the tech lender said on Mar 13 it was planning to explore strategic alternatives for its businesses, including the holding company, SVB Capital and SVB Securities.

site_title: PSA International’s 2022 net profit rises 13.5% to S$1.6 billion
summary: PSA International's 2022 net profit increased 13.5% to S$1.6 billion, driven by a 71.2% jump in group revenue due to business acquisitions and higher storage income. The company handled 90.9 million shipping containers, a 0.7% contraction from the previous year.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
PSA International operates more than 60 deep-sea, rail and inland terminals across 42 countries.
Flagship PSA Singapore contributed 37 million TEUs in 2022, down 0.7 per cent.

PSA, the world’s second-biggest container terminal operator, whose global network encompasses 160 locations in 42 countries, had acquired the stake in the Hong Kong-based conglomerate’s ports business for US$4.4 billion in 2006.

site_title: Eurozone inflation eases in Feb but core prices pick up
summary: Eurozone inflation eased to 8.5% in February, down from 8.6% in January, despite a surge in services costs. Underlying price growth accelerated to 5.6%, fueled by rising wages, and is expected to remain above the ECB's 2% target through 2025. This could prolong overall inflation, making it harder to tame. Energy costs are expected to continue falling, but underlying price growth is likely to remain sticky, causing concern among policymakers.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians pass the Reserve Bank of Australia. Though the 2 per cent inflation target has become widespread, central banks can afford to be flexible in getting there.

site_title: Are young Singaporeans spending too much?
summary: Young Singaporeans are often perceived as financially irresponsible, but experts argue this is not the case. According to a DBS report, millennials' expenses rose by almost 30% between 2021 and 2022, hinting at pent-up spending. However, research by Endowus found that younger Singaporeans are more financially aware than given credit for, with a significant increase in the awareness of retirement savings and a desire to build wealth earlier. Many young Singaporeans are prioritizing saving for retirement, homeownership, and financial freedom, and are using online platforms to invest and manage their finances. Experts caution that while digital savviness is on the rise, it's not the same as financial savviness, and young investors need to be mindful of the risks of speculative investments.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim

A 2022 study found that negative emotions influenced people’s motivation to shop. Angry individuals reported spending to regain control, while those who felt depressed, apathetic or bored would shop to make themselves feel better.
Credit card penetration in Singapore is high with over 2.4 million people having more than four credit card accounts according to Credit Bureau Singapore.
money, home, coin

site_title: WHO sees Covid-19 posing similar threat to flu this year
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) expressed confidence that the Covid-19 pandemic will settle down to a threat similar to the flu by 2023, potentially allowing the declaration of an end to the emergency. The WHO chief, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, stated that countries should have acted sooner, but the organization is increasingly hopeful about the pandemic phase coming to a close.

images.alt_text: Japan is one of the last major economies to relax official guidance on the coverings, whose usage has been nearly universal throughout the country even without firm regulations or penalties governing their use.

site_title: CapitaLand in talks to buy Vietnam property assets from Vinhomes: sources
summary: CapitaLand Group is in talks to acquire Vietnam's Vinhomes property assets worth approximately US$1.5 billion, marking one of the largest real-estate transactions in South-east Asia. The deal comes as Vietnam's property sector struggles with a cash crunch following an anti-graft campaign. The value of the deal is still being negotiated, with talks reaching an advanced stage.

images.alt_text: Vietnam EV maker VinFast files for US$2b US IPO
CGS-CIMB has an "add" call on Capitaland Investment and a target price of S$4.50.

site_title: OECD raises global growth forecast but recovery 'fragile'
summary: The OECD has raised its global economic growth forecast to 2.6% for this year, citing improved business and consumer sentiment, falling food and energy prices, and China's full reopening. However, the recovery is considered "fragile" due to vulnerabilities seen in the US bank sector. The growth forecast remains below the 3.2% expansion seen in 2022.

images.alt_text: One hot spot for zones is Dubai, with “legal bubble-domes” dedicated to different activities: Healthcare City is next to Media City is next to Internet City, each with a bespoke set of laws drawn up with foreign investors in mind.

site_title: Sentosa Cove property sales pick up in H2 2022
summary: Sentosa Cove luxury house sales increased by almost 60% in value to S$207.5 million in the July-December 2022 period, with 10 units sold. This represents a significant jump from the first six months, when eight bungalows were sold for S$130.3 million. The increase is attributed to the high-end landed market softening elsewhere, allowing Sentosa Cove to attract buyers.

images.alt_text: List Sotheby’s International Realty’s senior associate vice-president Steve Tay believes that 2023 will be a record year for rental markets, with demand continuing to be strong as China reopens its borders and more foreigners, especially from North Asia, decide to set up a base in Singapore.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's non-oil and non-liquefied petroleum (NODX) exports to its top 10 markets declined in February for the fifth straight month, according to data from Enterprise Singapore. The key exports contracted 15.6% sequentially, marking a sharp turn for the worse. Despite this, the year-on-year decline eased relative to the previous month. This decline is attributed to a slowdown in demand for Singapore's key exports.

site_title: China starts the year in deficit as land sales continue to slump
summary: China's government started the year in a deficit for the first time since 2020, with land sales revenue falling 29% year-over-year to 563 billion yuan. This slump in revenue, combined with a record 9 trillion yuan shortfall from last year's abandoned Covid Zero policy and housing crisis, has raised concerns about the country's high debt levels and potential for limited stimulus to spur growth. Finance Minister Liu Kun warned of "outstanding conflicts" between income and spending.

images.alt_text: Data this week showed China is gradually recovering since pandemic curbs were abruptly dropped in December, but the rebound has been uneven.

The People’s Bank of China (PBOC) said it would cut the reserve requirement ratio (RRR) for all banks, except those that have implemented a 5 per cent reserve ratio, by 25 basis points (bps), effective Mar 27.

site_title: German firms in Singapore see ‘psychological distress’ among staff from rising rents: Survey
summary: A survey of German firms in Singapore found that nearly half anticipate rising housing rents by 30-50% in 2023, with 16% expecting even higher increases. This comes after private housing rents surged by nearly 30% in 2022, causing psychological distress and lower work performance among staff. The survey highlights the impact of rising rents on German companies and their employees in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Singapore saw annual rents jump 28 per cent in the quarter from a year earlier, according to a report by Knight Frank.

site_title: US factory output increases in February for a second month; consumer sentiment ebbs in March
summary: US factory output increased for a second month in February, driven by improving supply chains and a rebound in orders, suggesting firmer economic growth in Q1. The 0.1% gain followed an upwardly revised 1.3% advance in January. In contrast, US consumer sentiment fell for the first time in four months in March, with households expecting inflation to subside over the next 12 months.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - DECEMBER 02: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange during morning tradingon December 02, 2022 in New York City. Stocks opened low this morning and are expected to rise after the release of the November jobs report that showed 263,000 jobs added in the month amid the surging rate hikes by the Federal Reserve.   Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Michael M. Santiago / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: KTL Global’s subsidiary served with S$203,300 claim by Fastfixs Systems
summary: A subsidiary of KTL Global, Tianci Agritech, has been served an originating claim of S$203,300 by the State Courts. The claim was raised by contractor Fastfixs Systems, alleging Tianci Agritech owed them this sum for construction works. This is part of KTL Global's ongoing legal woes, with the company's stock price currently at 0.8%.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
pixgeneric- Generics of Sub/State court exteriors and lawyers

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as bank worries linger
summary: US stocks opened lower on Friday as investors remained cautious about a potential banking crisis, despite the country's largest banks rescuing troubled regional lender First Republic Bank. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 29.23 points, or 0.09%, to 32,217.32, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. The market concerns persist despite the recent bank rescue efforts, indicating lingering worries about the stability of the financial sector.

site_title: Credit Suisse and the crazy, rich, anxious Asians
summary: Wealthy Chinese clients are increasingly worried about parking their money in Swiss banks due to the nation's strict sanctions approach. Credit Suisse, facing a record slump in its share price and a spike in credit default swaps, has announced plans to borrow up to $54 billion from the Swiss National Bank and repurchase senior debt securities. The lender aims to restore confidence and prevent a mass exodus of funds from the bank.

images.alt_text: A woman walks near the logo of Credit Suisse outside its office building in Hong Kong, China, March 16, 2023. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu

site_title: Petronas wants to extend LNG contracts with Japan
summary: Petronas, Malaysia's state oil and gas firm, wants to extend its long-term contracts with Japanese gas distributors Tokyo Gas and Osaka Gas to supply liquefied natural gas (LNG). Vice President Shamsairi Ibrahim said the company aims to continue supplying LNG to Japan, which imported 97.9 billion cubic meters last year, and potentially increase volume. Petronas is also exploring entry into Japan's offshore wind power market, with talks underway with local partners.

images.alt_text: A logo of Petronas is seen at their office in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, April 27, 2022. Picture taken on April 27, 2022. REUTERS/Hasnoor Hussain

site_title: TikTok’s Chinese ownership, security concerns spark bans across nations
summary: The US has demanded that TikTok's Chinese owners, ByteDance, divest their stakes in the app or face a possible US ban. This move follows the introduction of a new US legislation that would allow the White House to ban TikTok or other foreign-based technologies if they pose a national security risk. Several countries, including New Zealand, India, and Canada, have already banned or restricted TikTok due to security concerns and proximity to the Chinese government.

images.alt_text: TikTok will be banned on all devices with access to New Zealand’s parliamentary network by the end of March, said Parliamentary Service chief executive Rafael Gonzalez-Montero.
TikTok’s leadership is now considering more drastic measures to keep operating in the US, including separating from its parent, according to people familiar with the matter.

The TikTok logo on a smartphone arranged in the Brooklyn borough of New York, US, on Thursday, March 9, 2023. The US is moving closer to restricting access to the popular video-sharing app TikTok, with Senate Intelligence Committee Chairman Mark Warner set to unveil a bill Tuesday that the Biden administration is poised to support, according to people familiar with the issue. Photographer: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg
It is the first time under the administration of Democratic President Joe Biden that a potential ban on TikTok has been threatened.
TikTok agreed last year to implement a number of measures to address US officials’ security concerns.

site_title: Australian surfs for 40 hours to smash world record
summary: Australian surfer Blake Johnston set a new world record for the longest surfing session, riding over 700 waves in 40 hours to break the previous record of 30 hours and 11 minutes. Johnston, 40, raised over A$200,000 for mental health and braved pitch-black seas and shark-infested waters to achieve the feat. He was carried off the beach by friends after finally hanging up his surfboard, and his official record time was not immediately known.

images.alt_text: Novak Djokovic in action at the Adelaide International earlier this week. His unvaccinated status means he will miss two top events in the US in March.
Photos taken in 1937 by the explorer Bradford Washburn with the current topography on the Walsh glacier in Kluane National Park and Reserve in Canada in August 2022.

site_title: Credit Suisse faces first US investor lawsuit over meltdown
summary: Credit Suisse has faced its first US investor lawsuit, alleging the bank made "materially false and misleading statements" in its 2021 annual report. The complaint, filed by the Rosen Law Firm, claims the bank overstated its financial prospects to shareholders. The lawsuit includes allegations against Chairman Axel Lehmann and other current and former officers, citing instances of misrepresentation and material weaknesses in internal controls. The complaint was filed following significant stock price declines following the bank's disclosure of internal control issues in March.

images.alt_text: First Republic Bank's cash injection has also been engineered by government officials.

site_title: Indonesia pledges policy transparency with new palm oil exchange
summary: Indonesia plans to channel crude palm oil exports via a futures exchange starting from June, aiming to improve policymaking and avoid export bans. The move aims to create a benchmark price, similar to those in Kuala Lumpur and Rotterdam, and increase transparency. The plan comes after last year's haphazard policymaking, which led to a three-week export ban. Industry groups have expressed concerns about additional costs, but authorities are working to exempt transactions from value-added tax and ensure timely data release.

site_title: US$2.7 trillion wall of expiring options a worry for traders reeling from bank crisis
summary: US traders face a potentially volatile options expiration on Friday, with an estimated $2.7 trillion in derivatives contracts set to mature. This could lead to a spike in trading volume and price swings, exacerbating concerns about the global banking crisis and recession. Investors are seeking bearish options, and market makers are caught in a "short gamma" stance, making them more sensitive to market fluctuations. The event may also coincide with a rebalancing of benchmark indexes, potentially sparking significant single-day volume.

images.alt_text: Wall Street has already begun to take a more cautious approach to developing-market assets as an early-year rally fades and a soft landing for the global economy appears.

site_title: Japan pushes plans to raise birthrates by last chance deadline
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has announced policies to ease financial burdens on parents and raise birthrates, as the country faces a declining birthrate that threatens its long-term economic prospects. The government plans to enhance childcare allowances, provide housing assistance, reduce education costs, and raise wages for younger workers. Kishida aims to increase paternity leave to 50% by 2025 and 85% by 2030 to encourage men to participate in childcare. The period to 2030 is considered Japan's "last chance" to reverse the declining birthrate.

site_title: Singapore stocks climb on Friday to end volatile week; STI up 0.9%
summary: Singapore stocks ended the week on a positive note, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.9% to close at 3,183.28. The rebound marked a week of volatile trading, with 2.3 billion securities worth S$1.9 billion traded. The market saw 307 gainers and 233 losers, with the STI up 0.2% from last Friday's close. The gains followed a similar trend in the region, as investors turned more optimistic.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
In early trade on Friday, Hong Kong rose more than one per cent while Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta were also in the green.

site_title: Thailand’s gradual policy tightening still appropriate, central bank says
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, has reaffirmed that its gradual policy tightening approach remains suitable for the economy. The strategy has helped prevent a rapid rise in private sector borrowing costs and allowed for sectoral adjustments. Deputy governor Mathee Supapongse stated that the bank is prepared to adjust the pace and timing of policy tightening if the economic outlook and inflation shift. This move aims to support the economy's recovery driven by increased tourism and domestic spending.

site_title: Japan’s labour unions confirm three-decade-high wage hikes of 3.8%
summary: Japan's major companies agreed to the largest pay rises in a quarter century, with average wage hikes of 3.8% for the coming fiscal year, according to trade union confederation Rengo. This is the highest raise in about three decades, with top firms agreeing to the hikes at annual labour talks. The move is seen as a response to rising living costs, with Prime Minister Fumio Kishida calling for higher wages. Rengo will update the pay negotiation results in several stages before compiling the final results in summer.

site_title: Vietnam plans tighter limits on stakes in banks in blow to foreign investors
summary: Vietnam's central bank is proposing tighter limits on foreign investors' stakes in banks, reducing individual investors' shares to 3% from 5% and institutional shareholders' shares to 10% from 15%. The move aims to reduce risks of market manipulation and follows several cases of fraud, including a suspected manipulation of Eximbank's share value. Foreign investors, who are already limited to a 30% stake in banks, may be impacted by the new caps, which could exacerbate liquidity challenges in the sector.

site_title: Fed to stay the course with 25 bps rate hike on March 22, says poll
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates by 25 basis points on March 22, bringing the federal funds rate to 4.75-5.00%, according to a Reuters poll of 82 economists. Despite recent banking sector turmoil, 76 economists predict the rate hike, with 56 expecting another hike in the second quarter. Most economists, 65%, believe the Federal Open Market Committee will maintain its "higher for longer" stance and keep rates on hold for the remainder of the year.

images.alt_text: WASHINGTON, DC - FEBRUARY 07: Federal Reserve Board Chairman Jerome Powell speaks during an interview by David Rubenstein, Chairman of the Economic Club of Washington, D.C., at the Renaissance Hotel on February 7, 2023 in Washington, DC. The Federal Reserve announced last week a 0.25 percentage point interest rate increase to a range of 4.50% to 4.75%.   Julia Nikhinson/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Julia Nikhinson / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Bailing out retail or commercial banks is bad business for central banks
summary: The US government's recent interventions in the banking sector, including a bailout of Silicon Valley Bank and a cash injection for First Republic Bank, have raised concerns about moral hazards and the government's increasing role in deposit insurance. The rapid spread of news and high inflation have fueled a financial crisis, with bank stocks plummeting and contagion spreading across the Atlantic. Regulators are struggling to contain inflation, and some experts warn that the government's actions may create unforeseen consequences, including a potential repeat of the 2008 financial crisis. The US Federal Reserve may need to reconsider its tightening moves, while the European Central Bank sticks to its inflation-fighting stance.

images.alt_text: The Fed had unveiled the scheme alongside the Treasury and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation on Sunday night, as authorities looked to prevent other banks from running into the liquidity issues that ultimately doomed California’s SVB.
First Republic’s shares have lost over two-thirds of their value in the past seven days and are down more than 72 per cent month-to-date.

Some of the biggest US banking names including JPMorgan Chase & Co, Citigroup, Bank of America, Wells Fargo & Co, Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley poured US$30 billion into First Republic Bank on Thursday.
The FDIC is aiming to sell both SVB and Signature in their entirety, while offers for parts of the banks could be considered if whole company sales do not happen.
The ECB said the elevated level of uncertainty reinforces the importance of a data-dependent approach to the Governing Council’s policy rate decisions.

Customers exit Silicon Valley Bank headquarters in Santa Clara, California, US, on Monday, March 13, 2023. The collapse of Silicon Valley Bank has prompted a global reckoning at venture capital and private equity firms, which found themselves suddenly exposed all together to the tech industry's money machine. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

Goldman Sachs would buy a US$21.5 billion bond portfolio from SVB to boost its coffers, after startups began pulling their deposits from the technology-focused lender, which does business as Silicon Valley Bank.

site_title: Japan to lift restrictions on chip material exports to South Korea
summary: Japan plans to ease licensing requirements on essential ingredients for the manufacture of displays and semiconductors, including fluorinated polyimide, hydrogen fluoride, and photoresists. The move comes after South Korea agreed to finance a foundation to address forced labor disputes and drop its complaint to the World Trade Organization. Shares of Korean electronics makers surged, with SK Hynix, Samsung Electronics, and LG Electronics rising 7.3%, 2%, and 1.7% respectively. The announcement was made during the first formal summit between Japan and South Korea leaders in over a decade.

images.alt_text: The hope of the Chips and Science Act is to revitalise US semiconductor manufacturing after decades of production shifting to Asia.

site_title: China cuts banks’ reserve ratio for first time in 2023 to aid recovery
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, cut the reserve requirement ratio (RRR) for all banks except those with a 5% RRR by 25 basis points, effective March 27, to aid economic recovery. The move aims to keep liquidity ample and support a nascent economic rebound. The cut is the first in 2023 and follows data showing a gradual but uneven recovery in the economy. Analysts estimate the move will free up over $97.5 billion in long-term liquidity. The central bank has promised to make its policy "precise and forceful" to support the economy.

images.alt_text: The dramatic policy U-turn as Beijing tightens its grip on a broad range of areas including finance, technology and data security, threatened business confidence and roiled the market, with bond trading volumes plunging over two days.
The line between the party and the government has become decisively blurred, so there is no way that the new financial watchdogs will contradict with what the party wants.

site_title: Further weakness ahead for Singapore exports after 5 months of contraction: economists
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) shrank 15.6% year-on-year in February, easing from the 25% tumble in the previous month. This marks the fifth consecutive month of contraction. Economists predict further weakness in global demand, citing monetary policy tightening and economic slowdowns in developed markets. While China's reopening has lifted some exports, the impact is limited, with NODX still down 25% year-on-year. Despite this, economists remain optimistic about economic growth, citing "pockets of resilience" in sectors such as tourism-related services.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Generic property landscape in Singapore
For the upward momentum in Singapore's PMI to be sustainable, a further improvement in new export orders is key, says chief economist Selena Ling.
Economists also disagree on the likelihood of a global recession, which will impact demand for Singapore's exports.

site_title: China’s DCP Capital aims to sell Singapore tech firm MFS for at least US$550 million: sources
summary: Chinese private equity firm DCP Capital aims to sell its Singaporean tech firm MFS Technology for at least $550 million. MFS, which manufactures circuit boards for automotive, industrial, and data storage, was acquired by DCP in 2018. The sale process has begun, with initial bids expected by late May. Financial sponsors and strategic buyers are targeting the deal, with BDA Partners and Jefferies advising DCP on the sale. MFS has seen earnings of $46 million in 2022.

site_title: DC Reit not exposed to SVB, First Republic; share price correction makes for attractive valuation: analysts
summary: Digital Core Reit (DC Reit) has denied having any banking relationship with Silicon Valley Bank or First Republic Bank, despite 30% of its assets under management being from Silicon Valley. Analysts remain positive on the Reit's prospects, citing well-capitalized tenants and potential income guarantees in case of a tenant default. The Reit's share price correction is seen as an attractive valuation, with analysts forecasting yields of 7.5-9.5% in 2023 and 2024. An index inclusion and share buyback are also expected, boosting the stock's investability and liquidity.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

Some of the biggest US banking names including JPMorgan Chase & Co, Citigroup, Bank of America, Wells Fargo & Co, Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley poured US$30 billion into First Republic Bank on Thursday.
California banking regulators shut down Silicon Valley Bank on March 10 after a run on the lender, which had US$209 billion in assets at the end of 2022.

site_title: Xi Jinping to visit Russia next week
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping will visit Russia next week from March 20 to 22, marking his first trip to Moscow in nearly four years. The visit aims to deepen the partnership and strategic cooperation between the two countries, including on the international stage, with important bilateral documents expected to be signed.

images.alt_text: Flags of China and Russia are displayed in this illustration picture taken March 24, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Getting a workout on the closed streets of KL with OCBC Cycle
summary: The OCBC Cycle Kuala Lumpur 2023 event, held on March 12, welcomed over 2,500 cyclists for a 21-km and 42-km ride through the city's closed streets. The 21-km route took riders past iconic landmarks such as the Petronas Twin Towers, National Mosque of Malaysia, and KL railway station, before returning to Dataran Merdeka. The event marked the return of the OCBC Cycle after a three-year hiatus due to the Covid-19 pandemic, and was held in humid conditions at 6 am.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
This year, OCBC Cycle introduces two new races — the 500 km Virtual Ride and the Indoor Ride by Shimano.
More than 1,500 participants signed up for one of 12 spin sessions, held as part of this year’s OCBC Cycle’s new Spin Ride category.

site_title: Global turmoil makes Australian banks' refinancing mountain a harder climb
summary: Australia's largest banks, including Westpac, ANZ, Commonwealth Bank, and National Australia Bank, are facing a more challenging refinancing process due to shrinking appetite for new debt in global markets. The banks aim to refinance A$300 billion worth of funding, a two-year record, amid concerns about bank stability and liquidity. Refinancing costs are expected to rise by 5-10 basis points, adding to banks' already pressured margins.

images.alt_text: Direct exposures among Fitch-rated APAC banks do not seem to be material to credit profiles for now, Fitch says.

site_title: Deutsche Bank CEO paid 8.9 million euros in 2022
summary: Deutsche Bank's CEO Christian Sewing received a bonus of 8.9 million euros in 2022, up from 8.8 million euros the previous year. This is part of a 2.1 billion euro bonus pool, the same as the previous year. Sewing led the bank through a successful turnaround plan, and the bank forecast a slight increase in revenue for 2023. The bank highlighted risks to its outlook, including economic and geopolitical factors, and inflation.

site_title: China fines Deloitte, suspends Beijing operation for 3 months for auditing negligence
summary: China's Ministry of Finance fined auditing firm Deloitte 211.9 million yuan for auditing negligence, suspending its Beijing operation for three months. The fine was given for Deloitte's failure to assess the asset quality of China Huarong Asset Management. China Huarong and its investment arms were also fined for internal governance lapses and risk control failures. The Ministry's decision aims to ensure compliance with auditing regulations and protect investors.

site_title: Hong Kong’s pro-Crypto pivot spurs data provider Kaiko to shift Asian base from Singapore
summary: Cryptocurrencies market data provider Kaiko plans to relocate its Asian headquarters from Singapore to Hong Kong, drawn by the city's push to establish a global hub for the digital-asset industry. Hong Kong's pro-crypto policy pivot and emerging from Covid-related curbs have attracted the Paris-based company, which feeds data to major exchanges. The move comes as Hong Kong develops crypto rules to encourage growth and protect investors, contrasting with a tightening crackdown on crypto in the US and proposed tighter rules in Singapore.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index climbed 1.23 per cent, or 235.93 points, to 19,439.84 on during early trade on Friday.
Hong Kong has noticed a marked outflowing of wealth management operations to Singapore, attributed to political risk.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Friday’s open; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.5% on Friday, tracking global gains, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,170.38. Gainers outnumbered losers 101 to 30, driven by solid gains in the banking sector worldwide, including a rescue package for embattled US lender First Republic. Key exports in Singapore contracted for the fifth straight month in February, albeit at a slower pace.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Stocks to watch: ThaiBev, Keppel, Singapore banks, Top Glove, Southern Alliance Mining

site_title: Kitchen Culture receives letter of demand from CDL unit for S$250,970 in unpaid rent
summary: Kitchen Culture, a kitchen solutions provider, received a letter of demand from CDL Properties for S$250,970 in unpaid rent for December 2022 to March 2023. The company plans to request an extension to March 31 to pay the outstanding sum, or face eviction. Kitchen Culture is currently securing financing to support its working capital, following a failed attempt to remove directors from its board in November last year. The company's shares have been suspended since July 2021.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim

Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture. Ooway Group became a substantial shareholder of Kitchen Culture in 2020, after it sold 30 per cent of its subsidiary Ooway Technology to Kitchen Culture in exchange for 90 million shares – around 21.2 per cent – of Kitchen Culture.

site_title: BT Market Focus: Bank fails and liquidity fears drive markets (Ep 36)
summary: Bank failures and liquidity fears drove markets this week, with significant market movements reported. Claressa Monteiro discusses the key drivers and analysis from SGX and The Business Times' newsdesk. Key highlights include SGX's wrap for the week, notable corporate news for investors, and other news of note. The podcast provides insights into market movements and drivers, offering analysis and perspectives on the current market landscape.

images.alt_text: Why global markets had a uneasy week.
Have rising interest rates reared their heads again?

site_title: Japan says closely coordinating with Bank of Japan, overseas authorities on banking issues
summary: Japan's Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki said the country is closely coordinating with the Bank of Japan and international authorities to monitor potential fallout from the crisis in Western banking, particularly after the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank in the US. Market turmoil has also affected Credit Suisse, fueling fears of a global financial crisis. Despite this, Japanese policymakers believe the possibility of another crisis is low. Suzuki emphasized the need for close coordination and careful monitoring of the economy and financial markets.

images.alt_text: The reversal of impacts from January’s Chinese New Year holidays meant that China was a lead cause behind the narrowing of Japan’s trade deficit last month.

site_title: Crypto-linked bank failures fuel regulation debate
summary: The global cryptocurrency market has experienced setbacks, scandals, and high-profile failures, prompting a regulatory rush to protect consumers from fraud and scams. The collapse of Silicon Valley Bank, Silvergate, and Signature, as well as the bankruptcy of FTX, has raised concerns about the sector's risks. Regulators are increasingly keen for oversight, citing the lack of transparency and the potential for illicit transactions. In response, the US, EU, and UK are introducing or consulting on regulatory frameworks, with the aim of protecting consumers and preventing further failures.

images.alt_text: Coinbase is optimistic about the transition to Web3 by a range of companies, says Singapore country director Hassan Ahmed.
Cryptocurrencies market data provider Kaiko plans to relocate its Asian headquarters to Hong Kong from Singapore, drawn by the city’s push to establish a global hub for the digital-asset industry.

site_title: China's US$21 trillion bond market breathes sigh of relief as data feeds resume
summary: China's US$21 trillion bond market has breathed a sigh of relief after regulators lifted a two-day ban on data feeds, allowing real-time bond price quotes to resume on most financial platforms. The ban, citing data security reasons, had driven down bond trading volumes by 25% over two days, with traders struggling to access price information. The reversal is seen as a policy U-turn, suggesting the industry-wide ban was ill-conceived, and traders expressed relief at the restored market activity.

images.alt_text: An employee counts genuine Chinese one-hundred yuan banknotes at the Counterfeit Notes Response Center of KEB Hana Bank in Seoul, South Korea, on Monday, Aug. 14, 2017. China's factory output and investment slowed somewhat in July, according to data released today, yet the yuan appeared not to take the data as negative, if in fact it's paying attention to it at all. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

site_title: Petronas plans to expand venture capital arm with up to US$200 million
summary: Petronas, Malaysia's national oil company, plans to expand its corporate venture capital arm by up to US$200 million, focusing on innovation and technology investments across Asia-Pacific. The expansion aims to diversify amid volatility in oil markets. Petronas Ventures, established in 2019, has invested in companies such as Brantree Technologies and Ekamor, and has also launched a renewable energy unit called Gentari, which aims to build 30-40 gigawatts of renewable energy capacity by 2030.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo of Petronas is seen at their office in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, April 27, 2022. REUTERS/Hasnoor Hussain/File Photo

site_title: Exposures to recent US bank failures appear limited for Apac banks, Fitch says
summary: Fitch Ratings says direct exposures to recent US bank failures, such as Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank, are limited for Asia-Pacific (Apac) banks under its coverage. Few Apac banks have depositor concentration profiles similar to SVB, and structural factors like regulation and expected liquidity support mitigate risks. However, Fitch notes potential risks of deposit volatility for digital banks in Apac, particularly in India and Japan, and warns that a shift in US monetary policy could negatively impact Apac banks' creditworthiness, potentially leading to easier monetary policy in Apac markets.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
California banking regulators shut down Silicon Valley Bank on March 10 after a run on the lender, which had US$209 billion in assets at the end of 2022.
First Republic Bank's cash injection has also been engineered by government officials.

On Friday, Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki said he was closely watching financial markets in and outside of Japan and for any impact from problems in the banking sector in the West on the Japanese economy.

Some of the biggest US banking names including JPMorgan Chase & Co, Citigroup, Bank of America, Wells Fargo & Co, Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley poured US$30 billion into First Republic Bank on Thursday.
The FDIC is aiming to sell both SVB and Signature in their entirety, while offers for parts of the banks could be considered if whole company sales do not happen.
Silicon Valley Bank headquarters in Santa Clara, California, US, on Thursday, March 9, 2023.
The Hang Seng gave up more than two per cent, while Tokyo, Sydney, Shanghai, Seoul, Singapore, Wellington, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta markets were also down on Thursday.

site_title: Credit Suisse sees central bank cash as buying time for overhaul
summary: Credit Suisse has secured 50 billion Swiss francs (S$72.4 billion) in central bank funding as "precautionary liquidity" to aid its overhaul amid a crisis of confidence. The move follows a 25% drop in shares and comes after the bank sought an emergency liquidity line from the Swiss National Bank. CEO Andre Helfenstein stated the funding will allow Credit Suisse to continue its transformation and reassure clients. The bank is working to stem customer outflows, but this process may take time.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse Group headquarters in Zurich. Photographer: Pascal Mora/Bloomberg

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts positive on Top Glove, but mixed on whether the worst is over
summary: Analysts have raised their target prices on Top Glove Corporation, citing a potential upside of 7.3% after the glove maker's recent earnings disappointed. UOB Kay Hian upgraded the company to "buy" with a target price of RM0.95, while CGS-CIMB raised its target price to RM0.82, but believes the worst may not be over. Maybank, however, reiterated "sell" and lowered its target price to RM0.57, citing a wider-than-expected net loss for FY2023. Despite the mixed views, analysts believe the worst is over for Top Glove and expect gradual increases in sales volume and average selling prices.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Top Glove says the long-term industry prospects are “still promising”.
Catalist-listed Medtecs gains as much as 19.4 per cent, while Top Glove rises 5.9 per cent.
This marked the second quarterly loss for the group since its listing in Malaysia in 2001, and the red ink more than tripled from last quarter’s net loss of RM52.6 million.

site_title: Cherry blossoms are back, but is Tokyo?
summary: Tokyo's cherry blossom viewing parties have resumed after the COVID-19 pandemic, marking the first year without government caution. However, the city's nightlife, particularly in the service sector, remains down 50% from pre-pandemic levels, with many bars and izakaya restaurants seeing sales decline 42% from 2019. This shift is attributed to changing attitudes, including Gen Z workers' preference for smaller gatherings and the country's increasing focus on work-life balance, as well as the pandemic's accelerated trend of people working from home and taking more paid leave.

images.alt_text: Japan is one of the last major economies to relax official guidance on the coverings, whose usage has been nearly universal throughout the country even without firm regulations or penalties governing their use.

Mori thinks it’s a little strange that his coffee shop has a queue out the door most days. He hears from his customers that he’s famous on the Internet, but he doesn’t use social media and doesn’t have a cell phone.

site_title: Manulife US Reit denies reported 200 billion won figure for sale of its manager
summary: Manulife US Reit denied reports that Korean asset manager Mirae Asset Global Investments has proposed a 200 billion won (S$206.4 million) figure for the sale of its manager. Mirae's non-binding proposal does not contain the figure, and only mentions a purchase price for the manager's shares. The Reit's manager stated that the deal involves the subscription of new units, not existing units, and due diligence is ongoing to determine the number of new units Mirae can subscribe to for the Reit to maintain its US Reit qualification.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: New Zealand banks operating above minimum regulatory requirements: central bank
summary: New Zealand's Reserve Bank stated that all local banks are operating above its minimum regulatory requirements, despite global financial stability issues. The central bank is closely monitoring the situation and has regular contact with regional regulators. This contrasts with international banks, such as Credit Suisse and First Republic Bank, which are facing significant challenges due to the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and other mid-size US lenders. The RBNZ's banks have different business models, making them less exposed to risks, and have passed rigorous stress tests showing they can handle more adverse situations.

site_title: Indian startups have deposits of about US$1 billion in SVB, minister says
summary: Indian startups had approximately $1 billion in deposits with Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) before its shutdown on March 10, according to Deputy IT Minister Rajeev Chandrashekhar. Chandrashekhar suggested that Indian banks lend more to startups, considering the uncertainty in the US banking system. He proposed a deposit-backed credit line to startups using SVB funds as collateral, citing a suggestion passed on to Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman. This move aims to help Indian startups transition to the Indian banking system.

images.alt_text: First Republic’s shares have lost over two-thirds of their value in the past seven days and are down more than 72 per cent month-to-date.
Founders are warning that Silicon Valley Bank's  failure could wipe out startups around the world without government intervention.
The FDIC is aiming to sell both SVB and Signature in their entirety, while offers for parts of the banks could be considered if whole company sales do not happen.

site_title: The implosion of FTX: lessons from an accounting perspective
