summary: The collapse of FTX, a major cryptocurrency exchange, highlights the importance of regulation and proper auditing in the crypto industry. Despite receiving over $2 billion in funding from institutional investors, FTX failed to engage a Big 4 firm as its auditor, leading to a lack of oversight and concentration of power. The exchange's founder, Sam Bankman-Fried, is accused of transferring funds to his sister company, Alameda Research, without accountability. The FTX fiasco has led to a loss of trust in crypto exchanges, with investors and depositors questioning whether they can entrust their assets to these platforms. Experts emphasize the need for full disclosure, audits, and governance standards to restore confidence in the industry.

images.alt_text: The upshot of regulatory intervention is that crypto companies are now being disenfranchised from the US banking system.
SVB’s failure was attributed largely to its exposure to slumping tech startup valuations and some unwise bond investments.
Sam Bankman-Fried, out of jail on a US$250 million bail package but confined to his parents’ home with an electronic monitor strapped to his ankle, has maintained his innocence.

site_title: ST Engineering wins S$430 million rail services contract in Taiwan
summary: ST Engineering has secured a S$430 million contract to provide rail services for the Kaohsiung MRT Red Line South Extension in Taiwan. The 11.27 km line, set to be completed in 2030, will feature six underground stations and one elevated station. ST Engineering Urban Solutions will lead systems integration and project management, with partners Hyundai Rotem and others contributing to the project. The contract adds to ST Engineering's global track record of 200 smart metro projects in over 50 cities.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
sT Engineering proposed a final dividend of 4 Singapore cents, to be paid on May 9 after books closure on Apr 27.

site_title: Asia: Markets extend global rally as banking sector fears ease
summary: Asian markets extended their global rally on Friday, driven by multi-billion-dollar shows of support for troubled banks aimed at soothing concerns about contagion in the sector. US banks including JPMorgan, Bank of America, and Citigroup deposited US$30 billion into First Republic, while Credit Suisse borrowed nearly US$54 billion from the Swiss central bank. The measures helped the Dow and S&P 500 rise over 1% and the Nasdaq over 2%, easing banking sector worries and allowing investors to refocus on inflation and interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: ST20230303_202311925234 Kua Chee Siong/ pixgeneric/ Generic pix of the SGX logo at SGX Centre 1 located along Shenton Way on March 3, 2023.
The Hang Seng Index climbed 1.23 per cent, or 235.93 points, to 19,439.84 on during early trade on Friday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares kick off Friday’s session with healthy gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks experienced healthy gains on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index climbing 1.23% to 19,439.84, driven by news of a rescue package for US lender First Republic. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains, adding 0.57% and 0.71% respectively. The positive market sentiment is attributed to the rescue package, which alleviates concerns about the financial health of regional US lenders.

site_title: Is the global investment boom turning to bust?
summary: A global investment boom, sparked by the pandemic, appears to be turning into a bust. Companies are scaling back their ambitions, with Meta, Disney, and Calavo Growers reducing their capital expenditures. A global survey of purchasing managers shows demand for investment goods returning to 2018-19 levels, while a Goldman Sachs tracker indicates zero growth in American capex. Economists attribute the decline to reduced cash reserves, improved global economic conditions, and a shift in consumer spending habits. The capex boom, which fueled a surge in productivity and living standards, is now expected to slow down.

images.alt_text: This photo taken on February 28, 2023 shows a worker producing semiconductor chips at a workshop in Suqian, in China's eastern Jiangsu province. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Microsoft unveils AI for its office suite in increased competition with Google
summary: Microsoft has unveiled its AI-powered "copilot" for its Microsoft 365 office suite, aiming to boost productivity growth. The new AI feature will offer a first draft in various applications, such as Word documents, Excel spreadsheets, and PowerPoint presentations. This move follows rival Google's recent upgrades to its office software, including AI features for Gmail and a "magic wand" for drafting prose. Microsoft's CEO Satya Nadella believes the new AI will unlock a new wave of productivity growth, as companies compete to deploy software that can reshape how people work.

site_title: Bank rescues ease crisis fears, but investors worry it's not enough
summary: A US$30 billion rescue package for First Republic Bank calmed market fears of an imminent banking collapse, but investors remain concerned about sector-wide risks. Large US banks provided the emergency funding, with US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen, Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell, and JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon involved in the deal. Despite the rescue, First Republic's shares fell 18% after disclosing its cash position and emergency liquidity needs. Authorities emphasize the banking system's resilience, but contagion risks persist, and the Fed's policy decision next week will be closely watched.

images.alt_text: A trader works at the post where First Republic Bank stock is traded on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., March 16, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Fabled Antakya fears losing 'soul' in Turkish quake ruins
summary: Antakya, a historic city in Turkey, faces a bleak future after a devastating 7.8-magnitude earthquake and its aftershocks, leaving its multicultural society and cultural heritage at risk. Residents fear the city's vibrancy and tradition of cultural acceptance will be lost if it is rebuilt on the outskirts of the mountains, with historic sites and buildings relocated. The Turkish government's plans to rebuild the city have sparked concerns that developers will prioritize profit over preserving the city's unique character, with some calling for a more inclusive and community-driven approach.

images.alt_text: A man stands amid rubble of a collapsed buidling while Greek and Turkish rescuers try to exhume the bodies of six of his relatives, including four children, in Antakya, south of Hatay, on Feb 15, 2023.
More than 298,000 people have been made homeless and 180 shelters for the displaced had been opened.

site_title: You can trust your money fund not to fail this time
summary: A recent financial crisis and bank failures have raised concerns about the stability of money-market funds. However, experts believe these funds are unlikely to fail like they did in 2008, due to significant changes in their holdings and exposure to corporate debt. Most money funds now hold US Treasuries or government bonds, with minimal exposure to corporate debt issued by banks. The average maturity of debt held by funds has also decreased, making it more liquid. Despite recent market turmoil, investors have continued to deposit funds, and yields have spiked, with the industry reaching a record $5.38 trillion. The main concern now is the potential impact of the Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions on these funds.

images.alt_text: Money market funds have seen renewed interest in recent months amid rising interest rates.
The PBOC urged fund managers to comprehensively and prudently assess the impact of such major money market funds on investors, the broad capital markets and the financial system.

site_title: CK Hutchison 2022 net profit up 9.5% helped by big one-off gain
summary: CK Hutchison Holdings reported a 9.5% rise in 2022 net profit to HK$36.7 billion, beating forecasts. The company attributed the gain to a one-off HK$10 billion profit from mergers and acquisitions, as well as improved performance in its ports division. However, analysts expect lower one-off gains and headwinds to affect the company's profit this year, with shares ending down 2.3% ahead of the results.

site_title: Kim Jong Un says ICBM launch before South Korea-Japan summit was to ‘strike fear’
summary: North Korea launched the Hwasong-17 intercontinental ballistic missile, its most powerful, just before a summit between Japan and South Korea, with leader Kim Jong Un saying it was to "strike fear" into the enemies. The test came hours after the US and South Korea started joint military exercises, prompting North Korea's pledge of an unprecedented response. The missile reached an altitude of 6,000 km and traveled 1,000 km before landing outside Japan's exclusive economic zone. The launch is the latest in a series of tests by North Korea, which has vowed to counter US and South Korean military drills.

images.alt_text: South Korea's President Yoon Suk Yeol and his wife Kim Keon Hee arrive at Haneda Airport in Tokyo, Japan March 16, 2023.

site_title: Petronas offers 38 billion rupees for stake in India’s NTPC’s green arm: sources
summary: Petronas, a Malaysian state-run firm, has offered 38 billion rupees (S$619 million) to buy a 20% stake in NTPC Green Energy, India's green energy arm, valued at US$2.3 billion. The offer price of 27.52 rupees per share outbid other local firms, including REC and Indraprastha Gas. The deal, the first time an Indian state-run company has offered a stake in a renewable energy arm, aims to expand NTPC's non-fossil businesses and meet India's goal of becoming net-zero by 2070.

images.alt_text: Petronas has declared force majeure on gas supply to one of its liquefaction terminals, Malaysia LNG Dua, after a pipeline leak caused by soil movement at the Sabah-Sarawak pipeline on Sep 21.

site_title: Thrive celebrates official launch at Projector X
summary: Thrive, a young audience initiative of The Business Times, celebrated its official launch at Projector X: The Picturehouse with a panel discussion featuring four industry professionals. The discussion, moderated by BT young audience editor Vivien Shiao, covered topics such as finding purpose in work, overcoming challenges, and maintaining mental health. Panelists shared their experiences and offered advice on navigating career, money, and life. Thrive aims to build a community for young adults to connect and discuss issues relevant to their lives, providing clarity and useful advice.

images.alt_text: Sign-up page for the Thrive newsletter, which will provide weekly advice on career, money and life. Find out more at bt.sg/thrive.
🙉 When being yourself at work becomes a TMI problem
BT

site_title: Inside TikTok’s fight to avoid a US ban
summary: TikTok's leadership is considering drastic measures to keep operating in the US, including separating from its parent ByteDance, amid a growing threat of a US ban. The company has proposed a $1.5 billion plan called Project Texas, which includes housing user data with Oracle and accepting oversight from a US government-appointed board. Despite these efforts, lawmakers continue to express concerns about national security and data transfers, and the Biden administration has warned ByteDance to spin off TikTok or face a ban. The company's future remains uncertain, with a potential divestiture or stake sale requiring China's approval.

images.alt_text: It is the first time under the administration of Democratic President Joe Biden that a potential ban on TikTok has been threatened.

The TikTok logo on a smartphone arranged in the Brooklyn borough of New York, US, on Thursday, March 9, 2023. The US is moving closer to restricting access to the popular video-sharing app TikTok, with Senate Intelligence Committee Chairman Mark Warner set to unveil a bill Tuesday that the Biden administration is poised to support, according to people familiar with the issue. Photographer: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg

site_title: India’s DLF to focus on luxury, premium housing after near-80 billion rupees project sells out
summary: India's top real estate developer DLF has sold out its luxury residential project in Gurugram near New Delhi in 72 hours, generating over 80 billion rupees in sales. The company will focus on luxury and premium projects due to difficulties in making profits in the affordable housing segment. Luxury housing sales boomed in 2022, with 65,700 units sold, driven by rising disposable incomes and demand for spacious apartments with conveniences. DLF plans to expand its luxury housing projects in cities like New Delhi, Mumbai, and Chennai.

site_title: No concrete plans to list or sell spirits business, ThaiBev clarifies
summary: Thai Beverage (ThaiBev) has clarified that it has no concrete plans to list or sell its spirits business, despite exploring options including an initial public offering in Singapore. The company reported a 13.2% increase in revenue to 272.4 billion baht and a 22.2% rise in net income to 30.1 billion baht in its 2022 financial year. ThaiBev remains confident in its spirits product group, which accounts for 42.7% of revenue and 71.9% of net profit, and is continually evaluating strategies to optimize its businesses.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting

site_title: US: Stocks end higher as major banks shore up First Republic
summary: US stocks rose 1.2% on Thursday as major banks announced a $30 billion rescue package for embattled lender First Republic, alleviating concerns over its financial stability. The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished at 32,246.55, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index gained 1.8% and 2.5%, respectively. The package, led by JPMorgan Chase and Morgan Stanley, aims to demonstrate confidence in the banking system. First Republic's stock price surged 10.0% after the announcement.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 46.92 points, or 0.15 per cent, at the open to 31,827.65.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ThaiBev, Keppel, Singapore banks, Top Glove, Southern Alliance Mining
summary: Thai Beverage clarified it has no concrete plans to list or sell its spirits business after Bloomberg reported it's exploring options, including an initial public offering in Singapore. Keppel Corp signed a pact with Cambodia's Royal Group Power for the import and sale of low-carbon electricity. Singapore banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC were found to have insignificant exposures to Credit Suisse and are well-capitalized. Top Glove reported a RM164.7 million loss for the second quarter, while Southern Alliance Mining reported a loss of RM7 million for the first half.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Across the broader market, losers outnumbered gainers 298 to 210 on Thursday after 1.9 billion securities worth S$1.3 billion were traded.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as banks drag, ECB hikes rates
summary: US stocks fell at the open on Thursday as banks dragged down Wall Street, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 0.15% to 31,827.65. First Republic Bank shares plummeted amid fears of a banking crisis, while the European Central Bank's interest rate hike also negatively impacted sentiment. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite followed suit, opening lower by 0.33% and 0.43%, respectively.

site_title: Eugene Ho to succeed Philip Yuen as chief of Deloitte Southeast Asia
summary: Eugene Ho will succeed Philip Yuen as the chief executive officer (CEO) of Deloitte Southeast Asia, replacing him from June 1, 2023. Yuen, who has held the CEO position since 2016, will also step down as chairman of Deloitte Singapore. Ho, with over 28 years of management consulting experience, has been with Deloitte for more than 38 years, starting his career in the UK. His succession marks a change in leadership for the professional services company in Southeast Asia.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: UK to ban TikTok on government phones
summary: The UK has announced it will ban TikTok on government phones with immediate effect due to security concerns over user data potentially ending up in the hands of the Chinese government. This move follows other Western countries, including the US, Canada, Belgium, and the European Commission, that have already barred the app. Britain's National Cyber Security Centre reviewed the decision, citing the need to protect Western security interests.

images.alt_text: It is the first time under the administration of Democratic President Joe Biden that a potential ban on TikTok has been threatened.

site_title: Banking system sound after 'decisive' actions, Yellen tells lawmakers
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen reassured lawmakers that the country's banking system is sound and depositors can feel confident that their savings are safe. The statement came after "decisive and forceful" actions were taken to shore up public confidence after Silicon Valley Bank's collapse. Yellen attributed the bank's demise to its inability to meet depositor demands due to interest rate hikes and high levels of uninsured deposits. Treasury, the Fed, and the FDIC worked together to protect depositors and set up an emergency facility to provide banks with access to funds.

images.alt_text: The FDIC is aiming to sell both SVB and Signature in their entirety, while offers for parts of the banks could be considered if whole company sales do not happen.

site_title: US single-family housing starts, building permits rebound in February
summary: US single-family housing starts and building permits rebounded in February, with single-family starts increasing 1.1% to 830,000 units and permits rising 7.6% to 777,000 units. This marks the highest level of single-family starts since last April and a significant rebound from the previous month's decline. The rebound is seen as a sign that the housing market may be stabilizing after being impacted by higher mortgage rates, which have been the result of the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes to combat inflation.

images.alt_text: SVB says it has helped to build or rehabilitate about 10,000 affordable homes in the San Francisco Bay Area.

site_title: China issues policies to stabilise soybean production
summary: China has introduced policies to stabilize soybean production in 2023, including buying domestically produced soybeans in key regions Heilongjiang and Inner Mongolia. The Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs will guide the China Grain Reserves Group to set up new plans, increase subsidies for soybean and corn producers, and establish rational subsidy standards. The goal is to stabilize production and develop coordination between production and sales.

site_title: US Fed lends banks US$12 billion under one-year scheme unveiled on Sunday
summary: The US Federal Reserve has lent US banks nearly $12 billion under a one-year lending program to ease stress on the financial system after Silicon Valley Bank's collapse. The program, unveiled alongside the Treasury and Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, aims to prevent other banks from facing liquidity issues. The total outstanding amount reached $11.9 billion by Wednesday, and major US banks have deposited $30 billion into First Republic Bank to rescue it, indicating confidence in the country's banking system.

images.alt_text: Some of the biggest US banking names including JPMorgan Chase & Co, Citigroup, Bank of America, Wells Fargo & Co, Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley poured US$30 billion into First Republic Bank on Thursday.
First Republic’s shares have lost over two-thirds of their value in the past seven days and are down more than 72 per cent month-to-date.

site_title: Dubai’s Majid Al Futtaim cuts 105 jobs as new CEO makes mark
summary: Dubai-based shopping mall developer Majid Al Futtaim has cut 105 jobs, about 0.2% of its 46,000 staff, as part of an "ongoing review" under its new CEO Ahmed Galal Ismail. The cuts follow the removal of former CEO Alain Bejjani in January. The company cited the need to boost returns and adapt to evolving market conditions. MAF reported a 12% increase in revenue to 36.3 billion dirhams in 2022, but a 2% decline in net profit.

site_title: Major US banks inject US$30 billion to rescue First Republic Bank
summary: Major US banks, including JPMorgan Chase & Co, Citigroup, and Bank of America, injected $30 billion into First Republic Bank to rescue the lender amid a widening crisis triggered by the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and Credit Suisse. The move aimed to shore up liquidity and calm investors' concerns about a potential contagion. First Republic's stock rose 10% after the rescue, but later fell as the bank suspended its dividend. The US banking system remains sound, according to US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen, who credited "decisive and forceful" actions for mitigating the crisis.

images.alt_text: First Republic’s shares have lost over two-thirds of their value in the past seven days and are down more than 72 per cent month-to-date.

“I can reassure the members of the committee that our banking system is sound, and that Americans can feel confident that their deposits will be there when they need them,” Yellen told the Senate Finance Committee.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 1.2 per cent higher at 32,246.55 on Thursday.

site_title: Southern Alliance Mining sinks into the red with H1 loss of RM7 million
summary: Southern Alliance Mining, a Malaysian iron-ore producer, reported a net loss of RM7 million (S$2.1 million) for its first half, down from a net profit of RM19.6 million in the same period last year. Revenue fell 47% to RM52.2 million due to intense overburden removal activities at its Chaah Mine. This marks a significant decline from RM98.5 million in revenue for the same period last year.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
The Malaysia-based iron ore producer attributed the losses for H1 FY2023 to a decrease in iron ore production.

This photograph taken on February 22, 2023, shows a part of a steel production line inside the steelwork site of an ArcelorMittal factory, as the site goes through a plan to reduce its carbon footprint (CO2) up to 35 percent for 2030, in Fos sur mer. - ArcelorMittal will reoperate one of the two blast-furnaces that was stopped at the end of 2022 due to the reduction in steel demand and the impact of rising energy prices, announced the site's director on February 22, 2023. (Photo by Christophe SIMON / AFP)

site_title: ThaiBev exploring options for spirits unit, including IPO: sources
summary: Thai Beverage (ThaiBev) is exploring options for its spirits business, including an initial public offering (IPO) in Singapore, as the company struggles to bring a separate unit to the market. Initial discussions have been held with banks on alternatives, including selling a stake in the maker of popular liquor brands Mekhong and Ruang Khao. Valuations range from US$5 billion to over US$10 billion, with no final decisions made yet.

images.alt_text: Thai Beverage's beer business, revenue was up 23.5 per cent to 122.5 billion baht in FY2022,  despite the increase of key raw material and packaging costs such as malts and bottles.
ThaiBev’s beer business reported a 13.7 per cent year-on-year rise in sales revenue to 37.9 billion baht, helped in part by the recovery of economic activity in Thailand and Vietnam

site_title: Europe: Shares jump as Credit Suisse bailout offsets ECB rate hike
summary: Europe's stocks jumped 1.3% on Thursday as a Credit Suisse bailout offset concerns about a global banking crisis following the ECB's 50-basis point interest rate hike. The Stoxx 600 index touched a 10-week low earlier in the day but recovered, with the banks sector index gaining 1.2% and euro zone banks rising 1.4%. Credit Suisse shares surged 19.2% after securing a Swiss National Bank lifeline, while the ECB cut inflation projections and lifted growth forecasts.

site_title: Meta maps way to ‘kill’ online deception campaigns
summary: Meta has released a framework to combat online deception campaigns, dubbed the "Online Operations Kill Chain," which aims to identify and disrupt malicious operations. The framework, developed by Meta's Ben Nimmo and Eric Hutchins, outlines a unified approach to analyzing online deception campaigns across various platforms. By mapping the steps involved in these operations, defenders can "trip up" malicious campaigns and prevent them from reaching targets. The goal is to stop attackers before they reach their target, addressing human weakness and the limitations of computer users.

images.alt_text: A phone screen displaying a video about a Filipino woman finding sand in her power bank she had purchased from a Facebook page.
YouGov data shows that about 41 per cent of people in Singapore aged between 18 and 24 have used TikTok in October 2022.
With Meta now hitting a nearly 25 per cent staff reduction, others in the tech world may follow suit. But if there was ever a time to break free of tech’s group-think mentality, this is it.

site_title: Euro gives back gains after ECB’s interest rate decision
summary: The euro fell as much as 0.25% after the European Central Bank (ECB) stuck to its plan for a half-percentage-point interest rate increase, reversing earlier gains. The decision was made despite recent market volatility, which had threatened to upend the ECB's rate-hiking plans. The ECB stated that the future rate path would depend on incoming data, aiming to curb high inflation.

images.alt_text: The safe-haven US dollar rose sharply, with the US dollar index surging 0.9 per cent to 104.65.

site_title: US regulator eyes Friday bids for SVB, Signature Bank: sources
summary: US regulators are set to auction off failed lenders Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) and Signature Bank, with bids due by March 17. The FDIC aims to sell both banks in their entirety, but may consider part sales if whole company sales fail. Only bidders with existing bank charters will be allowed to review financials, giving traditional lenders an advantage over private equity firms. Signature must agree to divest its crypto business, but an FDIC spokesperson said no such requirement will be imposed. US taxpayers will not bear the cost of salvaging the banks, with any shortfalls covered by a government fund.

images.alt_text: Customers exit Silicon Valley Bank headquarters in Santa Clara, California, US, on Monday, March 13, 2023. The collapse of Silicon Valley Bank has prompted a global reckoning at venture capital and private equity firms, which found themselves suddenly exposed all together to the tech industry's money machine. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

Goldman Sachs would buy a US$21.5 billion bond portfolio from SVB to boost its coffers, after startups began pulling their deposits from the technology-focused lender, which does business as Silicon Valley Bank.
Silicon Valley Bank headquarters in Santa Clara, California, US, on Thursday, March 9, 2023.

site_title: Boeing resumes deliveries of 787 Dreamliner as order book swells
summary: Boeing has resumed deliveries of its 787 Dreamliner after a data issue was resolved with the Federal Aviation Administration. The company delivered a 787 to German airline Lufthansa, its first since halting deliveries in late February. Boeing has received orders for almost 200 Dreamliners in the past four months, including a $37 billion deal with two Saudi airlines. The company aims to ramp up 787 production to 10 a month by the end of 2026, with CEO Dave Calhoun confident in meeting production goals due to high demand for the aircraft.

images.alt_text: On Tuesday,  Boeing announced orders for 78 Dreamliners, split between state-owned Saudi Arabian Airlines (Saudia) and new national airline Riyadh Air.

site_title: Yellen, Dimon, Powell helped clinch First Republic deal with key lawyer: sources
summary: Top US banking officials, including Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen, Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell, and JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon, helped broker a $30 billion rescue deal for First Republic Bank. The deal, which includes uninsured deposits from major banks, aims to stabilize the regional US banking sector, which has been hit by the collapse of SVB Financial and Signature Bank. First Republic's shares have lost over two-thirds of their value in the past week, but closed up 10% on Thursday after the announcement.

images.alt_text: Some of the biggest US banking names including JPMorgan Chase & Co, Citigroup, Bank of America, Wells Fargo & Co, Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley poured US$30 billion into First Republic Bank on Thursday.

site_title: Last Qing emperor Puyi’s Patek Philippe to go on auction
summary: The last Qing emperor, Puyi, is set to have his Patek Philippe watch, a Reference 96 Quantieme Lune, auctioned off later this year. The watch, made in 1937, features a moon-phase and triple-date calendar and is one of only eight produced, with only three having this specific dial configuration. The watch has a rich history, having been worn by Puyi during his five years as a Soviet captive and later being gifted to his Russian translator, Georgy Permyakov. Experts estimate the watch could sell for a price in the seven figures, potentially breaking records due to its royal provenance and rare watchmaking history.

images.alt_text: The S&P 500 stock index averaged annual returns of 8 per cent from August 2018 to January 2023 while a basket of pre-owned watch models from top Swiss brands grew at more than twice the pace.

The volume of Rolex, Audemars Piguet and Patek Philippe watches on the secondary market roughly doubled last year, while financial and geopolitical uncertainty, as well as Chinese lockdowns, kept some buyers away.

site_title: UK government agrees on pay deal with healthcare unions: report
summary: The UK government has agreed on a pay deal with healthcare unions, ending months of strikes by nurses and ambulance workers. The agreement, reported by the i newspaper, brings an end to the labor disputes. Finance Minister Jeremy Hunt had earlier expressed optimism about the breakthrough. The deal's impact on other NHS staff, such as junior doctors and midwives, remains unclear.

images.alt_text: The strikes will heap more pressure on Britain’s state-funded NHS which is already stretched by staff shortages and record backlogs.
Unions representing National Health Service workers say that the government has imposed years of real-term pay cuts.

site_title: Keppel and Cambodian group ink pact to create Singapore’s largest cross-border electricity contract
summary: Keppel Corp has signed a pact with Cambodia's Royal Group Power to import and sell 1 gigawatt of low-carbon electricity, marking Singapore's largest cross-border electricity contract. The deal, conditional on EMA approval, aims to support Singapore's decarbonization goals and utilizes solar energy, hydropower, and wind power. The power will be transmitted through 1,000 km of subsea cables, the longest in South-east Asia, and is expected to start after 2030.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
While it would be a sweet victory for climate goals to see this radical project take fruition, Sun Cable’s fate has been eclipsed by shareholder spat
EMA said it remains on track to meet its imports target of 4GW by 2035.
The proposal for Singapore to draw critical energy supply from a source some 4,200 KM away through an undersea cable was deemed a hard sell from the get-go by market watchers.

site_title: Singapore banking trio’s exposures to Credit Suisse are insignificant: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has stated that the exposures of Singapore's three major banks (DBS, OCBC, and UOB) to Credit Suisse are insignificant, given the embattled Swiss lender's crisis. The banks are well-capitalized, conduct regular stress tests, and have healthy liquidity positions. MAS reiterated that Singapore's banking system remains sound and resilient.

images.alt_text: Chief executive officer Ulrich Koerner is battling a crisis of confidence, just days after the failure of US lender Silicon Valley Bank prompted a selloff in financial stocks globally.
The Hang Seng gave up more than two per cent, while Tokyo, Sydney, Shanghai, Seoul, Singapore, Wellington, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta markets were also down on Thursday.

site_title: New Zealand to ban TikTok on devices linked to parliament
summary: New Zealand plans to ban TikTok on devices connected to its parliamentary network due to cybersecurity concerns by the end of March. This move follows similar actions by other governments to curb the Chinese-owned video-sharing app from sensitive devices. The ban aims to protect the country's parliamentary network from potential security risks.

site_title: Singapore key exports contract 15.6% in February in fifth straight month of decline
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) declined 8% in February, the fifth straight month of contraction, with a 15.6% year-on-year drop. Exports to electronics and non-electronics fell, with the shipment of electronic products down 26.5% year-on-year. However, exports to Japan and the US rose, with growth of 15.2% and 8.7% year-on-year, respectively. Economists attribute the decline to broad-based contraction and warn of continued weakness in global demand.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
On the whole, NODX to Singapore's top 10 markets shrink in January, mainly due to .

site_title: ECB raises rates as planned despite banking turmoil
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) raised interest rates by 50 basis points as planned, maintaining its data-dependent approach to policy rate decisions despite concerns about banking turmoil. This is the ECB's fastest pace of rate hikes on record, targeting inflation above its 2% target through 2025. The decision follows a rout in global markets following the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank in the US. The deposit rate has been lifted to 3%, the highest level since 2008.

images.alt_text: The ECB’s 26-member governing council will “very, very likely” raise interest rates by another half a percentage point at its meeting in Frankfurt, president Christine Lagarde said last week.

site_title: Hong Kong’s December-February unemployment eases to 3.3%
summary: Hong Kong's unemployment rate eased to 3.3% in the December to February period, improving for a tenth consecutive quarter. The rate was 3.4% in the November to January period. The government attributes the improvement to continued economic activity and the rebound in inbound tourism, expecting further labor market conditions to improve in the near term.

site_title: India’s TCS CEO Rajesh Gopinathan to resign
summary: Tata Consultancy Services (TCS) CEO Rajesh Gopinathan is resigning as CEO, effective September 15. Gopinathan completed his six-year term in January and was reappointed until 2027. The move comes amidst a challenging macro-economic environment in the US and Europe. K Krithivasan, who has held various leadership roles, has been named as CEO-designate, subject to shareholder approval.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Tata Consultancy Services (TCS) Chief Executive Officer Rajesh Gopinathan attends a news conference announcing the company's quarterly results in Mumbai, India, January 10, 2019. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas/File Photo

site_title: Oil snaps declining streak as Saudi, Russia meeting calms markets
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Thursday, ending a three-session losing streak, after Saudi Arabia and Russia met to discuss market stability. Brent crude futures rose to $74.70 a barrel and WTI to $68.35 a barrel, supported by a broader market recovery and a weakening dollar. Both OPEC and the IEA forecast stronger oil demand, but oversupply concerns remain.

images.alt_text: Brent crude was down US$3.76, or 4.9 per cent, to US$73.69 a barrel on Wednesday.

site_title: Macron rams through pension change without parliament vote
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron has used a rarely used constitutional power to pass a pension reform bill without a vote in the National Assembly, amid strong opposition from trade unions and the right-wing opposition. The bill raises the retirement age from 62 to 64, despite polls showing two-thirds of French people oppose the reform. Macron's government faces a confidence vote in the next 24 hours, which could lead to its downfall, with far-right leader Marine Le Pen threatening to file a motion.

images.alt_text: Demonstrators gather at Place de la Republique during a rally called by French trade unions in Paris, Jan 19, 2023.

site_title: Oiltek reaches agreement on rectification works linked to refinery plant fire
summary: Oiltek International has reached an agreement with its customer to complete rectification works at a refinery plant in six months. The work is expected to be completed within the financial year ending Dec 31, 2023. This comes after a fire incident occurred at the plant supplied by the integrated process technology and renewable energy solution provider.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting

site_title: Australia’s Latitude Group, IPH hit by cyberattacks amid wave of hacks
summary: Australia's Latitude Group and intellectual-property-services provider IPH reported data breaches, joining other major companies such as Optus and Medibank Private. The breaches, which occurred since September, resulted in the theft of around 328,000 customers' personal information, including driver's licenses and customer records. This adds to a growing wave of hacks targeting Australian companies, with no information on the perpetrators or motives behind the attacks being released.

images.alt_text: The ECB has long been warning banks to be alert for cyberattacks from Russia after the European Union passed a long series of sanctions against Moscow over its invasion of Ukraine.
Federal authorities took over Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) last week less than 48 hours after it first announced bad news.

site_title: Vietnam domestic coffee prices edge down, tight supplies in Indonesia
summary: Vietnam's domestic coffee prices fell to 46,300-47,400 dong per kg, down from the previous week's range, following a global trend. In Indonesia, supplies from the mini harvest were scarce due to unfavourable weather, resulting in a US$135 premium to the July contract. Traders in Vietnam reported limited beans available for trade, with one trader offering a discount of US$20 per tonne. The decrease in prices is attributed to the global trend and limited supply in Indonesia.

site_title: US jobless claims drop by most since July, led by New York
summary: US jobless claims dropped by 20,000 to 192,000 in the week ended March 11, the largest decrease since July. Continuing claims fell by 29,000 to 1.68 million, indicating a tight labor market with robust job creation and low unemployment. The data contrasts with slowing wage growth and rising layoffs, creating a challenging backdrop for the Federal Reserve ahead of its policy meeting.

images.alt_text: WASHINGTON, DC - FEBRUARY 07: Federal Reserve Board Chairman Jerome Powell speaks during an interview by David Rubenstein, Chairman of the Economic Club of Washington, D.C., at the Renaissance Hotel on February 7, 2023 in Washington, DC. The Federal Reserve announced last week a 0.25 percentage point interest rate increase to a range of 4.50% to 4.75%.   Julia Nikhinson/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Julia Nikhinson / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Green tech boom looms but poor nations risk being eclipsed: UN
summary: The UN's trade and development agency, UNCTAD, warns that developing countries risk being left behind in the green technology boom, which could be worth $10 trillion by 2030. Currently, advanced countries are outpacing developing nations in green technology exports, and without intervention, developing countries will struggle to catch up, losing lasting advantages to early adopters.

site_title: Indonesia central bank leaves interest rates unchanged
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, held interest rates unchanged at 5.75% for the 7-day reverse repurchase rate, citing sufficient previous hikes to steer inflation back to its target range. Governor Perry Warjiyo played down concerns about risks to Indonesian banks from global bank problems, citing a government stress test showing domestic lenders' resilience. Inflation remains on track to reach its target range, with growth outlook for 2023 maintained at the upper end of 4.5-5.3%.

site_title: Credit Suisse loses equities heads in Asia as exodus worsens
summary: Credit Suisse is losing senior executives in its Asia-Pacific equities business amid financial health concerns. Nick Silver, Jonathan Jenkins, and Chris Prasertsintanah are leaving, with Silver focusing on opportunities outside the bank. The departures come as CEO Ulrich Koerner battles a crisis of confidence following Silicon Valley Bank's failure. Adil Virani takes over as head of equities for Asia Pacific, and several other executives are appointed to new roles in the region.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The euro sign is photographed in front of the former head quarter of the European Central Bank in Frankfurt, Germany, April 9, 2019. Picture is taken on slow shutter speed while the camera was moved.  REUTERS/Kai Pfaffenbach/File Photo

site_title: China to create powerful financial watchdog run by Communist Party
summary: China is set to create a powerful financial watchdog run by the Communist Party, replacing the state-run Financial Stability and Development Committee. The new Central Financial Commission will oversee financial affairs, giving the ruling party direct control and supervision. This move aims to strengthen "unified leadership on financial work" and is seen as part of a broader reorganization of governing bodies. The creation of the watchdog is expected to blur the line between the party and the government, further solidifying the party's control over financial affairs.

images.alt_text: Xi has used the annual parliamentary gathering to hit back at the US for trying to prevent the country’s rise.

site_title: Malaysia’s Dialog Group to expand into renewable fuels storage
summary: Dialog Group, a Malaysian company, plans to expand its terminal operations for renewable fuels storage facilities at Johor by end-2024. The storage facility will have a capacity of 24,000 cubic meters and will be connected to truck loading bays and existing marine facilities. This marks Dialog Group's first foray into the renewables market. The expansion aims to cater to renewable fuel feedstocks and products.

site_title: Invesco, Franklin among firms that added SVB before collapse
summary: Several major asset managers, including Invesco and Franklin Resources, added shares of Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) in the months before its collapse, which wiped 60% off its stock value in a single day. These firms, along with others such as Two Sigma Investments, DE Shaw & Co, and BlackRock, were among the top 10 buyers of SVB shares since September. The swift collapse of SVB sent shockwaves through the tech and finance industries, prompting government protection for client deposits.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs would buy a US$21.5 billion bond portfolio from SVB to boost its coffers, after startups began pulling their deposits from the technology-focused lender, which does business as Silicon Valley Bank.
Silicon Valley Bank headquarters in Santa Clara, California, US, on Thursday, March 9, 2023.

site_title: Gianni Infantino re-elected Fifa president until 2027
summary: Fifa president Gianni Infantino has been re-elected until 2027 after standing unopposed at the congress of world football's governing body. The 52-year-old Swiss lawyer succeeded Sepp Blatter in 2016 and was re-elected by acclamation, with delegates from 211 member federations waving him in for a third term. Infantino expressed his love for both supporters and critics, noting the voting system did not register dissident voices in the Rwandan capital where the congress took place.

site_title: UK payment firms lack controls and pose unacceptable risk, FCA says
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has expressed concerns over hundreds of electronic-money and payments institutions, citing "material issues" with anti-crime controls and "elevated fraud rates" among some firms. The regulator warns that these firms pose an "unacceptable risk" to customers and the financial system. The FCA has authorized many firms in recent years, but its oversight has been criticized for being insufficient. The regulator plans to take "more assertive action" against problematic firms amid the UK's cost-of-living crisis.

site_title: Eurozone bond yields jump after Credit Suisse’s US$54 billion lifeline
summary: Eurozone bond yields surged after Credit Suisse announced a US$54 billion loan from the Swiss Central Bank to shore up liquidity. Germany's 2-year bond yield rose 36 basis points to 2.737%, while Italy's 2-year yield increased 14 basis points to 3.246%. The European Central Bank is set to set interest rates later on Thursday, amid rising investor concern over the lender's financial stability.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise as investors cheer Credit Suisse securing lifeline
summary: European shares rose 0.9% on Thursday as Credit Suisse recovered 28% after securing a US$54 billion lifeline from the Swiss National Bank, alleviating concerns of a global banking crisis. The STOXX 600 index has fallen nearly 3% this week amid the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank. The European Central Bank's meeting later in the day will be closely watched for its response to growing banking fears, with traders now seeing a 42% likelihood of a 25 basis-point rate hike.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index closed the day 3 per cent lower, a day after recording its best day this year.

site_title: China renews pledge for wider market access for foreign investors
summary: China's commerce ministry has renewed its pledge to relax market access for foreign investors, aiming to attract more foreign capital as the country emerges from three years of COVID-19 disruptions. The move follows the lifting of China's zero-tolerance policy for COVID-19 in December and the restoration of visa issuance for foreigners. China's economy, which grew at its slowest rates last year in half a century, is expected to benefit from increased foreign investment, with Goldman Sachs raising its forecast for GDP growth to 6% from 5.5%.

images.alt_text: An employee counts genuine Chinese one-hundred yuan banknotes at the Counterfeit Notes Response Center of KEB Hana Bank in Seoul, South Korea, on Monday, Aug. 14, 2017. China's factory output and investment slowed somewhat in July, according to data released today, yet the yuan appeared not to take the data as negative, if in fact it's paying attention to it at all. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg
CBIRC told brokers including the joint ventures of Tullett Prebon and NEX International to stop providing their bond feeds to outside parties due to data security concerns.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore and Indonesia signed six government-to-government agreements during the Leaders' Retreat, focusing on tech talent and smart cities. The agreements aim to boost cooperation between the two countries. Meanwhile, Singapore's six-month Treasury bill saw a cut-off yield of 3.65%, the lowest since last September. The country also revised toll charges at Tuas Checkpoint to match Malaysia's toll rates. Singapore state investors GIC and Temasek joined US fintech Stripe's US$6.5 billion fundraising, halving the company's valuation to US$50 billion.

site_title: China cash squeeze returns as traders look for PBOC response
summary: China's short-term borrowing costs rose to a two-year high, fueling expectations of a central bank response with increased cash injections amid global market volatility. The overnight repo rate climbed to 2.3%, driven by demand for cash for tax payments and credit expansion. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) injected $15.4 billion via reverse repo, aiming to stabilize interbank liquidity. Despite this, market rates may not fall significantly, and the yuan weakened to 6.90 per dollar, while Chinese stocks fell with peers.

images.alt_text: The PBOC’s net injection on Wednesday was more than the 199 billion yuan provided in February.

site_title: In a parallel universe, these Oscars 2023 nominations could have won
summary: Andrea Riseborough's Oscar-nominated performance in "To Leslie" is a standout despite the film's mediocre plot. Her portrayal of an alcoholic mother in freefall is a marvel, earning praise from A-list actors. In contrast, other nominees like Michelle Yeoh in "Everything Everywhere All at Once" and Cate Blanchett in "TAR" were considered front-runners. Meanwhile, Paul Mescal's performance in "Aftersun" is a highlight among the Oscar nominees who went home empty-handed, offering a unique and devastating portrayal of grief and loss.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Everything Everywhere All At Once starring Michelle Yeoh is a triumph not just of Asian representation - it is also one of the most culturally astute films in recent memory,
Vicky Krieps is magisterial as Empress Elisabeth in Corsage.
Cate Blanchett is a force of nature playing a famous conductor in Tar, though the film itself is highly problematic.

site_title: China decides to protect Hong Kong as a financial centre
summary: China has reaffirmed its commitment to Hong Kong as a key financial centre, amid a surge in external investment interest. Following a period of political unrest, Beijing has shifted its focus to attracting foreign investment, citing Hong Kong's unique position as a bridge between East and West. China's central bank and major banks have emphasized the importance of Hong Kong to the Chinese capital markets ecosystem, with some officials even suggesting the potential for Hong Kong's currency to become a major trading currency. This move aims to counterbalance the influence of the US dollar and stabilize China's economy.

images.alt_text: Lennon Lee, Partner, Financial Services Tax Leader, PwC Singapore.

Glitzy Hong Kong shopping streets once packed with luxury stores that attracted 56 million visitors in pre-pandemic 2019 now have about half of their shop units sitting vacant, according to property management companies.

site_title: Luxury property rents increase faster in Singapore than New York
summary: Singapore saw annual rents surge 28% in the last quarter of 2022, surpassing New York's 19% growth, according to Knight Frank. The city-state's strong demand, fueled by a supply crunch and new visa rules, drove the increase. However, 17,000 private homes set for completion this year may provide some relief. Hong Kong ranked lowest, with a 6.4% year-on-year decline in rents, attributed to declining tenant demand. The overall rate of annual growth is starting to slow across many global cities, according to Knight Frank.

site_title: Singapore stocks slip 0.5% on Thursday as Asian markets tumble
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.5% on Thursday, tracking a broader regional decline, as banking sector concerns continued to weigh on markets. The Straits Times Index closed at 3,155.54, with local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB falling between 0.7% and 1.3%. The US-centric banking crisis has shifted globally, with contagion risks and economic growth risks impacting the global economy, according to Stephen Innes of SPI Asset Management.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Generic pix of the SGX logo at SGX Centre 1 located along Shenton Way on March 3, 2023.
The Hang Seng gave up more than two per cent, while Tokyo, Sydney, Shanghai, Seoul, Singapore, Wellington, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta markets were also down on Thursday.
The bank is making a tender offer to buy back up to approximately 3 billion francs of dollar- and euro-denominated debt.

site_title: GIC, Temasek join US$6.5 billion fundraising of US fintech Stripe
summary: Stripe, a US fintech, has raised US$6.5 billion in its latest funding round, valuing the company at US$50 billion. Singapore state investors GIC and Temasek, along with existing investors, participated in the round. The funds will be used to address tax obligations and provide liquidity to employees. Despite the significant valuation drop, Stripe's co-founder, John Collison, stated that the company "does not need this capital to run its business." The funding comes amid pressure on private tech companies to turn profitable amid global economic headwinds.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

site_title: SVB collapse: A timeline
summary: Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) collapsed after a series of events, including high deposit outflows due to aggressive interest rate hikes and a broader downturn in the startup industry. The bank sold $21 billion of securities and $2.25 billion of shares, incurring a $1.8 billion loss, but ultimately failed to halt withdrawals. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp (FDIC) put the bank in receivership, managing its assets to ensure all depositors and creditors were paid. The collapse triggered a US banking sector rout and had far-reaching effects on the global economy, including a decline in cryptocurrency values and a slowdown in China's GDP growth.

images.alt_text: Jeanette Tan
The dramatic downfall of one of tech’s biggest lenders has prompted rethinking of compliance and risk controls.
The collapse of the California-based lender was as sudden as it was surprising. And the shockwaves are felt as far as Singapore and Asia.
The loss of SVB is likely to have a chilling effect on an industry already suffering from higher interest rates.
By promising to reimburse the depositors of Silicon Valley Bank, Biden risks being portrayed as beholden to powerful elites.
Silicon Valley Bank – a key lender to startups across the United States since the 1980s – collapsed after a sudden run on deposits, prompting regulators to seize control on Friday.

site_title: LTA to revise toll charges at Tuas Checkpoint from Mar 31
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) will revise toll charges at the Tuas Checkpoint in Singapore, starting March 31. The change will see a single all-day charge for all vehicles except motorcycles, mirroring Malaysia's recent removal of off-peak toll charges. The revised toll rates will be identical to peak rates, with the largest toll for cars, vans, and light goods vehicles at S$11.30. This adjustment is in line with Singapore's long-standing policy of matching Malaysia's toll rates, and no changes will be made to toll charges at Woodlands Checkpoint.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
The government is looking at adopting the use of transhipment permits, similar to existing practices for air and sea transhipment, said Senior Minister of State for Transport Chee Hong Tat.

site_title: EU unveils plans to lead in green industrial revolution
summary: The European Union has unveiled plans to lead in the green industrial revolution, aiming to triple global investment in the green transition to $3 trillion by 2030. President Ursula von der Leyen declared "the race is on" during a speech to the European Parliament, highlighting the EU's efforts to compete with the US and China in clean tech production and access to raw materials. The EU's Net-Zero Industry Act and Critical Raw Materials Act are part of its Green Deal Industrial Plan, designed to ensure the bloc's industry is ahead in cutting carbon emissions and technology.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen presents a "communication" detailing the EU's "Green Deal Industrial Plan" to ensure the bloc plays a leading role in clean tech production, partly in EU's response to the U.S. Inflation Reduction Act, which will provide $369 billion of subsidies for electric vehicles and other green products, in Brussels, Belgium February 1, 2023. REUTERS/Yves Herman/File Photo

site_title: Zee set to repay IndusInd US$10 million to wrap Sony deal
summary: Zee Entertainment has agreed to repay IndusInd Bank approximately US$10 million to settle dues, potentially resolving insolvency proceedings initiated against the company. The repayment could happen as early as Friday, allowing the Mumbai-based bank to withdraw its insolvency proceedings. This move is part of Zee's efforts to complete a merger with a Sony Group unit, creating a US$10 billion media giant, and comes after the National Company Law Appellate Tribunal halted the insolvency proceedings last month. The Sony deal has received necessary approvals, including from Zee's shareholders and India's antitrust regulator.

site_title: For Goldman Sachs, SVB’s botched stock sale had a silver lining
summary: Goldman Sachs acquired a $21.5 billion bond portfolio from Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) after startups pulled their deposits, boosting its coffers. The deal was part of a two-part plan to address SVB's capital shortfall. However, Goldman's initial offer was worth $1.8 billion less than the book value due to rising interest rates, resulting in a loss for SVB. The stock sale to fill the funding gap collapsed, leading to SVB's failure and regulatory interventions. For Goldman, the deal has a silver lining, as the bond portfolio is now worth more due to declining Treasury yields, with estimated gains in the hundreds of millions of US dollars.

images.alt_text: Silicon Valley Bank headquarters in Santa Clara, California, US, on Thursday, March 9, 2023.
Silicon Valley Bank’s fall last week was the biggest US bank failure in more than a decade.

site_title: Judicial managers appointed for Alpha DX Group
summary: The High Court appointed Tan Wei Cheong and Lim Loo Khoon of Deloitte & Touche as joint and several judicial managers of Catalist-listed Alpha DX Group. The company was placed under judicial management due to uncertainty over its ability to continue as a going concern. Trading of Alpha DX's shares remains suspended. Judicial managers will exercise powers and entitlements of directors to oversee the company's affairs. Further announcements will be made as material developments occur. Alpha DX had flagged concerns over negotiations with creditors, including a letter of statutory demand for S$1.9 million.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting

site_title: Singapore, Indonesia ink agreements on tech talent, smart cities during Jokowi’s visit
summary: Singapore and Indonesia signed six government-to-government agreements during President Joko Widodo's visit, focusing on tech talent, smart cities, and renewable energy cooperation. The agreements include a tech talent exchange program, a renewable energy cooperation MOU, and a deal on smart city development for Indonesia's new capital, Nusantara. The partnerships aim to strengthen bilateral relations and promote mutual benefits, with Singapore committed to assisting Indonesia in making Nusantara a smart and sustainable city.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Moderating growth means Bank Indonesia maybe on the verge of its last interest-rate increase when it meets later this month.
Song Fa Bak Kut Teh is looking to open new stores in Bandung and Surabaya this year, after opening a store in Medan right before the Covid-19 pandemic began in early 2020.
One advantage of Indonesia is the market of about 280 million people, but SBF's country head for Indonesia Hisyaamuddin Abu Bakar noted that the Indonesia market is a “marathon game” for companies.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares sink 1.75% at open
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index fell 1.75% to 19,197.97, amid concerns over Credit Suisse and bank contagion fears. The decline also mirrored losses on China's Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes. The market anxiously awaits the Federal Reserve's policy meeting next week, which could further impact global markets.

site_title: LMS Compliance launches ESG reporting service for Bursa listcos
summary: LMS Compliance has launched an environmental, social and governance (ESG) reporting service to help Bursa-listed companies meet the Malaysian stock exchange's enhanced framework for sustainability reporting, which became compulsory last September for main market listed issuers. The framework requires companies to disclose common sustainability matters for the financial year ending on or after Dec 31, 2023, with additional requirements for FYs ending after Dec 31, 2025. The ESG reporting service aims to support Bursa-listed companies in aligning their disclosures with the Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures (TCFD).

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
Bursa Malaysia CEO Muhamad Umar Swift at the launch of the first Shariah-compliant carbon exchange in the world on Dec 9, 2022 in Kuala Lumpur.
Bursa Malaysia opened an exchange this month, joining more than a dozen that are underway or planned across the region.
The announcement comes as Malaysian companies look to improve their ESG practices, amid new European Union laws on deforestation and sustainability.

site_title: Art auction business is being dominated by US$1 million-plus sales
summary: A new report by Sotheby's and ArtTactic reveals significant growth in high-end art transactions, with US$1 million-plus sales generating US$8.15 billion in revenue for Sotheby's, Christie's, and Phillips between 2018 and 2022. The number of painting sales above US$1 million decreased, but the average price increased to US$6 million. The report also shows that private sales, previously undisclosed, accounted for 85.9% of Sotheby's sales above US$1 million, and that there's an inverse relationship between public and private sales, suggesting a stable market.

site_title: Credit Suisse shares leap in delicate truce with doubters
summary: Credit Suisse shares surged 24% in the first few minutes of trade after securing a $54 billion loan from the Swiss National Bank to shore up investor confidence. The lifeline helped stem heavy selling in Asian financial markets and prompted a modest rally in European equities. However, analysts at JPMorgan said the loan may not be enough to soothe investor concerns, and a takeover of Credit Suisse by rival UBS is now considered the most likely outcome.

images.alt_text: The bank is making a tender offer to buy back up to approximately 3 billion francs of dollar- and euro-denominated debt.

site_title: China’s bond market mayhem pressures regulator to address issue
summary: China's bond market has been shaken by a sudden suspension of commonly used bond price feeds, causing transactions to plummet by 30-60% on Wednesday. The move, ordered by the China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission (CBIRC), was allegedly made to address data security concerns. The halt has added to concerns about the transparency of China's regulation, and the issue comes as the country seeks to make its financial markets more efficient and attractive to foreign investors.

images.alt_text: An employee counts genuine Chinese one-hundred yuan banknotes at the Counterfeit Notes Response Center of KEB Hana Bank in Seoul, South Korea, on Monday, Aug. 14, 2017. China's factory output and investment slowed somewhat in July, according to data released today, yet the yuan appeared not to take the data as negative, if in fact it's paying attention to it at all. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg
The total debt of China’s LGFVs has swelled to a record 66 trillion yuan, equivalent to half of the country’s economy.

Although details have yet to be revealed, the announcement indicates Beijing is shifting its financial regulatory system to a “twin peaks” model similar to that adopted by countries such as the United Kingdom and Australia.

site_title: Mining the past for artistic inspiration
summary: Three solo art exhibitions, "Moby Dick (I Am The Devil In Your Heart)" by Ian Tee at Yavuz Gallery, "The Water The Body The Spirit" by Ari Bayuaji at Mizuma Gallery, and "Strategies Against Time" by Jacopo Pagin at 39+ Art Space, explore artistic legacies and the psychology of desire and ambition. Tee's paintings draw from Herman Melville's classic novel, while Bayuaji's tapestries are made from discarded plastic and fishing nets, and Pagin's surrealist-inspired works tap into the subconscious. The exhibitions showcase the artists' unique perspectives on the human condition.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
At Walk Walk Don't Run, visitors are welcome into art spaces and design studios (such as Grey Projects,  featured here), to sit down and chat at length with the creatives.
Everything Everywhere All At Once starring Michelle Yeoh is a triumph not just of Asian representation - it is also one of the most culturally astute films in recent memory,
The Dhaka Art Summit opened with a riotous dance conceived by Miet Warlop titled Chant For Hope, an upbeat piece for a post-pandemic future.

site_title: Apple supplier Foxconn wins AirPod order, plans US$200 million factory in India: sources
summary: Foxconn, the world's largest contract electronics maker, has won an order to make AirPods for Apple and plans to build a factory in India worth over $200 million. This deal marks Foxconn's first time becoming an AirPod supplier and underlines efforts to diversify production away from China. The new factory, which will be built in the southern Indian state of Telangana, is expected to start construction in the second half of this year and begin production by the end of 2024.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Foxconn is seen outside the company's building in Taipei, Taiwan, Nov. 10, 2022. REUTERS/Ann Wang/File Photo
Apple has risen about 15 per cent in 2023 and is on course for the biggest quarterly gain in more than a year.
Apple, the world’s most valuable company, began a belt-tightening effort last July, when galloping inflation and recession fears spurred it to take a more cautious stance.
Foxconn, which assembles around 70 per cent of iPhones, has been diversifying production away from China, whose strict Covid restrictions disrupted its biggest iPhone plant last year.

site_title: A net US$3 billion was redeemed from crypto’s USDC stablecoin this week
summary: US$3 billion was redeemed from USDC stablecoin between Mar 13 and Mar 15, following US banking turmoil. Circle Internet Financial, the issuer, said it had redeemed US$3.8 billion of USDC tokens and minted US$800 million. This move helped USDC recover its US$1 peg after its value slumped due to US$3.3 billion of reserves being tied to the collapsed Silicon Valley Bank. Circle has cleared a backlog of requests and is working to bring back banking capabilities. USDC's circulating supply has dropped by roughly 5.9 billion tokens since Mar 10.

site_title: Social media frenzy fuels bank busting panic
summary: Federal authorities took over Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank after massive withdrawals by customers fearing bank collapse, fueled by social media frenzy and online banking ease. The rapid pace of the bank runs, sparked by Twitter and WhatsApp posts, was unprecedented in the age of online communication. Experts warn that the increased use of technology has heightened the risk of bank runs, and regulators need to implement "circuit breakers" to prevent such crises.

images.alt_text: Silicon Valley Bank – a key lender to startups across the United States since the 1980s – collapsed after a sudden run on deposits, prompting regulators to seize control on Friday.
At the end of last year, deposits at Bank of America were down US$8 billion compared to the end of the third quarter.
By promising to reimburse the depositors of Silicon Valley Bank, Biden risks being portrayed as beholden to powerful elites.
The loss of SVB is likely to have a chilling effect on an industry already suffering from higher interest rates.

site_title: Sri Lanka sinks deeper into recession as IMF bailout hangs
summary: Sri Lanka's economy contracted 12.4% in the fourth quarter of 2022, the largest drop in two years, due to high borrowing costs and inflation. The country is seeking a $2.9 billion IMF bailout to stabilize its finances. Despite a four-quarter contraction, the economy may see respite with IMF approval, which could unlock more funding and steady finances. Dollar inflows, a stable currency, and an end to power cuts are expected to boost manufacturing activity.

images.alt_text: Economic mismanagement coupled with the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic left Sri Lanka severely short of US dollars for essential imports at the start of last year tipping the country into the worst financial crisis since Independence from the British in 1948.

“So somewhere in April we will announce ... how we are going to meet those medium-to-long-term (debt) targets. That is the next step,” Sri Lanka central bank governor P Nandalal Weerasinghe said on Thursday.

site_title: Australia employment rebounds in Feb, jobless rate drops to 3.5%
summary: Australia's jobless rate dropped to 3.5% in February, a 50-year low, following a strong rebound in employment with 64,600 net jobs added. Hours worked also increased by 3.9%. The better-than-expected result was overshadowed by concerns over a global recession amid a bank share rout.

site_title: CapitaLand Investment, CDL, UOL are top property picks on trading discount: CGS-CIMB
summary: CGS-CIMB has reiterated its "overweight" view on Singapore's property sector, citing trading discounts in counters like CapitaLand Investment, City Developments Ltd, and UOL Group. The analysts consider the developers' valuations "inexpensive" and note a rebound in home sales in February. Despite moderate price growth expectations, CGS-CIMB recommends investing in developers with visible residential pipelines and strong balance sheets, citing CapitaLand Investment, CDL, and UOL Group as top picks with target prices of S$4.50, S$8.97, and S$8 respectively.

images.alt_text: Generic property landscape in Singapore. CapitaLand.
Yong Hui Ting

site_title: Top Glove reports RM164.7 million loss for Q2
summary: Top Glove, a major glove manufacturer, reported a net loss of RM164.7 million (S$49.4 million) for the second quarter of FY2023, driven by a 58% decline in revenue and rising production costs. The company attributed the loss to the ongoing glove oversupply situation, softer order book, and lack of customer urgency to place orders. Despite this, Top Glove maintained that long-term industry prospects are promising and expressed optimism for the industry's eventual recovery.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Top Glove Corporation's dismal Q1FY23 showing follows two years after the glove maker's best year ever
Although analysts expected the weaker financials, they said the rate at which the declines are taking place is alarming. Companies did not buffer themselves sufficiently during their heydays.
The Malaysian glove maker on Tuesday posted its first quarterly loss since listing amid rising cost pressures and a pullback in demand.
The softer financial performance comes as the industry weathers an adjustment period, dealing with oversupply and excess stockpiling by customers during the pandemic, the group said.

site_title: Fed was the ‘culprit’ on SVB, Signature bankruptcies, Wood says
summary: US Federal Reserve policy, not crypto, is blamed for the bankruptcies of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank, according to Ark Investment chief Cathie Wood. Fed policy led to a VC funding drought and higher yields on money market funds, causing deposits to leave the US banking system. The Fed introduced a new backstop to shore up confidence in the financial system, protecting the entire nation's deposits. This move came after Silicon Valley Bank's fall, the biggest US bank failure in over a decade.

site_title: Asia: Banks feel impact as markets are hit by contagion fears
summary: Asian markets slid on Thursday, with bank stocks leading the decline amid fears of contagion from Credit Suisse's struggles. The Hang Seng fell over 2%, while Tokyo, Sydney, and Shanghai also dropped. Credit Suisse tanked nearly 25% after its main shareholder, Saudi National Bank, stated it would not increase its stake. The bank announced a $54 billion loan to "support" the group. The European Central Bank's tightening campaign is also under scrutiny, with some expecting a rate cut before the end of the year.

images.alt_text: On the Singapore Exchange, losers outnumber gainers 82 to 29.
The Nikkei 225 index was down 1.65 per cent, or 449.80 points, at 26,779.68 in early trade on Thursday.

site_title: US regulators to visit Hong Kong for fresh round of audit inspections: sources
summary: US regulators will conduct a fresh round of audit inspections in Hong Kong, with branches of EY, Deloitte, PricewaterhouseCoopers, and other firms selected for the review. The inspections are part of a deal with Beijing to prevent delistings of Chinese companies from the New York bourse. The US Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (PCAOB) has obtained full inspection access, removing the risk of around 200 Chinese companies being booted off US stock exchanges. The inspections will follow a protocol similar to last year's onsite inspection in Hong Kong, with Chinese officials assisting the US regulators.

site_title: Brokers’ take: RHB raises Food Empire target to S$1.39 after FY2022 earnings surprise
summary: RHB Research has raised its target price for Food Empire to S$1.39 from S$0.95 after the company's FY2022 earnings surprise, driven by strong revenue growth in Russia and Ukraine. Analyst Alfie Yeo attributes this to the group's strong operating cash flow and sustainable profitability in key markets. The brokerage maintains its "buy" call, citing a compelling six times price-to-earnings multiple and a 5.8% estimated FY2023 dividend yield.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
As the geopolitical situation still remains uncertain, Food Empire said it could face some margin pressure due to volatility in the foreign exchange rates and economic situation.
Maybank analysts express confidence that Food Empire will pay its shareholders a special dividend that will bring the group’s total payout for FY2022 to S$0.04.

Profit increase for Q1 2022 was mainly due to higher average selling prices of its products, lower advertising and promotional expense - coupled with higher share of associated profit despite higher foreign exchange loss, the group noted in a business update on Wednesday (May 11).

site_title: Singapore’s 6-month Treasury bill yield drops amid lower Fed rate hike expectations
summary: Singapore's 6-month Treasury bill yield dropped to 3.65% in the latest auction, the lowest since September. The allotment size was $4.6 billion, with an oversubscription rate of 2.8 times. The drop reflects risk aversion amid global market volatility, with the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike expectations pared. The median yield was 3.58% and the average yield was 3.41%. Experts attribute the decline to concerns over financial stability and the potential for the Fed to cut rates, with some predicting yields may plateau until the Fed's next decision.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
The T-bills were around 2.8 times subscribed for the S$4.7 billion allotment in the latest auction.
DBS, UOB and OCBC ATMs at the Singapore Institute of Management (SIM) on March 12, 2020.
While bond yields are up, investors should bear in mind that interest rates are rising because central banks worldwide are trying to tame inflation.
The SSB opened on Tuesday furnishing lower interest rates than the recent yields on Singapore Treasury bills and fixed deposit.
The last time yields were at the 4 per cent level was in 1989.
Due to overwhelming interest, the MAS put out a notice in the afternoon to announce the delay in publication of the results of the latest six-month Treasury bill auction.

site_title: Vietnam looks to ease visa requirements to woo more tourists
summary: Vietnam's Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh has ordered officials to relax visa requirements to attract more foreign tourists, targeting 8 million visitors this year. The move comes after the country struggled post-pandemic to lure international travelers, with less than 3.7 million foreign visitors in 2022. Officials plan to offer more visa waivers, increase stay lengths, and expand the e-visa program to make Vietnam more appealing to tourists. The goal is to reverse the 2019 record of over 18 million international tourists, which fell to 3.7 million in 2022.

site_title: Luxury leather bags could be your next cash cow
summary: Luxury bag prices are expected to continue rising, making them a potential investment opportunity. Brands like Hermès, Dior, Chanel, and Louis Vuitton have seen significant increases in resale values over the past five years. Investment-worthy pieces, such as Hermès' Birkin and Chanel's Classic Flap, tend to fetch high prices due to their rarity and brand equity. However, accessing these pieces can be challenging, and even with rare styles, returns on investment are likely to be lower than those of other luxury items. Experts recommend buying now, as prices are expected to continue increasing, and holding onto investment-worthy pieces for the long term.

images.alt_text: From left: Hermes' Kelly, Dior's Lady Dior, Hermes' Birkin, Chanel's Classic Flap, Louis Vuitton's Speedy handbags in various colours and patterns.

site_title: PwC’s 4,000 legal staffers get AI assistant as law chatbots gain steam
summary: PwC has partnered with AI startup Harvey to provide its 4,000 legal professionals with access to an artificial intelligence platform, offering assistance with contract analysis, regulatory compliance, and other legal advisory services. The platform will not provide legal advice to clients and will not replace lawyers. The partnership is exclusive among the Big Four professional services firms and will also be used to develop custom products and services. Other companies, including Allen & Overy and Casetext, have also started experimenting with generative AI technology in the legal industry.

images.alt_text: In its Jan 16 resignation letter to Evergrande’s audit committee and board, PwC noted it still hadn’t received information relating to “significant matters” of the 2021 audit.
While the world is changing at an unprecedented rate, Bob Moritz, PwC global chairman, indicated the firm isn't feeling any pressure to split the firm the way its rival EY has decided to,

site_title: China home prices rise first time in 18 months after stimulus
summary: China's home prices rose 0.3% in February, marking the first increase in 18 months, as government efforts to revive the real estate sector show signs of paying off. Authorities have provided financial support and lowered mortgage rates in cities, leading to a 15% rise in new home sales by the 100 largest developers. Beijing aims for a soft landing, focusing on shoring up "high-quality" developers, rather than fueling rapid growth. While improvements are limited to popular cities, analysts say it's too early to call an all-round recovery nationwide.

images.alt_text: “It is necessary to strengthen the financial risk disposal mechanism and capacity building, strengthen monitoring, early warning and evaluation,” the central bank said.
Oil supply is still outstripping relatively slow demand, the IEA added, but the market is set to balance by around the middle of the year with China and developing countries driving demand.

site_title: Japan trade deficit narrows sharply from record as imports slow
