summary: Japan's trade deficit narrowed sharply in February to 897.7 billion yen, a reversal of January's record shortfall, as imports slowed due to the Chinese New Year holidays. Exports rose 6.5% driven by car sales, while exports to the US and Europe also gained pace. Despite the narrowing deficit, the 19th consecutive month of trade deficit highlights Japan's ongoing struggle to recover from the COVID-19 impact. Economists warn of downside risks, including global interest rate hikes and banking crises.

images.alt_text: Some companies are favouring loans amid speculation in the bond market that incoming BOJ governor Kazuo Ueda will tweak the yield curve-control framework at some point.
Japan’s wages have grown just about 5 per cent over the last 30 years, far below an average 35 per cent gain among member countries during the same period, OECD data shows.

site_title: Volkswagen presents new low-price electric car
summary: Volkswagen unveiled its new budget electric vehicle, the ID. 2all model, with a range of up to 450 km and a price under 25,000 euros. The company plans to roll out 10 new electric models by 2026, aiming for an 80% electric car share in Europe. Volkswagen is investing 122 billion euros in electric vehicles, with a focus on growing its presence in North America and increasing competitiveness in China. The company expects EVs to make up 10% of its car sales in 2023 and plans to maintain low prices through economies of scale.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen confirmed in December it was looking for sites for a plant in Canada.
The logo of German automaker BMW is seen in Brussels, Belgium February 28, 2023. REUTERS/Yves Herman

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 1.65% lower on banking worries
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 1.65% lower on Thursday due to concerns over Credit Suisse's capital and liquidity levels, deepening fears over the banking sector. The Nikkei 225 index fell 449.80 points to 26,779.68, while the Topix index lost 31.21 points to 1,928.91. Major US indices also declined, with shares in Credit Suisse reaching historic lows. The Swiss National Bank later stated Credit Suisse had adequate capital and was prepared to provide liquidity if needed, but the damage had already been done, with Japanese shares expected to continue with losses.

images.alt_text: Some companies are favouring loans amid speculation in the bond market that incoming BOJ governor Kazuo Ueda will tweak the yield curve-control framework at some point.

site_title: World Bank plan targets US$50 billion lending boost over 10 years
summary: The World Bank is evaluating a plan to boost lending by $50 billion over 10 years through rule changes, aiming to present it at the Spring Meetings next month. The plan involves lowering the minimum equity-to-lending ratio to 19% from 20%, allowing the institution to take more risk with existing capital. The strategy aims to meet challenges such as climate change and pandemics, and is in response to urging from US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and other Group of 20 leaders.

images.alt_text: The Feb 6 earthquakes of 7.8 magnitude and 7.5 magnitude, the most deadly in modern Turkey’s history, killed more than 44,300 people.

Three private banks, which together deal with over 30 per cent of Sri Lanka’s remittances and exports, will receive the facility to fund essential imports, including medicine, food and fertiliser, the IFC said

site_title: Gold prices rise as global banking crisis spurs safe-haven demand
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,919.86 per ounce as global banking crisis fears spurred safe-haven demand. The rise followed troubles at Swiss lender Credit Suisse, which saw shares slump 30% and regulators pledge a liquidity lifeline. US retail sales fell 0.4% in February, while producer prices unexpectedly dropped 0.1%. The US dollar index eased, making bullion cheaper for buyers holding other currencies, and the dollar index eased 0.1%.

images.alt_text: Bullion is often seen as a hedge against inflation, but the opportunity cost of holding the non-yielding asset rises when interest rates are increased to bring down inflation.

site_title: TSMC’s founder says he supports US efforts to slow China’s chip advances
summary: TSMC's founder, Morris Chang, expressed support for US efforts to slow China's chip advances, citing the need to protect Taiwan's economic interests. Chang warned that the "bifurcation" of the global supply chain and reversal of globalization would lead to higher chip prices and reduced ubiquity. He also criticized US "friend-shoring" policies, stating that Taiwan is not included and is considered a "dangerous place" for chip production. Chang noted China's chip manufacturing technology lags behind Taiwan's by 5-6 years, citing TSMC's ability to produce advanced chips with ease compared to China's struggles.

images.alt_text: The firm advanced enough to produce a machine that could print circuit patterns as tiny as 90 nanometres (nm) on silicon wafers — two decades behind ASML
The average overall salary of a new engineer with a master’s degree is T$2 million (S$88,172), according to TSMC.
TSMC has been courted by governments around the world, including the US and Japan, as they seek more domestic production of semiconductors.

site_title: Credit Suisse in crisis taps 50 billion francs from central bank
summary: Credit Suisse, Switzerland's second-largest lender, has arranged to borrow up to $72.6 billion from the Swiss National Bank to shore up its finances amid a collapse in market confidence. The bank is also offering to repurchase up to $3 billion of its debt to restore investor confidence. This is the largest move to stabilize the bank since the 2008 financial crisis, following a 31% slump in its shares and deep financial distress.

images.alt_text: Switzerland’s second-largest lender has been pummelled over the last several years by a series of blowups, scandals, leadership changes and legal issues.
While Credit Suisse’s American depositary receipts pared losses after the announcement by Swiss authorities, they were still down 14 per cent at the close of regular trading in New York.
The regulator confirmed Credit Suisse meets the capital and liquidity requirements it imposes on systemically important banks.

site_title: Swiss government holds talks on options to stabilise Credit Suisse
summary: The Swiss government is discussing options to stabilize Credit Suisse, including a liquidity backstop, a potential separation of the Swiss unit, and a possible acquisition of a stake in the bank. The bank's shares plummeted 31% on Wednesday, and its debt insurance costs reached crisis levels, prompting the Swiss National Bank and regulator Finma to issue a statement of support. The move aims to shore up confidence and prevent a potential break-up of the bank, which has been struggling with financial issues and outflows of assets.

images.alt_text: Several other Credit Suisse bonds plunged by more than 10 US cents on the dollar on Wednesday, leading declines in New York credit trading, with spreads flaring above 1,000 basis points across the maturity curve.
The safe-haven US dollar rose sharply, with the US dollar index surging 0.9 per cent to 104.65.
Credit Suisse on Tuesday published its annual report for 2022 saying the bank had identified “material weaknesses” in controls over financial reporting and not yet stemmed customer outflows.
Lehmann, who took up the role in January 2022, will not receive the standard fee that’s usually paid on top of board members’ salaries.

site_title: AusGroup to terminate services for Esso Thailand refinery
summary: AusGroup Thailand, a subsidiary placed under judicial management, will terminate its agreement with Esso Thailand's refinery to provide scaffolding and insulation services due to a failed bid to attract investments or restructure the company. The decision was made to mitigate potential exposure from the company's inability to fulfill its obligations, given its current financial position. The agreement will cease 45 days from the notice date, and trading of AusGroup's shares remains suspended.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
It's been a rather unfortunate turn of events for AusGroup, which had held up over oil’s previous downturns
Shane Kimpton, chief executive officer of AusGroup. The company's application for judicial management comes after restructuring plans, talk of potential sales and several resignations.

site_title: New Zealand’s rising recession risk suggests tightening may slow
summary: New Zealand's economy contracted 0.6% in Q4 2022, exceeding expectations, and may have entered recession earlier than predicted by the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ). This contraction and lower-than-expected growth in the fourth quarter suggest the central bank may slow the pace of interest rate hikes, with some economists now predicting a 25-point rate hike instead of a 50-point increase. The RBNZ's goal to engineer a recession to control inflation may be less aggressive than initially planned.

images.alt_text: A pedestrian passes buildings in Auckland, New Zealand. Photographer: Fiona Goodall/Bloomberg
The central bank reiterated it expects a recession starting in the second quarter of this year, but the economy is seen bouncing back a little sooner next year.

New Zealand inflation is running at a near-three decade high of 7.2 per cent and is increasingly becoming the key political issue ahead of the election in October, which polls indicate will be tightly contested.

site_title: Japan firms turn to loans for longer-term funding amid BOJ risks
summary: Japanese companies are turning to loans for longer-term funding amid speculation that the Bank of Japan's yield curve-control framework may be tweaked by incoming governor Kazuo Ueda. Loan rates have become more favorable, with new loans averaging 0.704% compared to higher corporate bond coupons of 0.86%. Major banks have seen a surge in loan demand, with outstanding amounts reaching a two-decade high of 240 trillion yen in January. Companies such as Japan Airlines and Suntory Holdings are opting for loans over bonds to refinance debt, citing concerns about rising interest rates and the potential for monetary policy changes.

images.alt_text: Japan’s wages have grown just about 5 per cent over the last 30 years, far below an average 35 per cent gain among member countries during the same period, OECD data shows.

site_title: Sri Lanka’s economy shrinks 7.8% in 2022
summary: Sri Lanka's economy contracted 7.8% in 2022, the country's worst financial crisis in over seven decades, due to economic mismanagement and the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. The agriculture sector shrank 4.6%, industries contracted 16%, and services dropped 2%. The country is awaiting a $2.9 billion IMF bailout program, with growth expected to shrink by 3% in 2023 but rebound in 2024.

site_title: TikTok says US threatens ban if Chinese owners don’t sell stakes
summary: The US government has demanded that TikTok's Chinese owners divest their stakes in the app or face a possible US ban, according to a spokesperson for TikTok. The move comes after the Biden administration raised concerns that TikTok's US user data could be passed on to China's government. The US Treasury-led Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) had previously recommended that ByteDance divest TikTok, but the company has rejected this, stating that divestment does not solve the problem of national security concerns.

images.alt_text: TikTok agreed last year to implement a number of measures to address US officials’ security concerns.
YouGov data shows that about 41 per cent of people in Singapore aged between 18 and 24 have used TikTok in October 2022.

Mori thinks it’s a little strange that his coffee shop has a queue out the door most days. He hears from his customers that he’s famous on the Internet, but he doesn’t use social media and doesn’t have a cell phone.

site_title: Stablecoin operator moves US$1 billion in reserves to Bahamas
summary: Archblock, the operator of the world's fifth-largest stablecoin, TrueUSD, has moved $1 billion in reserves to a bank in the Bahamas, Capital Union Bank, amid worsening banking conditions for crypto businesses in the US. The move follows the collapse of several crypto-friendly lenders in the US, including Signature Bank, which had held $852 million in reserves for Archblock. The decision was made to secure funds and access short-term US Treasuries, with Archblock's chief financial officer citing concentration risk and lack of clear regulations.

site_title: US still struggling with snow, wind and flooding
summary: A winter storm in the North-east and flooding in the West left nearly 400,000 US homes without power on March 15, 2023. Heavy snowfall and wind toppled trees and blocked roads along the upper Atlantic coast, while torrential rains caused flooding in California, including a levee burst in the town of Pajaro. Utility crews are working to restore power, with warnings to exercise caution, particularly for those with heart problems. Additional snowfall is forecast for the region.

images.alt_text: Falling trees took down power lines and blocked roads, leaving about 193,000 homes and businesses without electricity by 4.30 am local time, according to the poweroutage.us website.

site_title: ECB faces rate dilemma on anxious eve of hike touted for months
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is set to make a crucial decision on interest rates on Thursday, amid market turmoil centered around Credit Suisse Group. The ECB may consider a smaller quarter-point step or even staying on hold, to avoid harsh hindsight judgments if the situation rapidly deteriorates. The decision comes as inflation figures for February showed underlying price pressures surged to a new record, and investors have split the difference, pricing in a smaller move. Former ECB officials have advised caution, warning of the potential for a repeat of past mistakes.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen outside the European Central Bank (ECB) building, in Frankfurt, Germany, July 21, 2022. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo
The ECB’s 26-member governing council will “very, very likely” raise interest rates by another half a percentage point at its meeting in Frankfurt, president Christine Lagarde said last week.

site_title: Nasa unveils new spacesuits for astronauts returning to the Moon
summary: NASA has unveiled new spacesuits designed for astronauts returning to the Moon as part of the Artemis program. The suits provide greater flexibility and protection from the lunar environment, along with specialized tools for exploration. The agency plans to land the first woman, person of color, and astronaut from another country on the Moon by 2025, with the first landing potentially occurring as early as 2025. The new suits were developed in partnership with Axiom Space, with a combined contract worth up to $3.5 billion.

site_title: Taiwan shipping giant Evergreen to give staff 11-month mid-year bonus after massive year-end payout
summary: Taiwanese shipping giant Evergreen Marine will give its staff mid-year bonuses worth 10 to 11 months of salary for their 2022 performance, following a record-breaking year-end payout of up to 52 months' pay in December. The company posted a record net profit of NT$334.2 billion for its 2022 financial year, driven by the rebound of the global container shipping industry. The generous payouts have sparked envy on social media and made Evergreen Marine the top-ranked dream employer in Taiwan, according to a job portal survey.

images.alt_text: evergreen

site_title: Wholesale central bank digital currencies could change cross-border payments
summary: Wholesale central bank digital currencies (CBDCs) could revolutionize cross-border payments in international trade. The Bank for International Settlements highlights the challenges in cross-border payments, including paper documentation and counter-party risks. However, experts believe that wholesale CBDCs can provide a secure, efficient, and transparent solution. Eight jurisdictions are currently exploring wholesale CBDCs, with projects like Project Dunbar and UBIN+ aiming to deliver a proof of concept by mid-2023. Fiat backing is essential for wholesale CBDCs, giving them an edge over private cryptocurrencies. This development is particularly important as global trade finance is poised to digitalize, driven by the passage of the UK's Electronic Trade Document Bill and ESG concerns.

images.alt_text: The real value in the crypto industry comes not from speculating in cryptocurrencies, but from tokenising assets for use cases that increase economic efficiency or enhance social inclusion, said Ravi Menon.

site_title: BOE’s next rate decision may be overshadowed by market turmoil
summary: The Bank of England's next interest rate decision may be overshadowed by market turmoil, as investors pare back bets on a rate hike amid concerns about the health of Credit Suisse and the UK's banking system. Chancellor Jeremy Hunt's £91 billion fiscal stimulus, announced in the budget, may also influence the decision, with economists warning that it could boost demand and inflation. The BOE is expected to consider the broader economic impact of the stimulus, which could lead to a more dovish stance if financial stability concerns fade.

images.alt_text: Climate programmes will slip lower on the BOE’s agenda so that officials can focus more on the core operations such as financial stability, markets and a digital currency

site_title: UK woos corporate investment with tax breaks in latest budget
summary: UK Chancellor Jeremy Hunt presented a "budget for growth" to boost business investment, productivity, and employment. The budget includes tax breaks for investments, offsetting a 25% increase in headline corporate tax for companies earning over £250,000. The UK Office of Budget Responsibility predicts a 3% increase in business investment and a 0.2% GDP decline this year, followed by growth of 1.8% and 2.5% in 2024 and 2025, respectively. However, critics, including opposition Labour Party leader Keir Starmer, call the budget inadequate to address the nation's economic problems, with concerns about rising taxes and high government borrowings.

images.alt_text: Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt has ruled out a major spending spree or big tax cuts in his budget plan but confirmed a three-month extension of energy bill subsidies for households and extended a decade-long fuel duty freeze.
The next generation of business incentives could bring together domestic and regional strengths, offering investors the best of both worlds – all from a base in Singapore.
Singapore has an edge within the region specifically – and Asia remains a crucial market for MNEs, said analysts.

site_title: Credit Suisse troubles erupt into full-blown crisis as banks seek protection
summary: Credit Suisse's financial troubles escalated into a full-blown crisis, with the bank's stock and bonds plummeting 31% and 40% respectively. Global banks rushed to shield themselves from potential fallout, with some, like BNP Paribas, refusing to accept derivatives contracts with Credit Suisse. Swiss authorities pledged emergency financing if needed, but the crisis has raised concerns about the global banking system's stability. The bank's persistent problems are seen as a significant threat to the credit markets, with experts warning that Credit Suisse's woes carry bigger problems for the entire financial system.

images.alt_text: The regulator confirmed Credit Suisse meets the capital and liquidity requirements it imposes on systemically important banks.

Several other Credit Suisse bonds plunged by more than 10 US cents on the dollar on Wednesday, leading declines in New York credit trading, with spreads flaring above 1,000 basis points across the maturity curve.

site_title: Baidu showcases China’s answer to ChatGPT in high-stakes debut
summary: Baidu is set to debut its "Ernie Bot" chatbot equivalent to ChatGPT in a high-stakes launch event, marking China's first move in a battle with the US to dominate generative AI. The Beijing-based company is leading a race with peers like Alibaba and Tencent to create a next-generation platform for China's largest internet market. Baidu's Ernie Bot is expected to power its cloud and content businesses, and the company is planning to integrate it into its main operations, including search and autonomous-driving software. The launch comes as Baidu aims to reinvent itself from an online marketing firm to a provider of deeper technology, with a focus on artificial intelligence.

images.alt_text: With the update, text responses from GPT-4 will be more accurate, and – in future – will come from both image and text inputs in a major leap forward for the technology.
Microsoft said a line of business-intelligence and app-development tools within Power Platform, including Power Virtual Agent and AI Builder, was updated with the new capabilities.
The product, to be called “HunyuanAide”, will incorporate Tencent’s AI training model named “Hunyuan”.
Baidu is regarded as at the forefront of efforts to create a Chinese rival to the AI platform developed by OpenAI and backed by Microsoft.

site_title: Alpina Holdings secures term sheet to buy Wan Dormitory for S$24 million
summary: Alpina Holdings has secured a non-binding term sheet to acquire Wan Dormitory in Singapore for S$24 million. The property, located at 180 Woodlands Industrial Park E5, was previously disposed of by Oriental Group in 2016 for S$24.2 million. The acquisition is intended to address Singapore's dormitory shortage and provide additional space for Alpina's foreign workers. Negotiations between Alpina and the property's vendors will continue until September 12.

images.alt_text: Alpina Holdings, Terrenus Energy win 6th solar tender from HDB

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Thursday amid new banking woes; STI down 0.9%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.9% to 3,143.43, due to fresh fears sparked by a liquidity crisis at Credit Suisse. The US and European markets also ended in the red overnight, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.9% and the pan-European Stoxx 600 index closing 2.9% lower. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also fell, with DBS dropping 1.8% and UOB losing 0.5%.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
The insurer is proposing a higher second dividend.

site_title: After strategic 787 wins, Boeing jet battle shifts to factory floor
summary: Boeing secured its fifth-largest commercial order by value with a $37 billion sale of 78 Dreamliners to Saudi Arabian Airlines and Riyadh Air. The deal caps sales of almost 200 Dreamliners over the past four months, giving Boeing a major industrial and political win against European rival Airbus. However, the production and delivery of the 787s face significant challenges, including supply chain pressures and production quality issues, which may impact Boeing's target to boost production to 10 a month by 2026.

site_title: UK economy will avoid recession this year, says Hunt
summary: Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt has ruled out a major spending spree or big tax cuts in his budget plan, but confirmed a three-month extension of energy bill subsidies for households and extended a decade-long fuel duty freeze. The UK economy is set to avoid a recession in 2023, with a 0.2% contraction expected, down from a 1.4% contraction projected in November. Economic growth is forecast to rise 1.8% in 2024 and 2.5% in 2025.

images.alt_text: Britain's gross domestic product has grown 0.3 per cent after a 0.5 per cent decline in December,

site_title: Credit Suisse to get liquidity backstop if needed, SNB says
summary: Switzerland's central bank and financial regulator said Credit Suisse Group will receive a liquidity backstop if needed, aiming to restore confidence in the troubled lender after a record slump in its shares. Credit Suisse shares fell 31% on Wednesday and bonds hit record lows, amid concerns over the scandal-ridden lender's financial health. The Swiss National Bank and Finma stated that Credit Suisse meets capital and liquidity requirements, but did not specify terms of the liquidity backstop. The move aims to stabilize the bank after a tumultuous day of discussions over a potential separation or tie-up with rival UBS.

images.alt_text: While Credit Suisse’s American depositary receipts pared losses after the announcement by Swiss authorities, they were still down 14 per cent at the close of regular trading in New York.

site_title: Europe: Shares clock worst day in a year, Credit Suisse hits new record low
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index closed 3% lower, its worst day in over a year, following a selloff in bank stocks amid renewed concerns about sector stresses. Credit Suisse plummeted to a fresh record low, contributing to the decline. The banks sector index logged its steepest one-day drop in over a year, marking a reversal of its best day this year.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended at 31,874.57 on Wednesday, down 0.9 per cent, but nearly 450 points above its session low.

site_title: South Korea likely to extend market stabilisation steps as risks grow
summary: South Korean financial regulators are likely to extend market stabilisation measures due to growing threats, including a slump in real estate and offshore crises. The measures, introduced since October, include increasing liquidity for real estate project-finance debt and easing bank liquidity rules. Despite recent bond yield tumbles and stabilised spreads, vulnerable sectors, such as project-financing asset-backed securities, haven't fully recovered. Authorities are cautious amid potential fallout from the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and Credit Suisse, and the spread between yields on corporate notes remains elevated.

images.alt_text: Earlier this year, South Korea launched several policy measures to support sharply falling property prices.
The labour market is a key barometer of Korea’s economic performance following a year and a half of monetary tightening by the central bank.

site_title: South Korea’s Yoon seeks friend in Tokyo hours after North Korea missile launch
summary: South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol visited Tokyo just hours after North Korea fired a ballistic missile, marking the first visit by a South Korean president to Japan in 12 years. Yoon met with Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida to discuss regional security, supply chain cooperation, and reviving "shuttle diplomacy." The visit aims to strengthen ties amid perceived threats from North Korea and China, but Japan remains cautious about immediate improvements in relations. Yoon's visit comes amid skepticism at home, with 64% of respondents saying there's no need to rush to improve ties with Japan if there's no change in its attitude.

images.alt_text: South Korea's President Yoon Suk Yeol and his wife Kim Keon-hee arrive at Tokyo International Airport (Haneda Airport) in Tokyo, Japan March 16, 2023.   REUTERS/Issei Kato

site_title: Meta layoffs reveal a deeper truth: Tech exceptionalism is dead
summary: Meta Platforms has announced a nearly 25% staff reduction, with an additional 10,000 layoffs on top of the 11,000 already cut in November. This move reflects a shift away from tech exceptionalism, where rapid headcount growth was seen as a sign of success. Instead, companies are turning to traditional metrics like profitability and profit margins. Other tech companies, such as Salesforce, may follow suit, with CEO Marc Benioff having cut his workforce to focus on profit margins. The move is seen as a response to Wall Street demands and a changing economy, with CEO Mark Zuckerberg dubbing 2023 the "Year of Efficiency".

site_title: Garbage mounts in Paris as Macron eyes French pension reform vote
summary: Protests against French President Emmanuel Macron's pension reform, which aims to raise the retirement age from 62 to 64, have led to overflowing garbage bins and bags of trash left on the streets of Paris. A rolling strike by municipal garbage collectors has resulted in an estimated 7,000 tonnes of trash piling up, with 480,000 people marching to protest the reform. Despite opposition from two-thirds of French people, Macron's minority government seeks to secure parliamentary backing for the legislation. The Senate and National Assembly are set to hold votes on a compromise bill, with the outcome uncertain, potentially leading to a confidence vote if the government loses.

images.alt_text: Strikers blocking a motorway on Thursday; polls show that a majority of voters oppose President Emmanuel Macron’s plan to delay the state pension age by two years to 64.

site_title: ValueMax addresses significant loans, borrowings exceeding S$600 million
summary: ValueMax, a Singapore-listed company, has significant loans and borrowings of S$610.5 million in its 2022 financial year, which caught the attention of the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading (SGX-ST). The company cited its pawning and moneylending businesses as the main reasons for the increased loans and borrowings. Despite a net profit position, ValueMax reported a net cash outflow from operating activities of S$163.4 million, citing a working capital outflow due to growing trade receivables. The company has banking facilities to fulfill its payment obligations and maintains sufficient cash and cash equivalents to meet daily cash management needs.

site_title: Changi Airport regains crown, named world’s best airport for 12th time
summary: Changi Airport has regained its title as the world's best airport for the 12th time, according to Skytrax's 2023 World Airport Awards. The airport, which was previously dethroned in 2021 and 2022 due to the Covid-19 pandemic, regained its top spot after a global survey conducted between August 2022 and February 2023. Changi Airport also took home awards for best in Asia, best for leisure amenities, and best for airport dining. The airport's popularity has seen passenger numbers return to 80% of pre-pandemic levels, with expectations to reach pre-pandemic levels by 2024.

images.alt_text: In 2022, some 54 new tenants opened in Jewel Changi Airport, translating to more than a new store every week, according to chief executive officer of Jewel Changi Airport Development James Fong.

site_title: CICT unit issues HK$755 million fixed rate notes due 2033 priced at 4.85%

site_title: US tariffs on metals, some China goods raised American prices
summary: US tariffs imposed on Chinese goods have led to a one-to-one increase in US import prices, contradicting President Trump's claim that China paid the cost of the duties. A report by the US International Trade Commission found that prices for imports from China rose 25% in 2021, while US-produced goods prices rose 3-4%. The tariffs lowered Chinese imports by 13% and raised US output by 0.4%. The Biden administration is reviewing the tariffs' effectiveness, considering keeping them in place to leverage China into changing unfair practices.

site_title: Tighter rules for corporate finance advisers may weigh on listings’ attractiveness
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) introduced new business conduct requirements for corporate finance advisers, which may impact the timeline for listings and reduce their attractiveness. Industry practitioners expect minimal differences in due diligence, but the new rules may lead to greater enforcement action and extra documentation, potentially weighing on listing activities. The stricter regulations could also result in higher costs for companies seeking to list.

site_title: Singapore’s F&B industry back to pre-Covid levels but cautious outlook remains
summary: Singapore's food and beverage (F&B) industry has largely recovered to pre-Covid levels, with mid- to high-end restaurants seeing significant gains. Boosted by corporate functions, big events, and second Michelin stars, F&B operators are cautiously optimistic despite higher operating costs and manpower woes. While new entrants increase competition, established players continue to thrive, and gains are seen across all market segments. However, challenges persist, including inbound tourism not yet compensating for local dining, and ongoing manpower issues.

site_title: US arrests Chinese tycoon who backed Trump advisor Bannon
summary: US authorities have arrested Chinese tycoon Guo Wengui, also known as Ho Wan Kwok, on charges of leading a complex conspiracy to defraud his online followers out of over $1 billion. Guo, who has ties to former Trump adviser Steve Bannon, was accused of bilking funds from participants in an investment scheme to buy luxuries, including a yacht and a mansion. He pleaded not guilty but consented to detention. This arrest comes nine years after Guo fled China, where he faced charges of fraud and corruption. Guo's arrest is a significant development in the ongoing investigation into his business dealings and his alleged ties to Bannon.

site_title: California storm blackouts plunge Silicon Valley into darkness
summary: A storm in California's Silicon Valley caused widespread power outages, leaving approximately 193,000 homes and businesses without electricity. Falling trees took down power lines and blocked roads, resulting from heavy rain and strong winds brought by an atmospheric river. The National Weather Service warned of flash flooding and localized areas of heavy rain, which are expected to continue overnight. Utility workers are working to restore power, but the exact timeline is not specified.

site_title: Bagging an investment opportunity
summary: Luxury handbags are being considered as a viable investment opportunity, with some bags, such as those from Hermes and Chanel, appreciating in value. According to Knight Frank's 2022 luxury investment index, handbags are the fourth most popular passion investment, with collectors carrying a significant nest egg. Buying the right bags and selling them at the right time can also net owners a profit, making luxury bag investment a potentially lucrative venture.

site_title: Hundreds of thousands of workers strike in latest UK industrial action
summary: Hundreds of thousands of UK workers, including junior doctors, civil servants, teachers, and London Underground train drivers, went on strike on March 15, 2023, in a mass walkout. The stoppage, which was the largest single day of industrial action since last year, was sparked by the government's refusal to offer pay hikes to match inflation. The strikes are part of a broader wave of unrest across the economy, with workers demanding better pay, conditions, and job security. The government has offered a 2% pay rise, which was rejected by striking workers, who are calling for a 10% increase.

images.alt_text: British finance minister Jeremy Hunt  – who is due to make a budget speech to parliament at around 1230 GMT – has dismissed calls from other lawmakers in the ruling Conservative Party for big tax cuts now to boost their fortunes before an election expected in 2024.

British employers agreed pay rises averaging 5.0 per cent during the three months to the end of January, well above historic norms, and a tight labour market means pay settlements are likely to remain high, a survey showed on Wednesday.

site_title: ECB quizzes banks on ties to Credit Suisse, sources say
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is investigating financial ties between Credit Suisse and eurozone banks, with supervisors contacting banks to quiz them on their exposure to the struggling Swiss lender. Credit Suisse's largest shareholder said it could not provide any more support, causing the bank's value to drop nearly a fifth. However, ECB supervisors do not see Credit Suisse's problems as systemic, and the inquiry is focused on specific bank exposure.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as Credit Suisse renews bank worries
summary: US stocks opened lower on Wednesday, March 15, as Credit Suisse's renewed banking concerns fueled market worries. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 395.53 points, or 1.23%, to 31,759.87, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. The declines came despite hopes of a less aggressive monetary policy move by the Federal Reserve next week, driven by US economic data.

site_title: Stocks, US futures reel amid Credit Suisse turmoil
summary: European stocks plummeted over 2% as Credit Suisse turmoil worsened, with banks experiencing significant losses. US futures contracts fell over 1%, while the 10-year Treasury yield dropped 16 basis points. Renewed banking sector jitters complicate policy makers' efforts to combat inflation, with some predicting a possible interest rate cut by year-end. Analysts say a resilient macro backdrop and tighter lending standards will make a difficult trade-off between inflation and financial stability risks.

site_title: Fed gets more room to pause rate hikes after drops in producer prices, retail sales
summary: The US Federal Reserve has more room to pause interest-rate hikes after producer prices and retail sales declined in February. The producer price index fell 0.1% and retail sales declined 0.4%, indicating easing inflation pressures and consumer spending. These data points give the Fed more flexibility to reassess its interest-rate hiking plans, which have been impacted by the banking crisis.

site_title: US business inventories fall for first time in nearly two years

This decline follows a 0.3% gain in December and was weaker than expected. Inventories increased 11.1% year-over-year, but the drop in January's inventory levels could offset this growth, suggesting a potential drag on economic growth.

site_title: Vietnam’s travel players parry rising costs and stiff competition amid industry’s rebound
summary: Vietnam's tourism industry is experiencing a rebound, with tourist arrivals below pre-pandemic levels, but struggling with high costs and stiff competition. Average room rates are 70-80% of pre-pandemic levels, and hoteliers are competing for every guest. To attract customers, they are offering discounts, new services, and technology upgrades. Despite this, Vietnamese tourism has not fully overcome the crisis period, and hoteliers need to adapt to the changing market.

summary: Oil prices plummeted US$5 a barrel to their lowest in over a year due to mounting banking fears, particularly surrounding Credit Suisse. Brent crude dropped 4.9% to US$73.69 a barrel. Experts warn of a risk-asset pullout across various instruments, with oil prices expected to remain volatile.

site_title: SMEs can tap digitalisation, grants to mitigate rising costs: business leaders
summary: Singaporean business leaders emphasize the need for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to adopt digital tools and utilize government schemes to mitigate rising costs. This can help SMEs become more productive and efficient, crucial in today's volatile economic environment. The shortage of talent, particularly in tech, is a significant constraint, with job market demand outpacing supply. By leveraging digital solutions and government support, SMEs can improve their competitiveness and lay the foundation for long-term success.

summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) must consider software options that can be integrated with their existing solutions to stay competitive in the rapidly changing business landscape. Despite limited resources, the right software can empower SMEs to deliver a faster and more efficient customer experience. A range of software solutions, including CRM, customer service, and cloud storage, can help SMEs run their business processes smoothly and ensure customer success. site_title: Biden administration looks to free up wireless spectrum for advanced technology
summary: The Biden administration has launched a National Spectrum Strategy to identify 1,500 megahertz of wireless spectrum for repurposing for advanced technology needs, including 5G, 6G networks, and connected vehicles. The NTIA is seeking public input to repurpose spectrum for competition and innovation, with a focus on areas such as aviation safety, weather prediction, and industrial applications. The strategy aims to address current and future spectrum needs, and is part of a broader effort to manage the US's wireless spectrum.

site_title: US: Stocks end mostly lower as bank shares face more pressure
summary: US stocks ended mostly lower on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.9% to 31,874.57. Bank shares faced pressure due to concerns of more bank failures. Despite this, major indices spent most of the day in the red, with investors on high alert for any news that could be disappointing or related to banks.

site_title: Sweden faces recession as housing market troubles take toll on economy
summary: Sweden is facing a recession due to a troubled housing market. Over the last 20 years, house prices have almost quadrupled, outpacing wage growth and boosted by generous mortgage tax relief and low real estate taxes. This has led to a limited rental market and under-supply of housing, causing households with big mortgages to cut spending as interest rates rise. The country is set to be the only EU economy experiencing outright recession this year, with the central bank struggling to curb inflation due to housing market worries.

images.alt_text: Soaring consumer prices and a string of interest-rate increases have dealt a heavy blow to the Swedish economy, which is particularly sensitive to rising borrowing costs.

site_title: Fintech startup Stripe integrating OpenAI’s new GPT-4 AI
summary: Stripe, a fintech startup, is integrating OpenAI's new GPT-4 artificial intelligence (AI) model into its digital payment processing and other products. This represents one of the first known integrations of OpenAI's GPT-4 technology, highlighting large companies' interest in embedding AI in their product offerings. The move follows OpenAI's announcement of the new AI model, which has powered the popular chatbot ChatGPT.

site_title: Pakistan police postpone arrest of ex-PM Imran Khan, easing unrest
summary: Pakistan's Lahore high court ordered police to postpone the arrest of former Prime Minister Imran Khan until Thursday, easing unrest and clashes with his supporters outside his home. The court intervened after police fired water cannon and tear gas in response to protests. The decision brings an end to the clashes, which had been escalating since Khan's arrest warrant was issued. Security forces withdrew from the area, easing political instability in the nuclear-armed nation. The postponement will allow Khan to remain at his home until Thursday.
