summary: A landmark treaty has been agreed upon to protect biodiversity in the high seas, preserving marine creatures like the whale shark. The treaty, which took two decades to negotiate, aims to conserve and sustainably use marine biological diversity beyond national jurisdiction. The agreement reinforces efforts to protect the world's oceans and their inhabitants, following a series of high-profile fishing and environmental issues. The treaty's implementation is expected to have a significant impact on marine conservation, with the whale shark and other marine species benefiting from the new regulations.

images.alt_text: This aerial photo taken on December 25, 2022 shows cargo ships loaded with containers berthing at Yantian Port in Shenzhen, in China's southern Guangdong province. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Pockets of opportunity for Asean-UK ties to be further strengthened: forum
summary: The UK-Asean Business Forum in London highlighted opportunities for strengthening ties between the two regions. Representatives from the UK and Asean emphasized the need for greater collaboration in areas such as digital assistance, education, sustainability, and green finance. Bill Winters, Standard Chartered CEO, noted that Asean's economy is poised for growth, with developing Asia expected to outpace China for the first time in decades. The UK is committed to strengthening its ties with Asean, with a goal of opening markets, sharing knowledge, and engaging business communities.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan
banner, great britain, british

site_title: B2B startups look more attractive in tough climate, but VCs need different skills for this game
summary: B2B startups are gaining attractiveness in a tough funding climate due to their better capital efficiency and lower risk of burning cash. Unlike consumer-facing ventures, B2B startups typically have more stable financials and make sense in a rising cost of capital environment. Investors are scrutinizing pitch decks and financials, favoring B2B startups over consumer-facing ventures. This shift is driven by the limited consumer spending power in developing South-east Asian markets like Indonesia, where per capita income is lower.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

Workers at a market in Kampung Baru village at the port city of Balikpapan in East Kalimantan, Borneo, Indonesia, on Tuesday, March 7, 2023. Indonesia lowered taxes on some investments and sweetened land acquisition terms as part of efforts to attract funds for its $34 billion new capital project thats struggling to take off. Photographer: Rony Zakaria/Bloomberg
The quarterly data raises concerns over the potential for a further slowdown in venture funding this year.
Patricia Sosrodjojo, partner at Seedstars International Ventures.
Willowmore produces smart locks pictured above, which could be unlocked using your phone rather than a physical key.

site_title: CLSA to double South-east Asia investment bank team in five years
summary: CLSA, the investment banking arm of China's state-owned conglomerate Citic Group, plans to double its staff in South-east Asia over the next five years, aiming to reach around 50 employees. The move is driven by the region's rapid growth, with China's reopening expected to increase inquiries from Chinese corporates seeking investments in the area. CLSA's parent company, Citic Securities, currently leads the global league tables for initial public offerings, with US$1.8 billion worth of deals this year.

images.alt_text: HSBC was judged to provide both a halo effect of giving confidence to customers and markets, and to have the upfront funds to pump into SVB in extra liquidity if needed.

site_title: Amazon to test satellite Internet service starting next year
summary: Amazon plans to launch its first Project Kuiper production satellites in 2024 and start beta testing its satellite internet service with customers the same year. The constellation, consisting of 3,236 low-Earth satellites, aims to provide low-latency internet coverage to millions of potential customers worldwide. Amazon's senior vice-president of devices and services, Dave Limp, showcased prototype user terminals that will be used to tap into the satellite constellation, including a small seven-inch-square model. This marks a significant step towards Amazon's ambitious internet-from-space service.

images.alt_text: Amazon in 2017 announced plans for a second headquarters that would ultimately house 50,000 employees, prompting cities around North America to bid ferociously for the project.
Last year, AWS had announced a US$5 billion investment in Thailand.

site_title: Europe: Stocks log strongest one-day gain this year after three-day rout
summary: European stocks logged their strongest one-day gain this year, rebounding from a three-day 3.9% selloff, with the Stoxx 600 index closing 1.5% higher. The rally was driven by a resilient banking sector outlook and growing optimism over a slowdown in the Federal Reserve's rate-hiking cycle. European banks rebounded 2.5% after their worst single-day sell-off in over a year.

site_title: Women more likely to bag jobs paying US$100,000  despite fewer applications
summary: Women are less likely to apply for jobs paying US$100,000 or more, with fewer than 40% of applicants being female. However, those who do apply are more likely to get hired. Research shows women tend to only apply for roles they're 100% qualified for, whereas men apply for positions they're not fully qualified for. This may be due to lower confidence in finding a new job, with 13% of women feeling very confident, compared to 30% of men. Despite this, women who do apply are often high-quality candidates.

images.alt_text: Office workers / PMET in CBD along Cross Street March 4, 2022.

site_title: HSBC starts to dig into what it bought from Silicon Valley Bank
summary: HSBC has begun examining the financial details of Silicon Valley Bank's (SVB) UK arm, acquired by HSBC for £1, following a rapid deal-making process. The acquisition was finalized on Monday, with HSBC's management not speaking to SVB UK's senior executives before signing the deal. The sparse details in the data room set up by Rothschild added to the challenge. This examination is crucial for HSBC to understand the financial implications of the acquisition and ensure a smooth integration.

images.alt_text: HSBC’s UK-based ring-fenced subsidiary bought the unit for £1 on Monday.
The acquisition follows moves by US financial regulators on Sunday, to assure all depositors their money was safe following SVB’s collapse.

site_title: Vietnam central bank cuts rates to support growth
summary: Vietnam's central bank cut interest rates for the first time since 2020 to support economic growth, aiming for a 6.5% GDP growth this year. The cuts aim to increase liquidity, control inflation, and remove obstacles for businesses and individuals. The annual rediscount rate, overnight electronic interbank rate, and loan interest rate were each reduced by 1 percentage point, effective March 15. This move reverses a trend of rate increases and comes as inflation is under control, with the goal of keeping inflation below 4.5% this year.

images.alt_text: Vietnam's property crisis started last year, after officials issued a crackdown on corporate bond issuance following allegations of illegal activities.

site_title: Facebook-parent Meta to lay off 10,000 employees in second round of job cuts
summary: Meta Platforms, the parent company of Facebook, is laying off 10,000 employees in its second round of mass layoffs, following a 11,000 job cut in November 2022. CEO Mark Zuckerberg aims to reduce the company's team size by 10,000 and close 5,000 open roles, as part of a cost-cutting plan to reach $89-95 billion in expenses. This move is part of the tech industry's broader trend of mass layoffs, with over 280,000 workers let go since 2022.

site_title: Fidelity, Schroders win big on Treasuries bets as markets swoon
summary: Top money managers Fidelity, Schroders, and M&G Investments are reaping gains from the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank, which triggered a rally in US Treasuries. Yields on two-year Treasuries plummeted 65 basis points, the largest move since the 1987 stock market crash. Funds are positioning for recession, with some predicting a pause in Fed rate hikes and even a potential cut in rates. Experts believe the crisis may prompt the Fed to reconsider its tightening path, fueling further gains in Treasuries.

images.alt_text: US authorities’ efforts to support the banking sector has spurred some calls for the central bank to soften its policy stance, but there is a lack of consensus on how the crisis will impact official thinking.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Ho Bee Land, Wing Tai, Boustead, Soilbuild
summary: Wing Tai Holdings' wholly-owned subsidiary Wincove Investment acquired Holland Tower at 10 Holland Heights for S$76.3 million. Meanwhile, Ho Bee Land sold two industrial properties for S$115 million, expected to result in a gain of S$47.1 million. Boustead Singapore's bid to acquire Boustead Projects garnered 87.88% of shares, while Soilbuild Construction Group's subsidiary Soil-Build was ordered to pay a subcontractor almost S$1 million. These developments may affect trading of these companies' securities.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

site_title: Thai premier clears multi-billion spending plan as vote nears
summary: Thailand's cabinet approved a 3.35 trillion baht (S$130.4 billion) budget for fiscal year 2024, covering various ministries, infrastructure projects, and social programs. The budget includes a 24 billion baht expressway project, investments in mobile networks, and income guarantees for farmers. Prime Minister Prayut Chan-O-cha is set to dissolve parliament on March 20, paving the way for a general election, which could extend his eight-year reign. The meeting marked the cabinet's last meeting before the dissolution, with more than 60 issues discussed.

site_title: US: Stocks rebound as bank shares rally, while oil prices tumble
summary: US stocks rebounded 1.7% on Tuesday, driven by big jumps in regional banks, including First Republic Bank, which lent support to major US indices. Oil prices fell sharply, hitting a four-month low, amid recession risks and concerns about the impact of the banking industry turmoil on the economy. The US consumer price index rose 6% from last year, below January's figure, but still above the Federal Reserve's inflation goal of 2%. Analysts predict the Fed will end its hiking cycle on March 22, but policymakers may complicate efforts due to the banking crisis.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., March 13, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: World Cup 2026 to feature 12 groups of four teams
summary: The 2026 World Cup will feature 48 teams, an increase from 32 sides in the previous tournament. The expanded format will consist of 12 groups of four teams, providing balanced rest time and ensuring teams play a minimum of three matches. This change mitigates the risk of collusion and provides a more balanced schedule, resulting in 104 matches, a significant increase from the 64 games played in the previous tournament.

images.alt_text: Argentina's Lionel Messi with his Best Fifa Men's Player Award next to Fifa President Gianni Infantino on stage during an ceremony in Paris, France, Feb 27, 2023.
Fontaine achieved the record in the 1958 finals in Sweden where France reached the semi-finals for the first time in their history, losing to Pele’s Brazil.

site_title: A look at Evergrande’s restructuring scenarios as key date looms
summary: China Evergrande faces a March 20 court hearing in Hong Kong on a winding-up petition, which could have broad implications for China's $60 trillion financial system. The company must unveil a detailed debt restructuring plan by then, with potential scenarios including the announcement of more details, a possible adjournment of the hearing, or a winding-up order if no progress is made. A winding-up order could lead to greater losses for all parties involved and result in the loss of control of the restructuring process.

images.alt_text: Evergrande chairman Hui Ka Yan owns two other luxury homes in the same development in The Peak, which were pledged to Orix Asia Capital in November 2021 for undisclosed amounts.
Evergrande began one of China’s biggest debt-restructuring processes early last year but has yet to reach agreements with bondholders on the details.

site_title: China's money brokers prepare to suspend data feed business at regulators' request
summary: Chinese money brokers are set to suspend their data feed businesses at regulators' request due to data security concerns. Regulators told the brokers to stop providing price quotes to data vendors, which could potentially slow trading in China's money and bond markets. The move affects six money brokers, including local joint ventures of Tullett Prebon and NEX International, and is a result of regulators citing data security concerns. The China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission did not immediately comment on the matter.

site_title: EU unveils electricity reforms to reduce price spike threat
summary: The European Union has unveiled reforms to reduce the threat of price spikes in electricity bills, aiming to make electricity costs less dependent on fossil fuel prices. The reforms introduce new rights for citizens to secure long-term fixed-price contracts, cutting exposure to sharp rises. The EU also aims to bolster investment in non-fossil fuel energy, with plans to triple the rate of new renewable energy infrastructure to meet climate goals.

images.alt_text: The current cold spell in northern and western Europe has put a temporary hold to the price falls on the European gas market.

site_title: TikTok considers splitting from ByteDance if deal with US fails
summary: TikTok is considering separating from its Chinese parent company ByteDance if the US deal to address security concerns fails. The company agreed to implement measures, including hosting US user data with Oracle and appointing an oversight board, but a national security review by the US Committee on Foreign Investment has stalled. Lawmakers have proposed banning the app or selling it, and TikTok's CEO is set to testify about the app's data privacy and security practices. A divestiture is considered a last resort, requiring approval from the Chinese government.

images.alt_text: YouGov data shows that about 41 per cent of people in Singapore aged between 18 and 24 have used TikTok in October 2022.
Belgian Prime Minister Alexander De Croo said the Belgian national security council had warned of the risks associated with the large amounts of data collected by TikTok.
“This warning is based on fundamental misconceptions about our company ownership and our data security,” a TikTok spokesperson said via email.
US adult users will spend an average of nearly 56 minutes per day on TikTok this year, six minutes less than the time spent watching Netflix, the market tracker forecast.

site_title: Crypto exchange Binance to halt sterling transfers
summary: Binance, the world's largest crypto exchange, has halted sterling transfers due to its partner Paysafe's decision to stop services from May 22. This move affects less than 1% of Binance's 128 million customers and comes as the company faces growing US authorities' crackdown on crypto, including an investigation into suspected money laundering and sanctions violations. Binance is working to find an alternative solution for sterling transfers.

images.alt_text: Exchanges Binance and Coinbase Global had temporarily halted certain conversions of the stablecoin, which is used to facilitate trading and as a haven from price swings.

site_title: Cathay’s new CEO outlines rebuild with profit in sight this year
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways CEO Ronald Lam has outlined plans to rebuild the airline with a focus on profit this year. Despite being hit hard by the pandemic, Cathay is expected to post a net profit and return to full capacity in 2024. The airline's average daily passenger numbers have improved, with 33,000 passengers in January, and overall passenger capacity is expected to reach 50% of pre-pandemic levels by this month and 70% by year-end. Lam also plans to reactivate dozens of parked planes and increase staff numbers, but acknowledges a staffing challenge and a need to be more productive and competitive.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file photo taken on March 15, 2017 shows a Cathay Pacific Boeing 777 passenger aircraft (top) taxiing past a stationary plane on the tarmac at the international airport in Hong Kong. - Cathay Pacific is being investigated and faces possible legal action over an Omicron variant coronavirus outbreak in Hong Kong that began with the airline's employees, the city's leader said on January 11, 2022. (Photo by Anthony WALLACE / AFP)

site_title: Soilbuild unit ordered to pay subcontractor almost S$1 million, borne S$20K in adjudication costs
summary: Soil-Build, a subsidiary of Soil-Build Construction Group, has been ordered to pay a subcontractor nearly S$1 million within seven days, with S$20,000 in costs for the adjudication application. The company intends to seek recovery of the adjudicated amount and is working with its legal advisers to initiate a dispute resolution process. The adjudication determination is not expected to have a material impact on the group's financial position for the financial year ending Dec 31, 2023.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting

site_title: Most Bank of Korea board members want door open for further tightening: minutes
summary: Most Bank of Korea board members voted to hold interest rates steady, but agreed it was premature to end tightening. Four members said the door should remain open for further rate increases to contain inflation, while one member disagreed. This decision comes as South Korea's economy is on the brink of recession and inflation pressure eases. The Bank of Korea has raised interest rates by 300 basis points since August 2021 to combat inflation.

images.alt_text: Outside the Bank of Korea headquarters in Seoul.Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg
Slumping exports, slowing consumption and a shaky housing market are among the risks to the economy that are staying in the BOK’s hand.
The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) raised its main rate by a quarter point on Feb 7.

site_title: Nervous traders react first, question later as US treasuries swing
summary: US Treasury yields swung wildly on Tuesday, with two-year yields dropping 15 basis points to 3.82% after Credit Suisse identified material weaknesses in its reporting procedures. The sharp moves highlighted market nervousness following the failure of Silicon Valley Bank and other US lenders, which may impact the Federal Reserve's policy plan. Investors now focus on US inflation data later in the day for clues on future interest rates, with some economists suggesting the Fed may take a breather or cut rates, while others expect rate hikes to combat inflation.

images.alt_text: If the saga at Silicon Valley Bank hastens the arrival of the next recession, expect to see many more properties go into default sooner rather than later.
Food prices are expected to have risen moderately after climbing 0.5 per cent in January.

site_title: Fed seen raising rates by 25 bps next week and in May
summary: The Federal Reserve is expected to raise its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points next week and again in May, as US inflation remained high in February. The rate hike aims to stem persistently high inflation, despite concerns of a long-lasting banking crisis easing. The benchmark rate is forecast to rise to a 5.00-5.25% range by May. This decision shifts expectations from a larger half-point rate hike earlier, following a dramatic move by the Fed to ensure deposit safety and shore up confidence in the banking system.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of the European Central Bank (ECB) is pictured outside its headquarters in Frankfurt, Germany, December 8, 2016.  REUTERS/Ralph Orlowski/File Photo

site_title: Chinese consumers out of Covid gates with caution, rather than zest
summary: China's household consumption, a key driver of the country's economy, is expected to recover gradually and unevenly as consumers return to spending after lifting of Covid-19 restrictions. Despite a rebound in consumer savings, shoppers remain cautious due to lingering worries over job stability, a battered property market, and government parsimony in wages and benefits. Analysts warn that policymakers may need to further stimulate the economy through additional support, but direct consumer subsidies are unlikely.

images.alt_text: Under China’s current tax sharing system, local authorities get slightly more than half of the national revenue from taxes and fees.

site_title: Credit Suisse chairman waives US$1.6 million award, takes pay cut
summary: Credit Suisse chairman Axel Lehmann has waived a $1.6 million award for his first full year on the job, taking a pay cut. Lehmann, who took the role in January 2022, will not receive the standard fee on top of board members' salaries. He will instead propose a lower total pay of 3.8 million Swiss francs for the next pay period. The bank's compensation report was delayed due to US regulators' queries over its financial statements. Lehmann's move mirrors executive-board members who are not receiving bonuses due to the bank's poor performance.

images.alt_text: Axel Lehmann Photographer: Ting Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Wing Tai Properties may see FY2022 loss on adverse change in fair value of JV properties
summary: Wing Tai Properties, a Hong Kong-based associate company of Wing Tai Holdings, has issued a profit warning, stating it may report a loss for the financial year ended Dec 31, 2022, due to an adverse change in the fair value of investment properties of joint ventures. The expected loss is attributed to a change in the fair value of the investment properties, which may be more than double the previously reported amount of HK$527.4 million. The company's operating cash flow is expected to remain unaffected.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
Revenue for H1 was largely attributable to progressive sales recognised from The M at Middle Road, among other things, said Wing Tai Holdings.
Generic photo of condos and private properties

site_title: Toppled crane at ExxonMobil project site not related to Huationg Global, company clarifies
summary: A lorry crane operated by Huationg Holdings toppled on Monday at an ExxonMobil project site in Singapore. Huationg Global, a separate company from Huationg Holdings, has clarified that it was not involved in the incident. Despite this, shares of Huationg Global fell 1.1% on Tuesday. The incident has raised concerns about the crane's operation and safety, but the company has denied any connection to the incident. The cause of the crane's toppling is still unknown.

site_title: Alecta CEO calls US$2 billion US bank foray ‘a big failure’
summary: Alecta CEO Magnus Billing described the fund's $2.1 billion investment in three US banks, including SVB and Signature Bank, as a "big failure" after the banks' collapse. Alecta will likely write off its entire holding, estimated at $1.1 billion, and may also write off its investment in First Republic Bank. The losses equate to about 1% of the fund's total assets under management. Billing emphasized the importance of learning from the failure and balancing market actions to prevent further market turmoil.

images.alt_text: SVB, which was founded in the 1980s, claimed that “nearly half” of US technology and life science startups banked with them for a wide range of services, but mainly to park cash handed to them by their venture capitalist backers to operate.

site_title: Companies must restore free float if delisting conditions not met; Boustead Projects no exception
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has stated that companies that fail to meet delisting conditions must restore their free float, which can be done through a placement. Boustead Projects, a company facing a potential delisting due to its parent company's failed privatization offer, will be required to restore its free float, according to SGX RegCo. If not, its securities may be suspended, and it may be required to delist.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Don’t let delistings take you for a ride.
Helge Muenkel , Chief Sustainability Officer, DBS
The revised offer price of S$0.95 per share will now represent 75.1 per cent of Boustead Project’s last reported NAV.
Boustead Singapore is looking to take Boustead Projects private at S$0.90 per share.

Wong Fong Fui, chairman and group chief executive officer of Boustead Singapore. The company’s S$0.90 per share offer translates to a premium of 7.8 per cent over Boustead Projects’ last traded price per share of S$0.835 on the Singapore Exchange on Feb 3.

site_title: Boeing nabs Dreamliner order from two Saudi airlines
summary: Saudi Arabian Airlines and new national airline Riyadh Air have ordered 78 Boeing 787 Dreamliners, marking the fifth-largest commercial order by value in Boeing's history. The deal includes options for 10 additional planes for Saudia and 33 for Riyadh Air, with a total list price of nearly $37 billion. Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun attributes the order to the huge demand for wide-body planes worldwide amid a rebound in tourism, saying it's the largest he's seen. The US Federal Aviation Administration has approved Boeing's plan to resume 787 deliveries.

images.alt_text: The launch of Riyadh Air is part of Saudi Arabia’s strategy to help kickstart its tourism industry and make it one of the world’s most popular destinations.
The Saudi deal comes on the heels of a major December order from United Airlines for 100 787 Dreamliners and 100 737 MAX jets.
Beachgoers in Bali. Indonesia has committed to prioritising sustainability in its tourism industry.

Beoing and Airbus said that if an offer by Airbus to build a military version of its H175M super-medium helicopter is selected, then Boeing Defence UK will provide aircrew, ground crew and maintenance training.

site_title: UK pay growth slows as Bank of England mulls rates pause
summary: The UK's pay growth slowed in the three months to January, with total pay rising 5.7% and basic pay excluding bonuses increasing 6.5%. This marks a slowdown from the 6.0% growth in the previous period. Despite strong pay growth, inflation remained above 10% in January, leading to a 3.5% decline in basic pay when adjusted for inflation. The Bank of England is closely monitoring these numbers as it considers pausing its interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: The sharp uptick in February was driven by rising customer demand and increasing confidence among business executives after a subsidence in the market turmoil triggered by then-Prime Minister Liz Truss’s budget plan.

site_title: Rock legend Lou Reed's tai chi book to be published
summary: Rock legend Lou Reed's unpublished tai chi book, "The Art of the Straight Line," will be released a decade after his death in 2013. The book features essays and riffs by Reed, detailing his three decades as a dedicated tai chi practitioner. Written in scattered notes, the book offers insight into Reed's gentler side, revealing his desire for balance and inner peace. The book was compiled by his partner Laurie Anderson, who aims to complete Reed's original project, which began in 2009.

images.alt_text: Dance work Abyss choreographed by Hyerim Jang is one of the highlights of SIFA 2023.

site_title: Boustead Singapore’s hold on Boustead Project shares rises over 1% in a day
summary: Boustead Singapore's bid to acquire Boustead Projects at S$0.95 per share gained 1.06% in a day, reaching 87.88% of total shares held. This surpasses Monday's 86.82%. The Securities Investors Association Singapore urged shareholders to reject the offer unless the price is raised to a "fair and reasonable" amount. Boustead Singapore acquired 1.3 million shares, with 4.96% of total shares accepted. The offer price remains unchanged at S$0.95, with Boustead Projects shares closing flat at the same price.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
As at Mar 10, the total number of shares owned, controlled or agreed to be acquired by Boustead Singapore and its concert parties as well as valid acceptances of the offer amounted to 86.55 per cent.
Singapore shares snapped a 2-day winning streak on Thursday, spooked by the US Fed's hawkish tilt

site_title: The crypto bros are fast becoming unbankable
summary: Regulators have widened the firebreak between traditional banking and decentralized finance, effectively making crypto companies unbankable. The US government intervened in the banking system by placing Signature Bank, a crypto-friendly bank, into receivership, citing volatile tokens and decentralized finance risks. This move aims to reduce risk in the system, following warnings from regulators and echoes of the 2008 global financial crisis. Crypto companies are now having to find new banking partners or go abroad, and regulators are seen as trying to "stuff as much of the genie back in the bottle" as they can.

images.alt_text: A security worker reads a newspaper inside of one the Signature Bank branches in New York City, U.S., March 12, 2023. REUTERS/Eduardo Munoz

site_title: The greatest secrets of investing (not taught in schools)
summary: Successful investing is not about chasing high returns, but finding the best return for the longest period of time. Focus on the business narrative, not the stock price, and look for companies with growing revenues, profits, and free cash flows. Businesses with strong growth and returns on capital tend to outperform. A small minority of stocks generate the bulk of returns, while most underperform. Don't overpay for a business, and be patient, as compounding returns require time. Consistency and the right mindset, including vision, courage, temperament, and patience, are key to long-term success.

images.alt_text: Forecasting business cycles is extremely tough, but stock markets are adept at discounting the future into today's prices.
The pain of losing is thought to be psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining.

site_title: Reits notch healthy gains even as STI falls 0.1% amid regional decline
summary: Singapore's Reits posted healthy gains, with six of the top seven gainers on the Straits Times Index (STI) being Reits, despite a 0.1% decline in the STI. Reits such as Mapletree Logistics Trust and Keppel DC Reit rose 3.8% and 3.6% respectively. The gains came amid dovish expectations for US rate hikes and concerns over the contagion risk from banking collapses. However, analysts remain cautious, citing the need for greater fallout in the financial system to sustain the current sentiment.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
The sudden failure of Silicon Valley Bank last week is not expected to prevent the Fed from continuing to raise interest rates at its upcoming meeting on  March 21 to 22.
FILE PHOTO: A U.S. Dollar banknote is seen in this illustration taken May 26, 2020. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: US’ affordable homes under threat as SVB falls
summary: Silicon Valley Bank's sudden shutdown has put affordable housing projects in the US, particularly in California, under threat. The bank had provided financing for over 10,000 affordable homes in the San Francisco Bay Area, with one project, The Kelsey Civic Center, facing a potential delay due to the loss of its US$52 million construction loan. California is under pressure to address its housing shortage, with Governor Gavin Newsom and Attorney-General Rob Bonta enforcing a new state law to increase the state's housing stock, despite local authorities' resistance.

images.alt_text: SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA - FEBRUARY 20: Rows of homes are seen in the Sunset District on February 20, 2023 in San Francisco, California. As home prices continue to rise across the United States, San Francisco saw home prices drop 6.1 percent from the previous year with a median price of $1,230,000. Home prices in San Jose, California were down 5.8 percent from one year ago.   Justin Sullivan/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JUSTIN SULLIVAN / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Volkswagen to invest 180 billion euros over 5 years to hit EV target
summary: Volkswagen plans to invest 180 billion euros over 5 years to achieve 50% electric vehicle sales globally by 2030. Over two-thirds of the budget is allocated to electrification and digitalization, with 15 billion euros dedicated to battery plants and raw materials. Investment in combustion engine technology will peak in 2025 and decline afterwards. The company also announced its first North American plant in Canada, set to start production in 2027.

images.alt_text: epa10521707 A worker cleans an ID.Buzz Volkswagen car prior to the beginning of the annual press conference of the automotive group Volkswagen, at the Volkswagen Group Forum showroom in Berlin, Germany, 14 March 2023. Volkswagen hosted the company's 2023's annual press conference in Berlin.  EPA-EFE/CLEMENS BILAN

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Q2 business outlook has deteriorated for the fifth consecutive quarter, with a slowdown in manufacturing and wholesale trade sectors. The Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau reported this, citing a decline in local businesses' outlook. In other news, the Singapore High Court ordered Matthew Peloso, founder of the failed solar company Sun Electric, to pay S$366,025 in interest and costs. Market participants expect the European Central Bank to delay or reduce interest rate hikes amid the Silicon Valley Bank crisis, potentially affecting planned rate rises by the US Federal Reserve and the Bank of England.

images.alt_text: Generic photos for Budget 2023 Singapore Skyline

site_title: Europe: Stocks mostly drop on bank contagion fears
summary: European stocks fell on Tuesday as investors fretted over contagion fears following the collapse of US lenders Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank. The FTSE 100 index dropped 0.6%, with HSBC leading the fallers board at 2.5%. The eurozone's Paris CAC 40 index retreated 0.2%, while Frankfurt's DAX rose 0.1%. The downturn was attributed to concerns over global bank shares feeling the reverberations from the SVB issue.

images.alt_text: Among banks in the region, Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group has slid more than 7 per cent.

site_title: Dollar rises after tumbling on SVB collapse
summary: The US dollar rose 0.11% to 103.79 on Tuesday, reversing its 0.94% drop on Monday after Silicon Valley Bank's collapse. Fears of a banking crisis led traders to scale back expectations for Federal Reserve rate hikes, causing the euro to fall 0.08% and the dollar to rebound against other currencies. The swift move in the dollar index was attributed to traders' reevaluation of the Fed's rate hike path, with a 30% chance of holding rates steady on March 22 and a 70% chance of a 25 basis point hike.

images.alt_text: The Australian dollar slid 0.5 per cent to US$0.6636 as tanking share markets, gripped by contagion fears from the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank, shattered confidence.

site_title: Britain loses another 220,000 days to worst strikes since Thatcher
summary: The UK has lost 2.67 million days to labour disputes since June last year, the worst spell of strikes since 1990, with 220,000 working days lost in January. This marks a decrease from 822,000 in December 2022, largely due to a non-strike month by postal workers. Disputes continue with the National Health Service, teachers, and junior doctors, with some unions suspending strikes and resuming pay talks. The government has made some progress, but a resolution remains elusive.

images.alt_text: The doctors' strike is the latest involving staff at Britain’s state-funded National Health Service, following walkouts by nurses, paramedics and other workers.

site_title: Japanese banks have sufficient buffers to counter risks, says BOJ
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has stated that Japanese financial institutions have sufficient capital buffers to counter risks, including those caused by the collapse of US lender Silicon Valley Bank. The BOJ found that many regional banks face challenges in risk management, particularly in assessing impacts on portfolios during market volatility. Some banks have also failed to adequately assess how declining interest payments could affect future earnings, leading to issues with effective risk management. The BOJ's report noted that Japanese financial institutions have become "somewhat cautious" on investments amid rising global interest rates.

images.alt_text: Among banks in the region, Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group has slid more than 7 per cent.

site_title: Spain’s Mango plans US expansion after China retreat
summary: Spanish fashion retailer Mango plans to expand its US presence with 40 stores by 2024, after abandoning its Chinese market. The company aims to target states with strong online sales and will focus on higher-priced, special occasion clothing. Mango's US relaunch began in 2022 with a flagship store on New York's Fifth Avenue and will expand to Texas, Georgia, and California this year. The company reported record sales last year, driven by higher prices, and maintains four franchise outlets and online sales in China.

images.alt_text: Shein is set to raise around US$2 billion in a new funding round this month and is aiming for a US listing in the second half of this year.
The end of Covid lockdowns in China is expected to drive up sales for major retail brands, but for adidas that boost will likely be wiped out by the impact of its split with Yeezy collaborator Ye.

site_title: Musk, China’s BYD deny report on Tesla ending battery supply cooperation
summary: Tesla CEO Elon Musk and Chinese battery maker BYD denied a report that Tesla was ending their battery supply cooperation. The report claimed Tesla had not asked BYD for additional battery supplies after their deal expired. Musk stated that the report is "false" and that relations between the companies are positive. BYD also disputed the report, saying it "is not in line with the actual situation".

site_title: Are they for real? South Korean girl band offers glimpse into metaverse
summary: South Korean girl band MAVE: has debuted in the metaverse, offering a glimpse into the evolving technology. Created by web designers and artificial intelligence, the virtual quartet's songs, dances, and hairstyles are indistinguishable from those of a real band. The move is backed by tech giant Kakao Corp, which has also launched a tender offer to buy SM Entertainment, a major K-pop pioneer. While virtual groups like MAVE: are gaining attention, experts question whether they can match the interaction between conventional popular bands and their fans, citing concerns over predictability and authenticity.

images.alt_text: Naver’s Webtoon reached 180 million global monthly active users as of March 2022.

site_title: Green energy investors demand Vietnam speed up policy changes
summary: Renewable energy companies in Vietnam are urging the government to change power price policies that threaten their projects' viability and deter investors. A letter from 36 companies, including wind and solar developers, calls for more favorable prices, immediate grid connection, and new rules to sell energy directly to customers. The companies' projects, delayed by the pandemic, now risk bankruptcy due to a new lower price policy. The government's anti-corruption campaign has slowed decision-making, complicating the nation's goal of transitioning away from coal to hit net zero emissions by 2050.

images.alt_text: Thuong, 52, is the youngest member of the party’s Politburo, the country’s top decision-making body, and is widely regarded as being close to General Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong, Vietnam’s most powerful figure.

site_title: US expected to report strong consumer price increases in February
summary: The US is expected to report strong consumer price increases in February, with economists forecasting a 0.4% rise in the Consumer Price Index (CPI), bringing the year-on-year increase to 6.0%, the smallest since September 2021. Sticky rental housing costs and rising food prices are driving the inflation, but some economists believe the data may not be enough to prompt the Federal Reserve to hike interest rates again next week, amid financial market turmoil following the collapse of two regional banks.

images.alt_text: In a joint statement on Sunday, the US Federal Reserve, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) and the Treasury Department said SVB depositors would have access to “all of their money.”
US President Joe Biden's promised bank regulations could be a tough sell now that he faces a divided Congress.
President Joe Biden talks about his proposed federal budget – seen as a preview of his 2024 re-election platform – at the Finishing Trades Institute in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

site_title: Asia: Markets sink as banks bear brunt of SVB contagion fears
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Tuesday, with banks bearing the brunt of selling due to fears of contagion following the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank. The Hang Seng Index fell 2.27% and the Shanghai Composite Index declined 0.72%. Major banks in Japan, Hong Kong, and South Korea also saw significant losses, with Mitsubishi UFJ Financial and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group down over 8% and 7% respectively. Authorities have prevented a US bank run, but investors remain concerned about the risk of a financial crisis.

images.alt_text: Equity markets were well in the red in early Asian trade on Tuesday, with Tokyo, Sydney and Seoul almost two per cent down, while Hong Kong, Shanghai, Singapore and Taipei suffered hefty selling.

site_title: Founder of failed Sun Electric ordered to pay claimant for defaulting on ‘friendly loan’
summary: The Singapore High Court ordered Matthew Peloso, founder of the failed solar company Sun Electric, to pay S$366,025 to Kumar Vikram at 5.33% interest per annum, along with judgment and costs of S$3,061.20, for defaulting on a "friendly loan" of S$250,000 provided in 2015. This decision follows a claim filed by Vikram in November 2022, with Peloso representing himself in the case.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

EMA is looking to strengthen consumer protection by enhancing regulatory requirements on electricity retailers and tightening the eligibility criteria for consumers on Wholesale Electricity Price (WEP) plans

site_title: Local banks not recession-proof, but long-term growth prospects look good
summary: Singapore's local banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, are not recession-proof but have long-term growth prospects due to their stable net interest margins. Rising interest rates benefit the trio, with DBS' net profit growing 20% in 2022 and UOB's net profit increasing 12%. The banks' focus on Southeast Asia and China, where economies are growing, also provides opportunities for growth. The Singapore government's support and robust financial system help mitigate the effects of a global recession. The trio's strong governance, technology investment, and attractive dividend yields make them attractive investments.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee

The chief executives of the respective banks remained cautiously optimistic of their FY2023 performance, as they expect interest rates will largely remain elevated and continue to boost their net interest margins (NIM), although they warned of costs catching up.

site_title: Banking’s next threat might be commercial real estate
summary: Commercial real estate's rapid weakening poses a significant threat to the banking industry, similar to the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank. With total real estate loans and leases on banks' books increasing by 16% to a record $5.31 trillion, banks are exposed to significant risk. Default rates are expected to rise, and declining property values are already evident, with a widely followed index of commercial real estate prices plummeting 3.5% last quarter. Lenders are tightening standards, but it may be too late, as the crisis at SVB suggests an unhealthy banking system.

images.alt_text: SVB, which was founded in the 1980s, claimed that “nearly half” of US technology and life science startups banked with them for a wide range of services, but mainly to park cash handed to them by their venture capitalist backers to operate.
Amancio Ortega acquired five US logistics sites for more than US$700 million in September.

site_title: Philippines posts biggest trade deficit in 5 months
summary: The Philippines recorded its largest trade deficit in five months in January, with a gap of US$5.74 billion. Exports fell 13.5% to US$5.2 billion, while imports rose 3.9% to US$11 billion. This marked the first monthly rise in imports in three months. The trade deficit is expected to put pressure on the peso, with the currency having fallen over 2% since February. The persistent deficit is attributed to depreciation pressure for the Philippine peso.

site_title: Crypto exchange Huobi Global says withdrew funds from failed US banks
summary: Huobi Global, a major cryptocurrency exchange, has withdrawn all its funds from failed US banks Signature Bank and Silvergate Capital, with no impact on its customers' funds. The withdrawals were made after Signature was closed on Sunday, the third-largest US banking failure in history, and Silvergate announced plans to wind down operations. Huobi Global's adviser Justin Sun stated that the exchange business remains unaffected, and it is applying for a virtual asset service provider license in Hong Kong.

site_title: Asia: Markets sink as SVB contagion fears hit banking sector
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Tuesday, with Tokyo, Sydney, and Seoul down almost 2% and Hong Kong, Shanghai, Singapore, and Taipei suffering significant selling. The collapse of US lenders Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank sparked fears of contagion in the sector, despite US authorities' pledge of support. Shares in regional banks fell, and yields on government bonds dropped, with analysts warning of a global economic slowdown and increased risk of recession.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index fell for a third straight session, declining 2.1 per cent to 6,960.40 by 0006 GMT on Tuesday.
The benchmark Nikkei 225 index was down 1.72 per cent, or 479.25 points, at 27,353.71 in early trade on Tuesday.

site_title: Credit Suisse says outflows have stabilised but not reversed
summary: Credit Suisse reported that customer outflows have stabilized at lower levels, but not reversed, according to its 2022 annual report. The bank saw a sharp acceleration in customer withdrawals in the fourth quarter, with outflows exceeding $120 billion. This led to breaches of liquidity buffers. The report was delayed due to a request from the US Securities and Exchange Commission, which raised questions about the bank's earlier financial statements. The bank's share price fell 14% to a record low, and the cost of insuring against a debt default rose to a new all-time high.

images.alt_text: Struggling to recover from a string of scandals, Switzerland’s second-biggest bank has begun a major overhaul of its business.

site_title: Inflation: permanent or transitory?
summary: Inflation's short-term decline is likely, but a return to low inflation is unlikely, according to a recent article. The US Federal Reserve's characterization of the 2021 inflation spike as "transitory" has been widely criticized, and investors are now focusing on the longer-term outlook for inflation. The Fed's reaction to a weakening economy with inflation still above its target is uncertain, but the article suggests that the true concern is the potential for a more permanent shift in inflation expectations, rather than a return to the pre-Covid era of low inflation.

images.alt_text: Food prices are expected to have risen moderately after climbing 0.5 per cent in January.
Money markets are betting that the Fed is probably done with interest-rate hiking for this cycle.

site_title: ChatGPT: How do we police the robots?
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) models like ChatGPT pose significant legal issues, including data privacy and intellectual property concerns. The indiscriminate review of millions of publicly accessible articles and documents raises questions about the use of personal data without consent. Generative AI systems, such as ChatGPT and DALL-E 2, can create art and literature, but their use raises concerns about copyright infringement and the potential for AI to replicate human styles, potentially disincentivizing art creation. Additionally, AI systems often present biased and prejudiced narratives, highlighting the need for policies to mitigate bias and prejudice in AI development.

images.alt_text: ChatGPT: Has artificial intelligence come for our jobs?
Microsoft has gone the furthest in pushing out generative AI to consumers and has pledged to pump billions of dollars into OpenAI, the company behind ChatGPT.
ChatGPT had “ignited a conversation about the implications of generative AI for cybersecurity”, Darktrace noted on Wednesday.

site_title: After rollercoaster ride, prices of raw materials likely to remain volatile due to economic uncertainty
summary: The raw materials market is expected to remain volatile due to economic uncertainty, with prices of base metals and commodities likely to fluctuate in the coming months. Analysts predict a 30% drop in copper prices to between $6,000-$6,500 a tonne, amid fears of bank losses and a global recession. The boom and bust cycle of basic raw materials over the last three years has been extraordinary, with prices experiencing massive surges and deep slumps. Unsound monetary policies and global economic factors are driving the market's volatility.

images.alt_text: The White House is prioritising access to minerals such lithium, nickel and cobalt needed for electric-vehicle batteries as it pushes an ambitious climate plan.
The licenses grant Fortress Minerals to conduct prospecting operations for copper, nickel and cobalt minerals.
Traders work on the floor of the London Metal Exchange, in London. The LME says said that it had taken active steps to enhance nickel market liquidity and transparency.

site_title: More than 130 European MPs demand tax on ultra-rich individuals
summary: A group of over 130 European MPs, led by French MEP Aurore Lalucq and economist Gabriel Zucman, have called for a tax on ultra-rich individuals to fund the transition to a carbon-free world. The proposal aims to reduce inequalities and finance investments in green and social projects. The MPs pointed to examples of wealthy individuals not paying taxes, such as Elon Musk's 2018 tax bill of zero. The campaign seeks a 1.5% tax on wealth above €50 million, with the exact level to be determined collectively and democratically.

site_title: Silicon Valley Bank ‘conducting business as usual’: new CEO
summary: Silicon Valley Bank's new CEO, Tim Mayopoulos, has assured clients that the lender is operating normally and protecting deposits up to $250,000. The bank, taken over by the FDIC after its collapse, will resume cross-border transactions in the coming days. Existing and new deposits are protected by the FDIC, and the bank will conduct business as usual within the US.

site_title: Australian business activity strong in Feb, even as confidence wanes
summary: Australian business conditions remained strong in February, with a sales measure of +27, supported by low unemployment and rapid population growth. The National Australia Bank's index of business conditions dipped to +17, still above its long-run average, while confidence fell to -4. The Reserve Bank of Australia cited the strong business activity as a reason for its recent interest rate hike to 3.6%. However, market expectations suggest only a minor chance of further rate hikes in April, with a possibility of tightening altogether.

images.alt_text: The RBA has acted as a bellwether for global central banks over the past six months, ever since it slowed the pace of hikes in October.

site_title: Stablecoin USDC sees redemptions even as crypto market rebounds
summary: USDC stablecoin, pegged to the US dollar, saw nearly $1.74 billion in redemptions on March 13, accounting for 2% of its circulating supply. This comes after the stablecoin lost its peg last week when its issuer, Circle Internet Financial, revealed it held only 8% of reserves at Silicon Valley Bank, which collapsed. Despite assurances from Circle's CEO and a government plan to return money to bank depositors, traders are still redeeming USDC, with institutional investors holding record-low amounts.

images.alt_text: Representations of cryptocurrencies including Bitcoin, Dash, Ethereum, Ripple and Litecoin are seen in this illustration picture taken June 2, 2021. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration

site_title: Sub-sales in private property at 10-year high in 2022
summary: Sub-sales in Singapore's private residential market reached a 10-year high in 2022, with 765 transactions, a 34.7% jump from the previous year. The majority of sub-sale deals were profitable, with an average profit of S$373,230. Sub-sales accounted for 5.7% of all transactions in Q4 2022, the highest level since 2013. The bulk of sub-sale transactions were found in the outside central region and the rest of central region, with prime core central region deals making an average profit of S$707,640. Experts attribute the increase in sub-sales to the current boom market, with healthy demand from investors and owner-occupiers, and the introduction of cooling measures.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim

List Sotheby’s International Realty’s senior associate vice-president Steve Tay believes that 2023 will be a record year for rental markets, with demand continuing to be strong as China reopens its borders and more foreigners, especially from North Asia, decide to set up a base in Singapore.
Another year of pain for tenants
URA figures on released Wednesday (Feb 15) showed that the number of new private residential units sold in January rose 130 per cent to 391.

site_title: Volkswagen picks Canada for first battery cell plant outside Europe
summary: Volkswagen has chosen Canada to build its first battery cell plant outside Europe, granting its electric vehicles access to Canadian and US subsidies. The plant will utilize Canada's abundant mining sector for key raw materials, including lithium, nickel, and cobalt. This move aims to localise Volkswagen's EV production chain in the region and tap into the US's Inflation Reduction Act subsidies, which require batteries to contain a minimum proportion of critical minerals extracted or processed in the US. The plant's capacity is expected to be around 20 gigawatt hours.

images.alt_text: A new version of Volkswagen’s flagship ID.3 electric car model will go on sale from the end of March for just under 40,000 euros.
VW shares have soared as much as 11.3 per cent, the steepest intraday gain since Mar 9, 2022.

site_title: Yoma Strategic to restructure debt for suspended Myanmar project
summary: Yoma Strategic and its partners have agreed to restructure the debt facilities for the suspended Yoma Central project in downtown Yangon, Myanmar. The project was halted in mid-2021 due to an uncertain economic environment. Lenders IFC and ADB have granted a standstill period until June 15, 2025, allowing the developer, Meeyahta Development Limited, to obtain foreign exchange approvals. MMJ Yangon Development will also contribute additional shareholder loans to repay and prepay loan instalments. The project's development cost is expected to be reduced with a revised development plan.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said that Asean, which is leading diplomatic efforts to bring peace, needed to be more assertive and noted that his country was shouldering 200,000 displaced people from Myanmar.
Yoma in February 2022 announced a change of its financial year end from Sep 30 to Mar 31. Its financial reporting period for FY2022 will therefore span 18 months from Oct 1, 2021, to Mar 31, 2023.

site_title: Stemming tide of SVB collapse may create other ripples
summary: Central banks and regulators are taking steps to counter a growing banking panic in the US and Europe, potentially delaying or reducing interest rate hikes. The ongoing Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) crisis is causing concern, with US and European inflation potentially accelerating if money is flushed. Bank stocks have tumbled, with regional banks like First Republic and Western Alliance experiencing significant declines. The European Central Bank is expected to delay or reduce interest rate hikes, and investors are wary of corporate bonds and a potential recession.

images.alt_text: HSBC’s UK-based ring-fenced subsidiary bought the unit for £1 on Monday.
US President Joe Biden's promised bank regulations could be a tough sell now that he faces a divided Congress.
The dramatic downfall of one of tech’s biggest lenders has prompted rethinking of compliance and risk controls.

MAS said the Singapore banking system remains “sound and resilient” amid the recent collapse of Silicon Valley Bank (SVB), while analysts also expect the fallout will have limited impact on Singapore banks, given fundamental differences between the local lenders and SVB.

site_title: Hard, soft, or no landing?
summary: The US economy is defying expectations of a hard or soft landing, with growth remaining positive despite higher interest rates and inflation. This "no landing" scenario is prompting the Federal Reserve to continue raising rates, and investors are bracing for potential further rate hikes. The yield curve remains inverted, a sign that often precedes a recession, and bond prices are under pressure. As a result, investors are advised to tailor their decisions accordingly, particularly if the "no landing" scenario persists.

images.alt_text: Aglobal recession is not around the next corner, and near-term sentiment and growth outlooks are supportive. But we are not out of the woods.

Friday’s labour market report is among key pieces of data that Fed chair Jerome Powell and his fellow monetary policymakers are tallying in the run-up to their Mar 21-22 policy-setting meeting in Washington.
One possible reason for the inverted yield curve is that bond investors think Fed chair Jay Powell will follow in Paul Volcker’s footsteps and unleash a deep recession.

site_title: British crypto lender Euler suffers US$200 million hack
summary: A British crypto lender, Euler, has suffered a massive hack resulting in losses of approximately US$200 million, according to security firm PeckShield. The hack exploited a flaw in Euler's system, and the company is working with security professionals and law enforcement. This incident is the largest crypto hack for months, ranking eighth on the all-time list of biggest thefts. Euler has confirmed the incident and will release further information as it becomes available.

images.alt_text: ChatGPT had “ignited a conversation about the implications of generative AI for cybersecurity”, Darktrace noted on Wednesday.
As counterintuitive as it may sound, the growing sophistication of cybercrimes means that cyber risk management cannot be addressed solely by technology.

site_title: Canada 2-year yield plunges most since 1990s; rate bets shift
summary: Canada's two-year benchmark bond yield plummeted 41 basis points to 3.538% as investors anticipate the Bank of Canada to cut rates in response to regional US bank collapses. This marks the largest two-day drop since 1995. Overnight interest swaps now price in 50 basis points of rate cuts by July, reversing expectations of a rate hike. The move is attributed to financial stability concerns and market sensitivity to rallies.

site_title: Globe Telecom eyes prepaid home fibre in Philippines
summary: Globe Telecom plans to launch a prepaid home fibre service in the Philippines in the second quarter, aiming to increase network utilisation and deliver fibre connectivity to a broader market. CEO Ernest Cu notes that the postpaid broadband segment is nearing saturation, and the company expects another round of explosive growth in home broadband, similar to the 1990s mobile-phone boom. The move comes as competition heats up with Elon Musk's Starlink satellite broadband service set to launch later this quarter.

images.alt_text: Globe intends to use the bulk of proceeds to fund capital expenditures to support ongoing network expansion, as well as sustain network consistency and reliability scores.

site_title: Gold holds above key US$1,900 as SVB collapse fuels hopes of rate-hike pause
summary: Gold prices held above $1,900 per ounce, fueled by expectations of less-aggressive Federal Reserve rate hikes following the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank. Spot gold remained flat at $1,913.54 per ounce, while US gold futures were listless at $1,916.20. Markets now largely price in a 25-basis-point rate hike at the Fed's next policy meeting, with a 31.4% chance of a pause in hikes. This lifts gold's appeal as a hedge against economic uncertainties.

images.alt_text: Gold bars sit stacked in this arranged photograph at Solar Capital Gold Zrt. in Budapest, Hungary, on Thursday, March 10, 2016. Gold advanced to the highest level in a year after the European Central Bank indicated it wouldnÕt cut interest rates further, boosting the euro and making dollar-denominated bullion less expensive for investors. Photographer: Akos Stiller/Bloomberg

site_title: Signature Bank’s real-time crypto payments network still online, for now
summary: Signature Bank's real-time crypto payments network, Signet, remains operational despite the lender's receivership by New York regulators on Sunday. The network, which counts stablecoin issuer Circle, crypto exchange Coinbase, and other crypto trading shops among its users, has been performing smoothly without interruption. Tassat, the technology developer behind Signet, stated that its system continues to function without interruption. However, the long-term impact of Signature's receivership on the crypto market and Signet's future remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: Exchanges Binance and Coinbase Global had temporarily halted certain conversions of the stablecoin, which is used to facilitate trading and as a haven from price swings.

Circle, the company behind stablecoin USD Coin (USDC), plans to line up a new transaction banking partner with automated minting and redemption, possibly as early as Monday, Jeremy Allaire, co-founder and chief executive officer of Circle said.
Coinbase Global Inc has about US$240 million in corporate cash balance with Signature Bank, the US crypto exchange said in a tweet on Sunday.
Silicon Valley Bank abruptly became the biggest US lender to fail in more than a decade on Friday, unravelling in less than 48 hours after outlining a plan to shore up capital.

site_title: Sea’s MariBank launches to select members of the public
summary: Digital bank MariBank has launched to select members of the public within the Sea ecosystem, offering a savings account with a 2.5% annual interest rate, credited daily. The account has a S$60,000 limit and no fees. MariBank is the last of the Singapore digital bank licensees to launch a publicly available offering. Applications can be opened through the MariBank app, and interest earnings are calculated based on the previous-day balance. The bank is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Sea.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp, Yoma Strategic, Geo Energy, Metech
summary: Sembcorp Industries clinched a contract to build, own, and operate a 500 megawatt solar power plant in Oman, its first renewables project in the Middle East. Yoma Strategic's partners agreed to restructure debt facilities for its city quarter development in Yangon, and Geo Energy Resources stopped transactions with a coal mine owner affecting its earnings. Meanwhile, Metech International was sued over missing diamond seeds and loose diamonds. These developments may impact trading of their securities on Tuesday.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

site_title: Submarine deal highlights concerns over rising Chinese power
summary: The US, Australia, and Britain have signed a landmark nuclear submarine pact, known as AUKUS, amid growing concerns over China's military power. The deal aims to counter China's expansion in the Indo-Pacific region, with Australia replacing its diesel-powered submarines with nuclear-powered ones from the US, and later producing domestically. However, the timeline for implementation is years long, and production capacity is a challenge, with China continuing to improve its armed forces and pursue territorial claims.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. and Chinese flags are seen in this illustration taken, January 30, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

Amphibious armoured vehicles under China's People's Liberation Army taking part in a training exercise in Fujian province, China August 14, 2022. cnsphoto via REUTERS   ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY. CHINA OUT./File Photo

Australia's prime minister Anthony Albanese said last month that Australia's fleet of nuclear submarines provided under the AUKUS agreement will be the "biggest leap in our defence capability in our history".

site_title: Australian dollar slips, bonds enjoy biggest rally in a decade as RBA cuts priced in
summary: The Australian dollar slipped 0.5% to US$0.6636 on Tuesday as tanking share markets, fueled by contagion fears from Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank, shattered confidence. Bond futures surged 43 ticks, reaching 97.008, in their biggest three-day rally since 2011, with investors pricing out further RBA rate hikes and even betting on a cut in April. The RBA is now expected to pause its tightening cycle in April, with a 7% chance of a 25 basis point rate cut.

images.alt_text: australian, dollar, money

site_title: Australia: Shares fall 2% as potential US banking crisis alarms traders
summary: Australian shares fell 2.1% to their lowest level since early January, led by mining and banking stocks, amid concerns over a broader financial fallout from the US-based Silicon Valley Bank collapse. The S&P/ASX 200 index declined for a third straight session. Global investors sold off bank shares despite US regulatory actions, with the 'Big Four' banks retreating between 1.7% and 2.7%. Energy and technology stocks also fell, while gold stocks rose 2.6% to a four-week high.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Nikkei 225 index was down 1.72 per cent, or 479.25 points, at 27,353.71 in early trade on Tuesday.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended 0.3 per cent lower at 31,819.14 on Monday.

site_title: Global financial stocks lose US$465 billion on SVB impact worry
summary: Global financial stocks have lost US$465 billion in market value due to investor concerns over Silicon Valley Bank's (SVB) collapse. Asian lenders, considered more insulated from direct risk, saw significant declines, with Japan's Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group dropping 8.3% and South Korea's Hana Financial Group falling 4.7%. US peers also tumbled, with investors questioning the effectiveness of a government rescue plan. The declines are attributed to concerns over SVB's impact on financial firms, including large investments in bonds and other financial instruments, and potential economic hard landing in the US.

images.alt_text: SVB, which failed last week, was a key banker for some 3,000 British venture capital firms and startups.
Silicon Valley Bank N.A’s new chief executive officer Tim Mayopoulos said in a letter to clients on Monday that the lender is open and conducting business as usual.
FILE PHOTO: Destroyed SVB (Silicon Valley Bank) logo is seen in this illustration taken March 13, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Traders see under 50% chance of half-point hike by ECB this week
summary: Traders now see a less than 50% chance of a half-point interest rate hike by the European Central Bank (ECB) this week, with the deposit rate peaking at 3.30% instead of 4.10%. The collapse of Silicon Valley Bank has led to a swift shift in monetary policy expectations, with bond yields plummeting 60 basis points. The ECB is facing a "tricky problem" as it may be forced to rescind its promised rate hike, and some analysts recommend a 25-basis-point move to avoid a policy mistake.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange on March 3, 2023. - Wall Street stocks rose early Friday, extending a market upswing despite lingering worries about the likelihood of more central bank interest rate hikes. (Photo by TIMOTHY A. CLARY / AFP)

site_title: Apollo eyes SVB assets as suitors circle US$73.6 billion loan book
summary: Apollo Global Management, a leading alternative asset manager, is interested in acquiring a portion of Silicon Valley Bank's US$73.6 billion loan book. The bank, seized by federal regulators last week, had a long-established customer base of tech startups withdrawing deposits en masse. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) created a bridge bank to house SVB's deposits, promising to make all customers whole. Apollo is one of several investors exploring opportunities to buy pieces of the bank, including SVB Capital and SVB Securities.

images.alt_text: Silicon Valley Bank branch in San Francisco Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

site_title: HDB to pilot new type of public rental housing with own room, shared facilities for low-income singles
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) in Singapore will pilot a new type of public rental housing, called Single Room Shared Facilities, at a former hostel site in Ang Mo Kio. The pilot will accommodate 480 low-income singles in single rooms with basic furnishings, sharing common facilities such as kitchens, bathrooms, laundry, and activity rooms. The initiative aims to provide greater privacy and a community-type living environment. The pilot will run for one to two years to collect data on its effectiveness, with the possibility of becoming a permanent solution among the government's public rental schemes.

images.alt_text: Generic pix of HDB flats and condominiums in Bishan on Feb 16, 2023.
A five-room unit at The Pinnacle@Duxton claims the highest transacted price of S$1.34 million in February.
Successful applicants for Jurong West Crystal and Brickland Weave be able to move into their new homes earlier, as these projects have shorter waiting times.

site_title: Etsy, other e-commerce companies feel squeeze of SVB collapse
summary: E-commerce companies Etsy and Shopify were affected by the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank (SVB), with approximately 2,700 Etsy sellers (0.5% of active sellers) experiencing delayed payments. Etsy resumed payments after the US government ensured SVB's customers had access to their funds. Shopify paused payments to online sellers with SVB accounts, requiring them to switch to another bank. Some sellers have received payments on schedule, while others have had to scramble to switch bank accounts and access funds.

images.alt_text: SVB (Silicon Valley Bank) logo and decreasing stock graph are seen in this illustration taken March 10, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

FILE PHOTO: A man puts a sign on the door of the Silicon Valley Bank as an onlooker watches at the bank’s headquarters in Santa Clara, California, U.S. March 10, 2023. REUTERS/Nathan Frandino/File Photo
In a joint statement on Sunday, the US Federal Reserve, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) and the Treasury Department said SVB depositors would have access to “all of their money.”

site_title: The great hiking cycle is seen as done as yields drop below cash
summary: Global bond markets signal the end of the steepest monetary tightening campaign in a generation, with benchmark short-end bond yields crashing below economy's cash rates. US two-year yields rallied by over a percentage point, while yields in other developed markets dropped at least 39 basis points. The collapse of Silicon Valley Bank has raised concerns about policymakers' efforts to quash inflation, potentially tipping economies into recession. The ECB is still seen as the leading hawk, but its plans for rate hikes may face opposition, while the Fed is now expected to hold its next meeting.

images.alt_text: Money markets are betting that the Fed is probably done with interest-rate hiking for this cycle.
Aglobal recession is not around the next corner, and near-term sentiment and growth outlooks are supportive. But we are not out of the woods.

site_title: Singapore consumer, F&B brands go all out to tap Indonesia’s growing middle class
summary: Singaporean consumer and food brands, such as Love, Bonito, Song Fa, and Saladstop!, are expanding their presence in Indonesia, targeting the country's growing middle class. The middle class, accounting for 43% of total household consumption, has seen its consumption increase by 12% per year since 2002. Companies are looking to tap into this growing segment, with plans to open new outlets in cities like Medan, Bandung, and Surabaya, and to increase their e-commerce presence. The proximity of the two countries and the familiarity of Indonesian consumers with Singapore brands are seen as advantages in leveraging the South-east Asia market.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Oyika offers single-use, weekly and monthly packages for electric motorbike riders to swap their motorbike batteries at a “swap station”.
One advantage of Indonesia is the market of about 280 million people, but SBF's country head for Indonesia Hisyaamuddin Abu Bakar noted that the Indonesia market is a “marathon game” for companies.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 1.72% lower on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 1.72% lower on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 479.25 points at 27,353.71. The decline followed a mixed Wall Street session and falls in European markets, despite reassurance from US President Joe Biden on the soundness of the US banking system.

site_title: Tampines executive condominium site, Jalan Tembusu plot up for sale
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) and Housing and Development Board (HDB) have released two residential land plots for sale, one in Jalan Tembusu near Tanjong Katong and the other an executive condominium (EC) site at Tampines Street 62. Together, they may yield around 1,540 residential units. Analysts expect a cautious bidding process, with fewer than five bids for the Jalan Tembusu plot due to high acquisition and construction costs. The Tampines Street 62 EC site is expected to attract up to 10 bidders, with prices ranging between S$600 and S$700 per square foot.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Launched by the Urban Redevelopment Authority, the Jalan Tembusu site is the largest of the three, with an area of 20,572.1 sq m and a maximum gross floor area of 72,003 sq m.
krtender2 - Aerial view of Dunman Road site
The new launch is next to the upcoming Marina South MRT station.

site_title: Regret and blame in Silicon Valley after bank run
summary: Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) collapsed after a bank run, leaving the US tech scene in shock. The bank, which catered to startups and venture capital firms, was criticized for its narrow focus and lack of diversification. After a bungled presentation, powerful venture capital firms urged clients to withdraw their funds, triggering a panic. The collapse is reminiscent of the Great Depression, with distressed depositors rushing to withdraw money from failed banks. The event is expected to have ripple effects on the tech industry for the next decade.

images.alt_text: Silicon Valley Bank N.A’s new chief executive officer Tim Mayopoulos said in a letter to clients on Monday that the lender is open and conducting business as usual.
SVB, which failed last week, was a key banker for some 3,000 British venture capital firms and startups.
HSBC’s UK-based ring-fenced subsidiary bought the unit for £1 on Monday.

site_title: PSA’s CK Hutchison ports US$4 billion stake sale attracts China giants: sources
summary: PSA International, owned by Singaporean state investment firm Temasek Holdings, is seeking a US$4 billion sale of its 20% stake in CK Hutchison Holdings' ports business. Chinese state-owned conglomerates China Merchants Group and China Cosco Shipping are among firms expressing interest in the stake. The sale process has kicked off with preliminary talks between PSA and potential bidders, including China Merchants and Cosco. The discussions are preliminary, and firms could decide against making offers. The sale would be a significant move by PSA, which bought the stake in 2006 for US$4.4 billion.

site_title: Metech JV files lawsuit against ex-director Deng Yiming over missing diamonds
summary: Metech International has filed a lawsuit against Deng Yiming, the former director of its subsidiary's joint venture partner X Diamond Capital, over missing diamond seeds and loose diamonds. The lawsuit was filed after the JV entity, Asian Eco Technology, commenced legal action in the High Court, citing unresolved issues including missing diamonds, outstanding loan advances, and irregularities in machine imports. Deng was removed as AET's director in January, and Metech closed up 52.2% on Monday following the filing.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
Recent boardroom tussles involving SGX-listed companies have seen varying degrees of success for requisitioning parties, and not all cases are straightforward.
Metech is looking to focus on its lab-grown diamond business

site_title: Nurturing accountants with the right expertise for the green economy
summary: Singapore aims to nurture a new generation of accounting graduates with sustainability expertise to meet the growing demand for sustainability reporting. The International Sustainability Standards Board will release two sustainability reporting standards by June, setting a global baseline for comparability and transparency. Integrating sustainability into accounting curricula can equip students with skills to tackle financial risks, track carbon emissions, and develop strategies to manage or mitigate them. The Singapore Accountancy Commission projects a need for 6,000 to 7,000 new accountants by 2025, with the integration of accounting and sustainability in education expected to revive interest in the accounting profession.

images.alt_text: A recent study has set alight concerns that issues with the current practice of sustainability assurance could increase the threat of greenwashing rather than diminish it. PHOTO: REUTERS
The skills, judgment and all-around perspective of professional accountants are invaluable as organisations measure, report and verify their sustainability performance.

site_title: Meta to wind down NFTs on platforms amid crypto bust
summary: Meta Platforms is winding down support for digital collectibles, or non-fungible tokens (NFTs), on its platforms due to the crypto market's decline. The company rolled out support for creators to share NFTs on Instagram and Facebook last year, but will focus on other ways to support creators.
