Meta's fintech head, Stephane Kasriel, stated that the company will continue investing in fintech tools, including Meta Pay, and will streamline payments. This move comes after the collapse of major crypto exchange FTX and US banks last week.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower on bank contagion fears
summary: US stock markets opened lower on Monday due to fears of bank contagion following Silicon Valley Bank's collapse. The Dow Jones fell 89.71 points, or 0.28%, to 31,819.93, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. Expectations rose for a pause in interest rate hikes in March, adding to the downward pressure.

site_title: Customers calm at under-pressure US banks
summary: US bank customers, particularly those at SVB, were reassured after authorities stepped in to protect deposits. In a joint statement, the US Federal Reserve, FDIC, and Treasury Department confirmed that SVB depositors would have access to "all of their money." This move calmed customers, despite market concerns about systemic contagion, and a few dozen account holders waited outside a San Francisco branch without evident panic.

images.alt_text: Signage outside the Silicon Valley Bank headquarters in Santa Clara, California, US, on Monday, March 13, 2023. The collapse of Silicon Valley Bank has prompted a global reckoning at venture capital and private equity firms, which found themselves suddenly exposed all together to the tech industry's money machine. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

site_title: Banks, STI stocks come out tops as Singapore Q4 corporate earnings rise 24.6%
summary: Singapore Q4 corporate earnings rose 24.6% to S$5.9 billion, with 47 out of 86 listed companies on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) reporting profits. The sector performing well included banks and STI stocks, as the local economy showed resilience despite inflation and recession concerns.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

Passenger load factor – the percentage of available seating capacity filled by paying passengers – as well as passenger yield were record high for Singapore Airlines and Scoot in the quarter to December.
Operating profit for the three months ended Dec 31, 2022 rose 11.4 per cent to S$755 million, up from S$678 million in the second quarter - which was itself a quarterly record then.
Maybank Securities now rates UOB and OCBC at “hold”. DBS remains the research house’s only “buy” pick.

site_title: Crane topples at ExxonMobil lubricant plant project site
summary: A lorry crane toppled onto its side at an ExxonMobil lubricant plant project site in Singapore on Monday, March 13. The incident occurred at 35 Shipyard Road and was captured in images on the "Complaint Singapore Unrestricted" Facebook page. The crane's outriggers, which maintain stability, were not extended at the time of the incident. The cause of the collapse is currently unknown.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
The maximum fines for breaches of WSH Act Subsidiary Legislation will be increased to S$50,000 from S$$20,000.

site_title: Hong Kong GDP outlook lifted on China; Singapore sees high costs
summary: Hong Kong's economy is expected to expand 3.4% this year and 3.5% next year, up from previous estimates of 2.7% and 2.8%, due to China's reopening. In contrast, Singapore's GDP is forecast to expand 1.9% this year, down from a previous estimate of 2.2%. Economists expect pressures on consumer prices to increase in both cities, with Hong Kong's CPI expected to rise 2.7% in the final quarter of 2023 and Singapore's CPI forecast to reach 4.7% in 2023.

images.alt_text: Realtors are pinning their hopes on the return of mainland enterprises, after the border reopening. But instead of offices, Chinese companies seem more keen on industrial buildings.
Song Fa Bak Kut Teh is looking to open new stores in Bandung and Surabaya this year, after opening a store in Medan right before the Covid-19 pandemic began in early 2020.

Glitzy Hong Kong shopping streets once packed with luxury stores that attracted 56 million visitors in pre-pandemic 2019 now have about half of their shop units sitting vacant, according to property management companies.
The dramatic downfall of one of tech’s biggest lenders has prompted rethinking of compliance and risk controls.

site_title: Europe: Stocks log steepest one-day fall this year as banks extend slide
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed 2.3% lower on Monday, its steepest one-day fall this year, due to selling pressure on bank, financial, and energy stocks. European banking stocks dropped 5.7%, their worst two-day selloff since the Russia-Ukraine war. The decline comes amid concerns over the sudden collapse of Silicon Valley Bank, despite authorities' efforts to limit the fallout.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended 0.3 per cent lower at 31,819.14 on Monday.

site_title: Geo Energy says it has stopped dealing with coal mine owner that triggered US$15.4 million in allowances
summary: Geo Energy Resources has stopped transactions with a third-party coal mine owner that failed to deliver on coal purchases and meet conditions for a sale-and-purchase agreement. The company had to make US$15.4 million in allowances for expected credit losses due to the mine owner's inability to repay. Discussions over potential repayments are ongoing, and the company has made full allowance for credit loss on outstanding receivables.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
Geo Energy's cash profit from coal mining for 2022 averaged at US$29.04 per tonne, versus US$25.05 per tonne for 2021.

site_title: HSBC plans to inject £2 billion of liquidity into UK unit of SVB
summary: HSBC's UK-based ring-fenced subsidiary has acquired Silicon Valley Bank's (SVB) UK unit for £1, injecting £2 billion of liquidity into the division. The acquisition aims to ensure business continuity and improve HSBC's presence in tech and life-sciences sectors. The bank's CEO, Noel Quinn, stated that the deal makes "strategic sense" and will maintain the unit's existing operations, with no major changes expected. The unit had £5.5 billion in loans and £6.7 billion in deposits as of March 10.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man walks past a HSBC bank branch in the City of London, Britain November 12, 2014.   REUTERS/Stefan Wermuth/File Photo

site_title: Boeing expected to sell nearly 80 787 planes to Saudi airlines: source
summary: Boeing is expected to sell nearly 80 787 Dreamliner airplanes to Saudi Arabian Airlines and Riyadh Air, with a total list price of nearly $37 billion. The deal comes after a major order from United Airlines in December for 100 787s and 100 737 MAX jets. Riyadh Air, the kingdom's new national airline, aims to serve over 100 destinations by 2030 and create 200,000 jobs. The deal is part of Saudi Arabia's efforts to diversify its economy and wean itself off oil, with the new airline expected to add $20 billion to the country's non-oil GDP growth.

images.alt_text: A logo sits on a pilot's seat in the cockpit of a Boeing Co. 787 Dreamliner aircraft on the first day of the Paris Air Show in Paris, France, on Monday, June 17, 2013. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: US dollar drops as Fed rate hike expectations trimmed on SVB collapse
summary: The US dollar dropped 0.55% to near one-month lows of 103.67 as Goldman Sachs downgraded expectations of a large interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve, citing the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank. The Fed announced measures to limit the fallout, including a new Bank Term Funding Program. The market now prices a nearly 60% chance of a rate hike, down from 70% before the SVB collapse.

images.alt_text: Canadian one hundred dollar banknotes are arranged for a photograph in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg

site_title: Singapore’s Q2 business outlook deteriorates for fifth consecutive quarter: Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau
summary: Singapore's business outlook for Q2 2023 has deteriorated for the fifth consecutive quarter, with the business optimism index falling to +4.6 percentage points. This decline was driven by poor sentiment in manufacturing and trade, with only selling prices improving quarter-over-quarter. The construction, financial, services, and transportation sectors showed optimism, but manufacturers and wholesalers experienced declining sentiment. Rising interest rates, global financial vulnerabilities, and geopolitical tensions are expected to weigh on business confidence in the coming months.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Similar to the fourth quarter, five out of six indicators remains expansionary.

SCCB’s chief executive officer Audrey Chia attributed the “overall lukewarm outlook” for local businesses to weakening external demand, escalating geo-political tensions as well as an overall slower pace of global growth.

Local business sentiment has moderated slightly for the second consecutive quarter in the third quarter of 2022, amid a global economic slowdown and geopolitical uncertainties, said the Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau on Tuesday (Jun 14).
Singapore business sentiment moderates slightly in Q2 on global uncertainty: SCCB

site_title: United Airlines slumps after forecast of surprise loss on labour costs
summary: United Airlines Holdings has warned of a surprise loss in the first quarter due to high labour costs, with an adjusted loss of 60-100 cents per share. This marks a sharp turn from the company's previous forecast of a profit of up to $1 per share. The airline is grappling with expenses from a potential new collective bargaining agreement with its pilots union. The news has led to a slump in the company's stock price.

images.alt_text: A United Airlines passenger has been arrested after trying to open an emergency exit door during a flight on Sunday from Los Angeles to Boston and then trying to stab a flight attendant in the neck, US prosecutors said on Monday.
Airlines like American are benefiting from a recovery in demand for travel, especially among higher-end consumers.

site_title: SVB collapse not 'significant risk' to Europe: EU economy chief
summary: EU economy commissioner Paolo Gentiloni says the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank in the US does not pose a significant risk to Europe, citing "predictable" market impacts but no real risk of contagion. He emphasizes monitoring indirect effects but downplays concerns, as European stocks fell sharply following the bank's demise.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of the European Central Bank (ECB) is pictured outside its headquarters in Frankfurt, Germany, December 8, 2016.  REUTERS/Ralph Orlowski/File Photo

site_title: Major cryptocurrencies stabilise after US intervenes on SVB
summary: US authorities have taken emergency measures to shore up confidence in the banking system after Silicon Valley Bank's collapse threatened a broader financial crisis. Major cryptocurrencies stabilized on Monday, with USD Coin recovering to $0.9917 after a record low of $0.87. USDC remained redeemable with the dollar, despite concerns over Circle's exposure to SVB. SVB customers will have access to their deposits starting Monday, and US authorities announced plans to limit the fallout.

images.alt_text: Analysts remain sanguine on the outlook of Singapore’s banks, arguing that there are several fundamental differences which set local lenders significantly apart from Silicon Valley Bank.

site_title: China lifts sweeping visa curbs on foreigners
summary: China has lifted sweeping visa curbs on foreigners, allowing entry to the country for those with valid visas issued before March 28, 2020. This move marks a significant easing of travel restrictions that have been in place since the Covid-19 pandemic. The new policy also includes the review and approval of new travel documents. This move is part of Beijing's gradual shift away from its strict zero-Covid strategy, signaling a return to normalcy in international relations.

images.alt_text: Xi has used the annual parliamentary gathering to hit back at the US for trying to prevent the country’s rise.
Singapore Exchange Centre (SGX) at Shenton Way.
China set an economic growth target of “around five per cent” for 2023, a goal that new premier Li Qiang admitted would not be easy.

site_title: Container ship count in US waters falls by half
summary: The number of container ships in US coastal waters has fallen by 51% compared to last year, with 106 vessels in port and off the coastline late Sunday, according to vessel data. This marks the lowest level since mid-September 2020, with a weekly count of port calls in US waters through March 4 slowing to 1,105 from 1,906 the previous year. The decline is seen as an ominous sign of slowing global trade.

site_title: Oil prices fall 2% in choppy trade as banking fears rattle markets
summary: Oil prices fell 2% in volatile trading on Monday, with Brent crude futures settling at $80.77 a barrel, down $2.01 or 2.4% from the previous day. The decline was attributed to concerns over a potential financial crisis, triggered by the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank. However, a recovery in Chinese demand provided support, limiting the losses. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures also dropped 2.5% to $74.80 a barrel, its lowest price since December.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures fell 15 cents, or -0.18 per cent, to US$82.63 per barrel by 0132 GMT on Monday.

site_title: Britain toughens up diversity targets for UK companies
summary: The UK government has announced tougher diversity targets for FTSE 100 companies, requiring ethnic minorities to account for 20% of board positions and 10% of senior staff by 2027. Currently, ethnic minorities hold 17.9% of board positions and 5.7% of senior staff. The move aims to increase representation of women and individuals from modest social backgrounds in top corporate and financial roles, following recommendations from the Parker Review Committee in 2015.

images.alt_text: For equitable progress for all, we need to implement initiatives on diversity that target equitable opportunities for all, regardless of gender, ethnicity, age, socio-economic background, says Valerie Mantot-Groene, regional managing director, Asean, Apex Group. PHOTO:

site_title: New Zealand flirts with recession amid sharp economic slowdown
summary: New Zealand's economy may be flirting with recession sooner than expected, with a Bloomberg survey predicting a 0.2% contraction in the final quarter of last year. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand had forecast 0.7% growth for the fourth quarter. If the economy fails to expand in the current quarter, it would have entered a recession six months before the central bank's prediction. The RBNZ is expected to slow the pace of monetary tightening or stop before reaching its forecast peak of 5.5% interest rate.

images.alt_text: New Zealand inflation is running at a near-three decade high of 7.2 per cent and is increasingly becoming the key political issue ahead of the election in October, which polls indicate will be tightly contested.
The central bank reiterated it expects a recession starting in the second quarter of this year, but the economy is seen bouncing back a little sooner next year.

site_title: US: Stocks end mixed as regional bank shares plunge
summary: US stocks ended mixed on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.3% to 31,819.14, while the S&P 500 declined 0.2% to 3,855.76. In contrast, the Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.5% to 11,188.84. The decline was attributed to a sell-off in regional bank shares amid concerns of contagion, despite a relatively stable performance in the tech sector.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., March 6, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Crypto-friendly Customers Bancorp falls during sector sell-off
summary: Customers Bancorp, a regional lender that relies on the crypto market, plummeted 24% on Monday amid a sell-off of financial stocks following the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and other regional bank seizures. The Pennsylvania-based bank's shares dropped by nearly 70% before recovering slightly, closing at $17.43. The bank's stock has fallen 38.5% this year and over 70% from its peak in January 2022.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Destroyed SVB (Silicon Valley Bank) logo is seen in this illustration taken March 13, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

FILE PHOTO: A man puts a sign on the door of the Silicon Valley Bank as an onlooker watches at the bank’s headquarters in Santa Clara, California, U.S. March 10, 2023. REUTERS/Nathan Frandino/File Photo
SVB (Silicon Valley Bank) logo and decreasing stock graph are seen in this illustration taken March 10, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

site_title: Court orders KTL Global to pay S$933,800 to alleged shareholder
summary: A High Court judge ordered KTL Global to pay S$933,800 to alleged shareholder Khua Kian Keong for allegedly not paying the full amount of 5,500,000 shares in 2015. KTL Global is currently discussing the judgment with professionals and may appeal within 14 days. The company has advised shareholders to exercise caution in their dealings and refrain from taking any action that may be prejudicial to their interests. Trading of KTL Global's shares remains suspended.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
KTL and the placees have now mutually agreed to terminate the placement, the board said, citing factors such as unfulfilled conditions precedent and an ongoing trading suspension.
The group had earlier acquired vegetable and fruits supplier and distributor Tianci Agritech for S$200,000 in June last year.

site_title: Sias tells shareholders to reject Boustead offer, which IFA calls ‘not fair but reasonable’
summary: Sias advises Boustead Projects shareholders to reject the Boustead Singapore offer of S$0.95 per share, citing it as "not fair but reasonable". The offer, which accounts for 86.55% of shares, is seen as undervalued by Sias, as it falls short of the estimated valuation range of S$1.17 to S$1.38. The company's independent directors recommend accepting the offer unless a higher price is achieved, but Sias warns that delisting is possible if the offer is not accepted.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
Helge Muenkel , Chief Sustainability Officer, DBS
SGX should devise a strategy to manage companies that attempt to slip away from the public market without properly compensating minority investors

site_title: Sri Lanka raises far less than targeted from bond sale
summary: Sri Lanka's central bank sold 110.44 billion rupees in bonds, falling short of its 180 billion-rupee target, with only 441 million rupees accepted for the two-year paper. The central bank set a cut-off yield of 29.99% for the two-year debt and 28.11% for the four-year debt. Analysts attribute the low turnout to the central bank's desire to wait for more favorable interest rates, which could be influenced by a pending $2.9 billion IMF bailout deal.

images.alt_text: “So somewhere in April we will announce ... how we are going to meet those medium-to-long-term (debt) targets. That is the next step,” Sri Lanka central bank governor P Nandalal Weerasinghe said on Thursday.

site_title: As Sea awes investors with profits, its challenge is sustaining momentum
summary: Sea Ltd, the parent company of Garena, reported its first-ever quarterly profit of US$422.8 million, with core earnings of US$270.8 million, a sharp turnaround from the US$616.3 million loss in the previous year. Revenue grew 7.1% to US$3.5 billion. However, CEO Forrest Li expressed caution on "near-term fluctuations" due to macro factors, citing challenges in sustaining momentum, particularly with dampened profitability in the gaming business and potential costs associated with expanding its digital banking venture.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Sea executed a “decisive pivot to focus on efficiency and profitability”, said CEO Forrest Li in a press statement.
The latest cuts affect fewer than 500 full-time and contract workers in Shopee’s customer service team in Indonesia.
Sea's adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation has turned positive three quarters ahead of market expectations.

site_title: China’s provinces are increasingly reliant on Beijing for money
summary: China's local governments are increasingly reliant on Beijing for money due to a drop in tax revenue and Covid Zero costs. Transfer payments from the central government are expected to reach 10 trillion yuan (S$1.97 trillion) this year, accounting for 86% of local governments' income from taxes and fees, up from 66% in 2015. This trend is attributed to rising debt risks, with economists stating it's "only reasonable" for the central government to continue transferring funds.

images.alt_text: In addition to new travel documents being reviewed and approved, visas issued before March 28, 2020 that are still valid will once again allow entry to China, said the embassy notice posted on Monday.
China set an economic growth target of “around five per cent” for 2023, a goal that new premier Li Qiang admitted would not be easy.

site_title: India to discourage foreign trade settlement in Chinese yuan
summary: India has asked banks and traders to avoid using Chinese yuan to settle foreign trade, particularly for Russian imports, due to strained relations with China. The government prefers the use of UAE dirhams for trade settlement, citing concerns over the yuan's role in the global economy and Russia's reluctance to accept payment in Indian rupees. The move follows a review of the situation after UltraTech Cement used yuan to settle a Russian coal import last year. India has emerged as a top buyer of Russian oil and coal, and the government expects most payments to Russia to be in dirhams in the coming months.

images.alt_text: China imported a daily 1.73 million barrels of Russian crude in 2022, up 8.3 per cent from a year earlier.

site_title: Bank stocks plunge resumes as SVB market turmoil continues
summary: US banking shares plummeted on Monday as investors failed to reassure themselves that other banks remain financially sound after the US guaranteed deposits at collapsed tech-focused lender Silicon Valley Bank (SVB). The Stoxx banking index in Europe fell 5.8%, with Commerzbank and Credit Suisse Group experiencing significant losses. Markets now price in a 40% chance that the US central bank will not raise interest rates, indicating reduced concern about financial stability. The move follows previous market turmoil and is seen as a sign of shifting investor sentiment.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange on March 3, 2023. - Wall Street stocks rose early Friday, extending a market upswing despite lingering worries about the likelihood of more central bank interest rate hikes. (Photo by TIMOTHY A. CLARY / AFP)
The Silicon Valley Bank headquarters in Santa Clara, California. Photographer: Philip Pacheco/Bloomberg

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Tuesday’s open; STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.6% to 3,112.54, extending losses from the previous day. The STI declined despite 79 gainers outnumbering 60 losers. Banking stocks led the decline, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC dropping 2.2%, 0.7%, and 0.9% respectively. The slump follows global market downturns, with Wall Street and European stocks experiencing their largest one-day falls in 2023.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Sembcorp Industries' 80 per cent-owned joint venture is building a 500 megawatt (MW) solar power plant in Oman.

site_title: Sembcorp wins first greenfield renewables project in Middle East
summary: Sembcorp Industries has won a 500 MW solar power project in Oman, its first greenfield renewables project in the Middle East. The Manah Solar II Independent Power Project, backed by a 20-year power purchase agreement, is expected to be operational by 2025. The project, financed through internal and external resources, will augment Sembcorp's presence in Oman's power and water desalination sector. The company stated that the project is not expected to impact its earnings per share, net asset value, and leverage for the financial year ending December 2023.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
Thanh Long Phu Yen Solar Power Plant is one of the two first utility-scale solar assets SP have secured in Vietnam.
Commissioned in six months, the Sembcorp ESS (energy storage system) is Southeast Asia’s largest ESS and is the fastest in the world of its size to be deployed

site_title: Indonesian farmers fight for their land in nickel-mining boom
summary: Indonesian farmers are fighting to protect their land from nickel mining, which is part of a global boom in the metal used in electric-vehicle batteries. On the island of Wawonii, in the Sulawesi region, residents have taken to armed vigilance to defend their land against foreign and domestic mining companies, including Chinese firms. The mining projects have harmed the environment and local communities, with pollution and poor working conditions reported. Despite a presidential decree recognizing farmers' rights to state lands, the government is leveraging its resources to entice investors, exacerbating the conflicts.

images.alt_text: A nickel mine in Indonesia. Most of Indonesia's nickel is currently exported to China as low-grade pig iron, but more investment could allow it to be processed into higher-value battery-grade exports.

site_title: US regional banks remain under pressure after collapse of SVB, Signature
summary: US regional banks are under pressure following the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank, with the KBW Regional Banking Index sinking 12% on Monday, its largest intraday decline since March 2020. The collapse of SVB Financial Group's Silicon Valley Bank on Friday and Signature Bank's seizure by regulators sent tremors through the banking system, prompting investors to reduce exposure to the industry. Regulators' efforts to intervene may not be enough to alleviate market concerns, with some analysts describing the situation as a "lose-lose" for the Fed and the market.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden's promised bank regulations could be a tough sell now that he faces a divided Congress.

site_title: Indonesian steelmaker giant Gunung Raja Paksi eyes a low-carbon future
summary: Indonesian steelmaker Gunung Raja Paksi (GRP) aims to transition into a low-carbon company, aligning with the government's push towards renewable energy. With a record high revenue of $723 million and net profit of $49 million in Q3 2022, GRP has reduced its debt burden by over half and is investing in green technologies, including new machinery to increase steel production yield by 10% and reduce waste to less than 5%. GRP's long-term goal is to move from steel production to an energy-transition player, with the company seeking clarity and stability in government policies.

images.alt_text: A truck carries coal in Tabalong, Indonesia. Fitch expects the country's coal production levels to remain stable or grow moderately in the medium term.

The new Presidential Palace under construction in Nusantara. Located in eastern Borneo – the world's third-largest island – Nusantara is set to replace sinking and polluted Jakarta as Indonesia's political centre by late 2024.
To meet its carbon goal, Nippon Steel plans to boost the use of hydrogen in existing blast furnaces, as well as building 100 per cent hydrogen-based so-called direct-reduction plants.

site_title: Iron ore climbs on improving China steel margins, demand outlook
summary: Iron ore prices surged 2.5% on the Singapore Exchange, reaching its highest since February 21, driven by improving steel margins and demand outlook in top steel producer China. The April contract rose to US$132 a tonne, while the May contract on China's Dalian Commodity Exchange gained 0.5%. Chinese steelmakers resumed operations after maintenance, boosting blast furnace capacity utilization and iron ore demand. However, regulatory concerns may curb surging prices.

images.alt_text: China, the world’s largest iron ore consumer, brought in 194 million tonnes of the steel-making ingredient in January and February.

site_title: Financial tremors now muddying Fed inflation debate
summary: US Federal Reserve officials will meet on March 21-22 to continue raising interest rates to combat inflation, despite the sudden failure of Silicon Valley Bank. Despite the Fed's efforts to maintain confidence in the banking system, the collapse may prompt a softer approach to monetary policy if risks intensify. Inflation remains above the Fed's 2% target, with wage growth slowing and unemployment rising. The Fed is expected to consider a smaller rate increase, with some economists suggesting it may be too cautious to follow through with its aggressive rate hike plans.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Federal Reserve building is seen in Washington, U.S., January 26, 2022. REUTERS/Joshua Roberts/File Photo

site_title: Traders bet on no more Fed hikes, US 2-year yields plunge
summary: US traders are betting the Federal Reserve will stop interest-rate hikes, with 2-year Treasury yields plummeting to their lowest level this year. Investors believe the collapse of three US lenders will prompt policymakers to halt monetary tightening. Swaps indicate a less than 1-in-2 chance of another Fed hike, with yields on 2-year Treasury notes falling 60 basis points to 3.99%. The US dollar also declined as the 3-month London interbank offered rate dropped 27 basis points.

images.alt_text: The Silicon Valley Bank headquarters in Santa Clara, California. Photographer: Philip Pacheco/Bloomberg
FILE PHOTO: A U.S. Dollar banknote is seen in this illustration taken May 26, 2020. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: SVB bonds the US says will be ‘wiped out’ gain in rare session
summary: US government officials stated that investors in the bonds and shares of Silicon Valley Bank's holding company will be "wiped out." However, some traders are betting on a higher recovery value for the bonds, contrary to the market's pricing during the tumultuous Friday session. The US government's pledge to protect all depositors has been made, but the exact financial outcome for bondholders remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange on March 3, 2023. - Wall Street stocks rose early Friday, extending a market upswing despite lingering worries about the likelihood of more central bank interest rate hikes. (Photo by TIMOTHY A. CLARY / AFP)

site_title: Credit Suisse shares hit new record low
summary: Credit Suisse shares hit a new record low, falling 8% to 2.29 Swiss francs per share, amid a major overhaul of its business to recover from scandals. The bank has cut costs and jobs, creating a separate investment bank under the CS First Boston brand. The bank also delayed publishing its annual report due to questions from the US Securities and Exchange Commission about its earlier financial statement.

site_title: Chinese startups scramble for alternatives to SVB
summary: Chinese startups are scrambling for alternatives to Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) after the US bank's sudden collapse, despite US regulators guaranteeing all deposits. SVB was a dominant foreign bank for Chinese startups, offering easy access to dollar financing. Chinese banks such as China Merchants Bank and the Industrial & Commercial Bank of China are stepping in to fill the gap, but many startups are still hesitant due to concerns over the level of services offered. Regulators have warned that companies may need to set up two accounts for domestic and foreign capital, creating an opportunity for other banks to fill the market space left by SVB.

images.alt_text: The Silicon Valley Bank headquarters in Santa Clara, California. Photographer: Philip Pacheco/Bloomberg

site_title: Pfizer signs US$43 billion Seagen deal in cancer drug push
summary: Pfizer has signed a $43 billion deal to acquire Seagen, a cancer drug developer, to bolster its oncology portfolio. The deal includes four approved cancer therapies with combined sales of nearly $2 billion in 2022. Pfizer aims to mitigate a $17 billion revenue drop by 2030 due to patent expirations and declining Covid-19 demand. The acquisition is expected to generate over $10 billion in "risk-adjusted" sales by 2030, and is unlikely to face major antitrust challenges.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Pfizer logo is seen in this illustration taken, May 1, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Fed’s new backstop shields banks from US$300 billion of losses
summary: US authorities introduced a new backstop for banks, shielding them from $300 billion of losses after the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank. The Federal Reserve's "Bank Term Funding Programme" provides one-year loans to banks under easier terms, while the discount window was relaxed to provide bigger loans. The measures aim to soothe investors worried about a fresh financial crisis and recession. The US Treasury Secretary assured that all depositors will be protected, and taxpayers will not be on the hook for covering losses.

images.alt_text: MAS said the Singapore banking system remains “sound and resilient” amid the recent collapse of Silicon Valley Bank (SVB), while analysts also expect the fallout will have limited impact on Singapore banks, given fundamental differences between the local lenders and SVB.

site_title: Employers warn EU to cut costs or see businesses flee
summary: European businesses warned the EU to lower energy prices and ease regulations to avoid industry fleeing the continent, citing massive US and Chinese subsidies and lower energy costs. The EU's main business lobby group, BusinessEurope, said Brussels' efforts were insufficient and too slow, with many companies already partially or totally relocating production outside Europe. The EU executive arm is set to present plans to reform the electricity market and boost the green transition, but BusinessEurope called for more action, including cutting taxes on energy and reducing regulations.

images.alt_text: The White House is prioritising access to minerals such lithium, nickel and cobalt needed for electric-vehicle batteries as it pushes an ambitious climate plan.

site_title: Porsche posts record earnings, sets long-term margin goal of 20%
summary: Porsche has reported record earnings and revenue, with a 27.4% rise in annual profit to 6.8 billion euros and revenue of 37.6 billion euros. Deliveries rose 2.6% to nearly 310,000 cars. The company aims to reach a 20% margin in the long term, targeting a revenue rise to 40-42 billion euros this year. Despite supply chain issues and geopolitical strains, Porsche's outlook is aligned with competitors, including Ferrari and Aston Martin, which also expect stronger results in 2023.

images.alt_text: The Porsche Automobil Holding debut follows a record number of investment-grade firms issuing such debt last year, helping the market to a total 33 billion euros of sales.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore banking system remains "sound and resilient" amid the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank (SVB), with the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) stating it has "insignificant exposures" to the failed US bank. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.4% due to concerns over the SVB collapse, but analysts expect limited impact on Singapore banks. Meanwhile, a Vietnamese telehealth startup, Medigo, raised S$2 million in funding to strengthen its services and develop a healthcare ecosystem in Vietnam.

images.alt_text: Indonesia comes in as the top source of visitors to Singapore in February, followed by Malaysia, Australia and South Korea.

site_title: British doctors begin strike likely to be ‘most disruptive’ for health service
summary: Thousands of junior doctors in Britain walked out on Monday in a three-day strike over pay, which they claim is lower than that of a barista. The strike, the latest in a series of NHS walkouts, will disrupt patient care, with emergency services prioritized. The British Medical Association, the junior doctors' trade union, says starting pay can be as low as £14.09 per hour. The strike is set to be the most disruptive, according to NHS England, with routine appointments, surgeries, and some urgent cancer treatments potentially affected.

images.alt_text: The strikes will heap more pressure on Britain’s state-funded NHS which is already stretched by staff shortages and record backlogs.

site_title: Canadian dollar posts biggest weekly drop since September
summary: The Canadian dollar posted its biggest weekly drop since September 2022, falling 1.7% against the US dollar, as investors sought safe havens following the failure of SVB Financial Group. Despite the drop, the loonie held near a five-month low, trading at 72.31 US cents. The Canadian economy beat expectations with 21,800 jobs added in February, putting pressure on the Bank of Canada to consider another rate hike.

images.alt_text: The dollar may be range-bound as slowing inflation to the Fed’s target of 2 per cent is likely to be bumpy, says a senior market analyst.

site_title: Singapore banking system remains ‘sound and resilient’ amid SVB collapse: MAS
summary: Singapore's banking system remains "sound and resilient" despite the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) and other US banks, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). The local banks have "insignificant exposures" to failed US banks and are well-capitalized, conducting regular stress tests. Analysts expect limited impact from SVB's fallout, citing fundamental differences between local lenders and SVB. MAS stands ready to provide liquidity to ensure stability in the financial system, and analysts see opportunities to accumulate Singapore bank shares amid potential share price declines.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Analysts remain sanguine on the outlook of Singapore’s banks, arguing that there are several fundamental differences which set local lenders significantly apart from Silicon Valley Bank.
FILE PHOTO: SVB (Silicon Valley Bank) logo and decreasing stock graph are seen in this illustration taken March 10, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Founders are warning that Silicon Valley Bank's  failure could wipe out startups around the world without government intervention.

site_title: Singapore VCs, startups rethink risk, as some are exposed to SVB fallout
summary: Singaporean tech companies and venture capital firms are reevaluating their risk management strategies after Silicon Valley Bank's (SVB) collapse, which has prompted US regulators to assure depositors they will get their money back. Despite being geographically distant, some Singaporean companies have banking relationships with SVB, raising concerns about potential contagion risks. In response, companies are reassessing their exposure to SVB and exploring alternative financial institutions. Experts warn that the collapse serves as a reminder to monitor exposure to banks and have backup plans in place to mitigate risks.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Sharanya Pillai

Circle, the company behind stablecoin USD Coin (USDC), plans to line up a new transaction banking partner with automated minting and redemption, possibly as early as Monday, Jeremy Allaire, co-founder and chief executive officer of Circle said.
The acquisition follows moves by US financial regulators on Sunday, to assure all depositors their money was safe following SVB’s collapse.

MAS said the Singapore banking system remains “sound and resilient” amid the recent collapse of Silicon Valley Bank (SVB), while analysts also expect the fallout will have limited impact on Singapore banks, given fundamental differences between the local lenders and SVB.

site_title: Adani founders prepay share-backed loans worth US$2.15 billion
summary: Gautam Adani and his family have prepaid $2.65 billion in share-backed loans before the March 31 deadline, including a $500 million loan for Ambuja Cements acquisition. This follows previous prepayments of $902 million and $1.1 billion. The prepayments demonstrate the group's strong liquidity management and capital prudence, but come weeks after a report alleged stock manipulation and accounting fraud. Adani has denied the accusations. The prepayments led to a surge in Adani Group stocks, with four out of 10 stocks jumping by their daily limit.

images.alt_text: Adani Group has been looking to ease concerns about its credit profile after a US-based short seller noted high debt and alleged improper use of offshore tax havens and stock manipulation, which Adani denied.
The meetings could be key to Gautam Adani’s efforts to shore up confidence in his sprawling ports-to-power empire.
FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: The logo of the Adani group is seen on the facade of one of its buildings on the outskirts of Ahmedabad, India, April 13, 2021. REUTERS/Amit Dave/File Photo/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: The logo of the Adani Group is seen on the wall of its realty office building on the outskirts of Ahmedabad, India, January 27, 2023. REUTERS/Amit Dave/File Photo

site_title: German airports face fresh disruption as staff plan pay strike
summary: German airports face disruption as staff plan a pay strike, with scores of flights cancelled at Berlin airport and others affected at Hamburg, Hanover, and Bremen airports. The Verdi labour union is pushing for improved pay and conditions due to the soaring cost of living and acute labour shortages. This follows a tumultuous summer of strikes and delays at Germany's biggest airports last year. The planned industrial action comes amid public sector workers seeking a 10.5% pay bump.

images.alt_text: Labour union Verdi called on workers from Germany's major airports to strike on Friday (Feb 17). The union is demanding a pay increase of 500 euros (S$713) a month for some workers, and higher holiday-shift compensation for others.

site_title: Nobel laureate Kenzaburo Oe, who wrote of war and his son, dies at 88
summary: Nobel laureate Kenzaburo Oe, 88, has died of old age on March 3, 2023. A prominent writer of war and his son, Oe won Japan's second Nobel Prize for literature in 1994. His works, including "A Personal Matter," often explored themes of nuclear war and pacifism. Oe was also a vocal critic of former Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's efforts to revise the country's pacifist constitution and a strong advocate for nuclear disarmament.

images.alt_text: Publisher Shinchosha says it cannot confirm when translations of the latest book by Haruki Murakami (above) might be released, or even when the title of the book would be announced.

site_title: Bali to tighten visa requirements for Russian tourists
summary: Indonesia's Bali is tightening visa requirements for Russian tourists amid a series of visa violations, including at least four deportations this month. The island's governor, I Wayan Koster, has asked the central immigration agency to cancel a visa-on-arrival policy for Russian and Ukrainian nationals due to significant infractions. The move comes after complaints from locals about Russian tourists' actions, including posing nude at a sacred tree and driving under the influence. The decision aims to curb illegal work and other misconduct among Russian tourists.

images.alt_text: Chinese tourists have accounted for one fifth of the total number of foreign visitors in Bali before the pandemic. This year, Indonesia targets 255,300 Chinese tourists in total – a fraction of the nearly 2.1 million who visited in 2019.

site_title: China reopening drives SGX derivatives trading in February: report
summary: China's reopening drove trading activity on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) in February, with total derivatives traded volume reaching its highest in three months at 20 million contracts. Foreign exchange futures volumes rose 39% year on year, driven by hedging demand over China's outlook. The Straits Times Index (STI) slipped 3.1% in February, while total securities market turnover value fell 25% year on year to S$22.1 billion.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
In 2020, SGX signed a wide-ranging agreement with China Central Depository and Clearing Co, (CCDC) to strengthen and promote Singapore and China’s bond markets.
Earnings per share has risen to S$0.266 in H1 2023 from S$0.204 in H1 2022.

site_title: Malaysia’s industrial output grows at slowest pace in 17 months
summary: Malaysia's industrial output grew 1.8% in January, the slowest pace in 17 months, according to the Department of Statistics of Malaysia. The growth was lower than the median estimate of 2.3% in a Bloomberg survey. The decline was largely due to weakening external trade, particularly in the global semiconductor industry, which saw output growth slow to 0.8% from 7.6% in December. The decline in manufacturing output was attributed to slower momentum in global trade.

site_title: ‘Laser focus’ on wealthy clients pays off for Sun Life
summary: Canada-based financial services group Sun Life is launching a new index-linked universal life (UL) product in Singapore, targeting high-net-worth clients. The move follows the company's "laser focus" on HNW clients, which has served it well in Asia. Sun Life has invested in partnerships and asset management businesses in the region, with a 130-year presence and $1.33 trillion in assets under management globally. The company believes there is a "massive opportunity" in Asia's retirement savings markets, particularly in Singapore and other developing economies, where it plans to expand its presence in the next 15-20 years.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua
Tax incentive scheme for donors with family offices may spur philanthropic activity out of Singapore.

According to EDB, the changes aim to encourage GIP investors to deploy more funds in the local financial system and generate more jobs for Singaporeans, including in the finance, tax, legal, and fund management fields.

site_title: Banks drag European stocks down
summary: European stocks slid, with the Stoxx 600 down 2% and banks down 4%, their largest two-day drop since the Ukraine war began in February 2022. Credit Suisse shares plummeted 9.2%, Commerzbank fell 9.3%, and Bawag Group dropped 10.6%. The heavy selling came despite US authorities' efforts to shore up confidence in the banking system after Silicon Valley Bank's collapse. Europe's volatility index reached its highest since October, reflecting market nervousness.

site_title: Upcoming Johor energy complex scores US$102b worth of feedstock supply, product off-take deals
summary: The Pengerang Energy Complex (PEC) in Johor, Malaysia, has secured US$102 billion worth of feedstock supply and product off-take agreements with leading energy majors Chevron, Equinor, PTT, and Mitsui & Co. The deals will support PEC's full needs for its initial 12 years of operation, forecasting an annual export turnover of US$5 billion. The complex is expected to deliver the lowest carbon footprint per tonne of paraxylene produced globally, when operational in late 2026, propelling Malaysia up the value chain in the petrochemical sector.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting

Indonesia state-owned Pertamina launched a refinery development master plan that seeks to revitalize five of its major refineries by increasing their capacities and product slate while improving product emissions standards and reducing the country’s dependence on foreign imports.

site_title: Recession delayed but not avoided
summary: A global recession is unlikely in the near term, but a cyclical recession is probable within the next 12 months due to complacent market sentiment. The global economy has shown strength, with the US labor market and European economic surprises. However, central banks' hawkish stance and monetary tightening will lead to higher interest rates, affecting credit markets before equity markets. Emerging markets, particularly China, are a bright spot, with improving corporate earnings and attractive valuations. Investors need to maintain a cautious stance and consider alternative strategies to navigate the potential growth slowdown and inflation risks.

images.alt_text: The Fed set up a new emergency facility to let banks pledge a range of high-quality assets for cash over a term of one year.
China’s consumers are in focus as household spending is expected to drive demand in the world’s second-largest economy.

site_title: STI falls 1.4% amid mixed Asian trading as investors weigh SVB collapse
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.4% on Monday, March 13, amid mixed Asian trading following the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) in the US. The STI closed at 3,132.37, with all but four counters ending the day in the red. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC were the top three most actively traded counters, falling between 1.4% and 1.7%. Markets are pricing in idiosyncratic risks from SVB, with US regulators strengthening confidence in the banking system.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Analysts remain sanguine on the outlook of Singapore’s banks, arguing that there are several fundamental differences which set local lenders significantly apart from Silicon Valley Bank.
SVB’s collapse into FDIC receivership came suddenly on Friday, following a frenetic couple of days where its long-established customer base of tech startups yanked deposits.
FILE PHOTO: SVB (Silicon Valley Bank) logo and decreasing stock graph are seen in this illustration taken March 10, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Bank of London said it had submitted a formal proposal to the UK arm of SVB, as well as sending it to authorities, including the Treasury and the Bank of England.

site_title: Vietnam telehealth startup Medigo raises S$2 million in East Ventures-led round
summary: Vietnam-based telehealth startup Medigo has raised S$2 million in Series A funding led by East Ventures. The funding will be used to develop a healthcare ecosystem in Vietnam, including remote doctor consultation, 24-hour medicine delivery, and home testing services. With around 500,000 active users and 1,000 pharmacy partners, Medigo plans to strengthen its services and expand its offerings. The company aims to create a comprehensive healthcare platform in Vietnam.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: BT Mark to Market: A tale of two SGX delistings (Ep 29)
summary: Singapore's SGX delisting rules are being tested with two recent deals: Golden Energy and Resources' proposed break-up and delisting, and Boustead Projects' general offer. Both deals have been criticized for undervaluing minority investors, with Golden Energy trading above the all-cash consideration and Boustead Projects' offer significantly below its Net Asset Value (NAV) and Real Net Asset Value (RNAV). SGX has tightened its rules on de-listings since 2019, but the current deals may push the exchange to re-examine its position on general offers and de-listings.

images.alt_text: Boustead Singapore is offering to buy Boustead Projects at S$0.95 per share
Gear said a key rationale for the deal is to cut its exposure to the thermal coal business conducted by Gems, which faces ESG pressures
Boustead Singapore's new offer price of S$0.95 per share is unlikely to have satisfied long-term shareholders of Boustead Projects
Gear has pushed the long-stop date for the deal from Apr 9 to Aug 9
Gear said the distribution-in-specie is meant to reduce its exposure to energy coal, which is facing scrutiny as a fuel source.

site_title: Petronas reports highest-ever earnings in 2022, cautious on outlook for 2023
summary: Petronas, Malaysia's state energy company, reported its highest-ever earnings in 2022, with a profit after tax of RM101.9 billion, driven by higher oil and gas prices. Revenue rose 51% to RM375.3 billion. However, Petronas president and CEO Tengku Muhammad Taufik Tengku Aziz took a cautious outlook for 2023, citing anticipated economic slowdown and market volatility. He expects oil prices to moderate, averaging between US$70 and US$80 per barrel in the next five years.

images.alt_text: Petronas has declared force majeure on gas supply to one of its liquefaction terminals, Malaysia LNG Dua, after a pipeline leak caused by soil movement at the Sabah-Sarawak pipeline on Sep 21.
Last month, Luxembourg court bailiffs issued fresh seizure orders for two units of Petronas in a similar effort.

site_title: BOJ pivot pressure to ease as SVB collapse drags US yields lower
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) left its negative interest rate and government debt yield cap unchanged in its final meeting under outgoing Governor Haruhiko Kuroda. This decision may ease pressure on the BOJ to abandon its yield curve control programme, as Japan's benchmark 10-year government bond yield dropped to 0.32%, its lowest level since December. The move is attributed to the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank, which tempered hawkish Federal Reserve rate-hike bets and may lead to a decrease in Japanese rates.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Maybank turns ‘neutral’ on Singapore banks with DBS as top pick
summary: Maybank Securities has downgraded its rating on Singapore banks to "neutral" from "positive" due to balanced risk-reward dynamics, limited upside catalysts, and rising asset quality risks. Analyst Thilan Wickramasinghe expects a sharp deceleration in net interest margins and potential recession in the US and Europe. DBS remains Maybank's top pick, but target prices for UOB and OCBC have been lowered to S$31.73 and S$13.58, respectively, amid reduced earnings estimates and higher cost-of-equity projections.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Analysts remain sanguine on the outlook of Singapore’s banks, arguing that there are several fundamental differences which set local lenders significantly apart from Silicon Valley Bank.
DBS, UOB and OCBC ATMs at the Singapore Institute of Management (SIM) on March 12, 2020.
Generic of UOB bank, at Raffles Place on Feb 23, 2023

The chief executives of the respective banks remained cautiously optimistic of their FY2023 performance, as they expect interest rates will largely remain elevated and continue to boost their net interest margins (NIM), although they warned of costs catching up.

site_title: HSBC buys SVB’s UK unit for £1 in reprieve for tech sector
summary: HSBC Holdings acquired the UK arm of Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) for £1, providing a reprieve for the tech sector. The deal, announced Monday, follows US financial regulators' assurances that all SVB depositors' money is safe. The acquisition will not impact HSBC's forecasts and will allow SVB UK to continue operating normally. The Bank of England confirmed that all depositors' money is secure and that no other UK banks were directly affected by the actions. The deal is seen as a strategic move to boost HSBC's exposure to the technology and life-science sectors.

images.alt_text: Regulators seized the Santa Clara, California-based company last week and put it into receivership, marking the biggest failure of a US bank since 2008.

site_title: Canadian farms buck housing market trend as prices keep rising
summary: Canadian farms defied the national housing market trend, with farmland prices rising 13% in 2022, the largest increase since 2014. Despite rising interest rates and higher fertilizer costs, demand remained robust due to tight supplies. Ontario saw the largest gains, with prices jumping 19% for large farm operations and investors. Experts expect prices to rise but at a slower rate in 2023, with strong demand and limited supply maintaining a stable market.

site_title: China self-driving startup WeRide files for US$500 million US IPO
summary: Chinese self-driving startup WeRide Technology has filed for a US$500 million initial public offering (IPO) in the US, working with advisers on a potential listing that could take place in the first half of this year. The Guangzhou-based company, valued at $4.4 billion in a 2022 fundraising round, aims to raise funds to support its autonomous driving technology development. WeRide will outsource data collection to address concerns raised by Beijing about sensitive data selling shares abroad, following a crackdown on Chinese companies with sensitive data selling shares abroad in 2021.

images.alt_text: Dida has obtained assurances from Chinese regulators for the share sale to go ahead, and could list in Hong Kong as soon as in June, sources say.

site_title: Mask-free Monday comes to Japan as government eases Covid-19 guidelines
summary: Japan relaxes face mask norms, allowing maskless visits to Tokyo Disneyland and other major companies starting Monday, as the country eases Covid-19 guidelines. The move comes after Japan's Covid vaccination rate exceeds 80% and cases have decreased. Experts note that Japan's universal mask usage and emphasis on hygiene and social distancing contributed to its relatively low death toll. However, they warn that a rapid behavioral change is unlikely, with many people likely to continue wearing masks, even after the rules are relaxed.

images.alt_text: China and Hong Kong removed Covid curbs for mainland travellers in early February, and visitor numbers are expected to pick up rapidly.
The WHO's director general notes that understanding Covid 19's origins and exploring all hypotheses remains a scientific imperative to help prevent future outbreaks.

site_title: China premier warns 2023 growth target ‘no easy task’
summary: China's new premier, Li Qiang, warned that the country's 5% economic growth target for 2023 is not an "easy task" to achieve. The target, set by the government, is one of the lowest in decades and comes after China posted 3% growth last year, missing its stated target. Li attributed the modest figure to various factors, including the impact of strict Covid policies and a property crisis. He emphasized that most people focus on specific issues rather than growth figures, and the government will need to redouble its efforts to meet the target.

images.alt_text: The PBOC’s decision will follow Yi Gang’s reappointment as the central bank governor by China’s Parliament on Sunday along with several other top economic officials including the finance minister.
Xi has used the annual parliamentary gathering to hit back at the US for trying to prevent the country’s rise.

site_title: Does demand for HDB BTO units in mature estates need tempering?
summary: The demand for HDB BTO units in mature estates in Singapore remains strong despite higher prices and lower chances of securing such flats. The latest BTO exercise saw a higher application rate for four-room flats in mature estates compared to non-mature estates. However, some experts suggest that prices of BTO flats in mature estates should be tempered to discourage applicants who opt for such estates due to profit motives, rather than raising them to eliminate applicants. This could lead to lower prices, but may also increase application rates and anxiety among homebuyers.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
Successful applicants for Jurong West Crystal and Brickland Weave be able to move into their new homes earlier, as these projects have shorter waiting times.

ST20230207-202313441712-Lim Yaohui-pixgeneric/
Generic photograph of HDB flats being built around Darul Ghufran Mosque as viewed from Blk 413 Tampines Street 41 on Feb 7, 2023.
Can be used for stories on money, property, land, religion, invest, budget, income, finance, financial, URA, HDB, housing, marriage, fertility, BTO, population, economy, and development.
(ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI)

site_title: Underperforming aviation counters trade at attractive levels: DBS
summary: DBS Group Research believes Singapore's aviation stocks are trading at attractive levels with favorable risk-to-reward ratios, despite recent underperformance. The research team recommends "buy" ratings for ST Engineering and Singapore Airlines, with target prices of S$4.20 and S$6.80, respectively. They attribute the sector's decline to underwhelming earnings, but expect strong growth over the coming years, citing ST Engineering's 14% compound annual growth rate and Singapore Airlines' impressive earnings momentum.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Leslie Thng, CEO, Scoot

UOBKH has lowered its target price to S$5.35 from S$5.40 as it believes valuations are now “stretched”, with the stock trading about 1.9 standard deviation points above its historical mean before the pandemic.

Passenger load factor – the percentage of available seating capacity filled by paying passengers – as well as passenger yield were record high for Singapore Airlines and Scoot in the quarter to December.
The International Civil Aviation Organization expects passenger demand to recover to pre-Covid levels on most routes this quarter and then to about 3 per cent higher than 2019 levels by year-end.

site_title: Delisting plans by Golden Energy, Boustead Projects a test of SGX’s rules, stated views
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has reminded Golden Energy and Resources (GEAR) to ensure its independent financial adviser's (IFA) opinion on its proposed delisting and exit offer is fair and reasonable. GEAR had proposed a distribution in-specie of its 62.5% stake in Indonesia-listed thermal coal producer Golden Energy Mines (GEMS) and an exit offer of S$0.16 per share, which would see shareholders receive an effective consideration of S$1.045 per share. The SGX has also expressed concerns about Boustead Projects, which has proposed a general offer for Boustead Projects at S$0.95 per share, but has not extended the offer to all shareholders, including those held by nominees of Wong Fong Fui. The SGX is considering devising a strategy to manage companies that attempt to slip away from the public market without properly compensating minority investors.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
Boustead Singapore is offering to buy Boustead Projects at S$0.95 per share
Gear said the distribution-in-specie is meant to reduce its exposure to energy coal, which is facing scrutiny as a fuel source.
Gear said a key rationale for the deal is to cut its exposure to the thermal coal business conducted by Gems, which faces ESG pressures
The shift away from energy coal - the world's largest single source of energy-related greenhouse gas emissions - could seem somewhat less opportune for Golden Energy and Resources
Boustead Singapore's new offer price of S$0.95 per share is unlikely to have satisfied long-term shareholders of Boustead Projects

David Gerald, founder and chief executive of the Securities Investors Association (SIAS), says Golden Energy and Resources shareholders strongly maintain their view that the current exit offer price of S$0.16 per share is too low.

site_title: Michelle Yeoh makes history as first Asian to win best actress Oscar
summary: Michelle Yeoh made history by becoming the first Asian woman to win the Best Actress Oscar for her portrayal of Evelyn Wang in the sci-fi film "Everything Everywhere All at Once." Yeoh, 60, won over Academy voters with her complex take on the Chinese American laundromat owner, who navigates multiple universes to evade a supernatural enemy. Yeoh's win comes after a successful awards season, with previous wins at the Golden Globes, Spirit Awards, and Screen Actors Guild Awards. She dedicated her award to inspiring Asian representation in Hollywood, saying "dream big and dreams do come true."

images.alt_text: The cast and crew of "Everything Everywhere All at Once" Michelle Yeoh (second right), Ke Huy Quan (second left), Stephanie Hsu (right), Jamie Lee Curtis (left), James Hong (third left), Daniel Kwan (bottom left), Daniel Scheinert (bottom right), Jonathan Wang (centre) pose with their Oscar trophies at the 95th Annual Academy Awards in Hollywood, California, March 12, 2023.

site_title: Asia: Most markets sink after US lender’s collapse
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Monday following the collapse of two US banks, Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank, with Tokyo, Sydney, and other markets down over 1%. The US Federal Reserve, Treasury Department, and Federal Deposit Insurance Corp pledged to protect depositors and provide support to struggling lenders, citing the US banking system's resilience. The crisis may complicate the Fed's interest rate hike plans, and investors now expect a smaller rate increase at the next meeting.

images.alt_text: The banking trio slid between 0.9 and 2.2 per cent on Friday.
The Topix Banks Index has tumbled 5.4 per cent, the most since March 2020.

site_title: New Zealand government to boost financial support for 1.4 million people in face of soaring inflation
summary: New Zealand's government is boosting financial support for 1.4 million citizens to combat soaring inflation, which has reached a near-three decade high of 7.2%. The move aims to offset the cost of living crisis ahead of the October election, which polls indicate will be tightly contested. Prime Minister Chris Hipkins announced the package, which includes benefits for pensioners, students, children, and parents, to help those feeling the impact of rising living costs.

images.alt_text: The RBNZ this week raised the Official Cash Rate (OCR) by 50 basis points to 4.75 per cent.

site_title: Sustainability through art
summary: Singapore's Art of Trash Competition, a sequel to UBS' Trash-Sure campaign, showcased over 190 artworks created from upcycled plastic waste by artists as young as seven years old and people with special abilities. The competition, which included categories for primary school, secondary school, and open, aimed to raise awareness on sustainability and inspire conversations for a greener future. The first-prize winner, Naomi Chu, created a sculpture highlighting coral bleaching, with the works of 22 finalists displayed at Ang Mo Kio Library from March 16.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang

site_title: Beyond the US budget debate, Powell remains the big decider
summary: US President Joe Biden's proposed budget, aimed at promoting socio-economic programs and climate change efforts, is being countered by Republicans who focus on cutting the budget deficit and national debt without raising taxes. However, monetary policy is seen as crucial in determining the economic and political outcome of 2024, with Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell holding significant sway over inflation and recession. Powell has indicated a willingness to raise interest rates to tame inflation, but warned Congress of the risks of a debt default and financial catastrophe if the debt ceiling is not suspended or increased.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden talks about his proposed FY2024 federal budget during an event at the Finishing Trades Institute in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, March 9, 2023.

Friday’s labour market report is among key pieces of data that Fed chair Jerome Powell and his fellow monetary policymakers are tallying in the run-up to their Mar 21-22 policy-setting meeting in Washington.

site_title: Oil prices slip as concerns over rate hikes rattle investors
summary: Oil prices slipped 0.18% on Monday as concerns over US interest rate hikes weighed on investors, despite a weaker dollar and recovery in Chinese demand providing some support. Brent crude futures fell to $82.63 per barrel and West Texas Intermediate crude futures dipped to $76.59 per barrel. Analysts attributed the fragile market sentiment to high US crude oil inventories and worries about further monetary tightening by the Fed.

images.alt_text: Expectations of further rate hikes in the world’s largest economy and in Europe have clouded the global growth outlook and driven both crude benchmarks down this week.
Saudi Aramco's performance has been bolstered by record production and oil prices soaring to around US$130 a barrel after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: Offbeat multiverse movie ‘Everything Everywhere’ dominates the Oscars
summary: Michelle Yeoh made history by becoming the first Asian woman to win the Best Actress Oscar for her role in "Everything Everywhere All at Once." The film also won Best Picture, Best Supporting Actor for Ke Huy Quan, and Best Supporting Actress for Jamie Lee Curtis. The movie, directed by Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, is a sci-fi comedy-drama about a Chinese-American family's struggles across multiple dimensions. The 95th Academy Awards ceremony, which aired on ABC, aimed to move past last year's controversy surrounding Will Smith's slap on stage and boost sagging TV ratings.

images.alt_text: Everything Everywhere All At Once starring Michelle Yeoh is a triumph not just of Asian representation - it is also one of the most culturally astute films in recent memory,
"Scream VI" starring (from left) Melissa Barrera and Jenna Ortega took in an estimated US$44.5 miilion at the North America box office.

site_title: Singapore shares open slightly lower on Silicon Valley Bank contagion fears; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.2% to 3,171.41, with banks opening in the red due to contagion fears from the US closure of Silicon Valley Bank. The US Dow Jones, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the KBW regional banking index falling 3.6%. Other major indexes in Europe finished at a seven-week low, with financial stocks leading declines.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Stage 1 Properties of Bei Gang Logistics, one of six properties in EC World Reit’s portfolio. Its manager says the Reit has adequate current assets to meet its short-term liabilities.
SVB’s collapse into FDIC receivership came suddenly on Friday, following a frenetic couple of days where its long-established customer base of tech startups yanked deposits.
FILE PHOTO: SVB (Silicon Valley Bank) logo and decreasing stock graph are seen in this illustration taken March 10, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Coinbase says it has about US$240 million cash balance with Signature Bank
summary: Coinbase announced it has a US$240 million cash balance with Signature Bank, hours after the New York-based lender was closed by state regulators. The US Treasury Department stated that all Signature Bank depositors will be made whole, with no losses to the taxpayer. This comes after California's Silicon Valley Bank collapse, the third-largest US bank failure in history, which left billions of dollars of deposits stranded. Coinbase is facilitating client cash transactions with other banking partners due to the FDIC's hold on Signature's transactions.

site_title: Gold hits over 5-week high on weaker dollar, bank worries
summary: Gold prices rose to a five-week high on Monday, reaching $1,877.30 per ounce, driven by a weaker US dollar and concerns over the largest US bank failure since the 2008 financial crisis. Investors sought safe-haven assets amid worries over economic uncertainties and potential interest rate cuts. The dollar index fell 0.4%, making gold cheaper for buyers holding other currencies. US officials assured customers of Silicon Valley Bank would have access to their deposits starting Monday, stemming financial fallout.

images.alt_text: Gold prices are en route to a second consecutive weekly rise.

site_title: Kitchen Culture breaches Catalist rule, fails to file financial statements by deadline
summary: Kitchen Culture, a Catalist-listed kitchen outfitter, breached listing rules by failing to file its unaudited financial statements for FY2022 by the deadline of Mar 1. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) rejected its request for an extension, citing no extenuating reasons. Kitchen Culture has agreed to announce the statements as soon as possible and hold its annual general meeting by Apr 30. The company has also suspended its shares from trading since July 2021, amidst a boardroom tussle.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

site_title: Fed bets pared as Goldman scraps March hike call on flaring risk
summary: The US Federal Reserve has pared its expectations for interest-rate hikes amid rising financial strains at regional banks. Goldman Sachs economists cited "recent stress in the banking system" as the reason for their revised call, and Treasury yields dropped 25 basis points to 4.34%. The Fed set up a new emergency facility to provide liquidity to banks and regulators pledged to protect uninsured depositors at Silicon Valley Bank. Economists now expect a smaller rate hike, if any, at the next meeting, citing uncertainty about the banking sector's future.

images.alt_text: President Joe Biden talks about his proposed federal budget – seen as a preview of his 2024 re-election platform – at the Finishing Trades Institute in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.
A locked door to a Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) location on Sand Hill Road is seen in Menlo Park, California, U.S. March 10, 2023. REUTERS/Jeffrey Dastin

The use of the Fed’s emergency lending authority is for “unusual and exigent” circumstances, and signals that US regulators view the spillovers from SVB’s collapse as a sign of systemic risk in markets.
Pricing of swaps linked to Fed meetings suggest the central bank’s policy rate will peak at around 5.3 per cent in June, and end the year below 5 per cent.

site_title: US says all SVB deposits safe, creates new backstop for banks
summary: US financial regulators have created a new backstop to protect depositors' funds after Silicon Valley Bank's (SVB) sudden collapse into FDIC receivership. The Treasury Department, Federal Reserve, and FDIC announced measures to strengthen confidence in the banking system, protecting all depositors and ensuring they can access their money starting Monday. The government also established a new "Bank Term Funding Programme" to provide loans to banks under easier terms, and a $25 billion backstop for the program. The actions aim to stem fears of spillover effects from SVB's failure, which has raised concerns about smaller lenders' financial stability.

site_title: Signature Bank closed by New York regulators in SVB’s wake
summary: New York regulators closed Signature Bank, citing the fallout from Silicon Valley Bank's collapse, which has spread to other lenders. Signature Bank had $110.36 billion in assets and $88.59 billion in deposits as of December 31. Depositors will have access to their money under a similar systemic risk exception, and regulators said no losses will be borne by taxpayers. The closure comes as US regulators rush to find solutions for failed Silicon Valley Bank and prevent a potential contagion.

images.alt_text: A Signature Bank branch in New York. Photographer: Jeenah Moon/Bloomberg

site_title: Stocks to watch: EC World Reit, Boustead Singapore, Boustead Projects, Southern Alliance Mining
summary: EC World Reit reported it has adequate current assets to meet its short-term liabilities, boosting its shares 2.9% on Friday. Boustead Singapore acquired 86.55% of Boustead Projects shares, aiming to take the subsidiary private and seek delisting. Southern Alliance Mining expects to report a net loss for the six months ended Jan 31 due to lower iron ore production. Sysma posted a net loss of S$2.7 million for the six months ended Jan 31, while Sunright narrowed its net loss to S$1.3 million for the same period.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

site_title: Billions worth of crypto trades at risk as bank shutdowns take toll
summary: Cryptocurrency trades are at risk due to the shutdowns of Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) and Silvergate Capital. The closure of Silvergate's electronic payments platform, the Silvergate Exchange Network (SEN), threatens to disrupt the crypto market's liquidity and growth. SEN facilitated fast and cost-free transactions between crypto firms and banks, but its shutdown has led to increased costs for fiat conversions and reduced access to liquidity, potentially stalling institutional adoption. Alternative networks are emerging, but some may struggle to compete with the lost resources and liquidity.

images.alt_text: SVB’s collapse into FDIC receivership came suddenly on Friday, following a frenetic couple of days where its long-established customer base of tech startups yanked deposits.
Regulators seized the Santa Clara, California-based company last week and put it into receivership, marking the biggest failure of a US bank since 2008.
At Silicon Valley Bank, north of 93 per cent of the bank’s deposits are uninsured.
Silicon Valley Bank abruptly became the biggest US lender to fail in more than a decade on Friday, unravelling in less than 48 hours after outlining a plan to shore up capital.
The main entrance of Silicon Valley Bank is pictured in Menlo Park, California, U.S. March 10, 2023. REUTERS/Michaela Vatcheva  NO RESALES. NO ARCHIVES
Bank of London said it had submitted a formal proposal to the UK arm of SVB, as well as sending it to authorities, including the Treasury and the Bank of England.

site_title: Six Hong Kong-listed firms say their deposits at SVB are immaterial
summary: Six Hong Kong-listed firms, primarily Chinese pharmaceutical companies, have disclosed that their deposits at Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) are immaterial, aiming to calm investors amid the largest US bank failure since the 2008 financial crisis. SVB collapsed on Friday, stranding billions of dollars. Companies such as Brii Biosciences, Broncus Holding, and CStone Pharmaceuticals reported deposits ranging from 0.2% to 6.5% of their total cash, with most stating their cash and assets are diversified to minimize risk.

images.alt_text: The main entrance of Silicon Valley Bank is pictured in Menlo Park, California, U.S. March 10, 2023. REUTERS/Michaela Vatcheva  NO RESALES. NO ARCHIVES

site_title: Bitcoin jumps the most in almost a month after US supports banking sector
summary: Bitcoin surged 5.3% to US$21,582, its largest gain in almost a month, after US authorities pledged to protect depositors' money and ease lending terms for banks. The move alleviated concerns about the US financial system's stability following the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank. Other altcoins also posted significant gains, with Cardano, Litecoin, and Tron rising 6.1%, 7.4%, and 12% respectively. The Federal Reserve's rescue plan boosted market confidence and allayed concerns about a broader collapse of banks and the crypto industry.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A representation of virtual currency Bitcoin is seen in front of a stock graph in this illustration taken January 8, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/File Photo

site_title: ECB seen hiking rates again, but for how much longer?
summary: The European Central Bank is expected to raise interest rates by another half percentage point at its meeting, marking the sixth consecutive increase. The decision, which is "very, very likely," aims to tame inflation, which reached 8.5% in February, driven by energy and food costs. Analysts expect the ECB to hike rates further, potentially to 3.5-4.0% this summer, and are watching for clues on future moves. The bank's new economic forecasts, released on Thursday, are expected to provide guidance on the pace of rate hikes.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen outside the European Central Bank (ECB) building, in Frankfurt, Germany, July 21, 2022. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo

site_title: Run on Silicon Valley Bank offers old-school lessons in risk management
summary: Silicon Valley Bank's (SVB) collapse was accelerated by inadequate risk management, poor communication, and a rapid social media-driven panic among venture capital investors.
