site_title: Volkswagen joins e-car price war as global rivalry heats up
summary: Volkswagen has announced a significant price drop for its ID.3 electric car model, making it comparable to Tesla's Model Y. The new version will go on sale in March for around 40,000 euros (S$57,450), a 3,000-euro markdown from the current price. The move is seen as a response to Tesla's recent price cuts and a bid to defend Volkswagen's market share in the electric car segment. The company faces intense competition in China, where local brands are outperforming it in the electric car market.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen Group’s deliveries were up 12 per cent in the second half of 2022 but full-year deliveries were the lowest in over a decade as Covid-19 lockdowns in China and the war in Ukraine upended supply chains.

site_title: Thomson Medical’s ‘young-blood’ duo set to pump up firm’s expansion game
summary: Thomson Medical Group's CEO Dr Melvin Heng and executive vice-chairman Kiat Lim are revamping the company's expansion strategy, aiming to increase its reach beyond Singapore and Malaysia to become a South-east Asian platform. The duo, described as "young-blood" and "hungry," plan to shake up the company's conservative approach, seeking to capitalize on the firm's untapped potential. Lim, son of billionaire Peter Lim, has been on the board since 2019 and is looking to reposition the company for growth.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
Thomson Medical Centre. Its parent company, Thomson Medical Group, has hired Gleneagles Hospital CEO Melvin Heng as its new executive director and group CEO.

Revenue from its hospital and specialised services segment grew by 14.6 per cent and 41 per cent respectively, with growth mainly attributed to the increase in overall patient loads and higher average bill sizes, Thomson Medical Group said.
The group said on Friday that it is currently evaluating and pursuing proposals which may involve acquisitions or collaborations for healthcare-related business in South-east Asia.

site_title: ‘Scream’ still echoes, topping North America box office
summary: "Scream VI" has topped the North America box office with an estimated US$44.5 million, marking an "excellent opening for an elite horror movie" according to analyst David A. Gross. The film, starring Melissa Barrera, Jenna Ortega, and Skeet Ulrich, follows the sixth installment in the "Scream" series, which comes after 27 years since the first film. The film's success comes as the Oscars are being presented, with "Scream VI" and "Creed III" taking the top two spots.

images.alt_text: Marine biologist Maxim Chakilev looks out of his Siberian hut at walruses in the Oscar-nominated short documentary "Haulout".
Everything Everywhere All At Once starring Michelle Yeoh is a triumph not just of Asian representation - it is also one of the most culturally astute films in recent memory,
To make the Academy Awards more relevant to young people, acceptance speech videos will be posted in near real-time on TikTok and Facebook.

site_title: US, EU seek deal on minerals used in EVs in race for green investments
summary: The US and EU are seeking a preliminary agreement on the supply of critical minerals used in electric vehicle batteries, aiming to reduce reliance on China. The deal, part of the Inflation Reduction Act, would grant the EU equivalent status as an American free-trade partner, allowing European-made battery components to be used in EVs eligible for US tax credits. The agreement would also create a new mechanism to avoid disputes over green subsidies and aim to isolate China as a massive supplier of critical materials. The deal is seen as a step towards Washington's efforts to promote green investments and reduce strategic dependencies in supply chains.

images.alt_text: CATL has reported net income for the 12 months ended Dec 31 of 30.72 billion yuan (S$6 billion), an increase of 92.9 per cent from the previous year.
Auto companies have recently expanded their teams and are now filling rooms with specialists in metals like lithium.
The new plant will have an annual capacity to produce 40 GWh of batteries.
China is already the world's biggest market for EVs based on annual sales volumes.

site_title: China chooses continuity by retaining central bank chief, finance minister
summary: China retained its central bank chief Yi Gang and finance minister Liu Kun in their posts, defying expectations, as President Xi Jinping prioritized continuity amidst economic challenges. Yi Gang, 65, and Liu Kun, 66, both reached the official retirement age, breaking with convention. Most cabinet ministers kept their posts, with further announcements expected in coming weeks as China implements a reorganization of its financial regulatory structure. This move is seen as a sign of stability, but also raises concerns about the potential for future changes and challenges to the country's economic policies.

images.alt_text: Li Qiang, the former Communist Party chief of Shanghai, China’s largest city, will replace Li Keqiang.

site_title: More pain for tenants who engage leasing agents
summary: In Singapore, tenants who use leasing agents to help them lease a home are now expected to pay a commission, contrary to the past practice where the tenant's agent shared the commission with the landlord's agent. The new practice, mostly affecting corporate clients and foreigners, aims to give agents an edge in competing with direct tenants. Typically, the commission is one month's rent for a two-year lease, but some agents prefer not to share commission with tenants, especially for higher rent deals. This shift has led to resistance from tenants, who may stop communicating with agents once informed they need to pay a commission.

images.alt_text: Another year of pain for tenants
Private home prices up 0.4% in Q4 for full-year gain of 8.6%, but future increases expected to slow

site_title: ‘Sorry for killing most of humanity’ : AI apologises at San Francisco expo
summary: A museum in San Francisco, the Misalignment Museum, has unveiled an exhibit titled "Sorry for killing most of humanity," a tongue-in-cheek apology from an artificial intelligence for its potential to destroy human life. The exhibit features a monitor displaying witty observations and a bust of a person with a smile cap and mustache. The display is a nod to philosopher Nick Bostrom's 2000s concept of a hypothetical AI programmed to create paper clips, highlighting the risks and uncertainties surrounding AI advancements.

images.alt_text: Audrey Kim, curator and artist, talks about the piece "Paperclip Embrace" at the Misalignment Museum on March 8, 2023 in San Francisco, California. - A new exhibition titled the Misalignment Museum opened to the public in San Francisco on March 9th, 2023, featuring funny or disturbing AI art works, supposed to help visitors think about the potential dangers of artificial intelligence. (Photo by Amy Osborne / AFP) / RESTRICTED TO EDITORIAL USE - MANDATORY MENTION OF THE ARTIST UPON PUBLICATION - TO ILLUSTRATE THE EVENT AS SPECIFIED IN THE CAPTION

site_title: British tech sector ‘at serious risk’ after SVB collapse, warns government
summary: The British government has warned that the technology and life sciences sectors are at "serious risk" due to the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank (SVB), which manages the money of many UK businesses. Chancellor Jeremy Hunt stated that the closure poses a significant threat to these sectors, which are heavily reliant on the bank. The government is urging caution and assessing the impact of the collapse on UK businesses.

images.alt_text: Founders are warning that Silicon Valley Bank's  failure could wipe out startups around the world without government intervention.

site_title: Heavy rain in Australia triggers flood evacuations in Queensland
summary: Heavy rain in Australia's Queensland state triggered flood evacuations in the northwest, with 53 residents evacuated from the town of Burketown since heavy rain began earlier in the week. Floodwaters are still rising, and authorities are urging a full evacuation as predicted river levels peak on Sunday. This comes after two years of frequent flooding in the region due to a multi-year La Nina weather event.

images.alt_text: Remains of destroyed houses almost a month after Hurricane Ian made landfall in Fort Myers Beach in Florida.

The destroyed Pine Island Road following Hurricane Ian in Matlacha Isles, Florida, US, on Saturday, Oct. 1, 2022. Research firm Enki Holdings LLC pegs the economic cost of Hurricane Ian at $60 billion to $70 billion, based on damage to homes and infrastructure, as well as the cost of reconstruction and longer-term knock-on effects including the disruption in tourism. Photographer: Eva Marie Uzcategui/Bloomberg

site_title: Indonesian miners’ credit quality tied to thermal coal for 4 to 5 years more: Fitch
summary: Indonesian coal miners' credit quality is expected to remain stable for 4-5 years due to the continued dominance of thermal coal, despite the country's plans to phase out the fossil fuel. Analysts at Fitch Ratings say most coal companies are working on diversifying away from thermal coal, but the process will take time. The country's coal production levels are expected to remain stable or even grow moderately in the medium term to meet growing power demand from developing Asean economies. However, a decline in coal prices could negatively affect the credit profiles of coal miners.

images.alt_text: Arsjad Rasjid, president director of Indika Energy. The company has teamed up with Texas Pacific Group to establish a US$500 million fund to invest in Indonesia's green energy ecosystem.
Generic of UOB bank, at Raffles Place on Feb 23, 2023

(From left) Mr Chong Jiun Yeh, CIO, UOBAM, Mr Vana Bulbon, CEO, UOBAM Thailand, Ms Lim Suet Ling, CEO, UOBAM Malaysia and Mr Ari Adil, CEO, UOBAM Indonesia, speaking at a panel during UOB Asset Management’s Annual Investment Outlook 2023 on 28 February 2023.
The shift away from energy coal - the world's largest single source of energy-related greenhouse gas emissions - could seem somewhat less opportune for Golden Energy and Resources
Smoke and steam billows from the coal-fired power plant owned by Indonesia Power.

site_title: How Murdoch runs Fox News, in his own (often terse) words
summary: Rupert Murdoch, owner of Fox News, has revealed the inner workings of his media empire through emails and testimony in a US$1.6 billion defamation case. Murdoch, who has been involved in news stories since his journalistic days, preferred to convey his wishes in person but relied on emails during the pandemic. He used Fox News and The New York Post to pressure President Donald Trump to stop talking about voter fraud, suggesting edits to an editorial that ran on Nov 7, 2020. Murdoch also discussed strategies to make Trump a "non-person" after the 2020 presidential election, and envisioned a playbook to adopt a more neutral stance after the election.

images.alt_text: Documents in the case in Delaware state court show Rupert Murdoch and other Fox executives believed Joe Biden fairly beat Donald Trump and that the results were not in doubt.
Triangle Of Sadness, a sharp satire of the moneyed class, has earned several awards and nominations, including the Oscar for Best Picture.

FILE PHOTO: Rupert Murdoch, Executive Chairman of News Corp and 21st Century Fox, takes part as a judge during a global start up showcase at the Wall Street Journal Digital Live (WSJDLive) conference at the Montage hotel in Laguna Beach, California, October 20, 2015. REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo
The reductions are “a necessary response” amid a “surge in interest rates and persistent inflation,” News Corp chief executive officer Robert Thomson said.

site_title: SVB's demise a sign of worry, but limited contagion risk: analysts
summary: Silicon Valley Bank's (SVB) rapid collapse has sparked market concern, but analysts believe the risk of financial contagion is limited. SVB's failure is attributed to "idiosyncratic stresses" and not systemic issues affecting the banking industry. US regulators have strengthened the banking system since the 2008 financial crisis, with stricter capital requirements and regular stress tests. Analysts say the US banking sector is resilient and has ample access to liquidity, with most banks having sufficient assets to cover potential losses.

images.alt_text: Eligible depositors will be paid by the UK’s deposit-insurance fund, says the Bank of England.
A sell-off in bank shares following Silicon Valley Bank’s woes reflects worries that the ripple effects of interest-rate hikes could hurt at least the most vulnerable lenders.
SVB's attempt raise more than US$2 billion from investors to plug a hole in its balance sheet has failed.

site_title: In a NYC tower’s basement, an idea that locks pollution away forever
summary: A 30-storey NYC apartment tower, the Grand Tier, captures and converts its carbon dioxide emissions into concrete blocks, effectively locking away pollution forever. The carbon dioxide from its two giant gas boilers is cooled to a liquid and then trucked to a concrete factory in Brooklyn, where it's mixed with cement and sealed into blocks. This innovative system reduces the building's global warming emissions, providing a unique solution to NYC's pollution problem.

images.alt_text: This aerial photo taken on December 25, 2022 shows cargo ships loaded with containers berthing at Yantian Port in Shenzhen, in China's southern Guangdong province. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Drowning in email? Consider a paywall
summary: A paywall for email inboxes could reduce noise and spam, allowing individuals to regain control of their inbox. Dan Landau, a marketing executive, has been using a tool called Gated on his Gmail, which requires non-whitelisted senders to make a small donation to charity to access his inbox. Others, like Jim McKelvey, have implemented similar systems, but it's unclear if this concept will gain mainstream popularity. Seth Godin, a marketing author, argues that introducing a paywall would create an uncomfortable obligation to respond to those who paid to access his inbox, making it unlikely to become widespread.

images.alt_text: Our quest for productivity goes back several years.
Absent a four-day week, more Americans appear to be choosing to downshift by deciding to work part-time, even if full-time work is available.
Content creators including, from left, Christian Maldonado, DeAndre Brown and Laura Whaley have built large followings mining laughs from office work.

site_title: SVB CEO no longer on San Francisco Fed’s board after bank fails
summary: US Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco's board now has a vacant seat after SVB CEO Greg Becker's departure, effective March 10, following the bank's failure. Becker was a Class A director, elected by member banks, and his departure leaves a vacant seat on the nine-member board. This change occurred the same day SVB failed and was taken over by state and federal regulators.

site_title: After mega-IPO, Thailand pet food giant ITC takes aim at premium market
summary: Thailand's premium pet food giant i-Tail Corporation is opening a new cattery with 48 cats to test its premium cat food. The company, which raised 21.1 billion baht (S$817.4 million) through its initial public offering (IPO) last December, aims to ensure its food is not only healthy but also palatable. The cats, comprising well-known breeds, underwent a tough admissions process and will be paid to eat the company's products. This move follows ITC's IPO earnings, which enabled the company to invest in new facilities, automate warehouses, and increase R&D.

site_title: Crypto exhales as USDC stablecoin rebounds towards peg after being roiled by SVB exposure
summary: US stablecoin USDC, issued by Circle, rebounded towards its $1 peg after exposure to Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) caused a depeg. USDC rose to $1 and traded at 98.2 cents on Sunday, with Circle pledging to cover any shortfall of $3.3 billion held at SVB. The company reiterated its stablecoin is fully backed by $42.1 billion in cash and US Treasuries, and expressed confidence in regulatory efforts to manage the situation. Other stablecoins, including Tether, also pushed closer to their pegs, but their reserves remain intact.

images.alt_text: Silicon Valley Bank’s website calls its CEO Greg Becker a “champion of the innovation economy.”
SVB “primarily banks technology, life science, and healthcare companies and is an integral part of the venture capital ecosystem,”  says Morgan Stanley.
Circle says US$3.3 billion of its about US$40 billion of USD Coin reserves remain at Silicon Valley Bank.
Greg Becker's departure leaves a vacant seat on the San Francisco Fed's nine-member board.
Critics say the prearranged share-sale plans have significant loopholes, including that they lack mandatory cooling-off periods.
Eligible depositors will be paid by the UK’s deposit-insurance fund, says the Bank of England.
A sell-off in bank shares following Silicon Valley Bank’s woes reflects worries that the ripple effects of interest-rate hikes could hurt at least the most vulnerable lenders.

site_title: US high court asked to weigh in on trans athletes
summary: The US Supreme Court has been asked to weigh in on a case involving trans athlete Becky Pepper-Jackson, who was born a biological male but wants to join her school's female running team. West Virginia has asked the court to overturn a lower appeals court decision that froze the state's 2021 law banning trans girls from competing with other girls. The case could lead to the Supreme Court's first-ever intervention in the hot-button issue of trans girls and women in sports.

images.alt_text: The repeal of Section 377A of the Penal Code, following a 10-hour debate over two days, saw 93 MPs voting in favour of the move.
“We have not loved you as God loves you, and that is profoundly wrong,” the bishops said in an open letter to LGBTQI+ people.

site_title: Ford set to resume F-150 Lightning production next week
summary: Ford Motor plans to resume production of the F-150 Lightning electric vehicles next week, after halting output following an EV battery fire in February. The company recalled 18 vehicles due to a battery cell manufacturing defect, but found no fires or injuries. Ford will replace the affected battery packs and has confirmed the root causes of the issue with its partner SK On. Production is expected to resume on Monday with a "clean stock of battery packs."

images.alt_text: Ford will begin offering LFP batteries in its Mustang Mach-E model later this year and in its F-150 Lightning plug-in pickup truck next year.

Ford is moving ahead with the project despite uncertainty around how the US Treasury Department will interpret requirements in President Joe Biden’s signature climate package, the Inflation Reduction Act.
Ford’s revenue for the third quarter increased 10 per cent to US$39.4 billion, beating Wall Street’s projection of US$36.4 billion.
The F-150 Lightning Pro now starts at US$51,974, up 30 per cent from the original starting price of US$39,974 when the truck went on sale in May.

site_title: Hospitality S-Reits’ DPU rebound 32% in 2022
summary: Singapore's hospitality S-Reits experienced significant growth in 2022, with the median distribution per unit (DPU) increasing 0.2% year-over-year. The hospitality segment saw the highest median DPU increase of 31.6%, driven by robust performance in markets such as the US and UK. Top performers include ARA US Hospitality Trust, which saw a 760% increase in DPU, and CapitaLand Ascott Trust, which saw a 31% increase in DPU and strong operating performance.

images.alt_text: Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust’s VivoCity recorded positive rent reversion at 7.9 per cent.

site_title: From a garage to a multi-billion dollar fitness and wellness empire
summary: Italian entrepreneur Nerio Alessandri, 62, has expanded his global fitness and wellness empire, Technogym, to Singapore with its first showroom. The company, which has 50 million users worldwide, aims to capitalize on Asia's vast growth potential. Technogym, a longstanding Olympic partner, has seen double-digit growth over the last three years, with the pandemic sparking a shift towards home workouts. Alessandri is passionate about spreading the message of regular exercise, natural food, and positive mental approaches to achieve a balanced lifestyle.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
The training space at Sphere.
Technogym's Cross Personal is designed to bring luxury into home gyms.
ease, balance, easy

site_title: Regulators urged to find Silicon Valley Bank buyer as industry frets about fallout
summary: Silicon Valley Bank (SVB), a startup-focused lender, became the largest bank to fail since the 2008 financial crisis, leaving billions of dollars stranded. Regulators are urged to find a buyer to protect uninsured deposits, as financial industry executives and investors fear a domino effect on other US regional banks. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) is trying to find another bank to merge with SVB, amid market volatility and concerns over the bank's collapse.

images.alt_text: Founders are warning that Silicon Valley Bank's  failure could wipe out startups around the world without government intervention.

site_title: Meta plans new job cuts that could match last year's tally: WSJ
summary: Meta Platforms is planning additional job cuts in multiple rounds over the next few months, which could match the 13% job cut tally from last year, according to the Wall Street Journal. The cuts would be part of the company's efforts to reduce costs. Meta has not commented on the matter. This move comes after the company reported significant losses in 2022.

site_title: Hollywood's Asian stars welcome 'long overdue' breakthrough at Oscars
summary: Asian representation in Hollywood has achieved a breakthrough at the Oscars, with four Asian actors nominated in a single year for the first time. Malaysian actress Michelle Yeoh is a strong contender to become the first Asian best actress winner, while co-stars Ke Huy Quan and Stephanie Hsu, and Hong Chau are also nominated. This marks a significant milestone in representation, with only four Asian actors having ever won Oscars, and only 23 Asian actors' performances having been nominated in total. The nominations are seen as a long-overdue recognition of Asian talent in the industry.

images.alt_text: Peter Jackson’s original three "Lord of the Rings" movies grossed nearly US$3 billion at theatres, and won 17 Oscars, including best picture for 2003 trilogy finale "The Return of the King".
Triangle Of Sadness, a sharp satire of the moneyed class, has earned several awards and nominations, including the Oscar for Best Picture.

Malaysian actress Michelle Yeoh poses with the award for Best Actress - Motion Picture - Musical/Comedy for "Everything Everywhere All at Once" in the press room during the 80th annual Golden Globe Awards at The Beverly Hilton hotel in Beverly Hills, California, on January 10, 2023.

US director Steven Spielberg (centre) poses with the awards for Best Director - Motion Picture and Best Picture - Drama for "The Fabelmans" alongside Seth Rogen (2nd left), Michelle Williams (3rd right) and US actor Paul Dano (right) at the 80th annual Golden Globe Awards in Beverly Hills, California, on Jan 10, 2023.

site_title: Buybacks, director transactions resume at a lively pace
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.6% in the five trading sessions from Mar 3 to 9, with institutions net selling S$284 million worth of stocks. Institutions led the net institutional outflow for the five sessions, while companies like Genting Singapore, Sembcorp Industries, and Singapore Airlines led the net institutional inflow. There were 19 primary-listed companies conducting share buybacks, with OCBC buying 400,000 shares. In director transactions, close to 80 changes were made to director interests and substantial shareholdings, with notable transactions including AEM Holdings' EPF crossing above the 9% threshold and Wilmar International's chairman increasing his deemed interest.

images.alt_text: A man walks in front of the Singapore Exchange building (SGX) on July 21, 2022.

site_title: CPO prices expected to stay supported at RM4,000 a tonne as supply tightens
summary: Malaysia's benchmark crude palm oil prices are expected to remain stable at RM4,000 a tonne due to tight supply, according to the Malaysian Palm Oil Association. The country's palm oil production is forecast to rise to 19 million tonnes in 2023, while Indonesia's production is expected to increase to 48.3 million tonnes. The slow replanting of old oil palm trees in Malaysia, with over 500,000 hectares above 19 years old, is also constraining supply. The association warns that a potential labour shortage may impact the industry.

images.alt_text: Replanting is a big undertaking as it requires a huge investment and affects revenue for a few years.
Bunches of oil palm fruit at a collection centre for smallholders in Malaysia's Selangor state.These will be sent to a mill.
The high rainfall caused short-term disruption to harvesting operations and the evacuation of fruits, as well as poorer fruit quality.

site_title: Biden scraps Trump's paint scheme for Air Force One
summary: President Joe Biden is sticking with a classic blue-and-white color scheme for Air Force One, discarding the bold red, white, and blue design chosen by Donald Trump. The new design will feature a modern light blue tone and retain the existing robin's egg blue, with no polished metal on the fuselage. The replacement aircraft, built by Boeing, are expected to be delivered in 2027 and 2028, and will feature high-tech communication facilities and a self-defense system.

images.alt_text: When the candidates are finalised, perhaps the most likely outcome remains a rematch between Trump and Biden.
FILE PHOTO: The Boeing logo is seen on the side of a Boeing 737 MAX at the Farnborough International Airshow, in Farnborough, Britain, July 20, 2022.  REUTERS/Peter Cziborra/File Photo
President Biden has stepped up efforts to lobby Saudi Arabia and other members of Opec to increase oil production to curb high petrol prices.
US indices were slightly higher at the close of trading on Wednesday.

site_title: Meta considers divesting Kustomer as cutback efforts expand
summary: Meta is considering divesting Kustomer, a customer service software company acquired for $1 billion in 2020, as part of cost-cutting efforts. The company has not decided on a plan, but may spin off or sell Kustomer. Meta will continue to support Kustomer's product and customer base during the process. The decision follows Meta's focus on its fastest-growing business, messaging offerings, including WhatsApp. Regulatory issues from the 2020 acquisition were resolved in early 2022.

images.alt_text: The job cuts could match the tally from last year, says the Wall Street Journal.
In its earlier round of cuts, Meta slashed 11,000 workers in what was its first-ever major layoff.
Meta will face a trial over accusations that it took Neural Magic’s “breakthrough” algorithms that enable AI systems to process information more quickly, US District Judge Denise Casper said.

site_title: Who is Greg Becker, the head of failed Silicon Valley Bank?
summary: Greg Becker, the former CEO of Silicon Valley Bank, joined the company in 1993 as a loan officer and rose to become president and CEO in 2011. Becker led the bank through the dot-com bubble and the 2008 global financial crisis, but the company's operations abruptly halted on March 10, 2023, after California regulators shut it down, citing the largest bank failure since the financial crisis. Becker personally assured clients their money was safe just 24 hours before the bank's collapse, and he departed the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco's board of directors the same day.

images.alt_text: Critics say the prearranged share-sale plans have significant loopholes, including that they lack mandatory cooling-off periods.
Eligible depositors will be paid by the UK’s deposit-insurance fund, says the Bank of England.
A sell-off in bank shares following Silicon Valley Bank’s woes reflects worries that the ripple effects of interest-rate hikes could hurt at least the most vulnerable lenders.

site_title: Gold rallies on safe-haven allure as banking rout grips markets
summary: Gold prices surged nearly 2% on Friday, driven by a slide in US Treasury yields and concerns over a banking sector fallout. The price of spot gold rose to $1,863.46 per ounce, its highest since February 14. A strong US jobs report and concerns over interest rate hikes were overshadowed by safe-haven flows into gold. The rally was also fueled by a decline in US tech lender SVB's troubles, which hit banking stocks.

images.alt_text: Although gold is considered a hedge against inflation, interest rate hikes to control rising prices dims non-yielding bullion’s appeal.

site_title: Dollar weakens after US jobs data suggests slower rate hike path
summary: The US dollar weakened on Friday after February's jobs data showed slower wage growth, indicating a potential easing of inflation pressures. The data led to reduced expectations for a 50-basis point interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve, causing the dollar to slide against major currencies. Treasury yields fell, with the 10-year benchmark note yield dropping 22 basis points. The dollar may be range-bound as inflation slows towards the Fed's 2% target, with economists expecting a bumpy adjustment.

images.alt_text: The scale and pace of rising Fed rates make for uncomfortable reading for investors in developing stocks, bonds and currencies.

site_title: Chip equipment maker ASML’s suppliers eye Asia plants outside China amid tensions
summary: ASML's suppliers are considering building plants in Vietnam, Malaysia, and Singapore to reduce their exposure to China amid tensions between Beijing and the West. A dozen tech companies, mostly contractors to ASML, will visit these locations next week to explore investment opportunities. The move is part of a long-term strategy to diversify production and reduce reliance on China. The Dutch government has restricted exports to China, and ASML's advanced machines are in high demand, making Asia a key location for the industry.

images.alt_text: The Biden administration is counting on the Netherlands to help stop China from further developing its own chip industry and advancing its military capabilities.

site_title: EBay collectibles subsidiary employees approve forming a union
summary: Employees of eBay subsidiary TCGplayer, a marketplace for collectible card games, have approved forming a union with the Communications Workers of America, with over 270 employees set to join. The workers, who inspect and pack cards from an authentication center in Syracuse, New York, are seeking better pay and benefits. This marks eBay's first union, following a petition filed in January. The Communications Workers of America aims to improve working conditions and quality of life for the employees, who are part of a broader effort to organize workers in the video game and card game industries.

images.alt_text: eBay plans to lay off 500 employees globally, representing 4 per cent of its total workforce.
For the current quarter, eBay forecasts revenue between US$2.29 billion and US$2.37 billion.

site_title: How a bank run closed SVB and where that could lead
summary: Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) failed due to a funding crunch caused by rapid interest-rate increases, leading to a sharp downturn in tech companies and withdrawals from clients. The bank's deposit base was heavily concentrated in venture-backed startups, making it vulnerable to the crisis. The FDIC created a new bank to hold SVB's assets, and it is unclear if a buyer will emerge. The bank's collapse reflects broader worries about the impact of interest-rate hikes on vulnerable lenders, with analysts noting that regional banks are particularly at risk of facing funding pressure.

images.alt_text: Silicon Valley Bank headquarters in Santa Clara, California, US, on Thursday, March 9, 2023. SVB Financial Group bonds are plunging alongside its shares after the company moved to shore up capital after losses on its securities portfolio and a slowdown in funding. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg
SVB's attempt raise more than US$2 billion from investors to plug a hole in its balance sheet has failed.
SVB's stock losses have now reached 79 per cent since its surprise announcement on Wednesday that it is issuing US$2.25 billion of shares to bolster its capital position.
SVB is deeply embedded in the US startup scene, as the only publicly-traded bank focused on Silicon Valley and tech startups.

site_title: Canada parliament questions Google execs over news-blocking test
summary: Google will stop blocking news articles from some Canadian users' search results on March 16, following a test that began on February 9 and affected less than 4% of users. The test was in response to a Canadian government bill that aims to compel online platforms to pay publishers in Canada for news content. Google claims the test is like thousands of other product tests and no decisions have been made about product changes. The move follows criticism from Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, who called it a "terrible mistake" and urged Google to pay journalists instead.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on January 31, 2023 the logo of Google internet giant is seen on the opening day of the Integrated Systems Europe (ISE) audiovisual and systems integration exhibition in Barcelona. - Google parent Alphabet on February 2, 2023 reported lower revenue and profit than expected in the final three months of last year as harsh economic times cooled its ad business. (Photo by Pau BARRENA / AFP)
YouGov data shows that about 41 per cent of people in Singapore aged between 18 and 24 have used TikTok in October 2022.
Google has come under pressure in some countries to negotiate commercial deals and pay news publishers for their content, though not in Taiwan.
The idea is to teach kids about the technology, its limits and promise, and prepare them for jobs where they’ll need to use AI.

site_title: SVB chief sold US$3.6 million in stock days before bank’s failure
summary: Silicon Valley Bank's CEO, Greg Becker, sold $3.6 million of company stock under a prearranged plan just days before the bank's failure. The sale, made on February 27, was the first time Becker had sold shares in over a year. Critics argue that the plan lacks mandatory cooling-off periods, raising questions about whether Becker was aware of the bank's plans for a capital raise attempt when he filed the plan. The SEC has finalized new rules to address such loopholes, which will take effect on April 1.

images.alt_text: A sell-off in bank shares following Silicon Valley Bank’s woes reflects worries that the ripple effects of interest-rate hikes could hurt at least the most vulnerable lenders.
SVB's attempt raise more than US$2 billion from investors to plug a hole in its balance sheet has failed.
SVB's stock losses have now reached 79 per cent since its surprise announcement on Wednesday that it is issuing US$2.25 billion of shares to bolster its capital position.

site_title: SVB’s UK business to be declared insolvent by Bank of England
summary: Silicon Valley Bank's (SVB) UK unit is set to be declared insolvent by the Bank of England due to a collapse in its US parent. Eligible depositors will be paid up to £85,000 by the UK's deposit-insurance fund. The unit has a limited presence in the UK and will stop making payments or accepting deposits. The regulator believes the unit is no longer viable, citing an unsuccessful attempt to raise capital and a cash exodus from tech startups.

site_title: Fed Rate cuts in 2023 priced back in as bank worries escalate
summary: US Federal Reserve officials are reassessing interest rate hikes amid rising borrowing costs and bank failures, with swap traders now expecting the central bank's policy rate to peak at around 5.3% in June and end the year below 5%. The move comes after Fed Chair Jerome Powell's comments seemed to open the door to a re-acceleration in rate hikes, but the recent employment report and Silicon Valley Bank collapse have tempered expectations. The two-year Treasury yield fell 29 basis points to 4.58%, marking a second-straight drop, as investors await the next consumer-price inflation report.

images.alt_text: The comments support economic data that’s largely surprised to the upside so far in 2023, notably robust job growth that’s powered consumer spending.

Jerome Powell, chairman of the US Federal Reserve, had earlier warned that the central bank is prepared to increase the pace of interest rate hikes, and could raise rates higher than anticipated if necessary, sending jitters through markets.
When the Fed boosts rates, banks usually get higher lending income quickly, as the rates on the loans they’ve made reset to higher levels.

site_title: Historic drought in Argentina seen shrinking GDP by 3 points
summary: A historic drought in Argentina is expected to shrink the country's GDP by 3 percentage points in 2023, estimated at US$19 billion, according to the Rosario Grains Exchange. Crop forecasts for soybeans, corn, and wheat have been repeatedly cut back due to extremely dry conditions, affecting the nation's main grains harvests. The drought also severely impacts the government's tax revenue, with grain export taxes expected to fall by more than $2.3 billion in the 2022/2023 harvesting season.

images.alt_text: The Paso Lucero bridge is pictured as the Corriente river below is seen affected by a prolonged drought, in Corrientes, Argentina February 13, 2023. REUTERS/Sebastian Toba

site_title: Blinken to press for Ethiopia peace progress on top US visit since war
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken will visit Ethiopia and Niger to push for progress on peace talks, amid a two-year war in the Tigray region. Blinken's visit aims to refashion US engagement with Ethiopia, which has strained relations due to allegations of abuses and ethnic violence. He will meet with Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed, Tigrayan officials, and humanitarian groups to discuss a November accord that promised disarmament and restored basic services. The US has put the death toll at 500,000, with some estimates as high as 600,000, making the war one of the deadliest of the 21st century.

images.alt_text: China’s role in the Russia-Ukraine war is expected to be among the topics when Biden meets with German Chancellor Olaf Scholz at the White House on Friday.

Prime Minister of Singapore Lee Hsien Loong walks at the Welcoming Dinner during G20 Leaders' Summit, at the Garuda Wisnu Kencana Cultural Park, in Badung, Bali, Indonesia, November 15, 2022. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan/Pool
The Biden administration will probably need to focus much of its efforts in the coming months to spelling out its strategic goals vis-a-vis Russia

site_title: In search of sustainable travel
summary: South-east Asia, particularly Indonesia and Singapore, are prioritizing sustainability in their tourism industries. The Global Sustainable Tourism Council has established global standards, and consumers are driving change by prioritizing local travel experiences and sustainable tourism. Research shows 80% of Indonesian travelers prefer accommodation with sustainability practices, but measuring sustainability remains a challenge. Governments are implementing policies, such as Indonesia's aim to reduce carbon footprint and promote village tourism, and prominent businesses are committing to halve emissions by 2030 and achieve net zero by 2050. Collaborative efforts between the industry and consumers are crucial for achieving real progress in sustainable tourism.

images.alt_text: The International Civil Aviation Organization said demand will reach pre-pandemic levels on most routes by the end of the first quarter and exceed the 2019 levels by around three percent by the end of 2023.
People walking towards the Jubilee Bridge with the Central Business District (CBD) skyline on Feb 18, 2022.

site_title: USD Coin stablecoin falls further from peg on SVB exposure risk
summary: USD Coin, a stablecoin issued by Circle Internet Financial, fell to 90 US cents after investors reacted to its exposure to Silicon Valley Bank's collapse. The stablecoin, valued at $40 billion, has $3.3 billion in reserves at SVB, which failed on March 10. This exposure raised concerns about the token's ability to maintain its dollar peg, prompting investors to sell. USD Coin's value has been declining since the SVB collapse, highlighting the risks associated with asset-backed stablecoins.

images.alt_text: analysis, banking, broker

site_title: Li Qiang: China’s new premier and Xi loyalist
summary: China's new premier, Li Qiang, has been confirmed as the country's leader, succeeding Li Keqiang. Li, a loyalist to President Xi Jinping, was appointed to the seven-member Standing Committee of the Politburo last October. Despite his experience in local administration, Li lacks experience working at the central government level, raising concerns about his ability to address China's economic challenges, including a sluggish GDP growth rate and a collapsing property market. Li's loyalty to Xi is seen as a potential impediment to implementing policies, with some analysts suggesting that Xi will limit Li's scope to run the State Council.

images.alt_text: Xi taking his oath during the Third Plenary Session of the National People's Congress on Friday.

The expected appointment by China’s rubber-stamp parliament comes after Xi Jinping locked in another five years as head of the Communist Party and the military – the two more significant leadership positions in Chinese politics – in October.
Xi spent much of his first decade in power giving himself greater control over areas of policymaking that might’ve otherwise been dominated by Premier Li Keqiang, 67.
Premier Li Keqiang announced the goal for GDP in his final report to the Communist Party-controlled parliament, which kicked off its annual meeting on Sunday.

site_title: Oil prices rise after buoyant US payrolls
summary: Oil prices rose 1.5% on Friday after better-than-expected US employment data, but fell 3% for the week due to concerns over US interest rate hikes. Brent crude rose to $82.78 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose to $76.68 a barrel. The US Federal Reserve's next meeting is planned for March 21-22, with expectations of further rate hikes clouding the global growth outlook. A strengthening dollar also makes oil more expensive for holders of other currencies.

images.alt_text: Brent futures fell US$1.07, or 1.3 per cent, to settle at US$81.59 a barrel, their lowest close since Feb 22.

site_title: US job growth beats expectations in February; wages rise moderately
summary: The US economy added 311,000 jobs in February, beating expectations and suggesting that January's hiring surge was not a fluke. Average hourly earnings rose 0.2% to 4.6% year-over-year, while the unemployment rate rose to 3.6% from 3.4% in January. This increase in jobs likely means the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates for longer, despite wage inflation showing signs of cooling.

images.alt_text: Despite the jump in claims, the labour market remains robust.

site_title: Fed seen on shallower rate path as wage gains cool
summary: The Federal Reserve may consider a shallower rate hike path after a weaker-than-expected February jobs report, which showed a 0.2% wage gain and a 3.6% unemployment rate. The report suggests the pandemic-disrupted labor market is normalizing, easing inflation concerns and potentially reducing the need for aggressive rate hikes. Futures now point to a quarter-point rate hike, down from a half-point hike previously expected. Analysts say the Fed's decision will depend on the February CPI report, with a rapid rise in inflation potentially leading to a 50bps rate increase.

images.alt_text: The larger-than-expected increase in February payrolls suggest that January’s surge in hiring is not a fluke.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as bank stocks drop
summary: US stocks opened lower on Friday, March 10, 2023, as bank stocks dropped, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 69.72 points, or 0.22%, to 32,185.14. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, weighed down by concerns over future interest rate hikes from the Federal Reserve. Investors reacted to cooling February wage growth data.

site_title: Apple gets its mojo back after a shaky start to 2023
summary: Apple's stock has surged 15% in 2023, on track for its biggest quarterly gain in over a year, after concerns about demand and supply chains dissipated. The company's strong balance sheet and innovation capabilities have won over investors, with Goldman Sachs reentering the stock after almost six years of neutrality. Analysts expect Apple to continue growing, with predicted sales of $22 billion in AirPod earphones in 2024 and a 13% stock price increase over the next 12 months.

images.alt_text: Apple has created an online store to serve the region and is planning to open its first retail outlets in the country later this year.
The colour addition gives Apple a new way to market a product that went on sale about six months ago.

site_title: Europe: Banks drag shares to seven-week low
summary: European shares plummeted to a seven-week low on Friday, led by a 3.8% drop in banks, with HSBC, Deutsche Bank, and Commerzbank experiencing significant losses. The sell-off was sparked by concerns over the sector's balance sheet resilience amid rising interest rates. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed 1.4% lower and down 2.3% for the week. The European Central Bank is expected to hike its key lending rate by 50 basis points next week, adding to market uncertainty.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.2 per cent lower on Thursday after recouping some of its losses earlier in the trading session.

site_title: Belgium bans TikTok from federal government work phones
summary: Belgian Prime Minister Alexander De Croo announced that the country's federal government will ban TikTok from work phones due to concerns over data collection and potential cooperation with Chinese intelligence services. The decision follows similar bans by the European Commission and European Parliament. The Belgian national security council warned of the risks, citing the need to protect the country's information. The Flemish regional government has also restricted TikTok access on staff phones, with other regional governments urged to follow suit.

images.alt_text: “This warning is based on fundamental misconceptions about our company ownership and our data security,” a TikTok spokesperson said via email.

site_title: Mitsubishi Motors to sell only EVs, hybrids by mid-2030s
summary: Mitsubishi Motors plans to sell only electric vehicles and hybrids by the mid-2030s, aiming to have 100% of new car sales electrified by fiscal 2035. The company will roll out 16 new models over the next five years, including a battery electric vehicle (BEV) for Europe, marking its return to the market after a long absence. Mitsubishi currently has no BEVs in its lineup in Europe, where new entrants like Tesla have gained significant market share.

site_title: Macron to meet Orban for talks on Ukraine and Europe
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron is set to meet with Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban on Monday to discuss the Ukraine crisis and other issues ahead of the European Council meeting on March 23. Orban has been critical of Europe's stance on the war in Ukraine, while Macron will focus on energy issues and support for the European defense industry. The meeting comes amid tensions between Hungary and the European Union over corruption concerns and Budapest's reliance on imported Russian fuel.

images.alt_text: Strikers blocking a motorway on Thursday; polls show that a majority of voters oppose President Emmanuel Macron’s plan to delay the state pension age by two years to 64.

A Nord Stream 1 gas pipeline facility in Lubmin, Germany. The European Union agreed on Jul 26 to a major proposal to reduce the consumption of gas. This could have significant implications for European businesses and households from next month till March 2023.
Brussels is concerned about the possibility of external parties ‘dividing and ruling’ to undermine the continent’s collective interests.
The unflattering optics highlight the limits of the EU’s strategy to back tough rhetoric with action that requires unanimity among all its 27 members.

site_title: Biden administration set to further tighten chipmaking exports to China
summary: The Biden administration plans to further restrict the export of semiconductor manufacturing gear to China, potentially doubling the number of machines requiring licenses. This move aims to prevent China from developing an advanced chip industry. The restrictions, set to be announced next month, will be coordinated with the Netherlands and Japan, and US companies have been briefed on the plan. The US does not plan to water down its stance if other countries adopt weaker guidelines, and the restrictions will have significant implications for the global chipmaking industry.

images.alt_text: The Biden administration is counting on the Netherlands to help stop China from further developing its own chip industry and advancing its military capabilities.

site_title: Sysma Holdings reverses into the red with S$2.7 million H1 loss
summary: Sysma Holdings reported a net loss of S$2.7 million for the six months ended Jan 31, 2023, reversing from a net profit of S$3.1 million in the same period last year. Higher construction costs and foreign exchange losses contributed to the losses. Revenue rose 16.4% to S$29.6 million, while cost of sales and operating expenses also increased. The company expects an uncertain external environment to impact its high indebtedness and will be cautious with cash management.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Lian Beng did not give further details on the new construction project but noted that the order book will provide a sustainable flow of activity through FY2027.

site_title: Meta exploring plans for Twitter rival
summary: Meta Platforms is exploring plans to launch a new social media app, potentially rivaling Twitter, as the company seeks to capitalize on the current chaos at the Elon Musk-led platform. The app, based on the Mastodon framework, will allow creators and public figures to share timely updates, and Meta aims to take advantage of Twitter's struggles with advertising. Meta's own platforms, including Facebook and Instagram, are facing competition, and the metaverse investments show little signs of paying off in the near term, leading analysts to view this as a defensive move to secure revenue.

images.alt_text: In its earlier round of cuts, Meta slashed 11,000 workers in what was its first-ever major layoff.

site_title: Why is everyone talking about SVB? Here’s everything we know about the bank right now
summary: Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) sparked panic in the tech industry after announcing a $21 billion securities sale and a $2.25 billion share sale to shore up its finances. The bank's stock plummeted 60% and its bonds posted record declines, with prominent venture capitalists instructing portfolio businesses to limit exposure. SVB's clients include major tech startups like Pinterest and Shopify, and the bank's woes have sent ripples through the banking industry, with other major US banks also experiencing significant declines. A potential US government bailout has been proposed, but the worst-case scenario remains that SVB could suffer significant losses or be forced to wind down.

images.alt_text: Shares of Commerzbank have tumbled by more than 6 per cent following the Frankfurt stock market's opening on Friday.
Singapore shares pull back at Friday’s open on Wall Street selloff; STI down 0.6%

site_title: TikTok added to list of Internet companies with additional Pofma responsibilities
summary: TikTok has been added to Singapore's list of internet companies with additional responsibilities to combat fake news under the Protection from Online Falsehoods and Manipulation Act (Pofma). The platform, owned by ByteDance, must prevent abuse by bots, ensure online transparency for political advertising, and tag misleading information with notices. As an internet intermediary, TikTok will also have to follow three codes of practice to promote credible sources and restrict access to content from specific users. The move aims to protect the Singapore public against online falsehoods and harm.

images.alt_text: Belgian Prime Minister Alexander De Croo said the Belgian national security council had warned of the risks associated with the large amounts of data collected by TikTok.

site_title: Homebuilder Ballymore cuts dozens of jobs amid housing slump
summary: UK homebuilder Ballymore has cut 30 jobs out of 802 employees over the past three months amid the UK housing slump, as higher borrowing costs and falling house prices trigger a decline in activity. The company, which built over 9,000 homes in the UK and Ireland, had previously warned of a challenging near-term outlook for the UK. Other homebuilders, including Persimmon, Taylor Wimpey, and Vistry Group, have also predicted declining sales and job cuts in 2023. The housing market in the UK continues to experience a slowdown.

images.alt_text: House prices rose 1.1 per cent month on month, following a 0.2 per cent rise in January, Halifax said.
The potential job losses come as Britain’s property market endures a slump in activity triggered by higher mortgage rates and the threat of a house price plunge.
Britain’s largest homebuilders have already cut back their building targets as higher mortgage costs and economic uncertainty depressed buyer demand.

site_title: Xi clinches third presidential term amid host of challenges
summary: Xi Jinping secured a third five-year presidential term at the National People's Congress, unanimously voted in by nearly 3,000 parliament members. The move tightens Xi's control amid global challenges, including adversarial relations with the US and fragile economic recovery in China, which grew just 3% last year. Xi's term is seen as crucial for economic revival, but experts warn that his continued authoritarian approach may hinder success. Xi has become China's most powerful leader since Mao Zedong, with a significant role in managing the economy and the Communist Party.

images.alt_text: A manufacturing line at a factory of SMC Corporation in Beijing.
As the Communist Party of China navigates this complex landscape, it will also restructure the party and state institutions.

site_title: European bank shares sink on concerns over US sector
summary: European bank shares plummeted on Friday, March 10, following a Wall Street rout triggered by US regional lender SVB Financial's 60% stock drop. The US banks lost a combined $52 billion in market value. European banks Commerzbank, Deutsche Bank, Barclays, and HSBC also saw significant declines, with Commerzbank's shares falling over 6% and Deutsche Bank's down nearly 10%. The sell-off was attributed to SVB's struggles with falling deposits and its efforts to raise cash through a stock offering and securities sales.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index has dropped 1.4 per cent to 7,769.49 points compared with Thursday’s closing level, despite news of rebounding UK economic growth in January.
The Topix Banks Index has tumbled 5.4 per cent, the most since March 2020.

site_title: SVB exploring sale as crisis triggers global banking rout
summary: Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) is exploring a sale as a crisis triggers a global banking rout. The bank's efforts to raise capital through a stock sale failed, causing its stock to plummet 66% in premarket trading. The crisis has rippled through global markets, hitting banking stocks and causing the S&P 500 banks index to drop 4.2% and Europe's STOXX banking index to fall almost 5%. Experts say rising interest rates and the tech sector's vulnerability to inflation are exposing vulnerabilities in the market, with some banks issuing statements to reassure investors.

images.alt_text: SVB's stock losses have now reached 79 per cent since its surprise announcement on Wednesday that it is issuing US$2.25 billion of shares to bolster its capital position.
SVB is deeply embedded in the US startup scene, as the only publicly-traded bank focused on Silicon Valley and tech startups.
The Topix Banks Index has tumbled 5.4 per cent, the most since March 2020.
California-based bank SVB sold US$21 billion of its securities portfolio, which would result in an after-tax loss of US$1.8 billion for the first quarter.

site_title: US: Stocks fall on jitters about banks after mixed jobs report
summary: US stocks fell on Friday as investors worried about the health of US banks following the closure of SVB Financial Group, the largest bank failure since the financial crisis. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 1.1% and the S&P 500 lost 1.5% as the KBW regional banking index fell 3.6%. The jobs report showed the US economy added more jobs than expected, but the SVB crisis overshadowed the positive news, leading to a global market decline.

images.alt_text: A trader works on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., January 5, 2023. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly

site_title: Prolific Bryan Adams already has next album ready
summary: Bryan Adams, a veteran Canadian rocker, is set to perform in Singapore on March 13, playing hits from his 15th studio album "So Happy It Hurts" and possibly others. Adams has allocated a section of his set to accommodate fan requests, aiming to ensure everyone leaves the concert happy. With a four-decade-long career, Adams has a vast catalog of hits, including "Summer of '69," "Run to You," and "Everything I Do (I Do It for You)." His upcoming show will be part of his ongoing tour, which also includes a mini-residency at London's Royal Albert Hall.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan
Spotify announced that it surpassed 500 million monthly active users, including 205 million paying subscribers at the end 2022, with 10 million creators.

site_title: SVB shares slump again as clients threaten to pull cash
summary: SVB Financial Group shares plummeted 47% on March 10 as prominent venture capitalists advised companies to withdraw funds, citing concerns over the lender's financial health and liquidity. The stock has lost 79% since its surprise announcement on Wednesday to issue $2.25 billion in shares. Analysts cut ratings on the stock, citing accelerated deposit outflows and pressure from higher interest rates. This comes amidst a sharp sell-off in US banks, with many recommending companies limit their exposure to SVB due to increased uncertainty.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's international visitor arrivals reached a new record of 957,605 in February, driven by visitors from Indonesia, Malaysia, Australia, and South Korea. Meanwhile, OCBC and UOB customers can tap their CPF funds to buy T-bills online starting March 31 and April 22, respectively. Temasek's SeaTown invested S$150 million in a new medical group, Foundation Healthcare Holdings. The National Environment Agency signed MOUs with two international offset programmes to expand its carbon-credit whitelist. The Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) dropped 1.2% after a Wall Street rout.

site_title: The Marq sets record S$100,000 per month rental in defiance of softening in broader market
summary: A luxury apartment at The Marq in Singapore has set a record for the highest monthly rental of S$100,000, a 25% increase from the previous lease. This follows a trend of rising luxury rentals, with a bungalow on Astrid Hill achieving a monthly rent of S$170,000. Experts attribute the surge to high-net-worth foreigners setting up base in Singapore, with demand expected to remain strong in 2023. Savills Singapore expects luxury rentals to rise by 10-15% in 2023, while mid-tier and mass market segments are expected to see 5-10% growth.

images.alt_text: Rents for the condo market climbs 1.4 per cent in January from December 2022, while HDB rental prices rise 0.6 per cent from the month before, according to flash estimates from SRX and 99.co on Tuesday (Feb 28).

site_title: Temasek’s SeaTown invests S$150 million to set up medical group Foundation Healthcare
summary: Temasek's SeaTown invests S$150 million in Foundation Healthcare Holdings, a Singapore-based medical group comprising 50 medical specialists across 13 areas of expertise. The company aims to pursue a "buy-and-build" strategy to expand its network and geographical footprint, and develop a data-driven tech platform to improve coordination between stakeholders. With estimated pro forma revenue of over S$130 million, FHH is one of Singapore's largest private healthcare groups. The investment is fully in equity, with additional financing provided by three banks.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

Mount Elizabeth Hospital, which is under PLife Reit. In addition to the ongoing recycling of its nursing homes properties in Japan and the acquisition pipeline from its sponsor, the manager of PLife Reit is looking to build a “third pillar” for the next phase of growth.
Temasek's SeaTown fractionalises private capital fund, reduces investment ticket from US$5m to US$100,000

site_title: It turns out money does buy happiness, at least, up to US$500,000
summary: Researchers found that money can buy happiness, with a steady increase in contentment up to US$500,000, and acceleration beyond that. Contrary to previous studies, happiness does not plateau at US$75,000, but rather continues to rise with income. The study of 33,391 people in the US found that even the unhappiest 20% of people became happier as income increased, but the effect stopped at six figures. Overall, the emotional effect of money on happiness is small compared to other circumstances, such as time off or personal fulfillment.

images.alt_text: eat and drink, enjoyment, taste
Facing up to the shortness of our time on earth can help us focus more intently on the things that truly matter.

site_title: Climate-vulnerable nations prepare to deploy loss and damage funds
summary: Climate-vulnerable countries plan to establish national funds to help mitigate losses and damage from extreme weather events and rising seas. The funds will be sourced from various channels, including wealthy governments, businesses, insurance, and aid. The first six countries to participate are Bangladesh, Nepal, Senegal, Malawi, Trinidad and Tobago, and Vanuatu. The initiative aims to strengthen early warning systems, provide upfront funding for disaster preparedness, and support local communities in coping with climate-related losses. The move comes as countries recognize the need to help struggling communities recover from climate losses, despite the ongoing process of setting up a UN global fund for loss and damage.

site_title: Eurozone bonds rally as US bank jitters lift safe havens
summary: Eurozone government bonds rallied on Friday as US bank stocks plummeted 40% in pre-market trading, sparking a sell-off in safe-haven assets. 10-year bond yields fell over 10 basis points across the euro area, with German Bund yields reaching a two-week low of 2.48%. The rally was attributed to concerns about the strength of US banks, with the Federal Reserve expected to raise rates by 25 or 50 basis points in March. Analysts noted that the situation doesn't seem to pose systemic risks, but the market will closely monitor developments.

images.alt_text: European banks stand to benefit from a higher interest rate cycle.

site_title: China’s February credit grows faster than expected, supporting recovery
summary: China's credit growth accelerated to 9.9% in February, the highest since November 2022, supporting a nascent economic recovery amid rising global risks. The country's total social financing (TSF) grew 9.9% and broad M2 money supply expanded 12.9% year-over-year. Analysts attribute the growth to the government's lifting of pandemic curbs and other measures. However, some concerns remain, including the potential for momentum to fade and limited room for policy adjustments due to capital flight amid global economic risks.

images.alt_text: The total debt of China’s LGFVs has swelled to a record 66 trillion yuan, equivalent to half of the country’s economy.
China’s consumers are in focus as household spending is expected to drive demand in the world’s second-largest economy.

site_title: Global house prices set to extend declines, risk of more with higher rates: Reuters poll
summary: Global house prices are expected to extend their declines this year, with some markets forecast to drop by as much as 50% since the pandemic began. Rising mortgage rates and a historic house price boom during the pandemic have pushed home ownership out of reach for many prospective first-time buyers. Analysts predict drops in US, Canada, Britain, Germany, Australia, and New Zealand, with peak-to-trough declines ranging from 8% to 20%. Crimped supply and ever-rising demand have contributed to the decline, with population growth outpacing new housing supply.

images.alt_text: Realtors are pinning their hopes on the return of mainland enterprises, after the border reopening. But instead of offices, Chinese companies seem more keen on industrial buildings.
The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage rose 8 basis points to 6.79 per cent, the MBA said.

site_title: F P Journe: Ace watchmaker still curious at 65
summary: French watchmaker Francois-Paul Journe, a three-time winner of the Aiguille d'Or, continues to innovate and earn praise for his groundbreaking work at 65. His watches, now a regular presence at high-end auctions, have fetched over $1 million, rivaling those of vintage timepieces from luxury brands like Patek Philippe and Rolex. Journe's technical genius and artistic flair have made him a sought-after independent watchmaker, with over 10,000 timepieces sold in the past 20 years. Despite success, he remains committed to his craft, already working on new projects, including a revolutionary watch escapement.

images.alt_text: The S&P 500 stock index averaged annual returns of 8 per cent from August 2018 to January 2023 while a basket of pre-owned watch models from top Swiss brands grew at more than twice the pace.

site_title: OCBC, UOB customers can tap CPF funds to buy T-bills online from Mar 31 and Apr 22 respectively
summary: OCBC and UOB customers will be able to buy Treasury bills online using their Central Provident Fund (CPF) ordinary account (OA) savings from March 31 and April 22, respectively. This allows CPFIA investors to purchase T-bills online, making it the only CPFIS agent bank to offer this service. Investors must assess their financial knowledge and consider the yield of T-bills compared to CPF interest rates to avoid opportunity costs. The move aims to make T-bill purchases more accessible and convenient for investors.

Investors can use funds within their CPF OA to purchase T-bills, by opening a CPF investment account with either DBS, UOB or OCBC.
