site_title: Southern Alliance Mining expects H1 net loss on lower iron ore production
summary: Southern Alliance Mining, a Malaysia-based iron ore producer, expects a net loss for the first half of FY2023 due to decreased iron ore production and lower sales volume. The company attributed the losses to intense overburden removal activities and lower average selling prices. The financial performance details will be disclosed on Mar 17, and the company's shares closed flat at S$0.60 on the day of the announcement.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

site_title: China’s debt-laden local governments pose challenges to economic growth, financial system
summary: China's local governments, fueled by debt, pose a challenge to the country's economic growth and financial system. The total debt of local government financing vehicles (LGFVs) has reached a record 66 trillion yuan, equivalent to half of China's economy. LGFVs face increasing pressure to repay their debts, with some pushing banks to extend maturities and cut interest rates. This could impact China's modest economic growth target of 5% this year, as LGFVs play a key role in funding infrastructure projects. Defaults are feared, with some analysts predicting a collapse of LGFVs or quiet recapitalization by banks.

images.alt_text: China’s consumers are in focus as household spending is expected to drive demand in the world’s second-largest economy.

site_title: Europe: Stocks sink on global banking sell-off
summary: Europe's main stock markets plummeted on Friday, with the FTSE 100 index dropping 1.4% to 7,769.49 points, and the eurozone's DAX and CAC 40 indices also falling 1.7%. The sell-off was triggered by concerns over the global banking sector and ahead of US jobs data, with traders fearing a forecast-beating figure could prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. This follows a similar rout on Wall Street, where signs of trouble at a regional US lender sparked fears about the broader sector's stability.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 1.7 per cent to 32,254.86 on Thursday.

site_title: AIA upbeat for new sales growth this year as China’s Covid-19 curbs scrapped
summary: AIA Group, a Hong Kong-based insurer, is optimistic about new sales growth this year following China's removal of Covid-19 curbs for mainland travellers. The company's value of new business (VONB) for its China business plummeted 17.3% in 2022, but is expected to recover as visitor numbers pick up. AIA's Hong Kong business saw a 4% increase in VONB, driven by growth at its Macau branch and agency channels. The insurer declared a 5% higher final dividend, citing encouraging signs in the first two months of the year.

images.alt_text: Growth of outstanding total social financing (TSF), a broad measure of credit and liquidity in the economy, quickened to 9.9 per cent in February from a year earlier, the highest since November 2022, and rising from 9.4 per cent in January.

site_title: Indonesia’s anti-graft push tarnished by US$20 billion tax scandal
summary: Indonesia's anti-graft efforts are being tarnished by a US$20 billion tax scandal, with a state financial watchdog identifying questionable dealings at the Ministry of Finance from 2009 to 2023. President Joko Widodo's pledge to root out corruption has been undermined by the scandal, which has sparked public anger and calls for the resignation of trusted ally Sri Mulyani Indrawati. The case has raised concerns about transparency and foreign investment, with analysts warning that corruption could deter investors. An investigation is underway, but many are questioning the government's ability to tackle the issue.

images.alt_text: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin was charged with abuse of power and money laundering at a Kuala Lumpur court on Friday.
Surya Darmadi (right), the owner of Duta Palma group, was sentenced to 15 years in prison.

site_title: Girl with AI earrings sparks Dutch art controversy
summary: A Berlin-based digital creator submitted an AI-generated image of Johannes Vermeer's "Girl with a Pearl Earring" to the Mauritshuis museum in the Netherlands, which sparked controversy over whether it belongs in a museum and whether it can be considered art. The image, created using AI tool Midjourney, was chosen from over 3,400 submissions for an installation called "My Girl with a Pearl." The decision has sparked debate among artists and critics, with some calling it an "incredible insult" and others defending its inclusion as a creative process.

site_title: JGB yields fall sharply on short cover buying after BOJ maintains policy
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its ultra-low interest rates and bond yield control policy, defying expectations of a policy tweak. Japanese government bond yields fell sharply after short sellers rushed to close their positions by buying back bonds, with the 10-year bond yield dropping to 0.385% and the 368th 10-year bond yield falling to negative 0.035%. The move was attributed to investors needing to buy back bonds to close their short positions, rather than the BOJ's policy change.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man walks past the headquarters of Bank of Japan in Tokyo, Japan, January 17, 2023. REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo
The Bank of Japan maintained its short-term interest rate target at -0.1 per cent and that for the 10-year bond yield around 0 per cent at its two-day meeting that ended on Friday.

site_title: Ford to cut 1,100 jobs in Spain
summary: Ford is cutting 1,100 jobs at its Valencia, Spain plant as part of changes to its car production lineup in Europe. The layoffs are due to the company's decision to stop assembling Galaxy minivans and S-Max station wagons. This move follows Ford's previous statement that it would delay production investments in Spain, citing a revised outlook for Europe, but plans to start producing electric vehicles later this decade. The job cuts were shared with unions and will have an impact on employees, their families, and the local community.

site_title: Is there a happy ever after for cinema operators?
summary: Singapore's cinemas are emerging from the pandemic with a focus on alternative programming and premium experiences to draw back crowds. Despite attendance not yet reaching pre-pandemic levels, cinemas are optimistic about further recovery. Shaw Theatres has seen 80% of pre-Covid numbers in attendance, while Golden Village's admissions have been steadily increasing. Alternative content, such as concert screenings and e-sports events, now forms a bigger part of post-pandemic programming. Cinemas are also offering premium experiences like Imax and 3D screenings, luxurious viewing environments, and enhanced food and beverage options.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
The silver screen appears to have lost some of its appeal as a crowd puller. How does this change the way mall operators try to draw the crowds?

“The successful signing of this exchangeable bond deal indicates the confidence and belief in the strong recovery and fundamentals of our cinema business and the mm2 group in general,” said Melvin Ang, executive chairman of mm2 Asia.

A Cineworld cinema in London. The world's No. 2 cinema operator had a net debt of US$8.9 billion as at the end of 2021. Excluding lease liabilities, Cineworld’s net debt was US$4.84 billion at end-2021, and it had cash of US$354 million.

site_title: What's Manchester United’s value to private equity?
summary: Manchester United, a publicly traded English Premier League club, is valued at around £4.5 billion, according to a rejected Qatari offer. Despite posting three consecutive annual pretax losses totaling £194 million, the club has a storied history and a massive global following. Valuations vary, with a discounted cash flow analysis suggesting an enterprise value of £2.7 billion and a multivariate model estimating a value of £857 million. Private equity firms are attracted to the club's potential for turnaround and growth, but the industry's dysfunctional cost structure and underinvested stadium require significant changes to achieve profitability.

images.alt_text: Under disciplinarian Dutch manager Erik ten Hag, United appear to be on the rise and ended their long wait for silverware by beating Newcastle 2-0 in the League Cup final at Wembley.
Sky Sports and The Telegraph say the bidders will now have the opportunity to conduct due diligence on the club by accessing detailed financial information.

site_title: Nippon Yusen plans 1.2 trillion yen investment in 4 years, boosts shareholder return
summary: Nippon Yusen KK, a Japanese shipping and logistics company, plans to invest 1.2 trillion yen (S$11.9 billion) over the next four years, focusing on decarbonizing its vessels and expanding into new businesses. The company aims to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050 and has set a new dividend payout ratio goal of 30%. It will allocate 140 billion yen to mergers and acquisitions and 100 billion yen to new businesses, including offshore wind power and hydrogen. The net profit target for the year to March 2027 is set at 240 billion yen.

images.alt_text: The change in marine war insurance can affect Japan’s imports of liquefied natural gas (LNG) among other energy and commodities.

site_title: Brokers’ take: UOBKH downgrades BRC Asia to ‘hold’ on lack of near-term catalysts
summary: UOB Kay Hian downgraded BRC Asia to "hold" from "buy" due to the company's weaker 9M FY2023 outlook, citing the effects of Singapore's extended safety period measures on on-site construction activities and project timelines. The analysts slashed the target price to S$1.66 from S$2.42 and expect lower revenue and margin assumptions. Despite this, they remain positive on BRC's longer-term prospects due to its strong order book and market share dominance, and anticipate a boost from increased public Build-To-Order housing supply.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
BRC Asia noted that while Singapore’s construction industry grew by 6.5 per cent in 2022, its value-added remained 19.3 per cent below pre-pandemic levels.
BCA expects 60 per cent of construction demand to come from the public sector.
BRC Asia saw increased sales volume and higher steel prices in the year, it said in a bourse filing on Tuesday (Nov 29).
Worksite safety issues and dengue outbreaks have impacted the productivity of construction companies.
BRC Asia's revenue for Q3 2022 rose to S$515.3 million, up from S$340.2 million a year ago,

site_title: Tina – ‘there is no alternative’ – is the only Wall Street acronym that matters
summary: Tina, a Wall Street acronym meaning "there is no alternative," advises investors to stay in the market despite disappointing stock performance, as there are no better alternatives. This stance was challenged by analysts from top firms, who suggested alternatives to stocks, such as cash or other investments. However, the article concludes that Tina's philosophy remains valid, as all investments require robust long-term growth in corporate profits for good inflation-adjusted returns.

images.alt_text: Alibaba headquarters in China's eastern Zhejiang province. Fundamentals of China's new-economy sector have remained resilient, and the sector is expected to shine again.
The money that investors do put to work in the markets this year is more likely to go to passive funds than actively managed mutual funds.

site_title: Singapore’s central bank boosts gold reserves 30% in Jan
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore, boosted its gold reserves by about 30% in January, reaching 6.4 million fine troy ounces or 199 tons, valued at $4.5 billion. This is Singapore's second-largest gold purchase in one month, following a 1968 purchase of 100 tonnes. The move comes as central banks worldwide build up holdings of bullion amid weakening US dollar strength and geopolitical uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore bourse’s a sea of red on US banks’ woes
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.2% on Friday, closing at 3,177.43, due to a sell-off in Asian markets following the overnight US Wall Street rout. Two US regional banks went public with financial problems, contributing to the decline. Despite this, only two stocks, Sembcorp Industries and Wilmar International, rose 0.5% and 0.3% respectively. The STI declined 1.7% over the week, with analysts warning of potential contagion risks from US banking woes.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
HSBC lost more than two per cent in Hong Kong, as was National Australia Bank in Sydney, while Tokyo-listed Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group gave up around three percent.
Singapore shares pull back at Friday’s open on Wall Street selloff; STI down 0.6%
City Developments completes its £395 million (S$636 million) acquisition of the St Katharine Docks development in London.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 1.7 per cent to 32,254.86 on Thursday.

site_title: Ascent Bridge chief executive faces bankruptcy charges
summary: Ascent Bridge's chairman and CEO, Sun Quan, faces bankruptcy charges due to his guaranteed repayment of a loan to one of his wholly-owned companies. The application, filed on March 2, will be settled by Sun, who has informed the board of the progress. Shares of Ascent Bridge fell 10.7% to close at S$0.50 after the announcement. The company had planned to diversify into the alcoholic beverages business but will now focus on managing key-man risk for business continuity.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

site_title: European energy prices spike amid supply woes in France
summary: European energy prices surged amid supply disruptions in France, driven by worker strikes, constraints on nuclear output, and a cold blast in northern Europe. Benchmark gas futures rose 11% and power futures advanced, with French and German power futures also increasing. The strikes at energy facilities and nuclear reactors in France are expected to continue, putting pressure on the market and potentially curbing power production. Europe's fragile energy situation remains a concern, despite higher-than-normal gas inventories.

images.alt_text: Investing sustainably does not mean that investors have to settle for lower returns, says Julius Baer's Pearlyn Wong and Cheryl Tan.

site_title: Tesla taps Asian partners to address 4680 battery concerns
summary: Tesla is partnering with Asian suppliers to address production issues with its 4680 battery cells, which are crucial for its futuristic Cybertruck. The company has signed deals with China's Ningbo Ronbay New Energy and Suzhou Dongshan Precision Manufacturing to trim materials costs. LG Energy Solution and Japan's Panasonic will also supply 4680 cells, which will help augment Tesla's own output and secure future EV production. The new battery is expected to play a key role in the launch of the Cybertruck later this year, and Tesla aims to ramp up production to meet its ambitious 20 million vehicles per year by 2030.

images.alt_text: CATL has reported net income for the 12 months ended Dec 31 of 30.72 billion yuan (S$6 billion), an increase of 92.9 per cent from the previous year.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CDL, Del Monte, Sembcorp, Yangzijiang Financial
summary: CDL completes £395 million acquisition of St Katharine Docks development in London. The acquisition increases the group's total commercial assets in the UK to around £1 billion. Del Monte Pacific posted a net profit of US$9.8 million for the third quarter, down 62% year-over-year. Its shares closed flat.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

site_title: Indonesia tech firm GoTo to cut 600 more jobs
summary: Indonesia's tech firm GoTo Group announced it will cut 600 more jobs as part of its efforts to streamline the organization and boost profitability. This follows 1,300 jobs cut last year, aimed at making the company more agile and responding to market demands. The layoffs are part of a cost-management strategy, which GoTo expects will turn its adjusted Ebitda positive in the last quarter of 2023. The company will also redesign its merchant business and consolidate certain businesses and teams across the ecosystem.

site_title: British economy rebounds 0.3% in January
summary: The UK economy rebounded 0.3% in January, narrowly avoiding recession in the fourth quarter of last year. This growth was driven by the services sector, which offset poor performances in construction and manufacturing. The rebound avoided a technical recession, which is defined as two straight quarters of economic contraction. The main drivers of the growth were the return of children to classrooms, the Premier League's return to a full schedule, and strong performances from private health providers and postal services.

images.alt_text: Business investment recovered to pre-pandemic levels at the end of last year, but the BCC expects very weak spending growth of just 0.2 per cent in 2023.

site_title: Sunright narrows H1 net loss to S$1.3 million, no dividend proposed
summary: Sunright, a semiconductor company, reported a narrowed net loss of S$1.3 million for the six months ended Jan 31, 2023, compared to a net loss of S$1.5 million in the same period last year. Revenue declined 15% to S$43.8 million due to lower volume for burn-in and test services, as well as a scale-down in electronic manufacturing services. Despite this, CEO Sam Lim expects improvements in the latter part of the year driven by new product offerings for automotive devices, data centers, and cloud computing.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

From left: Atsushi Ichii, managing director of Nomura Islamic Asset Management; Ibrahim Sani, the moderator of the panel discussion, Wong Siew Hai, president of Malaysia Semiconductor Industry Association; Takeshi Kawamoto, senior equity analyst of Nomura Asset Management UK; and Leslie Yap, managing director and country manager, Nomura Asset Management Malaysia, at the launch of the Nomura Global Shariah Semiconductor Equity Fund.
On a seasonally adjusted, monthly basis, manufacturing output falls 1.1 per cent in January, reversing from an expansion in December 2022.

site_title: Schroders to set up Britain’s first new-style private asset fund
summary: Schroders, the UK's largest standalone asset manager, has received regulatory approval to set up the country's first private asset fund targeting sophisticated investors. The Long Term Asset Fund will provide access to illiquid assets such as private equity and venture capital. The fund will be marketed to defined contribution and other eligible investors, offering a new regulatory structure for illiquid assets. This marks a significant development in the UK's private asset fund market, providing investors with greater access to alternative investments.

images.alt_text: Schroders Capital has invested more than US$1 billion in over 30 transactions since the onset of Covid-19.

site_title: Bank of Japan keeps ultra-low rates at Kuroda’s final policy meeting
summary: The Bank of Japan maintained its ultra-low interest rates, keeping the short-term interest rate target at -0.1% and the 10-year bond yield around 0%, in its final policy meeting chaired by Governor Haruhiko Kuroda. This decision leaves options open ahead of a leadership transition in April, as the prolonged low interest rates have been praised for pulling the economy out of deflation but also strained bank profits and distorted market function.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man walks at the headquarters of Bank of Japan in Tokyo, Japan, January 18, 2023.   REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo

The increase in the corporate goods price index (CGPI), which measures the price companies charge each other for their goods and services, was smaller than a median market forecast for a 8.4 per cent gain and followed a 9.5 per cent rise in January.
Financial institutions globally are finding ways to trim expenses amid persistent inflation and the slowdown in dealmaking.
Upper house lawmakers okayed Kazuo Ueda’s nomination a day after their counterparts in the lower house, paving the way for the 71-year-old to take over next month.

site_title: Former Malaysian PM Muhyiddin charged with abuse of power, money laundering
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin has been charged with abuse of power and money laundering over projects launched during his premiership. He faces up to 20 years in jail and a heavy financial penalty if found guilty. The charges come ahead of crucial regional polls and are seen as a test for Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim, who has vowed to tackle corruption. Muhyiddin denied the accusations, calling them "organised political persecution", and claimed no public funds were misused during his tenure.

images.alt_text: “I myself disagree with the past decisions, which were too light when the understanding was made,” said Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim.

site_title: Bank of England to cut spending for work on climate change
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) plans to cut spending on climate change work and redirect funds to core operations, citing rising costs and inflation pressures. The decision marks a shift from the emphasis on climate change during Mark Carney's term as governor, who prioritized climate-related risks to financial stability. Climate programmes will now focus on financial stability, markets, and a digital currency, while the challenge of climate change remains one of the BOE's seven strategic priorities.

images.alt_text: “There is some price depreciation, but it’s really not much compared to how much prices on average appreciated over the last couple of years,”  said Catherine Mann, rate-setter at the Bank of England (BOE),
Governor of the Bank of England, Andrew Bailey, cautions "against suggesting either that we are done with increasing Bank Rate, or that we will inevitably need to do more.”

site_title: Asia: Markets tumble as bank worries spread from Wall Street
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Friday, following a rout on Wall Street, as concerns about regional US lenders and the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes spread. US lenders like SVB Financial Group and JP Morgan suffered hefty losses, while major banks like HSBC and National Australia Bank fell over 2% in Hong Kong and Sydney. The sell-off was fueled by fears of a forecast-beating US jobs report, which could prompt the Fed to hike rates further.

images.alt_text: The greenback maintained its strength in Asian business. It was at a more than three-month high against the sterling and a two-month high on the yen.

site_title: Shares in Chinese developer Kaisa plunge as trading resumes
summary: Chinese developer Kaisa's shares plummeted 21.43% to a record low of HK$0.66 after an 11-month trading halt was lifted following the release of long-delayed financial data. The company reported attributable losses of 7.7 billion yuan and 12.7 billion yuan for the first half of 2022 and 2021, respectively. Kaisa is in negotiations with creditors and will publish an update on restructuring negotiations in due course. The company's debt, totaling over 131 billion yuan, remains a concern for the industry still reeling from Beijing's 2020 crackdown on excessive borrowing.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A sign of the Kaisa Holdings Group is seen at the Shanghai Kaisa Financial Centre, in Shanghai, China, December 7, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo
China is also planning to relax restrictions on borrowing for property developers by dialling back the “three red lines” policy.

site_title: Aviva boosts investor payouts after profit beat
summary: Aviva, a British insurer and asset manager, announced a payout boost to investors, paying more than £5 billion since 2021. The company's final dividend for 2022 was 20.7 pence per share. This move comes after navigating a volatile year in key markets, with pressure from activist investor Cevian to boost returns. The hike in payouts is seen as a response to the strain faced by the wider insurance sector due to claims inflation and extreme weather.

site_title: Grab’s finance chief reduces stake through US$1.1 million share sale
summary: Grab's finance chief, Peter Oey, has sold US$1.1 million in shares through a US$1.1 million share sale on February 28, according to a regulatory filing. Oey and affiliated person Eve Oey sold 341,202 shares at an average price of US$3.17 through JPMorgan Securities. The sale was to cover tax obligations, and Oey remains committed to the business.

images.alt_text: Grab logo.

site_title: China Evergrande chairman’s seized Hong Kong mansion put up for sale
summary: China Evergrande Group's chairman Hui Ka Yan's Hong Kong mansion has been put up for sale by its receivers, marking the first known case of his personal assets being seized in the city. The mansion, located in the prestigious The Peak district, is one of several Evergrande assets in Hong Kong that have been seized or sold since the company defaulted on its debt in 2021. This move comes as Evergrande continues to face financial struggles and asset seizures in Hong Kong and other jurisdictions.

images.alt_text: Evergrande began one of China’s biggest debt-restructuring processes early last year but has yet to reach agreements with bondholders on the details.

site_title: Singapore tourist arrivals rise again to 957,605 in February; Chinese reopening more impactful in H2
summary: Singapore's international visitor arrivals reached 957,605 in February, setting a new record since the pandemic began. Indonesia remained the top source of tourists, followed by Malaysia, Australia, and South Korea. The increase highlights an expectation of a sustainable recovery pattern, according to industry experts. China's reopening is expected to have a more significant impact in the second half of the year, with the city-state likely to meet its target of 12-14 million visitors for the full year.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
January’s arrival numbers nudges up slightly from the 931,337 visitors recorded in the previous month.

site_title: Bitcoin set for worst week since FTX crash on regulation, rates
summary: Bitcoin has experienced its worst week since the FTX crash, with a 11% decline, amid concerns over higher interest rates and a US regulatory crackdown on crypto. The largest token fell below $20,000 for the first time since January, with smaller tokens such as Ether and Dogecoin also affected. A US bank stocks rout and the potential classification of many cryptocoins as securities have contributed to the downturn, with some analysts predicting the token will trade in the lower end of a $15,500 to $25,000 range.

images.alt_text: Silvergate bank, which closed a key crypto payments network last week, said on Wednesday it plans to liquidate.

site_title: Chinese EV competition hots up as BYD offers discounts
summary: BYD, China's leading EV seller, announced discounts on its Song Plus and Seal models, intensifying competition in the country's biggest auto market. The discounts, which follow Tesla's price cuts in January, offer 8,888 yuan and 6,888 yuan deductions from the prices for Seal and Song Plus models, respectively. The discounts are available for buyers who place orders between March 10 and March 31. This move is seen as a response to Tesla's price cuts and is likely to increase pressure on other Chinese EV manufacturers.

images.alt_text: The BYD HAN EV is displayed during an exhibition test drive as the Chinese electric-vehicle producer announces its expansion to the consumer market next year in Mexico, in Toluca, Mexico November 29, 2022. REUTERS/Toya Sarno Jordan
After wild success at home selling affordable electric cars to the masses, BYD is looking beyond China.

site_title: China’s Xi set to be handed third term as president
summary: China's rubber-stamp parliament is expected to appoint Xi Jinping as president for a third term, cementing his position as the country's most powerful leader in generations. Xi, 69, has already secured leadership positions as head of the Communist Party and military, and his reelection caps a remarkable rise from a relatively unknown party apparatchik to global superpower. The move marks a significant departure from China's previous one-man rule, as Xi has abolished term limits and will rule into his 70s, potentially for life.

images.alt_text: Employees make chips at a factory of Jiejie Semiconductor Company in Nantong, in eastern China's Jiangsu province on March 17, 2021. The “Annual Threat” report singled out China’s dominance in technology sectors including semiconductors, critical minerals, batteries, solar panels and pharmaceuticals.
Xi spent much of his first decade in power giving himself greater control over areas of policymaking that might’ve otherwise been dominated by Premier Li Keqiang, 67.
China's consumer price index (CPI) in February was 1 per cent higher than a year earlier, rising at the slowest pace since February 2022, says the National Bureau of Statistics.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open sharply lower on Friday
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.73% on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 344.96 points to 19,580.78, amid global market concerns over the banking sector. The decline was fueled by US job data release later in the day. Meanwhile, other Asian markets also dropped, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling 0.63% and the Shenzhen Composite Index losing 0.56%. The losses were attributed to global economic worries, including a potential slowdown in China's GDP growth.

site_title: China’s consumer spending shows signs of strong rebound
summary: China's consumer spending is showing signs of a strong rebound, driven by increases in eating out and travel. High-frequency indicators of spending in sectors such as restaurants and travel have shown double-digit growth from a year ago. This rebound is expected to drive demand in the world's second-largest economy, helping to offset a slump in exports. Economists forecast China's growth to exceed 5% this year, with consumer confidence and car sales also on the rise. However, investors remain cautious due to the lack of economic stimulus from officials, with the MSCI China Index dropping 2.2% on Friday.

images.alt_text: China's manufacturing sector saw its biggest improvement in activity in more than a decade in February and consumer activity climbed, the latest purchasing managers’ surveys showed.

site_title: Sea cuts more jobs at Shopee days after posting surprise profit
summary: Sea Ltd. is cutting more jobs at Shopee in Indonesia, affecting fewer than 500 full-time and contract workers in the customer service team. This comes days after the company reported a surprise first-ever quarterly profit, largely due to last year's extensive layoffs that reduced headcount by over 7,000. The move contradicts Chief Corporate Officer Wang Yanjun's statement that no major changes were expected regarding headcount. The latest cuts are seen as a setback to investors who were hopeful for a significant turnaround in the company.

site_title: With its future at stake, the Academy tries to fix the Oscars (again)
summary: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences is making significant changes to the Oscars to make the event more relevant to young people and draw a broader international audience. The changes include posting acceptance speech videos in near real-time on TikTok and Facebook, live streaming the ceremony on Disney+ in Europe, and using QR codes to direct viewers to interactive vignettes about nominees and behind-the-scenes footage. The academy also aims to increase transparency and improve its marketing efforts, partnering with social media sites like Letterboxd and hiring the Met Gala creative team to revamp the red carpet preshow.

images.alt_text: Everything Everywhere All At Once starring Michelle Yeoh is a triumph not just of Asian representation - it is also one of the most culturally astute films in recent memory,

Malaysian actress Michelle Yeoh poses with the award for Best Actress - Motion Picture - Musical/Comedy for "Everything Everywhere All at Once" in the press room during the 80th annual Golden Globe Awards at The Beverly Hilton hotel in Beverly Hills, California, on January 10, 2023.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars rebound on yen as BOJ sticks to easy policy
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars rebounded against the yen after the Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its ultra-low interest rates and stuck to its yield control policy. The Aussie hit 89.99 yen, its highest in seven weeks, while the kiwi dollar jumped 0.5% to 83.43 yen. The BOJ's decision was seen as a surprise, as markets had expected a tweak to its bond yield curve control policy. The yen retreated 0.3% to 136.55 USD, leaving the Aussie 0.3% lower against the US dollar.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan maintained its short-term interest rate target at -0.1 per cent and that for the 10-year bond yield around 0 per cent at its two-day meeting that ended on Friday.
The Reserve Bank of Australia had taken a hawkish turn in February after consumer price data for the December quarter showed core inflation climbed more than expected and became more broad-based.

site_title: Crypto bros turn back time on their Rolexes, Patek Philippes
summary: The secondary market for Rolex, Audemars Piguet, and Patek Philippe watches has experienced stability, with volumes roughly doubling last year, despite financial and geopolitical uncertainty. The most hyped names have lost 30-40% of their value since their peak a year ago. However, tentative signs of recovery suggest that prices may be stabilizing, and the market may be entering a more reasonable price range. The secondary market is vulnerable to fresh financial trauma, but if conditions remain stable, it may become easier for buyers to acquire these luxury timepieces.

images.alt_text: The S&P 500 stock index averaged annual returns of 8 per cent from August 2018 to January 2023 while a basket of pre-owned watch models from top Swiss brands grew at more than twice the pace.
Luxury watches on the secondary market declined 8 per cent in value last year, an index compiled by research platform WatchCharts found.

site_title: Silvergate bet everything on crypto, then it all evaporated
summary: Silvergate Capital, a decade-old crypto-focused bank, is closing its doors due to a decade-long crypto dream that made it a central player in the industry. The bank was under siege from short sellers, had deserted depositors, and was shunned by business partners. Despite attempts by US regulators to find crypto-investors to help shore up liquidity, a desperate round of calls failed to find a buyer. The closure marks the end of Silvergate's crypto dream, which had made it a central player in the booming industry.

images.alt_text: Silvergate bank, which closed a key crypto payments network last week, said on Wednesday it plans to liquidate.
The challenge for a crypto investor is that the FDIC, along with two other top regulators, has been publicly urging banks to beware of the sector.
The company told investors on Mar 1 that it was reviewing whether it would be able to stay in business.
“The crypto market reacted to the negative news from Silvergate Bank, with both bitcoin and ethereum down about 4.8 per cent for the week,” analysts at brokerage Bernstein said.

site_title: When civilisational models collide
summary: The Russia-Ukraine war highlights the clash between oligarchic capitalism and civil society. In Russia, oligarchic capitalism has led to corruption and state control, while Ukraine has maintained a democratic system with a strong civil society pushing back against oligarchic influence. Western countries are also grappling with oligarchic capitalism, which has compromised democracy and fueled wealth inequality. The Ukrainian example offers a model for confronting these challenges, with civil society leaders advocating for anti-corruption efforts and reforms to dismantle oligarchic capitalism's financial structures. Ultimately, the conflict between these two models is also about the future of Western democracies.

images.alt_text: Most people did not want to be passive recipients of government benefits; rather, they wanted the social power to earn (and hence to deserve) their slice of the growing pie.
The sales and especially the market value of Elon Musk's companies depend at least in part on the strength of his personal brand.

site_title: Why is a day job seen as the mark of an artist’s failure?
summary: Many artists have day jobs, contrary to the myth that only successful artists can create. The exhibition "Day Jobs" at the Blanton Museum of Art in Texas showcases 38 artists who worked in various jobs, from painters to curators, while developing their art. The show highlights how these day jobs influenced their techniques, subjects, and inspiration, challenging the idea of spontaneous artistic genius. Artists like Jeff Koons, Andy Warhol, and Violette Bule, who still work in their day jobs, emphasize the value of experience and coming into contact with different people in their art. The exhibition aims to recognize and protect the relationship between artwork and day jobs, dispelling the notion that artists must suffer and starve to be great.

images.alt_text: It is easier for creators to connect directly with consumers today, but eking out a living is still a conundrum.
Visitors tour the exhibits during a VIP preview of the ART SG art fair in Singapore.

site_title: Ex-Goldman banker sentenced to 10 years in 1MDB scandal
summary: A US judge sentenced former Goldman Sachs banker Roger Ng to 10 years in prison for his role in the 1MDB bribery scandal. Ng was found guilty in a New York jury trial in April 2022 following testimony from co-conspirator Tim Leissner. The Department of Justice will determine a forfeiture amount later.

images.alt_text: Roger Ng and his former Goldman boss, Tim Leissner, were accused of conspiring with Malaysian financier Jho Low, the scheme’s alleged mastermind.
“I myself disagree with the past decisions, which were too light when the understanding was made,” said Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim.

site_title: Japanese bank stocks slide most in three years on BOJ policy, SVB concern
summary: Japanese bank stocks plummeted 5.4% on the Topix Banks Index, the largest decline in three years, due to the Bank of Japan's decision to maintain its easy-money policy and concerns over US tech lender SVB Financial Group's capital position. Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group fell 6.1%, while peers Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group and Mizuho Financial Group dropped 5%. Investors are selling to take profit after the recent run-up in bank shares, with the yen weakening and Japanese bond yields falling, as the BOJ's continued easing means ultra-low interest rates will persist.

site_title: Japan Airlines scraps 6,600 yen promo fares after demand crashes website
summary: Japan Airlines scrapped its "JAL Smiles" campaign after demand for discounted domestic flights crashed its website. The airline initially offered one-way tickets at a flat rate of ¥6,600 (S$65) for adults and ¥4,950 yen for children from April to June. Due to the overwhelming demand, Japan Airlines canceled the promotional sale, citing the impact on other customers and lack of restoration at this time. This move comes as travel demand in Japan is expected to increase with the government planning to downgrade Covid to seasonal influenza in May.

images.alt_text: A Japan Airlines Ltd. aircraft at Hong Kong International Airport in Hong Kong, China, on Friday, Feb. 17, 2023. A scarcity of workers in the air industry is hobbling Hong Kong's efforts to reestablish the international links vital for its role as a financial hub. Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg

site_title: Financial markets go down the rabbit hole
summary: The US Federal Reserve's yield curve has inverted, with two-year Treasury yields above 5% and 10-year yields barely moving, sparking concerns of a deep recession. Investors believe Fed Chair Jerome Powell will follow in Paul Volcker's footsteps and unleash a recession, citing historical models that show an inversion of the yield curve precedes every recession since the mid-1950s. However, there is no conclusive evidence of this, and regulators are monitoring speculative positioning and generational cognitive bias, which may be contributing to the inversion pattern.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - MARCH 08: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange during morning trading on March 08, 2023 in New York City. Stocks opened slightly higher after falling at the closing of the market on Tuesday amid Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell telling Congress that interest rates will likely continue to go higher as the Fed fights persistent inflation.   Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Michael M. Santiago / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

“The latest economic data have come in stronger than expected, which suggests that the ultimate level of interest rates is likely to be higher than previously anticipated,” Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell said.
In 2023, investment-grade firms have sold US$8.6 billion of the bonds known as “three-year non-call one bonds,” or 3NC1s.
Investor demand for high-quality debt is not being scared off by higher European Central Bank rate expectations.

site_title: NEA grows potential whitelist of carbon credits with new MOUs
summary: The National Environment Agency (NEA) of Singapore has signed Memoranda of Understanding (MOUs) with the American Carbon Registry (ACR) and the Architecture for REDD+ Transactions (ART), expanding its whitelist of carbon-credit certifiers and issuers. The new additions allow Singapore-based companies to acquire eligible high-quality carbon credits to offset up to 5% of their taxable emissions from 2024. The MOUs detail cooperation between NEA and the two providers to facilitate the purchase and retirement of ACR and ART-issued credits, providing more options for Singapore companies to offset their emissions.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu said the Singapore Government is aware of The Guardian’s report on rainforest credits issued by Verra, and the response and clarification issued by Verra.

Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu said the eligibility criteria for international carbon credits will “minimally reference” the Corsia standards for now, given that the carbon market is nascent and growing.
The programme will focus on sea level rise, water resource and flood management, biodiversity and food security, human health and energy and science-policy translation.

site_title: Move over, stablecoin – a new token is coming
summary: A new type of token, deposit tokens, is emerging as a potential game-changer in the world of digital cash. By tokenizing bank deposits, these digital assets can be traded on public blockchains, reducing the need for traditional stablecoins and central bank digital currencies (CBDCs). Deposit tokens offer a middle ground, sitting between sovereign liabilities and stablecoins, and could potentially eliminate settlement risks in cross-border payments. With the potential to reduce costs by 80% and settlement times by 80%, deposit tokens may outperform CBDCs and stablecoins in the future, according to a joint report by Oliver Wyman and JPMorgan's Onyx digital platform.

images.alt_text: The central bank has said it does not see a compelling use case for retail central bank digital currencies (CBDCs), as electronic payments in Singapore are already pervasive.

The development of various digital currencies over the past few years implies a need for digital representations of money, and it is the job of the central banks to meet this need, said Agustin Carstens, general manager of BIS.

site_title: Japan parliament approves new central bank chief
summary: The Japanese parliament has approved the nomination of Kazuo Ueda as the country's new central bank chief, paving the way for his 71-year-old appointment next month. Ueda, an economics professor, was chosen after a decade of monetary easing by outgoing chief Haruhiko Kuroda. The Bank of Japan is expected to leave its policy unchanged, with speculation about possible tweaks, including a widening of the 10-year government bond rate band, but most observers expect no surprises. Ueda's appointment comes as inflation in Japan hit 4.2% in January, driven by higher fuel costs, and Kuroda has resisted tightening despite peers in other economies hiking rates.

images.alt_text: Weaker private spending was the main factor behind the revision, rising less than initial estimates.

The increase in the corporate goods price index (CGPI), which measures the price companies charge each other for their goods and services, was smaller than a median market forecast for a 8.4 per cent gain and followed a 9.5 per cent rise in January.

site_title: Singapore shares pull back at Friday’s open on Wall Street selloff; STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore shares declined 0.6% at Friday's open, following a Wall Street retreat amid concerns over the financial sector. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 19.78 points to 3,194.73, with losers outnumbering gainers 112 to 22. Trading volume reached 54.3 million securities worth S$77.1 million. The market's decline was likely influenced by the recent US stock market selloff.

In a report, CGS-CIMB wrote that the Singapore market is a “safe harbour” and encouraged investors to stay nimble amid near-term market volatility driven by data.

site_title: UK high speed rail line faces two-year delay
summary: The UK government has announced a two-year delay to construction on part of the HS2 high-speed railway, connecting London with cities in the north of England, as part of cost-saving measures. The line running into central London will also be delayed. The project, expected to cost over £100 billion, will be built in stages and is funded mostly by the state. The delay is attributed to the need to reduce costs, with Transport Minister Mark Harper stating that it is part of the project's cost-saving measures.

images.alt_text: However, homeowners are being forced to sell up below their asking prices after a calming from the frenetic pace of the property market post-pandemic.
Britain has a target to reach net zero emissions by 2050.

site_title: Oil prices slip 1% to two-week low on recession worries
summary: Oil prices dropped 1% to a two-week low due to recession worries stemming from the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes to control inflation. Higher interest rates increase consumer borrowing costs, potentially slowing the economy and reducing future oil demand. The US central bank's actions have sparked fears of a possible recession, leading to decreased oil prices.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures were down 63 cents, or 0.8 per cent, to US$82.66 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures slipped 92 cents, or 1.2 per cent, to US$76.66 a barrel.

site_title: UK mulls easing visa policy amid labour shortages
summary: The UK government is considering easing visa policies to address labour shortages in the hospitality, road haulage, and agriculture sectors, which have been hit hard by Brexit and Covid-19. The current points-based immigration model adopted after Brexit has prioritized domestic workers, leading to labour shortages. The government aims to balance the need for skilled talent with the need to support the domestic workforce.

images.alt_text: Empty shelves at a Sainsbury supermarket in east London., Feb 24, 2023. Some UK supermarkets have introduced limits on customer purchases of some fruit and vegetables due to "sourcing challenges" blamed on weather conditions in southern Europe and north Africa, the industry said.
The part of the line running into central London would also be delayed, as part of cost-saving measures, Transport Minister Mark Harper said.

site_title: Japan’s wholesale inflation slows for 2nd month in February
summary: Japan's wholesale inflation slowed for the second month in February, with a 8.2% year-on-year increase in corporate goods prices. This marks a decrease from the 9.5% rise in January and is below market forecasts of an 8.4% gain. The slowdown in wholesale price increases suggests that the impact of past raw material cost spikes is fading, potentially leading to a moderation in consumer inflation, which is currently running at double Japan's 2% target.

site_title: Malaysia PM appoints Goldman Sachs critic to lead 1MDB taskforce
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim appointed Johari Abdul Ghani, a Goldman Sachs critic, to lead a task force to resolve 1MDB scandal matters. Anwar agreed with criticism Johari raised on the government's settlement deal with Goldman Sachs, stating the final sum was too low and that Goldman profited from Malaysia's hardship. This move aims to address the multi-billion dollar 1MDB scandal and increase accountability for the government's role.

site_title: US dollar holds near three-month high as rates reality kicks in
summary: The US dollar index held near a three-month high, driven by Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's message that interest rates will likely rise higher and faster than anticipated. The dollar eased 0.1% to 105.44, while the euro and sterling edged up. China's unexpectedly low inflation data weakened the yuan, and the Bank of Canada held interest rates steady, signaling a pause in monetary tightening.

images.alt_text: Higher rates benefit the US dollar by improving its yield and as traders look for safety while global stock markets drop.

site_title: No Signboard controlling shareholder GuGong argues termination of agreements unlawful
summary: No Signboard Holdings received a letter from controlling shareholder GuGong stating that the company's unilateral termination of agreements is unlawful and in breach of contracts. The company disputes these allegations and intends to defend itself "vigorously." GuGong's lawyers claim the termination is invalid, but No Signboard maintains its actions are lawful. The dispute may lead to further action.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

Expediting the completion of the proposed investment will allow the company to utilise the full investment amount to settle its liabilities upon completion to meet its working capital requirements for the next 18 months, said the company.

site_title: JPMorgan sues former executive over Jeffrey Epstein links
summary: JPMorgan Chase has filed a lawsuit against former executive Jes Staley, alleging he aided Jeffrey Epstein's sex-trafficking scheme. The US Virgin Islands and an unnamed victim, Jane Doe 1, claim JPMorgan provided Epstein with financial services while knowing about his activities. Staley worked at JPMorgan from 1979 to 2013 and is now facing a lawsuit. The bank is seeking damages for the alleged involvement in Epstein's crimes.

images.alt_text: Women-powered private firms in Asia, including unicorn Airwallex, a payments company co-founded by Lucy Liu, ranked first on list compiled by JP Morgan Private Bank and Ernst & Young.

site_title: Hyundai Motor in talks to sell Russia plant to Kazakhstan
summary: Hyundai Motor is in talks to sell its manufacturing plant in Russia to a Kazakhstan company, with negotiations in the final stage. The plant in St. Petersburg, which produces about 4% of Hyundai's global production capacity, was suspended operations last March due to sanctions and equipment shortages. A deal could be signed as early as June, according to a report. This move comes as many factories in Russia have suspended production due to the ongoing conflict in Ukraine.

site_title: Biden unveils US$6.9 trillion budget, setting up showdown with GOP
summary: US President Joe Biden unveiled a $6.9 trillion budget proposal, setting up a showdown with congressional Republicans over the debt ceiling and government funding. The proposal includes new taxes on the wealthy and corporations to bolster the social safety net, but is unlikely to be accepted by the Republican-controlled House of Representatives. Biden challenged Republican House Speaker Kevin McCarthy to detail his own plan, sparking a likely confrontation over the budget.

images.alt_text: Biden's budget proposal  is an attempt to advance a narrative that the president is committed to investing in US manufacturing, fighting corporate profiteering, reducing budget deficits and fending off conservative attacks on safety-net programmes.
When the candidates are finalised, perhaps the most likely outcome remains a rematch between Trump and Biden.

site_title: Tightening by central banks not about to end, says MAS’ Ravi Menon
summary: Singapore's central bank chief, Ravi Menon, says expectations that monetary policy tightening will end soon or be eased are "excessively optimistic." Menon notes that inflation appears to have hit its peak, but there are still "some ways to go" before rates can be relaxed. The trajectory of interest rates depends on the inflation outlook and monetary policy response, making it difficult to predict when tightening will end. Menon's comments come as interest rates have slowed in recent months, but central banks are unlikely to ease policy soon.

images.alt_text: Core inflation is expected to remain high in the coming months, providing room for further monetary policy tightening, economists say.
Economists barely change 2023 forecasts for Singapore’s growth, inflation: survey

site_title: US jobless claims jump to 211,000; led by New York, California
summary: US jobless claims rose to 211,000 in the week ended March 4, surpassing economists' forecasts. The jump was driven by spikes in California and New York, and may have been influenced by severe weather and school breaks. Despite the increase, the labour market remains robust, with solid hiring and demand for workers reported in recent weeks. The Federal Reserve may consider faster interest rate hikes if the jobless claims data supports it.

images.alt_text: Tech companies from Microsoft and Google-parent Alphabet to PayPal have cut thousands of jobs this year in an effort to curb spending and protect margins amid an uncertain economic outlook.

site_title: Europe: Shares dragged lower by real estate, rate hike worries
summary: European shares declined 0.2% on Thursday, weighed down by a 3.2% drop in the real estate sector, which hit two-month lows. Shares in Germany's LEG Immobilien plummeted 11.4% after suspending its dividend. Investors grew concerned about prolonged interest rate hikes, fueling worries about the sector's performance. The Stoxx 600 index recovered some losses in the trading session but ultimately closed lower.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 1.7 per cent to 32,254.86 on Thursday.

site_title: Startup lender Silicon Valley Bank to sell stock to cope with cash burn
summary: California-based bank Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) plans to sell $1.75 billion in shares to shore up its balance sheet amid declining deposits from startups struggling with venture capital funding drought. The sale, which includes a $500 million deal with private equity firm General Atlantic, will result in an after-tax loss of $1.8 billion for the first quarter. SVB's shares slid 36% in early trading, their lowest in nearly three years, as the bank forecasts a mid-thirties percentage decline in net interest income this year.

site_title: Jan-Feb US job cuts hit highest since 2009: report
summary: US companies announced over 180,000 job cuts in January and February, the highest since 2009. The technology sector accounted for more than a third of the cuts, with 77,770 layoffs in February alone. Retail and financial sectors also saw significant job losses. The job cuts are attributed to companies' efforts to curb spending and protect margins amid an uncertain economic outlook. Despite the layoffs, some tech companies have seen significant share gains, with Alphabet, Microsoft, and Amazon rising 6-54% this year.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on August 17, 2022 A "We Are Hiring" sign is posted in front of a restaurant in Los Angeles, California. - Hiring in the US economy slowed slightly in September, as expected, while the jobless rate ticked back down to the same level as July, the government reported on October 7, 2022. (Photo by Frederic J. BROWN / AFP)

site_title: BMW profits soar in 2022 despite supply chain woes
summary: BMW reported a 49% increase in annual profits to 18.6 billion euros in 2022, driven by higher prices for luxury models and the consolidation of its Chinese joint venture BBA. Group revenues rose 28% to 142.6 billion euros, beating analyst expectations. Despite delivering 2.4 million vehicles, a 4.8% decline from the previous year, BMW's fully electric vehicles saw sales more than double to 215,752 units. The company attributed its solid figures to improved pricing and demand for electrified vehicles.

images.alt_text: A Mini Cooper SE electric automobile at the BMW Mini final assembly plant near Oxford in 2019. BMW's investment in the plant, including a grant from the UK government, will secure its future production plans, said the Sky News report.

site_title: Hybrid work: Seven issues boards should consider
summary: Hybrid work, a flexible arrangement blending in-office, remote, and on-the-go employment, is here to stay, but organisations face uncertainty in implementing effective management and leadership systems. Key considerations for boards include monitoring workforce well-being, ensuring data protection, promoting diversity and inclusion, and tracking the carbon neutral footprint. Additionally, boards must assess the impact of hybrid work on corporate governance, leadership capability, and rigid real estate. To address these issues, boards should build strategies and capabilities to strengthen corporate governance, provide resources and training, and seize opportunities to build a loyal, engaged, and high-performance workforce.

site_title: US: Stocks fall as banking shares tumble
summary: US stocks fell on Thursday as banking shares tumbled due to concerns over regional banks, particularly SVB Financial Group's $1.8 billion loss and Silvergate's shutdown. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 1.7%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined. Analysts attributed the market movements to a "flight to safety" amid worries about the financial sector. Investors are cautious ahead of the government jobs report, which will be scrutinized for its implications for monetary policy.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 78.43 points, or 0.24 per cent, at the open to 32,876.83.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher ahead of payrolls data
summary: US stocks opened higher on March 9, 2023, ahead of a key payrolls report that could influence the Federal Reserve's monetary policy path. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 78.43 points, or 0.24%, to 32,876.83. This easing of rate-hike jitters was partly due to a greater-than-expected rise in weekly jobless claims. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, with gains of 6.65 and 2.30 points, respectively. The outcome of the payrolls report will determine the Fed's future policy decisions.

site_title: Singapore keen to facilitate US-China dialogue amid tensions
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong expressed willingness to facilitate dialogue between the US and China amid growing tensions, citing the detrimental effects on the global economy. The city-state relies heavily on trade with China and wants to foster a collaborative relationship. Gan emphasized the need for a stable and constructive relationship between the two superpowers to avoid negative consequences for the world.

site_title: Dubai housing boom shows no sign of slowing as prices jump again
summary: Dubai's property market continues to boom, with average annual rent for villas and apartments increasing by 26% and 28% respectively to reach 295,436 dirhams and 99,737 dirhams. The average sale price for villas rose 14% and apartment prices rose 11% through February. Despite a surge in prices, investors and developers remain optimistic, with 43.9% more transactions in February, driven by new projects and off-plan sales. The government's handling of the pandemic and liberal visa policies are attracting more foreign buyers, particularly from Russia and Israel.

site_title: Del Monte posts 62% drop in Q3 net profit due to increased interest expense
summary: Del Monte Pacific posted a 62% drop in Q3 net profit to US$9.8 million due to increased interest expense from higher bank loans and redemption of preference shares. Despite a 3.3% increase in turnover to US$681.2 million, gross margin fell 93 basis points to 19.9% due to inflationary pressures and commodity headwinds. The group's US subsidiary, Del Monte Foods, saw sales rise 5.8% to US$495.7 million.

site_title: Malaysia needs to invest US$375 billion in renewables to reach 2050 climate goals
summary: Malaysia aims to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050, but the country needs to invest at least US$375 billion in renewable energy to meet its climate goals. Currently, the nation generates only 1% of its electricity from renewable sources, with fossil fuels contributing the majority. To reach net-zero emissions, Malaysia must double its renewable energy investments and adopt solar, wind, and green hydrogen technologies, which could reduce energy-related emissions by up to 60%. This investment is expected to save the country US$9-13 billion annually in avoided costs.

site_title: JD sales rise 7% after Chinese online shopping stays resilient
summary: JD.com reported a 7% rise in quarterly revenue to 295.4 billion yuan (S$57.3 billion) despite China's economic downturn, beating analysts' projections. The company's net income was 3 billion yuan, in line with estimates. JD largely avoided the impact of China's 2020 and 2021 crackdown on internet companies, unlike rival Alibaba, which reported a 2.1% revenue rise in the same period. JD's shares are down 19% this year, reflecting lingering uncertainty about regulators' objectives and increased competition in Chinese online commerce.

site_title: Sembcorp launches digital platform for trading renewable energy certificates in Brazil
summary: Sembcorp Industries' digital platform, GoNetZero, has launched for trading Brazil International Renewable Energy Certificates (I-REC) in partnership with Instituto Totum. The move aims to streamline the process for renewable energy generators to sell their I-REC certificates, increasing liquidity and access to buyers. Brazil is now the world's second-largest I-REC market, with 22 million certificates issued in 2022, equivalent to powering four million households in Singapore for a year. This expansion is expected to provide faster speed to market and convenient access to GoNetZero's global network of buyers.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
UOBKH, Maybank and DBS continue to rate Sembcorp at “buy”, while CGS-CIMB maintains its “add” call on the stock.

site_title: 2023 Ferrari Purosangue review: High horse
summary: The 2023 Ferrari Purosangue is the brand's first SUV, boasting a V12 engine and 725 horsepower. Despite its bulk, the car delivers Ferrari magic through its suspension and active shock absorber system, providing a smooth and engaging ride. The Purosangue's unique features include a twin-cockpit layout, a rear-hinged door, and ventilated front seats with a massage function. While some may question its worth as a Ferrari, the car has already become a hit, with a waiting list for the $2 million vehicle. Its high-performance capabilities make it an ideal choice for long-distance driving.

site_title: Yangzijiang Financial signs MOU with ADDX to distribute funds
summary: Yangzijiang Financial Holding signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with private market exchange ADDX to distribute funds on its platform. The MOU aims to broaden Yangzijiang Financial's reach and boost its total assets under management. ADDX's platform will serve as an additional distribution channel for funds, including the Yangzijiang Maritime Private Equity Fund #2, which has secured US$500 million in capital commitments. The partnership utilizes blockchain and smart contract technology to reduce manual interventions and increase investor access to private markets.

site_title: Credit Suisse cuts most of Japan investment banking headcount: sources
summary: Credit Suisse has cut most of its investment banking division headcount in Japan, reducing staff by nearly half in a two-phase restructuring. The move is part of the bank's global overhaul amid heavy losses and scandals threatening its survival. Credit Suisse stated that its global franchise will continue to work with clients in Japan, as it has done for many years, despite the reduction in staff.

site_title: Tesla supplier CATL smashes profit estimate as electric vehicle sales soar
summary: China's Contemporary Amperex Technology Co Ltd (CATL) reported a 92.9% increase in net income to 30.72 billion yuan (S$6 billion) for the 12 months ended December 31, beating analyst estimates. The company's revenue rose 152% to 328.6 billion yuan, driven by strong demand for electric vehicles. CATL's dominance in the global battery market for EVs remains, with a 37% share of the market. The company faces intensifying competition, but analysts remain optimistic about its position due to lower costs.

images.alt_text: China's President Xi Jinping says he's "both happy and worried" about CATL's position as No 1 battery maker globally because of it comes with risks.

site_title: DBS cuts financed emissions in key sectors, but misses decarbonisation targets for shipping, steel
summary: DBS Bank reported its first sustainability report, revealing it lowered financed emissions in most key sectors in 2022, mostly on track to meet its decarbonisation goals. The bank's financed emissions for the oil and gas sector decreased by 7.8% to 35.6 metric tons of carbon dioxide equivalent, meeting its target of a 28% cut by the end of the decade. However, DBS missed decarbonisation targets for shipping and steel, with emissions intensity above recommended targets due to the addition of financed vessels with shorter trading routes.

site_title: How to maximise storage in a one-bedroom home? Put it all in one big box
summary: A Singaporean designer, Yen Poh, collaborated with principal architect William Ng to transform her 42 sq m one-bedroom apartment into "The Timber Box," a utilitarian core that maximizes storage and living space. The design features a continuous loop of spaces, including a shoe cabinet, kitchen cabinet, full-height wardrobe, and bathroom, all contained within a wooden box-like structure. The project aimed to create a sense of flexibility and flow, while also addressing storage and privacy concerns. The result is a cohesive and seamless interior that balances functionality with aesthetic appeal.

images.alt_text: The facade is a collage of features and openings, while the boundary wall and side gate are made of perforated sheets that provide visual connectivity to the street.

site_title: Biden will release dead-on-arrival budget, picking fight with GOP
summary: US President Joe Biden is set to release a budget proposal that will likely clash with Republicans over the size of the federal government. The proposal aims to reduce budget deficits by nearly $3 trillion, largely through tax increases on companies and high earners, while investing in US manufacturing, fighting climate change, and supporting high-tech factory jobs. Republicans will propose a starkly different budget, focusing on cuts to federal health programs and aid to the poor, in an effort to eliminate the budget deficit within a decade without raising taxes.

images.alt_text: When the candidates are finalised, perhaps the most likely outcome remains a rematch between Trump and Biden.

site_title: China’s Feb new yuan loans seen falling from record high: Reuters poll
summary: China's new yuan loans are expected to fall in February from a record high in January due to seasonal factors and the central bank's accommodative policy to support the slowing economy. Chinese banks are estimated to have issued 1.50 trillion yuan in net new loans last month, down sharply from 4.90 trillion yuan in January. The central bank has told some banks to slow the pace of lending to contain risks. China aims to achieve a modest economic growth target of around 5% this year, down from 3% last year, amid a tentative recovery from Covid-19 disruption and weaker demand abroad.

Although details have yet to be revealed, the announcement indicates Beijing is shifting its financial regulatory system to a “twin peaks” model similar to that adopted by countries such as the United Kingdom and Australia.

site_title: Frontier countries to suffer most if Fed rate hits 6%: analysts
summary: US Federal Reserve interest rates may rise as high as 6%, posing a significant risk to emerging markets, particularly frontier countries. Analysts predict that a 6% Fed rate could weaken currencies such as India's rupee, China's yuan, and the Philippine peso by up to 5%. This would exacerbate existing economic challenges for developing countries, potentially leading to increased interest-rate volatility and a decline in emerging-market assets.

site_title: Aniba - New restaurant hidden in CBD holds the key to globally-influenced Tel Aviv cooking
summary: Aniba, a Tel Aviv-inspired restaurant in Singapore's CBD, offers globally-influenced Israeli cuisine with a modern twist. Located on the 5th floor of 6 Battery Road, accessible only by private lift, the restaurant boasts a vibrant atmosphere. Chef Meir Adoni's menu features dishes such as smoked trout donuts, crispy fatayer, and halibut de Paris, with prices ranging from S$13 to S$89. While the restaurant lacks a waterproofing system and service, its food is solid, and the unique flavors will sustain diners. Rating: 7.

site_title: ECB to test banks for cyber resilience: supervisory chief
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) plans to test the cyber resilience of eurozone banks, following a significant increase in cyberattacks, including after Russia's invasion of Ukraine. ECB supervisory chief Andrea Enria announced the thematic stress test on cyber resilience, set to launch in 2024, to assess how banks respond to and recover from successful cyberattacks. The test aims to identify vulnerabilities in banks' critical IT infrastructure and mitigate risks, particularly given the potential for sanctions to cut off banks from counterparties.
