site_title: UK online job adverts rise by 4% in early March: ONS
summary: The number of online job adverts in the UK rose 4% in early March, but remains 20% lower than the same period last year. A shortage of workers has intensified, with 27% of businesses with 10 staff reporting shortages in late February. The Bank of England is monitoring the labour market for signs of inflationary pressure. Meanwhile, other economic indicators, such as consumer confidence and business surveys, show improvement, easing recession worries.

site_title: US clean energy ‘carrots’ could put Europe behind in decarbonisation race, execs say
summary: The US Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) has sparked concerns that it may hinder the European Union's (EU) energy transition by luring away investment and talent with billions of dollars in clean energy incentives. US Energy Secretary Jennifer Granholm challenged EU allies to follow the US lead by providing more subsidies, while European energy companies echoed the call for a shift from "stick" to "carrot" policies. The IRA has already attracted over 100 companies to invest in the US, with European companies like Repsol and TotalEnergies planning to spend significant amounts on US projects.

site_title: Britain lacks strategy to meet decarbonised power target: advisers
summary: The UK lacks a clear strategy to meet its target of decarbonizing its electricity system by 2035, threatening efforts to boost energy security. The Committee on Climate Change reports that reforms are needed to planning, consenting, and connecting new renewable projects. The UK aims to generate 70% of electricity from renewable sources, with nuclear and low-carbon back-up generation accounting for the remaining 30%. The government must provide essential details on investment and infrastructure to achieve the goal.

images.alt_text: Rishi Sunak’s government started a review in February to focus on how to approve new projects faster, with recommendations due in spring.
Britain pledged to become carbon net zero by 2050, but announced plans earlier this year to drill for more North Sea fossil fuels as it seeks to secure energy independence and axe Russian imports.

site_title: SPH Media responds on recent senior hires, outlines approach towards talent
summary: SPH Media has hired 21 people for senior leadership roles since its formation in December 2021. Of these, three came directly from Accenture, while another three had experience at Accenture. The remaining 15 were from other organizations. In response to public comments, SPH Media emphasized its approach of hiring individuals with different perspectives, skills, and experience to augment its talent pool. The company stated that every staff member is valuable regardless of their background or tenure.

images.alt_text: The bond-free scholarship, funded by the SPH Foundation, was set up in 2006 under the suggestion of the late Lim Kim San.

site_title: Rental model seen as the go-to-market strategy to boost Vietnam’s EV take-up
summary: Vietnam's richest man, Pham Nhat Vuong, has established a three trillion dong electric-vehicle rental and taxi company, GSM Green and Smart Mobility JSC, to boost the country's EV adoption. The company plans to use 10,000 electric cars and 100,000 motorbikes provided by VinFast. AhaMove, a logistics firm, has already introduced 150 VinFast electric motorbikes in Da Nang, with plans to rent 1,500 EVs this year. Other startups, such as Selex Motors and Dat Bike, are also investing in EVs, with Selex Motors selling 100 e-scooters and Dat Bike closing a US$8 million funding round. The Vietnamese government has set a target to switch to green vehicles by 2050, with a national action programme in place to support the transition.

images.alt_text: Oyika offers single-use, weekly and monthly packages for electric motorbike riders to swap their motorbike batteries at a “swap station”.
“This is our special offer to VinFast customers for the VF 8 City Edition models in order to stay competitive with other brands,” VinFast said in a statement.

site_title: As US primary election race heats up, Trump v Biden rematch remains firmly on the cards
summary: US presidential primary elections are heating up, with a potential rematch between Donald Trump and Joe Biden as the most likely outcome. Trump's bid for the Republican nomination is gaining momentum, with Florida Governor Ron DeSantis seen as a strong contender. However, Trump's divisive tactics and history of legal issues may hurt his party's chances. Meanwhile, Biden faces pressure to drop out of the race despite recent stumbles, with Vice-President Kamala Harris emerging as a potential alternative. The upcoming election is expected to test American democracy and could lead to divided government, posing risks to the global economy.

images.alt_text: Biden's budget proposal  is an attempt to advance a narrative that the president is committed to investing in US manufacturing, fighting corporate profiteering, reducing budget deficits and fending off conservative attacks on safety-net programmes.

Florida Governor Ron DeSantis answers questions from the media in the Florida Cabinet following his State of the State address during a joint session of the Senate and House of Representatives, March 7, 2023, at the Capitol in Tallahassee, Florida. - DeSantis positioned himself Tuesday as the leading Republican alternative to White House candidate Donald Trump, launching a legislative session that offers red meat for the ex-president's base as the party's rising star weighs his own 2024 campaign. (Photo by CHENEY ORR / AFP)

US Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Chairman Mark Warner talks to reporters while introducing the Restrict Act at the US Capitol on March 07, 2023 in Washington, DC. in reaction to software built in countries hostile to the United States, including China's TikTok.
Under pressure from the Republican's Trumpist and isolationist wing, House Speaker Kevin McCarthy has insisted that his party won’t give the Biden Administration a “blank cheque”

site_title: Art event invites you to spend an afternoon with artists in their spaces
summary: A unique art event, Walk Walk Don't Run, allows visitors to spend an afternoon with artists in their studios, fostering casual conversations about art and design. Organized by independent art space Grey Projects, the event features over 30 creatives and collectives opening their studio spaces for the public. Unlike traditional art fairs, Walk Walk Don't Run offers a more relaxed atmosphere, encouraging meaningful discussions between artists and visitors. The event aims to promote non-profit spaces and provide a platform for artists to share their work and perspectives.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Dance work Abyss choreographed by Hyerim Jang is one of the highlights of SIFA 2023.
The Dhaka Art Summit opened with a riotous dance conceived by Miet Warlop titled Chant For Hope, an upbeat piece for a post-pandemic future.
Vicky Krieps is magisterial as Empress Elisabeth in Corsage.

site_title: Singapore stocks drop 0.4% in tandem with most Apac markets
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 0.4% to 3,214.51 points on March 9, 2023, in line with most Asian-Pacific markets. The market volatility was driven by data and anticipation of the US Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hike. Nine out of 30 STI components stocks rose, led by Emperador's 1% gain, while three were flat and 18 declined.

images.alt_text: Helge Muenkel , Chief Sustainability Officer, DBS
Tay Peck Gek

site_title: French pension strikes continue to disrupt power output, fuel supplies
summary: French pension strikes continued to disrupt power output and fuel supplies, with 8.2 GW of electricity production reduced due to the strike. Fuel deliveries from refineries were also halted, affecting 7% of French refuelling stations. Despite the disruptions, there is no supply problem for service stations, and the situation is improving. Opinion polls show a majority of voters oppose President Emmanuel Macron's plan to delay the state pension age by two years to 64. The government argues the policy change is essential to ensure the pension system's financial stability.

images.alt_text: Public transport operator RATP says that most metro and suburban rail services in Paris will be severely restricted on Tuesday.

site_title: Philippines greenlights more than 100 infrastructure projects
summary: The Philippines has approved 123 new infrastructure projects worth 9 trillion pesos (S$220.5 billion) under President Ferdinand Marcos Jr.'s administration. Unlike previous administrations, Marcos prefers to use private capital to fund infrastructure projects, with 45 funded through public-private partnerships. The projects include improvements to physical connectivity, water infrastructure, digital connectivity, and others. Marcos aims to grow the economy by 8% and halve the poverty rate to 9% by 2028, with infrastructure playing a key role in achieving these goals.

site_title: How Everything Everywhere All At Once captures the zeitgeist
summary: Everything Everywhere All At Once, starring Michelle Yeoh, is a culturally astute film that captures the zeitgeist, addressing current concerns such as Asian representation, immigration, and social issues. The movie, a multiverse sci-fi picture, is a triumph of representation and a happy, optimistic film for a world coming out of a pandemic. With its broad themes and pop culture references, it is a deserving winner in any film contest, and its writers, Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, have distilled life's purpose into a question of hope and resilience, making it a singular triumph.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Vicky Krieps is magisterial as Empress Elisabeth in Corsage.
Cate Blanchett is a force of nature playing a famous conductor in Tar, though the film itself is highly problematic.

site_title: 😁 Can we have a four-day work week, please?
summary: Singapore companies are unlikely to adopt a four-day work week due to practical concerns such as extra costs and potential compromise on work quality. Industry experts warn that a shorter workweek may lead to increased pressure on workers, reduced productivity, and difficulties in meeting daily services requirements. However, some argue that long-term workplace flexibility is more important than the number of workdays, and employees can advocate for flexible arrangements by discussing their needs with managers and framing it as a win-win for both employers and staff.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim

site_title: Sri Lanka to announce debt restructuring strategy in April: central bank chief
summary: Sri Lanka aims to announce a debt restructuring strategy in April as part of its plan to meet medium-to-long-term debt targets. The country has secured financing assurances from major bilateral creditors, including India and China, paving the way for an International Monetary Fund (IMF) bailout review in six months. The IMF has approved a $2.9 billion, four-year bailout package, and Sri Lanka will expedite negotiations with commercial creditors to finalize debt restructuring terms. The goal is to restore debt sustainability over a 10-year period.

images.alt_text: A view from the observation deck of the Chinese-built Lotus Tower in Colombo, Sri Lanka's executive and judicial capital.

site_title: Rolex, Patek investment beats S&P gains over five years
summary: Over a five-year period, the value of pre-owned Rolex, Patek Philippe, and Audemars Piguet watches increased by an average of 20% annually, outperforming the S&P 500 stock index's 8% average returns. The secondary luxury watch market, worth $24 billion in 2022, is expected to grow 9% a year to $35 billion by 2026, potentially surpassing the primary retail market by 2033, according to a Boston Consulting Group report.

images.alt_text: “You see supply going up significantly for models that we would literally have killed for just a couple of months before.” said Arjen van de Vall, CEO of Watchfinder.
Luxury watches on the secondary market declined 8 per cent in value last year, an index compiled by research platform WatchCharts found.

site_title: Eurozone bond yields in touching distance of multi-year highs, eyes on data
summary: Eurozone bond yields reached near multi-year highs as investors expect interest rates to rise and stay higher than expected. The Federal Reserve's Jerome Powell hinted at potentially faster rate hikes, while European Central Bank rate expectations continue to rise. Germany's 10-year yield rose to 2.678%, its highest level since 2011, and the country's two-year yield reached 3.385%, its highest since the 2008 financial crisis. The ECB is expected to raise rates by 50 basis points this month, with a 90% chance of another 50 basis point rise at the next meeting.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The euro sign is photographed in front of the former head quarter of the European Central Bank in Frankfurt, Germany, April 9, 2019. Picture is taken on slow shutter speed while the camera was moved.  REUTERS/Kai Pfaffenbach/File Photo

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: A five-room unit at The Pinnacle @ Duxton in Singapore sold for S$1.34 million in February, the highest transacted price of the month. HDB resale prices remained steady in February, ending a 31-month price increase. DBS chief executive Piyush Gupta's annual salary rose 13.2% to S$15.4 million in 2022, while CDL completed a £395 million acquisition of St Katharine Docks in London. Singapore stocks dropped 0.4% on March 9, following a similar trend in Asia-Pacific markets.

site_title: 7-Eleven Japan operator rises on report it’ll close unprofitable stores
summary: Seven & I Holdings, Japan's largest convenience-store operator, plans to close around one out of four Ito-Yokado stores, reducing the number to 93 over the next three years. The move is in response to pressure from activist investor ValueAct Capital Management to streamline the business. The company will focus on core food and convenience-store operations, and rent out clothing floorspace at remaining Ito-Yokado stores. This comes after a 16% year-to-date gain in the company's shares, which have risen 4.1% following the announcement.

site_title: Venezuelan liquor cocuy is winning awards, but producers face hurdles
summary: Venezuelan liquor cocuy, made from agave, is gaining international recognition after winning top prizes at recent competitions. The drink's unique flavor sets it apart from tequila and mezcal, and its producers face challenges in increasing output due to limited wild crops and a labor-intensive production process. Despite this, cocuy producers are exploring opportunities to export their product, citing potential economic benefits for the country. However, mass production is hindered by lack of financing for crop development research and limited land availability, making exports difficult.

site_title: Nomura cuts entertainment budget as rising costs hurt profit
summary: Nomura Holdings cut its entertainment budget for executives by about 30% for the current fiscal year, following weak earnings in the first half. The move aims to rein in costs as the firm steps up efforts to restore profit growth. This decision is part of Nomura's broader cost-cutting measures, including reviewing expenses at its retail business and letting go of senior investment bankers. The move is seen as a temporary measure to control discretionary expenses, with the goal of revitalizing business and attracting new clients.

images.alt_text: A sign is lit up outside a Nomura Securities Co. branch in the Shinjuku district of Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, April 23, 2009.  Nomura Holdings Inc., Japan's largest brokerage, is expected to announce earnings today. Photographer: Kimimasa Mayama/Bloomberg News
Nomura’s wholesale division logged a pretax loss of 1.9 billion yen, its first loss since the April-June quarter of 2021.

site_title: DBS chief Piyush Gupta’s annual salary rises 13.2% to S$15.4 million in 2022
summary: DBS Group CEO Piyush Gupta's annual salary increased by 13.2% to S$15.4 million in 2022, following the bank's record-breaking earnings for the year. Gupta's remuneration includes a salary base of S$1.5 million, a cash bonus of S$5.8 million, and deferred remuneration totaling S$8 million. The bank reported record net profits for the full year, with earnings rising 20% to S$8.2 billion.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Norges Bank Investment Management is voting down poorly structured pay packages, said CEO Nicolai Tangen.
The move will mark a sea change for Singapore, where a culture of silence on pay and competition concerns mean disclosures are often sparse.
Chief executives at 13 STI companies receive higher remuneration in 2021
DBS chief Piyush Gupta's 2021 annual salary jumps 48% to S$13.6m

site_title: Surbana Jurong names Aecom’s Sean Chiao as new group CEO
summary: Surbana Jurong Group has appointed Sean Chiao as its new group CEO, effective April 1, 2023. Chiao brings over 35 years of experience in design and engineering consulting, most recently as global business line CEO of Aecom's Buildings + Places division. He succeeds Wong Heang Fine, who retired on September 30, 2022. Chiao aims to drive Surbana Jurong into a global platform and tackle the climate emergency.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Sean Chiao is appointed group CEO of Surbana Jurong with effect from Apr 1, 2023.

Prior to his appointment, Seah worked for infrastructure consultanct group Surbana Jurong in a number of leadership roles, including managing director of Surbana Technologies as well as senior director of the group’s executive office, among others.
Surbana Jurong eyes larger slice of Indonesia's trillion-dollar renewable energy sector
CMIA, Surbana to develop US$1.1b food-tech township in Vietnam
Surbana Jurong Group CEO Wong Heang Fine to retire, successor search underway

site_title: Thai mall builder Central Pattana scouts for acquisitions as it lines up more mega projects
summary: Thai mall builder Central Pattana is scouting for acquisitions as it embarks on a 135 billion baht (S$5.2 billion) expansion plan, aiming to increase net leasable retail area by 17% and hotel rooms by eightfold. The company, which operates Central World, Bangkok's largest shopping mall complex, is open to acquiring assets that fit its strategy of housing retail, residential, and office spaces at a single location. Central Pattana plans to transfer assets to real estate investment trusts to raise funds for expansion, and is considering investments in Malaysia and Vietnam.

images.alt_text: Headline inflation dropped to its lowest rate in 13 months of 3.79 per cent in February.
Cryptocurrencies have gained popularity in Thailand in recent years after the country’s Securities Exchange Commission began regulating digital assets.

site_title: Malaysia maintains 2.75% rate amid cooling inflation and economic growth
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara, maintained its benchmark interest rate at 2.75% for a second consecutive meeting, amid cooling inflation and economic growth. Analysts expect this to be the final cycle of rate hikes, with some predicting another 25 basis point increase in May to avert potential high inflation and household debt. The central bank said the current rate remains accommodative and supportive of economic growth, but will continue to monitor cost factors and inflation.

images.alt_text: BNM’s policy stance has been in line with that of other Asian central banks.
The central bank has also increased its ability to defend the currency from volatility as foreign reserves rebounded from a two-year low reached in October.

site_title: Asia: Markets fluctuate with nervous eye on US jobs data
summary: Asian markets fluctuated on Thursday ahead of US jobs data, with Hong Kong and Shanghai falling, while Tokyo, Sydney, and Jakarta rose. Federal Reserve boss Jerome Powell warned of possible interest rate hikes if the US economy doesn't show signs of slowing, fueling recession fears. Markets have been falling since February due to forecast-beating indicators, and bond markets suggest a contraction is on the cards. The US non-farm payrolls figures for February are expected to put pressure on the Fed to hike interest rates, with some predicting rates could reach 6% from 4.5-4.75%.

images.alt_text: The greenback maintained its strength in Asian business. It was at a more than three-month high against the sterling and a two-month high on the yen.

site_title: Shein, Temu in fierce fight over US market for US$10 dresses
summary: Shein, a fast-fashion retailer, is in a legal battle with its rival Temu over deceptive marketing tactics in the US market. Shein accuses Temu of contracting social media influencers to make false statements about Shein, potentially damaging its brand and sales. The case could have implications for US consumers and other online retailers with Chinese suppliers. Shein is also set to raise $2 billion in funding and pursue a US listing later this year.

images.alt_text: Shein already dominates the US fast-fashion market, far surpassing rivals Zara and H&M.
Shein taps on technology across its operations, giving it cost savings and lower overheads said Leonard Lin, country general manager, Singapore, Shein.

site_title: Britain’s property surveyors see improvement in housing market
summary: UK property surveyors report a slowdown in the housing market, with house prices declining in February. Despite this, surveyors see tentative signs of improvement, with buyer enquiries moderating and new sale listings increasing. Homeowners are selling properties below asking prices, with 60% of respondents saying prices were agreed at below the asking price for properties under £500,000. The market is adjusting to tighter lending climate and mortgage affordability remains a challenge, according to the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors.

images.alt_text: Business investment recovered to pre-pandemic levels at the end of last year, but the BCC expects very weak spending growth of just 0.2 per cent in 2023.
No Crypto ATMs operators are registered with the FCA, which means any operating here breach British anti-money laundering regulations.

site_title: Ex-Goldman banker Ng raises mental health before 1MDB sentencing
summary: Roger Ng, a former Goldman Sachs banker, is set to be sentenced in a US court on Thursday, March 9, for his role in the 1MDB scandal. Ng, 51, was convicted in April and claims to suffer from chronic post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), which his lawyer argues would be exacerbated by further incarceration. Prosecutors, however, have urged a lengthy sentence, citing Ng's key role in the conspiracy to loot billions of dollars from the Malaysian fund. Ng's lawyer argues that he has already served significant punishment, including six months in a Malaysian prison and four years of house arrest, and deserves leniency.

images.alt_text: Tim Leissner is Goldman's former South-east Asia head, who conspired with financier Jho Low along with Roger Ng.
Roger Ng was convicted by a federal jury in April of three felony counts, including conspiring to violate US anti-bribery laws and conspiring to launder money.
A federal jury in Brooklyn convicts Ng in April of conspiring to violate an anti-bribery law and commit money laundering.

site_title: China consumer inflation slowest in a year, leaves room for more stimulus
summary: China's consumer price index (CPI) rose 1% in February, the slowest pace since 2022, as consumers remained cautious despite the abandonment of pandemic controls. This has left room for the government to launch more monetary easing policies to support economic recovery. However, economists generally expect no big monetary policy moves this year, and inflation is expected to strengthen in the coming months. The government's growth target is set at around 5% for 2023, and the yuan weakened on the news, revived investors' doubts about the pace of recovery.

images.alt_text: The Biden administration is counting on the Netherlands to help stop China from further developing its own chip industry and advancing its military capabilities.

site_title: Japan’s economy narrowly avoids a recession in fragile recovery
summary: Japan's economy narrowly avoided a recession in the fourth quarter, with GDP growing at an annualized 0.1% due to weaker-than-expected consumption. The main factor behind the revision was a downward revision in private spending, which rose less than initial estimates. The ongoing weakness in the economy supports the central bank's view that Japan needs help from easy monetary policy, and analysts predict a gradual recovery despite factors such as elevated inflation and a global economic slowdown.

images.alt_text: Inflation-adjusted real wages in Japan, a barometer of households’ purchasing power, fell by 4.1 per cent in January from a year earlier, the largest decrease since May 2014.
Kishida has proposed the Asia Zero Emission Community, with the aim of sharing the philosophy of promoting decarbonisation in Asian nations.

site_title: China’s financial shake-up shows policymakers’ growing focus on stability, risk
summary: China has unveiled a sweeping overhaul of its financial regulatory system, shifting towards a "twin peaks" model to prioritize financial stability and curb risk. The new system will include a national financial regulator overseeing all sectors apart from securities, with the State Council directly under the regulator. The reforms aim to strengthen central government control, streamline processes, and promote de-risking for local governments and financial institutions. Analysts see the changes as a significant step towards maintaining stability and reducing debt, particularly with 60 trillion yuan in hidden local government debt.

images.alt_text: Staff at regulators including the central bank, the foreign exchange regulator, the new authority and the securities watchdog will be paid on par with the nation’s public servants.

A sculpture of bulls in the Lujiazui business district in Shanghai, China. The enlarged national financial regulatory authority will absorb the country's banking and insurance watchdog and oversee the financial sector.

site_title: Bitcoin at three-week low as Silvergate fallout weighs on crypto
summary: Bitcoin fell to a three-week low, dropping 1.9% to around $21,780, amid the collapse of crypto-friendly bank Silvergate Capital and concerns over higher central bank interest rates. The US lender plans to liquidate, adding to the volatility in the crypto sector. Investors are also digesting the likelihood of higher borrowing costs, which bodes ill for riskier investments like virtual coins. Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell reiterated his message of taking rates higher to combat inflation.

images.alt_text: The challenge for a crypto investor is that the FDIC, along with two other top regulators, has been publicly urging banks to beware of the sector.
The company told investors on Mar 1 that it was reviewing whether it would be able to stay in business.

Silvergate was hit hard by crypto exchange FTX’s implosion, revealing in January that a surge in withdrawals by clients forced it to sell billions of dollars worth of assets and take steps to stabilise its balance sheet.

site_title: UK economy seen sputtering below pre-pandemic levels until 2024
summary: The UK economy is expected to avoid a recession this year, but will not recover to pre-pandemic levels until the final quarter of 2024, according to the British Chambers of Commerce (BCC). Business investment recovered to pre-pandemic levels at the end of 2022, but spending growth is expected to be weak at 0.2% in 2023. The economy is forecast to shrink 0.3% this year, with interest rates rising to 4.25% before falling to 3.25% by 2025. The BCC urges the government to encourage business investment to avoid the UK being "left behind" by competitors.

images.alt_text: The UK cannot match the funds but has outlined plans to increase private sector investment in green technologies of the future.
HSBC barred customers from making crypto purchases via its credit cards from last month.

site_title: CDL completes £395 million acquisition of St Katharine Docks development
summary: CDL completes £395 million acquisition of St Katharine Docks development in London, increasing its total commercial assets in the UK to around £1 billion. The 23-acre mixed-use estate features over 500,000 sq ft of Grade A office and retail space, with an occupancy rate of 90% and a weighted average unexpired lease term of 8.2 years. The deal enhances CDL's recurring income stream and reinforces its long-term investment in the UK economy.

site_title: Fragrance Group founder’s privatisation offer for Global Dragon turns unconditional
summary: Fragrance Group's founder Koh Wee Meng's voluntary cash conditional offer to take Global Dragon private at S$0.12 per share has been declared unconditional after 30.36% of shares were accepted. The offer now values Global Dragon at S$81.8 million. The deal was initially set to close on March 24 but has been extended to April 7. The offeror and its concert parties now hold 90.96% of the company's issued shares, up from 84.17% before the offer.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
No married deals were recorded in early trade.
Koh first acquired a 51 per cent stake in the company, then known as TMC Education, through JK Global Assets in 2017.

site_title: Sias meets Golden Energy, asks for exit offer to be ‘raised considerably’
summary: Sias, a Securities Investors Association (Singapore), has urged Golden Energy & Resources (Gear) to raise its exit offer price from S$0.16 per share, citing concerns from minority shareholders. The current offer price is deemed too low, undervaluing Gear's stake in Australia-listed Stanmore Resources. Gear officials cited limited financing options and regulatory hurdles, including approvals in Indonesia and Singapore, as reasons for the low offer price. Sias plans to organize a dialogue session between Gear's board and shareholders to facilitate open communication and transparency.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
The shift away from energy coal - the world's largest single source of energy-related greenhouse gas emissions - could seem somewhat less opportune for Golden Energy and Resources

Golden Energy and Resources had on Nov 9 sounded its intention to give shareholders an option of cash, or a combination of cash and shares, to delist from SGX.
The series of proposals come as Gear seeks to reduce its exposure to energy coal by shifting away from its existing energy coal business currently conducted by Gems through the proposed distribution.

site_title: China Evergrande races court deadline on debt restructuring terms: sources
summary: China Evergrande Group is racing against time to unveil debt restructuring terms before a court hearing on March 20, aiming to seek another adjournment. The company, with over $300 billion in liabilities, has been trying to reach agreements with major offshore bondholders on terms including debt-to-equity swaps. Evergrande has made some compromises, but a mismatch in expectations remains, with bondholders pushing for better terms and more of chairman Hui Ka Yan's own money to repay debt.

site_title: No near-term refinancing risks for Cromwell E-Reit after loan rollover, new lender commitments
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust's wholly-owned subsidiary has restated a term loan facility by rolling over existing loans initially maturing in November 2023, securing 70.6 million euros in new commitments. The amended terms include an "accordion feature" allowing the Reit to increase the facility size up to 110 million euros. This move eliminates near-term refinancing risks for the Reit, with a final maturity date of 3.5 years from its first utilised date. Sustainability-linked key performance indicators will be set and measured annually, promoting environmental sustainability.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Simon Garing, chief executive of Cromwell E-Reit's manager, believes the Reit’s income growth will be supported by high occupancy, rising market rents and indexation.
The Reit's latest valuation represents a drop of 1.6 per cent from June last year, as the Reit’s assets in most countries’ saw a valuation decline.

site_title: SGX sees greater demand for capital raising by businesses expanding into S-E Asia
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) sees a surge in demand for capital raising by businesses expanding into South-east Asia, driven by the implementation of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) in 2022. The exchange is attracting international companies, particularly those from China and South-east Asia, to list on its platform, with 40% of listed companies being foreign companies. SGX is also witnessing a trend of companies issuing bonds, including green bonds, to align with sustainability goals. The exchange is strengthening its ties with China, having signed a wide-ranging agreement in 2020, and is exploring opportunities for collaboration and financial linkages with other exchanges in the region.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

Country Garden's Fengming Haishang residential development in Shanghai. The company focuses on the more challenging tier-3 and tier-4 cities. Its large scale and and uncertain outlook shows the limitations of policy support.

site_title: Credit Suisse delays annual report after last-minute call from SEC
summary: Credit Suisse has delayed publication of its annual report after a last-minute call from the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) raised questions about its earlier financial statements. The bank cited the need to understand the SEC's comments regarding technical assessments of previously disclosed revisions. The 2022 financial results are not impacted, but the delay does not help investor sentiment and rebuilding trust. Credit Suisse shares fell 3.2% in pre-market activity.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse Securities (China), the company’s China joint venture, recently obtained an investment consultancy licence.
Total assets at Credit Suisse’s wealth division fell to 540.5 billion Swiss francs by the end of last year from 742.6 billion francs a year earlier.

site_title: Preview these early launch show-stoppers ahead of Watches & Wonders 2023
summary: Several luxury watch brands, including Vacheron Constantin, Audemars Piguet, and Officine Panerai, are releasing new timepieces ahead of Watches & Wonders 2023. Vacheron Constantin's Overseas Chronograph features a long-awaited panda dial design, praised by reviewers as the "best-ever interpretation" of the chronograph models. Audemars Piguet's Royal Oak Offshore Selfwinding Chronograph boasts a black ceramic case and in-house automatic chronograph movement. Officine Panerai's Luminor Quaranta Razer Special Edition combines high-end horology with gaming aesthetics. IWC's Portugieser Automatic 40 features a striking salmon-colored dial and is priced at S$11,000.

images.alt_text: Bell & Ross’ founders Bruno Belamich (left) and Carlos Rosillo (right) were in Kuala Lumpur for the launch of the BR-X5, the sportier successor to the BR 05.

site_title: UK urged to keep up with US and EU in race for green energy
summary: The UK is set to miss its goal for a net-zero emissions power system by 2035 due to the government's lack of urgency in approving new projects, according to the Committee on Climate Change. The country's outdated policy and cumbersome planning process are delaying the infrastructure needed to electrify the country quickly, making it struggle to compete with other countries like the US and EU in the green energy race. The UK's review of new project approvals is due in spring, but critics warn that the government must respond to the EU and US in order to catch up.

images.alt_text: Business investment recovered to pre-pandemic levels at the end of last year, but the BCC expects very weak spending growth of just 0.2 per cent in 2023.
However, homeowners are being forced to sell up below their asking prices after a calming from the frenetic pace of the property market post-pandemic.

site_title: Nissan says new powertrains may cut hybrid costs by up to 30%
summary: Nissan is developing new modular powertrains that could cut hybrid costs by up to 30%. The company unveiled blueprints for two new powertrains, one for E-power hybrids and another for zero-emission vehicles. Nissan aims to lower hybrid car costs to the same level as petrol-powered cars by 2026, with production expected to start as early as 2024. The company also emphasizes the need for reliable, affordable batteries, citing the development of solid-state batteries as a key factor in the transition to electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: A Nissan dealership in Richmond, California.
FILE PHOTO: The logos of car manufacturers Nissan and Renault are seen in front of dealerships of the companies in Etampes, near Paris, France, January 26, 2023. REUTERS/Sarah Meyssonnier/File Photo
Nissan will raise Europe to the same level of importance as Japan, China and the US after gaining market share in the region in recent years.

site_title: China’s new premier steps into role stripped of its former power
summary: China's new premier, Li Keqiang, has taken office with a diminished role, stripped of former power by President Xi Jinping's efforts to consolidate control. Li's predecessor, also Li Keqiang, had been a key figure in economic reform and policy-making, but Xi has shifted power to the party, creating party committees to oversee key areas. Li's close ties to Xi and his past loyalty to the president's Covid Zero strategy raise questions about his ability to soften Xi's policies. The new premier will inherit a more Xi-centric policymaking approach, with his role limited to implementing the president's ambitions.

images.alt_text: Employees make chips at a factory of Jiejie Semiconductor Company in Nantong, in eastern China's Jiangsu province on March 17, 2021. The “Annual Threat” report singled out China’s dominance in technology sectors including semiconductors, critical minerals, batteries, solar panels and pharmaceuticals.
The Biden administration is counting on the Netherlands to help stop China from further developing its own chip industry and advancing its military capabilities.

Amphibious armoured vehicles under China's People's Liberation Army taking part in a training exercise in Fujian province, China August 14, 2022. cnsphoto via REUTERS   ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY. CHINA OUT./File Photo
Staff at regulators including the central bank, the foreign exchange regulator, the new authority and the securities watchdog will be paid on par with the nation’s public servants.

site_title: How SMEs can protect themselves against cyberattacks
summary: Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are increasingly targeted by cyberattacks, despite their relatively small size and limited financial resources. Threat actors view SMEs as a gateway to larger corporations, and their vulnerability to social engineering tactics makes them a prime target. To protect themselves, SMEs can adopt a "zero trust" model, which verifies every access request, and implement multi-factor authentication, such as two-factor or multi-factor authentication. Additionally, SMEs should prioritize cybereducation, seek financial support, and consider cyber insurance to mitigate the financial impact of a cyberattack.

images.alt_text: The demand for tech talent beyond the Information and Communication sector is strong, particularly in roles such as cybersecurity and artificial intelligence.
The emergence of chatbots and AI-powered tools presents new challenges in cybersecurity, especially when the technology ends up in the wrong hands.

site_title: Former Malaysia PM Muhyiddin arrested, to face multiple graft charges
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin has been arrested and charged with multiple corruption allegations, including abuse of power and money laundering. The charges stem from investigations into government projects approved during his 2020-2021 tenure, including COVID-19 relief programs. Muhyiddin denied the accusations, calling them a political vendetta. The arrests come ahead of regional elections in six Malaysian states, where his coalition is expected to pose a strong challenge to Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim's alliance.

images.alt_text: The premier’s approval rating stood at 68 per cent, just two months after the country’s general election resulted in a hung parliament last November.
Malaysia's former Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin has denied the accusations, describing them as political vendetta.

site_title: Thai economy growing strongly amid global slowdown: deputy PM
summary: Thailand's economy is growing strongly despite a global slowdown, with tourism rebounding and economic indicators improving. The country's customs-based exports contracted for the fourth straight month in January, but growth is expected to be 3-5% this year. The Bank of Thailand is expected to raise its key interest rate to contain consumer prices. Tourism Minister Pipat Ratchakitprakan predicts 25-30 million foreign visitors this year, up from 4.2 million in the first two months of 2023.

images.alt_text: Headline inflation dropped to its lowest rate in 13 months of 3.79 per cent in February.
The cabinet let the central bank extend its soft loan programme for smaller firms until early April 2024.

site_title: HDB resale prices flatten in February, ending 31-month rally: SRX, 99.co
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore remained flat in February, marking the first time since June 2020, according to SRX and 99.co. Prices of larger flats, such as five-room and executive flats, decreased 0.8% and 0.3% respectively. Resale volumes dropped 28.2% from the previous month, the lowest since May 2020. Analysts attribute the decline to lower demand from private home buyers and downgraders affected by the 15-month waiting period requirements. Resale prices are expected to remain stable, with potential growth in demand for smaller flats in the coming months.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Successful applicants for Jurong West Crystal and Brickland Weave be able to move into their new homes earlier, as these projects have shorter waiting times.

Rents for the condo market climbs 1.4 per cent in January from December 2022, while HDB rental prices rise 0.6 per cent from the month before, according to flash estimates from SRX and 99.co on Tuesday (Feb 28).

Generic photograph of HDB flats being built around Darul Ghufran Mosque as viewed from Blk 413 Tampines Street 41 on Feb 7, 2023.

site_title: Green economy competition rocks EU-US relations
summary: The EU-US relationship is experiencing contradictory impulses, with cooperation on Russia's war in Ukraine and tensions over the US Inflation Reduction Act (IRA). The IRA's massive funding for clean tech poses a risk for the EU's dominance in the green industrial revolution, as it discriminates against firms that export to the US. EU officials, including European Commission president Ursula von der Leyen, are seeking a more cooperative framework, while the Biden administration is concerned about the EU's accommodation of China. A possible compromise could be a bilateral commitment on critical raw materials, but its scope is limited.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An aerial view shows a wind farm in Graincourt-les-Havrincourt, France, November 7, 2020. Picture taken, November 7, 2020 with a drone.  REUTERS/Pascal Rossignol/File Photo

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB downgrades TDCX to ‘hold’, lowers target price on near-term headwinds
summary: CGS-CIMB downgraded its rating on TDCX to "hold" from "add" due to the company's FY2023 guidance disappointment, citing macroeconomic headwinds and margin pressures. TDCX's adjusted Ebitda guidance of 25-29% also fell short of expectations. The downgrade resulted in a target price of US$13.30, down from US$15.50 previously, as the brokerage cut its FY2023 to FY2024 earnings per share estimates. Despite the downgrade, CGS-CIMB remains positive on TDCX's longer-term outlook.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
The latest Q4 set of results brings Singapore-based TDCX’s earnings for the full year to S$104.9 million, up a marginal 1.1 per cent from its FY2021 profit of S$103.8 million.

The higher price target on the New York Stock Exchange-listed counter comes after CGS-CIMB raised its FY2023 to FY2024 forecasts for TDCX by 1.3 per cent to 3.1 per cent on stronger growth assumptions.
TDCX said revenue contributions from new economy clients stood at 93 per cent for the first nine months of the year.
Headquartered in Singapore, TDCX is a provider of digital customer experience solutions with a focus on new economy companies.
TDCX chief executive and founder Laurent Junique believes that the company's growth lies in its sales and digital marketing services segment.
TDCX supplied this image for file photo usage
CGS-CIMB cut its target price on digital customer experience solutions provider TDCX to US$18 from US$24 as it expects the company will face slower agent growth amid recent macro uncertainties.
TDCX chief executive Laurent Junique said growing geopolitical and economic instabilities may create headwinds for the business in the short term.

site_title: BMW iX5: When will hydrogen pick up steam?
summary: BMW has begun rolling out a small fleet of its BMW iX5 Hydrogen, a version of its X5 SUV modified to run on hydrogen gas, as part of its efforts to champion and demonstrate fuel cell electric vehicle (FCEV) technology. The company plans to build nearly 100 of the vehicles and use them to gauge public feedback and test the technology in daily use. FCEVs have already gained traction, with over 56,000 units sold worldwide, and BMW aims to make its FCEVs commercially viable by the second half of the decade.

images.alt_text: The GR86 feels like something created to engage the driver, with an analogue experience that rewards dedication and feel.

site_title: Hong Kong’s property recovery is as chaotic as its reopening
summary: Hong Kong's commercial real estate market is experiencing a mixed recovery, with restaurants, shops, and apartment sales picking up, but industrial buildings and offices seeing less demand. Despite the border reopening, Chinese companies are investing more in industrial spaces rather than offices. The city's biggest developer, Sun Hung Kai Properties, recently sold a prime commercial site for HK$4.73 billion, below expectations, reflecting business elites' skepticism towards Hong Kong's economic recovery. Vacancy rates for Grade-A office buildings remain high, with 15% of spaces currently empty.

images.alt_text: Glitzy Hong Kong shopping streets once packed with luxury stores that attracted 56 million visitors in pre-pandemic 2019 now have about half of their shop units sitting vacant, according to property management companies.
Lennon Lee, Partner, Financial Services Tax Leader, PwC Singapore.

site_title: Gold edges higher on softer dollar; hawkish Powell caps upside
summary: Gold prices edged 0.1% higher to $1,815.58 per ounce, as the dollar eased, despite US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's hawkish remarks. Spot gold hit a one-week low on Wednesday, but the dollar index's decline made bullion more affordable for foreign buyers. Powell reaffirmed interest rate hikes, but emphasized data would influence the decision. The focus now shifts to the US jobs report for February, scheduled for Friday.

images.alt_text: Although gold is considered a hedge against inflation, interest rate hikes to control rising prices tend to decrease the appetite for zero-yield bullion.

site_title: Thatcher, Sunak and the politics of the supermarket
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is facing a test of his economic competence as food prices soar due to the war in Ukraine, rising by 17% in the past year. The situation is worsened by Brexit's impact on the supply chain and the free movement of hauliers. Sunak's priority to halve inflation by the end of the year has made for miserable politics, with the public blaming the government for the issue. The Conservative Party's handling of supermarkets, a key area influenced by Thatcher's policies, has become a point of contention, with some retailers refusing to share data on shortages.

images.alt_text: Empty shelves at a Sainsbury supermarket in east London., Feb 24, 2023. Some UK supermarkets have introduced limits on customer purchases of some fruit and vegetables due to "sourcing challenges" blamed on weather conditions in southern Europe and north Africa, the industry said.
Kantar's research indicated that grocery-price inflation was the second biggest financial issue for Britons after rocketing energy costs.

site_title: US worries China will use supply chains as weapon
summary: The US intelligence community warns that China will use its dominance in global supply chains as a weapon to advance its political and military might. The "Annual Threat Assessment" report states that China is already forcing foreign companies to transfer technologies and intellectual property, and may use this power to disrupt global supply chains, particularly if it takes over Taiwan, which is a leading contributor to semiconductor chips. This could have significant effects on global supply chains and the US manufacturing and consumer sectors.

images.alt_text: Amphibious armoured vehicles under China's People's Liberation Army taking part in a training exercise in Fujian province, China August 14, 2022. cnsphoto via REUTERS   ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY. CHINA OUT./File Photo

US State Department spokesman Ned Price described Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen’s expected travel as “transit” rather than a “visit” to the United States, which supports but does not recognise the self-ruling democracy claimed by Beijing.
The Biden administration is counting on the Netherlands to help stop China from further developing its own chip industry and advancing its military capabilities.

site_title: Fitch downgrades LMIRT’s rating again as refinancing worries deepen
summary: Fitch Ratings downgraded Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust's (LMIRT) issuer default rating to "CCC" from "CCC+" due to increased refinancing risks, citing concerns over LMIRT's ability to refinance its term loans and US-dollar notes. The downgrade reflects the likelihood of debt restructuring if LMIRT fails to transition to a secured-capital structure, potentially involving an extension of its US$250 million notes due June 2024.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
LMIRT continues to explore options and measures to maintain a sustainable capital structure and reduce the aggregate leverage of the trust, says its manager.

Although LMIRT demonstrated an ability to “tap banks and capital markets” even during the worst of the Covid-19 pandemic, Fitch analysts said execution risks have “increased significantly” as capital market conditions have turned unfavourable.
The loan would be used to refinance existing debt obligations of Perpetual Asia, a trustee of Lippo Mall Indonesia Retail Trust.
Gross revenue rose 4.1 per cent to S$51.7 million in Q2, on the back of higher rental revenue as lower rental discounts were extended due to the stabilising Covid-19 situation in Indonesia.

site_title: The pursuit of economic growth in an environment of rising costs
summary: Finance Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the importance of economic growth to advance the well-being of all Singaporeans. Despite rising costs, Wong argued that growth remains paramount, as a shrinking economy would exacerbate difficulties. Transformation and productivity can help firms tackle manpower issues and maintain competitiveness. The government aims to increase supply to stabilize housing prices and mitigate cost pressures. Wong also stressed the need for productivity and innovation to differentiate Singapore from competitors and attract investments.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
The Straits Times-The Business Times Budget 2023 Roundtable.  DPM Lawrence Wong.
Singaporeans must take charge of their “career health” by taking “deliberate and purposeful steps” to stay ahead of the competition, says Manpower Minister Tan See Leng.
According to data from analytics platform Handshakes, out of 63,801 new corporate entities formed here last year, 29 per cent were foreign-owned.
Singapore has an edge within the region specifically – and Asia remains a crucial market for MNEs, said analysts.
Singapore extends investment promotion tax incentives; raises quantum for Global Investor Programme

site_title: Spotify woos creators, adds video in revamp
summary: Spotify has introduced new tools for artists and songwriters, focusing on video formats to compete with social media platforms. The company has also revamped its interface, offering song previews and personalized recommendations using artificial intelligence. Spotify has surpassed 500 million monthly active users and 10 million creators, with 205 million paying subscribers. The move aims to expand the platform's offerings and provide more interactive experiences for artists, following the company's struggles to break even despite strong subscriber growth.

images.alt_text: Premium subscribers, who account for most of Spotify’s revenue, rose 14 per cent to 205 million, topping estimates of 202.3 million.

site_title: US Federal Reserve warns of ‘widespread’ inflationary pressures
summary: The US Federal Reserve warned that the US faces "widespread" inflationary pressures, despite an aggressive campaign of monetary tightening. Chair Jerome Powell indicated the central bank is prepared to increase interest rate hikes if necessary. The Fed's "beige book" survey showed a modest to moderate rise in employment and overall economic activity, but price inflation remains above the Fed's 2% target. The labor market remains "extremely tight" with the unemployment rate at its lowest level since the 1960s.

images.alt_text: Private employment increased by 242,000 jobs last month, the ADP National Employment report showed on Wednesday (Mar 8).
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.2 per cent lower at 32,798.40 on Wednesday.

site_title: Uber is considering spinning off freight logistics division
summary: Uber is considering spinning off its freight logistics division, exploring a sale or initial public offering (IPO) to focus on ride-hailing and food delivery. The decision is driven by the freight unit's struggles during a broader downturn in trucking. If an IPO occurs, it may not happen until next year, depending on market conditions. The move would allow CEO Dara Kosrowshahi to focus on growing ride-hailing and food-delivery units, which outperformed expectations in the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: Uber has set a 2040 target for 100 per cent of its rides to be in zero-emission vehicles, public transport or with micro-mobility, including in India.
Uber has set a 2040 target for 100 per cent of its rides to be in zero-emission vehicles, public transport or with micro-mobility, including in India.
Uber, which operates in more than 70 countries and 10,000 cities, says that new ride-sharing products are boosting its revenue.

site_title: Silvergate slides on plan to wind down bank operations and liquidate
summary: Silvergate Capital, a US bank, plans to wind down operations and liquidate its bank after the crypto industry's meltdown weakened the company's financial strength. The bank's shares plummeted over 50% amid scrutiny from regulators and a Justice Department investigation into dealings with fallen crypto giants FTX and Alameda Research. This is the first US bank failure since 2020, and the collapse may put pressure on banks to demonstrate safe and sound dealings with crypto.

images.alt_text: Silvergate was hit hard by crypto exchange FTX’s implosion, revealing in January that a surge in withdrawals by clients forced it to sell billions of dollars worth of assets and take steps to stabilise its balance sheet.
“The crypto market reacted to the negative news from Silvergate Bank, with both bitcoin and ethereum down about 4.8 per cent for the week,” analysts at brokerage Bernstein said.
Silvergate suffered a run on deposits last year in the wake of the bankruptcy of FTX, which was a key client.

site_title: Lehman Brothers loses bid to collect on crisis-era swaps
summary: Lehman Brothers International Europe has lost a bid to collect $500 million from Assured Guaranty over a 2009 settlement of credit default swaps. A New York judge sided with Assured, ruling that Lehman failed to show incorrect settlement of the trades. The judge found that market prices were unavailable at the time and that Assured's calculation was reasonable, contrary to Lehman's claims. This decision is a blow to Lehman creditors seeking to recover more money from the bank's downfall.

images.alt_text: Citigroup chief executive officer Jane Fraser has sought to improve profitability by focusing on businesses like treasury services and wealth management.

site_title: Citigroup to ‘recalibrate’ investment banking headcount as needed
summary: Citigroup plans to adjust headcount in its investment banking division as needed to boost profits amid a recent slowdown in deals. CFO Mark Mason stated that the firm will "recalibrate" in certain areas to match the pace of investments. Revenue from the investment banking division is expected to drop, but the company aims to lower its efficiency ratio below 60% in the medium term. This move follows CEO Jane Fraser's focus on improving profitability through businesses like treasury services and wealth management.

images.alt_text: Citigroup’s recent moves in its mortgage division come after the bank already dismissed dozens of staffers last year.
Citigroup said that stubbornly high inflation across the globe may temper growth.

site_title: Adobe opens new office tower and pledges no companywide layoffs in 2023
summary: Adobe has opened a new 18-story office tower in San Jose, California, adding 3,000 employee workstations, despite industry trends of cutting jobs and reducing real estate. The company has pledged no companywide layoffs in 2023, bucking the trend of technology companies such as Salesforce and Meta Platforms. Adobe's chief people officer, Gloria Chen, emphasized the company's commitment to flexible work arrangements and its focus on growing and managing expenses judiciously.

images.alt_text: Adobe company logos are seen in this picture illustration taken in Vienna July 9, 2013. Picture taken July 9, 2013. REUTERS/Leonhard Foeger/File Photo
“The Commission will now ask Adobe to notify the transaction. Adobe cannot implement the transaction before notifying and obtaining clearance from the Commission,” European Commission said.

site_title: US economy got a strong start in 2023, Fed’s Beige Book says
summary: The US economy showed a strong start in 2023, with steady consumer spending and stabilizing manufacturing activity, according to the Federal Reserve's Beige Book. However, the outlook for the coming months is less optimistic due to heightened uncertainty. The report notes robust job growth powered by consumer spending, but also persistent price pressures, wage growth, and labor shortages. Policymakers are closely monitoring economic data to determine the path of interest-rate hikes, with officials indicating a possible acceleration of rate hikes if data continues to come in strong.

images.alt_text: Jerome Powell, chairman of the US Federal Reserve, had earlier warned that the central bank is prepared to increase the pace of interest rate hikes, and could raise rates higher than anticipated if necessary, sending jitters through markets.
Private employment increased by 242,000 jobs last month, the ADP National Employment report showed on Wednesday (Mar 8).

site_title: Innovation and productivity are ‘imperative’ for Singapore amid rising costs
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the need for innovation and productivity amid rising costs. The country aims to stay competitive by promoting economic growth, upskilling workers, and increasing supply of housing. The government will focus on industry-by-industry transformation, attracting high-quality investments, and reskilling workers to ensure productivity growth. To address rising house prices, the government plans to increase supply and moderate demand with cooling measures. The government will also review its fiscal system to ensure fairness and progressivity.

images.alt_text: At the ST-BT Budget Roundtable 2023: (from left): Associate editor of The Straits Times, Vikram Khanna, UOB senior economist Alvin Liew, DPM Lawrence Wong and vice-president of NTUC K. Thanaletchimi.
Finance M
Singapore has an edge within the region specifically – and Asia remains a crucial market for MNEs, said analysts.

site_title: US proposes new water pollution limits for coal plants
summary: The US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has proposed new water pollution limits for coal-fired power plants, aiming to reduce nearly 584 million tons of pollutants released through wastewater annually. The rules, set by President Joe Biden's administration, would prevent toxic metals and other pollutants, including mercury and arsenic, from contaminating drinking water sources and ecosystems. The proposal is subject to a 60-day public comment period, with some environmental groups welcoming the move to address surface water pollution caused by coal-fired power plants.

images.alt_text: A truck carries coal in Tabalong, Indonesia. Fitch expects the country's coal production levels to remain stable or grow moderately in the medium term.

A nickel mine in Indonesia. Most of Indonesia's nickel is currently exported to China as low-grade pig iron, but more investment could allow it to be processed into higher-value battery-grade exports.

site_title: US, EU to launch talks on free-trade-like status, easing EV trade dispute: sources
summary: US President Joe Biden and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen are set to agree on Friday to launch talks on a free-trade agreement-like status for the European Union, easing a trade dispute over electric vehicle (EV) tax credits. The US Inflation Reduction Act requires rising percentages of battery minerals to come from the US or a Free Trade Agreement partner, prompting criticism from the EU and other allies. The two leaders aim to ensure EU minerals are eligible for tax credits, strengthening US supply chains and reducing reliance on China for critical minerals.

images.alt_text: The Chips Act was a response to technological advances by China, regarded by a strong consensus in Washington as America’s leading global geo-strategic and geo-economic rival.

Australia's prime minister Anthony Albanese said last month that Australia's fleet of nuclear submarines provided under the AUKUS agreement will be the "biggest leap in our defence capability in our history".

site_title: Three years after Covid hit, US restaurants are still understaffed
summary: US restaurants continue to struggle with staffing shortages three years after the COVID-19 pandemic, with over 60% of establishments reporting understaffing. Despite the labor market showing strong employment numbers, the industry faces a shortage of workers, particularly among millennials and Gen Xers who left to care for family or pursue other opportunities. Boosted pay and benefits have not been enough to attract and retain workers, leading chains like Jack in the Box and Domino's to raise prices and struggle with service delivery.

images.alt_text: A staff member prepares a pizza at a Domino's Pizza restaurant in Moscow, Russia, July 14, 2017. Picture taken July 14, 2017. REUTERS/Sergei Karpukhin

site_title: Thailand’s inflation seen falling further, finance minister says
summary: Thailand's inflation rate fell to 3.79% in February, its lowest rate in 13 months, according to Finance Minister Arkhom Termpittayapaisith. The government plans to implement support measures to reduce the cost of living, driven by efforts to ease energy price impacts. Despite the decline, inflation remains above the central bank's target range, leading to expected interest rate hikes. The economy is expected to continue recovering, with consumption and tourism rebounding, as it transitions back to the 1-3% inflation target range.

site_title: Japan’s ispace to list shares in Tokyo ahead of planned Moon landing
summary: Japan's space startup, ispace, plans to list its shares on the Tokyo Stock Exchange's growth section on April 12, aiming to raise 24.7 million yen (S$187.1 million) for its lunar development and transportation services. The company, which aims to be the first commercial company to land a probe on the Moon, plans to list 200 million shares. The IPO is valued at 19 billion yen (S$187.1 million) and the stock may be priced at 244 yen (S$2.40).

site_title: Europe: Shares subdued as strong US jobs data deepens Federal Reserve’s rate hike angst
summary: European shares ended 0.1% higher on Wednesday, despite subdued mood, after better-than-expected US jobs data deepened concerns over Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's interest rate hike plans. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index hit its lowest level in a week but recovered, with basic resources and technology stocks rising. Powell's comments that the Fed had not decided on this month's rate hike also helped. However, real-estate stocks fell, and the euro zone's fourth-quarter growth numbers were lower than expected.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.2 per cent lower at 32,798.40 on Wednesday.

site_title: Singapore shares open stronger on Thursday; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore shares opened stronger on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 5.06 points or 0.2% to 3,231.92. Gainers outnumbered losers 49 to 24, with 40.1 million securities worth S$27.5 million changing hands. Sembcorp Marine saw the highest volumes, adding 1.9% to S$0.11. US stocks ended mixed, with the Dow Jones down 0.2% and the S&P 500 up 0.1%.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust's (Sabana Reit) NTP+ at 151 Lorong Chuan. Its substantial shareholder Volare's offer to acquire an additional 10 per cent of the Reit has been declared unconditional in all respects.

site_title: Global tax changes are a chance for Singapore to rethink investor incentives
summary: Singapore is poised to update its policies to remain a top destination for investors amid global tax changes. The upcoming shake-up in global tax rules, aimed at combating base erosion and profit shifting, may prompt Singapore to consider fresh ways to structure business benefits. The country could explore incentivizing multinational corporations to invest regionally, rather than just domestically, to leverage its strengths in technical know-how and regional partnerships. This approach could bring together domestic and regional strengths, offering investors the best of both worlds from a base in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Singapore has an edge within the region specifically – and Asia remains a crucial market for MNEs, said analysts.

Mr Lawrence Wong, Minister for Finance, arriving at Parliament House to deliver his Budget Statement speech on Budget Day, Feb 14, 2023.
