site_title: Lee Hsien Yang hints at never returning to Singapore, says he is unlikely to see his sister again
summary: Lee Hsien Yang, younger son of Singapore's first prime minister Lee Kuan Yew, hinted at never returning to Singapore amid a police investigation into him and his wife. He expressed sadness over being unlikely to see his sister, Lee Wei Ling, face-to-face again due to her poor health. Lee was previously found guilty of lying under oath and suspended from practicing law for 15 months. He has been living in Europe since leaving Singapore after refusing a police interview in 2022.

images.alt_text: News of Lee being investigated by the police has sparked speculation among some quarters, who questioned if it was being done to keep him out of the presidential race.
Lee Hsien Yang and his wife Lee Suet Fern have left Singapore after refusing to go for a police interview, which they had initially agreed to attend.

site_title: White House applauds bill that would allow TikTok ban
summary: The White House has welcomed a bipartisan bill that would allow the US to ban Chinese-owned video-sharing app TikTok, citing national security concerns. The bill, introduced by Senators Mark Warner and John Thune, would empower the US government to prevent foreign governments from exploiting technology services that pose risks to Americans' data and national security. The move comes after the US government banned TikTok on government devices and follows similar bans in other countries. TikTok has expressed concerns over the bill, likening a US ban to a "ban on the export of American culture and values."

images.alt_text: The phones are means of restricting or blocking applications and keeping corporate data secure.
TikTok’s commercial success in the US has come at the expense of local social media giants like Meta Platforms and Alphabet’s YouTube.

site_title: US: Stocks tumble after Fed testimony, Dow -1.7%
summary: US stocks plummeted on Tuesday after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell hinted at a potential half-point interest rate hike at the next meeting. The Dow Jones shed 575 points, or 1.7%, to 32,856.46, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes also declined. Powell stated the Fed is prepared to accelerate interest rate hikes if strong economic data persists, increasing expectations of a more aggressive response.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 3.13 points, or 0.01 per cent, at the open to 33,428.31.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.1 per cent to 33,431.64, while the broad-based S&P 500 Index ticked up 0.1 per cent to 4,048.43 on Monday.

site_title: China’s yuan weakens to 2-month low, with key 7-per-dollar level in sight
summary: China's yuan weakened to a 2-month low against the dollar, approaching 7 per dollar, due to the firmer dollar and hawkish US monetary tightening outlook. The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 6.9525 per dollar, down 0.53% from the previous fix, and the onshore yuan fell to 6.9782 per dollar, its weakest level since Dec 29, 2022. Traders expect the yuan to continue weakening if it breaches the 7 per dollar threshold, potentially triggering expectations of heavy yuan depreciation and risk capital outflow.

images.alt_text: Qin Gang, who was previously ambassador to the US, blamed Washington for a wide range of problems in geopolitics and the global economy.
The Chips Act was a response to technological advances by China, regarded by a strong consensus in Washington as America’s leading global geo-strategic and geo-economic rival.

site_title: Florida’s DeSantis courts right-wing as he weighs White House bid
summary: Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has positioned himself as the leading Republican alternative to Donald Trump, launching a legislative session that focuses on issues appealing to Trump's base. DeSantis's agenda includes expanding gun rights, curbing diversity efforts, and ending Covid-19 vaccine mandates, which are expected to gain traction in the 2024 Republican primary. The governor's populist right-wing stance is seen as a deliberate attempt to distance himself from Trump's chaotic presidency, but his efforts to court the right-wing have been met with criticism from some quarters, including Trump, who has accused DeSantis of being a "total failure."

images.alt_text: Former South Carolina governor and former US ambassador to the UN Nikki Haley announces her run for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination at a campaign event in Charleston, South Carolina, Feb 15, 2023.

The bill allows Republican Ron DeSantis to appoint his own board to oversee the services provided in the theme park by Disney, which attracted the governor’s ire last year after it criticised a law banning school lessons on sexual orientation.

site_title: EC World Reit releases more funds from escrow for loan repayments
summary: EC World Reit has released more funds from escrow to repay outstanding loan amounts. The Reit has S$57.7 million in offshore bank loans and S$81.2 million in onshore bank loans to repay. The release of funds will help reduce interest payments, but the Reit remains in breach of its mandatory repayment obligations until lenders consent to the extension of the deadline. As of March 7, 50% of onshore bank loan lenders and 75% of offshore bank loan lenders have agreed to the new repayment plan.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
After the release of funds, EC World Reit’s margin deposit as at Feb 11 stands at about 1.1 million yuan, which continues to be held in escrow.
EC World Reit's manager said lenders are in the process of obtaining the relevant internal approval for the repayment plan.
Gross revenue of the China-focused e-commerce logistics landlord was down 11 per cent to S$28.4 million for the quarter, from S$31.9 million in the year-ago period.
The long stop date for EC World Reit's proposed divestment of Bei Gang Logistics (above) and Chongxian Port Logistics has been extended to Feb 28, 2023.
The latest proposal is on the back of delays to divestment plans of two Chinese logistics assets, to the tune of some 2.03 billion yuan (S$392.7 million).
EC World Reit's manager says that "stringent" Covid-19 controls and holidays in October have caused delays in lenders’ internal approval processes for the transaction financing.

site_title: Nvidia, AMD grapple with latest US curbs on China’s Inspur
summary: US regulators are reviewing Nvidia and AMD's dealings with China's Inspur Group after adding it to a US export blacklist for allegedly supporting China's military modernization. Inspur's Chinese-listed subsidiary had nearly $10 billion in sales in 2021, and its listing restricts shipments of US-made semiconductors and other products. Companies are assessing whether to halt sales to Inspur's subsidiaries, which could be considered a violation of the listing. Inspur's listing is more restrictive than others on the US export blacklist, and may be comparable to the curbs placed on Huawei Technologies.

images.alt_text: The seal of the Department of Commerce is pictured in Washington, D.C., U.S. March 10, 2017. REUTERS/Eric Thayer

site_title: Microsoft, Google-backed group wants to boost AI education in low-income schools
summary: A non-profit backed by Microsoft and Google, the AI Education Project, aims to boost AI education in low-income schools. The group, founded in 2019, has reached 100,000 students and is expanding its efforts with new backers and partner schools. The goal is to teach kids about AI, its limits, and its promise, preparing them for jobs that require AI skills. With the rapid increase in interest in generative AI, the group seeks more funding to address the skills gap caused by automation and AI in marginalized regions.

images.alt_text: Microsoft said a line of business-intelligence and app-development tools within Power Platform, including Power Virtual Agent and AI Builder, was updated with the new capabilities.

site_title: US set to lift Covid-19 testing requirements for travellers from China: source
summary: The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) is set to lift mandatory Covid-19 testing requirements for travelers from China, joining other countries in dropping the requirements. This decision comes after China's decision to lift its zero-COVID policies, leading to a surge in cases. The US will continue to monitor cases in China and around the world through its Traveller-based Genomic Surveillance Programme. The move is part of a broader trend of countries easing travel restrictions as they adapt to the new normal of the pandemic.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Passengers wearing face masks following the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak are seen on a China Eastern Airlines flight at Shenzhen Baoan International Airport in Shenzhen, Guangdong province, China May 19, 2020. REUTERS/Martin Pollard/File Photo

site_title: Irish property market shows new stress when fund blocks withdrawals
summary: Ireland's Irish Life Assurance has blocked withdrawals from its €500 million Irish property fund for six months due to increased customer requests. This move adds to stress in the Irish commercial property market, where returns slumped 4% in the final three months of 2022. Bank of Ireland Group expects Irish commercial real estate prices to fall 6% this year, with a further 2.5% drop in 2024. The sector is considered a concern for the financial system, with rising interest rates and reduced demand for office space.

images.alt_text: Britain's Prime Minister Rishi Sunak (L) and European Commission chief Ursula von der Leyen hold a joint press conference following their meeting at the Fairmont Hotel in Windsor, west of London, on Feb 27, 2023.
The Immigrant Investor Programme was set up as a pathway for non-EEA nationals to secure immigration permission on the basis of long-term investment in a range of options.

site_title: S&P cuts Nissan credit rating to junk status
summary: S&P Global Ratings cut Nissan's credit rating to junk status, downgrading it to BB+ from BBB-, citing weaker-than-expected earnings due to a tough year ahead. The rating agency expects global supply-chain disruptions and softening demand for new car sales in the US and Europe to pressure sales prices. Despite this, the outlook remains stable due to Nissan's conservative financial discipline and sound balance sheet.

site_title: Trafigura doing ‘major’ audit of nickel fraud missteps, CEO says
summary: Trafigura, a major commodities trader, is conducting a "major internal audit" after discovering losses of nearly $600 million due to alleged nickel fraud. CEO Jeremy Weir acknowledged that the company found no internal involvement, but noted that despite thorough checks, problems can still arise. Trafigura is taking legal action against Prateek Gupta, accusing him of a "systematic fraud." The company's rival Glencore has expressed confidence in its strong controls, but Trafigura is reviewing its processes closely to prevent similar incidents.

images.alt_text: A Sept 2022 file photo of a nickel smelting facility in Konawe, Southeast Sulawesi. Many of the materials critical for the green transition are currently produced in far fewer areas than oil and gas are.
Indian businessman Prateek Gupta and his companies, against whom Trafigura secured a US$625 million freezing order this week, have a checkered history in the trading world.

site_title: Behaviours that build wealth
summary: A disciplined investment approach combined with a well-diversified portfolio can help overcome biases that may hamper investment decisions. Behavioural biases, such as the home bias, negativity bias, and loss aversion, can lead to poor investment choices. Investors may prioritize local assets over foreign ones, fearing higher risks, and sell losing assets too quickly, missing out on potential gains. A long-term strategy, focusing on time in the market rather than market timing, can help mitigate these biases. By understanding and avoiding these biases, investors can build wealth over the long term.

images.alt_text: Daniel Imhof
The aftermath of 2022's storm is likely to present a rainbow of opportunity for alternative investments, says Citi's Brad McCarthy.

site_title: China to set up enlarged financial regulatory authority
summary: China is establishing an enlarged national financial regulatory authority, absorbing its banking and insurance watchdog to strengthen Communist Party leadership and regulate the $60 trillion financial system. The new regulator will oversee financial sectors except securities, taking over investor protection and oversight of financial holding companies. The China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission will cease to exist, and the China Securities Regulatory Commission will become a government agency under the State Council.

site_title: US: Wall St slips at open as investors await Powell’s testimony
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday as investors awaited Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's testimony, which could provide insight into interest rate hike plans. The Dow Jones fell 3.13 points, or 0.01%, to 33,428.31, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropped. The cautious trading was attributed to Powell's testimony, which could shed light on the central bank's future economic decisions.

site_title: Policies, attitudes must change if Singapore is to have an equitable corporate society
summary: Singapore's corporate society still lags behind in achieving equitable representation of women in senior management and board seats, despite recent progress. Women make up 49% of university graduates but only 33% of senior management positions and 21.5% of board seats. The country also struggles with gender pay disparity, with women earning 83 cents for every dollar earned by men on average. To address these issues, companies must adopt more innovative approaches to attracting and retaining talent, and the public and private sectors must work together to develop equitable labor policies.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

For equitable progress for all, we need to implement initiatives on diversity that target equitable opportunities for all, regardless of gender, ethnicity, age, socio-economic background, says Valerie Mantot-Groene, regional managing director, Asean, Apex Group. PHOTO:
Boardrooms in Singapore are seeing an increased presence of women directors, but these numbers still lag those of more developed markets. PHOTO: PIXABAY
Women made up more than 24 per cent of the board members of MSCI AC World Index companies in 2022 compared with about 18 per cent in 2018.

Last year, women accounted for nearly 40 per cent of all new director appointments made by statutory boards and the largest Singapore Exchange (SGX) listed companies, according to an annual study by The Council for Board Diversity (CBD) published on Thursday (Mar 2).

site_title: Fed’s Powell opens the door to higher and possibly faster rate hikes
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell hinted that interest rates may rise more than expected due to stronger-than-anticipated economic data, which could lead to faster rate hikes to control inflation. Powell stated that if the data indicates a need for more aggressive measures, the Fed would be prepared to increase the pace of rate hikes. This move sparked a surge in bond markets, with investors boosting bets on a half-percentage-point rate increase at the upcoming Fed meeting.

site_title: Thailand offers tax breaks for companies issuing investment tokens
summary: Thailand's cabinet agreed to waive corporate income tax and value-added tax for companies issuing digital tokens for investment, estimated to generate 128 billion baht (S$5 billion) in investment token offerings over two years. The move aims to promote industry development, following the relaxation of tax rules for crypto trading last year. However, the country's central bank has banned digital assets as a means of payment, citing financial stability concerns.

site_title: Oil falls by US$3 a barrel as investors brace for steeper US rate hikes
summary: Oil prices fell by US$3 a barrel on Tuesday, with Brent crude futures dropping 3.4% to US$83.29 and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures falling 3.6% to US$77.58, amid US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's comments on potential rate hikes and a strengthening dollar. China's weak data on exports and imports also weighed on the market. Despite forecasts of tighter supply and higher demand, the market remains vulnerable to supply disruptions, particularly from Russia.

site_title: 5 Questions with founder-turned-investor Ooi Hsu Ken
summary: Ooi Hsu Ken, co-founder and general partner at Iterative, shares insights on being an investor versus a founder. As a former founder, Ken notes that being an investor is easier due to the lack of constant fear of failure and the ability to focus on building systems and products. Ken's own experiences, including the failure of his first startup Eggsprout and the success of Decide.com, have taught him to slow down and enjoy the ride, rather than being overly focused on success.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Dr Tan Si-Hui spent over 18 years diving into the great unknowns of quantum science, before taking the leap into the startup world.
Angel investor John Tan worked closely with the founders of Ninja Van during the startup's early days.
Jon Russell started out as a journalist covering startups in South-east Asia before becoming a partner at Crypto.com Capital.

site_title: NatWest adds new label in ESG debt with ‘women-led’ bond
summary: NatWest, a UK lender, has issued a 500 million euro bond to finance loans to women-led enterprises, marking the first social bond from a European financial institution with this specific focus. The bond, which matures in 2028, was oversubscribed and priced at 120 basis points above the mid-swap rate. This move comes as sales of green, social, and sustainability bonds declined in 2023 due to increased scrutiny and higher borrowing costs.

images.alt_text: The green transition presents both a challenge and an opportunity.
Recovery in ESG bond issuance seen in 2023 as rates stabilise, inflation subsides

The US$550 million SLD would allow RGE’s member company Apical, a vegetable oil processor, to partially hedge the interest rate risk of US$787 million of sustainability-linked loans it secured in November last year.

site_title: Britain to ban entry for asylum seekers arriving by sea
summary: Britain has introduced a new law barring the entry of asylum seekers arriving by sea, with those entering the country illegally to be deported to "safe third countries" rather than claiming asylum. The law, which comes into effect after a 28-day detention period, aims to prevent migrants from using anti-slavery laws to block their removal. However, refugee charities have raised concerns that the proposal could criminalize genuine refugees and shatter Britain's commitments under the UN refugee convention.

images.alt_text: Stanley Johnson would be a controversial pick in part because of accusations of sexual harassment against two women, and domestic abuse against his ex-wife.
UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak (left) and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen shake hands at a press conference after securing the deal, which will regulate trade in Northern Ireland.

Nadhim Zahawi, chairman of the Conservative Party, arrives at the party headquarters in London, Jan 25, 2023. Zahawi is facing calls to resign following allegations of tax evasion. The British prime minister has ordered an ethics probe into Zahawi's tax affairs.

site_title: Tencent-backed Airwallex acquires China licence via M&A deal
summary: Airwallex, a Tencent-backed payment platform startup, has acquired an online payment business licence in China through a merger and acquisition deal with Guangzhou Shang Wu Tong Network Technology. The transaction has cleared regulatory hurdles and allows Airwallex to become a third-party payment provider in China, expanding its access to the local market. This approval adds to Airwallex's existing licences in multiple markets, including Australia, Europe, and the US.

site_title: Biden plans tax high-earners in bid to save Medicare
summary: US President Joe Biden plans to raise the Medicare tax on high earners from 3.8% to 5% on income above $400,000 to extend the solvency of the Medicare Hospital Insurance Trust Fund by at least 25 years. The tax increase is part of Biden's budget proposal, which also aims to close loopholes and allow Medicare to negotiate prices for more high-cost drugs, saving $200 billion over 10 years. The plan faces likely opposition from Republicans who control the House.

site_title: China to restructure sci-tech ministry to achieve self-reliance faster
summary: China's State Council plans to restructure its science and technology ministry to boost self-reliance in technology and innovation. The restructuring aims to optimize whole-process management of scientific and technological innovation, with a focus on strategic planning and decision-making. The changes will centralize power over science and technology policies in the hands of the ruling Chinese Communist Party. The goal is to accelerate China's move towards self-reliance in key technologies, amid increased international competition and export controls.

site_title: IMF to temporarily raise borrowing limits to aid vulnerable countries
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has temporarily raised borrowing limits for vulnerable countries, increasing annual and cumulative access to 600% of quota and 12-month borrowing limits to 200% of quota. This move aims to provide financial support to emerging markets and developing economies facing increased financing pressures. The changes will be reviewed once additional resources are pledged by wealthier member countries, with the Poverty Reduction and Growth Trust's access limits expected to be adjusted in the future.

site_title: Carlsberg CEO Hart to retire after wrapping up Russia exit
summary: Carlsberg CEO Cees 't Hart will retire at the end of September after successfully guiding the company's strategic shift from Russia towards China and prioritizing price over volume. During his eight-year tenure, Carlsberg's shares rose over 60%, outperforming larger rivals Heineken and AB Inbev. Hart's departure, earlier than expected, is the third exit among top brass within a year, with Carlsberg seeking an external successor and expecting to find a buyer for its Russian business by June.

site_title: UN seeks US$876 million for Rohingya aid package after funding cuts
summary: The UN is seeking $876 million to support Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh due to a drastic fall in aid pledges, leaving only $553 million to meet their humanitarian needs. This shortfall has forced the World Food Programme to cut food rations, exacerbating malnutrition, school dropouts, and child marriage. The Rohingya community, fleeing a 2017 military crackdown in Myanmar, faces a protracted humanitarian crisis with limited access to employment and aid. The UN urges international donors to shore up their commitments to prevent worsening the crisis.

images.alt_text: Some 528 ethnic Rohingya refugees broke out of an immigration detention centre in Malaysia early Wednesday, with more than a hundred still at large, according to the Malaysian Immigration Department.
The former leader, 77-year-old Nobel laureate Aung San Suu Kyi, is expected to spend the rest of her life in jail.

site_title: China's Jan-to-Feb crude oil imports slip, but expected to rise
summary: China's crude oil imports decreased 1.3% in the first two months of 2023 compared to the same period last year, totaling 84.06 million tonnes. However, analysts attribute the decline to January's lower imports and expect imports to rise in February as fuel demand rebounds after Beijing scrapped Covid-19 controls. State-owned refiners increased Middle Eastern and discounted Urals oil imports in February, while independent refiners raised their crude throughput 4.4 percentage points higher than last year.

images.alt_text: China imported a daily 1.73 million barrels of Russian crude in 2022, up 8.3 per cent from a year earlier.
Sinopec, as well as PetroChina and Cnooc have started and will continue to ramp up their procurement of Russian grades in the coming months

site_title: Apple debuts yellow iPhone 14 to boost interest until new model
summary: Apple has introduced a yellow version of the iPhone 14 and 14 Plus, offering a new color option for the existing model that was released six months ago. The new model will be available for preorder on March 10 and go on sale in retail stores on March 14. This move is part of Apple's strategy to keep the product top-of-mind for consumers until the iPhone 15 launch in September, which is expected to feature significant changes, including a new titanium design and periscope camera.

site_title: Companies are paying to play in inverted debt markets
summary: European companies are selling new debt despite higher borrowing costs, taking advantage of an "inverse government curve" where yields are lower at longer maturities. To retain investor interest, borrowers are increasingly paying to play, offering wider new issue concessions. This year's issuance has been robust, with 68 billion euros of euro investment-grade corporate debt issued in the first two months, 89% ahead of last year. Investors are still demanding high-quality debt, but are willing to pay a premium for it.

images.alt_text: In 2023, investment-grade firms have sold US$8.6 billion of the bonds known as “three-year non-call one bonds,” or 3NC1s.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's parliament approved a budget of S$123.7 billion, with Leader of the House Indranee Rajah calling for MPs to avoid polarisation and populism. A review of the self-storage industry has stalled expansion plans, while two freehold sites are up for en bloc sale. Poor weather is expected to support Malaysia's crude palm oil prices, and business leaders in China are pushing for a tech agenda during the "Two Sessions" in Beijing. Singapore shares marginally rose as investors await Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's testimony.

site_title: UK opposition calls for better online protections for children
summary: The UK's Labour Party is calling on the government to strengthen the Online Safety bill, citing a Reuters report that Snapchat kicks off dozens of British children from its platform each month, compared to tens of thousands blocked by TikTok. The opposition party argues that the current age verification technologies are not foolproof and that platforms must take on their algorithms and business models to protect children. The Labour Party wants the government to take action to address the issue, following a report that showed Snapchat removed significantly fewer underage accounts than TikTok.

site_title: China to cut number of central government employees by 5%
summary: China to cut 5% of central government employees, with jobs redistributed in strategically important areas, as part of President Xi Jinping's efforts to streamline bureaucracy. The reform plan includes restructuring the Ministry of Science and Technology to achieve self-reliance in science and technology. Additionally, China will strengthen financial oversight, establish a national bureau to manage data resources, and make changes to government departments, including the National Health Commission and National Public Complaints and Proposals Administration. This is the largest administrative shakeup in decades since 1998.

images.alt_text: “Strengthen the Ministry of Science and Technology’s strategic planning ... optimise the whole-process management of scientific and technological innovation,” the cabinet said in the plan.

A sculpture of bulls in the Lujiazui business district in Shanghai, China. The enlarged national financial regulatory authority will absorb the country's banking and insurance watchdog and oversee the financial sector.
The meeting delegates and representatives include tech industry heavyweights who make proposals and lobby for their vision of the country’s development.

site_title: China Jan-Feb trade slumps again as global demand falters
summary: China's exports and imports declined in January and February, indicating continued weakness in global demand. Exports fell 6.8% from the previous year, while imports dropped 10.2%. The decline is attributed to global economic concerns and weakening external demand, particularly from the US and Europe. China's GDP growth target for this year is around 5%, after the economy suffered from pandemic controls last year. Economists expect imports to recover gradually, but the slowdown abroad may hold down the volume of goods coming into China.

images.alt_text: Immigration inspection officers checking a tanker carrying imported crude oil at the port in Qingdao in China's Shandong province.

site_title: Sea records first profit in Q4; narrows FY2022 loss by 19% to US$1.7 billion
summary: Sea Ltd., a New York-listed company, recorded its first profit in the fourth quarter, with a net income of US$422.8 million. The company's efforts to focus on efficiency and profitability led to a 19% reduction in its FY2022 loss to US$1.7 billion. Key drivers of the turnaround included cost cuts, debt extinguishment, and revenue growth in its e-commerce business, particularly in Shopee's Asian markets. Despite a downbeat gaming business, Sea remains optimistic about its long-term growth potential, citing its cash reserves and focus on stabilizing its user base.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
The optimism comes as the research team anticipates improvements in the group’s e-commerce and digital financial services segments, which will more than offset lower Ebitda from the gaming segment.

site_title: Hong Kong loses lustre as retail units go vacant and big brands look to China
summary: Hong Kong's luxury retail market is experiencing a decline, with about half of its shop units vacant and famous foreign brands opening new outlets in mainland China. Rents in Tsim Sha Tsui have dropped 41% from pre-pandemic levels, and luxury retailers believe Hong Kong will never regain its peak status. In contrast, China's domestic luxury sales have doubled to 471 billion yuan (US$68.8 billion) in 2021, outpacing Hong Kong's retail sales. Brands such as Tiffany, Valentino, and Burberry have closed stores in the city, while others like Adidas and Sweaty Betty have opened new outlets in its place.

site_title: Cosco Shipping enters JV to grow logistics supply chain value in S-E Asia
summary: Cosco Shipping International has entered into a joint-venture agreement with Supply Fortune to grow logistics supply chain value in South-east Asia. The JV will create a digital supply chain platform, providing customers with high-quality and diversified digital supply chain products and solutions. Cosco Shipping will subscribe for 49% of the JV company, while Supply Fortune will hold the remaining 51%. The agreement aims to improve service capability, enhance customer service, and derive industry supply chain value in the region, with no expected material impact on the company's net tangible assets and earnings per share.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Cosco Shipping said its FY2022 results were affected by a non-cash impairment of goodwill related to the company’s investment in Cogent Holdings.

site_title: US dollar climbs as traders wait for Powell testimony; Aussie slips
summary: The US dollar rose 0.25% to 104.52, its highest level since February, ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's testimony before Congress, as traders await potential signals on interest rate hikes. The Aussie slipped 1% to its lowest since December, following the Reserve Bank of Australia's dovish statement hinting at the end of monetary tightening. The US dollar index is expected to be watched closely for clear signals from Powell on adjusting interest rate hikes, with the NFP report due on Friday set to be the week's key development.

site_title: Australia’s central bank says it is closer to pausing on rate hikes
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) Governor Philip Lowe stated that the central bank is closer to pausing interest rate hikes due to the economy's response to monetary policy and data showing core inflation has peaked. The RBA lifted interest rates to an 11-year high of 3.60% in February, but Lowe said the bank is now in restrictive territory and may pause further increases. This is the strongest indication yet that the bank will pause its tightening cycle, which began in May, and markets have trimmed expectations to 4.10% for peak rates.

images.alt_text: Wrapping up its March policy meeting, the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) said wages growth was still consistent with the inflation target.

site_title: David Chipperfield, champion of civic architecture, wins Pritzker Prize
summary: British architect David Chipperfield has won the prestigious Pritzker Architecture Prize, recognizing his contributions to civic architecture. Chipperfield's work, spanning decades and continents, blends seamlessly into its historical context, as seen in his restoration of the Neues Museum in Berlin and his design for the Saint Louis Art Museum. His approach, characterized by restraint and attention to detail, sets him apart from other notable architects, including Richard Rogers and Zaha Hadid. The prize is a testament to Chipperfield's commitment to preserving and enhancing the built environment.

site_title: EU anti-deforestation rule will hit Malaysia’s palm oil exports: minister
summary: Malaysia's palm oil exports to the European Union are expected to decrease due to the implementation of the EU's deforestation-free regulation, which aims to ban imports of palm oil and other commodities grown on deforested land. The EU's new regulation is seen as a negative impact on Malaysia's palm oil exports, with Deputy Prime Minister Fadillah Yusof predicting a significant decline. In response, Malaysian palm oil producers are seeking technology solutions and recruiting younger talent to boost competitiveness and explore opportunities in the downstream segment.

images.alt_text: The EU agreed to a historic law in December that will stop products causing forest destruction from being sold in European shops and supermarkets.
The high rainfall caused short-term disruption to harvesting operations and the evacuation of fruits, as well as poorer fruit quality.

site_title: Oscar short-docs race showcases booming art form
summary: The Oscar-nominated short documentary "Haulout" showcases the booming art form of short documentaries, which have exploded as a powerful medium for storytelling and information dissemination. With films like "Haulout," "Stranger at the Gate," and "The Elephant Whisperers" competing for the Academy Award for best documentary short film, the genre's entertainment chops and ability to resonate with audiences are being recognized by major media companies like The New Yorker and Netflix. The democratization of filmmaking technology has allowed anyone to become a documentarian, leading to a surge in authentic and personal stories being told.

images.alt_text: Vicky Krieps is magisterial as Empress Elisabeth in Corsage.
Triangle Of Sadness, a sharp satire of the moneyed class, has earned several awards and nominations, including the Oscar for Best Picture.

site_title: Europe: Shares dip after Powell’s hawkish remarks fuel rate hike fears
summary: European shares plummeted 0.8% on Tuesday, their largest one-day drop in two weeks, amid concerns of a potential 50-basis point rate hike by the US Federal Reserve following Jerome Powell's hawkish remarks. The Stoxx 600 index was hit hard, with real estate and technology stocks taking a sharp hit. The European Central Bank is also expected to raise rates, with Citigroup economists predicting a 50-basis point hike in March and May. Despite a 8.4% gain in European equities so far this year, markets are repricing the interest rate outlook, citing inflationary pressures and slowing wage growth.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index closed flat on Monday, after last week clocking its best week since the beginning of the year.

site_title: New contract lifts Lian Beng’s Singapore construction order book to S$2.1b
summary: Lian Beng Group has secured a new construction project in Singapore, boosting its construction order book to S$2.1 billion. The project is expected to provide a sustainable flow of activity through FY2027, according to the mainboard-listed company. No further details on the project were provided, and shares closed flat at S$0.53 following the announcement.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

site_title: Cryptoverse: Hooked on growth, bitcoin investors turn to smart tokens
summary: Bitcoin's growth is slowing, with investors shifting towards smart-contract tokens as they offer high growth potential. MarketVector's Smart Contract Leaders Index has risen 36% in 2023, outpacing Bitcoin's 33% gain. Solana's token is up 76% this year, and analysts at Bank of America see smart contract tokens as similar to growth stocks. The correlation between Bitcoin and tech stocks is weakening, with Bitcoin's 30-day correlation with the Nasdaq turning negative for the first time since December. However, the global macro outlook and central bank policy may still impact the growth of crypto projects and their associated tokens.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Smartphone with displayed Binance logo and representation of cryptocurrencies placed on a keyboard in this illustration taken November 8, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Malaysia central bank to hold rates at 2.75% in March, reach peak at 3% or higher in Q2: poll
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia (BNM), will hold its policy interest rate unchanged at 2.75% in March, but is expected to lift it to a cyclical peak of 3% or higher by the end of June, according to a Reuters poll of economists. The decision follows concerns over inflation and a weaker currency, with 13 of 22 economists forecasting interest rates to rise to 3% or higher by the end of June.

images.alt_text: The central bank has also increased its ability to defend the currency from volatility as foreign reserves rebounded from a two-year low reached in October.
Banks in Malaysia have posted sterling financial results in FY2022, thanks to healthy loan growth and increased interest income.

site_title: Thai central bank allowed to regulate auto leasing: ministry
summary: The Thai cabinet approved a law allowing the central bank to regulate the auto leasing sector, aiming to strengthen consumer protection and tackle household debt. The move comes as auto leasing transactions accounted for 12.4% of total household debt, on an upward trend. The central bank's soft loan programme for smaller firms will also be extended until early April 2024 to support business operators during the economic recovery.

site_title: Singapore shares marginally higher as investors await Fed chair’s testimony
summary: Singapore shares rose marginally, 0.2% or 5.96 points, to 3,245.27 points, as investors awaited Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's testimony on monetary policy. Asian markets followed, with most gaining ground. DFI Retail Group topped the Straits Times Index, while OKP Holdings shares skyrocketed 18% to a 52-week high after winning a $43.8 million arbitration case. Investors remain cautious, awaiting Powell's testimony for interest-rate forward movements.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
In early Asian trade on Tuesday, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Tokyo, Sydney, Singapore, Seoul, Taipei and Manila rose, though Wellington and Jakarta dipped.
Vincent Toe, CEO, Yangzijiang Financial Holding. The company is partnering with Singapore-based fund manager Tahan Capital Management to invest in private credit assets in Asia.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.1 per cent to 33,431.64, while the broad-based S&P 500 Index ticked up 0.1 per cent to 4,048.43 on Monday.

site_title: Poor weather, flooding to support Malaysia crude palm oil prices in near term: observers
summary: Malaysia's crude palm oil (CPO) prices are expected to rise in the first half of 2023 due to short-term disruptions caused by high rainfall, which has led to lower-than-expected production. The flooding in southern Peninsular Malaysia and East Kalimantan has resulted in short-term harvesting disruptions and poorer fruit quality, supporting higher CPO prices in the near term.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Indonesia, the world’s biggest exporter of palm oil, last year surprised buyers by banning palm oil exports.
Most Indonesian palm oil exporters currently conduct sales directly with buyers without going through an exchange.

A formerly forested area in Kapuas Hulu in West Kalimantan, Indonesia that has been cleared to make way for an oil palm plantation. A replanting scheme to boost output without clearing more forested land has failed to meet its targets for the past five years.

site_title: UK house prices bounce unexpectedly in February: Halifax
summary: UK house prices rose 1.1% month on month in February, following a 0.2% rise in January, according to Halifax. This unexpected increase contrasts with economists' expectations of a 0.3% drop. The improvement in consumer confidence may be driving the trend, which still indicates a downward overall trend in the housing market.

images.alt_text: Britain’s housing market has slowed in recent months, hurt by a dent in demand for new homes as higher borrowing costs and a surge in the cost of living deterred prospective buyers.
Britain’s largest homebuilders have already cut back their building targets as higher mortgage costs and economic uncertainty depressed buyer demand.

A residential building in St John's Wood, London. Despite the fall in house prices, homes are still becoming more unaffordable for first-time buyers, due to higher mortgage rates and shrinking real wages.
The trend of higher borrowing costs hitting demand is likely to continue in 2023.

site_title: China backs Sri Lanka debt plan, paving way for IMF loan: sources
summary: China has given written support for Sri Lanka's debt restructuring, potentially clearing the way for a $2.9 billion IMF bailout. This comes after China's largest bilateral creditor, the Export-Import Bank of China, provided assurances. Sri Lanka's president expects the IMF board's approval in three to four weeks, which could provide fresh funds from the Asian Development Bank and the World Bank.

images.alt_text: People walk past the main entrance of the Sri Lanka's Central Bank in Colombo, Sri Lanka March 24, 2017. REUTERS/Dinuka Liyanawatte
“China has suspended more debt service payments than any other G20 member, and participated in the debt treatment under the Common Framework.” China's Foreign Minister Qin Gang said.

site_title: BOE policymaker sees signs of ‘revival’ in UK housing market
summary: UK Bank of England policymaker Catherine Mann sees signs of a "revival" in the UK housing market, citing a reduction in mortgage rates and increased competition among lenders. Halifax reported a 1.1% rise in house prices last month, the second increase this year, and a 2.1% increase from a year ago. Mann played down concerns over a housing slump, noting that prices have only depreciated by 28% since the pandemic, compared to the 50% rise in the previous two years.

images.alt_text: Catherine Mann, member of the monetary policy committee at the Bank of England (BOE), during a Bloomberg Television interview in London, UK, on Tuesday, March 7, 2023. Mann said the pound could weaken further in the coming months as investors absorb the implication of the US Federal Reserve and European Central Bank’s plans to raise interest rates. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

site_title: When governments intervene
summary: Governments worldwide are increasingly intervening in business, with the US and other countries acting with fewer constraints due to the pandemic and rising nationalism. Protectionist policies, such as the Inflation Reduction Act, favor domestic production of critical components, impacting global trade and competition. This trend is expected to continue, with companies adapting to navigate these changing regulations and ensuring their competitiveness in the market.

images.alt_text: A printed balloon with Chinese flag is placed on a U.S. flag in the shape of U.S. map outline, in this illustration taken February 5, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration
US companies are banned from exporting to the listed entities without prior government approval.

site_title: Shipping body responds to proposal to hasten decarbonisation of global commercial fleet
summary: The International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) has proposed a Fund and Reward (F&R) measure to accelerate the decarbonization of the global commercial fleet, aiming for net-zero CO2 emissions by 2050. The proposal, which includes a contribution system to incentivize the production and uptake of low and zero-carbon fuels, could be developed if technical regulations are required. ICS deputy secretary general Simon Bennett emphasized that the system will not be a tax, but rather a contribution system to support the industry's transition to a low-carbon future.

images.alt_text: Many energy companies, machinery manufacturers, shipping companies and other maritime-related organisations are working flat out to move towards zero carbon.

site_title: China's Xi has mixed feelings about CATL's pole position in battery market
summary: China's President Xi Jinping expressed mixed feelings about CATL's status as the world's largest battery maker, citing both happiness and worry due to the risks associated with its leading position. Xi's remarks came after a presentation by CATL chairman Zeng Yuqun, who highlighted the company's 37% global battery market share. Xi's concerns are amid CATL's rapid expansion abroad and efforts to undercut domestic rivals.

images.alt_text: Given CATL’s lithium access is secure, industry sources said the sale was more likely about booking profits given a slide underway in prices of lithium and its producers.
FILE PHOTO: A security guard stands outside the headquarters building of China Securities Regulatory Commission in Beijing, September 7, 2015. REUTERS/Jason Lee/File Photo
CATL will be joining other Chinese companies in tapping the European market, as lingering geopolitical risks and regulatory woes reduce the appeal of other offshore markets such as the US.

site_title: HSBC China says it’s unaware of remittance curbs after Mobius’ claims
summary: HSBC China's unit stated it's unaware of any policy changes restricting outbound remittances, contradicting billionaire Mark Mobius' claim that he couldn't take money out of the country. The foreign exchange regulator also denied any policy changes, reaffirming its commitment to promoting cross-border remittances and opening-up to the world.

images.alt_text: Hundreds of retail investors in Hong Kong — HSBC’s biggest market — were particularly upset when it scrapped its dividend in 2020 during the Covid-19 pandemic.
In a filing to the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, HSBC said the perpetual bond’s coupon had been set at 8 per cent.
Globally, HSBC is looking to cut office space by 40 per cent from pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: China warns US: Stop suppression or risk 'conflict'
summary: China's Foreign Minister Qin Gang warned the US that if it continues to suppress and contain China, "conflict and confrontation" will follow. Qin accused the US of having a "distorted" attitude towards China, viewing it as its primary rival, and likened the situation to a race where one side tries to trip the other up. Qin defended China's assertive diplomacy, known as "wolf warrior diplomacy," and reiterated China's call for dialogue to end the war in Ukraine, while also expressing support for Russia.

images.alt_text: In his work report, outgoing Premier Li Keqiang stresses the need for economic stability and expanding consumption, setting a goal to create around 12 million urban jobs this year, up from last year’s target of at least 11 million, and warns that risks remain in the real estate sector.
The envisioned data regulator would have powers to investigate the use of software algorithms to manipulate data or encourage Internet addiction.

Yi said in Beijing on Friday (Mar 3) that real interest rates are at a relatively appropriate level. He hinted at supporting the economy in other ways, saying cuts to the reserve requirement ratio remain an effective way for the People’s Bank of China to provide long-term liquidity.

site_title: Is the 30% rebound in Asian high yield sustainable? We think not
summary: Asian high-yield bonds have surged by 30% since November 2022, driven by supportive policies for the property sector. However, the rally is likely short-lived due to persistent default risk in China's property sector and uncertainty surrounding the sector's outlook. Country Garden's large-scale residential development in Tier 3 and Tier 4 cities highlights the limitations of policy support, suggesting that investors should steer clear of Asian high-yield bonds. The rebound is not sustainable, and investors should exercise caution.

images.alt_text: Premier Li Keqiang announced the goal for GDP in his final report to the Communist Party-controlled parliament, which kicked off its annual meeting on Sunday.
Chinese President Xi Jinping said that private firms should share the fruits of their growth with employees more equitably, in what he called a “community of shared interests”.

site_title: Henkel to lose momentum in 2023 after jump in sales
summary: Henkel, the maker of Persil detergents and Schwarzkopf haircare products, expects slower industrial and consumer demand to curb sales growth in 2023, following a 8.8% organic sales jump in 2022. The company forecasts organic sales to grow 1-3% this year, down from 22.39 billion euros in 2022. Despite this, Henkel aims to increase its adjusted return on sales to 10-12%, from 8.1% in 2022.

site_title: China iron ore imports rise 7.3% on year in January-February
summary: China's iron ore imports rose 7.3% in January-February, reaching 194 million tonnes, driven by anticipation of higher domestic steel demand after the government lifted Covid-19 containment measures. This growth is in line with expectations, with miners shipping more volume to China due to lacklustre demand in other markets. China's exports of steel products also increased 49% to 12.19 million tonnes in the first two months of the year.

site_title: Grab retires US$600 million in 2026 debt with extra cash
summary: Grab Holdings has prepaid US$600 million in debt ahead of its 2026 maturity, reducing its outstanding term loan to US$517 million. The move is seen as a strategic decision to generate interest savings, given the current macroeconomic environment. Grab's cash position is healthy, allowing it to take advantage of this opportunity. This may also help the company achieve its earlier break-even goal even in a slowing economy.

images.alt_text: An illustration on the Grab website shows that a S$1,500 cash advance, payable over one year, would be charged a S$120 admin fee
While Grab posted an impressive drop in losses, the market appears to think the opposite of analysts.

site_title: Book review: The enduring value of Roger Murray
summary: CFA Singapore has reviewed the book "The Enduring Value of Roger Murray" by Paul Johnson and Paul D Sonkin, restoring confidence in fundamental analysis, especially value investing. The book explores Murray's contributions as a dynamic successor to Benjamin Graham and David Dodd, emphasizing the importance of uncovering a stock's intrinsic value. Murray's approach to fundamental analysis is seen as a dynamic successor to Graham and Dodd, making the book a valuable resource for investors.

images.alt_text: With the exception of Apple, eight tech giants are no longer "pure growth" stocks, while Exxon and Chevron are, a new study says. Buyer, beware.
Some businesses grow even in recession. Apple's revenues rose between 2007 and 2009, despite one of the worst recessions in US' modern history.

site_title: One ‘R’ word to rule them all
summary: Investors face a challenging economic environment due to the uncertainty of whether an economic recession or recovery is likely. Rising interest rates are expected to contribute to recovery, but also risk tipping the economy into recession. Chart analysis suggests a downtrend line has changed its function from resistance to support, favoring a recession outlook. However, the Dow shows a similar downtrend breakout, adding support for a recession scenario. The lack of consensus creates a difficult investment environment, with cautious investors waiting for trend confirmation and aggressive investors entering early in anticipation of a trend change, managing risk with reduced exposure to the market and defensive stocks.

images.alt_text: Alibaba headquarters in China's eastern Zhejiang province. Fundamentals of China's new-economy sector have remained resilient, and the sector is expected to shine again.
Mortgage rates have topped 7 per cent - more than double the rates last year, adding hundreds of dollars to the average monthly mortgage payment

site_title: New China Fund plans 30% job cuts after US$4.2 billion outflows
summary: New China Fund, a Chinese mutual fund manager, plans to cut up to 30% of its 200 employees as its new controlling shareholder seeks to revive growth following a significant asset slump. The company's assets under management fell nearly 34% in the second half of last year, amid market volatility. The job cuts are part of the company's efforts to strengthen risk management and promote long-term stable operations. The move highlights the challenges faced by smaller players in the 27 trillion yuan mutual fund industry.

site_title: The 30-year battle to reform France’s pension system
summary: France is bracing for mass protests against President Emmanuel Macron's plan to raise the retirement age from 62 to 64. The six-day nationwide demonstrations, which began in January, have drawn large crowds, including a million-plus in two rallies. The pension reform is the culmination of a 30-year battle by governments of both the left and right to streamline France's generous pension system. Union leaders vow to bring the country to a standstill, as Macron's plan faces growing opposition and public discontent.

images.alt_text: The euro was 0.5 per cent lower against the US dollar at US$1.0618.

site_title: Lego looks to build on 2022 sales growth with more China stores
summary: Lego plans to open 145 new stores this year, mostly in China, as part of its expansion efforts. The company reported 17% sales growth in 2022, reaching 64.6 billion Danish krone ($12.5 billion), driven by strong demand in Western Europe and the Americas. Lego aims to outpace the market this year, with a total of over 900 stores globally, and expects "really good momentum" to continue, according to CEO Niels Christiansen.

site_title: Can the West’s perplexing employment miracle continue?
summary: The West's employment miracle continues, with little sign of job losses despite slowing GDP growth and reduced business confidence. The unemployment rate across the OECD is 4.9%, the lowest in many decades, with many countries having a higher share of working-age people in jobs. Japan's labor market is cited as an example of this trend, with employers reluctant to fire workers due to difficulties in rehiring. However, this could have disadvantages, such as reduced productivity growth, and may be a sign of structural issues, including an aging population and labor shortages.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - OCTOBER 07: People walk along Wall Street by the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on October 07, 2022 in New York City. Stocks fell in early trading on Friday as new employment numbers show steady hiring which investors fear will lead to increased interest rate hikes.   Spencer Platt/Getty Images/AFP
A robotic arm picks up sorting containers at an Amazon fulfillment centre in the United States.

site_title: Stocks with higher percentage of women in management perform better: BofA
summary: Bank of America (BofA) found that companies with a higher percentage of women in management outperform those with lower proportions by 26 percentage points over a 5-year period and 4 percentage points over the benchmark index. Stocks with more women managers also have higher average returns on equity, more attractive ESG rankings, and lower cost of capital. Women made up 24% of board members in MSCI AC World Index companies in 2022, up from 18% in 2018.

images.alt_text: Women earn only 51 cents for each US dollar of labour income generated by men, the ILO wrote in the study.
McKinsey found that companies with the highest percentage of women on their executive committees bring about a 55 per cent premium in operating results.

site_title: Meta plans thousands more layoffs as soon as this week
summary: Meta, the owner of Facebook and Instagram, plans thousands of layoffs, expected to be finalized in the next week, as the company aims to become more efficient. This round of cuts follows a 13% reduction in November and an earlier round of 11,000 layoffs in 2023, driven by financial targets and a shift in focus to the metaverse. The layoffs are separate from the company's "flattening" efforts, which include buyout packages for managers and cutting non-essential teams. The move comes as workers express heightened anxiety and low morale amid uncertainty about bonuses.

site_title: Dufry annual turnover jumps as international travel rebounds
summary: Dufry, a Swiss duty-free retailer, reported a 76.1% organic turnover growth in 2022, reaching 6.88 billion Swiss francs (S$9.9 billion), driven by a strong rebound in global travel post-pandemic restrictions. The company's turnover was 22% below the pre-pandemic 2019 level. Dufry's management decided against proposing a dividend for 2022 to focus on strengthening the company's financial position and closing the business combination with Autogrill. The retailer confirmed its medium-term outlook for 2023 to 2027.

site_title: After US$15 billion award, sultan’s heirs target Malaysian properties in Paris
summary: French bailiffs attempted to enforce a seizure order on three Paris properties owned by the Malaysian government, linked to a US$15 billion court award to descendants of a former sultan. However, Malaysian officials at the Paris embassy turned them away. The heirs, seeking to settle a colonial-era land deal dispute, had received a US$14.9 billion award from a French arbitration court last year. The heirs are targeting Malaysian properties in Paris, with Luxembourg court bailiffs issuing fresh seizure orders for two units of Petronas.

images.alt_text: The Petronas Azerbaijan (Shah Deniz) and Petronas South Caucasus units were first seized in July 2022, but the Malaysian government said last month that the order had been set aside by a Luxembourg district court.
Malaysia’s law minister Azalina Othman Said said the District Court of Luxembourg on Tuesday had set aside a request for an “attachment order” made by the Sulu heirs.
A logo of Petronas is seen at their office in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, April 27, 2022. Picture taken on April 27, 2022. REUTERS/Hasnoor Hussain
Malaysia will not entertain any territorial claim over Sabah

site_title: JTC reviewing self-storage operators’ use of industrial space
summary: JTC Corporation is reviewing the use of industrial space by self-storage operators amid rising demand for self-storage services. The review comes as the industry has evolved, with self-storage operators catering to a broader customer base, including small businesses and online businesses. Operators report high occupancy rates and increased demand for space, with rents rising 5-10% over the past two years. The review may lead to changes in regulations, with JTC considering whether self-storage falls under the logistics sector or requires a separate categorization. The outcome is expected to be announced by mid-year.

Many private homes in Singapore are getting smaller for good reasons.
About 70 per cent of Extra Space Asia's customers are using the facility to store their personal belongings and 30 percent are companies storing their inventories.

site_title: Asian palm oil buyers seek stable export policies from producers
summary: Asian palm oil buyers are urging producing countries, particularly Indonesia and Malaysia, to establish stable export policies due to recent volatility in the market. The Asian Palm Oil Alliance, comprising countries such as India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh, wants to add more buyers and resolve the issue of higher export duties on crude palm oil compared to refined oil. Producers must consider the impact of their policies on refineries and buyers, with major producers often prioritizing European buyers over Asian ones.

images.alt_text: Most Indonesian palm oil exporters currently conduct sales directly with buyers without going through an exchange.

A formerly forested area in Kapuas Hulu in West Kalimantan, Indonesia that has been cleared to make way for an oil palm plantation. A replanting scheme to boost output without clearing more forested land has failed to meet its targets for the past five years.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Yangzijiang Financial, OKP
summary: Yangzijiang Financial Holding is partnering Singapore-based fund manager Tahan Capital Management to invest in private credit assets in Asia, aiming to diversify its portfolio and promote sustainable growth. OKP Holdings' unit Or Kim Peow Contractors has been awarded S$43.8 million in an arbitration case related to a 2017 accident, expected to positively impact the group's financial performance. These developments may affect trading of the companies' securities.

site_title: Harnessing the power of female talent
summary: Singapore's 2023 Budget invests in supporting businesses and equipping workers with digital skills, aiming to tap into the country's underutilized female talent. Despite a lower employment rate among women (60.9% compared to 74.4% for men), 90.2% of women aged 25-34 have post-secondary education qualifications. The government has introduced measures to support working mothers, extended parental leave, and flexible working arrangements to encourage women's participation in the economy. Enabling women to thrive in emerging fields can boost the talent pool and create better business outcomes, while addressing the digital skills gap through targeted reskilling and upskilling programs.

images.alt_text: McKinsey found that companies with the highest percentage of women on their executive committees bring about a 55 per cent premium in operating results.

site_title: India’s Adani Group pre-pays over 73.74 billion rupees worth share-backed financing
summary: India's Adani Group prepaid 73.74 billion rupees worth of share-backed financing as part of its efforts to ease concerns over its credit profile. The move comes after a US-based short seller alleged high debt and improper use of offshore tax havens and stock manipulation, which Adani denied. Promoters of Adani Group's listed companies will release shares worth 31 million, 155 million, 1.2%, and 4.5% stakes. This repayment brings the group's total share-backed financing repayment to around $2.02 billion.

site_title: Philippines’ core inflation clocks fastest increase since 1999
summary: The Philippines' core inflation rate surged to its fastest pace in 24 years, rising 7.8% in February from a year ago, exceeding the 2-4% target. This is a significant increase from the previous month's 7.4%. Headline inflation, although slightly slower at 8.6%, still exceeds the target. The Philippine Central Bank expects inflation to remain above the target until early in the fourth quarter, indicating that policymakers may retain their tightening bias despite the slowdown. This suggests continued economic pressure and potential challenges for the country's economic growth.

images.alt_text: A security guard stands beside a logo of the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (Central Bank of the Philippines) posted at the main gate in Manila, Philippines April 28, 2016.    REUTERS/Romeo Ranoco/File Photo
President Ferdinand Marcos’ administration and business leaders had lobbied the Senate to ratify the pact, citing benefits for local consumers, businesses and the wider economy.
Inflation in the Philippines is running at 14-year highs, with January's rate coming in at a faster-than-expected 8.7 per cent.

site_title: Australia’s sovereign wealth fund screening for Chinese firms at risk of US bans
summary: Australia's Future Fund is screening its portfolio for Chinese companies at risk of US investment restrictions, following the Biden administration's plan to ban investments in some Chinese technology firms and increase scrutiny of others. The move aims to avoid losses similar to those experienced by Western investments in Russia after sanctions effectively shut foreign investors out of the country.

images.alt_text: Australia has posted monthly trade surpluses since January 2018, underpinned by sales of iron ore and natural gas.
The firm advanced enough to produce a machine that could print circuit patterns as tiny as 90 nanometres (nm) on silicon wafers — two decades behind ASML
The move has drawn an angry response from China, with the Ministry of Commerce urging the US to stop “unreasonable suppression” of Chinese firms.

site_title: IMF temporarily boosts fund limits to help members beat crisis
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has temporarily increased funding limits for member nations to help them overcome current economic challenges. The annual limit under the General Resources Account will be raised to 200% of quota for 12 months, and access to cumulative limits will be revised to 600% from 435%. This move aims to provide emerging markets and developing economies with access to funds without triggering tougher conditions. The IMF will review the higher limits if the circumstances warrant it.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A participant stands near a logo of IMF at the International Monetary Fund - World Bank Annual Meeting 2018 in Nusa Dua, Bali, Indonesia, October 12, 2018. REUTERS/Johannes P. Christo/File Photo

site_title: Australia central bank tempers hawkish outlook after hiking rates to over decade high
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) raised its cash rate to 3.6%, the highest in over a decade, but tempered its hawkish outlook after wages growth came in below expectations. The rate hike was the 10th straight move since May, but the central bank suggested it might be nearly done tightening as consumer spending slowed. The RBA dropped a reference to further rate increases, leaving open the possibility of a pause in April.

images.alt_text: Australia has posted monthly trade surpluses since January 2018, underpinned by sales of iron ore and natural gas.

site_title: Rivian plans to sell US$1.3 billion in bonds to shore up capital, shares fall
summary: Rivian plans to sell $1.3 billion in bonds to shore up capital, which will mature in March 2029 and offer investors the option to convert to cash or shares. The move comes as the electric vehicle maker faces a cash crunch due to weakening demand and high costs. Rivian's shares fell nearly 7% in after-hours trading.

images.alt_text: The company cites persistent supply-chain snarls sparked by the pandemic and bad weather that hampered production.

“Certainly, what we’re witnessing in the macro and what we’re seeing in terms of interest rate is ... across the industry, having an effective moderating overall demand,” Rivian chief executive RJ Scaringe said

site_title: German factory orders unexpectedly jump at start of year
summary: German factory orders unexpectedly increased by 1% in January, exceeding a 0.7% decline predicted by a Bloomberg survey. The jump was primarily driven by capital goods, including aircraft and motor vehicle engines. Despite a 0.4% decline in output in the final quarter of last year, the improvement in orders suggests the manufacturing sector has some grounds for optimism, potentially mitigating the risk of a recession due to higher energy bills and rising borrowing costs.

site_title: Stripe faces US$3.5 billion tax bill as employees’ shares expire
summary: Stripe, a US$55 billion payments giant, plans to use its latest fundraising to cover a US$3.5 billion tax bill. The company aims to raise US$2.3 billion and will withhold additional taxes of US$500 million and US$700 million in the next two years. The funds will also be used to exercise employee options, totaling US$600 million. Stripe has maintained that the fundraising is not needed to fund normal business operations, contradicting its previous statements.

images.alt_text: Stripe was among tech firms that spent more heavily on adding talent and pushing into new areas during the depths of the pandemic when it saw spending volumes soar.

summary: Investors should position their portfolios to navigate higher-for-longer interest rates amid sticky US inflation and strong jobs data. A Liquid+ Strategy can help generate income, but investors still need growth boosters, such as an allocation to China's new-economy sector, which has shown resilient fundamentals. The sector is expected to shine again, driven by Asia's growth and dollar asset diversification.

site_title: Business leaders push tech agenda at China’s ‘Two Sessions’
summary: Business leaders in China's tech industry have proposed various agendas for the country's development during this year's 'Two Sessions'. Xiaomi CEO Lei Jun suggested strengthening auto data security, while Sinopec Zhenhai's chairman Mo Dingge proposed accelerating the commercial use of aviation biofuel. JuneYao Group chairman Wang Junjin focused on promoting the sale of new-energy vehicles (NEVs) in rural areas, suggesting consumer subsidies and tax exemptions to encourage adoption. These proposals aim to support China's 'dual carbon' goals and drive growth in key industries.

summary: Two freehold sites, Kingsley Mansion and Roselane Court, in Singapore are up for sale by public tender. Kingsley Mansion, located in District 12, has a guide price of S$52 million and offers 18 apartment units, while Roselane Court, in District 15, has a guide price of S$23 million. The tenders for both sites will close on April 12 and April 5, respectively, with strong interest expected from developers due to the limited supply of freehold housing stock in the areas.

site_title: Meta must face trial over AI trade secrets: judge
summary: Meta Platforms Inc. will face a trial over allegations that it stole Neural Magic's "breakthrough" algorithms that enable AI systems to process information more quickly. US District Judge Denise Casper ruled that Meta must face a trial, despite the company's attempt to dismiss the case. An expert testified that Meta owes Neural Magic up to $766 million in royalties. The trial is set to begin in September, with Neural Magic accusing Meta of misappropriating 41 trade secrets.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise ahead of Powell testimony, US jobs data
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday ahead of US jobs data and Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell's testimony, with gains seen in Hong Kong, Shanghai, Tokyo, Sydney, and Singapore. The release of key US jobs data and Powell's remarks are expected to influence the central bank's plans to quell inflation, with several officials warning of higher interest rates. Traders anticipate two or three more quarter-point rises before the Fed holds fire, potentially impacting investor optimism and risk appetite.

images.alt_text: The Nikkei 225 jumped over one per cent in early trade, with gains posted in Taipei, Seoul, Jakarta, and Sydney.

site_title: Japan’s January real wages drop at fastest pace since 2014
summary: Japan's real wages dropped 4.1% in January, the largest decline since May 2014, due to four-decade-high inflation, squeezing consumer purchasing power. This follows a 0.6% decline in December and underlines the impact of inflation on households' buying power. Despite major firms such as Toyota and Nintendo announcing pay rises, real wages fell short of the 5.1% inflation rate used to calculate pay in real terms. The decline in real wages is a concern for the Bank of Japan, which has been monitoring wage trends to gauge the need for monetary policy adjustments.

images.alt_text: The wage negotiations highlight the difficulties Japan is facing in getting large-scale wage rises to take hold amid higher food and fuel prices.
Japanese so-called super-long bonds have managed to shake off the global angst about sticky inflation and higher-than-expected peak rates.

site_title: The Republican Party’s dangerous drift towards isolationism
summary: The Republican Party's shift towards isolationism has raised concerns, particularly under pressure from the Trumpist and isolationist wing. House Speaker Kevin McCarthy's stance against providing a "blank cheque" for US aid to Ukraine reflects this trend. Many Republican lawmakers, including some presidential candidates, have expressed sympathy for Russian President Vladimir Putin and questioned US President Joe Biden's handling of the conflict. This drift towards isolationism and nationalism contradicts the party's historical support for liberal democracy and international cooperation, sparking fears of erosion of American backing for Ukraine's fight for independence.

site_title: An economic test of wills in Ukraine
summary: The Ukraine war has become a war of attrition, with Ukraine's superior morale and leadership providing an initial advantage. However, the decisive factor is the balance of resources, with Ukraine's negligible economic potential pitted against the West's combined GDP of nearly $45 trillion. Despite declarations of solidarity, the West's material aid to Ukraine remains inadequate, with only a few dozen German-made tanks having been delivered. Russia's superior quantity of military equipment and potential fighters pose a significant challenge, and Western leaders may need to double or triple their support for Ukraine to give it a decisive material advantage.

images.alt_text: China’s role in the Russia-Ukraine war is expected to be among the topics when Biden meets with German Chancellor Olaf Scholz at the White House on Friday.

site_title: After completing two mega telco mergers, Telenor Asia seeks to strengthen its market position
summary: Telenor Asia, a subsidiary of Norway's telecom giant Telenor Group, has finalized the merger of Thailand's True Corporation and Total Access Communication (DTAC), the second and third-largest mobile operators in Thailand, worth US$20.7 billion. This move aims to strengthen Telenor's market position and compete with other telcos in the region. Jorgen Rostrup, executive vice-president of Telenor Group and head of Telenor Asia, believes that more mergers and partnerships are needed to meet changing consumer demands and increase profitability.

The merger between Celcom and Digi is expected to be completed within the second half of 2022.

site_title: Sias needs to play hardball to help minority investors fend off lowball offers
summary: Sias, the Securities Investors Association of Singapore, has urged Boustead Singapore to raise its offer price for Boustead Projects to a more reasonable level, citing the company's net asset value (NAV) of S$1.265 per share. The current offer price of S$0.95 is seen as lowball, with shares trading at S$0.99 prior to the offer. Sias has also called on Golden Energy and Resources (Gear) to improve its proposed break-up and delisting terms, citing the company's assets and potential for growth. Sias is considering shifting its approach from pleading with controlling shareholders to rallying minority investors to reject inadequate offers.

site_title: Gold prices in tight range ahead of Powell testimony
summary: Gold prices remained in a tight range ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's Congressional testimony, trading down 0.1% at $1,845.45 per ounce. The dollar index edged up, making gold less affordable for buyers holding other currencies. Investors await Powell's testimony for hints on interest rate policy, with market expectations of a 25-basis-point rate hike at the March 21-22 meeting. The US jobs report for February is due on Friday, and data showed global supply chains have returned to normal, potentially pointing to softening inflation.

images.alt_text: Although gold is considered a hedge against inflation, interest rate hikes to bring down price pressures increase the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

site_title: US wants hike in global crude output, including from Opec: official
summary: The US wants to see a hike in global crude oil production, including from Opec countries, due to expected increased consumption as economies recover. US Undersecretary of State Jose Fernandez stated that supply should meet demand. Opec+, which cut production by 2 million barrels per day in October, has maintained its output level since. The US has been calling for an increase in Opec+ production, but the cartel has not raised its quotas in six months, resulting in a 40% increase in oil prices compared to 2019.

site_title: Australia to diversify trade, foreign investment, says PM Albanese ahead of India visit
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Anthony Albanese announced plans to diversify the country's international trade and foreign investment, aiming for a more resilient and secure economy. He will lead a business delegation to India, a key trading partner, to strengthen bilateral ties. Australia seeks to reduce its reliance on China, its current largest trading partner, and explore new markets for its critical minerals and energy products. The move aims to deepen Australia's relationships with countries like India, Japan, and South Korea, while maintaining its status as a trusted energy supplier.

site_title: Dominance of dollar in crypto market wanes as drawbacks mount
summary: The dominance of the US dollar in the crypto market is waning as institutions increasingly turn to stablecoins, which are pegged to dollars. The collapse of FTX and a shrinking US payment network have contributed to this shift. As a result, the trading volume of dollar-denominated Bitcoin is dropping, while euro- and Tether-denominated trading pairs are gaining traction. This trend may lead to stablecoins becoming even more prevalent in the short term, but their long-term viability is uncertain due to the need for access to crypto-friendly banks.

site_title: US banks are finally being forced to raise rates on deposits
summary: US banks are being forced to raise rates on deposits for the first time in 15 years as depositors seek higher-yielding options amid rising interest rates. Commercial bank deposits fell last year for the first time since 1948, with net withdrawals reaching $278 billion. To stem the outflows, banks are increasing rates on certificates of deposit (CDs) and other deposits, with over a dozen lenders offering 5% annual interest rates. The move is expected to slow down lending and increase writedowns for the US banking industry, with smaller regional banks being the hardest hit.
