site_title: Parliament approves S$123.7 billion Budget as debate ends with call for MPs to avoid polarisation, populism
summary: Singapore's Parliament approved a budget of S$123.7 billion for the financial year, following a two-week debate. Leader of the House Indranee Rajah emphasized the need for MPs to avoid polarization and populism, citing examples of countries like the US where deep divisions led to ugly outcomes. The budget aims to position Singapore well for the post-pandemic future, with measures to support lower-wage workers, housing, and workforce development. Parliament Speaker Tan Chuan-Jin called for MPs to agree to disagree and come together to support a shared agenda. The budget's approval marks an important step for the country, with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressing confidence in the government's ability to stay relevant.

site_title: Kakao offers to buy 35% of K-pop label SM to fend off rival Hybe
summary: Kakao, backed by Saudi Arabia's wealth fund and Singapore's GIC, is launching a tender offer to buy up to 35% of K-pop label SM Entertainment for 150,000 won per share, valuing the offer at 1.25 trillion won. The bid is an attempt to fend off rival Hybe, which had secured a 14.8% stake in SM from founder Lee Soo-man but failed to get much support for its own offer. If successful, Kakao's bid could help stabilize SM's management and secure intellectual property of K-pop talent for overseas expansion.

site_title: US: Stocks rise slightly ahead of Federal Reserve testimony
summary: US stocks rose slightly on Monday, ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's testimony before Congress. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 Index ticked up 0.1%, while the Nasdaq Composite Index lost 0.1%. Powell's testimony is expected to provide insights into the central bank's efforts to counter inflation, influencing market movements. The key jobs data and jobs report for February will also inform the Fed's next meeting, potentially impacting risk appetite.

site_title: Global food system emissions imperil Paris climate goals
summary: Scientists warn that the global food system's greenhouse gas emissions will add nearly 1 deg C to Earth's surface temperatures by 2100, exceeding Paris Agreement climate goals. The sector accounts for 15% of current warming levels, mainly due to methane from livestock and rice paddies (60%), and CO2 from machinery and transport (20%). To mitigate emissions, a major overhaul of the food system is needed, including changes in production methods, diets, and waste reduction. Improving production methods for meat, dairy, and rice alone could reduce additional warming by a quarter, while adopting a healthy diet and using renewables could cut another 25%.

site_title: Germany planning to ban Huawei, ZTE from parts of 5G networks: report
summary: Germany's government is planning to ban the use of certain components from Chinese companies Huawei and ZTE in its 5G networks, citing security concerns. The ban could require telecoms operators to remove and replace existing components, and is part of a broader re-evaluation of Germany's relationship with China. The move follows Germany's 2021 IT security law, which set high hurdles for telecommunications equipment makers. Huawei and ZTE deny claims of close links to China's security services, saying they are motivated by protectionism. The ban is expected to impact the German 5G networks.

site_title: Twitter suffers major outage disabling external links
summary: Twitter experienced a major outage, disabling external links worldwide, on March 7, 2023. The issue was attributed to "unintended consequences" from an update to the platform, which was trying to stabilize after significant layoffs. The outage lasted less than an hour and was blamed on Twitter's reduced staff, making the platform vulnerable to outages and disinformation. This comes as the company seeks new revenue streams and faces a decline in advertisers due to chaos under Elon Musk's ownership.

site_title: United Airlines passenger tried to stab flight attendant, US prosecutors say
summary: A 33-year-old United Airlines passenger, Francisco Severo Torres, has been arrested after trying to open an emergency exit door and stabbing a flight attendant with a broken metal spoon during a flight from Los Angeles to Boston. Passengers tackled Torres, and the flight crew helped restrain him before the plane landed. Torres, from Massachusetts, was charged with one count of interference and attempted interference with flight crew members and attendants using a dangerous weapon. He faces up to life in prison if convicted and has been held without bail.

site_title: Paramount Global mulls sale of majority stake in BET
summary: Paramount Global is considering selling a majority stake in BET Media Group, which includes the BET cable network, BET Studios, and VH1. The company hopes to maintain a minority stake to benefit from potential value unlocked by the transaction. BET, an entertainment brand focused on the Black community, is expected to attract interest from Black investors or institutions. The sale was first reported by The Wall Street Journal, following Paramount's partnerships with Tyler Perry and Kenya Barris.

site_title: Europe: Shares wipe gains on hawkish remarks from ECB officials
summary: European shares closed flat on Monday, wiping out gains from the previous week, after European Central Bank officials hinted at further interest rate hikes. Euro zone retail sales rose 0.3% month-on-month but declined 2.3% year-on-year, highlighting weak consumer demand. Major movers included Deutsche Lufthansa, which gained 6%, and Helvetia Holding, which rose 4.5% after reporting earnings beats. The Stoxx 600 index remained flat, with some sectors, including basic resources, falling due to a drop in base metal prices.

site_title: Singapore’s energy decarbonisation must be pragmatic
summary: Singapore should preserve its leading position in the oil and gas industry until it's ready to transition to net zero, argues Tan Wooi Leong. The country has made strides in committing to a carbon-free future through the Singapore Green Plan 2030 and Energy 2050 Plan, but must balance ideals with the realities of the present. Pragmatism is key, as decarbonisation is not immune to hiccups and speed bumps, and a cautious approach is needed to mitigate the gap between renewable energy suppliers and consumers.

site_title: JPMorgan expects another busy year for dealmakers in India
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co. predicts another busy year for dealmakers in India, despite recent challenges to the country's allure. India sealed its busiest M&A year ever in 2022 with $191 billion in transactions. Geopolitical tensions may propel companies to diversify into the nation, driving decent deal flow. Smaller transactions, primarily in the $500 million to $2 billion range, are expected to drive deal flow this year, with key sectors including healthcare, energy, and technology.

site_title: Kilicdaroglu: Turkey’s ‘quiet force’ taking on Erdogan
summary: Turkey's main opposition Republican People's Party (CHP) leader Kemal Kilicdaroglu has been chosen as the party's presidential candidate, marking a significant shift in the country's politics. Kilicdaroglu, a 74-year-old former civil servant, has transformed his party's image, embracing minority groups and forging alliances with right-wing parties. His quiet and disciplined approach contrasts with President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's bombastic style. Kilicdaroglu's rise to prominence was marked by a "march for justice" in 2017, which allowed him to confront Erdogan and gain national attention. He has since become a thorn in Erdogan's side, accusing the government of corruption and lax building standards. Kilicdaroglu's election would be historic, as he would be the first Alevi to head the Turkish state.

images.alt_text: The Feb 6 earthquakes of 7.8 magnitude and 7.5 magnitude, the most deadly in modern Turkey’s history, killed more than 44,300 people.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Tuesday; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.1% in early trade on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,236.61. Losers outnumbered gainers 57 to 52, with Sembcorp Marine and Thomson Medical Group being among the top traded counters. Local banks UOB and OCBC rose, while DBS fell. The decline follows mixed activity in US and European markets, where the Dow Jones and S&P 500 rose, while the Nasdaq Composite fell.

site_title: Smiley, dimpled sphinx statue unearthed in Egypt
summary: Egyptian archaeologists have discovered a sphinx statue with a smiley face and two dimples near the Hathor Temple, a 500-kilometer south of Cairo. The limestone artefact is believed to be a stylized representation of an ancient Roman emperor, possibly Emperor Claudius. A Roman stele with demotic and hieroglyphic scripts was also found near the statue, which may shed light on the identity of the sculpted ruler. The discovery is part of a series of archaeological finds in Egypt, aimed at boosting tourism and reviving the country's economy.

site_title: US opens probe into Amazon’s Zoox robotaxi self-certification
summary: The US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) has opened an audit probe into Amazon's self-driving vehicle unit Zoox's self-certification of a robotaxi without traditional driving controls in 2022. The probe aims to determine if Zoox's certification basis depended on unilaterally developed test procedures. Zoox has stated its self-certification tests met federal performance requirements and is committed to working with NHTSA. The company's robotaxi, which has successfully tested with employees as passengers, is expected to bring the vehicle closer to commercial service, pending additional government clearances.

images.alt_text: Zoox, which Amazon acquired in 2020 for an undisclosed sum, is racing a collection of startups, including General Motors’s Cruise, to deploy robotaxis.
CEO of Zoox, Aicha Evans said she believes the development of Zoox’s so-called robotaxis is the “beginning of a wave” for autonomous driving.

site_title: How Vietnam elected the country’s youngest-ever president
summary: Vietnam's National Assembly elected 52-year-old Vo Van Thuong as the country's youngest-ever president, succeeding Nguyen Xuan Phuc who stepped down amid a year-long anti-graft crackdown. Thuong, a lifelong party official, has been a safe pair of hands and is seen as a close ally of the party chief. His appointment is part of the "four pillars" of Vietnam's collective political power and is expected to enhance the party's leadership. The new president will represent Vietnam in domestic and foreign affairs and wield major ceremonial power, but has limited policy-making authority.

images.alt_text: President Nguyen Xuan Phuc resigned as president of Vietnam in January.
The youngest member of the Politburo, Vo Van Thuong  is now seen as one of the contenders to take over the role of Communist Party chief in 2026.

site_title: Job switching in growth sectors not merely driven by salaries: industry players
summary: Job switching in Singapore's growth sectors is driven by factors beyond just salaries, according to industry players and manpower agencies. The job switching rate hit a six-year high in 2022, with 16.8% of employed residents changing jobs in the last two years. The information and communications sector saw the highest job switching rate, followed by financial and insurance services, and professional services. While higher salaries were offered in tech, work-life balance and career growth opportunities were also key drivers for job switching. As the economy recovers, job switching may ease, with employers focusing on niche areas to close skills gaps.

images.alt_text: The number of job vacancies fell to 108,200 in September. Meanwhile, the ratio of job vacancies to unemployed persons also decreased to 2.20.
While the manufacturing sector appears more downcast, there are still pockets of growth segments which will be hiring, said OCBC chief economist Selena Ling.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as focus shifts to Powell’s testimony
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday, March 6, 2023, as Treasury yields retreated ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's testimony and jobs data this week. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.10%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gained 0.24% and 0.41%, respectively. The focus on Powell's testimony and upcoming jobs data may provide fresh cues on interest rate trajectory.

site_title: Asean telecom tower owners draw investors on structural growth, stable cash flows
summary: Telecom tower companies in South-east Asia are attracting investors seeking stable returns due to the region's growing mobile data usage and digitalization. A Boston Consulting Group report found that towercos generated an average annual 16% three-year total shareholder return, above the telco industry median of 9%. Companies like Edotco and Edgepoint Infrastructure are expanding rapidly, with Edgepoint's CEO attributing its growth to telcos optimizing their balance sheets and the Covid-19 pandemic surge in data usage. However, rising interest rates and potential consolidation of network operators may pose risks to the industry.

Thai telecoms group Advanced Info Service is considering selling stakes in its tower business, which could be valued between US$2 billion and US$3 billion, say sources.

site_title: Goldman says ‘buy Apple’ after years on sidelines of 300% advance
summary: Goldman Sachs is recommending a "buy" on Apple Inc. shares for the first time in nearly six years, citing the company's strong brand loyalty and growing services business. Analyst Michael Ng notes that Apple's installed base of users reduces churn, lowers acquisition costs, and encourages repeat purchases. The new price target of $199 implies 32% upside from the stock's last close, marking a significant change from the "neutral" or "sell" ratings under the previous analyst, Rod Hall.

site_title: Boeing and Airbus pair up to bid for UK's helicopter contract
summary: Boeing and Airbus have teamed up to bid for the UK's helicopter contract, which would provide helicopters for the Royal Air Force and British Army. If Airbus wins the contract, Boeing Defence UK will provide aircrew, ground crew, and maintenance training. The joint bid comes as the UK seeks to replace its ageing fleet of twin-engined medium transport helicopters, the Puma HC Mk2.

site_title: Vietnam police raid country’s biggest pawn shop operator amid “violations”
summary: Vietnamese police raided F88 Investment, the country's largest pawn shop operator, on March 6 amid public complaints of "administrative violations." Authorities found evidence of overcharging clients, extortion methods in debt collection, and threats to hundreds of thousands of people to repay debts. The Ministry of Public Security stated that F88's operations were not following procedures and regulations. The company's shareholders, including Mekong Capital, claim to have been informed of no irregularities by authorities and will take disciplinary measures if found guilty.

site_title: Meituan to restructure ride-hailing unit: letter
summary: Chinese tech giant Meituan plans to restructure its ride-hailing service, reducing resources and transferring staff to other business lines. The move follows a relaunch of the service as a standalone app in 2021, after regulators barred Didi Global from registering new users. Meituan aims to cut costs amid a slowing economy, after being hit by Covid-19 curbs last year. The decision comes as the company swings back to profit after reducing heavy investment in new initiatives.

images.alt_text: China’s reopening is expected to spur economic activity and benefit Meituan in the longer run.
Meituan, whose services also include restaurant reviews and bike-sharing, said total revenue rose to 62.62 billion yuan (S$12 billion) in the three months ended September.

site_title: Australia’s trade surpluses enter sixth year on strong iron ore
summary: Australia began a sixth consecutive year of trade surpluses in January, driven by strong iron ore exports, with a windfall of A$11.7 billion. Exports advanced 1.4% and imports rose 4.6% in the month. The country's fiscal outlook remains among the best in the developed world, with economists predicting further gains ahead as China reopens after lifting Covid Zero policies. However, a shift in China's economic model to boost domestic consumption may impact Australia's commodity exports.

images.alt_text: Australia's prime minister Anthony Albanese said on Tuesday Australia would be deepening and diversifying its international investment and trade links.
The RBA is waging its most aggressive campaign against inflation in a generation, having hiked by 3.25 points since May to take the cash rate to a 10-year high.
Miners went into a challenging results season facing weaker commodity prices, inflation pain and big capital expenditures.

site_title: Proton VPN in media partnership against online censorship
summary: Switzerland-based Proton has partnered with German broadcaster Deutsche Welle to provide virtual private network (VPN) services, allowing users to bypass government censorship and internet blocks in several countries. The partnership is the first between a VPN provider and a media company, aiming to make independent news accessible worldwide, particularly in countries with censorship. Proton's CEO, Andy Yen, stated that free access to information is under attack and that authoritarian governments are censoring international news outlets, limiting citizens' access to information.

site_title: US dollar steadies ahead of Powell testimony and monthly jobs data
summary: The US dollar steadied at 104.63 ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's testimony and the February jobs report, which is expected to influence interest rate decisions. Investors await Powell's remarks on employment and inflation numbers, which may impact the likelihood of a 50-bp interest rate hike. The dollar has risen 2% since February, largely at the expense of the Japanese yen, while the euro and sterling have declined.

images.alt_text: DBS has bounced off its recent low of S$33.50, clocking a gain of nearly 1 per cent or S$0.32 to S$33.82.

site_title: Microsoft expands ChatGPT integration to more developer tools
summary: Microsoft has expanded its integration of ChatGPT technology into its Power Platform, allowing users to develop applications with minimal coding. The updated tools include Power Virtual Agent, AI Builder, and Dynamics 365, enabling businesses to build chatbots, automate workflows, and generate human-like text responses. The new features are available in the US and mark the latest move by tech companies to integrate generative AI into their offerings, following similar moves by Alphabet and Baidu.

images.alt_text: In today's AI-fuelled world, human financial advisers and analysts can still prevail in investment analysis or portfolio construction, if they offer authenticity, originality, and more than the conventional wisdom.
One Piece manga series has racked up more than 100 volumes and smashed sales records since the first instalment appeared in 1997.
Microsoft has gone the furthest in pushing out generative AI to consumers and has pledged to pump billions of dollars into OpenAI, the company behind ChatGPT.

site_title: KKR exits Malaysian helicopter services operator after a decade
summary: KKR sells its remaining 21% stake in Malaysian helicopter services operator Weststar Aviation Services to the Weststar Group for an undisclosed amount, marking its full exit from the company after a decade. Weststar Group, controlled by businessman Syed Azman Syed Ibrahim, is now the sole shareholder of the helicopter operator. Weststar Aviation is one of Southeast Asia's biggest helicopter services firms and the world's third-largest operator of AW139 helicopters.

site_title: Swiss National Bank reports annual loss of 132.5 billion Swiss francs – a record
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) reported a record annual loss of 132.5 billion Swiss francs, the largest in its 115-year history. The loss was caused by a decline in bond and stock market values, as well as a strengthening of the Swiss franc. This resulted in a net loss of 39.5 billion francs after provisions were taken into account. The SNB will not make a payout to the Swiss central or regional governments or dividend to investors for the second time since its establishment in 1907.

images.alt_text: The Swiss National Bank is skipping its yearly payment to the federal government and 26 Swiss cantons, for just the second time since its establishment in 1906.
While inflation has come down from a 3.5 per cent peak in August, it has now been above the Swiss National Bank’s (SNB) 2 per cent ceiling for almost a year, and averaged at 2.8 per cent in 2022.

site_title: HK casino operator SJM sees bigger 2022 loss on Covid travel curbs
summary: HK casino operator SJM Holdings forecast a larger loss for fiscal 2022 due to Covid travel restrictions in Macau, reporting an attributable loss of HK$7.80 billion (S$1336.3 million) compared to a loss of HK$4.14 billion in the previous year. A significant impairment charge and refurbishment costs also contributed to the loss. However, Macau's casino industry has seen a resurgence in January, with a 82.5% jump in gambling revenue, following the removal of Covid-19 testing requirements for inbound travellers.

site_title: Ant gets Asia’s biggest ESG-linked loan in US$6.5 billion deal
summary: Ant Group, a fintech company backed by billionaire Jack Ma, secured Asia's largest ESG-linked loan of $6.5 billion, surpassing the region's largest loan market. The sustainability-linked loan, supported by 20 banks, aims to achieve net zero by 2030. The loan features a tiered pricing mechanism linked to predetermined sustainability performance targets, with interest margin adjustments to encourage environmental, social, and corporate governance goals, including reducing carbon emissions and hiring underprivileged workers.

site_title: WhatsApp agrees to be more transparent on policy changes, EU says
summary: WhatsApp has agreed to be more transparent about changes to its EU users' contracts, following complaints from consumer bodies. The company will now explain changes in plain language, display the possibility for users to accept or reject updates, and allow users to close pop-up notifications. WhatsApp also confirmed that users' personal data is not shared with third parties for advertising purposes. The European Union's Justice Commissioner, Didier Reynders, stated that consumers have the right to understand what they agree to and can decide whether to continue using the platform.

site_title: North Korea accuses US of ‘intentionally’ aggravating relations
summary: North Korea's foreign ministry accused the US of "intentionally" aggravating relations by conducting joint military drills with South Korea, citing the recent air drill as a rehearsal for invasion. The drills, set to begin on March 13, have been described as defensive by the US and South Korea, but Pyongyang sees them as a threat. North Korea demands an immediate stop to the military exercises, warning of a "violent physical conflict" if the drills continue. The situation has raised tensions between the two countries and the international community.

images.alt_text: A strategic cruise missile is launched during a drill in this undated photo released by North Korea's Korean Central News Agency on Feb 24, 2023.

site_title: Oil edges higher on supply tightness, China demand hopes
summary: Oil prices edged higher on Monday, driven by supply tightness and hopes for rising Chinese demand. Brent crude futures rose 35 cents to $86.18 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures increased 78 cents to $80.46. Oil executives discussed supply disruptions and Chinese demand, with Chevron's CEO citing tight oil market conditions. Additionally, a weaker dollar and Saudi Arabia's price hike for Asian crude exports also supported oil prices.

images.alt_text: An oil pump jack at the New Harmony Oil Field in Grayville, Illinois, US, on Sunday, June 19, 2022. Top Biden administration officials are weighing limits on exports of fuel as the White House struggles to contain gasoline prices that have topped $5 per gallon. Photographer: Luke Sharrett/Bloomberg

site_title: Shoppers are cooling on luxury purchases, Saks Fifth Avenue says
summary: Saks Fifth Avenue's survey found that 62% of respondents plan to spend the same or more on luxury goods, down from 68% in September. Shoppers earning $100,000-$199,000 are more cautious, while millennials are the most bullish, with 64% planning to increase spending. The company attributes this to younger generations' lack of experience in economic downturns. Saks is being more deliberate with purchasing inventory due to a "much more challenging environment" this year, following a boom in luxury sales during the pandemic.

site_title: Retiring well – 8 guiding principles
summary: Retiring comfortably is achievable with a well-planned strategy. Lorna Tan, a financial expert, shares eight guiding principles for a sustainable retirement plan. Key takeaways include understanding one's retirement lifestyle, determining a "must-have income floor" (MIF) that accounts for inflation, and building multiple income streams to mitigate risks. Other essential principles include preserving principal, continuing to invest during retirement, ensuring healthcare and long-term care protection, and building a sound estate plan. By prioritizing retirement planning and implementing these principles, individuals can create a robust plan to achieve financial wellness and enjoy their golden years.

images.alt_text: A 2022 study found that negative emotions influenced people’s motivation to shop. Angry individuals reported spending to regain control, while those who felt depressed, apathetic or bored would shop to make themselves feel better.

site_title: Tesla is no longer Morgan Stanley’s top US carmaker pick – Ferrari is
summary: Morgan Stanley analyst Adam Jonas has downgraded Tesla as his top US carmaker pick, citing the company's struggling shares and concerns about demand for electric vehicles. Instead, Jonas now prefers Ferrari, citing the luxury carmaker's strong order backlog, earnings visibility, and pricing power. Ferrari's US-listed stock has gained 61% since June, while Tesla shares are down 51% from their 2022 high. Jonas raised his price target on Ferrari to $310, implying 14% upside, and maintains his overweight rating on the stock.

images.alt_text: Prices of Tesla’s Model S cars were cut by US$5,000.
“These figures provide the base for an even stronger 2023, fuelled by a persistently high demand for our products worldwide,” said Benedetto Vigna, Ferrari CEO.
Tesla’s initial spending in the plant will involve between US$5 billion and US$6 billion in a first stage before likely reaching a US$10 billion investment in different phases, the governor said.
Piero Ferrari has transferred the “bare ownership” of its shares to the trust, whose value amounts to around 4 billion euros at current prices.

site_title: China’s Xi urges private firms to ‘be rich and loving’
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping urged private firms to "be rich and loving" by sharing the fruits of their growth with employees more equitably and participating in charity undertakings. He called for private firms to be "patriotic" and compete fairly, with China treating them as "family." Xi also blamed the West for China's economic difficulties, stating that the US and other countries have implemented containment measures to suppress China's development. This comes as Beijing supports the private sector, which has been reeling from regulatory crackdowns and state-imposed Covid restrictions.

images.alt_text: Premier Li Keqiang announced the goal for GDP in his final report to the Communist Party-controlled parliament, which kicked off its annual meeting on Sunday.
A stable property market will be key for China’s recovery this year.

site_title: Mexico ultramarathon pits outsiders against indigenous runners
summary: Hundreds of athletes, including competitors from the Indigenous Raramuri people, participated in the 20th Caballo Blanco Ultramarathon in Mexico's Chihuahua state. The 80, 40, and 21 km races took place through rugged canyons, with Raramuri runners wearing simple sandals and completing the courses with remarkable endurance. Winners, Jupiter and Juan Carlos Carera, from Mexico City, finished in 6 hours and 12 minutes. The event aims to preserve Tarahumara culture while providing a social function for participants, with food vouchers given to those from neighboring villages.

images.alt_text: On the bike leg of the Roth Ironman race in Germany, 1997. The event covers a 3.8km swim, 180km cycling, and then a 42km run.
Abdi Abdirahman reacts after finishing in third place during the Men's US Olympic marathon team trials on Feb 29, 2020 in Atlanta, Georgia.

Prudential Singapore employee Caleb Seow
(second from left) and other participants getting
hands-on training at the PRURide Seeker’s
Society cycling clinics.

site_title: India’s real-time payments system expands its reach to the world
summary: India's Unified Payments Interface (UPI) has expanded its reach to ease cross-border payments with over a dozen foreign countries, including Singapore, where cross-border retail payments currently exceed $1 billion annually. The tie-up between UPI and Singapore's PayNow facility allows users to transfer up to $986.50 per day, and Indian tourists from G20 nations can now make payments using their local bank accounts in India. The expansion aims to inject $45.6 billion into the Indian economy by 2026, with plans to expand services to more countries.

images.alt_text: An Amazon spokesperson said the company remains committed to operating as per regulatory guidelines and maintaining compliance.
FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: The logo of the Adani group is seen on the facade of one of its buildings on the outskirts of Ahmedabad, India, April 13, 2021. REUTERS/Amit Dave/File Photo/File Photo
Uber says in 2022, more than 1.9 million trips took place to and from metro rail stations in Delhi on Uber Moto, its bike taxi service.

Monetary Authority of Singapore managing director Ravi Menon made a live demonstration of a cross-border payment transfer with his counterpart, Shaktikanta Das, governor of the Reserve Bank of India. The PayNow-UPI launch event was officiated by Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and India Prime Minister Narendra Modi.

site_title: UN takes step towards new way of tracking greenhouse gases
summary: The UN's World Meteorological Organization (WMO) has developed a new Global Greenhouse Gas Monitoring Infrastructure to provide standardized, real-time tracking of greenhouse gases. The platform will integrate space-based and surface-based observing systems to clarify uncertainties about emissions and inform policy choices. This move aims to fill a gap in the fight against climate change, with CO2 accounting for 66% of the warming effect on the climate. The WMO plans to provide faster and sharper data on the planet's atmosphere, supporting the implementation of the 2015 Paris Agreement on climate change.

site_title: OKP unit awarded S$43.8 million from arbitration over 2017 PIE worksite accident
summary: OKP Holdings, a unit of OKP Holdings, has been awarded S$43.8 million by an arbitration tribunal for a 2017 accident involving the Pan-Island Expressway (PIE) viaduct collapse. The award includes consultancy services company CPG Consultants' payment of the full sum within 28 days. The tribunal also ordered CPG to pay post-award interest on the total sum at a rate of 5.33% per annum. The payment is expected to positively impact OKP's financial performance for the current financial year ending Dec 31, 2023.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

site_title: Surge in salaries for software engineers hits a bump as caution reigns
summary: Singapore's software engineer salaries rose by an average 7.61% in 2022, lower than the 22% increase in 2021, due to tighter economic conditions and reduced hiring. Despite a slowdown, tech companies continue to offer high salaries, with competition driving record-high earnings for top engineers. Junior engineers saw a 5-13% increase in base salaries, while mid-level roles experienced a 16% rise, but lead roles saw a flat median salary. The tech sector remains a strong driver of job growth, with 9,000 job openings remaining available as of September 2022.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
The demand for tech talent beyond the Information and Communication sector is strong, particularly in roles such as cybersecurity and artificial intelligence.
Fazz has a presence in Singapore, Indonesia, Malaysia, Vietnam and Taiwan.
One of the worst mistakes that companies make is to give employees the sense that quick fix cost-cutting targets – rather than longer term strategic plans – are driving the process.

site_title: Global jobs ordeal for women hasn’t improved much this century
summary: A new study by the International Labor Organization (ILO) reveals that the global jobs ordeal for women has not improved significantly over the past two decades. The study found that 15% of female working-age individuals want to work but don't have a job, compared to 10.5% for men. Women earn only 51 cents for each US dollar of labor income generated by men, with disparities worsening in poorer countries. The ILO reports that progress in reducing gender imbalances in employment and working conditions has been disappointingly slow, with women still facing a harder time finding a job than men.

site_title: At spring budget, Britain to press on with commitment of financial stability
summary: The UK's Chancellor of the Exchequer, Jeremy Hunt, will deliver his spring budget on March 15, 2023, amid a stagnant economy that narrowly avoided recession. Despite high energy prices and inflation, tax revenues have outpaced government spending, resulting in a £5.4 billion surplus. Hunt is expected to press on with the planned increase in corporation tax to 25% from 19% in April, which will bring in £18 billion for the Treasury. However, economists warn of ongoing pressure on the government to address strikes and wage demands, which could lead to inflation and further interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Johnson conceded that the prevailing wind was behind Sunak. “It is clear that this is where people are now,” he told the audience in London. “People want to move on. I get that.”
Labour, led by Keir Starmer, has promised to ensure Britain has the fastest growing economy among the G7 on a sustained basis if it wins power.
The stubborn rise in mortgage costs, which is sharply slowing demand in the property market, is one of the headaches Rishi Sunak will inherit upon replacing Liz Truss as UK prime minister.

site_title: Silvergate’s deepening crisis jolts crypto stocks
summary: Silvergate Bank, a crypto-focused bank, suspended its crypto payments network and expressed doubts over its business, causing shares to fall 10% in early trading on Monday. The discontinuation of its main flagship product, the Silvergate Exchange Network, may signal a potential winding down of operations. This news negatively impacted the crypto market, with bitcoin and ethereum down 4.8% for the week, and led to a decline in shares of other crypto companies, including Signature Bank, Coinbase Global, and Riot Platforms Inc.

site_title: Fortress Minerals bags 2 prospecting licences in Sabah
summary: Fortress Minerals has secured two prospecting licences in Sabah, Malaysia, covering 40 sq km and 400 sq km areas. The licences allow the company to conduct prospecting for copper, nickel, cobalt, and iron ore minerals. Exploration activities are expected to commence in April 2023, with a total estimated commitment of RM30 million over two years. The move is seen as a strategic growth effort to diversify revenue streams and enhance long-term shareholder value.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Average realised selling price during the quarter fell to US$119.80 per DMT, compared to US$143 per DMT the year before.

site_title: Machine magic or art menace? Japan’s first AI manga
summary: A Japanese manga author, Rootport, has created the country's first fully AI-drawn manga, "Cyberpunk: Peach John", using the AI tool Midjourney. The 100-page manga took just six weeks to complete, a fraction of the time it would have taken a skilled artist. The technology has raised concerns over the threat it poses to jobs and copyright in Japan's multi-billion-dollar comic book industry, with some artists welcoming the new possibilities. However, others argue that AI art can be a great companion for human artists, helping to visualize and suggest ideas, and that humans still dominate in the creative process.

site_title: Head of UK business group steps aside over conduct probe
summary: The director-general of the Confederation of British Industry (CBI), Tony Danker, has stepped aside while an independent probe into allegations of his workplace conduct is carried out. The CBI was made aware of a new report on March 2, prompting the launch of an investigation into the matter. Danker apologized for any offense or anxiety caused, stating it was "completely unintentional." The CBI, which represents 190,000 businesses, has taken "all matters of workplace conduct extremely seriously" and will determine the outcome of the investigation.

images.alt_text: Tony Danker, director-general of the Confederation of British Industry (CBI), speaks at the National Farmers' Union (NFU) conference in Birmingham, UK, on Tuesday, Feb. 21, 2023. UK opposition leader Keir Starmer will pledge that a Labour government would boost public purchases of local food as he seeks to appeal to country’s embattled farmers. Photographer: Darren Staples/Bloomberg
Stanley Johnson would be a controversial pick in part because of accusations of sexual harassment against two women, and domestic abuse against his ex-wife.

A choir looks up at Pope Francis’ speech asking for for forgiveness for clerical child abuse at Knock shrine in Mayo, Ireland. August 26, 2018. Michal Gutowski, an investigator, said that late Polish pope John Paul II, then known as Karol Wojtyla, knew of cases of paedophile priests within the church while still a cardinal in Krakow.
The majority of Britons want flexible working, but company executives are more lukewarm even though staff having stronger bargaining power.

site_title: Crypto exchange Bybit suspends US dollar payments via bank transfers
summary: Crypto exchange Bybit has suspended US dollar payments via bank transfers, including Swift payments, citing "service outages" from its end-point processing partner. The move comes as the crypto industry faces increased scrutiny and regulatory pressure. Customers can still use other methods to buy and withdraw cryptocurrencies. The suspension follows the discontinuation of a crypto payments network operated by ailing US lender Silvergate Capital.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise in tandem with region and Wall Street; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.2% on Monday, following gains on Wall Street, as the Straits Times Index reached 3,239.31 points. DBS led gains, bouncing off its recent low, while UOB fell 0.1% and OCBC remained unchanged. The rally came after the US 10-year Treasury yield dropped to below 4%, lifting Asian markets.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
The money that investors do put to work in the markets this year is more likely to go to passive funds than actively managed mutual funds.
The Nikkei 225 jumped over one per cent in early trade, with gains posted in Taipei, Seoul, Jakarta, and Sydney.
The central bank has also increased its ability to defend the currency from volatility as foreign reserves rebounded from a two-year low reached in October.
On the Singapore exchange, gainers outnumber losers 79 to 20 after 102.5 million securities worth S$29.2 million change hands.
Keppel Corporation's property arm Keppel Land is divesting its full 100 per cent interest in a company that owns the right to build and operate a hotel in Myanmar
Miners went into a challenging results season facing weaker commodity prices, inflation pain and big capital expenditures.

site_title: Climate change to cost Germany up to 900 billion euros by 2050: study
summary: A study by Prognos, GWS, and Germany's Institute for Ecological Economic Research estimates that climate change could cost Germany up to 900 billion euros by 2050, with cumulative economic damage ranging from 280 billion to 900 billion euros between 2022 and 2050. This includes costs from extreme weather, loss of agricultural yields, and damage to buildings and infrastructure. Climate adaptation measures could potentially reduce costs by 60-80% if climate change is mild, with the study citing the need for Germany to become carbon-neutral by 2045.

images.alt_text: Picture taken on October 5, 2022 shows the lignite-fired Niederaussem power plant operated by German energy giant RWE near Niederaussem, western Germany. - German energy provider RWE is planning to entirely demolish houses in the village of Luetzerath for coal mining. RWE also brought forward its exit from coal power to 2030 on October 4, 2022 amid fears the country's plans to abandon fossil fuels are wobbling following the energy crisis caused by Russia's war in Ukraine. (Photo by INA FASSBENDER / AFP)
Climate activist Greta Thunberg and a few fellow activists had a meeting with Fatih Birol, the head of the International Energy Agency meeting, in Davos on Thursday (Jan 19).
Despite the WTO’s failings, the EU continues to defend the organisation, which it sees as a critical bulwark against the return of the power-based trading system that preceded the second World War.

site_title: CLCT, Sasseur Reit outperform S-Reit peers amid China reopening optimism
summary: Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (Reits) CLCT and Sasseur Reit have outperformed their peers amid optimism about China's reopening. CLCT generated 11.4% six-month total returns, surpassing the negative 8.6% average total returns from its peers. Sasseur Reit's 5.3% six-month total returns placed it in fourth position. Analysts attribute the outperformance to China's economic rebound, strong sponsor backing, and prudent balance sheets. Despite challenges from rising interest rates, the Reits' performance is expected to continue benefiting from China's reopening, with some analysts recommending a closer look at Sasseur Reit.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
China's manufacturing activity expanded as the fastest pace in more than a decade in February, official data showed.

In his work report, outgoing Premier Li Keqiang stresses the need for economic stability and expanding consumption, setting a goal to create around 12 million urban jobs this year, up from last year’s target of at least 11 million, and warns that risks remain in the real estate sector.
An outlet mall in Chongqing which is part of Sasseur Reit’s portfolio.
Mapletree Logistics Trust was one of the S-Reits that performed better year-on-year, but declined compared to the preceding period.

site_title: Stay calm when more luxury condos fetch above S$6,000 psf
summary: Singapore's ultra-luxury condominium market is experiencing growth, driven by factors such as the country's stability, wealth creation in neighboring countries, and its growing reputation as a wealth management hub. While prices in prime districts like Orchard Boulevard may see significant increases, they are unlikely to have a major impact on prices in other prime districts or city fringe areas. In fact, the market's high stamp duties and property taxes paid by luxury homeowners may benefit the community. As demand for luxury homes continues to rise, developers may focus on curating products for the super rich, potentially leading to more ultra-luxury condominiums selling for over S$6,000 psf.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
Singapore is one of the top 10 cities in the high-end activity index, with 18 ultra-prime property sales and 121 super-prime property sales, says Knight Frank.
Boulevard 88 on Orchard Boulevard was one of 2022's five best-selling new projects with units costing at least S$5 million.

krklimt - Artist's impression of Klimt Cairnhill

site_title: Singapore expected to rely on grants, loans and credit schemes to draw investors amid global tax shift
summary: Singapore may rely more on grants, loans, and credit schemes to retain multinationals amid the global shift to higher corporate tax rates. The country retains its well-established advantages, including infrastructure and rule of law, to stay competitive. Policymakers will need to review and update economic development schemes to stay ahead of cheaper regional peers. Analysts expect Singapore to enhance its suite of schemes, including grants, loans, and co-funding, to support businesses. Despite Pillar Two of the Base Erosion and Profit Shifting 2.0 limiting tax breaks, Singapore's overall attractiveness as an investment destination is expected to remain strong.

images.alt_text: “We want to help Singaporeans tackle cost of living pressures, but we must be careful not to inadvertently generate more demand and worsen inflation,” said Finance Minister Lawrence Wong in Parliament.

ST20230214-202336309352-Lim Yaohui-pixbudget/

Mr Lawrence Wong, Minister for Finance, arriving at Parliament House to deliver his Budget Statement speech on Budget Day, Feb 14, 2023.

(ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI)

Despite the potential advantages of various government measures to boost foreign investment, if put into action, industry observers expect the government to hold off on providing details at Budget 2023.

site_title: China will create a new agency to regulate data, WSJ says
summary: China plans to create a central agency to manage data within the country and abroad, becoming the top overseer of data-related issues. The new national data bureau will centralize power, replacing multiple bodies currently overseeing information management. The agency will investigate software algorithm manipulation, internet addiction, and cybersecurity vulnerabilities, and rule on data export abroad. The move is part of President Xi Jinping's efforts to consolidate the Communist Party's hold over the economy, following years of strict Covid restrictions and a widening geopolitical spat with the US. The agency's establishment aims to strengthen control over valuable data.

site_title: SoftBank-backed CloudMinds is said to weigh US$500 million HK IPO
summary: CloudMinds, a Shanghai-based artificial intelligence-powered robot developer, is considering a Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) that could raise up to $500 million. Founded in 2015, the company develops cloud-based robots for restaurants, hotels, and other industries. CloudMinds is working with China International Capital Corp and Haitong International Securities Group on the IPO preparations. This move could help the startup avoid US listing scrutiny due to China's tightening oversight of sensitive technology and data security.

site_title: Singapore Police open probe into  crypto fugitive Do Kwon’s Terraform Labs
summary: Singapore police have launched a probe into Terraform Labs, a cryptocurrency company co-founded by fugitive Do Kwon. The investigation is ongoing, with Kwon not currently in the city-state. The US Securities & Exchange Commission had previously accused Kwon and Terraform Labs of fraud, and South Korea has issued a warrant for his arrest. The probe comes as Kwon faces charges related to the $60 billion wipeout of digital assets, which he created with the TerraUSD stablecoin.

images.alt_text: Do Kwon was previously based in Singapore but is no longer in the Republic.

Do Kwon, co-founder and chief executive officer of Terraform Labs, in the company's office in Seoul, South Korea, on Thursday, April 14, 2022. Kwon is counting on the oldest cryptocurrency as a backstop for his stablecoin, which some critics liken to a ginormous Ponzi scheme. Photographer: Woohae Cho/Bloomberg
the Seoul Southern District Court rejected a request for an arrest warrant as they do not believe Shin poses a flight risk or would destroy evidence.

site_title: Are Russian oil prices being rigged?
summary: The US Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) is investigating potential manipulation of global oil prices, specifically the reported prices of Russian oil. Initial reports showed Russian oil trading at or below the $60 per barrel price cap imposed by the G7 and EU. However, some analysts, including Goldman Sachs, claim that reported prices are inaccurate, potentially due to market manipulation. The CFTC has a mandate to ensure derivatives markets function with integrity and prevent manipulation in spot markets that affect futures and derivatives. Whistleblower incentives could encourage individuals to expose manipulation in the secretive Russian oil market.

images.alt_text: By the second half of the year, analysts say, the market will face a shortage; the impending crunch shows that even as the world embraces cleaner sources of energy, the thirst for oil is hard to slake.

West Texas Intermediate US crude futures (WTI) traded at US$76.09 a barrel, 23 cents, or 0.3 per cent lower, while Brent crude futures were down 30 cents, or 0.36 per cent, at US$82.86 a barrel at 0411 GMT.
China imported a daily 1.73 million barrels of Russian crude in 2022, up 8.3 per cent from a year earlier.

site_title: Yangzijiang Financial partners Singapore-based fund manager to invest in Asia private credit assets
summary: Yangzijiang Financial Holding has partnered with Singapore-based fund manager Tahan Capital Management to invest in Asia private credit assets. The partnership aims to diversify the group's portfolio and promote sustainable growth in the region. According to Vincent Toe, CEO of Yangzijiang Financial, private credit offers attractive returns with the security of highly structured and well-collateralized investments. The partnership follows a trend of significant growth in the Asia-Pacific private credit market, supported by rising investor interest and increasing demand for alternative debt.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Yangzijiang Financial Holding  executive chairman Ren Yuanlin says he remains cautiously optimistic of Yangzijiang Financial’s prospects for 2023.

site_title: Tesla cuts prices of Model Y and Model X variants in US
summary: Tesla has cut prices of its Model S and Model X vehicles in the US by $5,000 and $10,000 respectively, following increased demand after previous price cuts. The basic version of Model S now costs $89,990, while its performance variant costs $109,990. The Model X's basic variant now costs $89,990 and its performance variant costs $99,990. This move aims to boost sales and maintain competitiveness in the electric vehicle market.

site_title: Worst for ringgit seen over as China reopening to boost inflows
summary: Malaysia's ringgit is expected to recover from its worst monthly performance in two years as China's reopening boosts tourist arrivals and exports. Analysts at DBS, Barclays, and RBC predict the ringgit will remain stable around 4.45 by the end of June, driven by China's economic rebound and easing pressure on emerging markets. The central bank's increased foreign reserves and ability to defend the currency also support the outlook.

images.alt_text: Banks in Malaysia have posted sterling financial results in FY2022, thanks to healthy loan growth and increased interest income.
The central bank last month surprised economists by holding the benchmark rate at 2.75 per cent after four quarter-point increases last year.

site_title: UBS cuts bonuses by 10% after dealmaking slump
summary: UBS Group cut employee bonuses by 10% for 2022, following a revenue decline due to a slump in mergers and capital raising, which dropped by roughly 50%. The bank's CEO, Ralph Hamers, received a 11% year-on-year bonus increase, despite the decline in dealmaking. This caps an uneven year for the bank, with gains in trading and wealth management offset by a drop in advisory services.

images.alt_text: Chinese households have around 8 trillion to 10 trillion yuan in excess available deposits due to limited spending during the pandemic, and the precedent in other countries suggests about 6 per cent end up in equities investment.
Among Europe's biggest lenders that have reported their 2022 earnings so far, 10 have boosted net lending revenue by 16 per cent, to a record 120.8 billion euros (S$173.1 billion).

Morgan Stanley is the latest bank to require individual staff to bear some of the burden of an unprecedented regulatory investigation, after it emerged that unapproved messaging platforms were being widely used to conduct business.

The challenges faced by Credit Suisse CEO Ulrich Koerner are steep. While he has persuaded a few clients to bring their money back, many are reluctant and some are probably gone for good, he has said.

site_title: Row as UK’s Boris Johnson reportedly touts father for knighthood
summary: Former UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson has reportedly nominated his father, Stanley, for a knighthood as part of his resignation honours list. The move has been met with criticism from Labour leader Keir Starmer, who calls it "outrageous" and hypocritical, given Stanley Johnson's history of domestic abuse and accusations of sexual harassment. The nomination poses a political headache for Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, who must sign off on Johnson's choices. Stanley Johnson has denied any wrongdoing, but his past actions have raised concerns among many.

images.alt_text: Johnson, who resigned as prime minister last summer after “Partygate” and other scandals, insists the report vindicated him.
Johnson conceded that the prevailing wind was behind Sunak. “It is clear that this is where people are now,” he told the audience in London. “People want to move on. I get that.”

One UK official says they have told Prime Minister Rishi Sunak that strong trading relations with Europe will be essential for the economic challenges of the future in areas such as emerging technologies, and to deal with threats like global supply shocks and China.

site_title: Indonesia to provide incentives to boost EV sales, attract investment
summary: Indonesia plans to provide incentives starting March 20 to boost sales of electric vehicles, including 200,000 electric motorcycles and 35,900 electric cars. The program aims to attract investment from companies like Tesla and will disburse 7 million rupiah (S$614.75) for each new motorcycle sold or converted into an electric bike. Indonesia seeks to develop domestic EV production facilities, leveraging its rich nickel reserves, and officials are in talks with Tesla and other companies to establish a presence in the country.

site_title: After playing wage catch-up, US firms may have found their footing
summary: US firms are slowly regaining footing in the labor market, with hiring and wage trends improving after a pandemic-induced labor crunch. Companies like Sprint Mart are adjusting wages and benefits to stay competitive, and recent data suggests wage growth will slow. The Federal Reserve, which has set an inflation target of 2% annual growth, sees these developments as positive. Experts predict wage growth will continue to slow, with some forecasting a 3.5% annual rate by the end of next year, which is more consistent with the Fed's inflation goals.

images.alt_text: Hiring last month unexpectedly surged and unemployment fell to a 53-year low, while average hourly earnings grew at steady clip.
Shoppers are shifting purchases to cheaper options such as Walmart, a trend that often coincides with a recession.
Consumer spending, which accounts for more than two-thirds of US economic activity, jumped 1.8 per cent last month, the Commerce Department said.

site_title: Shares in Vietnam developers rally on roll back in corporate bond reform
summary: Shares in Vietnamese property developers rose after the government amended corporate bond regulations to ease pressure on a sector squeezed by a credit crunch. The move temporarily rolls back parts of a major market reform adopted last year, allowing domestic bond issuers to negotiate with bondholders to make payments in assets instead of cash. This change is expected to remove most of the problems related to bonds maturing this year and next, but tighter measures are likely to be reintroduced next year.

images.alt_text: Vietnam's property crisis started last year, after officials issued a crackdown on corporate bond issuance following allegations of illegal activities.
After a torrid 2022, investors have been betting that a swift recovery in China’s economy will somewhat cushion the impact of a global slowdown and possible recession.

site_title: UK's FTSE 100 kicks off week on grim note; miners fall
summary: The UK's FTSE 100 index fell 0.2% on Monday, with miners suffering a 2.4% drop due to China's modest growth target of 5% for the year, impacting copper prices and the general market mood. This follows a strong performance by Ireland-based gaming company Flutter. Meanwhile, Aston Martin Lagonda Global Holdings surged 17.8% after price target raises, while AstraZeneca's cancer drug Enhertu showed positive results in a mid-stage trial.

images.alt_text: The size of the UK stock market has also shrunk over the past 16 years. The total market capitalisation of London-listed equities fell from a peak of US$4.3 trillion in 2007 to about US$3 trillion this year, according to data compiled by Bloomberg
The Stoxx 600 added 1.1 per cent by Monday's close.

site_title: German travel industry sees 2023 rebound to pre-pandemic highs
summary: Germany's travel industry has seen a rebound in 2023, with sales expected to return to pre-pandemic highs of 98 billion euros in 2019. Despite the war in Ukraine and cost-of-living crisis, the industry is optimistic due to consumers' high priority on vacationing. Revenue in January doubled year-on-year and increased 12% compared to 2019. The German Travel Association (DRV) forecasts a return to record sales in 2023, with 84 billion euros in sales in 2021, almost double 2020 levels.

site_title: Pakistan has to give assurances on financing BOP deficit: IMF
summary: Pakistan will need to provide assurances that its balance of payments (BOP) deficit is fully financed for the remaining period of its International Monetary Fund (IMF) program. The IMF wants Islamabad to give an assurance on external financing for clearing $1.1 billion in disbursements under the $6.5 billion Extended Fund Facility. Pakistan has completed most prior actions, but the external financing requirement remains. The program is set to end in June, and the country hopes to sign a staff level agreement with the IMF to settle policy framework issues.

site_title: UK construction sector rebounds in February: PMI
summary: The UK construction sector rebounded in February with a 6.2-point increase in the S&P Global/CIPS UK Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) to 54.6, its highest since May 2022. Commercial construction and civil engineering drove the growth, while residential building work fell for the third month in a row. Despite this, economists are cautiously optimistic about the economy, with the services PMI also showing a strong rebound. However, the housing market remains a weak spot, with house prices down 1.1% year-over-year and builders cutting jobs due to higher interest rates and subdued demand.

images.alt_text: The potential job losses come as Britain’s property market endures a slump in activity triggered by higher mortgage rates and the threat of a house price plunge.
Britain’s largest homebuilders have already cut back their building targets as higher mortgage costs and economic uncertainty depressed buyer demand.

site_title: Indonesia to tighten used shoe import controls after Reuters report
summary: Indonesia plans to tighten customs checks at small ports to combat the illegal import of second-hand shoes, following a Reuters report that found donated shoes were exported for resale in Indonesia. The move comes after a six-month investigation found that ten pairs of shoes donated to a recycling scheme in Singapore were shipped to Indonesia. The country's Ministry of Industry aims to stop the practice, citing its negative impact on the domestic footwear industry. New incentives and regulations are also being proposed for local footwear manufacturers.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Reuters reporter Joe Brock negotiates with a vendor to buy his own pair of second-hand shoes back, after tracing them via a tracking device, in Jakarta, Indonesia in this screenshot taken from a video, November 1, 2022.  REUTERS/Yuddy Cahya Budiman/File Photo

site_title: How open data can help Singapore prevail
summary: Singapore is poised to capitalize on the growing volume of global data by embracing open data initiatives, which can drive innovation and economic growth. The city-state's government and businesses are leveraging data to stay ahead in the market and ensure efficient operations. Successful organizations like the Singapore Tourism Board are making tourism data available to the public, while open data initiatives also aid in identifying and tracing fraud and threats. To ensure public trust, ethical data collection, stringent privacy and security measures, and quality control must be upheld, requiring collaboration between government and industry.

images.alt_text: Building a digital Silk Road in Asia
Vital to have stronger data protection in post-pandemic world

site_title: Capitalism put to work with gender diversity
summary: A study by McKinsey found that companies with higher female representation on executive committees experience a 55% premium in operating results. Research also shows that female investors are more likely to prioritize environmental, social, and governance (ESG) risks, which can lead to better investment decisions. This creates a virtuous cycle where businesses prioritize corporate social responsibility to boost profitability. Studies from the Peterson Institute, Ernst & Young, and S&P Global Market Intelligence confirm the correlation between female leadership and company performance. Closing the gender pay gap could also boost global wealth, with the World Bank estimating $160 trillion in lost human capital.

images.alt_text: For equitable progress for all, we need to implement initiatives on diversity that target equitable opportunities for all, regardless of gender, ethnicity, age, socio-economic background, says Valerie Mantot-Groene, regional managing director, Asean, Apex Group. PHOTO:
Boardrooms in Singapore are seeing an increased presence of women directors, but these numbers still lag those of more developed markets. PHOTO: PIXABAY
The path from entry-level positions to the corner office tends to be more encumbered for women than it is for men.

site_title: The politics of deglobalisation favours the robots
summary: Japan is poised to become a key player in the "robot revolution" as countries worldwide shift towards deglobalization, driven by rising labour shortages and increasing tensions between major economies. Automation sales are on the rise, with Japan's factory automation exports to the US reaching record highs. This shift is expected to continue, with forecasts predicting the global machine vision market will exceed $40 billion by the end of the decade. As geopolitics drive manufacturing arrangements, companies are increasingly turning to robots and automation to address labour shortages, making Japan a likely beneficiary of this trend.

images.alt_text: More than half of last year’s orders came from automakers and their suppliers – a group that has long led the way in automation of US factories.
A DeliRo delivery robot moving along on a street outside Tokyo, part of an experiment businesses hope will tackle labour shortages and rural isolation.
Do-it-yourself education has been on the rise in recent years, with the prevalence of platforms such as Udemy, LinkedIn Learning, and Coursera that support self-paced learning.

site_title: ‘Mad rush’ for luxury housing in India
summary: India's luxury housing market is experiencing a resurgence, with a record 65,700 luxury units sold in 2022, three times the previous year. The market is driven by a desire for upscale amenities such as concierge services, spas, and large green spaces, as well as a growing number of wealthy Indians who are upgrading their homes. Developers are offering exclusive deals and high-end properties, with prices ranging from $1.7 million to $3.3 million. The market is expected to continue growing, with 61% of high-net-worth Indians planning to buy luxury real estate this year.

images.alt_text: While sales have recently slowed, India house prices continue to rise, with average residential prices across the top eight cities increasing 5 per cent in the second quarter from a year earlier.

site_title: Manulife steps up hiring in China to tap big pensions opportunity
summary: Canada's Manulife Financial plans to hire at least two top-tier executives in China to tap into the country's growing pensions business. With 100% ownership of a joint venture, Manulife aims to capitalize on China's rapidly ageing population and pension crisis. The company sees an opportunity to shape the industry and help the government address the retirement funding gap, which is expected to worsen by 2035. Manulife's assets under management in China are growing, with mutual fund assets increasing by nearly 30% last year, and the company is focusing on expanding its private pension offerings.

site_title: South Korea plan will help ‘restore healthy ties’: Japan FM
summary: South Korea announced a plan to compensate victims of Japan's forced wartime labor, aiming to restore "healthy" ties with Japan. The plan, which includes a South Korean foundation compensating victims and their families, is seen as an effort to ease tensions. Japan's Foreign Minister Yoshimasa Hayashi welcomed the plan, stating it would help to restore ties, and hinted at lifting some trade restrictions. The move comes after years of strained relations, with Japan standing by its 1998 declaration that included an apology for its colonial rule of the Korean peninsula.

images.alt_text: Slumping exports, slowing consumption and a shaky housing market are among the risks to the economy that are staying in the BOK’s hand.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Successful applicants for Jurong West Crystal and Brickland Weave projects can move into their new homes earlier due to shorter waiting times. The February 2023 Build-To-Order (BTO) exercise saw the lowest overall number of flat applicants, particularly first-timer applicants, since 2020. Energy group SP Group secured its first solar farm assets in Vietnam, while Cycle & Carriage Singapore sold four properties for S$333 million. Keppel Land is divesting its 100% stake in a Myanmar hotel project for US$57.4 million. Singapore stocks rose 0.2% on Monday, following gains in the region and on Wall Street.

site_title: Asia’s very complicated interest-rate pause
summary: Asia's central banks face challenges in navigating interest rates, with the Reserve Bank of Australia set to raise its main rate by a quarter-point on Tuesday. Despite the US economy's resilience, Asian economies such as South Korea, Indonesia, and Malaysia have already suspended rate hikes, and cuts in borrowing costs may take longer to materialize. The situation is complicated by varying levels of economic development and inflation dynamics across the region, with China targeting a 5% growth rate and the Philippines opting for smaller increments.

images.alt_text: In his work report, outgoing Premier Li Keqiang stresses the need for economic stability and expanding consumption, setting a goal to create around 12 million urban jobs this year, up from last year’s target of at least 11 million, and warns that risks remain in the real estate sector.
The RBA is waging its most aggressive campaign against inflation in a generation, having hiked by 3.25 points since May to take the cash rate to a 10-year high.

site_title: Saudi Arabia raises oil prices for Asia and Europe for April
summary: Saudi Arabia raised most oil prices for Asia in April, increasing the price of its main Arab Light grade by 50 US cents to US$2.50 a barrel, following a Bloomberg survey that forecast a 55 US cents rise. This is the second month in a row that Aramco has increased prices for Asia, its largest market. Prices for North-West Europe and the Mediterranean jumped by up to US$1.30 a barrel, while US customers' prices remained unchanged. The move is seen as a sign that demand is picking up in Asia and Europe.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund now owns 8.3 per cent of Nintendo, building up a position that stood at just above 6 per cent at the start of the year.
The New Murabba Development Company’s project would have more than 80 cultural and entertainment venues.

site_title: Anwar will find the going much harder after initial spate of reforms
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim's first 100 days in office have seen significant reforms, including the abolition of procurement approvals without open tenders and the introduction of direct questioning by opposition members. However, he faces challenges in implementing further reforms due to political polarization, particularly from the opposition Perikatan Nasional (PN) coalition. To strengthen the government's fiscal position, Anwar should consider widening the revenue base through new taxation measures, such as re-imposing the 6% goods and services tax. The upcoming state elections will also test Anwar's ability to work with the opposition and address the country's racial and religious polarisation.

images.alt_text: The premier’s approval rating stood at 68 per cent, just two months after the country’s general election resulted in a hung parliament last November.
Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim is set to table the country's revised 2023 budget to parliament on Feb 24.
The latest budget tabled by the Malaysia's Prime Minister and Finance Minister Anwar Ibrahim last Friday (Feb 24) was seen as a pragmatic budget with "a populist flavour”.

site_title: BGI seeks to ‘clarify’ after US widens China export restrictions
summary: Chinese genetics firm BGI opposes US export restrictions on its units, citing "open and inclusive global scientific collaboration". The US Commerce Department imposed restrictions on BGI and other Chinese entities, citing national security and foreign policy concerns. China's Ministry of Commerce called the move "unreasonable suppression" and an "act of economic bullying". BGI stated it is willing and able to clarify the situation and denies involvement in human rights abuses. The US decision affects BGI units and server maker Inspur Group, which China considers integral to domestic innovation efforts.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Chinese and U.S. flags flutter outside the building of an American company in Beijing, China January 21, 2021. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo
US companies are banned from exporting to the listed entities without prior government approval.

site_title: China’s chip sector needs more than state money to dull impact of US restrictions
summary: China plans to spend $140 billion to support its chip sector, but government funds alone may not be enough to overcome US export restrictions and catch up with Western rivals. Chinese companies, such as Shanghai Micro Electronics Equipment Group, face challenges in accessing advanced chipmaking facilities and technology, hindering innovation and limiting their ability to move up the value chain. Industry experts say money is not enough to overcome the cycle of low-end production and that a complete rethink of China's approach to chipmaking is needed to catch up with Western peers.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A woman walks past a display at Semicon China, a trade fair for semiconductor technology, in Shanghai, China, March 17, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo
The move has drawn an angry response from China, with the Ministry of Commerce urging the US to stop “unreasonable suppression” of Chinese firms.
US companies are banned from exporting to the listed entities without prior government approval.

site_title: US lawmakers step up push to ban TikTok with bill this week
summary: US Senate Intelligence Committee Chairman Mark Warner plans to introduce a bill this week to ban Chinese technology, including TikTok, citing data collection and potential propaganda concerns. The bipartisan bill aims to give the US the power to ban or prohibit foreign technology where necessary. Warner's move comes amid concerns about the impact of Chinese technology on the US, with TikTok's commercial success in the US threatening local social media giants like Meta and YouTube.

images.alt_text: US adult users will spend an average of nearly 56 minutes per day on TikTok this year, six minutes less than the time spent watching Netflix, the market tracker forecast.
TikTok, owned by Beijing-based ByteDance, is hugely popular in the US, especially among teens.
The new approach will require younger users to enter a password if they want to binge more than an hour of videos at one time.

site_title: Australia’s biggest firms flash warning signals on recession
summary: Australia's largest companies reported a mixed earnings season, with 41% of 158 companies on the S&P/ASX 200 Index posting negative earnings surprises, up from 28% last year. Weaker commodity prices, inflation, and capital expenditures weighed on miners, while lithium firms saw a brief bright spot. The economy is expected to slow, with economists boosting the probability of a recession. Despite government confidence, cracks are forming in the A$2.2 trillion economy, and consumer spending is shifting towards holidays and lower-ticket items.

images.alt_text: Live sheep exports fell to below 500,000 in 2022, down from a peak of 6.5 million 20 years ago.
A housing shortfall risks further fuelling rental inflation at a time when the economy is seeing a strong rebound in population growth from immigration.

Data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics on Wednesday showed real GDP rose 0.5 per cent in the December quarter, down from 0.7 per cent in the previous quarter and under forecasts of 0.8 per cent.

site_title: Applicants for February BTO exercise lowest since 2020: HDB
summary: The February 2023 Build-To-Order (BTO) exercise in Singapore posted the lowest overall number of flat applicants since 2020, particularly among first-time applicants. The median application rate for first-timer applicants for three-room or larger flats stood at 1.8, with some projects having as low as 0.2. Successful applicants in certain projects, such as Jurong West Crystal and Brickland Weave, can move into their homes earlier due to shorter waiting times. The HDB has introduced stricter rules to improve flat allocation, which may lead to a shift in buyers towards the resale market.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

Rents for the condo market climbs 1.4 per cent in January from December 2022, while HDB rental prices rise 0.6 per cent from the month before, according to flash estimates from SRX and 99.co on Tuesday (Feb 28).
Two projects - Farrer Park Fields and Ulu Pandan Glades - are offered under the Prime Location Housing (PLH) model, which applies to flats in prime and central locations.
