images.alt_text: Sri Lanka has been struggling with soaring prices for over a year, largely caused by its worst financial crisis since it gained Independence from Britain in 1948.

site_title: China central bank signals stable policy as economy rebounds
summary: China's central bank Governor Yi Gang signaled stable monetary policy this year, citing relatively appropriate interest rates and mild inflation. The economy is rebounding from its Covid slump, with investors awaiting a shift in policy stance. Yi hinted at supporting the economy through reserve requirement ratio cuts and maintaining a stable currency. Economists expect a growth target of over 5% and officials have expressed caution against excessive stimulus, emphasizing price stability and long-term liquidity.

images.alt_text: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) building in Beijing.Source: Bloomberg

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher as yields pull back
summary: US stocks rose at the open on Friday, March 3, as Treasury yields pulled back from a week-long rally. The Dow Jones Industrial Average increased 72.76 points, or 0.22%, to 33,076.33. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, gaining 16.67 and 61.67 points, respectively. The rally came as investors awaited the Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions, which sparked concerns that rates might remain higher for longer.

site_title: Forging stronger professional and personal  relationships on the golf course
summary: Audi Singapore is sponsoring the BT Corporate Golf League 2023, offering a new Audi A6 to anyone who registers a hole-in-one during the event. The league, presented by Singapore Pools, aims to foster professional and personal relationships among participants. Audi Singapore Managing Director Markus Schuster values the association with BT, citing its significant influence across key business sectors and alignment with Audi's brand values of prestige and progress. The tournament is currently underway, with Schuster's Audi Sport team in third place.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Pools team (from left): former Cabinet Ministe Yaacob Ibrahim, Singapore Pools CEO Lam Chee Weng, Singapore Pools board member Lee Kwok Cheong, and Mohd Norhelmy.
"The Business Times" editor Chen Huifen speaking at a networking event on Feb 2 to launch the BT Corporate Golf League 2023 tournament.
South Korean Ko Jin-young will return to Singapore in March to defend the HSBC Women’s World Championship at Sentosa Golf Club’s Tanjong Course.

site_title: EU eyes trade deal with US to access green benefits
summary: The European Union is seeking a trade agreement with the US to access some benefits under President Joe Biden's climate plan, the Inflation Reduction Act. EU officials hope to reach an in-principle agreement on issues like access to raw materials during a visit to the White House next week. The EU is concerned that the IRA could harm European jobs, particularly in the energy and auto sectors, but is seeking to avoid a "subsidy race" that could be detrimental to both sides.

images.alt_text: Thoughtful recycling of household waste is one of several smart urban practices that are prevalent in Constance, Germany.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's retail sales fell 0.8% in January due to lower motor vehicle sales, primarily caused by a lower Certificate of Entitlement quota. Starting from 2030, new harbour craft must run on electricity or be compatible with net-zero fuels. A review of checkpoint procedures will help businesses save time and money. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks ended lower, weighed down by persistent inflation and rate hikes. SAVills Singapore has launched an energy and sustainability management department to provide custom energy solutions.

site_title: India central bank imposes penalty on Amazon Pay for non-compliance
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) imposed a 30.7 million rupees (S$505,684) penalty on Amazon Pay Private for non-compliance with prepaid payment instrument and Know Your Customer (KYC) rules. Amazon Pay, an online payment processing service, was found to have deficiencies in regulatory compliance. The company has stated its commitment to operating as per regulatory guidelines and maintaining compliance, with an Amazon spokesperson saying they continue to work closely with authorities to share their commitment.

site_title: US equity funds post biggest weekly outflow in eight weeks
summary: US equity funds experienced their largest weekly outflow in eight weeks, with investors withdrawing a net $12.9 billion from March 1-3, primarily due to concerns over the Federal Reserve's policy tightening and stickier-than-expected inflation. In contrast, money market funds saw a record weekly inflow of $64.86 billion. The outflows were mainly seen in large- and mid-cap equity funds, while small-cap funds faced a reversal of their four-week buying streak.

site_title: UK regulator launches probe into LME nickel trading halt
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority has launched an enforcement investigation into the London Metal Exchange (LME) over its decision to halt nickel trading last year, citing possible misconduct. The LME had suspended the market after chaotic price action, resulting in billions of dollars in cancelled trades. The regulator has also found shortcomings at LME clearing house LME Clear and will name an independent monitor to assess remedial actions. The LME has implemented changes to its control framework and committed to market reform.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Traders work on the floor of the London Metal Exchange, in London, Britain September 27, 2018. REUTERS/Simon Dawson/File Photo

site_title: Golden Energy and Resources working to meet exit offer conditions
summary: Golden Energy & Resources (Gear) is working to meet the conditions of its recent transaction, which includes a proposed distribution of its stake in Golden Energy Mines (Gems) and an exit offer for Gear shareholders. The conditions include approvals from Indonesian regulators, independent shareholders, and the Singapore Exchange. If satisfied, shareholders will have the opportunity to review disclosures and vote on the distribution and delisting. However, if conditions are not met, the company will not proceed with the transactions, and the exit offer will lapse.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

Sias president and chief executive David Gerald says the offer price should be higher after accounting for Stanmore Resources while also ignoring Golden Energy and Resources' Nov 8 closing price of S$0.67.
Gear said the distribution-in-specie is meant to reduce its exposure to energy coal, which is facing scrutiny as a fuel source.

site_title: IPhone maker Foxconn plans US$700 million India plant in shift from China
summary: Taiwanese electronics manufacturer Foxconn plans to invest around $700 million in a new plant in India, ramping up local production and shifting away from China due to growing US-China tensions. The 300-acre plant in Bengaluru, India, is expected to create approximately 100,000 jobs and may also produce iPhone parts and some electric vehicle components. This move marks a significant shift in the global electronics supply chain, with Foxconn's existing plant in China employing around 200,000 people.

site_title: Sri Lanka court orders delayed local election to go ahead
summary: Sri Lanka's Supreme Court has ordered the government to proceed with delayed local elections, overriding President Ranil Wickremesinghe's decision to delay them due to the country's economic crisis. The court issued a restraining order preventing the treasury chief and Wickremesinghe from withholding funds allocated for the polls. A final decision on the new election date will be made next week, with the polls originally planned for March 9. The delayed polls are seen as a test of Wickremesinghe's government and a referendum on austerity measures imposed to secure an IMF bailout.

images.alt_text: Around 40 trade unions in Sri Lanka, including government hospital staff and bank employees, called work stoppages on Wednesday (Mar 1), in defiance of a protest ban.

site_title: Hong Kong bourse’s expansion of Stock Connect to begin from Mar 13
summary: The Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEX) will expand its Stock Connect program, allowing eligible shares from the Shanghai Stock Exchange and Shenzhen Composite Index to be traded from the Hong Kong bourse starting March 13. This move aims to help Chinese firms delisting from US markets and list in Hong Kong. The expansion will facilitate Northbound trading, enabling mainland stocks to be traded from the Hong Kong bourse, and is part of HKEX's efforts to enhance the attractiveness of Hong Kong's and Mainland China's capital markets.

site_title: Equinor agrees to buy Suncor Energy UK for US$850 million
summary: Equinor has agreed to buy Suncor Energy UK for US$850 million, bolstering its North Sea oil and gas production as Europe seeks alternative energy sources following Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The deal grants Equinor a 30% non-operated stake in the Buzzard oil field and an 80% operated interest in the Rosebank development. The acquisition adds 15,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day to Equinor's production, with the company aiming to deepen its position as a reliable energy provider in Europe.

images.alt_text: The transaction is part of Iberdola’s plan to sell minority stakes in renewable developments to finance its climate action plan.

site_title: China to enhance credit management in financial sector
summary: China's banking and insurance regulator, CBIRC, has announced plans to enhance credit management in the financial sector. Qualified banks and institutions are encouraged to establish joint credit committees to share information on debt evasion by corporations, and excessive lending will be avoided through prudent assessment. The regulator also emphasized that banks should not relax risk management requirements to win customers. This move aims to better serve small firms and deepen financial sector reform.

site_title: Evercore Asia, Dymon-backed Hwa Hong take fees dispute to court
summary: Evercore Asia and Hwa Hong Corporation are in a legal dispute over fees, with Hwa Hong claiming Evercore is owed S$8.7 million in a success fee for advising on the acquisition of shares. Hwa Hong also alleges negligence and breaches of fiduciary duties against four former directors, including Ong Eng Hui David, Ong Eng Loke, Ong Eng Keong, and Ong Mui Eng. The case is one of two pending before the Singapore High Court, with a hearing scheduled for April 5.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
The battle for property player Hwa Hong Corporation is an intergenerational dispute among the members of its controlling family, the Ong family.
Hwa Hong's directors have clarified that the potential competing offerors have declined to make an offer for the company

The total number of shares owned, controlled or agreed to be acquired by Sanjuro and its concert parties, including valid acceptances, is now approximately 51.29 per cent of the total number of shares — which means the offer has turned unconditional in all respects.

site_title: Coinbase buys crypto asset manager One River in bet on institutional demand
summary: Coinbase Global acquired One River Digital Asset Management, a crypto asset manager focused on institutional clients, for an undisclosed price. The deal aims to bring institutional capital into the crypto ecosystem and expand Coinbase's asset-management business. One River Digital, founded by Eric Peters, has built a business to serve pension funds and other institutional clients, avoiding retail customers. The acquisition will be run as a separate division, Coinbase Asset Management, with Peters serving as CEO and CIO. The deal is seen as a strategic move to consolidate the industry and capitalize on long-term capital and money management opportunities.

site_title: Ericsson to pay Washington more than US$200 million to end major bribery case
summary: Ericsson agreed to pay the US$206.7 million fine to settle a major bribery case with US authorities. The Swedish telecommunications giant will plead guilty to deferred charges for violating the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act by paying bribes in several countries between 2000 and 2016. The company booked a $220 million provision in its fourth-quarter results to cover the penalty, resolving one of its biggest legal issues in the US. The Justice Department dropped charges after Ericsson agreed to follow certain conditions, and the company can now focus on delivering its strategy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An Ericsson logo is pictured at the Mobile World Congress (MWC) in Shanghai, China, June 28, 2019. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Private equity firms lend less as demand cools
summary: Private equity firms are lending less due to decreased demand and higher interest rates. In 2022, they disbursed $151.3 billion for middle-market deals, a 23% decline from 2021 and 41% less than in 2020. The economic slowdown, sticky price inflation, and increased borrowing costs are making private equity firms more risk-averse. This has led to a decrease in fundraising for private debt funds, with US private debt funds raising $216.2 billion in 2022, down 6% from the previous year.

images.alt_text: As ultra-cheap money drove a hunt for yield, debt investors competing for a piece of new deals accepted ever-weaker safeguards in loan contracts.

site_title: China’s rare earth stocks plunge as Tesla seeks alternatives
summary: Tesla plans to cut its use of rare earth materials in future electric vehicles, citing efforts to control material costs and reduce health and environmental risks. This move has led to a plunge in shares of China's rare earth suppliers, with China Northern Rare Earth and Inner Mongolia Baotou Steel Union experiencing significant declines. The change reflects Tesla's efforts to reduce its reliance on rare earths, which are essential for permanent magnets used in wind turbines and EV motors. Global demand for rare earths is expected to rise, driven by the growing electric vehicle market.

images.alt_text: Jars containing rare earth minerals produced by Australia's Lynas Corp from its Mount Weld operations are seen near Laverton, northeast of Perth, Australia, August 23, 2019.
Prices for lithium-ion batteries rose last year for the first time since at least 2010 as materials pushed up the price.

site_title: OCBC’s Teach-a-Child-to-Cycle rides back in 2023
summary: OCBC Bank's Teach-a-Child-to-Cycle programme is returning this year, teaching 20 low-income children aged 8-12 how to ride a bike over three sessions. The programme, which was introduced in 2015, aims to make cycling accessible to children from disadvantaged families. The children will receive bicycles and equipment, and will participate in OCBC Cycle's Mighty Savers Kids and Family Ride on May 6. Registration for the event has exceeded 3,800, with a 30% increase in sign-ups compared to the last full-scale event in 2019.

images.alt_text: UOB’s CEO Wee Ee Cheong (middle) with winning bidders Kelvin Lim (second from left) and Neo Kah Kiat (second from right) alongside Eric Lian, UOB’s head of group commercial banking (extreme left), and Frederick Chin, UOB’s head of group wholesale banking and markets. The two artworks were auctioned off as part of fundraising efforts. The funds, also raised through art workshops and a gala, will be used to support the arts, children and educational causes, as well as local small and medium enterprises (SMEs).

Many participants say that they found the programme interesting as they had the opportunity to try out different swim activities including aquatic dancing, flippa ball, diving, and an introductory swimming masterclass.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz begins building battery recycling factory in southern Germany
summary: Mercedes-Benz has begun construction on a sustainable battery recycling factory in Kuppenheim, southern Germany, with an annual capacity of 2500 tonnes. The pilot plant aims to produce over 50,000 battery modules for new electric vehicles. Recycled batteries will come from test vehicles and start-up batteries, with potential for scaling up production in the medium to long term. The facility is part of a scientific research project and will contribute to reducing the demand for raw materials such as lithium, cobalt, and nickel.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Mercedes-Benz logo is pictured at the 2019 Frankfurt Motor Show (IAA) in Frankfurt, Germany, September 10, 2019. REUTERS/Ralph Orlowski/File Photo

site_title: AI stocks surge as investors bet on growth prospects
summary: AI stocks surged on Friday, March 3, as investors bet on growth prospects. C3.ai's strong forecast of better-than-expected revenue and profit for the fourth quarter and fiscal year 2023 drove the gains, with its shares up 16% at $24.80. Other major AI stocks, including BigBear.ai, SoundHound AI, and Guardforce AI, also rose between 5% and 20%. This year, AI stocks have surged 33.9%-321.6%. Analysts say the segment is gaining momentum, but needs time to mature and prove profitability.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man talks on a phone in front of an Apple logo outside its store, following the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak in Shanghai, China, November 7, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo
Microsoft has gone the furthest in pushing out generative AI to consumers and has pledged to pump billions of dollars into OpenAI, the company behind ChatGPT.
The product, to be called “HunyuanAide”, will incorporate Tencent’s AI training model named “Hunyuan”.

site_title: Crypto hedge fund looks to Swiss banks after Silvergate exodus
summary: A US-based crypto hedge fund, Digital Asset Capital Management, is seeking Swiss banks to help replace a payments network operated by ailing US lender Silvergate Capital, which has lost key clients following the collapse of FTX. The fund, managing $400 million, is looking for banks that focus on crypto transactions, unlike Silvergate, which is reviewing its viability. Swiss banks such as Sygnum Bank and SEBA Bank are being considered, following a run on deposits last year.

images.alt_text: The exodus threatens Silvergate’s SEN network, the bank’s key source of deposits and a platform for crypto participants to transfer money among each other.

Coinbase said it would partner with other financial institutions to facilitate cash transactions for clients who had parked funds with the exchange, and that it had stopped accepting or initiating payments to or from Silvergate.

site_title: Indonesia to scrap pandemic-era trading restrictions at end-March: regulator
summary: Indonesia's financial regulator, OJK, will lift pandemic-era trading restrictions on the stock market by the end of March, including easing restrictions on short-selling and trading hours. The regulator will allow short-selling to resume for a list of stocks suspended during the pandemic, and trading hours will be adjusted to match the central bank's settlement timings. Trading restrictions, including auto-rejection rules, will also be lifted, with the bottom auto-reject threshold raised from 7% to 20-35%. This move comes as the government removed all coronavirus-related mobility restrictions late last year.

site_title: Sotheby’s pitches first of its kind offer secured by art collections of the wealthy
summary: Sotheby's is pitching a unique securitization product, the first of its kind, secured by art collections of wealthy individuals. The asset-backed security (ABS) is expected to be brought to the market later this year, with discussions with bond buyers beginning last year. This move follows a lucrative lending business for wealth managers, with outstanding loans against art forecast to reach $31 billion last year. The product would be a first for Sotheby's, following specialty finance firms that have underwritten art-backed loans.

images.alt_text: China is grabbing a bigger slice of the global art trade, with the world’s second-largest share of billionaire wealth.

At a soiree of some 90 people on a recent Friday evening in the centre of Hong Kong’s financial district, women in white gloves hobnobbed with Sotheby’s executives as they admired Hermes collectibles.

site_title: Newly minted top Thai mobile firm valued at US$9 billion on debut
summary: True Corporation, a newly formed Thai mobile firm created through the merger of Thailand's number two and three mobile phone operators, debuted with a market value of US$8.6 billion after its shares began trading in Bangkok on Friday. The firm's shares ended at 8.60 baht, giving the company a valuation of US$8.6 billion, surpassing the market capitalization of its rival, Advanced Info Service. The merger marks the end of Advanced Info's reign as the largest telecom company in South-east Asia's second-biggest economy.

images.alt_text: (EDITORS NOTE: Image was created using a variable planed lens.) Stock prices are displayed on an electronic stock board at the Stock Exchange of Thailand (SET) in Bangkok, Thailand, on Friday, June 22, 2018. The Thai exchange aims to increase the number of products it lists in an effort to boost trading, according to new president Pakorn Peetathawatchai. Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg Conditions for usage: SPH EDITORIAL BT Newsbank: Project Copyright: Bloomberg Credit: bloomberg Source: bloomberg
The combined market value of the two entities before trading was suspended to complete the merger was 294 billion baht.

site_title: Petronas aims to complete Malaysia LNG investigation by mid-year
summary: Petronas aims to complete its investigation into the disruption of Malaysia's liquefied natural gas (LNG) supply by mid-year. A pipeline leak caused by soil movement at the Sabah-Sarawak pipeline on September 21 led to the company declaring force majeure on gas supply to one of its liquefaction terminals. The disruption fueled concerns of a supply shortage, particularly in Japan and Europe, amid potential sanctions on Russian gas exports. Petronas CEO Tengku Taufik stated that the company will complete its investigation in the first half of the year, but declined to comment on lifting force majeure.

site_title: Hong Kong plays catch-up to Singapore in fierce battle for family offices
summary: Hong Kong is competing with Singapore to attract the world's richest family offices, with the Hong Kong government allocating HK$100 million (S$17.2 million) over three years to attract more family offices. The city will host an invitation-only "Wealth for Good in Hong Kong" summit and refine regulatory measures and tax arrangements for the asset and wealth management sector. Incentives such as streamlined suitability assessments and disclosure processes for sophisticated clients are expected to strengthen Hong Kong's competitive edge, with experts predicting that the city will attract individuals and families who have yet to set up family offices.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
Singapore extends investment promotion tax incentives; raises quantum for Global Investor Programme
Farro’s rapid accumulation of assets underscores Singapore’s continuing appeal to the super-rich, despite recent efforts to raise wealth taxes and introduce stricter conditions for tax breaks.
The city is looking to kickstart its economy as it sees rising competition from Singapore to be Asia’s top destination for business, talent and capital.

site_title: Japan’s top steelmaker eyes 100 billion yen ‘green steel’ project
summary: Japan's top steelmaker, Nippon Steel, is considering a 100 billion yen 'green steel' project using hydrogen to meet its carbon goal. The project, which could cost $990 million or more, aims to boost hydrogen use in existing blast furnaces and build 100% hydrogen-based direct-reduction plants. This move is part of a global push to decarbonize the steel industry, which is one of the biggest polluters. Nippon Steel plans to cut emissions by 30% by 2030 and achieve carbon neutrality by 2050, with Australia and Brazil being potential sites for the project.

site_title: Bearish China sentiment sends Apac venture capital fundraising down by record 49% in 2022
summary: Asia-Pacific venture capital funds saw a record 48.8% decline in aggregate capital raised to $29.4 billion in 2022, down from $57.4 billion in 2021, due to dampened risk appetite among Chinese investors following the tech crackdown. VC funds in Greater China raised only $17.8 billion, a 57% decrease from the previous year. Despite this, deal-making momentum remained robust, with 10,564 transactions, and Preqin expects Asia-Pacific VC to lead global returns with 16% in the 2021-2027 period.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Venture capital funding has flowed away from Series C startups to earlier stages in 2022, as total investment amount in South-east Asia declined compared to 2021.
The quarterly data raises concerns over the potential for a further slowdown in venture funding this year.

site_title: CAAS pumps S$50 million into new aviation sustainability programme
summary: The Singapore government has allocated S$50 million to establish a new aviation sustainability programme under the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS). The programme aims to reduce the sector's carbon footprint and develop new sustainability capabilities. It will provide funding for sector-wide and company-level projects, focusing on adopting energy-efficient systems, cleaner energy sources, and improving operational efficiency. CAAS director-general Han Kok Juan said the programme will provide a boost to decarbonisation efforts and build sustainability as a new competitive advantage for the Singapore air hub.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
If successful in scaling up the use of green hydrogen, Singapore's maritime, aviation and manufacturing sectors can tap low-carbon hydrogen and decarbonise.

Scheduled global capacity as of December 2022 was around 15 per cent lower than in 2019. This figure has been improving through the current quarter of this year, and is expected to stabilise at around 5 per cent below 2019’s figures, says aviation consultancy Cirium.
The study commences in the first quarter of 2023 and aims to assess the various models for driving structural offtakes for Singapore.

site_title: Singapore stocks end lower as rate hikes weigh on sentiment; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks ended lower on Friday, March 3, as inflation and rate hikes continued to weigh on investor sentiment. The Straits Times Index (STI) slid 0.1% to 3,232.02, with gainers outnumbering losers 282 to 230. Top gainer Thai Beverage rose 2.3%, while DFI Retail Group fell 5.3% after posting a 72% year-on-year decline in earnings. Regional markets, including the Hang Seng and Nikkei 225 indices, rose, while the FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI Index slid 0.1%.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
On the Singapore exchange, gainers outnumber losers 80 to 41 after 216.1 million securities worth S$83.6 million change hands.

site_title: Savills Singapore launches energy and sustainability management department
summary: Savills Singapore has launched an energy and sustainability management department to provide custom solutions to building owners, occupiers, and investors, aiming to reduce operational costs and embodied carbon footprint. The move follows Singapore's Green Plan 2030 to achieve net-zero carbon emissions and increasing demand for green properties. The department will offer solutions such as green leases, which promote mutual energy savings and reduce waste. Savills aims to be a choice consultant for clients seeking to green their properties and achieve sustainability targets.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Under the newly introduced Mandatory Energy Improvement regime, "energy-intensive" buildings will have to undergo audits on their energy use.
Construction workers building the new Fernvale Community Club.
The ambition of this government-to-government agreement is to facilitate more collaboration between UK and Singapore industry and academic partners.

Schroders takes into account the investments needed to transition its assets to net-zero, and factors the cost of the impacts they have on the environment in its net cash flows today, says its global head of Real Estate, Sophie van Oosterom. PHOTO: SCHRODERS

site_title: The global appeal of collectible sports trading cards
summary: The global sports trading card market is projected to reach US$2.2 billion by 2028, driven by growing demand from Asia. Collectors are willing to spend thousands or millions of dollars for rare cards of their favorite players. The market has seen significant growth since 2016, with eBay reporting a 109% increase in sports trading card transactions in Malaysia in 2021. Rare cards, such as those of LeBron James and Luka Doncic, have fetched high prices at auctions, with some selling for over US$3 million. The hobby has become a lucrative investment for some collectors, with some storing their most valuable cards in safe deposit boxes.

images.alt_text: A jersey worn by late NBA star Kobe Bryant fetched US$5.8 million at a Sotheby's auction in New York,  Feb 1, 2023.

The jersey that Argentina football legend Diego Maradona wore when scoring twice against England in the 1986 World Cup, including the infamous “hand of God” goal, was auctioned for US$9.3 million, a record for any item of sports memorabilia, Sotheby’s said on Wednesday.

site_title: Investing for China’s next phase
summary: China's annual legislative sessions in March are expected to reinforce the country's focus on stable economic growth, with policymakers likely to back up this priority with accommodative policy settings. The official gross domestic product growth target is expected to be set around 5.5% and fiscal firepower will be deployed to keep growth on track. Monetary policy will also be in play, and investors will be watching for indications of infrastructure investment and eased regulatory restrictions. China's new growth template is seen as marking an inwards turn, promoting domestic consumer spending and technological innovation, while maintaining its importance as a trading partner with the US.

images.alt_text: Andrew McCaffery
Thailand, Singapore, Indonesia and Vietnam are expected to be key beneficiaries of three years of pent-up demand from Chinese travellers.

Chinese households have around 8 trillion to 10 trillion yuan in excess available deposits due to limited spending during the pandemic, and the precedent in other countries suggests about 6 per cent end up in equities investment.
With yuan-denominated funds, investing in and exiting a local portfolio would be easier in the current macroeconomic environment, some investors said.

site_title: Advancing diversity across Asia
summary: Women are underrepresented in Asia's corporate leadership, with only 4% of CEOs, 5% of board chairs, and 10% of CFOs being female. This disparity is driven by legacy systems and societal norms, where women often take on more domestic responsibilities, leading to a 24:1 male-to-female ratio in senior positions. To address this, companies can implement policies such as flexible work arrangements, structured maternity leave, and paternity leave, as well as providing subsidies for childcare and eldercare. Effective diversity initiatives can help increase women's representation in the C-suite and drive business growth.

images.alt_text: “The conversation around women and leadership was really dominated by bias and discrimination,” gender researcher Leah Sheppard says. “We thought that there was a place to talk about women’s agency: Are women actually intending to pursue these positions as much as men?”
The initiative comes after the two organisations agreed to collaborate to increase the diversity and digital quotient of boards in September last year.
While DEI disclosure is nascent in Singapore, the US Securities and Exchange Commission in 2020 required companies to disclose enhanced human capital management details.

site_title: Family office of Nintendo heirs says patience is a super power
summary: The Yamauchi-No 10 Family Office, a $1.5 billion investment firm managed by Nintendo heirs, is willing to wait over a decade for a turnaround in portfolio companies, giving it flexibility and risk appetite in its hunt for technology to revitalize Japan. The family office, led by Banjo Yamauchi, is engaged in a takeover battle with Toyo Construction, accusing the firm of governance flaws and seeking to take it private. This approach allows the office to preserve the "unique creativity and pioneering mindset" of Nintendo's third president, Hiroshi Yamauchi.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Friday; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.3% on Friday, driven by gains in US and European markets. The Straits Times Index (STI) increased to 3,244.4, with Sembcorp Marine, Singtel, and Genting Singapore among the top gainers. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also rose, while the trio of US stocks, Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index, increased after investors engaged in bargain-hunting.

images.alt_text: On the Singapore exchange, losers outnumber gainers 71 to 61 after 331.5 million securities worth S$82.9 million change hands.

site_title: German exports rise in January on robust US demand
summary: German exports rose 2.1% in January, exceeding expectations, driven by strong demand from the US and UK. Exports to the US increased 3.1% and to the UK rose 7.8% compared to December. Imports fell 3.4% in January, resulting in a surplus of 16.7 billion euros. Despite this, the German Chamber of Commerce and Industry forecasts a 2.5% real export growth for 2023, one point below the previous decade's average. Supply chain problems, the energy crisis, and geopolitical risks are expected to impact exporting companies this year.

site_title: Asset managers must sharpen their focus on biodiversity
summary: The COP15 agreement has led to a historic commitment from nearly 200 countries to conserve at least 30% of global lands and waters by 2030. This pact has significant implications for businesses and investors, who must now prioritize biodiversity and adapt to new regulations. Asset managers can prepare by monitoring biodiversity-related risks, engaging with corporates, and preparing for regulatory change, including the Taskforce on Nature-Related Financial Disclosures (TNFD). Investors must navigate complex data and metrics, but the agreement underscores the crucial role of preserving biodiversity for both planetary survival and corporate bottom lines.

images.alt_text: Skeleton of a fish is seen in the Navarro lagoon, which dried up due to the climate phenomenon La Nina, in Navarro, in Buenos Aires province, Argentina.
Generics on sustainability and ESG and climate resilience

site_title: Smart cities should be people-centric, but is that really the case?
summary: Smart cities are launching immersive technologies such as metaverses and digital twins, promising improved public services and tackling urban problems. However, concerns arise about the human dimension of these developments, with some projects disregarding residents' needs and concerns over data use. Examples include the failed Toronto project Sidewalk Labs' Quayside and the Forest City project in Malaysia, which prioritized foreign investors over local community needs. Experts warn that unchecked tech creep could lead to dystopian urban futures where people are merely an afterthought, emphasizing the need for greater accountability and people-centric design.

images.alt_text: Smart buildings: What happens to our free will?

site_title: Boeing seals 737 Max order from HK’s Greater Bay Airlines
summary: Greater Bay Airlines, Hong Kong's newest carrier, ordered 15 Boeing 737-9 Max jets and 5 787s worth around $1.5 billion. The order is a boost for Boeing, which has seen business with mainland Chinese carriers dry up amid US-China tensions. The Max aircraft returned to commercial service in China in January after a nearly four-year absence following crashes in Indonesia and Ethiopia. Deliveries of new 737 Max jets remain stalled, with Boeing prioritizing getting existing planes flying again.

site_title: Marcel Marceau was a giant of an underappreciated art form
summary: French mime artist Marcel Marceau, born 100 years ago, was a giant of an underappreciated art form. Marceau, who was born Marcel Mangel, transformed his body into a powerful medium, creating iconic characters like Bip, a chalk-faced clown. He performed in over 80 countries, introducing a global audience to his brand of vivid yet fleeting poetry. Marceau's art paid tribute to those silenced during World War II, and he was a model of lithe discipline, inspiring other theatre practitioners with the eloquence of the body.

images.alt_text: French actor Vincent Cassel (left) is appearing in two blockbuster French films and Apple TV's spy thriller Liason, in which he co-stars with fellow French export Eva Green (right).

site_title: Lufthansa earnings up but still lagging pre-pandemic levels
summary: Lufthansa reported a full-year operating profit of 1.23 billion euros in 2022, a significant turnaround from a loss of 2.3 billion euros in 2021. Despite high cost inflation and fuel prices, passenger numbers more than doubled and net revenue reached 32.8 billion euros, driven by a strong recovery in air travel demand following the pandemic. However, operating profit remains 34% lower than the pre-pandemic year of 2019. Lufthansa CEO Carsten Spohr stated that the airline has achieved an "unprecedented financial turnaround" in just one year.

site_title: Bitcoin sinks to two-week low as Silvergate fallout hurts crypto
summary: Bitcoin fell to a two-week low, dropping 6% before paring some of the slide to trade around $22,330, amid the fallout of Silvergate Capital's troubles. The US bank, which offers a widely-used payments network for the crypto industry, is reviewing its viability after many exchanges and trading desks stopped accepting or initiating payments through it. The digital-asset industry is also facing regulatory clampdowns and expectations of higher interest rates, contributing to the market's decline.

images.alt_text: The exodus threatens Silvergate’s SEN network, the bank’s key source of deposits and a platform for crypto participants to transfer money among each other.
Silvergate waded deeper into the US policy debate when it revealed in early January how it was stabilising its balance sheet after selling billions in assets to pay depositors.
US cryptocurrency exchange Coinbase Global this week indicated that more layoffs could be in store, after cutting 20 per cent of its workforce in January.
Ethereum has become the world’s most commercially important blockchain platform.

site_title: CGS-CIMB optimistic on Sea’s Q4 earnings; expects Ebitda breakeven in FY2023
summary: CGS-CIMB research expects Sea Ltd to achieve Ebitda breakeven by the second quarter of FY2023, driven by improved e-commerce and digital financial services segments offsetting lower gaming segment earnings. The group is forecast to post narrower adjusted losses, with Shopee and SeaMoney expected to turn Ebitda-positive in the third and fourth quarters, respectively. This optimism allows for a focus on reaccelerating top-line growth in FY2024, with a target price raised to US$85 and a "best digital proxy" rating for the Asean region.

images.alt_text: Sea’s gaming segment remains the sole weak spot in the group’s latest set of financial results, notes CGS-CIMB.

site_title: SpaceX capsule delivers latest four-member crew to International Space Station
summary: SpaceX's Crew Dragon capsule successfully docked with the International Space Station on March 3, 2023, carrying a four-member crew on a six-month science mission. The crew, consisting of two US astronauts, a Russian cosmonaut, and a UAE astronaut, faced a busy workload of over 200 experiments and technology demonstrations. The docking process was delayed due to a faulty sensor issue, but was resolved after a software override. The crew is expected to conduct various research activities, including studying human cell growth in space and controlling combustible materials in microgravity, as part of NASA's Artemis program.

images.alt_text: The uncrewed missions will be launched out of Cape Canaveral, Florida, or Vandenberg Space Force Base in California and the contract could run for as many as 10 years through February of 2033.

site_title: New harbour craft have to run on electricity or be ready for greener fuels from 2030
summary: Singapore's Maritime and Port Authority (MPA) has set a target for harbour craft and pleasure craft sectors to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050. Starting from 2030, all new harbour craft will have to be fully electric or compatible with net-zero fuels like hydrogen. The government also plans to require cleaner energy for airport vehicles by 2040, with a new S$50 million aviation sustainability program to support research and trials. The Land Transport Authority (LTA) will tender for 400 new electric buses this month, and Changi Airport will increase its EV charging stations to over 300 by 2025.

Benefits of being a signatory include access to valuable asset-level information that can be used to assess potential climate risks that may impair returns in the future, according to the Poseidon Principles’ website.

Stacked containers are shown as ships unload their cargo at the Port of Los Angeles, the busiest seaport in the Western Hemisphere. Singapore is in talks with the port, together with the Port of Long Beach and C40 Cities, to establish a green shipping corridor.
Total business spending by shipping companies exceeded S$4.3 billion in 2022.
If successful in scaling up the use of green hydrogen, Singapore's maritime, aviation and manufacturing sectors can tap low-carbon hydrogen and decarbonise.
