Singapore outlines blueprint for maritime decarbonisation
Many energy companies, machinery manufacturers, shipping companies and other maritime-related organisations are working flat out to move towards zero carbon.

site_title: The price of risk and the reward of joy out in the wild
summary: Actor Julian Sands, an experienced hiker, went missing on Mount Baldy in California's San Gabriel Mountains on January 13. Despite being described as an "extremely advanced hiker" and "very, very fit," Sands failed to return from his solo hike, sparking a ground search by the San Bernardino County Sheriff's Department. The article's author, a fellow nature enthusiast, defends the risks of hiking and running in wild places, citing the importance of preparation and the thrill of the experience. The author finds solace and peace of mind in fell running on the UK's high hills, despite the dangers and unpredictability of the terrain.

images.alt_text: On the bike leg of the Roth Ironman race in Germany, 1997. The event covers a 3.8km swim, 180km cycling, and then a 42km run.
Yvon Chouinard, founder of outdoor apparel maker Patagonia, in Wilson, Wyoming, August 2022. The profits of the company he founded 49 years ago will now be used to fight climate change.

Andermatt Swiss Alps' Maureen Yeo participating in the Mongolia Sunrise to Sunset, an event consisting of 10 to 15 days of horse-riding treks before a full marathon around the craggy mountain past west of the stunning Lake Hovsgol.

site_title: Global asset managers in China grapple with fraudulent investor schemes
summary: Global asset managers in China are facing fraudulent investor schemes where online fraudsters dupe investors with juicy returns using their brands and logos. Fidelity International and Neuberger Berman, among others, are battling cheaters who use their trademarks to raise money illegally via the internet and social media. The scams, known as "pig butchering," have become widespread, with China's securities regulator issuing a warning to investors. The low cost of online cheating in China, combined with investors' desire for high returns, has made these scams a lucrative business for tech-savvy swindlers.

images.alt_text: “These are illegal behaviours designed to win investors’ trust with the promise of high returns,” the CSRC said.
Yi Huiman, the current chairman at the CSRC, is likely to be appointed to the same post at the CBIRC.

site_title: Adani shares surge after GQG Partners invests US$1.87 billion
summary: Shares of four Adani Group firms surged on Friday after global investor GQG Partners invested US$1.87 billion, alleviating concerns about the group's ability to attract funds. The stake purchases came after a short-seller's critical report resulted in a US$130 billion loss in market value for seven Adani-listed firms. Adani Group firms saw their net debt total US$24.1 billion as of September 2022, and the investment may assuage concerns about the group's ability to raise funding for loan repayments.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of the Adani Group is seen on the wall of its realty office building on the outskirts of Ahmedabad, India, January 27, 2023. REUTERS/Amit Dave/File Photo

site_title: Fintech company Fazz lays off staff across markets
summary: Fintech company Fazz, formed from the merger of Payfazz and Xfers, has laid off around 15% of its employees, approximately 120 staff, across its markets in Singapore, Indonesia, Malaysia, Vietnam, and Taiwan. The layoffs were made to improve operational efficiency and streamline the business. Fazz had initially planned to expand its workforce to 1,400 but will now focus on its core strengths in payments, credit, and stablecoins. The retrenched employees will receive healthcare benefits and a yearly bonus.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
US cryptocurrency exchange Coinbase Global this week indicated that more layoffs could be in store, after cutting 20 per cent of its workforce in January.

site_title: Credit Suisse dangles 6.5% deposit rate to lure Asia’s wealthy
summary: Credit Suisse is offering 6.5% annual interest on new $5 million+ three-month deposits and up to 7% for one-year deposits to attract wealthy Asian clients amid outflows and banker departures. The rates are 100-200 basis points higher than rivals JPMorgan, UBS, and Citigroup. The move aims to stem outflows and retain clients, but raises concerns about sustaining a funding gap. Total assets at Credit Suisse's wealth division fell to 540.5 billion Swiss francs by the end of last year.

images.alt_text: The business of managing money for the rich in Asia has been a major part of Credit Suisse’s growth efforts.
Credit Suisse froze and wound down a US$10 billion group of funds linked to Greensill Capital,

“Global valuations were negatively impacted by rising interest rates for CS REF International in its key markets of the United States, the United Kingdom, and Germany,” Credit Suisse said in the statement.

site_title: Thailand’s newly minted top mobile firm set for trading debut
summary: Thailand's newly formed top mobile firm, True Corporation, will start trading in Bangkok on March 3, marking the end of the merger between True and Total Access. The combined market value of the two entities before trading was suspended was 294 billion baht. True Corporation now has 55 million mobile subscribers, surpassing Advanced Info Service as the largest telecom company in South-east Asia. The merged entity's enterprise value is approximately US$20.7 billion, with investors including Telenor, CP Group, and China Mobile. The company aims to benefit from synergies and raise US$200 million in venture capital to invest in digital startups.

images.alt_text: Plans for a new industry leader in Thailand have been held up over competition concerns.
The combined entity will overtake Advanced Info Service (AIS), as market leader. True and DTAC have 34 per cent and 21 per cent of mobile subscribers, respectively.

site_title: Toyota GR86: Putting pedal to the mettle
summary: The Toyota GR86 is a lightweight, well-balanced sports car that pays homage to its 40-year-old AE86 predecessor. With a 2.4-liter boxer engine and six-speed manual gearbox, the GR86 rewards dedicated drivers with an engaging, analogue experience. Despite lacking refinement and having a rough cabin, the GR86's simplicity is part of its charm, making it a fun and playful drive. While not the fastest car, its handling and feel make it a standout among its competitors, such as the Mini Cooper S and Volkswagen Golf GTI.

images.alt_text: Global sales slipped 5.6 per cent to 709,870 vehicles, Toyota said, reflecting the continued impact of the chip shortage.

site_title: Japan PM urges extra inflation-relief steps as economy struggles to fire
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has ordered the ruling coalition to draft additional measures to counter price hikes amid intensifying cost-of-living pressures. The move aims to bolster Japan's fragile post-Covid economic recovery, which is being dragged down by a global economic slowdown. The new measures will be compiled by the end of March, and may include the use of budget reserves to protect citizens and businesses from rising costs. This comes as nationwide local elections draw near, further straining Japan's heavy public debt burden.

images.alt_text: More than 3,400 food items will be raised in price in March alone, almost double the number a year ago.

site_title: Singapore retail sales fall 0.8% in January on lower motor vehicle sales, GST hike
summary: Singapore's retail sales fell 0.8% in January, mainly due to lower motor vehicle sales and the impact of a 1% GST hike. Despite this, food and beverage services saw a 21.8% year-on-year growth, driven by increased demand for event and in-flight catering. Economists expect retail sales growth to remain positive this year, with some predicting a 5-6% rate, but citing concerns over inflation, demand fatigue, and uncertain economic conditions.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
People shopping for shoes at Pedro at Wisma Atria on Dec 26, 2022.
New measures were introduced on Thursday (Mar 2) to help entrepreneurs set up businesses in the heartlands.

site_title: China to unveil lowest growth goal in years: analysts
summary: China is expected to set a low growth goal at the National People's Congress, likely around 5.3% for 2023, amid long-running property woes, a sluggish global economy, and geopolitical tensions. The country's housing market remains in a slump, with real estate sales falling and developers struggling to survive. Economists predict that household consumption will drive growth, with a surge in demand expected to push GDP higher by 3.5 points. The low growth goal is seen as a conservative move to address China's economic challenges, which include a real estate crisis and a decline in export demand due to weaker global growth.

images.alt_text: Despite a slew of measures to boost demand and the end of Covid Zero, Chinese residents remain reluctant to commit their savings to a sector that’s seen its worst downturn.

site_title: Eurozone recovery gathers pace, allays fears of recession
summary: The eurozone economy is showing signs of recovery, with business activity growing at an eight-month high and inflation easing. The S&P Global Composite Purchasing Managers' Index rose to 52.0 in February, up from 50.3 in January, indicating a resurgent services sector. Demand picked up, and firms built up a backlog of work for the first time since October. While there are concerns about potential price inflation and the European Central Bank's monetary policy tightening, the overall trend suggests the eurozone will avoid a recession.

images.alt_text: The ECB has promised another half a percentage-point rate hike for Mar 16 to fight inflation.

site_title: South Korea court accepts injunction against Kakao purchase of SM shares
summary: A South Korean court accepted an injunction against Kakao's bid to acquire a 9.05% stake in K-pop agency SM Entertainment, blocking its attempt to own a significant share of the company. This decision could pave the way for HYBE, the agency of K-Pop supergroup BTS, to take over SM, which has been one of the big three K-pop powerhouses. HYBE has already secured a 15.8% stake in SM and is seeking to acquire more shares through a tender offer bid.

site_title: US expands crackdown on China with export ban on Inspur, BGI
summary: The US has expanded its crackdown on China with export restrictions on dozens of Chinese entities, including server maker Inspur Group and BGI Research units. The Commerce Department added these companies to the Entity List, citing activities contrary to US national security and foreign policy interests, including China's military modernization efforts and support to Russia's military. US companies are now banned from exporting to these entities without prior government approval.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Chinese and U.S. flags flutter outside a company building in Shanghai, China April 14, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song
TikTok, owned by Beijing-based ByteDance, is hugely popular in the US, especially among teens.
John Bozzella expects the number of EVs that qualify for tax credits to shrink from the 37 that are currently eligible when the rules are finalised.

site_title: Zoom abruptly fires president Greg Tomb ‘without cause’
summary: Zoom Video Communications abruptly fired President Greg Tomb, a former Google executive, without cause, effective March 3. Tomb, who had only started at Zoom in June, was in a high-profile role overseeing sales operations and appearing on earnings calls. The company will provide severance benefits in accordance with a "termination without cause" arrangement. A spokesperson declined to comment on finding a replacement, stating the company is not looking to fill the position at this time.

site_title: BT Market Focus: Interest rate fears bite markets again (Ep 34)
summary: Rising interest rate fears have again impacted markets, with key drivers and movements discussed in the latest episode of "BT Market Focus". Claressa Monteiro explores the impact of interest rate concerns on markets, featuring insights from SGX and The Business Times' newsdesk. The episode also covers notable corporate news, Singapore government initiatives, and market trends.

images.alt_text: Is inflation wreaking havoc again?
How did markets react after Singapore Budget 2023?

site_title: China’s fragile property market underscored by hesitant buyers
summary: China's property market remains fragile, with only about a third of units sold on debut, halving from a peak in mid-January. Despite measures to boost demand, buyers remain hesitant, prompting analysts to expect more policy support from the National People's Congress. Authorities may reaffirm support for first-time homebuyers and those upgrading, paving the way for further policy easing to stabilize the economy.

images.alt_text: “China has suspended more debt service payments than any other G20 member, and participated in the debt treatment under the Common Framework.” China's Foreign Minister Qin Gang said.
YMTC is one of only a handful of domestic chipmakers within striking range of the global leaders.
China Vanke will raise US$499 million in a Hong Kong share placement, its first in the Asian financial hub since 2020.

site_title: Adidas proves patience is key for brand strategy
summary: Adidas may be reviving its Yeezy deal with Kanye West after terminating the contract last October. Evidence from secondary sneaker reseller markets suggests Adidas' early statements and patience may help redeem the brand. The German apparel company is struggling to fill the gap in lost profits. A potential resurrection of the Yeezy deal could benefit Adidas, but the brand's reputation and profits remain uncertain.

images.alt_text: Craig Margolius
Adidas said that in a worst-case scenario, if it has to write off all existing Yeezy inventory, it faces an operating loss of as much as 700 million euros in 2023.

A pair of Adidas Yeezy shoes seen in a store on the day Adidas terminated its partnership with the American rapper and designer Kanye West, now known as Ye, in Garden City, New York, US, October 25, 2022.

site_title: Malaysia’s Anwar says Asean must be tougher in bid to resolve Myanmar crisis
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim emphasized the need for the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) to be more assertive in resolving the crisis in Myanmar, where his country is hosting 200,000 displaced people. Anwar urged Asean to be tougher and engage with the armed forces to bring about peace, as the military junta often fails to understand the civilian narrative.

images.alt_text: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim reviews honor guards during a welcome ceremony at the Malacanang Palace, Manila, Philippines, March 1, 2023. Ezra Acayan/Pool via REUTERS
Due to the “current economic situation”, Nestle’s factory in the commercial hub Yangon, as well as its head office, would “cease operations”, a spokesperson told AFP, without giving a timeframe.
The latest budget tabled by the Malaysia's Prime Minister and Finance Minister Anwar Ibrahim last Friday (Feb 24) was seen as a pragmatic budget with "a populist flavour”.

site_title: Time US adults spend on TikTok closes in on Netflix: market tracker
summary: US adult users are expected to spend nearly 56 minutes per day on TikTok this year, just six minutes less than the time spent watching Netflix, according to a market tracker forecast. This marks a significant shift, as TikTok use has surpassed YouTube's and continues to grow faster, particularly among US adults in their prime earning years.

images.alt_text: The new approach will require younger users to enter a password if they want to binge more than an hour of videos at one time.
TikTok, owned by Beijing-based ByteDance, is hugely popular in the US, especially among teens.

site_title: Dalian iron ore hits multi-month high on demand optimism
summary: Dalian iron ore futures reached an eight-month high on March 3, driven by favorable fundamentals and optimism about future steel demand. The May iron ore contract ended 1.04% higher at $133.15 a tonne, while April iron ore rose 0.1% to $126.5 a tonne. Mills are ramping up production but have low iron ore inventories, supporting prices. Steel output is expected to rise, preventing steel margins from improving, and steel futures prices are on the uptrend, with rebar, hot-rolled coil, and stainless steel prices increasing.

images.alt_text:
(FILES) This file photo taken on May 1, 2018 shows a worker handling steel cable at a steel factory in Lianyungang in China's eastern Jiangsu province.
China opened trade in iron ore futures to foreign investors on May 4, 2018 on the market of the north-eastern city of Dalian, aiming to boost its pricing clout for one of its top imports, in one additional signal of opening up amidst a trade row with the US. / AFP PHOTO / - / China OUT

The company logo adorns the side of the BHP gobal headquarters in Melbourne on February 21, 2023. - The Australian multinational, a leading producer of metallurgical coal, iron ore, nickel, copper and potash, said net profit slumped 32 percent year-on-year to 6.46 billion US dollars in the six months to December 31. (Photo by William WEST / AFP)

site_title: Apple blocks update to email app with ChatGPT tech: WSJ
summary: Apple has blocked an update to the email app BlueMail, which uses OpenAI's GPT-3 language model, due to concerns it may generate inappropriate content for children. The update was blocked last week, according to Ben Volach, co-founder of BlueMail developer Blix. Apple and Blix did not immediately respond to a request for comment. The decision was made after Apple expressed worries about the potential risks of the AI-powered tools.

site_title: Citigroup cuts hundreds of jobs, including in investment banking and mortgage units
summary: Citigroup is cutting hundreds of jobs across the company, including in investment banking and mortgage units, amounting to less than 1% of its 240,000-person workforce. The cuts are part of the bank's normal business planning and are not a result of a broad mandate for managers to cut staff. Various divisions have been grappling with different reasons for the cuts, following a similar move last year that dismissed dozens of staffers in the mortgage division.

images.alt_text: Citigroup said that stubbornly high inflation across the globe may temper growth.
For the fourth quarter, Citi’s personal banking and wealth management segment saw a 5 per cent jump in revenue to US$6.1 billion.
Citigroup has decided to remove lending value “to all Adani issued securities with immediate effect”.

site_title: Gold prices firm as dollar eases; set for weekly gain
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,840.89 per ounce, on track for its first weekly gain in five, as the dollar eased despite concerns about the US Federal Reserve raising interest rates to curb inflation. Elevated interest rates have reduced gold's appeal as an inflation hedge, increasing its opportunity cost.

images.alt_text: Elevated interest rates dull gold’s appeal as an inflation hedge while raising the opportunity cost of holding the non-yielding asset.

site_title: Big Oil to take centerstage at Houston meet as markets, alliances shift
summary: Top oil executives will attend a Houston meeting to make the case for investment in fossil fuels and renewables to meet rising energy demand while accelerating towards low-carbon energy. Despite Western governments calling for increased oil production, executives say they have a duty to shareholders to maximize returns in an uncertain industry future. A record 7,000 people are attending the CERAWeek discussion, which aims to address global energy security and the transition to a low-carbon industry.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Exxon Mobil logo and stock graph are seen through a magnifier displayed in this illustration taken September 4, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Brent crude futures settled at US$84.75 a barrel, gaining 44 cents, or 0.5 per cent on Thursday.

site_title: Biden inches closer to reelection bid
summary: US President Joe Biden has teased with a smile that he's inching closer to announcing his reelection bid for 2024, but stopped short of setting a launch date. During a brief exchange with reporters, Biden said "When I announce it" when asked when he would announce his candidacy, fueling speculation about his intentions. The president was meeting with Democratic senators in the Capitol Building, further hinting at his potential decision.

images.alt_text: Ajay Banga’s nomination by the United States all but assures he will assume a job that oversees billions of dollars of funding.
A printed balloon with Chinese flag is placed on a U.S. flag in the shape of U.S. map outline, in this illustration taken February 5, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

site_title: US: Stocks bounce as ‘oversold’ market rallies
summary: US stocks surged 1.1% on Thursday, closing at 33,003.57, as investors sought bargains after a recent selloff. The market rebounded despite concerns over tightening monetary policy. Analyst Patrick O'Hare attributed the bounce to the market's "primed" state after steady selling in February and early March. This marks one of the most upbeat sessions in weeks, with shares shaking off early weakness following eurozone inflation data.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 119.13 points, or 0.36 per cent, at the open to 32,780.97.

site_title: AI boost lifts Broadcom forecast amid lingering enterprise weakness
summary: Broadcom forecasts a 20% increase in networking revenue for the current quarter, driven by exponential demand for its AI-related chips in data centers. Despite a deteriorating economy, the company expects strong corporate tech spending, citing the growing potential of AI applications. The company's shares rose 0.4% in extended trading after the announcement, which also included a quarterly dividend of $4.60 per share. Analysts noted mixed end-market demand and lingering weaknesses in broadband and cloud spending.

images.alt_text: Broadcom said it would continue its “constructive work” with the European Commission.
Broadcom also has branched out into enterprise software by acquiring security and mainframe capabilities.

site_title: Review of checkpoint procedures ongoing to help businesses cut costs: Chee Hong Tat
summary: The Singapore government is reviewing checkpoint procedures to help businesses cut costs. Senior Minister of State for Transport Chee Hong Tat announced plans to adopt transhipment permits, similar to air and sea transhipment, to streamline the process. The move aims to reduce administrative and compliance costs, potentially saving up to $40 per transhipment, amounting to $2 million annually. Changes also include relaxing requirements for exports at air checkpoints and allowing non-Singapore registered trucks and foreign drivers to access container terminals.

images.alt_text: When the 4km rail shuttle service is ready, it will take five minutes to travel from Woodlands to Johor Bahru and vice versa.
The proposal, still in its initial stages, would have Malaysian immigration officials on the Singapore side of the Causeway, with Singaporean officials deployed to Johor.
Office workers walking at Raffles Place Park within the heart of Singapore's financial centre in the CBD area on Nov 1, 2022.

site_title: Dell sinks after downbeat outlook overshadows strong quarter
summary: Dell Technologies reported a disappointing quarterly outlook, with revenue expected to decline 19% sequentially in the first quarter due to cratering demand for personal computers. The company cited a "wide range of outcomes" for the full fiscal year, with revenue expected to decrease between 12% and 18%. This overshadowed better-than-expected earnings in the fourth quarter, which saw net revenue decrease 11% to $25 billion. Dell also announced plans to cut 6,650 jobs and retire its CFO, Tom Sweet.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An employee gestures next to a Lenovo logo at Lenovo Tech World in Beijing, China November 15, 2019. REUTERS/Jason Lee/File Photo
The reductions amount to about 5 per cent of Dell’s global workforce, according to a company spokesperson.

site_title: US mortgage rates jump to 6.65%, rising for fourth week in a row
summary: US mortgage rates surged to 6.65% for the fourth consecutive week, according to Freddie Mac. This marks a significant increase from 6.5% last week and is the lowest level of home-purchase loan applications in nearly three decades. Borrowing costs have been volatile since the start of 2023, with rates initially easing up in January before rising again. The increase in mortgage rates is expected to further crimp affordability ahead of the homebuying market's busiest season.

images.alt_text: Mortgage rates had been broadly declining since October but resumed their ascent in recent weeks on expectations the Fed will keep its federal funds rate higher for longer.
The average contract rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage has risen by nine basis points to 6.71 per cent for the week ended Feb 24.

site_title: Australia pushes to phase out live sheep exports to improve animal welfare
summary: Australia is pushing to phase out live sheep exports to improve animal welfare, with the government appointing a panel to consult on the plan. The trade, worth A$85 million, has declined to below 500,000 in 2022, down from a peak of 6.5 million 20 years ago. The ban will not take effect in this term of parliament, but the panel will report by September 30 and consider strengthening the local meat-processing sector and pursuing opportunities in markets like the UK and India.

site_title: Popping China’s balloon
summary: US President Joe Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping agreed to establish "guardrails" for their strategic competition in November. However, China's deployment of a surveillance balloon over American territory thwarted US Secretary of State Antony Blinken's visit to Beijing. China claimed the device was a weather balloon, but intelligence cover-ups are not unique to China. The incident echoes past events, including the cancellation of a 1960 summit due to a Soviet spy plane incident. The poor timing of Blinken's visit may have hindered the establishment of guardrails for their competition.

images.alt_text: Joseph S Nye
Chinese President Xi Jinping meeting with then US Vice President Joe Biden in Beijing, Dec 2013. On balance, the Biden team is correct about being unable to force fundamental changes in China.
An Electric Multiple Unit high-speed train for a rail link project, part of China's Belt and Road Initiative, at the Tegalluar train depot in Bandung, West Java, Indonesia, October 2022.

site_title: Foxconn commits to new electronics manufacturing in India
summary: Foxconn, Apple's largest supplier, has signed an agreement to invest in India's Telangana state, aiming to diversify manufacturing beyond China. The investment will create 100,000 jobs and is the largest in India's electronics sector. The move comes after a meeting between Foxconn chairman Young Liu and Telangana chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao, who also met with Prime Minister Narendra Modi earlier this week. This diversification effort follows a Covid-19 flare-up disrupting Foxconn's biggest iPhone plant in China.

site_title: Qantas to hire 8,500 workers over decade to reverse Covid cuts
summary: Qantas plans to hire 8,500 front-line workers over the next decade, matching the number of roles cut during the pandemic. This move aims to address a labor crunch in the aviation industry, which has faced a pilot shortage and experienced a surge in flight cancellations. The airline also plans to open an engineering academy to maintain its growing fleet of over 300 new aircraft expected to arrive in the next 10 years. This hiring spree highlights the rebuilding task confronting airlines as they rebuild their workforces decimated during the Covid-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: Sydney-based Qantas also announced a stock buyback of as much as A$500 million, adding to a A$400 million programme announced in August.
Qantas is due to report record six-month earnings on Feb 23.

site_title: Malaysia’s Najib acquitted of audit tampering charge
summary: Malaysia's former prime minister Najib Razak was acquitted of an audit tampering charge related to the 1MDB scandal. High Court judge Mohamed Zaini Mazlan found state prosecutors failed to provide sufficient evidence to prove the case, acquitting Najib and co-accused former 1MDB chief Arul Kanda Kandasamy. Najib continues to serve a 12-year prison term from another case, and his acquittal does not affect his current sentence, which could be lengthened by dozens of remaining charges related to the scandal.

images.alt_text: The firms had agreed to pay the settlement figure in three phases: US$800 million within seven days from the end of the London proceedings, and the remainder within two years of the termination.
No single coalition is expected to win a simple majority in parliament.
Former Malaysian prime ministers Mahathir Mohamad (left) and Muhyiddin Yassin have been accused by a Malaysian man of negligence and tort of misfeasance in public office.

site_title: Britain’s fresh produce shortages serve up blame game
summary: The UK is experiencing fresh produce shortages, with empty shelves and rationing due to "sourcing challenges" blamed on weather conditions in southern Europe and north Africa. The government denies Brexit as the cause, but experts say the problem runs deeper, citing a "broken" food system contributing to 30% of global greenhouse gas emissions. The UK food-price inflation soared above 17% last month, and the government is urged to implement a strategy to help UK farmers boost production and protect the environment.

images.alt_text: Kantar's research indicated that grocery-price inflation was the second biggest financial issue for Britons after rocketing energy costs.

site_title: Tokyo inflation slows sharply as subsidies mask ongoing strength
summary: Tokyo's inflation rate slowed sharply in February, decelerating for the first time in over a year, as government subsidies masked underlying price growth. Consumer prices excluding fresh food rose 3.3% from last year, in line with economists' forecasts. The Tokyo figure, a leading indicator of national data, suggests Japan's price growth may have peaked in January. The Bank of Japan's (BOJ) policy path under Kazuo Ueda's leadership will be closely scrutinized, with speculation of looming changes continuing.

images.alt_text: The final au Jibun Bank Japan Services purchasing managers’ index (PMI) rose in February to a seasonally adjusted 54.0 from January’s 52.3.

The Financial Services Agency (FSA) asked an expert panel to review takeover regulations, following a rise in unrestricted stake-building on the stock market that could result in companies effectively being taken over.

site_title: Oil rises on easing US rate hike fears, China demand hopes
summary: Oil prices rose on Thursday, driven by easing concerns over US rate hikes and strong economic rebound in China. Brent crude futures settled at $84.75 a barrel, up 0.5%, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 0.6% to $78.16 a barrel. China's manufacturing activity grew at the fastest pace in over a decade, and refiners are expected to increase seaborne imports of Russian oil. Comments from Atlanta Federal Reserve President Raphael Bostic also helped to ease concerns about rate hikes, while a strengthening dollar and US unemployment claims weighed on the market.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled up 86 cents, or 1 per cent, to US$84.31 a barrel. US West Texas Intermediate crude (WTI) settled up 64 cents, or 0.8 per cent, to US$77.69.

site_title: Blackstone defaults on Nordic CMBS as property values wobble
summary: Blackstone defaulted on a €531 million (S$758.4 million) bond backed by Finnish office and store properties due to rising interest rates, which have put off buyers and led to dropping European property values. The company sought an extension to dispose of assets and repay debt but bondholders voted against it. This comes as about a third of commercial-mortgage-backed securities maturing in 2023 and 2024 face high refinancing risks. The default highlights the impact of rising interest rates on the European property market.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen outside The Blackstone Group headquarters in Manhattan, New York, U.S., November 12, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo

site_title: Sky-high car prices have only one direction to go from here
summary: Car prices have been rising for three years due to pandemic-related disruptions, but a normalization process has begun as chip and component shortages ease. Major manufacturers like Tesla and Ford have made price cuts, while others, like Mercedes-Benz, remain bullish on pricing. Analysts predict a 6.1% drop in Volkswagen's net pricing, 5.6% for BMW, and 1.4% for Stellantis, with Mercedes-Benz expected to see a 0.5% increase. The trend suggests that consumers will eventually think twice about buying new cars due to rising energy and food costs.

images.alt_text: Tesla CEO Elon Musk, who also described how the world could transition to a sustainable energy future of “abundance,” is expected to lay out a plan to make a small, affordable electric vehicle that would broaden his brand’s appeal and fend off competition.
The news gives a boost to Mexico, which is seeking to benefit from geopolitical tensions by attracting investment and eroding Asia’s dominant position in manufacturing industries.

site_title: TikTok isn’t the only China-backed app the White House is worried about
summary: The White House is working to address national-security concerns related to Chinese social-media apps beyond TikTok, Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo stated. The concerns include Chinese-backed companies being on tens of millions of American phones, data concerns, misinformation, and privacy issues. Raimondo emphasized that the risks aren't limited to TikTok, as other Chinese apps pose similar threats. The efforts aim to counter rising economic and strategic threats from China, with Raimondo considering a trip to China this year.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file photo taken on March 24, 2022 shows logo of the networking application TikToK displayed on a tablet in Lille, northern France. - Canadian privacy protection regulators said February 24, 2023 that they have launched an investigation into TikTok over its use and collection of users' personal information. The Chinese-owned platform is under growing Western scrutiny, and Canada's move came just hours after the European Commission banned the app from all employees' work devices to "protect" the institution. (Photo by DENIS CHARLET / AFP)
The new approach will require younger users to enter a password if they want to binge more than an hour of videos at one time.

Australia has not received advice from its security agencies to follow the example of the United States, the European Parliament and Canada to ban Chinese video-sharing app TikTok from government devices, Treasurer Jim Chalmers said on Wednesday.
The app has prompted security concerns from Western governments due to its Chinese ownership and fears the government in Beijing could force the company to share its user data.

site_title: China to reshuffle Cabinet at upcoming annual Parliament session, restructure party and state organs
summary: China's Communist Party will restructure the party and state institutions at the upcoming National People's Congress, increasing party control over governmental functions. President Xi Jinping will secure an unprecedented third five-year term as state president, while outgoing Premier Li Keqiang will set an economic growth target of at least 5% and hand over the role to Li Qiang. The reshuffle aims to boost sagging investor confidence and get China's economy back on track, with Xi's economic team working to expand domestic consumption and create jobs. The party's control over the state apparatus is expected to be further strengthened.

images.alt_text: Despite a slew of measures to boost demand and the end of Covid Zero, Chinese residents remain reluctant to commit their savings to a sector that’s seen its worst downturn.
“China has suspended more debt service payments than any other G20 member, and participated in the debt treatment under the Common Framework.” China's Foreign Minister Qin Gang said.
YMTC is one of only a handful of domestic chipmakers within striking range of the global leaders.
China's manufacturing sector saw its biggest improvement in activity in more than a decade in February and consumer activity climbed, the latest purchasing managers’ surveys showed.

site_title: Japan’s Feb service-sector activity grows at fastest rate in 8 months: PMI
summary: Japan's services sector activity grew at the fastest pace in 8 months in February, according to the au Jibun Bank Japan Services purchasing managers' index (PMI), which rose to 54.0 from January's 52.3. This is the sixth consecutive month of expansion, as the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic receded globally. The PMI figure was higher than the flash reading and above the 50-mark separating expansion from contraction.

images.alt_text: Japan faced a number of setbacks during the last three months of 2022, including the global slowdown, whose effects have gradually become apparent.

The Financial Services Agency (FSA) asked an expert panel to review takeover regulations, following a rise in unrestricted stake-building on the stock market that could result in companies effectively being taken over.

site_title: Asia-Pacific tourism is on a long-haul flight to full recovery
summary: China's Labour Day travel peak season is expected to bring a slow trickle of Chinese tourists to Asia-Pacific countries, with air-ticket bookings from China only 22% of pre-pandemic levels as of February 21. Thailand is the top destination, followed by the US, Japan, Singapore, and Canada. Despite the slow recovery, airline schedules from major Chinese airports suggest a gradual increase in international seat capacity, with 30-40% of pre-pandemic levels expected for the next few months. Experts say the recovery will be gradual, with limited flights, expensive fares, and expired travel documents as major constraints.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Thailand, Singapore, Indonesia and Vietnam are expected to be key beneficiaries of three years of pent-up demand from Chinese travellers.
Leslie Thng, CEO, Scoot
Longer term, Spring Airlines has much bolder ambitions. China’s aviation market, while slower to recover from Covid, is still the world’s second biggest after the US.
Tourism once accounted for nearly five per cent of the city’s economy, but visitor figures plunged last year to 600,000 – less than one per cent of 2018 levels.

Scheduled global capacity as of December 2022 was around 15 per cent lower than in 2019. This figure has been improving through the current quarter of this year, and is expected to stabilise at around 5 per cent below 2019’s figures, says aviation consultancy Cirium.
Airlines around the world have pushed up fares as demand outstrips supply following rapid rebound in travel.
Hong Kong’s slow pace of reopening has put the city at risk of losing its spot as Asia’s premier arts and exhibition centre for good.

Russia's planes, including Aeroflot and Rossiya, are parked at Sheremetyevo International Airport in Moscow. Russian airspace has been closed to dozens of Western countries, and flights between many European countries and Uzbekistan have risen 105.9 per cent since 2019 and 36 per cent since Jan 2022.

Tourism is a key source of jobs and driver of Thailand’s economy and was typically worth about 12 per cent of its annual gross domestic product before the pandemic struck and decimated its travel sector.
Dusit International CEO Suphajee Suthumpun: "Covid-19 differentiated between those hotels who are able to adjust, and those who cannot."

site_title: Asia: markets rise with Wall Street on lower rate hopes
summary: Asian markets rose on Friday following a Wall Street rally, driven by a top Federal Reserve official's hints of a possible summer pause in interest-rate hikes. The official, Raphael Bostic, said he favors a 25-point rate hike at the March meeting, rather than a 50-point increase. This optimism lifted markets in Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, and other Asian cities, despite concerns about inflation and the US central bank's policy trajectory. The rally also followed a strong run of data in February, which led investors to bet on rates hitting a peak of 5.5% this year.

images.alt_text: In early Asian trade, Hong Kong stocks retreated after a four per cent surge on Wednesday, while Tokyo, Shanghai, Singapore, Wellington and Taipei were also in the red.

site_title: Harry and Meghan told to leave their royal cottage in the UK
summary: Prince Harry and Meghan, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, have been asked to vacate Frogmore Cottage, their five-bedroom Georgian house on the grounds of Windsor Castle, due to a "private family matter." The request comes after the publication of Harry's memoir, "Spare," which criticized his relationship with his father, King Charles III. The couple had been offered the house by Queen Elizabeth II in 2018, but will now be required to move out, potentially affecting their attendance at the king's coronation in May.

images.alt_text: A poster advertising the forthcoming publication of the book 'Spare' by Britain's Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex, is pictured in the window of a book store in London on January 6, 2023. - Prince Harry's autobiography "Spare" is not due out until next week but it dominated headlines on Thursday after a Spanish-language version of the memoir mistakenly went on sale. The book was hurriedly withdrawn from shelves in Spain but not before copies were obtained by media outlets, who pored over its contents -- and its implications for Britain's most famous family. (Photo by Daniel LEAL / AFP)

site_title: Ford creates new unit to develop semi-autonomous driving tech
summary: Ford Motor is forming a new unit, Latitude AI, to focus on semi-autonomous features. The company is hiring approximately 550 employees from Argo AI, a self-driving startup that Ford and Volkswagen shut down in October. The new unit will develop a hands-free, eyes-off-the-road automated driving system for millions of vehicles, utilizing technology such as BlueCruise, which has logged over 50 million miles of use. The Pittsburgh-based Latitude AI will be a major step forward for Ford's semi-autonomous driving capabilities.

images.alt_text: A row of 2014 Ford Motor Co. Escape vehicles sit on display at Uftring Ford in East Peoria, Illinois, U.S., on Saturday, Nov. 30, 2013. Automakers entered their year-end sales push in November with the most cars and trucks on U.S. dealer lots in eight years, a buildup that’s poised to test the industry’s newfound pricing discipline. Photographer: Daniel Acker/Bloomberg
The cuts were needed to “revitalise business in Europe”, Ford said in a statement.
Ford will begin offering LFP batteries in its Mustang Mach-E model later this year and in its F-150 Lightning plug-in pickup truck next year.

Ford is moving ahead with the project despite uncertainty around how the US Treasury Department will interpret requirements in President Joe Biden’s signature climate package, the Inflation Reduction Act.

site_title: UK banks ramp up crypto restrictions with new retail limits
summary: UK banks HSBC and Nationwide are imposing restrictions on retail customers' access to cryptocurrencies. Nationwide has set daily limits of £5,000 on debit-card purchases and banned credit card purchases, citing the Financial Conduct Authority's warnings on crypto as high risk. HSBC has also barred customers from making crypto purchases via its credit cards since last month, citing possible risk to customers.

site_title: Singapore’s PMI inches up to neutral reading after boost from China, but recovery still uncertain
summary: Singapore's Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) reading inched up to 50 in February, indicating a neutral reading after five consecutive months of contraction. The improvement was led by China's reopening and reduced recession risks in major economies. However, economists warned that risks to recovery remain, particularly with new export orders still in contraction and business confidence not yet returning strongly. A further improvement in new export orders is key for the upward momentum to be sustainable, according to OCBC chief economist Selena Ling.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Despite the slight improvement in January's PMI, economists said they remain unconvinced that the manufacturing sector will be seeing better days soon.
On a seasonally adjusted, monthly basis, manufacturing output falls 1.1 per cent in January, reversing from an expansion in December 2022.

site_title: Boris Johnson says voting for new Brexit deal will be hard
summary: Boris Johnson expressed difficulty in supporting a revised Brexit deal proposed by Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, calling it a "different" approach than his own. Johnson, a former UK leader, acknowledged the prevailing wind of public opinion is behind Sunak's efforts to reset the UK's relationship with the EU. Johnson's influence could impact potential rebellion against the deal, while Sunak has garnered support from the main opposition Labour Party and some Conservative MPs, including those in the European Research Group.

images.alt_text: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak (left) and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen shake hands at a press conference after securing the deal, which will regulate trade in Northern Ireland.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Jardine Matheson, Hongkong Land, DFI Retail Group
summary: Key developments in the stock market include: DFI Retail Group's underlying earnings dropped 72% to US$29 million for FY2022, while Jardine Matheson saw a 5% increase in underlying net profit to US$1.6 billion for FY2022, despite a 81% decline in net profit. Hongkong Land reported a 20% fall in underlying earnings to US$766.1 million for FY2022, reversing a net loss in 2021. These companies' stock prices moved as follows: Jardine Matheson (down 0.71%), Hongkong Land (up 0.48%).

site_title: DFI Retail Group posts 72% drop in underlying earnings to US$29m
summary: DFI Retail Group reported a 72% drop in underlying earnings to US$29 million for FY2022, down from US$105 million in FY2021. The group's net loss increased to US$114.6 million, primarily due to a US$171 million impairment loss related to its investment in Robinsons Retail. Despite a 1% decline in total revenue, reported subsidiary sales remained steady at US$9.2 billion. The company attributed the decline to easing movement restrictions in South-east Asia and store disruptions in Singapore. DFI expects improved performance in 2023, with a focus on recovery in its health and beauty and restaurants businesses.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
UOBKH has raised its target price on the stock to S$3.90 from S$2.96 to reflect a target price-to-earnings multiple 30 times, in line with DFI’s past five-year average.

site_title: Global obesity costs expected to double to US$4.27 trillion by 2035
summary: The global obesity crisis is expected to double in economic impact to $4.27 trillion by 2035, affecting almost a quarter of people over 5 years old. The prevalence of obesity and excess body weight is projected to rise to 54% of people over 5 years old, with 24% expected to be obese. This will drive costs to 2.9% of global GDP, affecting productivity and economic growth. New treatments and government programs are being pushed to address the issue, which is considered a longstanding, intractable problem.

site_title: Jardine Matheson Holdings FY2022 underlying profit up 5% to US$1.6b
summary: Jardine Matheson Holdings reported a 5% increase in underlying net profit to US$1.6 billion for FY2022, driven by strong performances from Astra and Jardine Cycle and Carriage. However, the company's net profit was down 81% to US$354 million due to non-trading losses. A final dividend of US$1.60 per share has been recommended, subject to shareholder approval. Despite the challenges from global economic headwinds, Jardine Matheson expects to benefit from growth in its South-east Asian and Chinese markets.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Looking ahead, Jardine C&C’s chairman Ben Keswick said the company expects to face challenges from uncertainties around the global economic outlook.

site_title: BlackRock becomes Mapletree Logistics Trust’s substantial shareholder
summary: BlackRock has become Mapletree Logistics Trust's (MLT) latest substantial shareholder after acquiring 1.8 million units for S$3 million, resulting in a stake of 5.02% in the trust. The acquisition lifted BlackRock's deemed interest in MLT, which now stands at 242.1 million units. The purchase price was S$1.69 per unit, slightly lower than the closing price of S$1.67 on the same day.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

site_title: World’s biggest currency crash prompts Lebanon to intervene anew
summary: Lebanon's central bank has announced a plan to intervene in the country's currency crisis by selling dollars at a weaker rate, pricing them at 70,000 pounds per US currency, down from the official exchange rate of 15,000. The move aims to reduce pressure on the pound, which has plummeted to a record 90,000 in the black market. The measures come as Lebanon faces a severe financial crisis, with the government defaulting on $30 billion in international debt in 2020. Economists warn that the plan is unlikely to succeed, citing the country's limited international reserves and a hyperinflationary spiral.

images.alt_text: In a protest against informal restrictions on cash withdrawals that have been in place since 2019, Lebanese depositors attacked banks in a Beirut neighbourhood on Thursday (Feb 19).  To gain access to their money, depositors resort to lawsuits and, often, violence.

site_title: Scientists discover hidden corridor in Great Pyramid of Giza
summary: Scientists have discovered a hidden 30-foot-long corridor near the main entrance of the 4,500-year-old Great Pyramid of Giza, using radar and ultrasound. The corridor, likely created to redistribute the pyramid's weight, was confirmed using a 6mm-thick endoscope. Egyptian antiquities officials believe it could lead to further findings, and the discovery may indicate the pharaoh had more than one burial chamber. The finding is part of the Scan Pyramids project, which has been using non-invasive technology since 2015 to explore the pyramid.

site_title: Alibaba and Ant venture to launch RISC-V chips for payments
summary: Alibaba's chip unit T-Head and Alipay are developing RISC-V chips for secure payments, to be released in commercially available hardware devices soon. The move comes as Chinese companies invest in chips amid US export restrictions. The open-source nature of RISC-V makes it less susceptible to export restrictions. This development is part of China's growing focus on the RISC-V architecture, with notable companies like Alphabet and Intel participating in the ecosystem.

site_title: China urges global lenders’ involvement in developing nations’ debt
summary: China's Foreign Minister Qin Gang urged global lenders to participate in restructuring the debt of developing countries, criticizing multilateral lenders for not accepting losses. China, the world's largest bilateral creditor, has suspended more debt service payments than any other G20 member. The G20 set up a Common Framework in 2020 to offer relief to low-income countries facing debt pressures due to the pandemic and Ukraine war. China has proposed initiatives under the framework, but the US has criticized China for "foot-dragging" on debt relief.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq fall as yields rally
summary: US stocks fell on Thursday as the 10-year Treasury yield surged above 4% on bets of tighter monetary policy. The Dow Jones rose 119.13 points, or 0.36%, to 32,780.97, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite opened lower, down 0.32% and 0.93%, respectively. Tesla declined after releasing few details on its affordable electric vehicle. The yield rally was driven by expectations of longer periods of monetary policy tightening.

site_title: American Airlines goes all-in on a US$15 billion debt-cutting plan
summary: American Airlines has unveiled a $15 billion debt-cutting plan, aiming to reduce its leverage metric to its lowest since 2017 by the end of the year. The airline's new CFO, Devon May, is optimistic about generating sufficient revenue to raise its credit rating from B- to BB, despite potential challenges from high labor and fuel costs and a possible recession. The plan is part of a broader effort to achieve a more balanced approach to capital, with a focus on free cash flow to pay down debt.

images.alt_text: Thailand has attracted the most forward bookings by the mainland Chinese for outbound travel in the Labour Day holiday period around May.
Tourism once accounted for nearly five per cent of the city’s economy, but visitor figures plunged last year to 600,000 – less than one per cent of 2018 levels.
Airlines around the world have pushed up fares as demand outstrips supply following rapid rebound in travel.
American Airlines expects an adjusted profit of US$2.50 and US$3.50 per share for 2023, up from 50 cents per share a year earlier.

site_title: India's Adani group gets US$1.87 billion investment from US boutique firm GQG
summary: US boutique firm GQG Partners has invested $1.87 billion in four Adani group companies, marking the first major investment since a short-seller's report sparked a stock rout. GQG bought shares in Adani Enterprises, Adani Ports, Adani Green Energy, and Adani Transmission, citing substantial long-term growth prospects. The investment comes as Adani has sought to calm investors, with the group securing a $3 billion loan from a sovereign wealth fund. This deal is seen as a positive for Adani stocks, but investors will monitor the results of an investigation into the group's regulatory disclosures.

images.alt_text: All 10 Adani Group stocks closed higher on Wednesday, the first such occurrence since the explosive report by US short-seller Hindenburg Research in late January sparked an unprecedented rout in the conglomerate’s shares.

site_title: Massive fire hits Hong Kong high-rise construction site
summary: A massive fire broke out at a 42-storey high-rise construction site in Hong Kong's Tsim Sha Tsui district on Thursday night, spreading to the fourth level of severity by morning. No casualties were reported, but 130 affected residents were relocated. Flames were visible across the harbour, and debris fell onto surrounding streets. The fire threatened to spread to nearby residential blocks, prompting evacuations. The cause of the fire is unknown, and officials are investigating.

images.alt_text: Cathay Pacific Airways check in counters at Hong Kong International Airport. Photographer: Ivan Abreu/Bloomberg
Looking ahead, the company said it continues to be disciplined in evaluating and selecting development opportunities in the Chinese mainland, with a focus on Tier 1 and Tier 2 cities.

site_title: Becoming ‘climate-smart’ – lessons from Constance
summary: Constance, Germany, a "smart city" model project, aims to become climate-neutral by 2035 through a comprehensive climate protection strategy, including renewable energy, sustainable urban mobility, and waste reduction. The city has implemented various initiatives, such as a climate donation fund, eco-friendly waste management, and a deposit system for reusable cups. Constance's approach to climate protection and sustainable urban development has drawn comparisons to Singapore, which has also made strides in becoming a "smart nation." The city's focus on citizen participation, digital sovereignty, and environmental protection has earned it recognition as a leader in climate-smart urban planning.

images.alt_text: Glass-walled building reflecting trees. Close to half of Singapore’s buildings have been retrofitted with green roofs, edible gardens, recreational rooftop gardens, and verdant green walls, leading up to the national target of greening 80 per cent of its buildings by 2030.

site_title: Eurozone inflation eases in February but core prices surge
summary: Eurozone inflation eased to 8.5% in February, below expectations of 8.2%, but core prices surged to 5.6%, fueling concerns about second-round effects and the need for further interest rate hikes. The European Central Bank (ECB) has promised another half-point rate hike on March 16, but markets are pricing in higher hikes, with some predicting a 50-basis-point increase. Underlying inflation, a key indicator, jumped above expectations, suggesting a protracted fight to reach the ECB's 2% target.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The euro sign is photographed in front of the former head quarter of the European Central Bank in Frankfurt, Germany, April 9, 2019. Picture is taken on slow shutter speed while the camera was moved.  REUTERS/Kai Pfaffenbach/File Photo
Most of the loss came from writedowns in the ECB’s relatively small own-funds and US dollar portfolio, and from the interest it paid to central banks of eurozone member countries.

site_title: US Q4 labour costs revised higher; productivity growth lowered
summary: US labour costs rose at a 6.9% rate in the third quarter and 3.2% annualized rate in the fourth quarter, revised higher from initial estimates. Unit labour costs surged 6.5% in 2022, outpacing the Federal Reserve's 2% inflation target. This has led to fears of continued interest rate hikes by the Fed, with two additional 25-basis-point rate hikes expected in March and May. Productivity growth was downgraded to a 1.7% rate from the previously reported 3.0% pace in the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: While the Biden administration push, described by economists as an industrial policy, has opened opportunities for some companies, significant hurdles remain.

site_title: Microsoft's licensing offer likely to satisfy EU on Activision, sources say
summary: Microsoft is likely to satisfy EU antitrust concerns over its $69 billion acquisition of Activision, with the company offering licensing deals to rivals, according to sources. The European Commission is not expected to demand that Microsoft sell assets, including the lucrative "Call of Duty" franchise, as part of the deal. Microsoft has signed 10-year licensing deals with Nintendo and Nvidia, which will bring Call of Duty to their gaming platforms, pending regulatory approval. The deal faces regulatory headwinds in Britain and the US, but Microsoft's offer appears to address EU concerns.

images.alt_text: Microsoft’s operating system will include the new Bing in desktop computers’ search box, which helps half a billion monthly users navigate their files and the Internet, the company said.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims decline further
summary: US weekly jobless claims declined by 2,000 to 190,000 for the week ended Feb 25, marking the seventh straight week below 200,000. This sustained labour market strength suggests the Federal Reserve may raise interest rates further. Economists attribute the low claims to companies over-hiring during the pandemic and severance packages, which may be keeping laid-off workers from filing claims. This strengthens the case for the Fed to raise interest rates at least three more times this year.

images.alt_text: Manufacturing is also being undermined by the dollar’s past appreciation against the currencies of the United States’ main trade partners and softening global demand.

site_title: Global CO2 emissions hit a record even as Europe’s decline
summary: Global CO2 emissions reached a record high in 2022, growing 0.9% to over 36.8 billion metric tons, despite a decline in industrial production in China and Europe. The increase was mainly driven by Asia's emerging markets, particularly coal-fired power. Extreme weather events contributed to about a fifth of the growth, with heat waves becoming more intense and frequent due to climate change. Emissions in the European Union fell 2.5%, while China saw a slight drop of 0.2%, and the US experienced a 0.8% increase.

images.alt_text: Governor Ron Desantis, seen here at his midterms election victory celebration in Tampa on Nov 8, 2022, is the unofficial leader of the conservative war against ESG.

site_title: Citi pledges to cut emissions for more sectors including coal mining
summary: US bank Citi has set targets to cut emissions from lending to coal mining, auto, steel, and real estate sectors by the end of the decade, in line with its goal of reaching net-zero emissions by 2050. Citi aims to reduce absolute emissions from thermal coal mining by 90% and emissions from auto manufacturing by 31%, while cutting emissions from commercial real estate in North America by 41%. The bank's approach is seen as more thoughtful than some European lenders, with Citi's chief sustainability officer stating the goal is to engage with clients, not divest.

site_title: Six successful Asian female chef-owners share their stories of grit in a male-dominated culinary world
summary: Six successful Asian female chef-owners share their stories of perseverance in a male-dominated culinary world. These women, from Singapore to Japan, have achieved Michelin stars and opened highly sought-after fine dining restaurants. They attribute their success to hard work, teamwork, and empathy. Key takeaways include: female chefs can excel in the industry, and women bring unique strengths such as multitasking and emotional intelligence to leadership roles. The women also emphasize the importance of community, collaboration, and adaptability in overcoming challenges.

images.alt_text: The interiors of Cloudstreet restaurant.

site_title: Hongkong Land posts 20% fall in underlying net profit to US$766m
summary: Hongkong Land reported a 20% decline in underlying net profit to US$766.1 million for 2022, down from US$966 million in the prior year. The company's net profit was US$203 million, with lower valuations of its investment properties and a lower contribution from its development properties business. Revenue fell 5.9% to US$2.2 billion, and the board recommended a final dividend of US$0.16 per share. Looking ahead, the company will continue to evaluate and select development opportunities in the Chinese mainland, with a focus on Tier 1 and Tier 2 cities.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

Light public housing, which will feature modular construction for speed, has been presented as a temporary fix when supply of traditional public rental apartments is struggling to keep pace with demand.
View of Marina Bay Financial Centre and CBD area taken on 18 June 2022.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise but stubborn inflation data caps gains
summary: European shares rose 0.5% on Thursday, boosted by consumer staples and energy stocks, but inflation data remained stubbornly high, fueling fears of more European Central Bank rate hikes. Consumer price inflation in the euro zone rose 8.5% in February, above projections. Energy stocks rose 1.4% and UK's FTSE 100 index gained 0.4% as sterling weakened. Analysts expect the ECB to remain hawkish, leading to less conducive business conditions for European companies.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 1.1 per cent higher at 33,003.57 on Thursday.

site_title: US unveils new cybersecurity strategy with tighter regulations
summary: The US has unveiled a new cybersecurity strategy aimed at bolstering the country's defenses against hacking and digital crimes. The strategy calls for tighter regulations on existing cybersecurity practices, improved collaboration between the government and private sector, and targeting Russia and China as the primary cybersecurity threats. The plan includes measures to reine in Russian hackers, improve patching of computer system vulnerabilities, and require cloud companies to verify foreign customers' identities. The strategy aims to guide future policy and address the growing issue of ransomware attacks.

site_title: Crypto exchange Coinbase ditches embattled lender Silvergate
summary: Coinbase has severed ties with embattled lender Silvergate, citing minimal exposure to the struggling financial institution. The decision comes as Silvergate faces a liquidity crisis following FTX's bankruptcy last year. Coinbase will partner with other financial institutions to facilitate cash transactions for clients who had parked funds with the exchange. Shares of Silvergate nearly halved after the announcement, while Coinbase's shares fell nearly 7%. Silvergate has also become a target for short sellers, with an estimated 82% of its float shorted.

images.alt_text: Coinbase has laid off staff and reduce its areas of focus in the past year.

site_title: Julius Baer plans to ramp up Asia hiring after China reopening
summary: Julius Baer, a Zurich-based private bank, plans to ramp up hiring in Asia following China's reopening, which is expected to boost business in the region. CEO Philipp Rickenbacher stated that the bank has a full pipeline in Hong Kong and Singapore and will continue to focus on its offshore franchise in China. This move follows other Swiss money managers like UBS Group, which are also hiring in Asia. Julius Baer's expansion plans come after the bank posted better-than-expected inflows of client funds and met cost and profitability targets in 2022.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file photo taken on September 30, 2018 shows a sign or logo of the Swiss private bank Julius Baer on the top of a building at sunset. - Swiss bank Julius Baer said on September 25, 2020, it would pay about 150 million Swiss francs (138 million euros, $162 million) following a ruling over unauthorised withdrawals at an East German trading company. (Photo by Fabrice COFFRINI / AFP)
Julius Baer said on Wednesday it was making an equity investment in Grow, a China-based domestic asset management company.

site_title: New York City is not waiting for the White House to enforce fair housing
summary: New York City has released a report on its progress towards achieving its fair housing goals, despite the federal AFFH rule no longer existing. The city has completed or advanced over three-quarters of its 81 agenda items, including apartment rehabilitation and down-payment assistance. The report tracks the city's work towards six goals, including combating discrimination and preserving affordable housing. New York's efforts have sharpened its fight against bias, and the city's approach could serve as a model for other cities and counties looking to undo segregation.

images.alt_text: Singapore is one of the top 10 cities in the high-end activity index, with 18 ultra-prime property sales and 121 super-prime property sales, says Knight Frank.
Homebuyers, already facing record-high prices, took an additional hit from mortgage rates which more than doubled last year.

site_title: Property developer China Vanke raises HK$3.92 billion in share sale
summary: Chinese state-backed property developer China Vanke raised HK$3.92 billion (S$672.6 million) in a share sale, selling 300 million shares at HK$13.05 per share. The placement was the first test of investor appetite for a mainland developer share sale in 2023, with nearly 100 institutional investors participating, including those from the US and Europe. Vanke plans to use 60% of the proceeds to repay debt and replenish working capital, and not for new domestic residential developments. The share sale came ahead of Vanke's earnings announcement and is seen as a positive sign for the sector's fundraising prospects.

images.alt_text: China Vanke will raise US$499 million in a Hong Kong share placement, its first in the Asian financial hub since 2020.

The easing could mark the most dramatic shift in China’s real estate policy, adding to a clutch of measures issued since November to bolster the battered sector that accounts for about a quarter of the nation’s economy.

The shares and bonds surge came after China Securities Regulatory Commission said on Monday it would broaden equity financing channels, including private share placements for China and Hong Kong-listed Chinese developers, lifting a ban in place for years.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Key developments include government tenders to prioritize environmental sustainability, new rules for HDB flat selection, a rising cut-off yield on the 6-month Singapore Treasury bill, increased investment requirements for ultra-rich seeking permanent resident status, and a Singapore-based social enterprise criticizing Japan-backed transition finance guidelines. The National Productivity Fund has disbursed over $1 billion for 47 projects in the last five years.

site_title: Onshoring, friendshoring, and the balancing act of “Made in America”
summary: US-China tensions escalated with the Chinese balloon incident, prompting a shift away from "Invest, align, compete" towards trade policies favoring national security. The Biden administration's CHIPS act and "Made in America" initiatives are part of this dynamic. However, overcommitting to economic nationalism could be detrimental, and a balanced approach is needed, allowing for selective engagement with China and maintaining global trade's prosperity.

images.alt_text: Japan’s G7 focus will be geopolitics, not economics
John Bozzella expects the number of EVs that qualify for tax credits to shrink from the 37 that are currently eligible when the rules are finalised.

US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen singled out China, which has come in for increasing criticism from the Biden administration over a number of issues, as a country on which the US and others should be less reliant.

site_title: Britain’s Nationwide curbs cryptocurrency purchases by customers
summary: Nationwide Building Society has restricted customers' ability to buy cryptocurrencies, banning payments to crypto exchanges using credit cards and limiting adult current accounts to £5,000 per day. The move is in response to regulatory concerns over the risks of buying digital currencies. This announcement follows similar restrictions by other UK banks, including Santander and Natwest Group, amid the US Department of Justice's investigation into Binance for suspected money laundering and sanctions violations.

site_title: Japan weighs broader tender offer rules as unsolicited takeovers rise
summary: Japan's Financial Services Agency (FSA) is reviewing takeover regulations amid a rise in unrestricted stake-building on the stock market, potentially allowing companies to be taken over without shareholder input. The FSA asked an expert panel to consider expanding tender offer rules to cover stake-building on the market, which currently does not require a tender offer. The review also aims to clarify rules on partial takeovers, joint proposals, and disclosure requirements. This would be the first revision of such rules in 17 years.

site_title: US home prices to fall 4.5% in 2023 despite higher rates
summary: US home prices are forecast to decline 4.5% in 2023, less than previously thought, despite higher interest rates. Demand has declined only slightly, and analysts expect interest rates to rise further, but not as much as initially predicted. Home prices are expected to fall 10% from peak to trough, less severe than during the 2007-08 financial crisis. However, an overall housing shortage will support historically elevated levels of prices, and volatile mortgage rates pose affordability challenges.

images.alt_text: The average contract rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage has risen by nine basis points to 6.71 per cent for the week ended Feb 24.
With competition easing, home shoppers who were determined to seal a deal gained a little leverage in negotiations with sellers.
Home sales dropped last year amid rising interest rates and prices cooled from pandemic-fuelled highs.

site_title: Choose or lose your BTO spot: HDB tightens rules on flat selection
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) in Singapore has introduced stricter rules for applicants who decline a flat offer, bumping them down the queue. First-time homebuyers and married couples will receive higher priority. Those who decline multiple times targeting popular estates or specific flat types may be blocked from HDB sales exercises for a year. The new rules aim to shorten long lines for new public housing flats and encourage applicants to take their applications seriously.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim

Rents for the condo market climbs 1.4 per cent in January from December 2022, while HDB rental prices rise 0.6 per cent from the month before, according to flash estimates from SRX and 99.co on Tuesday (Feb 28).

MPs call for even more support for families' housing aspirations, extend support for unwed single mothers.

site_title: Majority of firms qualifying for foreign worker flexibility scheme are foreign-owned
summary: Around 40% of companies qualifying for Singapore's Manpower for Strategic Economic Priorities (M-SEP) scheme have local shareholding of at least 30%. However, local shareholding is not a prerequisite for the scheme, which targets firms that contribute to the country's growth and competitiveness. About 1,000 firms are currently eligible, and they can hire foreign workers above the prevailing dependency ratio ceiling for two years, subject to certain conditions.

images.alt_text: CEO of Goldbell Group Arthur Chua with Dr Tan See Leng, Minister for Manpower and Second Minister for Trade and Industry at Goldbell's Benoi Road premise.
Companies eligible for M-SEP are aligned with Singapore's economic goals.
More 'targeted approach' taken to help firms with urgent foreign manpower needs: Tan

site_title: Singaporeans snap up free Hong Kong air tickets within the hour
summary: Singaporeans quickly snapped up 12,500 free round-trip air tickets to Hong Kong within 60 minutes, exceeding the initial allocation. The giveaway, part of Hong Kong's 500,000 free ticket campaign, was available from midday local time and was fully allocated. Winners will be announced on March 20. The tickets are part of a broader effort to boost tourism in the Asian financial hub, following the lifting of its outdoor mask mandate.

site_title: National Productivity Fund disbursed over S$1b for 47 projects in the last five years
summary: The National Productivity Fund (NPF) in Singapore has disbursed over S$1 billion across 47 government projects over the last five years, with about half spent on productivity projects and the other half on continuing education and training (CET) programs. The fund supports sector-specific schemes and industry transformation maps, and is available to government ministries and agencies to benefit trade associations and industry sectors. The NPF also considers industry feedback, local and global best practices, and relevant benchmarking studies when deciding how much to fund each sector.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Singapore extends investment promotion tax incentives; raises quantum for Global Investor Programme
Investments will include supporting businesses here in building new capabilities, adding greater value to the domestic ecosystem, and upskilling workers.

site_title: Euro falls against the US dollar after eurozone inflation data
summary: The euro fell 0.5% against the US dollar at US$1.0618, following weaker-than-expected eurozone inflation data in February, which eased to 8.5% from 8.6% a month earlier. Despite this, investors still expect the European Central Bank to raise interest rates, with a 50-basis-point hike predicted in March and May. The US dollar index rose 0.43% to 104.82, while sterling was down 0.46% to US$1.1970, following comments from Bank of England governor Andrew Bailey.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. Dollar and Euro banknotes are seen in this illustration taken July 17, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration//File Photo

site_title: Stop aping Western ways, China warns ‘hedonistic’ bankers
summary: China's top anti-graft watchdog has issued directives to bankers to clean up their "hedonistic" lifestyles and stop copying Western ways, amid President Xi Jinping's campaign to tighten the Communist Party's grip on the financial system. The move comes after the sudden disappearance of a top investment banker and the downfall of dozens of officials in a sweeping corruption crackdown. Authorities are considering reviving a powerful committee to coordinate economic and financial policy, and are also tightening control over capital outflows and foreign banks. The directives are seen as a key part of Xi's efforts to restore growth and manage the economic fallout of spiralling ties with the US.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Fan Bao, founder, Chairman and CEO of China Renaissance Group, an investment bank led by one of the country’s most famed rainmakers, holds a news conference on its IPO in Hong Kong, China September 13, 2018.      REUTERS/Bobby Yip/File Photo
Hong Kong led gains in early trade, piling on more than two per cent after falling for the previous six trading days, thanks to a rally in heavyweight tech firms.

site_title: Hong Kong retail sales rise in Jan, inbound tourism to add to cheer
summary: Hong Kong's retail sales rose 5.1% in January, the second consecutive month of growth, driven by improved consumer sentiment and the relaxation of pandemic-related rules. Retail sales value increased 7% to HK$36.2 billion, with tourist arrivals soaring nearly 70 times from a year earlier to 498,689. The government expects further economic growth this year, with an estimated 3.5-5.5% expansion, driven by recovering consumer spending on the mainland and a rebound in travel.

site_title: No changes to STI constituents following March quarterly review
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) will not undergo any changes to its constituent stocks following the March quarterly review, announced by FTSE Russell on March 2. The reserve list of stocks, which will replace ineligible constituents, includes CapitaLand Ascott Trust, Frasers Centrepoint Trust, Olam Group, Sembcorp Marine, and Suntec Real Estate Investment Trust. Changes to the STI will take effect on March 20, with the next review scheduled for June.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
A man walks in front of the Singapore Exchange building (SGX) on July 21, 2022.

site_title: Energy audits, improvements required for “energy-intensive” buildings
summary: Singapore's Mandatory Energy Improvement (MEI) regime will require "energy-intensive" buildings to undergo audits and implement energy-saving measures, starting with the most energy-hungry commercial buildings. The regime aims to reduce carbon emissions in the built environment, particularly in poorly performing buildings. Around 100 existing buildings may be audited by end-2024, with measures including simple upgrades and cost-benefit analyses to help building owners decide. Building owners can also apply for grants and work with occupants to reduce energy consumption.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
