At the same time, the government will help businesses strengthen their knowledge on sustainability through new courses and playbooks, said Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan. This would help businesses to learn more about sustainability topics and the steps needed to become more sustainable.

One 2022 meta-analysis found that in people with symptoms of depression, a digital break mitigated their symptoms, but that otherwise, there was no consistent impact on detoxers’ behavior, mood or performance.

MAS said the "measures-based" approach is proposed as it is difficult for the industrial sector to determine science-based metrics and thresholds under the “amber” category based on emissions performance of the activity.

site_title: Singapore raises minimum investment sums for ultra-rich seeking permanent resident status
summary: Singapore has raised minimum investment requirements for ultra-rich individuals seeking permanent resident status under the Global Investor Programme (GIP). Starting March 15, applicants must invest at least S$10 million in a business or S$25 million in an approved fund. For family offices, the minimum investment is S$50 million. The changes aim to attract high-calibre business owners and owners of capital who can make a significant economic impact and be "more rooted to Singapore".

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Singapore extends investment promotion tax incentives; raises quantum for Global Investor Programme
Office workers walking at Raffles Place Park within the heart of Singapore's financial centre in the CBD area on Nov 1, 2022.

site_title: UBS sees US$87 billion of China retail money supporting stocks
summary: UBS predicts that Chinese households, with around 8-10 trillion yuan in excess savings, may invest up to $86.8 billion in the nation's stock market, driving a potential rally. This would follow a precedent in 2014-2015 when $390 billion of retail inflows helped stage a 150% surge in onshore Chinese shares. Strategists believe conditions are ripe for retail inflows to pick up in the next 3-6 months, with the A-share market showing positive momentum.

images.alt_text: Regulators in China previously did not encourage amortised-cost accounting. But the government changed tack after the bond rout made it clear that the method can help prevent massive redemptions and protect the bond market.

site_title: Women filming women
summary: Three female-centred films, now in cinemas, celebrate International Women's Day. "Women Talking," directed by Sarah Polley, is a MeToo film inspired by true events of Mennonite women in Bolivia who fought against rape and abuse. The film, nominated for Oscars, explores the difficult decision of whether to stay and forgive or leave. "Corsage," written and directed by Marie Kreutzer, tells the story of Empress Elisabeth of Austria, a real-life figure who defied royal expectations and found agency. "Leonor Will Never Die," the debut film of Martika Ramirez Escobar, is a charming pastiche of a movie that explores the life of a female director who finds herself in her own action movie scenes.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Triangle Of Sadness, a sharp satire of the moneyed class, has earned several awards and nominations, including the Oscar for Best Picture.
Cate Blanchett is a force of nature playing a famous conductor in Tar, though the film itself is highly problematic.

site_title: China securities watchdog warns of scams from fake foreign investors
summary: China's securities watchdog has warned of scams by fake foreign investors, citing illegal behaviors such as selling financial products and recommending stocks to win investors' trust with high returns. The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) stated that these actions are designed to deceive investors and urged them to report suspicious activities to the police. The CSRC clarified that qualified foreign institutional investors (QFII) do not operate in China, but rather allow foreign institutions to invest in the country. The regulator aims to protect investors and maintain the country's financial reputation.

site_title: One year on, Sweden home price drop keeps market trough elusive
summary: Sweden's housing market remains volatile, with home prices failing to hit a bottom despite a 0.6% decline in February, according to state-owned mortgage lender SBAB. Soaring consumer prices and interest-rate increases have dealt a heavy blow to the Swedish economy, which is sensitive to rising borrowing costs. The central bank's benchmark rate has risen to 3% in 10 months, with another hike expected next month. New home construction is grinding to a halt, contributing to an economic contraction this year, and consumer spending has dropped. A housing crash may be looming.

images.alt_text: House and apartment prices are down 15 per cent from their peak after a 1 per cent decline for both categories in January.
In Sweden, a preponderance of short-duration mortgages mean rate hikes bite immediately into consumers’ wallets and overall consumption.

site_title: UK homebuilder Taylor Wimpey cuts jobs amid housing slowdown
summary: UK homebuilder Taylor Wimpey has cut jobs amid a housing slowdown, citing weaker sales and reduced building targets. The company, Britain's largest homebuilder, is seeking to reduce costs and has flagged a 25% reduction in homes to be built this year compared to the previous year. The redundancies affect around 5,000 employees, with some roles made redundant and others deployed to other parts of the business. The company expects to generate £20 million in annualized savings from cost-saving steps.

images.alt_text: A residential building in St John's Wood, London. Despite the fall in house prices, homes are still becoming more unaffordable for first-time buyers, due to higher mortgage rates and shrinking real wages.
House prices have soared by more than a quarter during the Covid-19 pandemic, but the boom has now gone into reverse.
Buyers were less likely to get a discount during the pandemic when pent-up demand spurred a boom in house prices.

site_title: Singapore International Festival of Arts shape-shifts again
summary: The Singapore International Festival of Arts (SIFA) 2023 has unveiled a new direction under the leadership of festival director Natalie Hennedige. This year's edition, themed around "Some People," features 14 sub-themes and focuses on mid-career artists, shifting away from grand productions. The festival includes 15 main productions, such as "£¥€$ (Lies)" by Ontroerend Goed and "Humans 2.0" by Circa, which explores the possibilities of human performance. Hennedige's vision emphasizes personal transformation and the interconnectedness of human experiences.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Vicky Krieps is magisterial as Empress Elisabeth in Corsage.
Sarah Choo Jing evokes the era of amusement parks in her haunting and melancholy video art.

Poklong Anading of the Philippines is one of the over 60 artists featured in the book SEA: Contemporary Art In Southeast Asia. His photograph titled Counter Acts seeks to subvert photography's claim of capturing an image by having his subjects turn the lights towards the viewer instead, obscuring their own faces.

site_title: Hilton eyes growth in uber-luxury, entry-level Apac markets, to open more than 100 hotels in 2023
summary: Hilton plans to open over 100 hotels in the Asia-Pacific region in 2023, focusing on its uber-luxury and entry-level brands. The company aims to reach 1,000 trading hotels in the region by 2025, but prioritizes deploying its core brands in major cities and resort locations. New Waldorf Astoria hotels are opening in Tokyo, Osaka, Sydney, Kuala Lumpur, Hanoi, and Shanghai, while Hilton Garden Inn will open over 30 hotels this year. The recovery of the region's tourism industry, driven by pent-up travel demand, supports Hilton's ambitions.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
For the fourth quarter, Hilton said RevPAR (revenue per available room), a key metric for investors, rose 24.8 per cent on a currency neutral basis from a year earlier.
Hilton eyes growth in APAC, set to open 2 hotels a week in region in 2022

site_title: Credit Suisse bids above rivals for rich clients as bankers exit
summary: Credit Suisse is increasing deposit rates to attract wealthy clients in Asia, with rates up to 6.5% for new money above $5 million, surpassing rivals UBS, JPMorgan Chase, and Citigroup. The move comes as the bank faces a run of senior banker departures, with at least a dozen private bankers leaving since September, taking assets worth up to $1 billion to their new employers. The bank aims to recoup $100 billion in outflows from the fourth quarter and restore stability under its wealth head Francesco de Ferrari.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse froze and wound down a US$10 billion group of funds linked to Greensill Capital,

“Global valuations were negatively impacted by rising interest rates for CS REF International in its key markets of the United States, the United Kingdom, and Germany,” Credit Suisse said in the statement.

site_title: Boost for businesses at HDB heartland shops
summary: Singapore's HDB heartlands to see new measures to enhance vibrancy, including an expanded Entrepreneur Scheme for innovative start-ups, offering 10% rental discounts and more shop space allocation. The Revitalisation of Shops scheme will provide co-funding for improvement works and rental discounts for social enterprises with inclusive hiring practices. Additionally, all 374 rental coffeeshops will provide "budget meals" by 2026, with a 5% rental discount for operators for a year to help with these costs. These measures aim to support local businesses and increase economic activity in the heartlands.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Shoppers participating in a hawker-themed gameshow organised as part of this year's Heartlands Festival.
Some MPs wanted small- and medium-sized enterprises to get more help to offset high operating costs, and enhanced productivity and digitisation initiatives.
Rental hike at some stalls : coffee shop, 21 Street Eating House, in Block 201 Tampines Street 21.

site_title: Smart ports an opportunity for 5G players, as port operators seek cost savings
summary: Chinese port operator Tianjin Port has successfully implemented a 5G-based smart port system, reducing energy consumption by 20% and increasing crane efficiency by 20%. The port, a showcase for Huawei's 5G technologies, features 76 unmanned electric trucks that use cloud-based dispatching to collaborate and navigate autonomously. Other ports, including Singapore's PSA and Saudi Global Ports, are also exploring similar solutions to reduce costs and address labor shortages. Industry experts predict that 5G-based industrial automation will be key to turning around declining mobile network revenues.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Telcos appear to be working more closely together to better serve customers and save costs.
Ericsson, which supplies the equipment for 5G networks, has laid off 8,500 people after profits slumped.

site_title: Lee Hsien Yang, Lee Suet Fern under police probe for lying under oath about Lee Kuan Yew’s will
summary: Singapore's police have launched an investigation into Lee Hsien Yang and his wife Lee Suet Fern for allegedly lying under oath about Lee Kuan Yew's will. The couple, who are Lee Kuan Yew's grandchildren, were found guilty of grossly improper professional conduct by a tribunal in 2020 and a court in 2020. They were accused of misleading the late Lee and presenting "an elaborate edifice of lies" during disciplinary proceedings. The couple initially agreed to a police interview but later refused, leaving Singapore and prompting the police to continue the investigation in their absence.

site_title: Tender evaluations for government projects to include environmental criteria from 2024
summary: The Singapore government plans to incorporate environmental-sustainability criteria into the evaluation of large construction and ICT tenders starting from 2024. Up to 5% of evaluation points will be set aside for environmental sustainability, with a focus on energy efficiency, packaging, and carbon footprint. The government also aims to encourage companies to track and disclose their environmental performance through annual reports. Additionally, the Energy Efficiency Fund will provide more support to manufacturers adopting pre-approved energy-efficient technologies, with upfront certainty of 70% grant support.

images.alt_text: Singapore reduced its emissions to 52.8 million tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent in 2020, equivalent to 32 per cent below business-as-usual levels, Wong said.
Lower-income households and vulnerable groups will feel the brunt of impact to decarbonise every corner of the economy, the economists agree.
Singapore’s Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong (left) and Australia’s Minister for Trade and Tourism Don Farrell signed the GEA in the presence of both prime ministers.
Higher tech co-funding for some farms, new disposable bag charge

Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu said the eligibility criteria for international carbon credits will “minimally reference” the Corsia standards for now, given that the carbon market is nascent and growing.
Singapore a potential claimant from loss, damage financing: Grace Fu

site_title: Adani stocks extend rebound amid series of block trades
summary: Adani Group stocks rebounded amid a series of block trades, with all 10 group companies closing higher on Thursday. The block deals suggest institutional investors are buying into the conglomerate, which has been hit by allegations of accounting fraud from US short-seller Hindenburg Research. The Indian top court has ordered a probe into the allegations and has also asked for an investigation into market manipulation. The Adani Group has welcomed the order, which it says will bring finality in a time-bound manner, and has seen its market value increase by around $9 billion in the last two sessions.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of the Adani Group is seen on the wall of its realty office building on the outskirts of Ahmedabad, India, January 27, 2023. REUTERS/Amit Dave/File Photo

site_title: Women participation on boards picks up pace in 2022
summary: Women's participation on boards in Singapore increased to nearly 40% in 2022, with women accounting for nearly 40% of new director appointments made by statutory boards and largest SGX-listed companies. This surpasses the Council for Board Diversity's target of 20% by end-2020 and brings women's participation closer to the 25% target by end-2025. Statutory boards met their 30% target, with 31.4% women participation, and the number of companies with all-male boards decreased to 13, down from 17 previously. The improved diversity on boards is seen as a growing necessity for organizations to thrive in today's environment.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Blackrock's managing director Shinbo Won also said that diversity targets needs to tie in with the company's capability to create financial return over time.
Diversity of Singapore boards approaching a momentous milestone
Listcos with diverse leadership are more profitable, NUS study finds

site_title: Amazon’s cloud unit to invest US$6 billion in Malaysia by 2037
summary: Amazon's cloud unit, AWS, plans to invest US$6 billion in Malaysia by 2037 to strengthen its cloud services infrastructure in the country. This investment will enable customers in the region to store data securely, supporting the company's plan to build AWS Infrastructure Regions across South-east Asia. The move marks AWS' latest expansion in the region, following a US$5 billion investment in Thailand last year.

site_title: Binance unit plans bid for Singapore crypto licence
summary: Binance's unit, Ceffu, plans to apply for a permit to offer payment services in Singapore, following similar approvals for US crypto exchanges Coinbase and Crypto.com, as well as Singapore's DBS Vickers. Ceffu, launched in 2021, will submit its application once relevant amendments to the Payment Services Act and the application for a custody licence open. This move comes after Binance's affiliate Binance Asia Services withdrew a local licence application in 2021 without explanation. The approval would mark Binance's return to Singapore's financial market after a previous setback.

site_title: London Stock Exchange Group posts steady 2022 earnings, eyes buyback on Blackstone/TR stake
summary: London Stock Exchange Group reported a steady 2022 earnings of £7.743 billion, slightly above analysts' expectations. The company announced plans to step up its ownership of Refinitiv, a data analytics group, and to seek shareholder approval for a directed buyback of up to £750 million from the Blackstone/Thomson Reuters consortium. This buyback will benefit all shareholders and is expected to be completed by April 2024. The company's integration of Refinitiv and a partnership with Microsoft are seen as key to its transformation strategy.

images.alt_text: David Schwimmer, chief executive officer, LSEG

site_title: Asia’s ‘best female chef’ Johanne Siy brings Lolla to a whole new level
summary: Lolla, a 10-year-old dining stalwart in Singapore, has undergone a transformation under the creative direction of Asia's best female chef, Johanne Siy. Siy's produce-driven style brings a fresh fine-dining perspective to the table, elevating the casual eatery to new heights. Her tasting menu, priced at S$238, features innovative dishes such as parmesan crisps with herbs and flowers, caviar with egg yolk sauce, and crab "relleno" with Filipino roots. Siy's intuitive approach to balance and harmony has earned her a spot as Asia's best female chef in 2023.

images.alt_text: Soothing interiors of beige and grey.

site_title: Cut-off yield on latest 6-month Singapore Treasury bill rises to 3.98%
summary: Singapore's latest six-month Treasury bill (T-bill) auction closed with a cut-off yield of 3.98% on March 2, 2.8 times subscribed for the S$4.7 billion allotment. The total value of applications reached S$13 billion, up from S$11 billion in the previous auction. Strong investor interest, driven by inflation data showing stickier-than-expected inflation in the US, has bucked the trend of waning enthusiasm after recent yield decreases.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
While the Fed has seemed to slow its hikes, analysts expect it will have to continue tightening its monetary policy to bring down persistent inflation.
The April tranche of SSBs is offering a first-year interest rate of 3.01 per cent and a 10-year average return of 3.15 per cent.

site_title: New water recycling requirements for wafer fab, electronics, biomed sectors from 2024
summary: Singapore will implement new water recycling requirements for wafer fabrication, electronics, and biomedical industries starting January 1, 2024. The rules apply to industries consuming at least 60,000 cubic meters of water annually, with mandatory recycling rates of 50% for wafer fabrication and 50-80% for electronics and biomedical. The move is expected to save 9 million gallons of water per day, equivalent to 15 Olympic-sized swimming pools, by 2035. Companies can receive financial support and technical advice to implement water recycling projects, with incentives for higher recycling rates to be explored.

images.alt_text: Construction workers building the new Fernvale Community Club.
Water scarcity is acute in Asia
N&E Innovations founder Didi Gan (left) and scientific advisor Jaslyn Lee aim to create products that are both medically effective and environmentally sustainable.

site_title: China’s CATL sells A$601 million stake in Australian lithium miner Pilbara
summary: China's CATL sells its nearly 5% stake in Australian lithium miner Pilbara Minerals for A$601 million (S$545 million) after booking profits due to a decline in lithium prices. CATL initially bought the stake in 2019 for A$0.30 cents a share, selling it at A$4.10 per share. The sale does not impact CATL's lithium supply access, as it has secured a five-year off-take agreement with another company. Industry sources attribute the sale to CATL's desire to lock in profits amid falling lithium prices.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A security guard stands outside the headquarters building of China Securities Regulatory Commission in Beijing, September 7, 2015. REUTERS/Jason Lee/File Photo
CATL will be joining other Chinese companies in tapping the European market, as lingering geopolitical risks and regulatory woes reduce the appeal of other offshore markets such as the US.

site_title: South Korea February factory activity shrinks for 8th month
summary: South Korea's factory activity contracted for an eighth month in February, according to a survey by S&P Global. The seasonally adjusted purchasing managers' index (PMI) for manufacturers stood at 48.5, below the 50-mark since July 2022. Output fell for a tenth month, while new orders shrank for an eighth month, easing slightly from the previous two months. Soft domestic and global economic conditions, as well as currency weakness, were linked to subdued demand.

images.alt_text: Chipmakers are a key driver of South Korea’s trade-reliant economy, accounting for about 12 per cent of total exports last month.
Statistics Korea data showed Asia’s fourth-largest economy could be headed for a recession with the cyclically adjusted coincident index falling in January for a fourth consecutive month.

site_title: Singapore shares extend decline on interest rate worries; STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.6% on Thursday, marking its fourth consecutive decline, as traders raised expectations of a higher terminal interest rate. The STI closed at 3,234.90 points, with losers outnumbering gainers 332 to 223. Major US indices were also under pressure, following the release of the US ISM manufacturing PMI, which pointed to a challenging "disinflation" process. Regional markets were mixed, with the Kospi Composite Index gaining 0.6% and the FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI Index rising 0.4%.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
On the Singapore exchange, losers outnumber gainers 71 to 61 after 331.5 million securities worth S$82.9 million change hands.

site_title: China plans to inject US$1.9 billion into top memory chipmaker
summary: China has pledged to invest US$1.9 billion in Yangtze Memory Technologies Co (YMTC), one of the country's top memory chipmakers, through the National Integrated Circuit Industry Investment Fund. The investment aims to bolster the chipmaker against US sanctions and an industry-wide downturn. YMTC is seen as a national champion, competing with global leaders like Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix. The deal marks the fund's most significant industry investment in months and follows a government crackdown on corruption in 2022.

site_title: Britain’s financial watchdog to investigate competition problems in trade data market
summary: Britain's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) will investigate competition problems in the market for trading data, including benchmarks, credit ratings data, and market data vendor services. The FCA found that concentration among few firms leaves investors with little choice, resulting in higher costs for data users. The study aims to address potential competition issues with "rule changes" if evidence is found. The FCA is working with the government to develop a standardized feed system called "consolidated tapes" to collect and distribute wholesale data.

site_title: China loses more than 40 million workers as population ages
summary: China has lost over 41 million working people in the past three years, with 733.5 million employed in 2022, down from 774.7 million in 2019. The decline is attributed to rising retirees and factors such as higher youth unemployment due to the pandemic. China's working-age population has been declining since 2012, with a 38 million drop to 857.6 million over the last three years. The country's aging population is expected to accelerate economic growth this year, but may pressure Beijing to raise official retirement ages.

images.alt_text: China is warming up after the lifting of Covid-19 restrictions late last year, with both manufacturing and services activities expanding sharply since the beginning of 2023.

site_title: Vietnam elects potential Communist Party chief as new president
summary: Vietnam's National Assembly has elected Vo Van Thuong, a 52-year-old Politburo member, as the country's new president, replacing Nguyen Xuan Phu. Thuong is seen as a potential successor to Communist Party chief Nguyen Phu Trong in 2026, following a series of anti-graft crackdowns and dismissals of deputy prime ministers. Thuong's appointment is seen as an attempt to strengthen the party and ensure those in power are ideologically aligned, with analysts noting his strong adherence to Leninist-Marxist philosophy.

images.alt_text: Thuong, 52, is the youngest member of the party’s Politburo, the country’s top decision-making body, and is widely regarded as being close to General Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong, Vietnam’s most powerful figure.

site_title: Renault, Geely ink pact with Aramco for engine venture
summary: Renault and Geely have agreed to set up a new powertrain engine company with Saudi Aramco, taking a minority stake of up to 20%. The joint venture aims to develop more efficient petrol engines and hybrid systems, focusing on ultra-low-emissions technology. Renault plans to focus on electric cars, while Aramco brings expertise in synthetic fuels and hydrogen. The new company will have an annual production capacity of over 5 million internal combustion, hybrid, and plug-in hybrid engines.

images.alt_text: Renault chief executive Luca de Meo says the carmaker is in talks with US car dealer AutoNation, to start selling Alpine sports cars in the US.
Zeekr said in a statement on Monday that proceeds from the funding round will be used to support technology research and the global expansion of the Zeekr brand.

site_title: Brokers’ take: UOBKH says First Resources’ strong earnings priced in; downgrades to ‘hold’
summary: UOB Kay Hian downgraded its call on First Resources to "hold" from "buy" after the palm oil producer posted strong H2 FY2022 financials. The research house expects FY2023 earnings to decline year-on-year due to lower downstream margins and competitive feedstock prices in Indonesia. Its target price on the stock was lowered to S$1.55 from S$1.85. In contrast, CGS-CIMB Research raised its price target to S$1.88, citing higher FFB output growth and a 14% year-on-year net profit forecast for FY2023.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

The palm oil maker will continue to monitor developments in the regulatory and macro space, paying close attention to the geopolitical situation in the Black Sea and the reopening of China – which it thinks will exert an influence on the direction of palm oil prices.
The brokerage continues to value First Resources at a nine times price to earnings ratio based on earnings estimates for FY2023
First Resources posts a surge in Q3 profit due to stronger palm oil prices and the resumption of palm oil exports in Indonesia.
Crude palm oil (CPO) futures fell after Indonesia announced a policy shift in early June this year to encourage exports by cutting export levies.
CPO futures contracts on the Bursa Malaysia Derivatives market are up 6.6 per cent since the beginning of the year. But since late April, the commodity is down about 33.3 per cent.

site_title: Malaysia’s top 5 banks post higher earnings, pay generous dividends
summary: Malaysia's top five banks, including Maybank, Public Bank, CIMB Group, Hong Leong Bank, and RHB Bank, posted higher earnings and generous dividends in FY2022, driven by healthy loan growth and increased interest income. The banks' revenue increased by 1.5% to 12.8% year-over-year, with RHB Bank being the top performer. Analysts attribute the strong financial performance to higher interest rate hikes last year and a healthy loan growth as the economy reopened. However, downside risks remain, including protracted deposit competition and potential loan loss provisioning, amid global headwinds and inflationary pressures.

images.alt_text: Looking ahead, Maybank said it will continue to focus on growth opportunities h across its consumer and business segments within its Asean franchise.

site_title: China’s job market better than expected in Jan-Feb: minister
summary: China's job market performed better than expected in January and February, with both manufacturing and services activities expanding sharply since the start of 2023, according to Human Resources Minister Wang Xiaoping. The country's employment is expected to continue picking up this year, with the government planning to support college graduates, migrant workers, and unemployed people. China needs to add 16.62 million people to the urban workforce this year, the highest number in recent years, amid a structural conflict between recruitment and finding jobs.

images.alt_text: China's manufacturing sector saw its biggest improvement in activity in more than a decade in February and consumer activity climbed, the latest purchasing managers’ surveys showed.
Leslie Thng, CEO, Scoot

site_title: AI-armed cyber strikes : Fighting fire with fire
summary: A cyberattack credited to ChatGPT is predicted to occur within the next year, according to a BlackBerry survey of 1,500 IT decision-makers. 51% of respondents believe foreign states are already using ChatGPT for malicious purposes, while 82% plan to invest in AI-driven cybersecurity in the next two years. The use of AI in cybersecurity is seen as a double-edged sword, offering benefits but also increasing the risk of sophisticated threats. To combat this, organisations are focusing on improving prevention and detection and incorporating more AI into threat classification processes and cybersecurity strategies.

images.alt_text: The cybersecurity industry must be ready to fight AI-powered exploits, says Palo Alto Networks' Sean Duca.
The demand for tech talent beyond the Information and Communication sector is strong, particularly in roles such as cybersecurity and artificial intelligence.
“Technology manufacturers must take ownership of the security outcomes for their customers,” Jen Easterly, director of the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA).

site_title: Sake is booming in America
summary: Sake sales are booming in the US, with imports more than doubling from 2012 to 2022, and exports from Japan reaching nearly 36 million liters per year. New sake breweries are opening, including Kato Sake Works in Brooklyn, which has seen significant growth and will soon move to a larger space. Retailers like Umami Mart in Oakland and Sakaya in New York City have also seen a surge in sake sales, with many customers discovering the versatility of sake beyond traditional sushi pairings. The US market is expected to continue growing, with experts attributing the rise to increased American tourism to Japan and a growing interest in Japanese culture and food.

site_title: Gold flat as investors assess interest rate outlook
summary: Gold prices remained flat at $1,836.69 per ounce as investors assessed the outlook for interest rates, which may deter gold's appeal as an inflation hedge. The US Federal Reserve's target rate is expected to peak at 5.465% in September, while European Central Bank rate-hike expectations rose following German consumer price data. The dollar index eased, making gold more affordable for buyers holding other currencies.

images.alt_text: High-interest rates dampen gold’s appeal as an inflation hedge while raising the opportunity cost of holding the non-yielding asset.

site_title: Indonesia wants crude palm oil exports to be routed via exchange from June
summary: Indonesia plans to require crude palm oil exports to go through a futures exchange, starting in June, to create its own benchmark price. Most exporters currently sell directly to buyers without an exchange. Authorities hope to reach price discoveries within a few months after the change. Industry groups support the policy but warn of the need for clear rules and no additional costs. The move aims to build trust for an exchange and prepare the infrastructure for physical trade.

images.alt_text: epa09969055 A worker loads freshly harvested palm fruits on a truck at a palm oil plantation in Deli Serdang, North Sumatra, Indonesia, 23 May 2022. Indonesia has lifted the ban on palm oil exports after it had been imposed for weeks to control cooking oil prices in the domestic market.  EPA-EFE/DEDI SINUHAJI

site_title: Five-cent plastic bag charge at large supermarket chains from Jul 3
summary: The Singapore government will implement a five-cent plastic bag charge for large supermarket chains starting July 3, 2023. The charge applies to five major supermarkets with annual turnovers over S$100 million, covering around 400 outlets. The aim is to encourage consumers to use reusable bags, with proceeds going towards supporting the shift away from disposable bags and local community programs. Supermarket operators with lower turnovers are encouraged to voluntarily implement bag charges, and they will be required to publish information on their bag usage and proceeds.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
A garbage collector gathering recyclable plastic at the Ban Tarn landfill site in Chiang Mai, Thailand.
Among the G20 countries that have yet to introduce national bans on single-use plastic products are Brazil, the United States, Indonesia and Turkey, the report said.
A year's worth of washed-up plastic from one small beach, ready to be taken away for disposal.

site_title: Elon Musk hints at next-generations Teslas, touts more efficient factories
summary: Tesla CEO Elon Musk hinted at the development of a next-generation electric vehicle and plans to cut vehicle assembly costs by half, with the goal of producing cars for 50% less than current models. Musk also presented a projection of the future electric fleet, showing a market of 440 million vehicles, with the Cybertruck and a shrouded future model as part of a 300 million-vehicle market. Musk aims to increase deliveries to 20 million vehicles by 2030, with a focus on improving battery technology.

images.alt_text: Malaysia is focusing on the development of an electric vehicle ecosystem and aims to provide at least 10,000 public charging facilities by 2025.
Users started reporting problems loading tweets from the site just before 10 am London time on Tuesday, according to outage tracking platform, Downdetector.
Microsoft has gone the furthest in pushing out generative AI to consumers and has pledged to pump billions of dollars into OpenAI, the company behind ChatGPT.

site_title: Sembmarine names new chief operating officer
summary: Sembmarine has appointed Chor How Jat as its new chief operating officer, effective March 1. The appointment comes after the company's combination with Keppel Offshore & Marine, with Chris Ong becoming the combined entity's chief executive. Chor will oversee offshore and marine group yard operations and ensure on-time and on-budget delivery. The new entity also appointed Mark Gainsborough as chairman and Yap Chee Keong as deputy chairman, with other independent directors joining the board.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Waymo cuts jobs as parent company Alphabet focuses on AI
summary: Waymo, Alphabet's driverless-vehicle unit, cut dozens of jobs as part of its parent company's efforts to control spending and focus on artificial intelligence. The layoffs, the second round of cuts for Waymo this year, follow Alphabet's January reduction of 12,000 jobs globally. The move is part of a broader culling of tech jobs, with other companies such as Meta, Twitter, and Amazon also slashing their ranks. Waymo's workforce reduction is about 8% of its total employees, with over 200 employees let go this year.

site_title: Blackstone blocked investor withdrawals from US$71 billion Reit in February
summary: Blackstone's US$71 billion real estate income trust (Breit) blocked investor withdrawals in February, fulfilling about 35% of the $3.9 billion requested. This is a 26% decrease from January. The firm continues to grapple with a backlog of unfulfilled requests, with some investors making larger withdrawals in anticipation of a reduction in Breit's size. Despite this, Breit generated 8.4% returns in 2022, outperforming the Dow Jones US Select Reit Total Return Index, which declined 26%. Blackstone expects to work through the backlog over time.

images.alt_text: Blackstone cemented its stature as a powerhouse in the real estate industry with the growth in Breit in recent years.
The Blackstone Group headquarters in Manhattan, New York.
Breit’s institutional class shareholders received an 8.4 per cent total return in 2022 when most real estate funds lost money and stocks and bonds declined.

site_title: Australia’s building approvals post record drop, drag on growth
summary: Australia's building approvals plummeted 27.6% in January, the largest drop on record since 1980, with permits for private houses tumbling 13.8% for the fifth straight month. The weak trend is attributed to material and labor shortages, falling property prices, and unwinding government subsidies. This may fuel rental inflation, particularly with a strong immigration-driven population growth. The Reserve Bank of Australia's aggressive rate hikes and higher borrowing costs are expected to persist, weighing on the economy.

images.alt_text: Data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics on Wednesday showed real GDP rose 0.5 per cent in the December quarter, down from 0.7 per cent in the previous quarter and under forecasts of 0.8 per cent.
Data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) on Tuesday showed retail sales rose 1.9 per cent in January from December.

site_title: A new acronym to “EIS” (ease) your innovation journey
summary: The Singapore government has introduced the Enterprise Innovation Scheme (EIS) to support local innovation and help businesses stay competitive amid rising costs. The EIS offers significant tax deductions and cash payouts for research and development, intellectual property registration, and training expenses. The scheme aims to encourage small and medium enterprises to invest in innovation, with 83% of R&D tax claims by SMEs being approved in full. The government has also enhanced the tax deductions for expenses related to IP registration, acquisition, and licensing, and introduced a cash payout option for qualifying expenses.

images.alt_text: (ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI)

site_title: South Korea’s chip inventory climbs at fastest pace in 27 years
summary: South Korea's semiconductor inventory rose 28% in January, the largest increase in almost 27 years, amid a prolonged tech slump. This surge in chip stockpiles, a key driver of the country's trade-reliant economy, contrasts with a 25.8% drop in factory shipments and a 5.7% decline in chip production. Global demand for semiconductors remains uncertain due to interest rate hikes and geopolitical tensions, casting a shadow over South Korea's economic growth prospects.

images.alt_text: Semiconductor chips are seen on a printed circuit board in this illustration picture taken February 17, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration

site_title: Brokers’ take: RHB downgrades Bumitama Agri to ‘neutral’ after results disappoint
summary: RHB downgraded Bumitama Agri to 'neutral' from 'buy' due to disappointing FY2022 results, citing lower-than-expected fresh fruit bunches output and higher-than-expected unit costs, inventory levels, and effective tax rate. The stock's new target price is S$0.66, implying a potential upside of 8% from its last trading price. This move comes after Bumitama Agri posted a 47.7% year-on-year drop in net profit to S$57 million for the second half-year.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Japan firms add to spending despite global slowdown, weak yen
summary: Japan's businesses continued to increase spending for five straight quarters despite a global economic slowdown, with capital expenditure rising 0.3% in the three months through December. However, profits fell for the first time since 2020, and sales were weaker than expected, raising concerns about future corporate spending plans. The data suggests the country still has a long way to recover before a full economic recovery, with the yen's decline and China's virus control measures affecting the economy. The Bank of Japan may remain cautious about pivoting away from supporting the economy.

images.alt_text: Government energy measures, including subsidies of around 20 per cent on household electricity bills, are expected to be the main factors behind the deceleration.

site_title: Consumer lender Zip abolishes global plans after 95% share drop
summary: Zip, an Australian consumer lender, is abandoning its global expansion plans after a 95% stock slump. The company will sell or end operations in 10 markets, focusing on its home country and a few other nations, in an effort to achieve profitability by mid-2024. CEO Larry Diamond expects significant capital inflows from asset sales and is prepared for regulation, citing the industry's customer-centric nature. This move follows a broader decline in valuations of consumer credit providers, including US-based Stripe and Klarna Bank.

images.alt_text: Stripe was among tech firms that spent more heavily on adding talent and pushing into new areas during the depths of the pandemic when it saw spending volumes soar.

site_title: South Korea promises all-out efforts to boost exports, attract tourists
summary: South Korea's government pledged efforts to boost exports and attract tourists amid a mixed January economic data showing a possible recession. The cyclically adjusted coincident index fell for a fourth consecutive month, while industrial output rose but exports collapsed. Finance Minister Choo Kyung Ho stated the government aims to avoid a decline in exports and attract 60% of pre-pandemic tourist levels, with foreign tourist arrivals currently at 40% of pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Thursday; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.3% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,246.54. The decline follows losses in US and Europe markets. Sembcorp Marine rose 3.5%, while Disa and Oceanus Group decreased 33.3% and 14.3% respectively. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also experienced losses. The market downturn is attributed to global economic concerns, with US Treasury yields hitting a multi-month high amid inflation worries.

images.alt_text: SGX RegCo on Tuesday said its actions apply to IPO and RTO submissions for which UOBKH had agreed to act as issue manager or full sponsor under any agreement entered into after Aug 31.

site_title: Top Australia banks part of central bank digital currency pilot
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia is piloting a central bank digital currency (CBDC) project with top banks ANZ Group Holdings and the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. The pilot aims to explore economic benefits and test use cases for a CBDC in real asset tokenisation and smart payments. The project, which involves 114 countries representing over 95% of global GDP, will contribute to hands-on learning and policymakers' understanding of a CBDC's potential benefits. A report on the Australian project is expected to be published mid-year.

images.alt_text: Data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics on Wednesday showed real GDP rose 0.5 per cent in the December quarter, down from 0.7 per cent in the previous quarter and under forecasts of 0.8 per cent.
Data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) on Tuesday showed retail sales rose 1.9 per cent in January from December.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as US rate saga plays against China reopening
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Thursday, following a rally on Wednesday, due to concerns over US interest rate hikes. The US Federal Reserve's comments from policymakers Raphael Bostic and Neel Kashkari suggested rates could rise above 5% and remain high for an extended period to combat inflation. This led to a decline in the S&P 500 and Nasdaq. Despite this, some Asian markets, such as Sydney and Seoul, edged higher, while Hong Kong and Shanghai retreated. The China reopening narrative provided some support, but its impact was uncertain.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong led gains in early trade, piling on more than two per cent after falling for the previous six trading days, thanks to a rally in heavyweight tech firms.

site_title: YouTube to add AI-powered tools for video creators, new CEO says
summary: YouTube will integrate AI-powered tools for video creators, allowing them to virtually swap outfits and create "fantastical film settings" through generative capabilities. New CEO Neal Mohan announced the features in his first message to the YouTube community, emphasizing the use of "thoughtful guardrails" and "protections" to responsibly develop the technology. This move comes as Google faces pressure to release generative AI products, following rivals like OpenAI and Microsoft, which have rolled out popular AI chatbots and image-creating services.

site_title: Tech rivals chase ChatGPT as AI race ramps up
summary: Global tech giants are racing to develop ChatGPT-like AI technology, with Microsoft leading the charge by investing billions in OpenAI and integrating its GPT-3 technology into its platforms. Other companies, including Google, YouTube, Meta, Snapchat, Shopify, Baidu, and Tesla, are also working on similar projects, with varying levels of investment and development. The AI push comes as the industry grapples with concerns over the technology's readiness for the general public, with controversies surrounding its capabilities and potential misuse.

images.alt_text: A smartphone with a displayed ChatGPT logo is placed on a computer motherboard in this illustration taken February 23, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration
The product, to be called “HunyuanAide”, will incorporate Tencent’s AI training model named “Hunyuan”.
The newly formed Meta product group will include dozens of employees from teams that were previously scattered throughout the company.
Microsoft’s operating system will include the new Bing in desktop computers’ search box, which helps half a billion monthly users navigate their files and the Internet, the company said.

New CEO Neal Mohan explained that YouTube creators will soon be able to virtually swap outfits in videos or create “fantastical film settings” through AI’s generative capabilities “in the coming months.”

site_title: Silvergate’s worsening crypto losses feed watchdogs’ worst fears
summary: Silvergate Capital, a US bank catering to the cryptocurrency sector, reported worsening financial losses and may need more time to assess the extent of damage. The firm sold billions in assets to repay advances from the Federal Home Loan Bank System, potentially exacerbating its losses. Silvergate's shares plummeted 33% after the close of regular trading, with the company's stock tumbling over 88% last year. The bank's struggles may lead to a chilling effect on the cryptocurrency industry, as other banks become more reluctant to work with crypto ventures, and regulators' warnings may stoke caution on their part.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Smartphone with displayed Binance logo and representation of cryptocurrencies placed on a keyboard in this illustration taken November 8, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: European banks, asset managers study halving stocks settlement time
summary: European banks and asset managers have formed a task-force to study halving the time it takes to settle share trades from two working days to one, similar to the US Securities & Exchange Commission's T+1 settlement. The move aims to make European markets more resilient to volatility, but reconfiguring IT systems would be costly. The task-force will assess whether Europe should adopt T+1 and when, with the US expected to implement the change by May 2024. Failure to follow suit could put Europe at a competitive disadvantage to Wall Street.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 fell 0.7 per cent by the close, after rising as much as 0.4 per cent in early trading.

site_title: US$1 billion AUM in just 4 months: Farro taps Singapore’s wealth clans
summary: Farro Capital, a Singapore-based multi-family office, has amassed over $1 billion in assets under management (AUM) just four months after its launch. Founded by former Bank of Singapore market head Hemant Tucker and ex-CEO of Maitri Asset Management Manish Tibrewal, the firm is targeting families across Asia and globally, with an average AUM contribution of $30 million each. This rapid growth highlights Singapore's appeal to the super-rich, despite recent efforts to raise wealth taxes and introduce stricter conditions for tax breaks.

images.alt_text: The quarterly data raises concerns over the potential for a further slowdown in venture funding this year.
Although four in 10 of the ultra-rich saw their wealth increase in 2022, “the overwhelming trend was negative”, the report said.
Singapore is one of the top 10 cities in the high-end activity index, with 18 ultra-prime property sales and 121 super-prime property sales, says Knight Frank.
Singapore extends investment promotion tax incentives; raises quantum for Global Investor Programme

site_title: German leader Scholz must step up in foreign affairs
summary: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz faces his biggest foreign policy tests since taking office, particularly with Russia's invasion of Ukraine and the US-China relationship. Scholz has struggled to rebuild the US-German alliance, which frayed during the Trump presidency. His meeting with US President Joe Biden on March 3 aims to address these issues, including Ukraine, security cooperation, and China policy. However, Scholz's cautious approach to Ukraine and Germany's strong trading ties with China may create tensions, complicating his efforts to strengthen ties with the US.

images.alt_text: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz expressed a conviction after talks with German industry that businesses were building ties with other markets and preparing for a more multi-polar world.
German Chancellor Olaf Scholz (right) and US Vice President Kamala Harris (left) attend their bilateral meeting at the Munich Security Conference in Munich, Germany, Feb 17, 2023.

site_title: 🏘️ What’s the deal with Reits?
summary: Reits, or Real Estate Investment Trusts, are a type of investment that pools money from multiple investors to invest in a portfolio of income-generating real estate assets. They offer higher yields on average compared to other stocks and government bonds, but this year's negative 12% total return was largely due to rising interest rates and a weaker leasing environment. Experts warn that higher interest rates may limit Reits' ability to grow their portfolios and make plans for new acquisitions. Despite this, Reits remain a popular choice for investors seeking diversification, especially for those with a conservative risk profile.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim

site_title: China developers Vanke, Poly to issue shares as market thaws
summary: China's largest real estate developers, Vanke and Poly, plan to raise funds by issuing shares. Vanke will raise $499 million in a Hong Kong share placement, while Poly is reviewing plans for a $2.44 billion onshore private share sale. The moves indicate a thawing of financing conditions for the industry, which has been affected by a clampdown on excessive leverage. China's property market is showing signs of recovery, with new-home prices halting declines and sales rising for the first time in 20 months. The government's sector rescue measures have eased restrictions on onshore equity fundraising.

images.alt_text: China's Finance Minister Liu Kun on Wednesday called the impact that declining land sales revenue is having on the spending power of local authorities “controllable.”
China has shifted policy to help the industry — first by easing financing for developers and then by reviving homebuyer demand.

site_title: US seeks allies’ backing for possible China sanctions over Ukraine war: sources
summary: The US is seeking backing from allies to impose sanctions on China if Beijing provides military support to Russia in the Ukraine war. The consultations, at a preliminary stage, aim to coordinate support from the G7 countries. The US has warned China directly against providing support, but the exact sanctions proposal remains unclear. China has denied providing military support and has issued a 12-point paper calling for a ceasefire, which was met with skepticism in the West. The US administration is considering targeted sanctions against private actors in China, potentially deterring government and bank support.

images.alt_text: Reflecting the decline in confidence in China, almost half of US firms which are already in the market plan no new investments, while another 9 per cent are planning to cut investment.

site_title: Joe Green makes concrete go green
summary: Joe Green Marketing, a Singaporean company, has developed eco-friendly precast concrete walls made from recycled materials. The company, founded in 2006, was prompted to switch to recycled materials due to Indonesia's ban on sand exports, which made traditional concrete production unsustainable. Today, Joe Green recycles concrete and industrial waste to produce lightweight, green aggregates that are then processed into concrete panels. The company's products have received the highest rating from the Singapore Green Building Council and have reduced the use of cement in its green wall panels by 20%.

images.alt_text: Oilfield Services & Supplies general manager Michael Lim, managing director Kay Ong and business development manager Kenneth Loh at the Enterprise 50 Awards 2021 ceremony.
Having a headstart in e-commerce enabled Adirect Singapore to continue selling its premium meats during the pandemic, said chief executive officer Jackie Goh.

site_title: HSBC activist shareholder demands AGM vote on Asia business spin-off
summary: HSBC's most vocal minority investors, led by Ken Lui, are demanding a vote at the 2023 shareholder meeting on whether to spin off the bank's lucrative Asian business to boost returns. At least 100 retail investors, mostly in Hong Kong, have signed a letter calling for the move. Lui also proposes restoring pre-Covid-19 dividend levels of at least 51 US cents per share annually. The demand comes after HSBC reported a 92% surge in quarterly profit and pledged more regular dividends. The proposal faces opposition from some institutional shareholders, who prefer the current structure and believe the bank should focus on maximizing returns rather than breaking up the group.

images.alt_text: In a filing to the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, HSBC said the perpetual bond’s coupon had been set at 8 per cent.
A spokesman for HSBC said the bank wasn’t raided and declined to comment further.
Globally, HSBC is looking to cut office space by 40 per cent from pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Debate erupts over Japan-backed transition finance guidelines for S-E Asia
summary: A Singapore-based social enterprise, Asia Research and Engagement, has criticized two South-east Asian transition finance guidelines for promoting coal and gas power plant "retrofits" as suitable for the region's energy transition. The guidelines, issued by Jakarta-based Economic Research Institute for Asean and East Asia and the Asia Transition Finance Study Group, validate and promote carbon capture and utilization and storage (CCUS) and ammonia co-firing technologies. Critics argue that these technologies are commercially unviable and may disrupt capital invested in renewable energy, while proponents argue that they provide a bridge to clean technologies and can buy time for the region to transition.

images.alt_text: MAS said the "measures-based" approach is proposed as it is difficult for the industrial sector to determine science-based metrics and thresholds under the “amber” category based on emissions performance of the activity.

People riding motorbike past Pha Lai thermal power plant in Hai Duong province on October 14, 2022. Even though Vietnam may have the highest amount of installed solar and wind energy capacity in South-east Asia, many of these farms are unable to operate at full capacity.
The latest budget tabled by the Malaysia's Prime Minister and Finance Minister Anwar Ibrahim last Friday (Feb 24) was seen as a pragmatic budget with "a populist flavour”.
There is a need for Singapore’s fashion and textile industry to take more action on sustainability in its end-to-end supply chain.

The Services 2030 strategy builds on the Manufacturing 2030 and Trade 2030 ones that Trade and Industry Minister Gan unveiled last year, all three of which are part of the Singapore Economy 2030 vision.
The EIB’s calls for more green energy money come after the development bank said it already financed a record 19.4 billion euros in the sector last year.

site_title: Peaking inflation risks are sending Japan investors a curveball
summary: Japan's inflation is expected to cool sharply from its peak due to government energy subsidies, including 20% subsidies on household electricity bills. Early Tokyo inflation figures are expected to show core consumer price growth slowing to 3.3% in February, from January's four-decade high. The slowdown may complicate the Bank of Japan's assessment of inflation and its policy response, with some analysts warning of the risk of underestimating the inflationary trend.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Nio, OUE, Japfa, ValueMax, Rex International
summary: Nio, a Chinese electric vehicle maker, reported a widened net loss of 5.8 billion yuan (S$1.1 billion) for its fourth quarter of 2022, despite a 60% increase in vehicle sales and a 62.2% increase in revenue. OUE, Japfa, ValueMax Group, and Rex International also released financial updates, with OUE's net profit nearly doubling, Japfa's net loss widening, ValueMax's net profit falling 16.8%, and Rex International's net loss reversing.

site_title: BOJ must ‘patiently’ maintain ultra-loose policy, says board member
summary: Japan's Bank of Japan (BOJ) must maintain its ultra-loose monetary policy "patiently" due to the economy's moderate recovery, said board member Hajime Takata. The BOJ will monitor market developments to ensure stable bond-yield moves and consider the impact on market function when guiding monetary policy. With inflation exceeding Japan's 2% target, speculation surrounds the BOJ's potential phase-out of its massive stimulus program after Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's term ends in April. The BOJ will scrutinize whether the economy and prices can achieve a sustained, positive cycle.

site_title: From gold jewellery to golden tunes
summary: Parthiban Murugaiyan, founder of Maestro Productions, turned his passion for music into a concert company after failing to make a profit from his first concert investment in 2017. He organized his first concert in 2018, featuring Indian musician Ilayaraaja, which was a success. Since then, Maestro Productions has organized several concerts, including a sold-out show by Indian superstar Anirudh Ravichander, with plans for hybrid-concert formats and expansion into concerts for English and K-pop artistes. The company aims to launch a record label and explore markets beyond Singapore, including the Middle East and Australia.

images.alt_text: Battered live music scene takes centre stage again
Having a headstart in e-commerce enabled Adirect Singapore to continue selling its premium meats during the pandemic, said chief executive officer Jackie Goh.

site_title: Vietnam’s “blazing furnace” war on corruption
summary: Vietnam's Communist Party has launched a "blazing furnace" war on corruption, targeting senior officials, including President Nguyen Xuan Phuc, who resigned in January. The party aims to eradicate corruption, which is closely linked to poverty in Asia, and believes it will spur business growth. Despite concerns about instability and foreign investor sentiment, researchers say corruption has a negative impact on private investment, employment, and per capita income, and undermines cultural integrity and innovation. The party's campaign has already led to the prosecution or "disciplining" of over 530 party members and 453 corruption cases.

images.alt_text: Vietnam's President Nguyen Xuan Phuc arrives to attend APEC Leader's Dialogue with APEC Business Advisory Council during the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit, November 18, 2022, in Bangkok, Thailand. Lillian Suwanrumpha/Pool via REUTERS
The National Assembly voted to dismiss Deputy Prime Minister Vu Duc Dam from office during a four-day special session that began today (Jan 5).

site_title: Rex International reverses into the red with US$5.8m loss in H2
summary: Rex International, a Singapore-based oil exploration and production company, reported a net loss of US$5.8 million for the second half of 2022, down from a net profit of US$43.2 million in the same period in 2021. Revenue from crude oil sales decreased 14% to US$70.8 million. The company attributed the loss to production stoppages and unforeseen operational issues. Despite this, Rex International targets to pay out a final dividend of S$0.005 per share and aims to reach 20,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in the long term.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
REX International’s 91.65-per cent owned subsidiary Lime Petroleum has been offered participating interests in two new offshore licences

site_title: The ultra-rich lost 10% of fortune in 2022: study
summary: The world's ultra-rich saw their fortunes decline by 10% in 2022 due to the war in Ukraine and rising interest rates, according to a study by London-based property consultants Knight Frank. Four in 10 ultra-high-net-worth individuals (UHNWIs) with a net worth of at least $30 million experienced wealth growth, but the majority saw a decline. Europe was hit hardest, with a 17% drop in fortunes, followed by Australia and the Americas. The outlook for the ultra-rich is expected to shift later this year, with 69% of wealthy investors anticipating growth in their portfolios.

images.alt_text: Amancio Ortega acquired five US logistics sites for more than US$700 million in September.

site_title: SoftBank-backed Arm rules out UK listing for now to focus on US IPO
summary: SoftBank-backed chipmaker Arm has ruled out a UK listing for now, instead focusing on a sole US IPO later this year. The company, which is based in Cambridge, England, and is a key player in the global tech industry, will maintain its headquarters in the UK but is unlikely to pursue a secondary listing in London. The decision comes after SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son prioritized a US listing due to the country's deep investor base and attractive valuations, following UK government turmoil that obstructed talks.

images.alt_text: The company, set up in 2018 as a joint venture of British chip technology firm Arm, laid off nearly 100 employees last week, most of them engineers.

site_title: Cardinals must pay rent; no subsidised rent for senior Vatican officials, says Pope
summary: Pope Francis has introduced new rules requiring senior Vatican officials, including cardinals and bishops, to pay rent for Vatican-owned apartments, eliminating free rents and subsidized subsidies. The move aims to increase income flows and direct funds to the Church's mission. The new rules apply to senior management levels, with exceptions requiring personal approval from the pope.

images.alt_text: epa10491945 Faithful attend Pope Francis' Angelus prayer in St. Peter's Square, Vatican City, 26 February 2023.  EPA-EFE/GIUSEPPE LAMI
No paycheque for popes, Francis says in a new book

site_title: Britain’s Prince Harry loses home on royal estate
summary: Prince Harry and his wife Meghan Markle are being evicted from Frogmore Cottage, a home on the British royal estate, after being told to vacate the property in January following the publication of Prince Harry's memoir "Spare." The couple, who refurbished the cottage at a reported cost of £2.4 million, will no longer have a UK base. The decision comes amid an overhaul of the royal family's finances, with King Charles III's brother, Prince Andrew, reportedly being offered the cottage instead.

images.alt_text: A television interview broadcast on ITV of Britain's Prince Harry on Jan 8, 2023, ahead of the publication of his book, 'Spare'.

A poster advertising the forthcoming publication of the book 'Spare' by Britain's Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex, is pictured in the window of a book store in London on January 6, 2023. - Prince Harry's autobiography "Spare" is not due out until next week but it dominated headlines on Thursday after a Spanish-language version of the memoir mistakenly went on sale. The book was hurriedly withdrawn from shelves in Spain but not before copies were obtained by media outlets, who pored over its contents -- and its implications for Britain's most famous family. (Photo by Daniel LEAL / AFP)

Britain's Prince William and Prince Harry march during a procession where the coffin of Queen Elizabeth II is transported from Buckingham Palace to the Houses of Parliament for her lying in state, in London, Sept 14, 2022.

site_title: US mortgage rates remain at highest since November
summary: US mortgage rates remain at their highest level since November 2022, averaging 6.71% for a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association. This rise follows stronger-than-expected inflation and job gain data, prompting investors to expect further Federal Reserve interest rate hikes. The rate has increased by 50 basis points over the past month, affecting the housing sector and leading to a decline in mortgage loan applications.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as yields rise again
summary: US stocks opened lower on March 1, 2023, as Treasury yields rose due to bets of more rate hikes by the Federal Reserve, offsetting optimism from strong China manufacturing data. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.33 points, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropped.

site_title: Europe: Shares kick off March lower as BNP Paribas slides
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 fell 0.7% on March 1, weighed down by BNP Paribas' 4.2% decline after the Belgian state said it would sell a third of its stake in the bank. The banking index slipped 1.6% despite strong data from China, which boosted hopes of demand recovery, and gains in rate-sensitive banking shares. Fears of further monetary tightening by the European Central Bank also impacted the market, while utilities declined 2.6% and luxury firms rose 0.4-3.3% on positive China data.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended flat at 32,661.84 on Wednesday.

site_title: Salesforce jumps after upbeat outlook eases investor fears
summary: Salesforce released an upbeat forecast for fiscal 2024, citing a focus on profitability with an operating margin of 27%, exceeding analyst estimates of 22.4%. The company also increased its share repurchase program to $20 billion. Following the announcement, the company's shares gained over 14% in late trading. This move may ease pressure from activist investors who have pushed the company to cut costs, following years of aggressive growth and large acquisitions.

images.alt_text: Salesforce said earlier in January that it would eliminate about 10 per cent of its workforce.
Real estate will be a major part of the cost restructuring process.

site_title: US manufacturing sector contracts in February
summary: US manufacturing contracted for a fourth consecutive month in February, with the Institute for Supply Management's manufacturing PMI at 47.7, slightly unchanged from January. Despite factory activity showing signs of stabilization, a measure of new orders improved only slightly, and inflation remained elevated, with prices paid by manufacturers rebounding to 51.3. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes are expected to continue, limiting a quick turnaround in manufacturing.

images.alt_text: The rebound in business activity fits in with recent robust data on retail sales, the labour market and manufacturing production, which have suggested solid momentum in the economy at the start of the year.

site_title: Oil settled up as rising supplies face Chinese demand hopes
summary: Oil prices rose slightly, settling up 1% and 0.8% for Brent and WTI crude futures, respectively, due to ample supply and offsetting hopes for higher demand after China's manufacturing activity expanded in February, the fastest pace in over a decade. US crude inventories rose to a record high, while Russia's oil production reached pre-sanctions levels for the first time in February. Analysts expect resilient supply to limit price upside, with China's economic rebound seen as a positive driver for oil prices.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures for April, which expired on Tuesday, settled higher by US$1.44, or 1.8 per cent, at US$83.89 a barrel on Tuesday.

site_title: Singapore among top cities for ultra-prime residential property sales in 2022: Knight Frank
summary: Singapore ranks sixth among the top 10 cities for ultra-prime residential property transactions in 2022, with 18 ultra-prime sales and 121 super-prime sales, according to Knight Frank's Wealth Report. The city-state tied with London for fourth position in terms of price growth, with 34 sq m of prime residential property bought for every US$1 million. Knight Frank expects a 4% increase in prime prices in Singapore this year, driven by a rising number of wealthy individuals.

images.alt_text: Singapore will be one of the cities to get highest prime capital value growth in 2023.
In Singapore, an acute supply crunch and an influx of wealth has pushed up rents.

site_title: EV startups from Lucid to Rivian see demand fade, supply chain issues linger
summary: US electric vehicle startups Lucid, Rivian, and Nikola are facing declining demand due to economic pressure and increased competition from industry behemoth Tesla and traditional automakers offering cheaper EV models. Despite price cuts and new federal incentives, shares of these companies have fallen, with Rivian down 13%, Lucid 2-4%, and Nikola 5%. Supply chain issues continue to plague the industry, with Rivian forecasting production below analyst estimates. However, some experts believe demand will pick up in 2024 as EV makers cut prices and introduce lower-priced models, with Fisker's cheap SUV seeing orders improve.

site_title: Singapore, UK ink green economy framework to bolster energy, climate collaboration
summary: Singapore and the UK have signed a memorandum of understanding to establish a bilateral green economy framework, aiming to bolster energy and climate collaboration. The framework will be implemented through various mechanisms, including government policy dialogues, business matchmaking, industry workshops, and research partnerships. This agreement comes as the UK Secretary of State Grant Shapps emphasized the need for energy security, following the war in Ukraine. The partnership is expected to promote sustainable development and reduce carbon emissions.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Smoke and steam billows from the coal-fired power plant owned by Indonesia Power.
The European Union and the United States are raising the stakes with massive green subsidies and a pro-green business push, but the UK has yet to follow suit.

site_title: Engineering Singapore’s green future
summary: Singapore aims to achieve a green future through various initiatives, including the IES Green Plan 2030, which outlines strategies for decarbonization and circular economy growth. The country has made significant strides in energy efficiency, water management, and waste reduction, and is now focusing on decarbonizing its energy systems, manufacturing industry, and transportation sector. With investments in smart grid technologies, hydrogen energy, and nuclear energy, Singapore is poised to become a leader in green growth and avoid falling behind international competitors.

images.alt_text: Firms to receive higher support for energy-efficient technologies under NEA's Energy Efficiency Fund

At the International Solid Waste Association (ISWA) World Congress on Wednesday (Sep 21), Minister Grace Fu said the Government sees it as a priority to “get our economic policies right, to signal that there is a high environmental cost to unsustainable practices”.

site_title: TikTok is imposing time limits on teens to prevent binges
summary: TikTok is introducing a 60-minute time limit for users under 18 to curb binge-watching, a move aimed at mitigating the app's addictive nature and addressing concerns about its impact on teens. The limit will be the default, but can be removed by parents. The company is also allowing parents to monitor their teens' app usage and set custom time limits. This change comes as TikTok faces intense global scrutiny over its ownership by a Chinese tech company and its potential influence on young users.

images.alt_text: Australia has not received advice from its security agencies to follow the example of the United States, the European Parliament and Canada to ban Chinese video-sharing app TikTok from government devices, Treasurer Jim Chalmers said on Wednesday.
Videos under the hashtag #Ozempic have nearly 600 million views on TikTok, where many users regularly update followers about their weight loss.
The app has prompted security concerns from Western governments due to its Chinese ownership and fears the government in Beijing could force the company to share its user data.
China has pushed back on what it called “hysteria” over the balloon and said it doesn’t offer weapons to conflict zones.

site_title: Exxon starts new crude unit at Beaumont, Texas refinery
summary: ExxonMobil has started operations at its new crude distillation unit (CDU) C at its Beaumont, Texas refinery, increasing the facility's crude oil processing capacity by 68% to 619,000 barrels per day. The CDU C, commissioned in January, will initially produce diesel and other motor fuels before reaching full capacity of 250,000 barrels per day by the end of the first quarter of 2023. This expansion will make the Beaumont refinery one of the largest in the US, potentially surpassing it as the nation's largest refinery.

images.alt_text: Historically, Exxon has shunned speculative trading, preferring to focus on the production of oil, gas, motor fuels and chemicals.

site_title: Chinese phone makers emerge from Huawei’s shadow
summary: Chinese phone makers, including Xiaomi, Oppo, and Vivo, have emerged as major players in the global smartphone market, filling the gap left by Huawei's scaled-back smartphone business. Despite US restrictions and European Union efforts to limit Huawei's operations, Chinese firms continue to grow in sectors like network equipment and social media. Analysts say these firms have a huge catchment area of customers outside the US market, where they can expand their business without facing the same restrictions.

site_title: Royal Bank of Canada’s quarterly profit falls on higher provisions
summary: Royal Bank of Canada reported a decline in first-quarter profit to C$3.2 billion, or C$2.29 a share, due to higher provisions for potential loan defaults amid a challenging macro environment. The bank set aside C$532 million for bad loans, up from C$105 million a year ago. Earnings from personal and commercial banking units rose 8% and wealth management profit increased 3% from a year ago, driven by higher interest rates. This follows a similar trend among RBC's rivals, CIBC and Bank of Montreal.

site_title: LA County agrees to US$29 million settlement with Kobe Bryant's widow over crash photos
summary: Los Angeles County has agreed to pay nearly $29 million to the widow of Kobe Bryant, Vanessa Bryant, over emotional damages stemming from first responders sharing photos taken at the site of the 2020 helicopter crash that killed the NBA superstar and seven others. The photos, including those of the mangled remains of Bryant and his daughter Gianna, were shared by sheriff's deputies and firefighters who rushed to the scene. The settlement marks a conclusion to a lawsuit Vanessa Bryant filed, fearing the photos would surface on the internet.

images.alt_text: A jersey worn by late NBA star Kobe Bryant fetched US$5.8 million at a Sotheby's auction in New York,  Feb 1, 2023.

site_title: Thai brigade ready to make a splash at HSBC Women’s World Championship
summary: Thai golfers, led by world No. 4 Atthaya Thitikul, are poised to make a strong showing at the HSBC Women's World Championship in Singapore. Thitikul, along with fellow Thai golfers Natthakritta Vongtaveelap and Ariya Jutanugarn, impressed at the Honda LPGA Thailand tournament. The Thai golfers have received strong support from Thai sponsors and have been consistently performing well in domestic events. The tournament, which features 17 of the world's top 20 players, is expected to be a competitive event, with favorites including Lydia Ko and Ko Jin-young.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Pools team (from left): former Cabinet Ministe Yaacob Ibrahim, Singapore Pools CEO Lam Chee Weng, Singapore Pools board member Lee Kwok Cheong, and Mohd Norhelmy.

site_title: Toilet paper adding to 'forever chemicals' in wastewater: study
summary: A new study found that toilet paper is a significant source of "forever chemicals" (PFAS) in wastewater globally, contributing up to 89% in France. Researchers analyzed toilet paper rolls and sewage samples, discovering that toilet paper accounts for about 4% of PFAS in the US and Canada, 35% in Sweden, and potentially up to 89% in France. These chemicals are linked to various health issues and are found in cosmetics, cookware, and waterproof clothing. Reducing PFAS in wastewater is considered critical to minimize potential harm.

images.alt_text: WHO director-general Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus says: “Trans fat has no known benefit, and huge health risks that incur huge costs for health systems.”

site_title: US: Stocks slide, hit by latest spike in bond yields
summary: US stocks ended flat on Wednesday as bond yields hit a multi-month peak, following a manufacturing index showing price pressures persisting. The 10-year US Treasury yield rose to 4%, its highest since early November, amid concerns about inflation. The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed at 32,661.84, while the S&P 500 fell 0.5% and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.7%. Several stocks declined, including Lowe's and Novavax, while Eli Lilly rose after announcing a 70% reduction in insulin costs.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.33 points, or 0.00 per cent, at the open to 32,656.37.

site_title: Investors pull around US$6 billion out of Binance's stablecoin
summary: Investors have withdrawn approximately $6 billion from Binance's stablecoin, Binance USD, following a US regulatory crackdown. The value of Binance USD dropped to around $10.5 billion, down from $16.1 billion on February 13.
